But the board contended that this increase was different.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Yankees and the Minnesota Twins, both of whom sank to the bdttom of their divisions early this season, will meet in Shea Stadium Friday night at 8 o'clock and Saturday at 2 P.M.

title: Pope Expresses Anxiety Over Situation in Ireland
description: ROME, June 1Pope Paul VI today expressed his growing anxiety over the situation in Ireland, and appealed for an end to the violence.

title: The Nation
description: Two points are implicit in the Nixon Administration's special report on the state of the economy: Inflation is both serious nad persistent; the methods to combat it will be orthodox and painful.

title: Mountain People, Mountain Crafts
description: Years ago my husband bought me a dulcimer, and on one of our trips through the Appalachian mountains, we decided to stop and see Edd Presnell, the man who had made it. The real hope was that during the visit I could pick up some mud needed help in playing this relatively simple instrument.

title: Miss Deuchar Is Wed To G. B. Paulding 3d
description: In the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Irene Deuchar daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Deuchar of Leonia, IsLJ., became the bride of G. Bartlett Paulding 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paulding 2d of Westfield, N. J.

title: 4 Deaf Students Are First to Get Master's in Theater Education
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., June 1Four deaf students became the first in the country to be awarded graduate degrees in theater education when they received master's degrees today in commencement exercises at Connecticut College.

title: What Ails the Fabulous Invalid? It's Not What You Think!
description: AMERICAN theater is taking an unprecedented step today to confront its permanent financial crisis. Over the next four days, representatives of both profit and nonprofit theater, as well as concerned Unions, businesses and foundations, will gather at Princeton University  many of them meeting for the first time. They Will discuss their common economic Problems  skyrocketing inflation, near recession, stiff competition from the mass media, a deteriorating urban environment and so forth. The event is called the First American Congress of Theater (FACT).

title: Nixon Plans to Abolish Subversives List
description: WASHINGTON, June 1President Nixon is planning to abolish the Attorney General's formal list of subversive organizations, according to Administration officials.

title: Summer Living: Guard Against Spoiled Foods
description: Summer, a time for picnics, camping and easy living, is also, unfortunately, the prime season for foodborne illnesses.

description: CAIRO, June 1More than 150 members of the Palestine National Council, the parliament of the Palestine Liberation Organization, opened a fourday meeting here today to discuss policies to be followed in the coming months.

title: Clothing Workers Strike 750 Plants Across U.S.

title: A Modest Proposal To the Stars: Quit While You're Ahead

Mr. Moyers recently announced that he was concluding Bill Moyers' Journal precisely when the series had become a solid fixture on the shaky public television schedule. I hereby propose that all television, public and commercial, follow the Moylead.

description: Vice President Ford has many of the nation's editorial cartoonists gnawing on their drawing pens.

In fact, Dames at Sea, the musical spoof of the Dick PowellRuby Keeler movie musicals of the thirties, marks several firsts for members of the Celebration Playhouse.

title: New York Removed a Governor in 1913 for Laundering Campaign Funds and Withholding Evidence
description: The only Governor of New York ever impeached was removed from office for la undering campaign contributions and for keeping subpoenaed books, records and documents from the joint legislative committee investigating him.

description: The United Nations International School and the Waterside apartments are squabbling  diplomatically, of course  over the school's plan to erect a tennis bubble that the apartment owners contend will block their property's river view.

title: A Subpoena: Is Its Demand Universal?
description: WASHINGTONRichard Nixon, the most subpoenaed President in history. Richard Nixon, subpoena fighter. For 10 months he's been at it, battling subpoenas from prosecutors, defendants, Congressional committees, judges. Now he's been told that he may be impeached for it, and he's still at it, claiming executive privilege, insisting he's doing for the Presidency and the nation, not the man.

title: Arab Oil Officials Meet on Further Easing of Curbs
description: CAIRO, June 1  Arab oil ministers discussed today further elimination of production restrictions and sales embargoes imposed after the Middle East war, in October, but they postponed decisions until tomorrow, when the Syrian reresentative is expected to arrive.

title: Behind That $1 Loaf of Bread
description: WASHINGTONThere is a clamor in some quarters for the Government to once again stockpile food and fiber under the name of a strategic reserve. The supposition is that the reserve would be used to meet humanitarian needs around the world and any shortages here at home. These laudable motives, however, are not the only pressures to build up Governmentheld supplies of food and fiber.

title: YOUNG KOREANS PLAY VIOLIN, PIANO
description: The joint recital offered Friday evening by the Korean Community Activity Center at Carnegie Recital Hall turned out to be something of a mismatch. Soomi Lee, a 16yearold native of Seoul who is in the precollege division of the Juilliard School, is no doubt a promising pianist. But at this stage of her career she plays most of the notes without investing them with much personality, and major midtown exposure like this seemed premature.

title: Courageous Sets Pace In Regatta
description: GREENWICH, Conn. June 1The first half of the New York Yacht Club's 120th annual regatta on Long Island Sound today marked the occasion for the competitive debut of three of the 12Meter sloops which are candidates to become defender of the America's Cup in September.

title: Fumes Send 72 to Hospital

Two of those treated were hospitalized and listed in satisfactory condition today. The fire was in the machine shop of the GPE Control Division of the Vapor Corporation.

title: The World
description: The moderate coalition Government that had seemed to herald peace for Northern Ireland's Catholics and Protestants has now fallen. Britain will once again rule Ulster by force instead of reason, and eventually it will be the Protestant hardliners who determine how to answer the Catholic minority's demands for a greater role in running the rebellious province.

title: Herb, of Folklore
description: COMFREY, a magical herb of folklore, was once thought to cure the ailments of man or beast. The old herbalists, Gerard and Parkinson, described the benefits of comfrey. It is still sometimes used in cough medicine. Health food devotees now drink comfrey tea. Its generic name, Symphytum, derives from the Greek, meaning to make grow together or bind, as a wound.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: HIGHLIGHTS:OF THE WEEK

The compensation is expected to come in the form of tariff concessions reducing duties on American goods imported by Common Market countries.

title: A Witty, Incisive Portraitist

The Gila in southwestern New Mexicowhere ceremonies today will mark the establishment of the nation's first designated wilderness areahas always seemed to resist man's incursions, and still does.

Perkins Jr. of Raymond, N. H. The Rev. John Sabia performed the ceremony.

description: MOSCOW, June 1  Moscovites picked Tchaikovsky Hall Thursday night to hear the (Roger Wagner Chorale. They sat in the aisles and listened to music ranging from Ave Maria and a Bach cantata to Aaron Copland and Oklahoma?, and they would not go home when it ended.

description: PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) Fred T. Corletto, former Philadelphia city managing director, was fined $7,500 and sentenced to five years probation Thursday in United States District Court for tax evasion.

title: Specialists Can't Explain the Handful of Cases
description: Almost by definition, cancer Is a oneway process. It starts for reasons that are usually mysterious. Unless something drastic is done to halt it, such as surgery or radiation, a cancer grows, sometimes rapidly, sometimes slowly, until it kills.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Night watchmen and guard dogs are being replaced at many companies by the use of closed circuit television cameras for security purposes. The companies that make the cameras report a booming business.

title: Congressional Church
description: SALEM, ORE. June 1 (UPI)An Election Day advisory note from Gov. Tom McCall's office last Tuesday said the Governor would be voting at the First Congressional Church. The note was later corrected to read Congregational.

title: A Hundred Years of Of American Masters of Watercolor
description: THE principal function of the striking exhibition, Ten Americans: Masters of Watercolor, now on view at the Andrew Crispo Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, may be a charitable onethe show is a benefit for OnetoOne, a recently formed organization seeking to provide better care for the mentally retarded. Comprised of some 158 works, drawn largely from public and private collectionsand admirably selected by Patricia Hamilton of the gallery's staffit spans a century from the works of Winslow Homer to the recent paintings of Andrew Wyeth.

title: Condominium Craze Brings Complaints Over Lack of Protection for Consumers
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 A condominium craze, virtually without Government regulation, is bringing fundamental changes to American housing and creating a number of special problems.

title: Burlington Aiding Consumers
description: MOUNT HOLLYThe Burlington County Office of Consumer Affairs has embarked upon a bold experiment it is using Mr. and Mrs. Average Shopper to uncover false or deceptive advertising.

title: News of the Screen
description: The Oscar winners Glenda Jackson and Michael Caine, who obviously have helped promote British acting talent on the international scene but who have never faced the cameras together, are now prepared to do just that. Mr. Caine, stopping off here briefly on his way to Hollywood, enthusiastically disclosed that they will be together in The Romantic Englishwoman. It will be directed by Joseph Losey (The Servant, Accident, etc.) and independently produced by Daniel M. Angel from a novel by Tom Wiseman, who also wrote the screenplay.

title: Cultural policeman
description: In this new collection of essays, Mordecai Richler speaks in passing of the old  time Catskill comedians known as tummlers, and a note of affectionate admiration can be heard in his voice. With recent novels like Cocksure and St. Urbain's Horseman, Richter has himself been recognized as one of the most accomplished tummlers of contemporary fiction  but a noisemaker with a difference. Like Philip Roth and othets, Richter has been working in an extravagant comic mode that jams fierce, no  holdsbarred pornography into the same paragraphs with wild allusions to Auschwitz, Agnew, and June Allyson. Eichmann and Captain Marvell; matzoh balls and pubic hair; Dr. Johnson and Dr. Reuben; Dr. Leavis and Dr. Learyall decorum, all coherence gone.

title: Some Expert Pros and Cons
description: Manhattan's West Side boasts more block parties per square mile than any other part of town. Here, four members of the West SideColumbia University world offer their opinions on the phenomenon.

title: TV Set Stolen From Police
description: BALTIMORE, June 1 (UPI)The men at Baltimore's Western District police station are unhappy. Somebody stole their television set Thursday, It's sort of bad when thieves come right into the district station, Capt. Walter T. Jasper said. It takes a lot of nerve.

title: Calendar of Dog Show Events

title: South River Moves Slowly
description: SOUTH RIVERGrowth in population and the development of community facilities are major concerns of the 16,200 people who live in this quiet, fully inhabited Middlesex County borough. Some hope for improvement is now expected because a new bridge linking Main Street with Washington Road in adjacent Sayreville is nearing completion. Also, the munivipality has taken over operation of the public library, which was run for many years by a group of residents.

title: E. Illinois, Norfolk Share Track Title
description: CHARLESTON, Ill., June 1 (AP) Eastern Illinois and Norfolk State tied yesterday for the National Collegiate Division II track championship during action which established two meet and five stadium records at Eastern Illinois, Both teams finished with 51 points.

title: Numismatics
description: MANY millions of Americansnot jus the million or so coin collectors seem determined to engage in penny ante speculation by squirreling away as many cents as they can get their hands on. The daily press has lately been full of reports about penny shortages in supermarkets, 5 & 10's and other pennypricing stores. It would seem that the new Federal law against melting or exporting pennies has caused these people to act on a premise that might be stated in these words:

title: YOUNG DUVALIER RELAXES CURBS
description: PORT  AU  PRINCE, HaitiThree years after the death of President Francois Duvalier, the dictator's son and heir is firmly in power and assuming an ever larger role in the daytoday government of this impoverished Caribbean nation.

title: WILLIAM L. POLLOK
description: William Leeson Pollok, who had served for 12 years as senior architect of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, died Friday evening of cancer at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 47 East 64th Street and East Hampton, L. I.

title: Miss Killefer Has Nuptials
description: Miss Caroline Killefer, a graduate of the University of Colorado, was married yesterday noon to John Borland Thayer 5th, who will receive his bachelor's degree there in August.

title: Miss Giniger Is Bride Here
description: Miss Marianne Giniger, an editdr and translator for the French Embassy offices here, was married yesterday afternoon to John LaVette Moncrief Jr., a lawyer. State Supreme Court Justice Sidney Ash performed the ceremony at the Gotham.

title: Carey Bids Crangle Step A side If He's Supporting a Candidate
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, called on Joseph F. Crangle yesterday to step aside temporarily as state chairman if he makes a commitment to one of the candidates.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Sally Margaret Stark Wed to Ronald Harper
description: Miss Sally Margaret Stark, daughter of Mrs. Walter E. Stark of Riverhead, L.I., and the late Mr. Stark, and Ronald Robert Harper, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Harper of Turtle Creek, Pa., were married in Riverhead yesterday afternoon in St. John's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Kenneth T. Nee performed the ceremony.

title: Paulists Offer Family Sessions
description: PARAMUS  A new approach to religious education, one that is designed to permit entire families to participate in the learning process instead of depending on the traditional teacherpupil method, has been announced by the Paulist Press. The Press is the, publishing arm of the Paulist Fathers, a Roman Catholic order of prietts.

title: A Correction
description: In an article in this section May 19 on Democratic party nominees for county, legislative and Congressional contests, the name of the candidate for State Senator in the Second Senatorial District was misspelled through a typographical error. It should have reed Christin Veech.

title: Conservationist Stirs Furor in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 30A leading Brazilian conservationist who resigned as director of a nature foundation two weeks ago says the newspaper publicity that followed has probably done more for the cause of environmental protection than he did during his two years of service.

title: Television
description: TWO weeks ago a group of psychiatrists, psychologists, philosophers, theologians, broadcasters and professors of law gathered around conference table in Tarrytown, N. Y., to meditate on Behavior Control Through Media. I was invited for comic relief. Our purpose was to explore the ways in which TV modified social behavior and the ethical questions such modifying raises. After much lively discussion of general programing for adults and children, advertising, news, violence, the fairness doctrine, corporate greed, access, cable, images of women and minority groups, etc., we reached an adjournment of minds.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: In recent years many business organizations have been plagued with a series of abrupt earnings declines, extraordinary writeoffs an major reorganizations because of losses. In some cases shareholders were presented with a sudden announcement of a bankruptcy proceeding.

title: Gail Keenan Fiancee of Atlantan
description: Mrs. Albert J. Keenan Jr. of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Gail Lee Keenan, to Paul Taylor Zantzinger of Atlanta, assistant to the president of the GeorgiaKraft Company.

title: Wedding for Suzanne Sommer
description: Miss Suzanne Sommer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nolan B. Sommer of Saddle River, N. 3., was married yesterday afternoon to William Ray Brakebill, son of Mr. and Mrs. James William Brakebill of Memphis.

title: A Barren Land For All Seasons
description: DAVIS PARKSpring came a little late to Fire Island this year and the real estate saleswomen were still in car coats and boots in midMay as they showed hordes of hopeful clients through the depressing premises of dank summer cottages.

title: The Crass Rewards of Festival Competition
description: CANNES ALMOST anything you want to say about the justconcluded 27th Cannes International Film Festival is true, including the fact that the telephone service was sometimes so bad that people communicated between hotels via telegram. However, there is probably no other event on earth that could bring, together, under one metaphorical roof, such dissimilar American achievers as Jack Valenti, Linda Lovelace, Susan Sontag, Gerard Damiano and I F Stone. Cannes is an event with a purpose.

title: Japan's Small Cars Losing Ground
description: TOKYOUnder the cumulative impact of inflation the oil crisis and currency revaluations, Japan's automobile industry is suffering its worst slump since World War II, with production down 14.3 per cent in the first four months of this year.

title: Eastern College Baseball
A VolunteerMinded Grandmother
description: LAWRENCE  Dear Peggy, the letter begins, From time to time I learn that you are still the outstanding volunteer worker in Nassau County. I always admired your sense of organization and ability to get so many things done...

title: Daughter to Mrs. Brooks
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and. Mrs. Richard Brooks of New York and Woodstock, N. Y., on May 20 at Beth Israel Medical Center. The child has been named Gillian Courtney. Mrs. Brooks is the former Miss Judith Ann Schiffer. Mr. Brooks is president of Dick Brooks Organization, a publicrelations company.

title: Mrs. Geary Has Son
description: A son was born May 21 to Mr. and Mrs. John W. Geary 2d of New York and, Southampton, L. I., in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Geary is the former Hilary Somers Roche, daughter of J. Jeffrey Roche of New York and Mrs. Sidney D. Wood. Jr. of New York and Southampton. Mr. 3eary is a partner in Zie??arth, Geary & Co., stockprokers. The child has been named Alfred Harrison 2d for his late paternal grandfather.

title: apers Raise Price
description: June 1The price of s in Italy today went 25 cents a copy. The is effective for all e National Federation lian Press said the was caused by the ??t of newsprint and cost of labor.

title: Women Buy Idea First, Then a Club
description: After more than a year of operating the Hillaire Riding Club in White Plains, N. Y., Mrs. Helen Bilby and Mrs. Betty Doolittle have watched one problem recur dozens of times  and Horse there's no way to eliminate it. No one is sure how the name of the club is spelled, said Mrs. Bilby. We are located on Hillair Circle. The club name has an E at the end and the location does not have an E in it. How's that for confusion?

title: Wallace Stays Neutral in Alabama Lieutenant Governor Campaign
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 1 The state's Democratic voters will choose a candidate for Lieutenant Governor Tuesday in a runoff election in which Gov. George C. Wallace has steadfastly maintained his neutrality.

title: New Role for Old Mansion
description: TRENTON  Most Trentonians think of Ellarslie, the handsome Victorian mansion in Cadwalader Park, as the monkey house. Indeed, until recently it did house a collection of primates.

title: The North Cape: Land of the Midnight Tan
description: As though possessed, hundreds of travelers flog their cars up the rugged Norwegian coasi each summer to remote North Cape in an annual migration whose motives are as obscure as those which drive the lemmings to the sea. At four degrees of latitude above the Arctic Circle, the visitor has for his efforts only the meager pleasures of photographing the sun at midnight, sipping coffee at the snack bar and buying a reindeer skin at the souvenir stand. The Midnight Sun, after all, is quite visible in June and July several hundred miles to the south, where the coffee and reindeer skins are much cheaper.

title: Singapore to Tighten Control on Press
description: SINGAPORE, June 1  The Singapore Government is preparing to enact legislation that mill tighten its controls on this country's already subdued newspapers.

title: Arkansas Chancellor Named
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., June 1 (UPI)Dr Herman B. Smith Jr., director of the Office for the Advancement of Public Negro colleges in Atlanta, was named yesterday as chancellor of the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff.

title: What Portugal Does About Her Colonies Will Affect All of Africa
description: LONDONNo foreign country has watched the recent events in Portugal with the anxiety of the Rhodesians. Spain may be worried; South Africa may be worried; but neither stands to lose its major road and rail lines to the sea if, as now seems likely, General Antonio de Spinola's new Portuguese Government pulls out of Africa and hands over the reins to the black nationalists in Mozambique. The quarter of a million whites in Rhodesia stand to forfeit not only their most important lines of communication but also the use of their formerly friendly neighbor as a bogus countryoforigin for their exports, which would otherwise encounter sanctions.

title: Michael Giersch Weds Dorothy L. McConnell
description: Miss Dorothy Lee McConnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. McConnell of Mamaroneck, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Michael George Giersch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Giersch of Baltimore.

title: 6 Break 4:00 Mile; 3:55.1 for Wohlhater
description: WICHITA, Kan., June 1 (UPI)  The world recordholder in the halfmile, Rick Wohlhuter of the Chicago Track Club, broke the meet mile record tonight at the United States Track and Field Federation meet at Cessna Stadium.

title: BILL SIGNED TO SET UP INSTITUTE ON AGING
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)  President Nixon signed legislation today establishing a National Institute on Aging to consider the special problems of older persons.

title: Court Will Decide Plagiarism Charge On Psychology Book
description: A Federal appeals court last week alowed the continued sale until at least this Tuesday of Child Psychology, a text book that is the target of plagiarism charges by the authors and publisher of a competing text, Child Development and Personality.

title: Kathryn Phillips Wed
description: Miss Kathryn Elizabeth Phillips, a professional nurse, was married yesterday noon to Petty Officer 2d Class Anthony George Shook, who is assigned to the nuclear submarine Lafayette based in Groton, Conn. The Rev. Robert B. Goodwin performed the ceremony in the United Methodist Church in Madison, N. J. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Howard Emerson Phillips of Madison and the late Mr. Phillips. Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Shook of Swansboro, N. C., are the parents of the bridegroom.

title: Now Comes The Hardest Part in the Middle East
description: JERUSALEMA few hours after the IsraeliSyrian troop separation agreement was initialed here last Wednesday, an exhausted American official on the Kissinger negotiating team sat, fatigued, in a chair the lobby of the King David Hotel. If it took month to get this, he said, just imagine how long the next phase will take.

title: Pay Parity Principal Issue in Election Here
description: How about homosexual pulice officers? How about policewomen riding around in cars? And how about the doubling of auxiliary policemen for one purpose and one purpose onlyto cut out your overtime and to stop money from going into your pockets.... And here, the husky voice of the tall, broadshouldered police officer broke with indignation as he faced 35 fellow police officers in the back room of the Midtown South police station.

title: Efforts to Cut the Number Have Failed
description: Despite renewed attempts in Congress to cut United States troop strengths overseas, Americans undiminished force will continue on duty on the Elbe, the Yalu, the Mekong and elsewhere around the globe.

title: Jane Gardner Wed To Wynne Carvill
description: Miss Jane Kathryn Gardner, a magna cum laude graduate of Williams College, class of '71, was married in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., yesterday to Wynne Shepard Carvill, who graducated summa cum laude from Williams the same year.

title: Secession Movement On in Ocean County
description: BERKELEY TOWNSHIPDespite a State Supreme Court decision that would appear to stymie their plans, Ocean County peninsula communities are moving ahead with attempts to secede from mainland municipalities.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Merv Rettenmund of the Cincinnati Reds, who played six seasons with the Baltimore Orioles, compares the two leagues: The overall talent is better in the National League. The biggest difference I've noticed is that the pitchers here turn the ball over more. The breaking pitches are tougher.

title: Peter Miller to Wed Miss Scudder
description: Miss Carolyn Quinby Scudder, a schoolteacher in King of Prussia, Pa., and Peter Mason Miller, who is with the Pennwalt Corporation, Philadelphia chemical manufacturers, plan to marry Aug. 24 at the home of the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Scudder of Navesink, N.J., who have announced the engagement of the couple.

title: The Women's Tennis Tour: What Billie Jean and the Others Are Really Like
description: Winning, for Billie Jean, was a more potent drug than any chemist could devise, a more inspirational gospel than any scripture could preach. Sometimes, Julie Anthony told me, it takes so much togetherness when you're on the court that afterwards all the glue seems to come apart in some people. I have heard Billie Jean at times just absolutely babble incoherently.

title: Legal Test Due On Rent Control
description: FORT LEEThe legality of rentcontrol ordinances here and in West New York will be tested, this week in trials that could affect similar laws enacted in 90 municipalities throughout New Jersey.

title: Monmouth to Get WasteShredding Plant
description: FREEHOLDIt can shred everything from milk cartons to automobile bodies, Knud Scholer said the other day in announcing a new system to dispose of residential and industrial waste in Monmouth County.

title: Businessman Ready To Fight City Hall, But Son Is Mayor
description: OMAHA, June 1Hymie Zorinsky is a longtime downtown businessman whose property is being taken by the city for progress. He doesn't like what the city has offered for the property and is of a mind to fight City Hall.

title: ZAMBIAN RAILWAY TO BE READY SOON
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, June 1The great Uhuru Railway that will connect this copperrich and landlocked nation to Tanzania's Indian Ocean port of Dar es Salaam will be finished in the fall, more than a year ahead of schedule.

title: Miss Judith Sim, J.M.Sartonus Jr. Planning Bridal
description: The engagement of Miss Judith Terry Sim to John Manfred Sartorius Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Craig Sim of Garden City, L. I., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. Sartorius of Tenafly, N. J., and Quogue, L. I., and the late Mrs. Sartorius. The wedding is planned for August.

title: GUY EARL CONRATH
description: Guy Earl Conrath, who retired as a New York insurance executive in 1971, died Friday at his home, 2 Mansfield Place in Darien, Conn. He was 68 years old.

title: Progress and Pitfalls
description: The ink from the diplomats' pens is dry, the guns on the Golan Heights are silent. After years of despairing that it would ever happen, Israel and two of her Arab neighbors have come to terms in formal, binding contracts. No matter how limited in scope, how tenuous the obligations between longtime belligerents, the political and legal mutation that has just occurred in the evolution of the Middle East is breathtaking.

title: Heard Gains 3Stroke Lead on 65200
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 1 Who is this Jerry Heard? He is a cocky 26yearold golf pro from California who catches a hot scoring streak every so often, an ebullient personality who says he will quit playing if golf stops being fun.

title: She Is Young, Vivacious, Attractiveand Also a Rabbi
description: There is one member of the congregation who insists on calling me bubbi, said Michal Seserman, the first and only woman rabbi on Long Island, and it just drives me up a wall.

title: Film Mailbag
description: On March 31, The Times published a letter in the movie mailbag front Terry Boyle in which Mr. Boyle said, As a parent of a retarded child, found myself appalled at the return of the village idiot as a source of humor in Mel Brooks' Blazing Saddles. Mr. Boyle went on to say that from the point of view of every organization and every parent who has worked for the acceptance of Mongoloid children and all retarded children in the community, Mel Brooks has committed a grievous offense against humanity.

title: Proposed Hospital Facing Opposition
description: A plan for a new 475bed hospital and health care center in the East New York section of Brooklyn apparently is being opposed by some staff members of the Health and Hospitals Planning Council of Southern New York.

title: FORD ENCOUNTERS DISPUTE IN PARTY
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., May 31Vice President Ford, normally greeted warmly as he travels the country rallying the Republican faithful, found himself enmeshed in intraparty acrimony here tonight.

title: All Drivers Acquitted As Harness Trial Ends
description: Del Insko, William (Buddy) Gilmour and five other harness drivers accused of fixing superfecta races at New York tracks were acquitted yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

title: Sharp Gary, $28.40, Wins At Chicago by 3 Lengths
description: CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) Sharp Gary, overlooked at 131, scored a threelength victory today in the 17th running of the $105,100 Illinois Derby at Sportsman's Park.

title: Miss O'Connor Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert K. O'Connor of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Carolyn O'Connor, to Steven Mark Gluckstern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gluckstern of Amherst, Mass. The wedding is planned for July 20 at the Thomas School in Rowayton, of which the future bride is alumna.

title: Ulster's Choice
description: The Protestants of Northern Ireland are now being confronted by both the British Government and their own extremists with the consequences of their abandonment of powersharing with the Catholic minority.

title: SCHEUER SEEKING BRASCO'S OUSTER
description: In what could become one of the more rancorous political battles in the metropolitan area this summer, former Representative James H. Scheuer is set to announce tomorrow that he he will challenge Representative Frank J. Brasco for the Democratic nomination in the 11th Congressional District.

title: Swidler Lays Many Difficulties Of Consolidated Edison to City
description: Much of the blame for the Consolidated Edison Company's problems can be laid to a series of indifferent or even hostile city administrations, Joseph C. Swidler said last week.

title: A Selected Vacation Reading List
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of Dec. 2, 1973. Such a list can only suggest the high points the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from earlier issues of the Book Review.

title: STRIKE SETTLED AT MENEM'S
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., June 1A monthlong strike that had kept the pies, cakes and other pastries of Entenmann's Bakery off grocery shelves in five states ended today with 750 bakery workers accepting raises of about 30 per cent over three years.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Hotline To Assist Alcoholics A Busy One
description: CHERRY HILLMrs. Elinor Doyle is softspoken, friendly and wellversed in her specialty, and she loves the sound of a telephone ringing, day or night.

title: BRITAIN REFUSES I.R.A. SISTERS' BID
description: LONDON, June 1The British Government today resisted pressure for the transfer of two sisters on hunger strike from a London jail to one in Northern Ireland.

title: Klotzer Sets Jersey Mark With Discus
description: HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., June 1Ron Klotzer of Union set at state record of 196 feet 2 inches in the discus throw today at the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association group track and field championships.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 2, 1974

title: New Ties for Laotians
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 1 (UPI)The new Laotian coalition government announced yesterday that it had agreed to establish diplomatic relations with North and South Korea and with East Germany.

title: Frances Rea Is Bride
description: Miss Frances Brooke Rea and Brian Richard Olphie were married yesterday afternoon at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., by the Rev. Carlton Lee. Mr. and Mrs. William Rea Jr. and Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Olphie all of Lloyd Harbor, L. I., are the parents of the couple. The bride is a granddaughter of John L. Collyer of Vero Beach, Fla., former board. chairman and president of the B.F. Goodrich Company.

title: The World
description: Valry Giscard d'Estaing, inaugurated as the third popularly elected president of France and the youngest in this century, last week, has a key word to describe his emerging regime. It is simplicity, equated by many with modernity.

title: BERNARD GREENBERG
description: Bernard Greenberg, president of the Rockaway, (N.J.) Sales Company, Inc., discount department stores, died Friday in Dover, (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 16 High Street, Randolph Township, N. J.

title: We may also be damned if we don't
description: One of the dangers of swings in intellectual fashions is that ideas become accepted before their implications have begun to be explored, as yesterday's unconventional wisdom becomes transmuted into today's unquestioned orthodoxy. The success of the advocates of nongrowth in bringing about mass conversion to their view is a case in point.

title: Law Student Weds Linda Czarnecki
description: Miss Linda Czarnecki, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Czarnecki, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard M. Macksoud, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Macksoud. Both families are of Madison, N. J. Msgr. Elias Skaff performed the Melchite Catholic ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Holy Family Chapel of St. Elizabeth's College in Convent.

title: Problem That Isn't There
description: PARISTwo of the most powerful States of Western Europe, France and West Germany, spent this weekend an attempt to adjust the ninenation European Community to the changed situation following the death of French President Pompidou, the resignation of West German Chancellor Brandt and the electoral defeat of British Prime Minister Heath.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Will the Real Alex Comfort Please Stand Up? All One
description: It is simply not true that there are eight or nine different Englishmen named Alex Comfort, one of whom wrote that redoubtable bestseller, The Joy of Sex.

title: Democracy in Thailand Is a Nervous Business
description: BANGKOKThailand's selfconscious experiment in democracy, which is going on eight months, has survived its first leadership crisis and is moving toward general elections at the end of the year.

title: U.S, Senators Join Call for New Study Of Tocks Project
description: Seven United States Senators from New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Pennsylvania called yesterday for a $1million, yearlong study of the controversial and longdelayed Tocks Island Dam and Reservoir project, which has encountered mounting opposition in recent months.

title: Suburbia's Exclusive Beaches
description: We shall fight [them] on the beaches...!

title: Tradition Keeper At Coney Island
description: On West 22d Street, near Surf Avenue, with the ocean breakers providing sound effects, and towering apartment houses dwarfing the usual onestory Coney Island structure, William Meinch carries on an 04 tradition.

title: The Marschallin Who Almost Became a Tooth Doctor
description: THE METROPOLITAN Opera audience will hear a new Marschallin in Friday night's performance of Der Rosenkavalier. A role to test any soprano's sensitivity as an actress and skill as a singer, it will be taken by Teresa ZylisGara. She has been successful in the roles she has sung here already, such as Elvira in Don Giovanni and Desdemona in Otello. And next season she will sing Tosca here, her first in this country.

title: Legislature To Take Up Parkland Bond Issue
description: TRENTONIn response to environmentalist pressures and in fulfillment of campaign promises by Governor Byrne, the state Democratic administration has drafted a $150million Green Acres bond issue for legislative approval.

title: Wisconsin Oarsmen Retain Title
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., June. 1  A large and powerful Wisconsin crew won the national intercollegiate rowing championship today in impressive style. The Badgers rowed away from five rivals in the varsity final and won by three boat lengths in the time of 6 minutes 33 seconds for the 2,000 meters.

title: Hospital in Paramus Seeking Volunteers
description: PARAMUSJunior volunteers interested in assisting the Nursing Department at Bergen Pines Hospital can register for the June training class by calling Mrs. John King Coordinator of Volun??ers, at (201) 2619000, Ext. 217, before June 15.

title: Grumman Denies Company Asks Additional Funds for F14 Jets
description: BETHPAGE, LI., June 1Officials of the Senate Armed Services Committee have charged that the Navy concealed an apparent refusal by the Grumman Aerospace Corporation to go ahead with a $325million contract for 15 F14 jet fighters unless Grumman was guaranteed advance payments of up to $125million.

title: Builders Push Plan For Buyer Warranties
description: The nation's builders, wary of governmental intervention and embarrassed by reports of defective homes and lost down payments, are beginning to develop consumer protection programs of their own.

title: 104 Teachers Set Record in Walkout In New Hampshire
description: PLAISTOW, N. H., June 1What began as a strike of 104 teachers in a high school serving four tiny New Hampshire communities this week became the nation's longest teacher strike.

title: CITY UNIT SCORED ON SCOFFLAW LAG
description: The city's Parking Violations Bureau is falling behind in collecting fines at a rate of $4million a month, Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Book Ends
description: Transcripts. Now that the dust has settled in the Great Race between Bantam and Dell over who would be first with the most paperback editions of the President's transcripts, what can be concluded? First, on the question of who was on the stands first, we'll call it Bantam by a spine. They claim that the first copies In America went on sale at the Traver Gift Shop in Washington, D.C., just down the street from the White House, at 9:30 A.M. May 7. Dell, of course, claims that they were first on the basis of having copies on sate in New York just after noon May 7, at a Fifth Avenue bookstore; Bantam had them on the trucks by noon in New York, in the stores somewhat later. Dell has since trimmed Its claims somewhat and a spokesperson there allowed that the two versions were virtually simultaneous. The question of who was on that is strictly for the record books, however (although at least one bookseller attributed Bantam's larger sales to its primacy), suffice it to say that they were both out fast, their people working around the clock, Bantam, the veteran at instant books performing smoothly. Dell, the newcomer giving a creditable fight. Certain it is that the race was the news event of the year in publishing, widely covered by the press and TV.

title: Notes: Airlines and The Kosher Problem
description: AIRUNES, given sufficient notice, will serve specially prepared food to passengers aloft including Hindu meals, Moslem meals, Oriental mealsand kosher meals. Indeed, Jack Yohe, director of consumer affairs for the Civil Aeronautics Board, reports that the most frequent letters of complaint about the food service of airlines comes from people who have requested kosher meals and not received them. Says Yohe:

title: Apartment Dwellers Hoping for Windfall
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne's proposal to impose a state income tax to help finance equal educational opportunities in New Jersey has produced more questions than answers.

title: Veterans Still Fight Vietnam Drug Habits
description: While the Vietnam war apparently did not spawn a generation of hardcore, committed heroin addicts, as was widely feared, it has left thousands of veterans embroiled with the whole range of illicit drugs that saturated American forces in Vietnam.

title: Navy Is Sued by Officer Here Over Investigation of Streaker
description: If an officer and gentleman of the United States Naval Reserve dashes naked through a convention of his fellow officers and their wives in the ballroom of a big midtown Manhattan hotel, is it any of the Navy's business?

title: RENAISSANCE BAND PLAYS SKILLFULLY
description: The piquant charms of Renaissance instrumental music written between 1300 and 1600 appear to have caught the fancy of young people these days, judging from the large, mostly collegeage audience that attended the New York Renaissance Band's Carnegie Recital Hall concert last Sunday afternoon. The unusual style and sound of this music has also been creeping into certain areas of rock recently, but the Renaissance Band plays the real, unvarnished original.

title: Siberian Oil and NATO
description: A group of international energy experts, meeting at the headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have decided that the development of Siberian oil and gas resources is in the West's interest and that capital and technology might be provided to the Russians for that purpose.

title: With Measured Step
description: The nation is moving slowly but surely toward a judgment on the conduct of President Nixon and his closest ?? in the Watergate scandal. In the course of tads measured approach to a grave decision, the people through Congress and the courts are also defining some limits to the immense and seemingly shapeless powers of the modern Presidency.

title: Nassau Festival Will Open Today
description: ROSLYN HARBOR  The Great Neck Symphony Orchestra will mark the opening of the second annual Fine Arts Festival at 2 P.M. today.

title: Houston Area Is Sinking, and Many Families Are Preparing to Pull Up Their Stakes
description: HOUSTON, June 1  In April, 1836, when Texas was still part of Mexico, Sam Houston and a band of secessionminded freebooters beat a hasty retreat across east Texas toward Louisiana before the army of Mexican President Santa Anna.

title: The Region
description: Congressional and legislative districts in Manhattan and Brooklyn have now been redrawn to comply with a Federal directive intended to increase political representation of minority groups. But critics say that despite the good intentions, the new districts, appioved during a special legislative session last week, will not adequately do the job.

title: Duke Names Aide
description: DURHAM, N.C., June 1 (UPI)Bob Wenzel, assistant basketball coach at Yale and a former player at Rutgers, was named as an assistant coach at Duke today.

title: Beating Drum, $16, Takes Au Revoir
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., June 1 Beating Drum, ridden by Carl Gambardella, pulled ahead of Chas Beau at the 70yard post today at Narrangansett Park and scored a halflength victory in the 5 $7,500 Au Revoir Handicap.

title: Nikons Fly to Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)  President Nixon, accompanied by his wife and a friend, Charles G. Rebozo, flew by helicopter today to Camp David. A spokesman said they would remain at the mountaintop retreat in nearby Maryland until tomorrow evening.

title: Looking at Architecture
description: Books about architecture for young readers almost inevitably concentrate on the great monuments of the past. The Parthenon, the pyramids, Chartres, Versaillesand then on to an exhortation to the reader to look more carefully at the architecture which surrounds him in his daily life and which, now armed with the knowledge of history, he is presumably better able to appreciate.

title: RED CROSS REJECTS BLOOD OF PRISONERS
description: NORMAN, Okla., June 1. (AP)The local Red Cross chapter has refused to accept blood from four county prisoners.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Joe Namath might not play football anymore. If he retires as a quarterback, he probably would accept a multimilliondollar offer from the American Broadcasting Company to replace Don Meredith in its Monday Night Football booth. He also would focus on being an actor in films and TV shows. I just don't honestly know yet what I'm going to do, he said. Joe Namath isn't trying to be evasive. He's trying to make a decision. But the inflections in his voice over the telephone from his Bachelors III restaurant in Tuscaloosa, Ala., betrayed his inclinations. When he spoke of returning to the New York Jets for his 10th season, his voice was flat, almost uncaring. When he spoke of the takeover of Charlie Winner as the Jets' coach, he sounded disenchanted. When he spoke of the New York Stars, who hold the World Football League negotiations rights to him, he sounded disinterested. When he spoke of the ABC offer, he sounded agreeable to discussing a business deal. But when he spoke of being an actor, he sounded enthused.

title: Syria and Israel Begin Geneva Talks
description: GENEVA, June 1  Syrian and Israeli military planners today began drafting arrangements for carrying out the separation of forces called for in the accord concluded by their two Governments on Wednesday.

title: Son to Mrs. Snyder
description: A son was born May 17 to Dr. and Mrs. Frederic E. Snyder of New York at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Snyder, as Leslie Crocker Snyder, is an assistant district attorney for New York County. Her husband is a pediatrician.

title: Joan Gallagher Is Bride of John Warden
description: Miss Joan Killian Gallagher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thothas F. Gallagher of Armonk, N.Y., was married in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday afternoon to John Sheppard Warden, son of Dr. and Mrs. David E. Warden of Laurel Hollow, L.I.

title: The Forgotten Veterans
description: In his Memorial Day speech at the Arlington National Cemetery, Vice President Ford asked that the Amerjean people remember not only the men who lost their lives in past wars, but the men who survived, often crippled in body or spirit.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fourday auction that ended yesterday at the Louise C. Morgan estate, Salutation, on West Island, near Glen Cove, L. I., brought a total of $1,211,535. This was described as a record for a house sale by a spokesman for Sotheby Parke Bernet, which conducted the auction of the estate's rugs, furniture, art objects and personal belongings. The highest price paid for a single item was $44,000 by Ira Spanierman, a New York dealer, for a seascape by Samuel Scott, an eighteenthcentury English painter. The lowest price was $10 for a group of straw place mats used for outdoor dining:

title: Pinks Are Perfect For the Summer
description: PINKS, finely formed, gaily colored and often fragrant have enchanted gardeners down through the ages. Their botanical name Dianthus, comes from two Greek words Dios anthos, meaning divine flower. The common name pinks comes, not from the name of a color as one might think, but from the German word pfingsten which was the general term in Germany for all flowers blooming at Pentecost. Pfingsten became pinkster and finally pinks.

title: AROUND THE
description: What better time to think about peonies than now when the magnificent plants are in top form. These stately perennials were the center of attention recently at the Greenwich Garden Center, Cos Cob, Conn., when Miss Sylvia Saunders visited to talk about her favorite flower. The center's fine collection was just coming into peak bloom for the occasion. Her tate father, Prof. A. P. Saunders, was wellknown for his peony hybrids, which developed from a backyard hobby to a nursery business. He was also a chemistry professor at Hamilton College. Twentyfour years ago, Miss Saunders gave up her New York career as a magazine photographer and returned to Clinton, N. Y., to help out with her parents' small business for a year. She never left.

title: COLLEGE HOLDING TWO GRADUATIONS
description: The Albert Einstein College of Medicine will hold the second of two commencements within two weeks on Tuesday to help meet what the medical school stressed is to help meet the nation's serious shortage of doctors.

title: News of the Camera World: Courses, Products and Services
description: Summer courses in photography, film making and videotape will be conducted by the School of Continuing Education of New York University, 2 University Place, New York, N.Y. 10003, starting in June and July. Among these will be:

title: Miss Burkart Bride on L.I.
description: Miss Virginia Marie Burkart and William Lide Bryant were married yesterday afternoon at St. Elizabeth Roman Catholic Church in South Huntington, L I., by the Rev. Thomas E. Donohoe.

title: At Least 55 Killed in England By Explosion at Chemical Plant
description: LONDON, June 1At least 55 persons were killed today by an explosion that wrecked a chemical plant in a small village near Scunthorpe, 180 miles north of London, a police spokesman said.

title: Colleges Beginning Summer Sessions
description: As graduates fold their caps and gowns and undergraduates begin to catch up on the sleep lost during final examinations, dozens of colleges in the BrooklynQueensLong Island area are gearing for what amounts to a new semester  the summer session.

title: PHILIP H. SELLEW
description: Philip Hamilton Sellew, a retired business consultant, private investor and former vice president of the Gorton Pew Fisheries Company, died yesterday at the Yale Club, where he lived and of which he was president from 1944 to 1946. His age was 80.

title: Film Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Julie Sage Is Engaged To Jerome Corbin Day
description: Mrs. Anne Tilney Holmes of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julie Sage, to Jerome Corbin Day of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Day, also of Llewellyn Park.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 1 (UPI)Meeken Stable's Agitate, third in the Kentucky Derby and a winner of five of seven career starts, will carry top weight of 124 pounds tomorrow in the $63,800 Argonaut Handicap at Hollywood Park.

title: Distaff Side Shelving Its Problems
description: Women have made so many advances in athletics during the last year that just about every men's sport has been invaded at varying degrees of proficiency. And despite men's warnings and prophecies of a doomed society, problems are working themselves outpainfully and slowly.

title: Photography
description: RETURNING to New York after several months on the West Coast is akin to stepping through one of those cosmic warps of which science fiction writers used to be so fond. Perspectives change; things are simultaneously as they were, yet altered. It took me days. to reconcile the memory of my apartment's spatial contours with my new experience of it. Like two images of the same scene made with different lenses, they correlated but did not coincide. And I have not yet made the, full transition from California's mellow passivity to the abrasive of Funk City.

title: Nancy Stetson Is Wed To Kenneth Remsen
description: Miss Nancy Stetson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Damon Stetson of Verona, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Kenneth Remsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Remsen of Bryant Pond, Me. Town Clerk Charles Clark Coffin of Nantucket, Mass., performed the ceremony in the Siasconset (Mass.) Union Chapel.

title: Miss Evert Gains Final; Smith Wins
description: ROME, June 1 (AP)Chris Evert, playing seesaw tennis, advanced to the women's final and Stan Smith powered his way to the men's semifinals in the $134,000 Italian open championships today.

title: WE CALLED PERIL TO ANGOLAN VOTE
description: LUANDA, Angola, June 1 The commander of the Portuguese forces in Angola says that it will be a little difficult to create the conditions for a referendum on the future of the territory.

title: Helen Weist Bride Of Dr. Stephen Karl
description: In St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Helen Louise Weist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Weist of Vero Beach, Fla., was married to Dr. Stephen Rogers Karl, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard C. Karl of Hanover, N. H. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Andrew, who was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Frederick M. Morris.

title: Quarrte Defeats Crockett And Williams in Sprint
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 1 (UPI)  Donald Quarrie, the little Olympian from Jamaica, upset Ivory Crockett, the world recordholder, and Steve Williams in the featured 100yard dash today before a crowd of about 1,000 in the Kennedy Games.

title: Dr. William Scott Weds Joan McMonagle
description: The marriage of Miss Joan Marie McMonagle, a television, actress, to Dr. William Norman Scott, a surgical resident at Roosevelt Hospital, took place yesterday in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Richard Dillon performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. He was assisted bythe Rev. John Van Wie.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may, be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Jennifer Mervine Bride
description: Miss Jennifer Lee Mervine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Mervine of Harrison, N.Y., was married yes terday afternoon to Jules A. del Vecchio, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jules del Vecchio of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Arthur Leone performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in. Reid Hall it Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Bound to Die
description: Some time ago my friend Johnny Weiss and I, idle pessimists both, spent an evening trying to think of things which are better and cheaper now than they were 15 or 20 years ago: This is an instructive exercise. The only things which seemed to qualify were color televisions, ballpoint pens and air fares to Europe, and at least two of these are in danger. Everything else, we scientifically concluded, is either going down in quality or up in price, and generally in both directions at once, with wine, lobsters and books at the very head of the list.

title: Martial Artists Hold Exhibition Today
description: Although Aaron Banks is one of the few black belts in karate who can break boards in the air, thus eschewing the use of leverage, he has most often been referred to as a martial artist, with an emphasis on the artist.

title: Joyful Outbursts Mark Homecomings Of. Injured Israeli and Syrian P.O.W.'s
description: TEL AVIV, June 1Israel and Syria today exchanged wounded prisoners of war in the second step of an Americansponsored military disengagement agreement, following yesterday's ceasefire.

title: Roger Sanborn, Dairy Farmer, Marries Evelyn Adele Victor
description: Miss Evelyn Adele Victor; daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Royall Victor of Glen Head, L. I., and Coutoocook, N. H., was married yesterday afternoon to Roger Wheeler Sanborn, son of Mr. and Mrs.

title: Xaverian is Upset Victor In C.H.S.A.A. Title T rack
description: The events started early in the morning, it rained and many athletes failed to show up for both or either of these reasons.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: 11 Killed in Quebec
description: BALE ST. PAUL, Quebec, June 1 (UPI)A bus full of old people on their way to a picnic apparently lost its brakes on a steep incline near here today and careened off the road, killing 11 and injuring 33, the police said.

title: Saigon. Tries to Recapture BombedOut Nearby Village
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1 (Reuters)At least .60 South Vietnamese troops were reported killed, wounded or missing as 1,000 infantrymen battled against heavy artillery tonight to recapture a village:: on Saigon's northern defense, perimeter.

title: Letter Says S.L.A. Downed Los Angeles Police Copter
description: LOS ANGELES, June 1 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is studying the contents of a letter bearing the sevenheaded cobra insignia of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army in which the terrorist group said that it used an antiaircraft missile to shoot down a police helicopter last Wednesday.

title: Nadjari Asks Reopening of 2 Counts Against Rinaldi
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's special anticorruption prosecutor, will ask the State Court of Appeals tomorrow to reinstate two perjury counts to an indictment that charges State Supreme Court Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi with lying to a grand jury and obstructing government administration.

title: Mary Carr Bride of Jeffrey S. Soles
description: Miss Mary Ellen Carr, daughter of Mrs. Leo J. Carr of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Carr, was married yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey Scott Soles, son of Harold W. Soles of Naples, Fla., and Mrs. Katherine Scott Soles of New Canaan, Conn., and Athens.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: May a noneconomist, nonscientist; nonhistorian (only human being) reply to Peter Passeill's review of Time on the Cross: The Economics of American Slavery (April 28)? I can not comment on Fogel and Engerman's work except as Mr. Passell represents it (if his presentation is accurate one can only conclude that the title is supposed to be ironic), but his whole tone seems to me unforgivable. It just won't wash, he writes, to feign moral outrage about quantitive [sic] whippings or about the number of slave women in brothels, because it seems that these things hardly ever happened and that most slaves (as valuable property) were at least as well off as their free whiteI almost wrote counterpart under Passell's spellfellow laborers. Even that awful old bugaboo, the slave auction, can mostly be explained away, he assures us.

title: Washington Watches KissingerJackson Rivalry Over Detente
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The difference between Henry and me in making moves with the Russians, said Henry M. Jackson about Henry A. Kissinger, is I would push more.

title: She's Scrubbed, She's Sweet And She Dares a Little
description: PAT COLLINS, the hostessproducer of The Pat Collins Show, gesticulates with her right hand while her left hand holds a glass containing equal portions of champagne and orange juice. Mason Reese was on last week to talk about children's liberation, she says, oblivious to the fact that her drink is slowly trickling onto her floral print blouse. Ginger Rogers discussed the role of women in films with Molly Haskell. We had Diahann Carroll talking about living arrangements before marriage. We try to impart information in a lighthearted manner to people whose lives don't revolve around the continuing saga of Watergate. By midmorning, the spirit needs a little uplifting. Viewers want to be informed and they want to be entertained in informative way.

title: There Are Some Signs Of a Comeback, Maybe, For Life Drawing
description: DEPENDS what you mean, strictly, and depends what you academic, as to whether or Strictly Academic is the title for the exhibition of 19thcentury life drawings at the Finch College seum of Art. But let's not get about a title, when most people are a little vague about what drawing itself means.

title: Charlene C. Schuster Is Married
description: Miss Charlene Cecil Schuster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Joseph Schuster Jr. of Locust Valley, L. L, was married yesterday afternoon to Frank Edward Smyth, son of Mrs. Joseph Holmes Smyth of Baltimore and the late Mr. Smyth.

title: Diagramless, 19 by 19
description: ACROSS

title: Look What They did to Mozart's In Opera
description: WASHINGTON IN some circles, Mozart's Idomeneo is an in opera, and when Julius Rudel sparked a staged presentation on May 23 at the Kennedy Center, as part of the threeweek Mozart Festival, many connoisseurs from all over the country were present, enthusing about the music. Idomeneo, after all, does not get many performances. It is an opera seria, a serious opera, with some builtin defects that not even the genius Mozart could entirely overcome. It is static in action, with long stretches of recitative, and with stock mythological figures pretty much devoid of life. There is in Idomeneo some of the greatest music that Mozart or anybody else ever composed. But But there also are dull stretches, and Idomeneo does lack the bubbling life of the later operas.

title: Pop
description: IN contemporary music, perhaps more than in any other art, performers have to capture their audience on two separate frontsthe recording studio and the stage. Because each medium demands different kinds of skill, few performers achieve equal power in both places. The proper kind of setting is essential in each case. Good singers and good players have been killed by pallid arrangements on records just as they can be washed out by inadequate backing onstage.

title: Inspection of Leaks Planned By Atomic Power Company
description: WISCASSET, ME., June 1The Maine Yankee Atomics Power Company, will shut down its 855,000kilowatt generator on June 29 to inspect leaking fuel assemblies in the nuclear reactor core.

title: Nassau Gets BikeTheft Squad
description: MINEOLA  The Nassau County Police Department has started a special squad to investigate the growing number of bicycle thefts.

title: Jenkins Rides 6 to Devon Titles
description: DEVON, Pa., June 1Rod Jenkins rode Number One Spy to the open jumper chainpionship tonight to wind up a dazzling exhibition of horsemanship at the concluding session of the Devon Horse Show.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: The Winding Road to Quinby
description: QUINBY, Va.  Yes, Virginia, there is a Quinby, but don't try to find it after dark.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  Drag racing, Madison Township Raceway Park, Englishtown, N.J., 2 P.M.

title: Continental's McLean
description: A courageous and farsighted business statesman, John G. McLean sounded some of the earliest warnings of worldwide energy shortages and crises. A Ph.D. and former professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, Mr. McLean was chairman and chief executive officer of the Continental Oil Cornpany. His principal hallmark was his dedication to business ethics and social responsibility. John McLean died on May 20.

title: 100 Hurt in Arsenal Blast
description: RADFORD, Va., June 1 (UPI) An explosion leveled a TNT manufacturing building at the sprawling Radford Arsenal yesterday and injured 100 persons.

title: TheNation
description: J. W. Fuibright, United States Senator from Arkansas for 30 years, powerful and respected voice in foreign affairs and a symbol of early opposition to the war in Vietnam, has been defeated by a 2 to 1 margin in his state's Democratic primary.

title: Stephanie Evanitsky Challenges Gravity With Aerial Effects.
description: The obvious effort of clawing around trapeze machinery drains much of the esthetic beauty from Stephanie Evannitsky's presentation. For each moment of graceful posing one is presented with 10 struggling moments of preparation. Miss Evanitsky and her MultiGravin tational Experiment Group opened the Museum of Modern Art's Summergarden series Friday evening, this year assisted by a grant from the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: LILLA D. HAFER
description: Lilla D. Hafer who retired as director of the department of earlychildhood education of the Board of Education ire 1954, died yesterday at her home, 25 East 77th Street. Her age was 88.

title: The Democrats, Once Burned, Getting Warm Again
description: Four years ago, the Democratic state ticket headed by Arthur J. Goldberg was composed of four Jewish candidates and one black. Three of the five candidates came from Manhattan and two from Westchester. The ticket was badly defeated, at least partially because of its ethnic imbalance.

title: Plastic Sealant Reduces Tooth Decay in State Test
description: ALBANY, June 1 (AP)A plastic sealant applied to schoolchildren's teeth has reduced decay by about twothirds, according to state officials.

title: Right to Solitude
description: In announcing, a year ago, a ban on airplanes and motorboats in 700 Adirondack Forest Preserve lakes and ponds classified as Wilderness, Primitive and Canoe, the then State Environmental Conservation Commissioner Henry L. Diamond declared:

title: Architecture
description: ALITTLE revisionist history is taking place at the Museum of the City of New York. A small display in the entrance hall called Central Park's Calvert Vaux reminds us that a considerable share of the credit for the park belongs to Frederick Law Olmsted's partner  in  design. Vaux's sesquicentennial is being marked this year by park and landscape architecture buffs.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: The Value of Diego Garcia
description: NEW DELHIOn maps of the Indian Ocean, Diego Garcia appears as a scarcely visible dot. Until a few years ago, this Britishcontrolled coral atoll 1,200 miles south of India had a population of barely 500 and a modest annual production of copra, salt fish and tortoise shell.

title: Ideas&Trends Education, Migration, Cancer
description: Two researchers have found evidence that birds can sense barometric pressure changes and polarized light, an ability that apparently helps them navigate thousands of miles with great accuracy.

title: Grant Wood: He Got His Best Ideas While Milking a Cow
description: IN 1947, twenty years after. Grant Wood had been commissioned by a local American Legion post to create a large stainedglass window for the Veterans Memorial Building in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, and long after the window had been installed, the artist's name still was not inscribed on the central stone. The window, with its 16foot Lady of Peace flanked by lifesizecd American soldiers in uniforms representing all of our major wars from the Revolution to the First World War, certainly touched all the appropriate patriotic bases. Unfortunately, however, in the eyes of some members of the Legion and a few members of the D.A.R., Wood had committed the unforgivable faux pas of going in 1928 to Munich to have the work executed.

title: Sunday Observer
description: At our house we have been discovering the latest economic miracle. It is called the pass through. At first it looked like the keenest idea to emerge from the economic science since the Caesars came up with bread and circus.

title: CITY'S HOSPITALS DROP 1,700 BEDS
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation has taken more than 1,700 underutilized beds out of service in its 19 hospitals in a little more than 18 months. Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr., the agency's president, has estimated that the move would save about $7million a year.

title: Fashion: Teenage choices
description: They're 14 years old. They've outgrown children's clothes and shopping with mother. They go around the stores in pairs, but more for companionship than for advice. They know what they want. That's what we learned when we gave $50 each to four girls and set them loose. Here's what they bought (after it was made clear to them that they were not to spend the money on records).

title: Headliners
description: NOW, the eightyearold National Organization for Women, has a new president: Karen DeCrow, a lawyer from Syracuse. She defeated three other candidates to win the presidency. Miss DeCrow is a longtime NOW activist and spokesperson for the women's movement. Perhaps her best known act was a suit she brought against McSorley's Old Ale House in New York City, which helped bring an end to its 116yearold prohibition against women. Miss DeCrow says she plans to change the old NOW goal to integrate women into the mainstream of American life. She prefers, she said, to change the mainstream. Gender shouldn't be a very important aspect of how one functions in society, she says. What it means to be a male in America today is nothing that anybody should be fighting for.

title: Ruling the Roost in Farm Equipment
description: MOLINE, IllIn the massive east wing of its sprawling glass and steel headquarters on the outskirts of this northwest Illinois city, Deere & Co. displays prototypes of most of the farm machines and implements it has been making for the last 137 years.

title: F.B.I. Head Urges Caution On Crime News Coverage
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 1 (AP)Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, suggested today at extensive news coverage of sensational crimes stimulated similar crimes.

title: A Clinic at Rutgers Aids Drug Abusers
description: PISCATAWAY New Jersey's only research and treatment clinic for polydrug abusers chronic users of sleeping and diet pills, hypnotics, minor tranquilizers, amphetamines and Hallucinogenshas been in operation since April 1.

title: Dr. Marjorie H. Corker to Marry
description: The Rev. William F. Corker, rector of St Michael's Episcopal Church here, and Mrs. Corker of New York and Quogue, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Marjorie H. Corker, to Dr. Neri J. Holzer, son of Dr. and Mrs, Herbert Holzer of Orangeburg, N. Y.

title: Jesuit Praises Nixon
description: The Rev. John T. McLaughlin, the Jesuit priest who is a special assistant to President Nixon, in an interview assails the abuses of power and again praises Mr. Nixon. Details on Page 42.

title: West Orange to Get PartFree, PartPay TV Station in Fall
description: WEST ORANGE  Taste in television entertainment to will not be at the mercy of advertisers or dictated by a majority of viewers when WBTBTV (Channel 68), a UHF station, goes on the air here in September.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores in no communities throughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

title: For the foodobsessed
description: My fourthgrade homeroom teacher at Detroit's Hampton School used to moonlight on weekends at a bagel factory. Looking back now on the whole dismal affair, I like to hope that Mr. Grabstein had the sense to realize that, when he kneaded bagel dough on Saturday nights, he was touching greatness. Detroit bagels, you see, are the best bagels the world has produced since the sovietization of Vilna. At any rate, Grabstein had a hand, so to speak, in the floury wonders of the city's highest quality assembly line, until a classmate of mine caught him at it and spread the word.

title: High Costs Vex DayCare Units
description: MINEOLA  Increased costs may force the closing of Nassau County daycare centers, according to a spokesman for Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive.

title: Inflation Distorts the Retailing Picture
description: Retailers across the country are finding that business is not as good as it seems. Sales are up but so are prices. And once the effects of inflation are removed, what looked like an increase often turns into a decline.

title: Bridge
description: Few people agree about what should be thrown away. Many husbands cling grimly to wornout clothing and old papers that their wives would willingly dispose of. Defenders at the bridge table have discarding problems in an acute form every time they sit down to play. And most of them throw out valuable items and cling to garbage with monotonous regularity. This is partly due to lack of common sense, but more to lack of education the textbooks have little to say in this vital area.

title: Where Are the Films About. Real Black Men and Women?
description: UNLIKE white films which range at will over the full spectrum of human possibility from Deep Throat to the sixhour, hundredmilliondollar Soviet production of War and Peace, most black films have been mired in the rut of a single formulathe socalled action film which deals with marginal antisocial elements in the Northern urban ghetto. These films have been subjected to a tremendous amount of criticism.

title: Meeting the Natives At a City Block Party
description: THE street was filled with strollers of all ages. In front of a miniflea market a Haitian woman haggled in French over a pendant. . . . Kids raced up and down, pausing to add their mite to the collection of chalk drawings on a section of the pavement, to sample the meatfilled pastries called pastelillos. . . . Their parents wandered from table to table, studying the collections of printsand photos for sale; testing the weight of paperweights made from 19thcentury ...molds for chocolate and ice cream.

title: This Tennis Is Played With a Paddle And Punctured Ball in Select Company
description: Murray Geller, Mr. Paddle Tennis, opened a fresh can of Penn tennis balls yesterday, extracted a bright yellow one and, incredibly, struck a hypodermic needle in it.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: DR. GEORGE W. HILL
description: Dr. George W. Hill, medical director of the Ossining (N.Y.) Correctional Facility and an attending physician at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y., died Friday at the hospital.

title: Susan Ferris Is Bride
description: Miss Susan Elizabeth Ferris, daughter of Mrs. Bettina M. Ferris of New Canaan, Conn., and Frederick J. Ferris of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Lynn Andrew Rotando, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Lincoln Rotando of Bedford, N. Y. The ceremony was performed in St. Mark's Episcopal Church, New Canaan, by the Rev. Grant A. Morrill.

title: Dance
description: THE other weekend there were five major dance companies in town on the same night, and this is becoming increasingly frequent. Nor does this take into account individual concerts, ethnic groups and other assorted dance goodies, or occasionally baddies.

title: EDWARD SCHOEN JR., H.E.W. CIVIL JUDGE
description: Edward Schoen Jr., a judge with the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for the last six years who decided civil claims brought against the Government, died Friday in Atlanta, where he lived. His age was 60.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Ted Ailbeury's first novel published a little over a year ago, was named A Choice of Enemies, and it was impressive, a superior espionage story. In his latest novel SNOWBALL (Lippincott, $6.95), Allbeury is toying with the fate of nations rather than that of people. He has dreamed up a situation in which the Russians plan to release an explosive secret of World War II. The result could be a breakup of NATO and ultimate Soviet penetration of Europe. Operation Snowball, it's called. On the surface it appears to be a K.G.B. operation. But who is behind the K.G.B.?

title: Beverley Hutton Wed
description: The mariage of Miss Beverley Ann Jouet Hutton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lefferts Hutton of New Hope, Pa., and Port Jervis, N.Y., to Kenneth Claude Doiron took place at noon yesterday in New Hope. The Rev. Paul J. Carey performed the ceremony in St. Martin's Roman Catholic Church. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Hughes Doiron of Thornwell, La.

title: THAILAND'S PRESS PLAYS WIDER ROLE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 30 Thailand's press, which has long been one of the freest in Asia, is trying to come to grips with the almost limitless freedom bestowed on it by the new civilian administration.

title: Art
description: THERE will soon be upon us the first wave of that avalanche of national selfintoxication and mediasimulated euphoria known as the Bicentennial celebration. No doubt American life could do with a little euphoria these days, however dubious the source, and the wisest as well as the. easiest course may therefore be simply to lie down and let the whole thing batter our sensibilities until its energies are exhausted. On the other hand, one would already have had to suffer a certain occlusion of feeling not to shrink a little at the prospect of this uninterrupted succession of pageants, festivals, exhibitions, demonstrations, publications and assorted extravaganzas soon to assault our senses. The din is reach stupefying proportions.

title: The Inexorable Process: Can Anyone Call a Halt?
description: The issue of a President's duty to comply with the law has been with us from the earliest years of the Republic. History has ratified John Marshall's holding, in Marbury v. Madison in 1803, that Executive officials generally are subject to, orders of the courts. The classic test of Presidential power came when Harry Truman seized the country's steel mills 1952, to prevent a strike during the Korean War. By vote of 6 to 3, the Supreme Court rejected his claim that a President could meet what he called a national emergency on his own terms, without reference to laws passed by Congress. Justice Robert H. Jackson wrote:

title: Englewood School Emphasizes the Blind Spots in learning
description: ENGLEWOOD  In 18 years as a child psychologist, Dr. Beatrice Liegen had as patients innumerable bright children who were failing academically because they had learning blind spots that were not being overcome in public or special private schools.
