They were often brought to Dr. Liegen because, as a result of their years of failure, they had developed severe emotional problems.

title: Priscilla Gray, Richard Moon, Lawyers, Marry in Maryland
description: Miss Priscilla Finley Gray and Richard Goodwin Moon were married yesterday afternoon in Old Wye Church in Wye Mills, Md., by the Rev. William Hargett, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Centreville, Md.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Court Battle Leaves Drivers With Scars
description: While the aftermath of today's acquittal was filled with delirious relief for seven harnessracing drivers and their families, their happiness was tinged with bitterness over the nightmarish circumstances that had wreaked havoc with their lives.

title: Cynthia Lambert Wed To Andrew Stevenson
description: Miss Cynthia Weldon Lambert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Lambert, was married yesterday afternoon to Lieut. Andrew Gibb Stevenson of the Air Force, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew R. Stevenson, Both families are of White Plains, where the Rev. R. Bricker Gibson performed the ceremony in the Church in the Highlands (Congregational).

title: 20 at Atlanta Prison To Get College Honors
description: ATLANTA, June 1 (AP)Twenty inmates will don cap and gown Friday for the Atlanta Penitentiary's first college graduation ceremonies.

title: West Highland Terrier Takes Best at Memphis
Seaver Wins on 5Hitter
description: Just when people were beginning to pan his act, Tom Seaver regained his touch and delivered a virtuoso performance yesterdaya fivehitter with 11 strikeouts that carried the New York Mets to a 31 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Clergymen Urge Updating of Skills
description: Fifteen Methodist pastors from metropolitan New York, all members of a graduate course leading to a new Doctor of Ministry degree from Drew University of Madison, N.J., have just ended 30 weekly halfday seminars at Middle Village United Methodist Church, 7527 Metropolitan Avenue, convinced that updating of ministerial skills is a priority for the active clergymen of the nineteenseventies.

title: Library's Book Sales Ending
description: HACKENSACKThe Johnson Free Public Library is holding its 20th annual and last  book sale, which ends on Tuesday.

title: New vs. Old Is Upsetting Greek Life
description: ATHENS, June 1  For Voula Lionis, being stuck on the Long Island Expressway at rush hour would be a treat compared to her present schedule.

title: MRS. W. T. LONGOOPE
description: Mrs. Janet Percy Dana Longcope, widow of Dr. Warfield T. Longcope, for 24 years professor of medicine at the Johns Hopkins Medical School, died yesterday at her, home in Lee, Mass. Her age was 88.

title: Midtown Building to Be Auctioned
description: The fivestory building at 3017 East 52d Street that was formerly the Kips Bay Boys Club will be auctioned June 12 at a minimum upset price of $650,000.

title: 38 School Budgets Beaten
description: ALBANY, Jane 1 (AP)Budget proposals were defeated in 38 of the 181 schoolbudget referendums conducted in May, the State Education Department reported yesterday. Of the defeats, 11 were in Nassau County, eight in Westchester County and three in Rockland County.

title: HomeGrown Herbs Put Zest in the Spice of Culinary Life
description: Rising food costs have led many people to plant gardens or at least invest in a few pots of patio tomatoes.

title: U.N. Chief Meets Nixon And Kissinger on Truce
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger conferred today with Secretary General Waldheim on the role of the United Nations observer force on the Golan Heights following the signing of an agreement yesterday on the separation of Syrian and Israeli forces in the area.

title: Sports: Leagues Big And Little
description: A few weeks before Jackie Robi son died, he seemed to have may a stirring peace with life. He within his great stone mansion Connecticut, blindness filming eyes, and spoke slowly, gravely abot the serious issues of his existence.

title: Stamps
description: FOR the first time in almost two decades, the annual Europa issues have a new themenational sculptureinstead of the various symbolic designs that were graphic variations of the letter E.

title: How to Steer a Sailboat
description: In sailboat racing, there is much attention paid to tactics, strategy and use of the rules, but all these, important as they are, will not win races if the boat is not sailing fast.

title: Reuss Charges Administration Is Passive in Economic Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP). A spokesman for Congressional Democrats said today that the Nixon Administration was remaining passive while an economic crisis undermined the quality of life for millions of Americans.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Scientists have quit monkeying around, and, in an effort to explore the intellect of chimpanzees, are successfully using computers to help the animals communicate with humans.

title: AVHFTV Station Is Urged
description: WASHINGTONThe New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting has petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to assign a commercial VHF television channel to the state.

title: Sydney Hamilton, 78, Dies; Was Actress in Vaudeville
description: Sydney Hamilton, a vaudeville performer of the nineteentwenties, died Friday in Sydney, Australia. She was 78 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, June 1 Pakistan has called off a meeting with India scheduled for June 10 to discuss further steps toward normalization of relations.

title: The images constantly reversing
description: BERKELEY, Calif.In the fall of 1973, I returned to live in the San Francisco Bay Area after a nineyear absence. I found my old friends who had been activists in the sixties preparing to go back to school or work.

title: Uniondale Wins; Smith Ties Mark
description: GREENVALE, L.I., June 1 Willie Smith of Uniondale won the 100yard dash in 9.3 seconds to equal his second national high school record in two weeks today in the Nassau County track and field championships at C. W. Post College.

title: Thomas Kaufmann Weds Heidi Roehrig
description: Miss Virginia Burns Roehrig, a doctoral candidate in Columbia University's department of art and archeology, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas DaCosta Kaufmann, a doctoral candidate in fine arts at Hai.yard University. The Rev. William Berndt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Wellesley (Mass.) Country Club.

title: Colby Given $2Million
description: WATERVILLE, Me., June 1Colby College has received a, bequest in excess of $2million, the board of trustees was told at the annual commencement meeting this afternoon. It is the largest single gift in the 161year history of the coeducational school. The funds were left by Mrs. Mary Stafford Arey, who died last month in Worcester, Mass., at the age of 90.

title: Campaign Financing: Reform Is Not Easy
description: WASHINGTONAs the House Judiciary Committee tries to sort out the remaining mysteries of the Watergate scandal, a less celebrated House committee is trying to sort out conflicting views on how to make future Watergates less likely.

title: Miss Deane A. Rand Is Betrothed
description: Miss Deane A. Rande, a magna cum laude graduate of Princeton University, plans to be married to Paul E. Stepansky, a summa cum laude graduate of Princeton, where both received their degrees last year.

title: Patterns of Pleasure
description: When several pleasing habits or interests can be combined in one pattern of association and when enjoyment of one hobby means simultaneous enjoyment of the others, the satisfaction is pervasive and lasting. Needlepoint for me is part of such a pattern of pleasures. The elements are music; the company of my cat; a possible baseball game on the radio (not television to distract my eye) as alternative to the phonograph, and needlepoint in hand that is a large project with plenty of personal detail and a permanent destination like a piece of good furniture or a work worth framing.

title: BHUTAN REPORTS PLOT TO KILL KING
description: THIMBU, Bhutan, June 1The Bhutanese Government has reported a plot to assassinate the 18yearold King, Jigme Singhi Wangchuk, who is to be crowned tomorrow.

title: J. FEARON BROWN
description: J. Fearon Brown, lawyer for 55 years at his retirement in 1971, died yesterday at his home, 1115, Fifth Avenue. He was 83 years old and lived also in ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE GREAT SCHOOL WARS, by Diane Ravitch. (Basic Books, $12.95.) A quietly authoritative historical inquiry into the political struggles that wracked the New York schools between 1805 and 1973, as successive immigrant waves coursed through them.

title: DR. DELLA ROCCA
description: Dr. Anthony Della Rocca, an eye surgeon, died on Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, while attending an ophthamology congress in Paris. He was 72 years old and lived at 30 Colonial Road, White Plains.

title: In the Name of a Cause
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland One day recently a British officer looked over reports of the previous night's action in Derry and snorted: Three shootings in the Cregganpeanuts! It does not take much exposure to the unending violence of Northern Ireland to make three random shots in the night seem like peanuts.

title: 350th Birthday Creeps Up on Flatlands
description: Civic leaders in Flatlands, the first area settled by the Dutch in Brooklyn, are preparing celebrate its 350th birthday in the next few weeks.

title: Two cheers for eight winners
description: Professional associations generally represent an establishment of sorts, and the American Institute of Architects is no exception. Like all establishments, it moves cautiously, both with regard to what it does about its own architecture (it refused to fight the Washington Fine Arts Commission's rejection of its superb headquarters plan in 1968 and settled for a mediocre substitute) and with regard to what architecture it approves of around the country.

title: Woosnam Wants 20 Teams in N.A.S.L.
description: Encouraged by rising attendance figures and the progress soccer is making in other areas, Phil Woosnam, commissioner of the North American Soccer League, feels it is time that his league, which grew from nine to 15 teams this season, expands to 20 teams next season.

title: L.I. Officials Say BeachNudity Ban Will Continue
description: A state court's reversal of the conviction of a nude woman found guilty of lewdness on a public beach on Long Island in 1971 has touched off fears that nudity will run rampant, but a court spokesman said that this was not the intent of the ruling and that the police would not allow this to happen.

title: Elisse Walter Wed To Ronald A. Stern
description: Miss Elisse Barbara Walter and Ronald Allan Stern, who recently received LL.B. degrees from the Harvard Law School, were married last evening in the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L. I. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony.

title: A woman's prerogative
description: With whom would you like to swap lives for a month? I asked the question recently at a dinner party. A Hollywood agent picked Henry Kissinger, a sportsobsessed film producer wanted to be George Plimpton; I was torn between Billie Jean King and Barbra Streisand; three women opted for Mrs. Robert Redford. The idea trickled in and out of the conversation all evening.

title: What's Doing in LAGOS
description: THE FACE OF THE CITYIn Lagos there is a degree of integration between residents and foreigners rarely found in other African capitals. There are unintegrated slums, of course, beginning at the foot of Carter Bridge on the island of Lagos, but many Nigerians live in the sprawling middleclass housing de velopments of Apapa, Surulere and Ikeja and also in the plushly suburban mansions of Ikoyi Island, where most foreign diplomats and businessmen reside. Nigeria is under military rule, and by law politicking is not permitted, but ebullient Lagos residents talk long and loud about the proposed return to civilian rule in 1976.Three schools of thought on the subject are most often heard: 1. That the military should continue to rule. 2. That a civilian government should take over. 3. That the new government should consist of a combination of civilian and military leaders. Other current topics of conversationin English, the official language of this former British possession, and in various African languagesinclude traffic jams, housing shortages, the building boom and other indicators of a fastpaced, oilbolstered economic boom. In addition, people are talking about what promises to be the biggest of all African cultural celebrations, the Second World Black and African Festival of Arts and Culture, which is scheduled for November and December, 1975. Early indications are that as many as 100,000 visitors will come to this city of about a million people for the festival. Where are we going to put them? residents ask. Officials are replying by building a new city for at least 50,000 guests on the outskirts of town. After the festival, the development is to become apartments for local families.

title: Arm Weathers, R. H. Callender Plan Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eliot B. Weathers of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Brooks Weathers, to Robert Howard Callender, an assistant professor of physics at City College. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Callender of St. Paul.

title: Dodger 13Hit Attack Routs Cubs, 100
description: CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) Ron Cey slugged two homers and a single and drove in seven runs today in support of Andy Messersmith as the Los Angeles Dodgers posted a 10.0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Suffolk Awards $111,000 For Arts
description: HAUPPAUGEIn its first effort to subsidize the arts, Suffolk County will distribute $111,156.66 to 50 cultural organizations to spend beforethe end of 1974.

title: The New York Times Magazine June 2, 1974
description: HOLLYWOOD. In the center of the field was a gigantic pile of sets, flats and props. While he watched, a 10ton truck added another load to it. This was the final dumping ground. He thought of Janvier's Sargasso Sea. Just as that imaginary body of water was a history of civilization in the form of a marine junkyard, the studio lot was one in the form of a dream dump. A Sargasso of the imagination! And the dump grew continually, for there wasn't a dream afloat somewhere which wouldn't sooner or later turn up on it, having first been made photographic by plaster, canvas, lath and paint. Many boats sink and never reach the Sargasso, but no dream ever entirely disappears. Somewhere it troubles some unfortunate person and some day, when that person has been sufficiently troubled, it will be reproduced on the lot: NATHANAEL WEST, The Day of the Locust.

title: Food: The geography of chowder
description: Chowder sounds as American as Indian pudding, but the word actually is French in origin. It is derived from the French word chaudiere, meaning cauldron. This was the vessel in which French immigrants cooked their fish stews when they settled in the coastal areas of America. The chowders on this page represent two of this nation's favoritesManhattan clam chowder and Boston clam chowder.

title: A Flushing Bus Terminal Is Approved
description: The City Planning Commission gave its approval last week for construction of a new bus terminal with public parking space for 1,151 automobiles on the roof in the shopping district of Flushing, Queens.

title: Salem State College Faculty Votes to Censure President
description: SALEM, Mass., June 1 (AP)11 The Salem State College faculty senate has voted to censure the college president, Frank L. Keegan, and to ask the board of trustees to investigate him.

title: Psychiatrist Asserts Ruby Was Too Ill for '67 Trial
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) A Chicago psychiatrist says Jack Ruby was suffering from a severe mental illness at the time he was scheduled for a new trial for the 1963 murder of Lee Harvey Oswald, assassin of President Kennedy.

title: Leesburg Prison Chief Endorses Involvement
description: LEESBURG  Ronald M. Groomes, the new superintendent of Leesburg State Prison, is not interested in any alleged irregularities that might have occurred there in the past, such as widespread use of narcotics among the inmates.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH air conditioning is undoubtedly the most effective way of keeping the inside of the house coal during hot weather, energy shortages, coupled with the high cost of electricity these days, have brought back renewed interest in attic exhaust fansonce the homeowner's most effective way to insure a comfortable night's sleep.

title: Stars Are Coming to Camp Tomorrow, But Will They Glisten in the W.F.L.?
description: Babe Parilli has no idea what's going to happen when the New York Stars play their first World Football League game next month. Without films, scouting reports or any exhibitions to fall back on, the Stars' coach said recently of the new league and its 20game regularseason schedule, your guess is as good as mine. One thing's for sure  it will be something different.

title: Schooling Offered Handicappd Youth
description: WEST LONG BRANCHApplications are now being accepted for enrollment in the new Campus School for Exceptional Children that Monmouth College will open next month.

title: Mrs. Rankin Keeps Golf Lead at 144
description: BALTIMORE, June 1 (AP) Mrs. Judy Rankin slumped on the back nine in today's second round, but maintained a onestroke lead in the $40,000 Baltimore golf tournament, with a par 73 and a 36hole total of 144.

title: South Street Seaport: Offshore and OffBroadway
description: The foredeck of the Wavertree, an iron, squarerigged cargo ship built in 1885, is the best vantage point from which to see the pinstriped parade to the South Street Seaport. Each weekday at noon the whistle blows, signaling the stately seaward march of Wall Street bankers and brokers, who go to lunch out of brown bags in the salty atmosphere of the historic dock and museum.

title: Fulbright, The Scholar In Foreign Affairs
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.The writers always mentioned the gently mocking voice, the eyebrows arched in skepticism, the faintly flickering eyes peering over the top of the glasses into the flushed face of some confused, angry or bewildered witness.

title: PORTUGUESE PLAN TIE WITH RUMANIA
description: LISBON, June 1Portugal and Rumania todayannounced agreement to reestablish diplomatic relations, broken off more than 25 years ago.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe fifth annual Brookings Institution budget book, published last week, contains a bewildering array of information. Although it is 269 pages long, it is not susceptible to bookreview treatment because it covers so much unrelated ground.

title: E.R. Unterman Weds Miss Hoffstot
description: The Shadyside Presbyterian. Church in Pittsburgh was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Thayer Drew Hoffstot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Phipps Hoffstot of Pittsburgh, to Edward Robert Unterman, son of Col. Elvin Ian. Unterman, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Unterman of New York and Garrison, N. Y. The Rev. James Hiram Blackwood performed the ceremony.

title: Forces Against Abortion Assemble, With Optimism
description: WASHINGTON  Once again this week, physicians and geneticists will read their learned papers to a small group of earnestly attentive Senators and an audience sporting plastic roses. Outside on Capitol Hill, technicolor pictures of fetuses will be handed out to passersby.

title: Miss Maureen Merhoff Betrothed
description: The engagement of Miss Maureen Merhoff to Peter A. Velde has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Merhoff of Fond Du Lac, Wis. Mr. Velde is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Velde of Greenwich, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla. The wedding is planned for Aug. 17 in Fond Du Lac.

title: Letters: On Saving Venice
description: To the Editor:

title: Katrin Belenky Is Wed
description: Miss Katrin Tamara Belenky, daughter of Mrs. Selma Belinky of New York and the late Dr. Allen A. Belenky, was married here yesterday evening to Dr. Barry Evan Brenner. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Brenner of Tarrytown, N. Y. Rabbi Ronald Sobell performed the ceremony in the Cottage on the park at the Hampshire House. The bride's mother is a psychotherapist and her father was a psychiatrist. Dr. Brenner is studying for a doctorate in microbiology at the Medical College of Virginia School of Graduate Studies.

title: Epilogue A Glance Back at Some Major Stories
description: On Jan. 23, 1973, Henry A. Kissinger, representing the United States, and Le Due Tho, representing North Vietnam, initialed the Vietnam peace agreement. This was almost three months after Mr. Kissinger had announced to the world that peace is at hand and many months after American aircraft had bombed Hanoi and mined Haiphong Harbor.

title: Navy Officer Weds Joan E. Steinman
description: Miss Joan Ellen Steinman, a lawyer with Hardin & Waite in Chicago, and Lieut. Douglas W. Cassel, who is with the Judge Advocate's Office of the Navy, were married yesterday. The nondenominational ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Steinman, in Brooklyn, by the Rev. Jesse Lyons of the Riverside Church.

title: Oranges Will Get Advice on Housing
description: EAST ORANGEThe Department of Housing and Urban Development (HOD) has designated the Joint Enterprises Trusteeship Corporation (JET) as a creditcounseling agency for the Oranges. The program, provided for under the Housing Act, is designed to give free homebuyer, homeowner and tenant counseling.

title: After 50 Years, the American Wilderness Still Standsin Peril
description: Like winds and sunsets, wild things were taken for granted until proggress began to do away with them ...Now we face the question whether, a still higher standard of living is worth its cost in things natural, wild and free.

title: The grand old man of New York theater
description: At 73 Harold Clurman is the grand old man of New York theater. Exactly half a century ago he was general factotum at the Greenwich Village Playhouse, from which he graduated to the Theatre Guild, afterwards to become a founding father of the Group Theatre. Since the Group's dissolution in 1941, Clurman has combined directing with writing. The Divine Pastimethe title is Voltaire's description of theateris Clurman's third collection of theater essays. Of some 300 pages Clurman has culled about 100 from his Lies Like Truth and another 100 from his The Naked Image; only the last 100 are newly sandwiched between book covers. But almost all the bear rereading.

title: His life was a tug of war
description: Fade in: London, 1927. Enter Emlyn Williams, a 21yearold stagestruck kid who has just gotten off the train from Wales and wants to be a star. Cut to: failure. Cut to: poverty. Cut to: eight long years marked by an unending series of minor acting and playwriting successes that only make a determined Emlyn more determined to make it big. Finally dissolve to: opening night of Night Must Fall. Our hero waits stoically in the wings. He alone does not know that this one is the Big One and the Big Time is but a mere two hours away. A very slow fade out as expectant Emlyn prepares to make the most important entrance of his life.

title: Bikes Are for Everyone
description: Our eldest son just gave his eldest son a bike for his seventh birthday: my parents gave me one for mine. Yet bicycling is far older than this mere hal century or so span: According to Bicycling: a Golden Guide, the first bicycle was made in France in the late 1770's and was called the Celifer. Next about 1816, a German Baron invented a Draisine, whose front wheel could be turned for guiding. By 1880, some 2 million Americans rode bicycles. Today there are 75 mililion bike owners.

title: Unconventional Hampshire College at a Milestone
description: AMHERST, Mass., June 1It was conceived as a kind of academic Phoenix, rising out of the ashes of conventional liberal education and combining some very new and some very old ideas about learning and discovery.

title: Kym S. Snyder Bride Of Mark Shepley Rice
description: Miss Kym Elizabeth Snyder, who graduated last month from Newcomb College of Tulane University, was married at noon yesterday in Essex, Conn., to Mark Shepley Rice, a member of the class of '75 at the University of Maine.

title: Gerald Shea, Antiquarian, Headed Chain of Movies
description: Gerald Shea, president of the Jamestown Amusement Corporation, which operates a chain of movie theaters in New England and Ohio, died Friday at his home, 14 Sutton Place South. He was 65 years old and also lived in Bedford, N.H.

title: RED TIDE PERIL CUTS FISHING OFF COAST
description: BOSTON, June 2 (AP)Officials of three states have ordered a 70mile stretch of coastline from Cape Elizabeth, Me., to Cape Ann, Mass., closed to shellfishing after reports indicated possibly harmful contamination, known as red tide.

title: Public Libraries on Island Becoming Community Centers
description: PORT WASHINGTON With little fanfare, suburban libraries increasingly have taken on the role of community centers. Diversified, centrally located and attuned to community needs, libraries in Nassau and Suffolk Counties are growing yearly in both size and scope, backed by the people they serve.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Investor disappointment that interest rates have not peaked helped send stock prices down sharply last week in fairly active trading.

title: EUROPE PLANS AID FOR ALIEN LABOR
description: VIENNA, May 31West European ministers of justice today called for a special study of legal problems that are often encountered by foreign workers.

title: Pickers of Produce Can Acquire Guide
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Do you want to pick your own fresh fruits and vegetables this year?

title: Strategy of Corporate Shrinkage
description: Addressing a small group of security analysts at the Wall Street Club last week, James F. Towey, chairman and chief executive of the Olin Corporation, commented: The heavy pruning is finished. We like what's left.

title: Mary E. Stroup, Artist, Is Bride Of R. M. Wolters
description: Miss Mary Elizabeth Stroup, and Roger Mansfield Wolters were married yesterday afternoon at All Saints Chapel in the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N.Y., by the Rev. Mills R. Omaly. The bride is a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Dudley J. Stroup. Dr. Stroup is rector of St. James the Less.

title: Police Sessions Seeking Racial Amity
description: Thirteen persons were seated in a semicircle in an aged building on the Fort Totten Army base. All were dressed casually; some were wearing guns.

title: History: More and Still More
description: Soon the bags will be being packed for Vermont, New Hampshire, the Cape and the wilder shores of Maine. The seriousminded, the frivolous, the middleaged and the young will all want some books, and surprisingly more and more will want books about history. As fiction declines, history soars; and what was once a trickle is now a Mississippi in flood. Every publisher is hunting for new historical seriesmonarchs, families, great events. Never before has there been such a plethora to choose from.

title: Virgil Woodcock, ExHead Oft, Patent Law Association
description: Virgil E. Woodcock, a past president of the American Patent Law Association, died Friday evening at his home in Rosemont, Pa. He was 69 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Calendar of Horse Shows
description: Today  Hollandia Farms, Moriches Road, St. James, L.I. Regular, green and amateurowner working hunters; open and preliminary jumpers, adult horsemanship. 8:30 A.M.

title: Jesuit Assails Abuses of Power and Defends Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 Power! exclaimed the Rev. John J. McLaughlin, pacing his tiny office. What do we know about it? We don't know anything about it. We have sex educationwhy don't we have power education? You can train yourself to handle power.

title: Miss Kristina Hooker Vigeland Betrothed to Robert S. Ashton
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Frank Wiedernan of Haworth, N. J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wiedeman's daughter, Miss Kristina Hooker Vigeland, to Robert Stewart Ashton, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Ashton of Saratoga Springs, N. Y.

title: Abigail Stewart Is Bride
description: Miss Abigail J. Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton D. Stewart of Ward Hill, S. was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. David G. Winter, an assistant professor of psychology at Wesleyan University. Judge Holt Meyer of the Family Court performed the ceremony at the home of the parents of the bride, a graduate student in psychology at Harvard University. The bridegroom, whose former marriage ended in divorce, is the son of Dr, Garrett E. Winter of Grand Rapids, Mich., and the late Mrs. Wilamena Sprick Winter.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The proposed 96th Street luxury apartment building [96th Street Development Set, May 12] represents the beginnings of an assault on the West Side community. This assault will have various effects.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: If necessity and capital are the parents of invention, Morris Folsom Miller must be one of the most innovative matchMakers to ply Wall Street in many a year.

title: CALIFORNIA HOLDS PRIMARY TUESDAY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 1California voters on Tuesday will probably nominate the 36yearold son of a former Governor and a 44yearold former college teacher as the major parties' choices for Governor.

title: A talk with Simone de Beauvoir
description: PARIS. I don't want my life to obey any other will but my own, Simone de Beauvoir wrote in her diary when she was 19. She has indeed made her own life, and the will of others has played a remarkably small part in it.

title: Pair of Porsche Drivers Welcome Back a Rival
description: A couple of successful Porsche drivers are happy that Warren Agor is well and will be racing in the S. C. C. A. TransAmerican event at Montreal next Sunday.

title: Biography: Byron Yes, Faulkner No
description: Two arbitrary rules govern this sampling of recent biographies. First, all have been published since the beginning of this year. Second, summer reading is not a consideration: Put Hitler in your beach bag just isn't a workable approach.

title: A Book Examines Rise of Black Mafia
description: Control of organized crime in America is passing from Italian Americans to a rising new black and Hispanic Mafia. according to Francis A. J. Ianni, an anthropologist who has been studying organized crime.

title: DOWNTOWN BLOCK WINS A REPRIEVE
description: The realestate developers who own about twothirds of the Fraunces Tavern block downtown have agreed to stay any demolition for six months to permit a feasibility study to be made for the redevelopment of the entire block.

title: A Visit to the Howes of Houston, Who Formerly Lived in Detroit
description: It was not until New Year's Eve that the total realization hit us. The Howes truly were living in Texas and working with the Houston Aeros of the World Hockey Association. So much had happened since we first learned of Marty and Mark being pro draft choices, and there had been little time to think of all the many changes and adjustments that would affect our lives.

title: JEREMIAH O'SULLIVAN
description: Jeremiah M, O'Sullivan, professor emeritus of medieval history at Fordham University, died yesterday in a nursing home in Lawrenceville, N. J. He was 71 years old and lived at 201 Beechwood Avenue, Trenton.

title: Can't Tell Dogs Without Showcard at RareBreed Event
description: Have you ever heard of a Tibetan mastiff? A Little Lion dog? Or a Chinese crested? If you haven't, there's no need to be apologetic, Few in the United States have.

title: Hotel School: Learning to Love the Computer
description: As it happened, the only other person in the lobby at the time was the beautiful young desk clerk, Milo Maritimo. ... he was a graduate of the Cornell Hotel School. He was the homosexual grandson of ... a bodyguard of the notorious Chicago gangster, Al Capone.

title: My Life as a Man
description: Never in our history have Americans been so driven to expose themselves; in our recent revaluation of all values, privacy has been one of the big losers. Everywhere we turn in society and the arts people are baring their privates or spilling their guts, from the vogue of confessional poetry to the pervasiveness of pornography, from the New Journalism with its lens turned inward on the reporter himself to the new assertiveness of homosexuals and other increasingly proud minorities. Classical psychoanalysis  which, though a talking cure, is essentially an interior dialogue, as private as the confessionboxhas been more and more displaced by consciousnessraising groups, encounter therapies and other techniques which seek an alleviation of guilt and isolation by comparing private lives, not simply exploring one's own. Now even Richard Nixon, as closed and stagey a figure as ever walked the public boards, has gambled his neck in a reckless act of selfhumiliation, trying, like an avantgarde writer, to pick up all the marbles by achieving a new breakthrough, by daring to tell the worst.

title: WILSON APPROVES EXPATIENTS' AID
description: Seven bills designed to help discharged mental patients make their way back into society and to ease the burden of their return on local communities, have been signed into law, Governor Wilson's office reported yesterday.

title: Most in State Said To Feel Ford Is Fit For the Presidency
description: A majority of New Jersey residents deem Vice President Ford qualified to serve as President even though only one out of three believe he is doing a good or excellent job, according to the latest New Jersey Poll conducted by the Eagleton Institute of Politics.

title: BLACKS IN RHODESIA REJECT VOTING PLAN
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 2 (APIThe African National Council today rejected the latest proposals by Rhodesia's white minority government for political rights for blacks.

title: Protecting the Consumer
description: The Supreme Court's class action decision in the Eisen case deals a body blow to the burgeoning consumer protection movement in this country.

title: Vassar's Male Graduates Include an ExConvict
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 2A former inmate of Green Haven Prison graduated from Vassar College with general honors today. He was among 169 men in a class of 509, the first men to have spent four years at Vassar.

title: 4 Honorary Degrees Given By American International
description: American International College in Springfield, Mass., awarded honorary degrees at commencement exercises yesterday to Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger of New York; Judge Francis J. Quirico of the Massachusetts Supreme Court; Frederick Gladstone Smith, Minister of Communications and Works for Barbados, and Prof. Richard P. Wilbur of Wesleyan University, poet who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1957.

title: Oil and the Cash Flow
description: WASHINGTONArab oil earnings will rise by $65 billion this year, the amounts will get even bigger in following years, the balanceofpayments positions of the consuming countries will plunge into the abyss, the international monetary system will collapse, the Arabs will buy up all our companiesso goes the refrain heard frequently since the dramatic increase in oil prices in December.

title: 4 Winners On Coast For Pincay
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 2 (UPI)Laffit Pincay Jr. increased the earnings of his mounts to more than $2million today when he rode lightly regarded Battery E. to victory in the 33d running of the $63,800 Argonaut handicap for, 3yearolds at Hollywood Park.

title: Radiation From HTest In '54 Still Taking Toll
description: On March 1, 1954, a hydrogen bomb exploding at Bikini Atoll cast a cloud of radioactive coral dust that late rained down unexpectedly on islands far downwind as well as on a Japanese fishing boat.

title: Man Shot to Death in Ulster Said to Be ExI.R.A. Leader
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 2 (AP)A former highranking member of the Irish Republic Army was shot to death today in an apparent foud within the outlawed guervilla group, the police said.

title: Music: The AvantGarde
description: The first performance of Philip Glass's Music in 12 Parts, Saturday night at Town Hall, was both an end and a beginning.

title: Rainout Victory To Mrs. Rankin
description: BALTIMORE, June 2 (AP) Mrs. Judy Rankin was declared the winner of the $40,000 Baltimore tournament on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour today after heavy rain washed out the final round of the 54hole event.

title: 2 Dead in Philippine Sinking
description: MANILA, June 3 (AP)An interisland vessel carrying more than 275 peersons sank today in central Philippines waters, and the Coast Guard said that at least two persons were dead and 31 missing. Searchers reported pulling 244 survivors from the sea.

title: Personal Finance: Wage Assignments
description: If a borrower defaults on his loan to a finance company, can the company seize a part of his paycheck without first giving him a chance to defend himself?

title: Parley to Study Nazi Slaughter of Jews
description: Forty scholars and religious figures will meet at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine today for a fourday international symposium on the full meaning of the Nazi slaughter of six million Jews during World War II.

title: U.S.C. Captures N.C.A.A. Play off
description: LOS ANGELES, June 2 (AP)  Rich Dauer put on a powerful offensive show today as Southern California swept a doubleheader from Pepperdine, 41 and 121, to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association District 8 baseball playoff and advance to the college world series in Omaha.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: ISRAEL SAYS PATROL. KILLS 2 GUERRILLAS
description: TEL AVIV, June 2 (AP)An Israeli border patrol killed two Palestinian guerrillas infiltrating across the Lebanese frontier late yesterday, the military command said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a May 23 OpEd article I examined the contention of Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski that by recently raising the jurisdictional issue of his standing to sue the President the White House violated the promise of independence that was made to Mr. Jaworski. I remarked in passing that in my judgment the White House position on the jurisdictional issuealthough not necessarily on the propriety of raising it nowis correct as a matter of law. In an OpEd article you published on May 30, Prof. Paul M. Bator of Harvard plunges deep Into the history of the Englishspeaking peoples and emerges With the enthusiastic conclusion that I am dead wrong. Perhaps I am, but I should like to explain briefly how I got that way.

title: Seal Skin Report Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)  Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, said today that he had written to Commerce Secretary Frederick Dent for clarification of reports that the department was preparing to permit the importation of seal skins. Although the law prohibits the importation of seal skins for commercial purposes, Mr. Williams said, it does allow, the Commerce Department to grant waivers.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Tinderbox Near Boston Seeks Safer Times
description: CHELSEA, Mass., June 2For blocks and blocks around the firehouse of Engine 5, the land is vacant. The structures have all burned down. The edge of one of the big firehouse doors is charred, the paint blistered on a metal alarm box. The building's flagpole had to be taken off because its supports were so weakened by fire that it was a hazard.

title: Miyamoto Golf Winner
description: KAWANISHI, Japan, June 2 (AP)Shozo Miyamoto of Japan shot a finalround 73, one over par, and won the $107,142 Sports Shinko International open golf tournament today for his first tournament victory in six years. Miyamoto won the first prize of $21,428 with a 72hole total of 289.

title: EX  HOSPITAL CHIEF SURRENDERS IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI, June 2Sanford K. Bronstein, former president of the bankrupt Cedars of Lebanon Hospital of Miami, who had been sought in connection with criminal charges of conspiracy, larceny and forgery, surrendered to the authorities here yesterday and was later freed on a $25,000 bail.

title: 1,839 Dogs In Show at Memphis
description: MEMPHIS, June 2  The Centennial Show to celebrate the 100th anniversary of dog shows in the United States drew a field of 1,839 tonight to the MidSouth Fairgrounds, site of the first show held here on Oct. 7, 1874. The event carried a purse of $2,000 for the winner, with $500 for each group victory, making it one of the richest canine events in America.

title: Rich but Underdeveloped, Iran Seeks More Power
description: TEHERAN, Iran  Iran, where civilization flourished while Europe was barbarian, is today a country that cannot feed itself.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: LILIAN ARNOLD
description: Lilian Arnold, a theater talent representative who had run her own office here since 1957, died yesterday in FlowerFifth Avenue Hospitals. She was 69 years old and lived at 134 West 58th Street.

title: Combating Police Racism
description: The New York City Police Department has racial problems, but unlike many other similar institutions, it is making a convincing attemptto overcome them in at least two ways. First, Commissioner Michael S. Codd, in a policy statement acknowledging some racial polarization in the department, has directed firmly that internal interracial confrontations be investigated by superior officers who will be held accountable for their accuracy and integrity. Second, he has initiated a series of conferences on racial issues which are to involve officers from precincts where the severest difficulties have been encountered.

title: Peace With Honor
description: The United States bombed North Vietnam over Christmas, 1972, in order to persuade South Vietnam to accept the truce agreement. By brutalizing Hanoi, as Gen. Alexander Haig put it to Nguyen Van Thieu in Saigon, we aimed to convince President Thieu that he would be militarily secure after the truce.

title: The Singing Telegram Dies on Coast, Replaced by Raggedy Ann or Candy
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 One more thing is disappearing, relinquished forever to nostalgia and memory and those few history or sociology books that may characterize it as yet another example of the kind of thing that floundered and finally lost its place in modern times.

title: Some Area Congressmen Disclose Financial Status
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  A selfportrait of the financial status of members of Congress from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut today revealed that their net worths varied from the $22,761 reported by Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat of the Bronx, to the $4.1million reported by Representative Ogden R. Reid, Democrat of Westchester.

title: Nixon Returns to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House tonight after spending a rainy day at Camp David, Md., with his wife and his friend, Charles G. Rebozo. A spokesman said Mr. Nixon worked on foreign policy matters, presumably including his planned trips later this month to the Middle East and Moscow.

title: GOLDIN FORESEES 87MILLION DEFICIT IN BEAME'S BUDGET
description: City Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that Mayor Beame's proposed $11.1billion expense budget would be $87million in the red.

title: A ROCKET KILLS 29 IN BIEN HOA PRISON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Monday, June 3 (AP)A rock et from Communist launcher struck a South Vietnamese prison housing Vietcong and other political prisoners near Bien Hoa air base before dawn today, killing 29 and wounding 63, the police reported.

title: Church in Portugal Torn By Collaboration Charge
description: LISBON, June 2The church in this overwhelmingly Roman Catholic nation is being torn by charges that bishops and priests had collaborated with the former authoritarian regime and even with its secret police.

title: GreekAmericans and Cosmos Triumph
description: The New York GreekAmericans defeated Croatan of Chicago, 20, yesterday to capture the United States Challenge Cup, the most coveted prize in semipro and amateur soccer, for the fourth time.

title: SOVIET STRESSES DEMOCRATS ROLE
description: MOSCOW, June 2The Soviet press, in its first significant comment on President Nixon's visit since the date was announced on Friday, stressed today that the summit meeting beginning June 27 enjoyed the backing of Democrats as well as Republicans in Congress.

title: Riders Applaud L.I.R.R. Improvements
description: For the Long Island Rail Road it has been a long haul back from Teeteringonthe Brink. Most of its 221,000 daily riders now seem agreed that the improvement since the state took over the bankrupt operation in 1966 has been worthy of a salute in double highballs in the bar car.

title: Horse Show Results
description: AT ST. JAMES, L.I.

title: SOVIET STRESSES DEMOCRATS' ROLE
description: MOSCOW, June 2The Soviet press, in its first significant comment on President Nixon's visit since the date was announced on Friday, stressed today that the summit meeting beginning June 27 enjoyed the backing of Democrats as well as Republicans in Congress.

title: Jury to Resume Weighing GamblingProtection Case
description: MORRISTOWN, June 2A Morris County Court jury will resume deliberations today in the trial of the chief of detectives of Paterson and a Passaic County detective who are accused of accepting bribes to protect a gambling operation.

title: BRAZIL IS SEEKING A HIGH BIRTH RATE
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 29Brazilians are deeply divided over population policy, but the prevailing view appears to be that there is power in numbers.

title: Gulf Oil Cuts Prices Of Gas for Retailers
description: The Gulf Oll Corporation said over the weekend it was reducing its gasoline price to retailers by 1.3 cents per gallon for regular and premium, and 2 cents per gallon for nolead.

title: '49ers, Richer and Grayer, Revisit Harvard Business School
description: BOSTON, June 2  The 49ers came back East this weekend to see how much gold they had found in the hills of business. Twentyfive years ago they set out, not with pickaxes but with tools of management from the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration and plenty of capitalistic ambition to amass wealth and power.

title: KISSINGER THANKS TOP SYRIAN GUARD
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 30Adnan Barnieh, an officer in the Syrian secret police, was proudly showing his friends an autographed photograph of Henry A. Kissinger, whose life he had guarded during 13 visits here this month.

title: A Bit of Angola Learns to Live With Foes
description: CABINDA, Angola, June 1  Borders aren't what they seem in this steamy enclave of Angola, rich with petroleum offshore and timber inland.

title: Sugar Price, Now High, Is Heading Even Higher
description: When supermarket customers pay $1.29 for a fivepound bag of sugar today that cost 79 cents a year ago, they may be getting a bargain, for prices are heading even higher.

title: PALESTINIANS TIE A ROLE AT GENEVA TO THEIR RIGHTS
description: CAIRO, June 2The leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization presented a political platform today that bars participation by a Palestinian delegation in the Middle East peace conference at Geneva unless the terms of reference used at Geneva are changed to include the issue of the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people.

title: Soviet Matmen Win Again
description: LARAMIE, Wyo, June 2 (UPI)A Soviet Union junior wrestling team, making an eightstop tour of the United States, ran its wonlost record to 50 last night by winning all 10 matches against a group of Wyoming High School allstars for a 200 triumph.

title: Bridge: Von Zedtwitz and Butcher Meet in Finals of Reisinger
description: In the finals of the Reisinger knockout team championship, the most prestigious event in the New York bridge calendar, the defending champion, headed by Waldemar Von Zedtwitz of New York, played a team led by Bill Butcher of Hartford last night at the Americana Hotel.

title: TV: Solid Documentaries From CBS and P.B.S.
description: Two documentaries this evening provide separate but equal showcases for the television establishment and the video underground.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: PAKISTANI MOSLEMS RIOT AGAINST SECT
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, June (AP)  Tens of thousands of orthodox Moslems took to the streets today as rioting against an extreme Moslem sect, now in its tourth day, spread through all four provinces of Pakistan.

title: Books of The Times
description: In The Hair of Harold Roux, Thomas Williams seems to have succumbed to the anxieties and malaise that afflict so many writers in our times. Aaron Benham sits at his desk hearing the wrong voices, reads the opening of Mr. Williams's fifth novel. The human race he has been doomed to celebrate seems to be trying to prove to him that nothing is worthwhile, nothing at all. . . . And yet it is his work to seek meaning and order. On the shelf just above his desk are his five books in their various editions and translations, each full of words he has painfully arranged in order. And so he continues to write short stories, fables for his chil dren, a novel in progress called The Hair of Harold Roux. And he tries to be a helpful friendto a former student named Mark, Rasmussen who has dropped out into the drug culture, and to one of his colleagues, who, though a popular and successful classroom teacher, about to lose his position because he refuses to finish his doctoral thesis. And Mr. Williams, who in his earlier novels was wont to give us long, conventional narratives about life in his beloved fictional town of Leah, N.H., has made of Aaron Benham's fictions and acts of friendship what for him is a highly experimental novel.

title: James Beats Grant In Final, 60, 64
description: ROSLYN, L. I., June 2John James of Katonah, N. Y., who ranked as a top junior in Australia before coming to this country, won the Long Island men's tennis championship today by defeating 18yearold Mike Grant of Roslyn in the final, 60, 64, at the Tower Tennis Club.

title: Puerto Ricans Here Termed Their Own Worst Political Enemies
description: Paradoxically, it is the political volatility of the city's growing Puerto Rican population that some City Councilmen blame for the Council's small Puerto Rican membership. In those districts everyone wants to run, one Councilman explained the other day in discussing the challenge by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund to the lines for the special election this year of the 33 district Councilmen.

title: Black Creative Weekend Stresses Job Concerns
description: MONTCLAIR, June 2  A lively mixture of creative expression and career concerns marked Black Creative Weekend, an attempt by the Community Action Team of Montclair and North Essex to encourage the aspirations of young people.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BUCKLEY EXPLAINS HIS TRIP TO ALASKA
description: NEW PALTZ, N. Y., June 2Senator James L. Buckley assured a regional meeting of the National Audubon Society last night that it was Eskimos and their lifestyle, as well as the whale hunting essential for their survival, that interested him during his recent weeklong visit to Alaska.

title: Puerto Ricans Here Termed Their Own Worst Political Enemies
description: Paradoxically, it is the political volatility of the city's growing Puerto Rican population that some City Councilmen blame for the Council's small Puerto Rican membership. In those districts everyone wants to run, one Councilman explained the other day in discussing the challenge by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund to the lines for the special election this year of the 33 district Councilmen.

title: Kaunda's Appeal on Drinking Draws Attention to Urban Problem in Africa
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, June 2President Kenneth D. Kaunda told his countrymen last November that he would quit politics unless they drank less and he said he would rather die than run a drunken nation.

title: Daley's Condition Good After Arterial Surgery
description: CHICAGO, June 2 (AP)Mayor Richard J. Daley was reported in good condition today after undergoing surgery for removal of fatty deposits in an artery on the left side of his neck.

title: Negotiators Report Progress In Drafting Golan Heights Pact
description: GENEVA, June 2Israeli and Syrian military negotiators reported that they had made considerable progress today in drafting the technical arrangements for separating their forces on the Golan Heights.

title: Debate Stirred by Plans to Change. Federal Aid for. Medical Training
description: How much should be Federal Government contribute toward the training of the nation's highest wage earners, physicians?

title: FRENCH INVADE U.S. TO SAY MERCI
description: Thirty years after Allied troops swept down upon the coast of France to help liberate the Continent from Nazi occupation, a second Operation Overlord is beginning, this time in reverse.

title: Jewish Aid Sought In Providing Blacks Jobs and Training
description: The head of the National Urban League chided elements in the Jewish community yesterday who, because of their concern over quotas, are no longer including themselves in the coalition to build a more equal society.

title: Boat Crash Kills Skipp Walther, Car Driver's Brother
description: MIAMI, June 2 (AP)George (Skipp) Walther, an unlimited hydroplane driver and brother of the car driver David (Salt) Walther, was killed at Miami Marine Stadium today when his thunderboat went out of control and flipped several times at a speed of about 150 miles an hour.

title: Lin Garber, Singer in Chorales, Makes His Solo Recital Debut
description: Most orchestral players like an occasional solo night out, so why not a choral singer? Lin Garber, who has worked with the Gregg Smith, Camerata and other major vocal ensembles, successfully took the plunge Saturday night with a debut concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Trot Trial Leaves Threat of Stigmas
description: As Mrs. Eldon Turcotte put it, It's like finding out you're not going to get the electric chairin this business, it's your life.

title: How Upstate Area Skirted Accused D. A.'s Quirks
description: WELLSVILLE, N. Y.  This is the story of an elected official who, despite increasingly erratic and bizarre behavior for nearly a year, continued unchallenged in a highly sensitive post.

title: Red Smith
description: For the first time in five years, Angel Cordero Jr. gets to watch the Belmont Stakes like the rest of us Saturday, from this side of the outside rail. He has seen recent renewals from third, sixth or second place aboard horses named My Gallant, No Le Hace and Jim French, but he neglected to signal for a left turn in the home stretch the other day, so he is walking this week.

title: No Sale, Mr. Onassis
description: NEWMARKET, N. H.I've been asked why I will not sell my farm and golf course620 acresto Olympic Refineries, Inc., which is controlled by Aristotle Onassis. Let me explain.

title: Bill of the Year
description: The House of Representatives is about to consider a bill that for the long view takes precedence over any other environmental legislation on the calendar. We refer to the landuse planning bill which the Administration's Congressional lieutenants unsuccessfully tried to smother in the Rules Committee.

title: Weak Tourism Promotion Said to Cost State Millions
description: A team of professors at Stockton State College near Atlantic City, has charged that the state government is failing to exploit New Jersey's potential as a magnet for tourists.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Three women were killed near Hopewell when their car skidded into a tractortrailer on Saturday, the state police said. The victims were identified as Linda A. Lagnaioli, 21 years old, the driver, of Florence; Rayna S. Moskovitz, 20, of Bordentown, and Linda M. Wood, 22, of Hightstown.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, June 2 (AP)  I just put the mike in my pocket, went out there and let the fans know exactly what was going on, said Tom LaSorda, third base coach of the Los Angeles Dodgers. LaSorda was hooked in on yesterday's nationally televised game between the Dodgers and Chicago Cubs so the thirdbase coach could tell the viewers what the strategy was as it developed.

title: Theater: Culture Study
description: We have a great deal of theater in black and white but not too much in yellow. The American Place Theater, and its director, Wynn Handman, have been encouraging the ChineseAmerican writer Frank Chin. Last season Mr. Chin gave us The Chickencoop Chinaman, and this season the American Place Theater is rounding off its subscription series with his latest play, The Year of the Dragon, which officially opened Saturday night.

title: MRS. FRANK W. RITCHIE
description: Mrs. Helen Bartholomew Prizer Ritchie of West Orange, N. J., and Palm Beach, Fla., who had formerly been active in metropolitan golfing circles, died Saturday at the Hospital Center of Orange.

title: Next in the Mideast: Palestinians
description: PARIS, June 2Despite the sense of triumphant diplomacy that the IsraeliSyrian troop disengagement pact has evoked, both sides at Geneva are keenly aware that successes so far have been easy, compared with the problems ahead. That is not to say that the mood is pessimistic, because events in the Middle East in the last six months have created the belief that change is no longer impossible.

title: Officer and Assailant Die
description: PERRY, S. C., Jude 2 (UPI)  An unarmed policeman, L. C. Williamson, 34 years old, was shot and killed early today after a highspeed chase. His assailant, March Lightsel. 65, was killed seconds later by another patrolman, Tommy Williams, 35.

title: Dance: Stars and Stripes
description: The New York City Ballet is a curiously arranged organization. It certainly puts the adventure back in theatergoingyou go never knowing precisely what you are going to see. Whereas most ballet companies put out their casting some three months ahead, the City Ballet seems to experience difficulty in keeping just one week ahead. Then, although every company suffers from injuries, it rarely finds it necessary to change programs. Alternative castings and understudies are maintained to cover just such contingencies. But the City Ballet is usually willing to change a program at the drop of a dancer. After all, what do audience care?

title: Riders Applaud L.I.R.R. Improvements
description: For the Long Island Rail Road it has been a long haul back from Teeteringonthe Brink. Most of its 221,000 daily riders now seem agreed that the improvement since the state took over the bankrupt operation in 1966 has been worthy of a salute in double highballs in the bar car.

title: About New York
description: They were people of hard common sense, mixed in with visionaries and polemicists, and a few cranks, too. They were all members of the American branch of Amnesty International, and they came together in the McAlpin Hotel on West 34th Street the other day for a national conference.

title: Diego Rivera's Widow Dies
description: MEXICO CITY, June 2 (AP) Emma Hurtado Rivera, widow of the muralist Diego Rivera, died here today of cancer. She was 66 years old. Mrs. Rivera was the last of the artist's three wives, having been married to him in 1956, the year before his death. A former journalist, she established the tourist magazine This Week in Mexico.

description: WASHINGTON, June 2  A selfportrait of the financial status of members of Congress from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut today revealed that their net worths varied from the $22,761 reported by Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat of the Bronx, to the $4.1million reported by Representative Ogden R. Reid, Democrat of Westchester.

title: Curran to Permit Nadjari To Query Leuci Prompty
description: United States Attorney Paul J. Curran said yesterday that he would soon permit the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, to question Detective Robert Leuci, the policecorruption witness who was the focus of a custody fight between the two prosecutors last month.

title: Bradshaw Signs, Rejests Offer by Stars of W.F.L.
description: PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP) Terry Bradshaw said today he had spurned a substantial offer from the New York Stars of the World Football League and signed a multiyear contract with the Pittsburgh Steelers of the National Football League.

title: Bhutan King, 18, Crowned Amid Pageantry
description: THIMBU, Bhutan, June 2The King of Bhutan, Jigme Singhi Wangchuk, was crowned today in a ceremony that sought to merge the traditions of Buddhism with the awakening of this remote Himalayan; nation.

title: Pomeranian Picked Best At Memphis
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 2The smallest dog in the ring tonight won what was believed to be the biggest cash award in 100 years of dog shows. He was Ch. Randy's Jolly Wee Peppi, a four pound orange Pomeranian, owned by Mrs. Randall Frech of Kenesaw, Ga., and handled by Mrs. Houston Clark.

title: Watershed Group Marks 25th Year With a Party
description: PENNINGTON, June 2Eli, a sixfootlong blacksnake, was, the star attraction today as the Stony BrookMillstone Watersheds Association marked its 25th anniversary.

title: RACISM SHUNNED BY BLACK MAYORS
description: SANTEE, S.C., June 2No permanent enemies. No permanent friends. Just permanent needs.

title: 6 Governors Urge President to Give Up All Evidence to Impeachment Committee
description: SEATTLE, June 2Six Governors four Democrats and two Republicansagreed today that President Nixon should turn over all the tapes and documents that the House Judiciary Committee has asked for in its impeachment inquiry.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Behind the Scenes at U.S. Industries, Inc., Officials Wage an Intense Courtroom Battle
description: An intense court battle is raging between the management of U.S. Industries, Inc., giant conglomerate with headquarters in Manhattan, and some of its dissident former executives from the Midwest.

title: Tennis Crown to Colgate
description: ROCHESTER, June 2 (AP) Colgate piled up 42 points today to win the team title in the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis tournament, its first crown in 52 years of competition. Penn State, with 32 points, finished as runnerup.

title: Quebec Bus Plunge Kitts 13
description: ST. PAUL, Quebec, June 2 (AP)  Thirteen persons were killed and 31 injured when a bus went out of control and plunged into a ravine yesterday, the police reported.

title: Democrat Favored to Win House Seat in San Francisco Area in Special Election Tuesday
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 1With muted Republican opposition and little fanfare, John L. Burton, a Democratic State Assemblyman, is preparing to claim the Congressional seat of retiring Representative William S. Maillard, a Republican, in a special election Tuesday.

title: One Good Break Deserves Another
description: Once there was a little boy named Big Mac who would not eat pizza or peanut butter: or Happy Birthday cake.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: D.I.D. In a series of Monday evening gettogethers, the New York chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences is providing an opportunity for you to fraternize with some video luminaries. Tonight, for example, if two hours of evening news is not enough, you can meet Carl Stokes, Earl Ubell and Marjorie Margolies, all from WNBC, at the academy's first Dropin Dinner.

title: 10,000 Scouts Show Skills At a Weekend in Suffolk
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., June 2More than 10,000 Boy and Girl Scouts gathered here this weekend to reaffirm their faith in the traditional tenets of Scouting and to demonstrate their growing involvement in community service.

title: ARABS MAINTAIN DUTCH EMBARGO
description: CAIRO, June 2  The Arab oil producers maintained today their embargo on the. Netherlands at the insistence of Saudi Arabia. They set up a special fund for Arab countries without oil to offset deficits resulting from higher oil payments.

description: FACT, the First American Congress of Theater, began a fourday summit conference, in Princeton, N. J., yesterday to discuss the common artistic and economic concerns of the commercial and institutional theater.

description: A statistical study of municipal water supplies in 94 American cities has linked a corrosive factor in drinking water to fatal heart attacks.

title: Their Children Often Play Music Before They're 5
description: Since it is not uncommon for highranking pianists and violinists to have thoughts like these about their life's workand for them to remember the arduous beginnings in childhood, when they had very little to say about itwhat are they supposed to do when their own children begin to show musical talent almost as soon as they are out of the cradle?

title: Vacationers Expected To Stay Close to Home
description: In Yellowstone National Park, rangers expect fewer people to stay longer.

description: WASHINGTON, June 2The notice board in the lobby of the SheratonCarlton Hotel could just as easily have read: Chandelier Room: William E. Who?

title: Troop Talks in Vienna Inching Ahead
description: VIENNA, June 2 Negotiations here on reductions of troops in Central Europe are moving ahead slowly, with current emphasis on which of the NATO and Warsaw Pact countries involved will make the initial cutbacks, an American spokesman said this weekend.

PrudentialGrace to Shift From Newark to Brooklyn
description: A major steamship company, PrudentialGrace lines, will transfer its $15millionayear cargo operation from Port Newark to the new Northeast Marine Terminal on the Brooklyn waterfront.

description: At 56, Jacob Lawrence finds it no longer the novelty it once was to succeed as a black artist.

title: MRS. DAVID LIPSKY
description: Mrs. Ruth Aronson Lipsky, a psychologist with the Bureau of Child Guidance of the Board of Education for 14 years and the wife of David Lipsky, theatrical publicity man, died Saturday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 62 years old and lived at 251 West $9th Street.

title: How the Teams Stand Today
description: Monday, June 3, 1974

title: Horses & Equipment
description: REGISTERED QUARTER HORSES: SELLING AA Stallions, broodmares with foals, yearlings, gelding. Carry the bloodlines of The Haymaker AAA, Bold Lightening AAA, Depth Charge, Zantanon, Phone evenings 6075472263.

title: Jamaica Adamant on Bauxite Tax Plan
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica,Prime Minister Michael Manley has reiterated that there is no possibility that the Government will reopen the question of its planned tax on bauxite production.

title: W. W. KATZENBACH
description: W. Whittredge Katzenbach, who retired in 1958 as treasurer and vice president of Katzenbach & Warren, Inc., wallpapers, died yesterday at his home in Westport, Mass. He was 66 years old and formerly lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 22yearold inmate at the Brooklyn House of Detention was found dead, hanging from an upper bunk by a bedsheet, early yesterday, the Corrections Department reported. He left a suicide note, the department said, and had a history of 28 arrests on charges ranging from larceny to burglary and possession of drugs and dangerous weapons. His records showed no history of his being an addict, the department said, although he had a history of convulsive disorders for several years and was under treatment at the time of his incarceration.

title: Not a Total Role Change Accompanied by Fanfare, but a Quiet Sharing of Chores
description: The man who stays home while his wife goes out to work is still exceptional, but the one who pitches in and helps is not. It is being done quietly, with no fanfare, and it's changing the habits of the American family. The housewifeasdrudge image is disappearing as fewer men expect to he waited on and more contribute to the daily chores.

title: Redman, in Lola, Wins Formula 5000 Race
description: LEXINGTON, Ohio, June 2 (AP)Brian Redman of England charged past Mario Andretti midway through the race today and won the $58,000 MidOhio Formula 5000 auto road race. It was Redman's fifth straight victory in the series over two seasons.

title: CLOTHING WORKERS TO START PICKETING
description: Federal mediators kept in touch with both sides by telephone yesterday but failed to halt the strike begun Saturday by 110,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America against 750 manufacturers of men's and boy's clothing across the country.

title: GreekAmericans and Cosmos Triumph
description: The New York GreekAmericans defeated Croatan of Chicago, 20, yesterday to capture the United States Challenge Cup, the most coveted prize in semipro and amateur soccer, for the fourth time.

title: Coloradan Takes 20Kilometer Walk
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., June 2Jerry Brown of Longmont, Colo., the runnerup last year, captured the national Amateur Athletic Union 20kilometer (12.43 miles) racewalking championship today at Eisenhower Park. Brown, a 29yearold accountant, representing the Colorado Track Club, braved heavy rain to cover the course in 1 hour 33 minutes 33.4 seconds. The victory qualified him for the United StatesSoviet Union meet next month. Dave Romansky of New Jersey's Shore Athletic Club finished second, but was disqualified for running.

title: Courageous Is Winner In Regatta
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 2Courageous beat Mariner and Valiant today on Long Island Sound in a race among three of the 12Meter sloops that are candidates to become the defender of the America's Cup in September. The fourth candidate, Intrepid, was not in the area and did not participate in the workouts that were held conjunction with the New York Yacht Club's 120th annual regatta. A fleet of 66 raced off Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

title: Boat Crash Kills Skipp Walther, Car Driver's Brother
description: MIAMI, June 2 (AP)George (Skipp) Walther, an unlimited hydroplane driver and brother of the car driver, David (Salt) Walther, was killed at Miami Marine Stadium today when his thunderboat went out of control and flipped several times at a speed of about 150 miles an hour.

title: GOLDIN FORESEES 87MILLION DEFICIT IN NAME'S BUDGET
description: City Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that Mayor Beame's proposed $11.1billion expense budget would be $87million in the red.

title: Talks With Mozambique Rebels to Begin
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania June 2, (Reuters)Frelimo, the Mozambique Liberation Front, announced today that it planned to discuss a takeover of power in the territory in talks with the Portuguese opening in Lusaka, Zambia, tomorrow.

title: California Grape Grower Seeks to Enjoin Pickets
description: INDIO, Calif., May 31The air on the desert floor of Coachella Valley is so bloated with heat by noon that it gives a melted look to the mountains that rise above the date palm oasis called Indio.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following Is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: 2 Tornadoes in Carolina
description: ATLANTIC BEACH, N.C., June 2 (AP)Two tornadoes struck eastern North Carolina over the weekend and accornpanying rough seas and high winds sent a 441foot liberty ship into a pier at Atlantic Beach.. No injuries were reported.

title: Menne Wins Kemper Golf In a Playoff With Heard
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 2 Run, rabbit, run! Whoever heard of a rabbit winning a designated tournament?

title: 50,000 HERE TO TAKE READING TEST AGAIN
description: About 50,000 pupils, chosen at random in all of the city's 32 community school districts, will be retested for reading ability today and tomorrow because of irregularities found in some schools after the annual reading test in April.

title: GunCarrying Doctors
description: As I waited to renew my handgun permit at the New York City license bureau recently, I noticed that the police officer who paged applicants to step forward seemed to address about one in every six as Doctor.

title: CHARLES WINSTON
description: Charles Winston, vice president of Winston Network, Inc transit advertising, died yesterday in New Orleans, where he lived. His age was 65.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: PREMIERES IN DANCE FOR SCHOOL CONCERT
description: This year's dance concert by the High School of Performing Arts on Saturday nightusing the auditorium of another school (the High School of Art and Design, 1075 Second Avenue)carried the interest of commissioned works created by professional choreographers and dancers.

title: Ford Likens His Zigzag on Tapes to Football Tactic
description: WASHINGTON, June 2To those critics who have suggested that he openly zigs and zags on such important issues as the release of taped White House conversations, Vice President Ford is fond of saying:

title: Facing the Oil Threat
description: Members of the international oil cartelthe Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countriesare concerned about the way world inflation is cutting into the real increase in income they achieved by quadrupling crude oil prices. That enormous increase itself exacerbated world inflation; if the oil producers now tried to catch up by raising their prices still higher, they would only make the inflationary spiral spin faster.

title: Nearby Yacht Results
description: AT PORT WASHINGTON Y.C.

title: Playwright Pinero Seized After Words With a BMT Agent
description: Miguel Pinero, the playwright and former convict whose drama Short Eyes won the New York Drama Critics's Award as the best American play of the 197374 season, was arrested early yesterday by transit policemen and charged with harassment of a tokenbooth agent and possession of a marijuana cigarette.

title: EXPORT SUBSIDIES STIRRING CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON, June 2The next trade war will be war of export subsidies.

title: TERRY BAND PLAYS ELLINGTON CONCERT
description: The Duke Ellington Society, which has presented a concert of Ellington music once each year since 1961, entered the postEllington era yesterday afternoon at the New School, 66 West 12th Street, by turning over its 14th annual concert to Clark Terry's 18piece hand. Mr. Terry, one of Mr. Ellington's featured trumpeters in the nineteenfifties, had the assistance of Dizzy Gillespie, who sat in with the trumpet section, and Betty Roche, who sang with the Ellington band in the forties.

title: Man, 83, Is Slain in Room; Had Survived Hotel Collapse
description: An 83yearold man was found beaten and stabbed to death yesterday in his room at the Martinique Hotel, where he had moved following the collapse last August of the old Broadway Central Hotel.

title: Troy Vows Crackdown On Queens Insurgents
description: In an effort to restore strict party discipline, which has often been racked by intraparty primaries in Queens, the Democratic executive committee today intends to redesignate, with one exception, all Queens Democrats now in the House of Representatives, State Senate, State Assembly and City Council.

title: Y.M.Y.W.H.A.Tenants Strike Over Rent Rises
description: A $5 weekly rent increase has touched off a rent strike at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Asiociation for the first time since it began providing cultural activities and lowcost dormitory rooms for students and aspiring professionals a century ago.

title: Tennis Crown to Colgate
description: ROCHESTER, June 2 (AP) Colgate piled up 42 points today to win the team title in the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis tournament, its first crown in 52 years of competition. Penn State, with 32 points, finished as runnerup.

title: New Legislative District Lines for Two Boroughs
ACUPUNCTURE BILL URGED IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, June 2Dr. Edward H. Albano, the state's Chief Medical Examiner, says that proposed legislation authorizing the practice of acupuncture in New Jersey by qualified and certified specialists would prevent exploitation of patients by an unregulated racket.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Victory
description: Mrs. Indira Gandhi, India's perpetually embattled Prime Minister, scored an impressive victory last week with the collapse of a twentyday crippling rail strike.

title: WALDIESAYS NIXON USED ETHNIC SLUR
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI)  Representative Jerome R. Waldie, Democrat of California, said today that he heard President Nixon make an ethnic slur on a White House tape recording that is in the possession of the House Judiciary Committee.

title: F.A.O. Sees Developing Lands In FoodImport Crisis by 1981
description: ROME, June 2Developing countries will face shortages of grain by 1985 that they probably will not to be able to afford to meet through imports if present trends in population growth and demand continue, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations reported today.

title: Perry Breaks No Rules as He Takes 9th
description: Everything appears to be breaking well for Gaylord Perry. Some day he may even be considered a lawabiding baseball citizen and his greaseball throwing antics will be left for the library shelves where his book, Me and the Spitball, sits.

title: Coloradoan Takes 20Kilometer Walk
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., June 2Jerry Brown of Longmont, Colo., the runnerup last year, captured the national Amateur Athletic Union 20kilometer (12.43 miles) racewalking championship, today at Eisenhower Park. Brown, a 29yearold accountant, representing the Colorado Track Club, braved heavy rain to cover the course in 1 hour 33 minutes 33.4 seconds. The victory qualified him for the United StatesSoviet Union meet next month. Dave Romansky of New Jersey's Shore Athletic Club finished second, but was disqualified for running.

title: Vacationers Expected To Stay Close to Home
description: In Yellowstone National Park, rangers expect fewer people to stay longer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York State Senate Select Committee on Crime chastised the Queens Criminal Court's Bar Association for exonerating Supreme Court Justice Albert H. Bosch in his handling of two cases that the committee is investigating.

title: Marathon Runner Misjudges Finish, Loses by 6 Feet
Miyamoto Golf Winner
description: KAWANISH, Japan, June 2 (AP)Shozo Miyamoto of Japan shot a finalround 73, one over par, and won the $107,142 Sports Shinko International open golf tournament today for his first tournament victory in six years. Miyamoto won the first prize of $21,428 with a 72hole total of 289.
