title: State Senate Panel Assails Bar Group For Clearing Justice Bosch in 2 Cases
description: The State Senate Select Committee on Crime chastised the Queens Criminal Court's Bar Association yesterday for exonerating Supreme Court Justice Albert H. Bosch in his handling of two cases that the committee is investigating.

title: Major Bills in Congress
description: June 3, 1974

title: Bhutan Crowns 18YearOld King Amid Pageantry
Events Today
description: Music

title: ARKANSAS BLACKS EXPECTED TO GAIN
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June Blacks can be expected to continue the steady gains of recent years under the administration of the next apparent Governor of Arkansas, David H. Pryor.

title: Blast Toll Cut as British Villagers Return
description: LONDON, June 2  About 3,000 persons began moving back to their Lincolnshire villages tonight, hoping that their comes had escaped damage from the blaze that followed yesterday's explosion of a themical plant at Flixborough.

title: Puerto Means March to Tivas! in Rain
description: Steady rain dampened banners but not enthusiasm for the annual Puerto Rican Day parade here yesterday.

title: Mets Are Rained Out
description: Rain forced the postponement yesterday of the Mets' game against the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium. Before the Mets suffered their seventh washout of the National League season, the teams had divided the first contests of a scheduled threegame weekend series.

title: MINORITIES' ROLE IN BUILDING IS LOW
description: WASHINGTON, June 2Herbert Hill, director of labor for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, in a new study has condemned as failures federallyfunded training programs designed to put minority workers in construction jobs.

title: Citizens Budget Panel $65,258 in Red in '73
description: The Citizens Budget Commission appeared yesterday not to be under the same budgetbalancing strictures as the city government it scrutinizes.

title: Soviet Said to Have Played Crucial Role In Mediating 1973 Vietnam Peace Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 Moscow and Peking played mediating roles in helping Washington reach the 1973 Vietnam settlement with Hanoi, according to an article in the current issue of Foreign Policy magazine.

title: Chris Evert Wins Final; Smith Loses
description: ROME, June 2 (AP)Chris Evert won her first major international tennis tournament today by defeating Martina Navratilova of Czechoslovakia, 63, 63, in the women's singles final of the Italian open.

title: FINANCE MINISTER NAMED BY RABIN
description: TEL AVIV, June 2Premierdesignate Yitzhak Rabin night finally recruited a finance minister for his new government and was all set to request a parliamentary vote confidence in Jerusalem tomorrow.

title: Cost Overruns on Weapons; $26Billion, Proxmire Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged today that the Pentagon was experiencing outrageous cost overruns on 55 major weapons systems.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, June 2Thirteen became the Princeton University tennis team's lucky number when it beat Harvard to win its first astern Intercollegiate Tennis Association title in four years.

title: Antique Fire Engines Parade and Compete in Newark
description: NEWARK, June 2To the scream of sirens and the clang of bells, 16 brilliantly painted and lovingly restored antique fire engines, pumpers, hose carts and other firefighting apparatus paraded around Washington Park today.

title: WILLIAM MAGER
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 2 (AP)William, Mager of Norwalk, state commander of the American Legion, died yesterday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital after having suffered a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

title: Bhutan Crowns 18 YearOld King Amid Pageantry
HUGH OPPENHEIMER, ARMY TV EXPERT
description: Col. Hugh C. Oppenheimer, U.S.A., retired, professor of communications at La Guardia Community College, who helped introduce television for Army training, died Saturday of cancer at his home, 12 North Drive, Malba, Queens. He was 53 years old.

title: Arlene Popkin, Navy Physician Have Nuptials
description: Miss Arlene Popkin, who will receive an LL.B. degree this month from the New York University School of Law, and Lieut. Stephen E. Hirschberg, Medical Corps, U.S.N., who has just completed a residency in internal medicine at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, were married yesterday afternoon in Great Neck, L.I., at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Milton Popkin. Rabbi Marc Liebhaber of Minneapolis performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter also of the late Mr. Popkin. Her husband's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Morris Hirschberg, also of Great Neck.

title: Advertising: Federal Regulation
description: A multitude of advertising persons (about 300) discovered here on Friday that Senator Frank E. Moss does not like Federal regulatory agencies any better than they do. But his reasons are different.

title: Katherine Litz and Al Carmines Hit It Off
description: With They All Came Home Save One Because She Never Left, with music composed and performed by the Rev. Al Carmines, Katherine Litz has created an entertairling dancetheater piece. The new sevenpart work and Territory another premiere, as well as three older pieces, made up the program. The Katherine Litz Dance Company performed it Friday night at the American Theater Lib, 219 West 19 Street.

title: PALESTINIANS TIE A ROLE AT GENEVA TO THEIR RIGHTS
description: CAIRO, June 2The leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization presented a political platform today that bars participation by a Palestinian delegation in the Middle East peace conference at Geneva unless the terms of reference used at Geneva are changed to include the issue of the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people.

title: Lindner Duo Wins In Paddle Tennis
description: Ken Lindner and Jeff Lerner of Brooklyn defeated Mike Wooden and Chuck Fonarow, of Santa Monica, Calif., 46, 75, 64, to win the annual national paddle tennis doubles tournament here yesterday.

title: SIR ARNOLD LUNN, SLALOM INVENTOR
description: LONDON, June 2 (Reuters)Sir Arnold Lunn, the ski expert who invented the slalom, died today at the age of 86.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Stanley Van Ness, who recently added the post of New Jersey public advocate to his portfolio as public defender, thinks the state will be able to save money by relying on inhouse instead of outside counsel to represent consumer interests in utility cases.

title: The Next Telephone Operator's Voice You Hear May Be a Man's
description: Anyone who picked up telephone five years ago and dialed the operator had one chance out of 100,000 of hearing a male voice. Today the chances are one out of 20.

title: SCHEDULE HEAVY IN BOND MARKETS
description: The creditmarket schedule this week includes $655million in new corporate offering; $445million in new taxexempt bond offerings; and $500milion of new taxexempt note offerings, according to Salomon Brothers estimates Moreover, according to estimate compiled by The Daily Bond Buyer, the forward taxexempt calendar now stands at $1.6billion in new longterm state and municipal bonds to be marketed in June.

title: The Film Festival: A World Phenomenon
description: There are festivals of animated films, of comedy films, of sports films. There are festivals devoted to short subjects, to films on mountainclimbing, to films that celebrate human values. About the only kind of festival there isn't is a festival that celebrates inhuman values, though there are several that give exclusive attention to horror movies and science fiction.

title: MOTHER, 18, HELD IN INFANT'S DEATH
description: An 18yearold Brooklyn woman was charged with the murder of her infant son last night after admitting to the police that she had punched the child in the chest earlier in the day as punishment for his slowness in learning to walk.

title: Fire in Firehouse Is No False Alarm
description: MOSCOW, June 3 The citizens of Sukhumi, a pleasant resort city on the balmy coast of the Black Sea, have found their civic confidence as well as their homes jeopardized by the recent antics of their local fire department.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Colin Webster Watson was quite distressed when he lost the handcarved Maori greenstone Tiki he habitually wore. I felt my ancestors had deserted me, he recalled. However, the New Zealandborn sculptor had soon made himself a substitute in sterling silver. My gods had come back to me, he said.

title: Clothing Union Spends Its First Workday on Strike in 53 Years
description: About 110,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America abandoned their sewing machines and cutting tables yesterday, the first work day since their nationwide walkout began last Saturday.

title: Burglars Get 100 Fur Coats
description: Over the weekend, burglars in Brooklyn stole approkimately 100 fur coats being prepared for storage at the Eagle Fur Storage Company, 28 Cadman Plaza West, near the Brooklyn Bridge. The police estimated that the value of the coats, including minks, belonging to women customers, totaled $75,000.

title: Two of Three Speak At Ad Federation Talks
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 Three speakers were scheduled for the opening of the general session of the American Advertising Federation meeting here this morning. But there were only two. No. 3, Senator Lowell P. Weicker, showed up, but left.

title: KINNEY CORP ADDS TO URIS HOLDINGS
description: The National Kinney Corporation, one of the nation's largest building and real estate maintenance companies, announced yesterday that it had almost completed its acquisition of all outstanding stock and warrants of the Uris Building Corporation and that Uris stockholders would meet June 24 to consider merging Uris into Kinney as a subsidiary. The announcement stated that Kinney acquired approximately 45 per cent of the common shares of Uris in May, bringing its total common holdings in the construction company to 98.8 per cent. Kinney also owns 95 per of warrants.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ROBERT WINSTON, NAVY PILOT IN WAR
description: Capt. Robert A. Winston, a Navy flier in World War II who wrote several books, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 66 years old and lived on Long. Ridge Road in Bedford, N. Y.

title: N.H.L. Renews TV Pact
description: With no guarantee that it would cover the deciding game of the Stanley Cup championship, the National Broadcasting Company agreed yesterday to televise National Hockey League games again next season.

title: GOVERNORS NEAR A HEALTH DEBATE
description: SEATTLE, June 3Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the Nixon Administration and the American Medical Association brought their threeway battle over national health insurance before the National Governors' Conference today.

title: Political Rents
description: City and state politicians seem to be competing in irresponsibility in the political manipulaton of New York City rent control.

title: Hundreds of Scarlet Tanagers Die in New England Cold Spell
description: BOSTON, June 3Hundreds, perhaps thousands, of scarlet tanagers have perished in reIcent days as a cold spell in northern New England blocked their spring migration.

title: Cordaro Appeals His 7Day Suspension
description: Angel Cordero, the star Puerto Rican jockey who has been suspended for seven days for a riding violation last Thursday, appealed the sentence yesterday.

title: MOSCOW TENSION OVER JEWS RISING
description: MOSCOW, June 3Tensions between the Soviet authorities and Jewish activists have begun to mount a bit with the approach of President Nixon's scheduled visit to the Soviet Union later this month.

title: Trade With China Surges Ahead of U.S.Soviet Level
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  Trade between the United States and China, led by heavy Chinese imports of farm products, surged ahead of SovieAmerican trade in the first third of 1974 and is expected to reach $1.25billion by the end of the year. first third of 1974 and is expected to reach $1.25billion by the end of the year.

title: BRITAIN WILL KEEP TROOPS IN ULSTER
description: LONDON, June 3 (AP)The British Government said today it would not withdraw its army from Northern Ireland, warning retreat would bring a largescale bloodbath between Protestants and Roman Catholics in the province.

title: MRS. LOEL ACKER, 41, OF EDUCATION GROUP
description: Mrs. Loel Kaiser Acker, division head of special projects for the Institute of International Education, died yesterday in the New London (Conn.) Convalescent Hospital of pneumonia, following a heart attack four months ago. She was 41 years old and lived at 450 East 63d Street.

title: Brooklyn Youth, 15, Places No. 1 in Math Olympiad
description: A 15yearold junior at Stuyvesant High School, one of the youngest students to compete, scored highest in the country on last month's Mathematical Olympiad, a fiveproblem test of mathematical reasoning and ingenuity.

title: Giscard Brings a More Relaxed Style to the Presidency
description: PARIS, June 3In his first week in office, President Valry Giscard d'Estaing has acted to demystify the presidency, set France on a more liberal course and consolidate his power by moving friends into key positions.

title: Vasquez Wins Bout
description: David Vasquez of New York rallied in the late rounds to score a unanimous 10round decision of Benny Rodriguez of Los Angeles last night at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum. Vasquez weighed 117 pounds, half pound heavier than Rodriguez.

title: Soviet Writer, Though Critical, Is Favored
description: FRUNZE, U.S.S.R.  Chingiz Aitmatov is an unusual Communist, Many dissident Soviet intellectuals sing his praises, yet he is also toasted by Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Mets Defeated by Reds, 52, In the War of Roses Rematch
30Year Service to End
description: Representative John J. Rooney of Brooklyn, the ailing senior member of the New York State Congressional delegation, invoked the last hurrah of his 30year tenure in the House yesterday by disclosing his decision not to seek reelection this year.

title: New Prosecutor of I.T.T. Faces Complicated Issues
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 Richard J. Davis has his work cut out for him if he is to live up to the advance billing and pledge of the special Watergate prosecutor, ?? Jaworski. Last week, Mr. Jaworski named Mr. Davis the new head of the force investigating the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation case.

title: Market Place: Stock Strategy At Fields, Grant
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.In January of 1973, the investment advisory firm of Fields, Grant & Company here decided to act on its judgment that the stock market was going to fall precipitously in the months ahead. The firm sold all its clients' equity shares and began putting the money into fixedinterest securities, primarily commercial paper.

title: People and Business
description: Despite the current improvement in the availability of petroleum, the energy crisis can be expected to last practically indefinitely, according to Thornton F. Bradshaw, president of the Atlantic Richfield Corporation.

title: Expansion Tops Heavy N.F.L. Slate
description: Will it be Memphis? Or Seattle? Or all three?

title: Coast Judge Killed in Explosion Alter Package Is Given to Him
description: PASCO, Wash., June 3 (AP)A Superior Court judge was killed today when a small package delivered to his chambers exploded, two of his colleagues said.

title: Ballet: Feld's Tzaddik
description: This is clearly the year for Hasidic dance in American classic ballet. A couple of weeks ago we had Jerome Robbins's Dybbuk for the New York City Ballet, and then, on Sunday night, the Eliot Feld Ballet gave the world premiere of Tzaddik at the Newman Theater of the New York Shakespeare's Public Theater complex on Lafayette Place.

title: Suit on Convention Center Asks AirPollution Report
description: A lawsuit was filed in State Supreme Court yesterday, calling upon the city's Environmental Protection Administration and its administrator, Robert A. Low, to make public an analysis of the effect upon air quality of the proposed West Side convention center.

title: Leaders Predict a Light Vote in the Primaries Today
description: TRENTON, June 3Political leaders from both major parties today predicted an extremely low turnout in tomorrow's Congressional primary elections in New Jersey.

title: Books of The Times
description: MAMA DOESN'T LIVE HERE ANYMORE. By Judy Sullivan. 243 pages. Arthur Fields Books. $6.95. Men have been walking out on their families for centuries. You might say it started with the Crusades. Now that women have a crusade, they are starting to walk out too. At least that's what Judy Sullivan says in Manta Doesn't Live Here Anymore. Her husband was a successful professor, on his way to becoming a dean or president of a college. Mrs. Sullivan taught art, and generally left her husband and 11yearold daughter in the summers to study or work on projects in other cities. She loved them both, she insists, but after 14 years she couldn't live with them any more. I can't take care of anyone else, was the way she expressed it, when she announced that she was leaving, not for the summer, but for good.

title: Finley's A's Fly High, but on What Course?
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 3 The Oakland A's, winners of the World Series the last two years and currently carrying the best record in the American League, are 134,624 behind last year in home attendance. Even San Diego and Texas, baseball's two weakest situations the last two years, are drawing more than the A's with their starstudded roster.

title: Face of Jazz Is Changing Visibly
description: In times gone by, jazz was somberlooking black men wearing berets and blaring out more or less comprehensible improvisations in dim, smoky clubs. Serious contemporary new music, during that same notsodistant period, was shorthaired white people peering industriously through their spectacles at densely notated pages of music, making genteely complex music in genteelly academic environments.

title: Track Restores Drivers
description: The seven harness drivers acquitted last Saturday of fixing races got temporary licenses yesterday from the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: PRATER IS GIVEN LIFE IN YABLONSKI DEATHS
description: ERIE, Pa., June 3 (UPI) William J. Prater, a former organizer for the United Miner Workers, was sentenced today to three concurrent terms of life imprisonment for the 1969 slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter.

title: Stars Sign Gladieux
description: OAKDALE, L. I., June 3 (AP)Bob Gladieux, a former Notre Dame star and National Football League back, signal with the New York Stars today. He played for the New England Patriots and Buffalo Bills from 196972, but was inactive last season.

title: DRAMA CONGRESS CONFRONTS CRISIS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 3All theater is in a constant state of crisis, said producer Alexander Cohen today in the opening speech of the first plenary session of FACT, the First American Congress of Theater. We all work under the sword of Damocles. It's about time we wprked under a common shield.

title: Amtrak Will Get 6 French Turbotrains In Order for $110Million Equipment
description: Amtrak, the nationwide passenger rail system, was given approval by the Department of Transportation yesterday to order more than $110million worth of new equipment, including six Frenchbuilt turbotrains.

title: JAPANESE TO OPEN VITAL VOTE DRIVE
description: TOKYO, June 3  The Japanese Parliament closed its seslion quietly today and members leaded for their home districts for what is expected to be a lively political campaign ending in a critical election July 7.

title: HIGH COURT REFUSES VESCO & CO. REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)  The Supreme Court declined today to review a lower court order blocking disposal of the assets of a company controlled by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier.

title: Santarelli Is Said to Quit As Law Agency's Chief
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 Donald E. Santarelli has submitted his resignation as the head of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, Justice Department sources said today.

title: Interior Official Is Opposed to Delay on His Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 3An Interior Department hearing officer renewed today a dispute over whether a coal mine water impoundment at Wharton, W. Va., was an immanent danger to residents of the mountain valley below.

title: Dutch Horseman Is Victor
description: WIESBADEN, Germany June 3 (UPI)  Arno Nessen of the Netherlands won the closing day event of the Wiesbaden international horse show today in a jumpoff with John Heims, a fellow countryman. Robert Ridland and William Brown, of the United States finished third and fourth respectively.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CORN, SOYBEANS AND WHEAT FALL
description: Better weather over large areas of the Middle West caused a decline in the price of futures in corn, soybeans and wheat yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Scotland and Wales Edge Closer to Some Home Rule
description: LONDON, June 3The British. Government moved ahead today with plans to provide some form of limited selfgovernment for Scotland and Wales to meet rising demands of nationalist groups in both regions.

title: Big Board Considers 4 P.M. Market Closing
description: The New York Stock Exchange board is considering extending the market close by a half hour to 4 P.M., a spokesman for the exchange reported, yesterday.

title: Supertanker
description: Uncontrolled technology is the gravest menace to the future of people and the survival of a habitable planet. The nuclear arms race is the most hideous example the danger of technology careening out of man's control.

title: First National of Chicago Cats Level to 11.60% as Steady Advance Eases
description: The First National Bank of Chicago announced yesterday that its corporate base rate, which has been at 11.75 per cent, would be lowered to 11.60 per cent, effective today. A smaller bank, the Southwest Bank of St. Louis, announced a reduction in its prime lending rate from 11 per cent to 11 per cent. These two reductions in the rate commercial banks charge their largest corporate borrowers mark the first downturn in this rate since March of this year when it began its climb from 8 cent.

title: Butz Hints Nixon Backers In Congress Get Priority
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that he found himself playing pretty closely with those Congressmen who support President Nixon against impeachment.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 4, 1974

title: PaddlingCase Figure Lost a Job Over Other Charges of Beatings
description: William E. Green, the acting principal of a Bronx school where students were allegedly beaten to discipline them, was once dropped from a teaching job in a Brooklyn school after some parents had complained that he had struck their children, according to the former principal of the Brooklyn school.

title: A SUSPICIOUS BLAZE BURNS ARAB OFFICE
description: A suspicious fire yesterday damaged the offices of the Action Committee on AmericanArab Relations at 4 East 43d Street.

title: SAUDI ARABIA ASKS ENERGY DIALOGUE
Manhattan D.A. Race Bears Imprint of Past
description: The past is casting a long shadow on the contest for the Democratic nomination for District Attorney of New York County.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: 5 Camden Policemen Accused Of Beating and Shooting Blacks
description: CAMDEN, June 3 (UPI) Five Camden patrolmen were indicted today on charges of shooting or pistolwhipping blacks while doing police work.

title: Fonda's Clarence Darrow Coming to NBCTV Sept. 4
description: Henry Fonda's widely praised Clarence in Clarence Darrow, a oneman stage play by David W. Rintels, will be presented on television this summer as a 90minute prime time special. NBCTV has scheduled the show for Sept. 4 with the International Business Machines Corporation as sponsor.

title: Hurdle Record Tied
description: PARIS, June 3 (AP)Guy Drut of France equaled the European record for the 110meter hurdles of 13.2 seconds today at the French University championships.

title: 98 Foes of Uruguayan Regime Seized in Argentine Police Raid
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 3The Argentine police arrested 98 Uruguayan political exiles last night while they were meeting to organize a protest demonstration against the militarycontrolled government in Uruguay.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS EQUAL PAY SCALES FOR BOTH SEXES
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Supreme Court upheld today for the first time the 10year. old Congressional mandate that employers pay women equal wages for equal work.

title: COLSON PLEADS GUILTY TO CHARGE IN ELLSBERG CASE AND IS EXPECTED TO AID JAWORSKI AND RODINO PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 Charles W. Colson, formerly one of President Nixon's closest aides, pleaded guilty today to a charge that he attempted to obstruct justice and influence the trial of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

title: DEFAULT RISE FEARED ON STUDENTS' LOANS
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt warned yesterday of increasing defaults on stateguaranteed student loans for college and other higher education, estimating a potential loss of $88million to $129million, or 12 to 18 per cent, on loans outstanding last year.

title: KNESSET ENDORSES RABIN AS PREMIER
description: JERUSALEM, June 3Yitzhak Rabin succeeded Mrs. Golda Meir as Premier of Israel today and said his Government was prepared to negotiate peace with Arab countries, beginning with Egypt, but would not enter into talks with the Palestinian guerrillas.

title: 3 Revivak Close Exuberant Season By Ailey Dancers
description: Alvin Ailey has a sense of history and a sense of humor. It makes, him an unusual artistic director and his company's dances both thoughtprovoking and entertaining. The company closed an exuberant spring season Sunday evening at the City Center 55th Street Theater with three historical revivals and two pieces from repertory.

title: VOLVO PROFITS FALL AS SALES CLIMB 11%
description: A. B. Volvo of Sweden reported yesterday its first quarterly earnings decline in four years despite record sales in the first quarter. Net income for the period came to $46.7million, or $1.77 a share, down from $60.9million, or $2.33 a share, a year ago.

title: PLEDGE TO ISRAELIS IS CONFIRMED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (Reuters)The State Department acknowledged today that the United States had agreed to support Israel in efforts to prevent guerrilla incursions from Syrian territory.

title: FRANKLIN IS SUED OVER AN ACCOUNT
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 3Suffolk County is suing the Franklin National Bank to recover $7,000 that it says the bank owes it from a welfare account that was discontinued more than a year ago.

title: LOCKHEED CHANGE AT TOP PLANNED
description: The directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and Textron, Inc., tentatively approved yesterday a top  level management switch at Lockheed as part of a sweeping financial overhaul of the deeply troubled aerospace manufacturer.

title: Rough ExNixon Aide Charles Wendell Colson
description: In President Nixon's old inner circle, Charles Wendell Colson stood out for his capacity to inspire passionate distasteand enjoy it.

title: Mooney Quits as Coach
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., June 3 (AP)Jim Mooney, a former major league pitcher, has retired as baseball coach at East Tennessee State University. He pitched in the majors for the New York Giants in 193132 and the St. Louis Cardinals in 193334.

title: CALLEY LOSES PLEA FOR MY LAI REPORT
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., (UPI) June 3  A Federal judge refused today, to order the release of a classifid report on the My Lai massacre but directed the Army to produce the complete record of former Fist Lieut. William L. Calley's courtmartial.

title: Jury Acquits an Officer Of Perjury in S.I. Graft
description: A Staten Island police sergeant has been acquitted of a perjury charge brought by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state anticorruption prosecutor.

title: Reforming the Street
description: These days of distressingly low market averages and trading volume might not seem the psychological moment to press the nation's securities industry into longawaited structural reform. Under opposite circumstances, however, the sameargument could be cited by the holders of privilege in the Wall Street establishment: If the averages were soaring and the brokers thriving, why tamper with a good thing?

title: Westchester Intensifies Fight on Welfare Cheats
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 3. (AP)The Westchester County Board of Legislators voted unanimously today to authorize the hiring of four lawyers to work full time on. eliminating welfare cheats from the county's social services rolls.

title: Children's TV Premiums Illegal, F.T.C. Head Says
PROMISE TO HANOI IS DENIED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The State Department denied today that the United States had made secret commitments to North Vietnam as part of the Vietnam settlement.

title: Chess: The Prepared Variation Mailed Fist in an Old Glove
description: The greatest fear of the players on the tournament circuit is that they will run into an opponents prepared variation that puts them out of business without a chance to make a real, fight of it.

title: Man Is Shot Dead After Holding Two
description: An armed man died and a pedestrian was wounded yesterday in a bizarre happening in a sixthfloor apartment at 261 West 21st Street in which a man and woman had been held hostage before the police arrived.

title: NO. AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: CLIFFORD H. KEEP
description: Clifford H. Keep, a lawyer and retired attache of Kings County Court, died Saturday at his home in Jamaica, Queens. His age was 91.

title: Moody's Withdraws Key U.S.I. Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service, which rates the creditworthiness of the nation's corporations, yesterday withdrew a key rating from U.S. Industries, Inc., making it more difficult for the giant conglomerate to sell its shortterm commercial paper.

title: Molloy Keeps Title In Baseball by 121
description: Archbishop Molloy High School successfully completed defense of its Catholic High Schools Athletic Association baseball championship yesterday by overpowering Monsignor McClancy, 121, in the final game at St. John's University.

title: Giants' 440 Man Caught In Dispute
description: If he had it to do over again, Larry Jones said yesterday he would not have signed his New York Giants pro football contract and taken his bonus money until he had finished his career as an amateur quartermiler this spring.

title: POWER ON BUDGET ASKED IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 Staffs of SenateHouse conferees have drafted what is expected to be the final version of legislation to overhaul drastically the way Congress considers the Federal budget and decides where the money is to be spent.

title: Dave Anderson
description: OAKDALE, L. I., June 3Under a bright sun on a grassy plain next to the water and sea gulls of Great South Bay, the inaugural drops of perspiration by the New York Stars were slipping on to the practice field.

title: Rodriguez Acclaimed
description: Ellie Rodriguez, California Angels catcher, was named the American League player of the week yesterday. He hit .526 during the week, including two home runs last Friday night.

title: Brooklyn Youth, 15, Places No. 1 in Math Olympiad
description: A 15yearold junior at Stuyvesant High School, one of the youngest students to compete, scored highest in the country on last month's Mathematical Olympiad, a fiveproblem test of mathematical reasoning and ingenuity.

title: Textron Chief: Sink or Swim, He Swam
description: George William Miller, 49 years old, a former Wall Street lawyer who took a risky jump into corporate management 18 years ago, may soon add to his present job as chairman of Textron, Inc., the unenviable job of chairman and chief executive of the troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Giants' 440 Man Caught In Dispute
description: If he had it to do over again, Larry Jones said yesterday he would not have signed his New York Giants pro football contract and taken his bonus money until he had finished his career as an amateur quartermiler this spring.

title: DANIEL BAKER JR., THROAT SPECIALIST
description: Dr. Daniel C. Baker Jr., a specialist in diseases of the larynx and presidentelect of the American Laryngological Association, died Sunday of heart ailment at his home, 232 County Road, Demarest, N. J. He was 65 years old.

title: State Gets Experts to Put Value on Con Edison Units
description: The state's Power Authority retained independent outside experts yesterday to help determine the value of two Consolidated Edison plants it may buy under a new state law.

title: Banks Stir a Crisis Over Food Stamps In Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 3 (UPI)Welfare recipients were taken by car to a city 18 miles away today to get foodstamp vouchers because four banks here had refused to handle the stamps or had limited their participation in the program.

title: Notes on People
description: The Society for the Family of Man Award presented by the Council of Churches of New York City will be awarded Oct. 31 to President William R. Tolbert Jr. of Liberia.

title: The 2 Leaders Who Cast Union's New Militancy
description: A new wind of social innovation and aggressive leadership is blowing through the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, a union long noted for its harmonious collectivebargaining relationships.

title: Chinese Team to Tour U.S.
description: HONG KONG, June 3 (Reuters)A chinese team in martial arts left Peking today for a tour to the United States and Mexico, Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency reported.

title: Bowa's Running Helps Phils Top Braves, Gain First
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (UPI)  Larry Bowa stole third, then raced home with the lead run on Del Unser's squeeze bunt in an eighthinning surge that carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 52 victory over the Atlanta Braves, tonight.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 27year old Woodbridge woman who helped extinguish a fire on a couch in her apartment died in a predawn blaze yesterday that apparently began again later in. the couch. The police identified her as Mary Anne Minkewicz, who shared the firstfloor apartment at 270 Smith Street with a friend, Susan Conti. Miss Conti had left the apartment after the first fire, which began at about 2 A.M., the police said.

title: U.S. Approves CoOps At Forest Hills Project
description: After more than a year of uncertainty, the Nixon Administration has granted approval for converting the controversial Forest Hills lowincome housing project to a cooperative, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.

title: LowCost Eximbank Loans To Soviet Hit by Jackson
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 3 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington attacked today lowinterest loans being made by the Government's ExportImport Bank to the Soviet Union and to Iran and said he was drafting legislation that would give Congress a veto over the bank's transactions.

title: Dow Index Up 19.09Oil Issues Are Strong I.B.M. Adds 6
description: Wall Street's recent elusive dream  a reduction in the prime rate by a major bankcame true yesterday and the stock market responded by posting its best advance in almost three months.

title: Dutch Horseman Is Victor
description: WIESBADEN, Germany June 3 (UPI)  Arno Nessen of the Netherlands won the closing day event of the Wiesbaden International horse show today in a jumpoff with John Helms, a fellow countryman. Robert Ridland and William Brdwn, of the United States finished third and fourth respectively.

title: POWER ON BUDGET ASKED IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Staffs of SenateHouse conferees have drafted what is expected to be the final version of legislation to overhaul drastically the way Congress considers the Federal budget and decides where the money is to be spent.

title: Exploring the Latin Mentality
description: For all who are completely lost in the legal squirrel cage of Watergate, here is a concise guide that will clarify everything:

title: Bon Vivant to Let U.S. Destroy Food Stocks
description: NEWARK, June 3  The Bon Vivant Soup Company has agreed to let the United States Government destroy 1.5 million cans of Bon Vivant soup and other foodstuffs, after fighting against the action for three years. The value of the foodstuffs was estimated at $600,000.

title: Pressures on Shopping Centers
description: With more than half of the country's retail business already being done in some 14,000 shopping centers and with many more suburban than urban stores being built, the future would appear to be bright for those who build, operate or conduct their businesses in shopping centers.

title: KNESSET ENDORSES RABIN AS PREMIER
description: JERUSALEM, June 3Yitzhak Rabin succeeded Mrs. Golda Meir as Premier of Israel today and said his Government was prepared to negotiate peace with Arab countries, beginning with Egypt, but would not enter into talks with the Palestinian guerrillas.

title: Bridge: Von Zedtwitz Team Wins The Reisinger Title Again
description: The team headed by Waldemar Von Zedtwitz of New York retained its Reisinger Knockout Team title here Sunday. Teammates of the 77yearold veteran, who first won this prestigious title in 1937, were Tobias Stone and Philip Feldesman, also of New York, Ira Rubin of Paramus, N. J.; Kyle Larsen of San Francisco, and Barbara Brier of Miami.

title: Advertising: F.T. C. on Children
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Every year when the Americin Advertising Federation has its public affairs conference here the current chairman of the Federal Trade Commission is a luncheon speaker. Usually he doesn't have all that much to say. Today Lewis A. Engman did, and it was toughtough on advertisers to children.

title: Canadians Battling Ice to Plan Gas Pipeline From the Arctic
description: MONTREALIn a bleak frozen wilderness 600 miles beyond the Arctic Circle, a team of Canadian scientists is measuring ice floes and charting polar bear tracks in what could turn out to be one of the world's most ambitious pipeline projects.

title: OFFICER TESTIFIES ON KILLING BOY, 10
description: Police Officer Thomas J. Shea, testifying yesterday at his trial in the murder of 10yearold Clifford Glover, said that he had fired at the fleeing victim's back as the boy made a reaching motion and then raised his hand and I saw what I believed to be a revolver in it.

title: Governor Signs Bills Expanding State Consumer Board's Power
description: ALBANY, June 3Two bills one of them requiring that the state's Consumer Protection Board be notified of proposed rate increases and service charges by utilities, and the other permitting the board to intervene in such proceedings before the Public Service Commission, have been signed into law, Governor Wilson's office announced today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 4, 1974

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, June 2  the winningest baseball coach Bergen County high school sports history has dismissed the 1974 season as just one of those things. Joe Cervino's Teaneck Highwaymen finished under 500only the fourth time that has happened in his 22 years as coach.

title: U.S.Greek Ties: Athens Tries to Show It Is No One's Client
description: ATHENS, June 3Press reports here last week said that Greece was buying millions of dollars' worth of arms from France, and the news seemed to symbolize the deterioration of GreekAmerican relations.

title: West Side Highway Ramp Closed Because of a Hole
description: The northbound entrance ramp of the West Side Highway at 46th Street was closed last evening, shortly after the discovery of a hole in what was described as badly undermined pavement.

title: Lepers Sad but Hopeful in Giving Up Children for U.S. Adoption
description: OHJON, South Korea Chin Wu Bum broke off from the construction gang he had been helping out and walked up the dirt road to his small cinderblock house to get his two daughters.

title: Residents Doubtful That Impoundment Will Give Way
description: WHARTON, W. Va., June 3 The people in this little coalmining town nestled in the valley of the Little Coal River in the green hills of West Virginia are not easily frightened by the threat of disaster, natural or otherwise.

title: New Federal Rule to Limit Beef Sausage Fat Amount
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI)  A Federal regulation limiting the amount of fat in prodcuts eligible to carry the name beef sausage will be put into effect July 29, three and a half years after it was originally announced, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: LOCKHEED CHANGE AT TOP PLANNED
description: The directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and Textron, Inc., tentatively approved yesterday a top  level management switch at Lockheed as part of a sweeping financial overhaul of the deeply troubled aerospace manufacturer.

title: Roundup of Clubs in Metropolitan Area
description: Here is a guide to some country music clubs in the metropolitan area prepared with the help of Shorey Warren, the Eastern King of Western Swing, John Newman of radio station WHN and Jim Hilbert of the Long Island Country Museum Association. Bluegrass is not included. There are no cover or minimum charges except where noted.

title: POLITICAL REFORM ON COAST BALLOT
description: LOS ANGELES, June 3 Californians will vote on a stringent political reform act by referendum in tomorrow's primary election, with the out come uncertain.

title: Butz Hints Nixon Backers In Congress Get Priority
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that he found himself playing pretty closely with those Congressmen who support President Nixon against impeachment.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: ROGER DODGE DIES; A CHOREOGRAPHER
description: Roger Pryor Dodge, dancer and choreographer who translated jazz dances into ballet format, died Sunday in the New York Infirmary. He was 76 years old and lived at 25 Fifth Avenue.

title: Motor Vehicles Agency Under Nadjari Inquiry
description: The special state anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, has for the last year been investigating possible illegal actions by former high officials in the State Motor Vehicles Department, court papers disclosed yesterday.

title: A Miracle Coming to an End
description: MADRIDEven through the heavily shuttered windows of Spain, the roar of automobiles arouses a traveler before his early morning wakeup call. Along the broad, treelined avenues of Madrid, around its beautiful fountains and plazas, moves some of the heaviest traffic in the world. Every Spaniard seems to have his Seat or his Renault or his Simca, and most of them seem to be trying to move down tile Cane de Serrano or the Paseo de Castellana at the same time.

title: 30Year Service to. End By ROBERT D. McFADDEN
description: Representative John J. Rooney of Brooklyn, the ailing senior member of the New York State Congressional delegation, invoked the last hurrah of his 30year tenure in the House yesterday by disclosing his decision not to seek reelection this year.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Tuesday, ??

title: Badillo and Beame in a Bitter Exchange Over Federal Funds at Budget Hearing
description: In a bitter exchange at a budget hearing at City Hall yesterday, Representative Herman Badillo of the Bronx accused Mayor Beame of illegally using Federal revenuesharing funds, and the Mayor retorted by reading the law in an effort to show he had acted legally.

title: Jersey Energy Report
description: Governor Byrne's Task Force on Energy yesterday recommended new measures to control the use of energy in New Jersey, including a graduated increase in automobile  registration fees, an extra sales tax on electrical appliances and higher tolls for cars with only one occupant. Page 41.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: The second season of New York Philharmonic Rug Concerts opens next Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, with Pierre Boulez conducing a BrahmsDebussyBartok program. As before, seats will be removed from the hall's orchestra level and the floor will be, covered with rugs on which part of the audience will sit.

title: Colson Is First in Nixon Circle To Admit Guilt in Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Charles W. Colson became today the only member of President Nixon's inner circle of four former domestic and political advisers to have pleaded guilty and to have agreed to work with the prosecutors in the Watergate scandals.

title: 4 Tour Golfers Lose Open Bids
description: Gay Brewer, Ben Crenshaw, Miller Barber and George Archer were among the more prominent pro tour golfers who failed to qualify yesterday at the Charlotte (N. C.) Country Club for the United States Open.

title: LAWYERS SEE STUDY OF OIL UNITS NEEDED
description: FLINT, Mich., June 3A special investigative body representing the nation's 5,000 prosecuting attorneys reported here today that it was satisfied that the major oil companies were pursuing anticompetitive practices and tactics.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: REGISTERED QUARTER HORSES: SELLING AA Stallions, broodmares with foals, yearlings, gelding. Carry the bloodlines of The Haymaker AAA, Bold Lightening AAA, Depth Charge, Zantanon, Phone evenings 6075472263.

title: FIRST NIXON STOP IS SEEN AS EGYPT
description: CAIRO, June 3President Nixon will arive in Egypt on June 12 and visit Alexandria and Cairo for two days of talks with President Anwar elSadat and for some sightseeing, informed sources said here today. An official announcement of the visit is expected to be made public in Washington and Cairo tomorrow.

title: MRS. EDWARD H. SMITH
description: Mrs. Sarah Lowell Gifford Smith, former owner of. HuntingSmith, a silverchest manufacturing concern of Westfield, N. J., founded by her late husband, Edward Hunting Smith, died Friday at the Medicentel in Red Bank, N. J. She was 71 years old and lived at 657 Hill. side Avenue, Westfield.

title: Industry Output Of Autos Declined 22% Last Month
description: DETROIT, June 3American auto plants built 729,857 cars last month, down 210,556 units, or 22 per cent, from the 940,413 cars built in May, 1973.

title: City Pays Record Interest, 7%, on Anticipation Notes
description: The city paid the highest interest rate in its history for revenueanticipation and taxanticipation notes yesterday 7.019 per cent on a total borrowing of $431.8million.

title: Summary of Various Actions Taken by the U.S. Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Honored Guests Shun Rally for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The National Citizens' Committee for Fairness to the Presidency is holding a citizens' Congress in support of President Nixon next Sunday, but most of the invited honored guests, including Vice President Ford, are not coming.

title: Damascus Weighs the Benefits And Drawbacks of a Nixon Visit
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 3Syria is weighing the political consequences of the possible visit of President Nixon to this country.

title: AMEX CHAIRMAN BACKS FIXED FEES
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The chairman of the American Stock Exchange said today that elimination of uniform commission rates for floor brokerage would leave more than 1,000 maturing public companies without a secondary market for raising and allocating needed capital.

title: QUEENS DEMOCRATS BACK MOST IN OFFICE
description: The Democratic executive committee of Queens last night redesignated all Democratic incumbents from the borough except Councilman Arthur J. Katzman.

title: Vesco Accused of a Plot In Purchase of Jetliner
description: NEWARK, June 3  The receiver for the bankrupt Fairfield General Corporation, once owned by the fugitive financier Robert Vesco, charged today that Mr. Vesco had misled a Federal Court in New York by plotting with others to buy a Boeing 707 jetliner under false pretenses.

title: Text of Colson Statement After Guilty Plea on Obstruction of Justice
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Following is the text of a statement today by Charles W. Colson, former White House counsel, after he pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice in the Ellsberg breakin case:

title: 5 Camden Police Indicted For 2 Assaults on Blacks
description: CAMDEN, June 3 (UPI)Five Camden patrolmen were indicted today on charges of shooting or pistolwhipping blacks while doing police work.

title: Panel's Decision Against Open Hearings Reportedly Linked to Jaworski Position
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The House Judiciary Committee's decision last week to put off public, televised hearings for the time being was influenced by Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, according to committee members and officials.

title: TWO MORE INDICTED BY BALTIMORE JURY
description: BALTIMORE, June 3The special Federal grand jury that investigated Spiro T. Agnew and his successor as Baltimore County Executive handed ups two final indictments and one criminal information today, the final day in its 19month term.

title: Chase Investors Shows Asset Drop Of About 2.7Billion
description: The Chase Investors Management Corporation disclosed yesterday that in the year and half since it has been in business, assets under management have declined about $2.7billion.

title: Track Restores Drivers
description: The seven harness drivers acquitted last Saturday of fixing races got temporary licenses yesterday from the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Senator Shies From Nixon
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits announced his candidacy for a fourth term yesterday, emphasizing his independence of President Nixon and castigating the moral and systemic decadence that has led us to the disgrace and tragedy of Watergate.

title: Stock Prices Climb
description: A reduction in the prime rate by a major bank helped send the DowJones industrial average up 19.09 points to 821.26, its biggest daily advance in almost three months. The cut in the rate to 11.60 per cent was instituted by the First National Bank of Chicago. Details on Page 47.

title: Mooney Quits as Coach
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., June 3 (AP)Jim Mooney, a former major league pitcher, has retired as baseball coach at East Tennessee State University. He pitched in the majors for the New York Giants in 193132 and the St. Louis Cardinals in 193334.

title: The History Of Impeachment
description: Does the Constitution authorize impeachment of a President only for conduct constituting an offense punishable by the criminal law? The press has been full of conflicting answers in briefs and articles by the lawyers for the President, lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee and legal academics. The confusion that has resulted is not warranted by either the history or policy of impeachment.

title: Country Music Here Growing Apace
description: EAST PATCHOGUE, L.I., When the guitars throb and the lead singer gets to wailing Your Cheatin Heart, the scene could be any one of a thousand midAmerican towns where country music flourishes.

title: FRAUD SUSPECTED IN COAL DUST CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Justice Department said today that officials of the Consolidation Coal Company, the nation's second largest coal producer, were under criminal investigation for possible fraud in falsifying coal dust data de signed to protect miners from pneumoconiosis, an occupational disease often called black lung.

title: Dodge Estate Lawyers Share $497,500
description: MORRISTOWN, June 3 Five law firms that participated in the settlement of the $85million estate of Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge will share almost half a million dollars in lawyer fees under a ruling issued today by Judge Robert Muir Jr. in Superior Court.

title: Borg Upsets Nastase for Italian Title
description: ROME, June 3 (AP)Bjorn Borg Sweden's 17yearold star, won the $16,000 top prize in the men's singles at the Italian open today, surprisingly overwhelming topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 63, 64, 62.

title: THOMAS J. MURPHY
description: ROCHESTER, June 3 (AP)Thomas J. Murphy, a retired Rochester newsman who had held many posts in the Newspaper Guild, died today at the age of 70.

title: 8 States Holding Primaries Today
description: The year's biggest flurry of primary elections involves eight states today with voters choosing nominees to succeed retiring Governors in California and New Mexico and a United States Senator in Iowa.

title: SAWHILL DOUBTS ELECTRICITY LACK
description: The nation may well be fret of either blackouts or brown outs of electricity this summer John C. Sawhill, administrator of the Federal Energy Office indicated here yesterday.

title: Judge Backs Nixon On Claim by Hoffa For Data on Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)  A Federal judge upheld today President Nixon's claim of executive privilege and quashed a subpoena for documents relating to the conditional clemency granted to James R. Hoffa.

title: HANOI MEN IN LAOS BEYOND DEADLINE
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Tuesday, June 4The deadline for the withdrawal of foreign troops from Laos passed today with a considerable number of North Vietnamese soldiers reported still in the country.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS TRADING GAINS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter Market rose yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A suspended narcotics detective was convicted of selling heroin and cocaine that he helped seize in a West Side police raid four years ago. On its fourth day of deliberations, a Federal jury in Manhattan found the suspended detective, Joseph Novoa, 32 years old, of 1738 33d Street, Brooklyn, guilty on all eight counts. A codefendant identified only as Demetrios Papadakis, 30, was found guilty one count of selling narcotics.

title: Contract Awards
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that its international division had agreed to supply tire technology and engineering for a large tire plant in Turkey. Neither the value of the deal nor the site of the project were disclosed.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Paddling out of a cove on the lower end of New York State's Croton River with a friend a few weeks ago spied what I thought was a clump of the aquatic plants known as arrowhead.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Innovative College, at 4, Granted Accreditation
description: Hampshire College, founded four years ago as a center of educational innovation in Amherst, Mass., has been granted full accreditation by the New England Association of Schools and Colleges.

title: U.N. Paner on Mozambique Hears Atrocity Allegations
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 3 (Reuters)  A United Nations special commission was told today that Portuguese troops killed or wounded nearly 200 civilians in northern Mozambique in atrocities from 1965 to 1973.

title: RICHARDSON TROUPE DANCES TALE OF JOB
description: Larry Richardson is a likable and often arresting dancer. His company of nine is welltrained and equally agreeable. On Sunday evening their very agreeableness was a quality shared by Mr. Richardson's new piece, Kin. But since the work is a retelling of the story of Job, this soft edge detracts from the emphasis of the scenario.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 3 (AP)Johns Hopkins's newly crowned national champions, never higher than second during the regular season, have finished as the No. 1ranked major college lacrosse team of 1974.

title: REP. REID BREAK WITH PARTY HEADS
description: Only two years a Democrat himself, Representative Ogden R. Reid broke with party leaders yesterday and charged that they were trying to control the Democratic gubernatorial nomination and were more concerned about winning the Democratic primary than the general election.

title: Chile Permits 72 To Leave Embassy For Mexican Exile
description: MEXICO CITY, June 3 Seventy  two Chileans who had spent almost nine months in asylum in the Mexican Embassy in Santiago flew here last night after the Mexican Government had won safeconduct for them.

title: Treasury Bills Rose At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Yields on threemonth and sixmonth United States Treasury bills rose today in the Government's weekly competitive sale of these shortterm securities.

title: Trojan Force
description: There has to be an end to these intraparty bloodbaths, decrees City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Democratic overlord of Queens. To insure strict party regularity free of primary challenges in this year's elections, Mr. Troy has a formula that would seem mild any LatinAmerican dictatorship. We will try to kill anyone who wants to fight the party's designees, he says. It will be a vendetta to the death . . .

title: $1,000 Bid for Pillars Costing City $840,000
description: For two years now, the city has been eager to unload $840,000 worth of concrete support columns bought when the Board of Higher Education was planning a new 13acre campus for the Bronx Community College. The campus was to be built on a platform over the subway yards near Bedford Park Boulevard in the Bronx.

title: Children's TV Premiums Illegal, F. T. C. Head Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission said today that television advertising of premiums to children violated Federal law and that television advertising aimed at selling dangerous drugs and toys to children was not properly regulated. children was not properly regulated.

title: Two Cougars' Officials Move to Rockets
description: Carl Scheer and Larry Brown, who combined as general manager and coach respectively, to develop the Carolina Cougars into one of the most successful teams in the American Basketball Association, moved yesterday into similar jobs with the Denver Rockets. They had been given permission to seek other jobs by Tedd Munchak, the Carolina owner, who does not plan to operate the franchise next season.

title: Trade With China Surges Ahead of U.S.Soviet Level
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  Trade between the United States and China, led by heavy Chinese imports of farm products, surged ahead of SovietAmerican trade in the first third of 1974 and is ex pected to reach $1.25billion by the end of the year.

title: EVICTION OF ADDICTS IS UPHELD BY COURT
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court here yesterday refused to stay the eviction of residents in Encounter, Inc., a drugfree program for addicts at 35 East 68th Street, a facility many residents in the area have opposed. The judges gave no reason for their ruling. Encounter's lawyer was Maurice Reichman.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION SHOWS 2.1% CLIMB
description: Production of steel in the week ended June 1 totaled 2,901,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was gain of 2.1 per cent over the 2,840,000 tons poured during the preceding week, and pushed the index of production to 118.9 from 116.4.

title: Siderowf Gains in British Golf
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 3 (AP)Dick Siderowf of Westport, Conn., battled through galeforce winds today and moved into the second round of the British Amateur with a 5and3 victory over Ireland's Perry Malone.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: FILMS Parly because the United States is rich enough and technologically and visually oriented, more and more persons have acquired skills and equipment and gone out to make filmswe used to call them documentariesabout life as it is today and, with imagination and creativity, to show life in the past.

title: $4.5MILLION OFFER MADE IN HOE SUITS
description: Two former executives of R. Hoe & Co., Inc., the bankrupt printing press manufacturer, and the concern's former auditors, Lybrand, Ross Bros. & Montgomery, have offered to settle suits brought against them for $4.5million, plus interest accruing from March and April of last year.

title: HANOI MEN IN LAOS BEYOND DEADLINE
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Tuesday, June 4The deadline for the withdrawal of foreign troops] from Laos passed today with a considerable number of North. Vietnamese soldiers reported still in the country.

title: Expansion Tops Heavy N.F.L. Slate
description: Will it be Memphis? Or Seattle? Or all three?

title: Roxy Music Returns With Style That Overshadows First Visit
description: New York's rock Anglophiles were out in force Sunday night. They didn't quite manage to fill the Academy of Music for Boxy Musicwhich had a recent No. 1 album in Britainliut they managed to greet Boxy with rapture.

title: Simon Ottinger Dead at 89; CoFounder of U.S. Plywood
description: Simon Ottinger, who with his late cousin, Lawrence Ottinger, began the United States Plywood Corporation in 1937, died Sunday at his home, 912 Fifth Avenue. He was 89 years old.

title: A Crumbling Venice Still Waits for Help
description: VENICE, Italy  An arm dropped off a statue on the north facade of St. Mark's Basilica recently when touched only lightly by a photographer standing on a scaffold.

title: REGIONAL RAIL ACT ASSAILED IN COURT
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (UPI) The constitutionality of the fivemonthold Regional Rail Reorganization Act was challenged today before a threejudge Federal court by some creditors and stockholders of the Penn Central Railroad. The act was designed to revamp the Penn Central and six other bankrupt lines in the Northeast and the Middle West into one profitable system.

title: Aging Wine in No Time at All
description: Waiter, take back this wine and age it some more. I wanted a 1945 and this tastes like a 1961. Sounds silly, of course, but not if a new machine shown here last week becomes successful. It is supposed to age wine (or beer or whisky or perfume) by subjecting it to powerful light waves.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Elliott Sullivan, Actor of Stage And the Screen, Is Dead at 66
description: Elliott Sullivan, an actor who appeared in many stage and screen productions, but most dramatically in defying the House UnAmerican Activities Committee in 1955, died Sunday on a visit to Los Angeles. He was 66 years old and had been living in London for the last 11 years.

title: Senator Shies From Nixon
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits an nounced his candidacy for 4 fourth term yesterday, empha sizing his independence o President Nixon and castigating the moral and systemic decadence that has led us to the disgrace and tragedy o Watergate.

title: Drug Company Will Underwrite Costs Of Lab at CaseWestern Medical School
description: A drug company and a medical school have become partners in an unusual arrangement that may have broad implications for the future of basis medical research in this country.

title: WILLIAM M. DOUGHERTY
description: William M. Dougherty, who retired in 1960 as secretary and a director of Uniroyal, Inc., died Friday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: Sets Notch First Home Triumph
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., June 3 Sol Berg missed it. The rotund owner of the New York Sets, who is their most avid fan, passed up a Sets match for the first time this season and missed seeing his sorry group of tennis players blossom into a hardhitting team. The Sets gave the Detroit Loves and firey Rosemary Casals a run for their money tonight before a crowd of 2,017 persons at Nassau Coliseum.

title: BON VIVANT YIELDS ON DUMPING SOUP
description: NEWARK, June 3The Bon Vivant Soup Company has agreed to let the United States Government destroy 1.5 million cans of Bon Vivant soup and other foodstuffs, after fighting for three years against the action. The value of the foodstuffs was estimated at $600,000.

title: Merger, the Real and Rumored, Is an Urgent Topic for Brokers
description: A number of brokerage houses have found themselves tilting at rumor mills in recent days and trying to resolve the delicate question if where flirting ends and courtship begins.

title: Byrne Is Given Proposals to Save Fuel, Including Auto Fees as High as $200
description: TRENTON, June 3  The Governor's Task Force on Energy today recommended series of measures to reduce and control energy supplies in New Jersey, including a graduated increase in automobileregistration fees from the present maximum of $35 to more than $200, an extra sales tax on electrical appliances and higher expressway tolls for automobiles with only one occupant.

title: Business Briefs
description: Mortgage lending fell nearly 18 per cent during April from yearago levels at New York savings banks, industry figures disclosed yesterday.

title: Maddox, in New Yankee Spot, Is Switching His Life Style, Too
description: CHICAGO, June 3Along with 11 other Yankees, Elliott Maddox sat in the clubhouse in Minnesota at a 30minute Sunday morning devotional meeting, hearing a Baptist minister tell how we have to have some kind of consistent life style, to be able to say we're Christians, to be able to say I believe in Jesus Christ.

title: Issues in Clothing Strike
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A., representing 750 manufacturers men's and boys' suits, topcoats and overcoats, and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, representing 110,000 machine operators, cutters, markers, button and pocket makers.

title: 4 Tour Golfers Lose Open Bids
description: Gay Brewer, Ben Crenshaw, Miller Barber and George Archer were among the more prominent pro tour golfers, who failed to qualify yester day at the Charlotte (N. C.) Country Club for the United States Open.

title: Impeachment Standard
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 Charles W. Colson's plea of guilty today in the White House plumbers case underscored the importance of Section 3 of Article 2 of the United States Constitution in determining the likely outcome of the House impeachmentinquiry. Tucked into that long section of the nation's guiding principles is a 10word clause erecting the standard against which the House Judiciary Committee will measure President Nixon's conduct in office. He shall take care that the laws be faithfully executed.

title: Siderowf Gains in British Golf
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 3 (AP)Dick Siderowf of Westport, Conn., battled through galeforce winds today and moved into the second round of the British Amateur with a 5and3 victory over Ireland's Perry Malone.

title: Agnew Pays $1,100 On Home Improvements
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI)The Government has agreed to accept payment of $1,100 by former Vice President Agnew for nearly $180,000 in improvements made to his Washington home at Government expense. The agreement was signed April 12 by Mr. Agnew and Arthur W. Sampson, General Services Administrator.

title: An Awesome Reliving of Auschwitz Unfolds at St. John's
description: Auschwitz heads the glossay of 20thcentury evilsymbolizing the Holocaust in which sixmillion Jews died. But the barbarism of death camps like Auschwitz also imperils the faith of survivors: How to believe in God's power and purpose with evil writ this large?

title: Impeach Nixon, U.A.W. Says
description: LOS ANGELES, June 3 (AP)About 3,000 members of the United Auto Mobile Workers, representing the nation's largest industrial union, issued a nearly unanimous call today for the impeachment of President Nixon. The international convention of the 1.4millionmember union passed the resolution with only a few hands raised in opposition. No exact count was taken.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS EQUAL PAY SCALES FOR BOTH SEXES
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Supreme Court upheld today for the first time the 10yearold Congressional mandate that employers pay women equal wages for equal work.

title: Attendance Fluctuates For W.T.T.
description: It finally happened over the weekend.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is true that nuclear weapons and their proliferation are a threat to mankind, and India's test beneath the Rajasthan desert must be regretted. However, these dangers have existed ever since their development and use by the United States against Japan. The solution must surely lie in the elimination of all nuclear weapons by all countries. Why do the first five, who are also the permanent members of the U.N., not destroy their own nuclear arsenals? Surely it is the realization that there are inherent advantages in being nuclear powers. Is a balance of nuclear terror by five really all that stable?

title: Study in Britain Indicates Industry Confidence Low
Navy Wife of Year Named
description: WASHINGTON, June (UPI)Mrs. Frank O'Beirne Jr. of Mystic, Conn., has been named Navy Wife of the Year. Her husband is the commanding officer of the George Washington Carver.

title: House Panel Criticized By Nixon's Jesuit Aide
description: MIAMI June 3 (AP)The Rev. John J. McLaughlin, the Jesuit who is a deputy special assistant to President Nixon, said today that the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment hearings produced little but noise and a few selected leaks.

title: Israelis and Syrians Wrap Up Details of Disengagement Pact
description: GENEVA, June 3Israel and Syria said today they would sign a military accord on Wednesday on the practical arrangements for disengaging their forces.

title: House Demands More Data On the Missing in Indochina
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (Reuters)  The House approved today, by a vote of 273 to 0, a resolution opposing any consideration of foreign aid or accommodation with North Vietnam and the Vietcong until they do more to account for Americans missing in action.

title: The War on Poverty: Ten Years Later
description: The House of Representatives voted the other day to repeal the Economic Opportunity Act of 1964 and to let the Office of Economic Opportunity die next month. The Senate is likely to follow suit. The Times reported that few members... rose to mourn the end of the agency, which had been intended by President Johnson to bring total victory in the war against poverty.

title: JERSEY GETS PLAN TO SAVE ENERGY
description: TRENTON, June 3  The Governor's Task Force on Energy today recommended a series of measures to reduce and control energy supplies in New Jersey, including a graduated increase in automobileregistration fees from the present maximum of $35 to more than $200, an extra sales tax on electrical appliances and higher expressway tolls for automobiles with only one occupant.

title: Colson Guilty
description: In the first Nixon Administration, there were several insiders who had ready access to the President and who individually had knowledge of most of his political and legislative tactics. Those insiders included Jolin Mitchell, Attorney General and campaign manager, and H. R. Haldeman, John Ehrlichman and Charles Colson, three senior White House aides. All four are now under criminal indictment.

title: Homosexuals Gain Support on Campus
description: After arduous beginnings, student homosexuals have gained widespread recognition, financial backing and often the support of campus health officials at colleges and universities across the country.

title: SovietAmerican Study Of Big Cities Planned
description: A joint AmericanSoviet program to study the government of large cities this summer was announced yesterday by Columbia University.

title: Tocks I. Darn Plan Delayed By Bipartisan Opposition
description: TRENTON, June 4A surge of bipartisan opposition in Congress, Trenton and Albany appears to have ruled out a start on construction of the controversial Tocks Island Dam for at least another year.

title: Muskie Says Administration Aides Undermine Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, accused Nixon Administration officials today of undermining the revenuesharing program by failing to enforce strongly its regulations.

title: People and Business
description: Two university economists said yesterday that the Government's Wholesale Price Index grossly overstates the extent of inflation affecting the United States.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (Reuters)The House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to ease the way for transfer of assets between United States companies and their overseas affiliates by cutting down on some of the red tape. The proposal was put in the major tax reform bill the body is now considering.

title: Concert
description: At a signal from the leader, Julius Reentovich, 16 violins snap into position under 16 chins and the String Ensemble of the Bolshoi Theater is off, Moving in choreographed unanimity like so many Rock??. One is plunged again into the world of thirties musisals with their faded mixtire of popular and classical music, their hopeful appeal to brows high, low and middle.

title: 3% Vote Delights Corporate Critics
description: More resolutions, more issues, more participants, more success stories. That's how one activist in the movement to make corporations responsive to the public interest sums up the annual stockholder meeting season just ended.

title: PORTUGAL'S CHIEF.WILL VISIT AFRICA
description: LISBON, June 4Gen. Antnio de Spinola, provisional President of the new Portuguese Government, will visit Mozambique and Angola shortly, it was announced here to. day.

title: COMDR. G. S. FINDLAY
description: Comdr. Gabriel Scott Findlay, U. S. N. retired, who had been a teacher of engineering and an administrative officer in merchant marine schools, died in the Veterans Administration Hospital here Monday. He was 82 years old and lived at 23 Lexington Avenue.

title: When Half a Loaf Is Better
description: PARISIt is hard to realize that thirty years have already gone by since history's largest armada landed an Allied army in Normandy, breaching the defenses of Hitler's Fortress Europe and launching what General Eisenhower called the great crusade toward which we have striven these many months.

title: Excerpts From Tapes Report and Review of It
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Following are excerpts from the final report of the advisory panel on White House tapes appointed by the United States District Court and a review of that report done for the White House by the Stanford Research Institute. The members of the advisory panel were Richard H. Bolt, Franklin S. Cooper, James L. Flanagan, John G. McKnight, Thomas G. Stockham Jr. and Mark R. Weiss. The Stanford report was prepared by Michael H. L. Hecker, senior research engineer at the institute.

title: NIXON SOVIET TRIP A PROBLEM FOR TV
description: President Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union late this month, which is likely to receive substantial live television coverage in the United States, may overlap the single portion of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment hearings open to television cameras.

title: Gas PricePosting Readable to Drivers Is Voted by Council
description: A bill requiring the posting of footsquare gasoline price signs with numerals large enough to be read by a passing motorist was adopted yesterday by the City Council by a vote of 39 to 0.

title: Epsom Odds Are Sweet On Nonoalco
description: LONDON, June 4The man who gave the world Mars candy bars has given the 195th English Derby its favorite.

title: MISSILE DEBATE SOUGHT IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 4A move was begun in the Senate today to force a debate over whether the United States should develop larger, more accurate intercontinental missiles capable of striking at Soviet missile silos.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, JUNE 5, 1974
description: At least 10,000  perhaps as many as 20,000 people  in the Indian state of Bihar have died this year from smallpox in what has been described as one of the worst epidemics of the disease in recent years. More than 30,000 smallpox cases were reported in the last five weeks from virtually every vii. lage in Bihar, an official of the World Health Organization said in Geneva. [1:67.]

title: 11 DECLARE GUILT ON DRUG CHARGES
description: NEWARK, June 4  Eleven, men described as members of a large twostate drug ring pleaded guilty to narcotics charges in Federal District Court today. The case had been scheduled to go to trial tomorrow.

title: COAST LAND PLAN BEING EXPANDED
description: LOS ANGELES, June 4 California's experiment in regulation of land use is entering its critical second phase.

title: 3 Split on AntiSemitism Cause At Auschwitz Symposium Here
description: Is Christian theology responsible for antiSemitism, for the Holocaust and its six million Jewish victims?

title: NEWAUTO SALES OFF 23% IN MAY
description: DETROIT, June 4American newcar sales were down an estimated 23 per cent last month to 880,147 from 1,142,304 in May, 1973. But auto makers reported today some signs of improvement in the sales picture, including a resurgence in luxurycar sales and increasing demand for trucks. Canadian car sales also were high.

title: Dow Chemical Dividend Up
description: The board of directors of the Dow Chemical Company declared yesterday an increase in its quarterly dividend to 30 cents per share of common stock from 25 cents.

title: Forest Pest Bypasses Natural Defenses of the Tree It Feeds On
description: Larvae of the European pine sawfly, a common and costly forest pest, are able to eat their way to adulthood by making an end run around the natural chemical defenses of the pine trees they feed on, detailed chemical analysis has shown.

title: IMPROVED U.S. TIES EXPECTED IN SYRIA
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 4Syria expects improved relations with the United States to lead to the resumption of diplomatic relations and to economic aid, sources close to the Government said today.

title: Soviet Is Unlikely to Purchase Grain This Year
description: MOSCOW, June 4American officials said today that they did not expect a major new Soviet grain purchase from the United States this summer, despite reports of difficulties with the Soviet crop.

title: New Chairman Elected  By United Fund Here
description: The United Fund of Greater New York, the fundraising organization for 425 socialservice agencies, announced the election of a new chairman yesterday.He is Milton W. Mays, president of the Continental Corporation. Mr. Mays, who was general campaign chairman for the fund's 1973 appeal, succeeds R. Manning Brown Jr., board chairman of the New York Life Insurance Company, who held the post for the last two years.

title: India Smallpox Epidemic Fatal to at Least 10,000
description: At least 10,000and perhaps as many as 20,000people in the northeastern Indian state of Bihar have died so far this year from smallpox in what has been described as one of the worst epidemics of the viral disease in recent years.

title: 2 ARAB GUERRILLAS SEIZED BY ISRAELIS
description: TEL AVIV, June 4Security officials said today that two armed infiltrators from Lebanon had been intercepted and arrested but three others had apparently escaped back across the border.
