title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Conference on the International Sale of Goods, first committee10 A.M. and 3 P.M.Colonialism subcommittee10:30 A.M.TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.Tickets may be obtained at the public, desk, main lobby, United Nations Headquarters. Tours: 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M.

title: Mobil's Gasoline Price Raised 2 Cents a Gallon
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing the wholesale price of gasoline by 2 cents a gallon and the price of No. 2 heating oil by 1.1 cents a gallon, effective today.

title: E. F. Hutton Lifts Rate For Securities Trading
description: E. F. Hutton & Co., one of the nation's biggest brokers, and Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood, Inc., of Minneapolis, a major regional broker, said yesterday they would raise commissions by about 5 per cent on securities transactions of up to $300,000 in value.

title: About New York
description: The way it was, is still much the way it is, but neighbors change and people leave, and only the feeling of the place goes on forever. Bay Ridge in Brooklyn is still the home of the middle class and the people who fight to get into it.

title: Rule Bids State Judges Visit Jails and Prisons
description: More than 2,500 of the states judges will be required to make intermittent visits to jails, prisons, drugaddiction centers and training schools as a result of a rule adopted yesterday by the Administrative Board of the Judicial Conference.

title: WASHINGTON
description: President Nixon's mission to Moscow at the end of June has raised two new controversies in Washington: first, whether his new approach to the targeting and control of nuclear weapons is sound; and second, whether he should go to Moscow on such an important mission in his present weakened political position at home.

title: Fonda's Clarence Darrow Coming to NBCTV Sept. 4
description: Henry Fonda's widely praised performance in Clarence Darrow, a oneman stage play by David W. Rintels, will be presnted on television this summer as a 90minute prime time special. NBCTV has scheduled the show for Sept. 4 with the International Business Machines Corporation as sponsor.

title: BOSTON VOTERS PICK SCHOOL BOARD PLAN
description: BOSTON, June 4 (AP)In a ight turnout today, voters approved for consideration in the November election a proposal that would abolish the school committee and give educational policy and fiscal responsibility to the Mayor.

title: Ford, in Talk Here, Terms Kissinger Diplomatic Genius
description: Vice President Ford heaped lavish praise on Secretary of State Kissinger in a talk dealing mainly with foreign trade before an apparelindustry group here yesterday.

title: An Explanation: Nixon, I.T.T. and Milk Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The nature of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment hearings is changing this week.

title: Meany Calls Nixon Too Weak at Home For Summit Talks
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 4 George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., urged President Nixon today to call off his planned trip to the Soviet Union, asserting that the Watergate scandals had left him too weak to conduct meaningful negotiations.

title: Mrs. Fenwick Edges Out Kean in Jersey Primary
description: Mrs. Millicent Fenwick, the former director of the state Office of Consumer Protection and a former Republican Assemblyman from Somerset County, apparently won an extremely narrow victory yesterday in the Republican Congressional election in New Jersey's Fifth District.

title: Social Issues Thrive
description: The movement to make corporations responsive to the public interest was much in evidence at this year's annual stockholder meetings. Details on Page 65.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Classified pages distributed in metropolltan New York and adjacent territory.

title: FRANCIS J. SOUHAN
description: SENECA FALLS, N.Y., June 4 (AP)Francis J. Souhan, a textile manufacturer and former Assemblyman, died last night at his home. He was 66 years old.

title: Miss Aviva Wininger Wed to Jacob Wasser
description: Miss Aviva Wininger, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Harold Wininger, was married last evening to Jacob Wasser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Wasser. Both families are of Brooklyn. Rabbi Henoch Lebowitz performed the ceremony at the Terrace in the Park in Flushing, Queens.

title: How Not to Be No. 1 Without Even Trying
description: The other day there was an ad in the paper for Studs Terkel's new book, Working. One excerpt from this compilation of people's feelings about their labors was from The Executive:

title: Rabin's New Government: Control Passes Irrevocably From Generation of Founders to the NativeBorn
description: JERUSALEM, June 4  At first glance, the new Israeli Government headed by Premier Yitzhak Rabin could easily be mistaken for a reshuffled version of the outgoing Government of Mrs. Golda Meir. The policies as outlined by Mr. Rabin in his maiden speech yesterday all sound familiar and in fact 14 of the 19 ministers are carryovers from the previous Government.

title: TV: Bobbie and Beast
description: Tonight's new TV material, a scarce commodity at the height of the rerun season, includes a new series called Bobbie Gentry's Happiness Hour on CBSTV at 8 and Nourish the Beast, a play by Steve Tesich, on public television's Hollywood Television Theater at 8:30. Neither should seriously challenge the supremacy of the repeats.

title: U.S. Textile Industry Unfurls Trade Show
description: Seeking wider international recognition, the American textile industry yesterday opened the first American Fashion Textiles Exposition, Texpo 74, at the New York Coliseumamid fiber shortages, rising prices and growing financial pressures.

title: FIAT RAISES PRICES BY AVERAGE OF 13%
description: TURIN, Italy, June 4 (AP) Fiat, S.p.A., the giant Italian auto maker, announced today an average 13 per cent rise in the price of its models.

title: Bishop Mosley Quitting Union Theological Post
description: The Right Rev. J Brooke Mosley, under pressure reflected by the board of directors of Union Theological Seminary, announced yesterday his decision to resign from the presidency of the prestigious 138yearold Protestant school.

title: Liberals Assailed on Nixon
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 4 (UPI) Representative Earl Landgrebe, Republican of Indiana, charged here today that the liberals are trying to win by lynching our President. At a news conference, Mr. Landgrebe, a newly announced candidate for nomination to the Senate, said that President Nixon's success in bringing the Vietnam war to a settlement and his proposals for a stringent Federal budget alarmed the liberals.

title: Kasanof to Quit Legal Aid After 3 Years With Society
description: The Legal Aid Society said yesterday that Robert Kasanof, its acting attorney in chief for the last year, would resign June 15 to return to the private practice of law.

title: BROWN, GARDEN BID PLANNED BY G. & W.
description: Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., the widely diversified industrial company, announced yesterday it would make tender offers of $12 a share for Brown Company common stock and $6.75 a share for Madison Square Garden common stock.

title: Red Smith
description: About 100 visitors sat at little tables on the clubhouse terrace at Belmont Park yesterday, some eating pancakes, some watching the morning works, some just soaking up sunshine. There were pillars of the turf in perambulators and strollers and slightly larger handicappers riding iron horses set on stanchions in a patch lawn. Each horse had a name painted on the flankGitation, Man o War, Dark Mirage, Shuvee. Not surprisgly was in front; Nashua's tomboy daughter was always beating colts. Breakfast at Belmont is a regular weekday feature at the big gambling hell on Hempstead Turnpike, part of the New York Racing Association's campaign to keep children out of the Offtrack Betting parlors.

title: Gunmen in Ireland Kidnap English Earl and His Wife
description: DUBLIN, Wednesday, June 5 (UPI)  Three armed men broke into the estate of a prominent English racehorse owner and former member of the British Parliament early today and kidnapped him and his wife.

title: Rodino's Panel Intensifies Inquiry on ;Security Taps
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The House Judiciary Committee has quietly intensified its inquiry into 17 socalled national security wiretaps authorized by President Nixon beginning in 1969, court records showed today.

title: Mayor, 4 Councilmen Resign in State Dispute
description: FIELDSBORO, June 4 (AP) This tiny South Jersey community was virtually without a local government after the Mayor and four of six Council members resigned yesterday in a demand for more state funds to solve its sewage problems.

title: Soldiers in Angola Unsure and Bored
description: SANTA EULALIA, Angola, June 1In the coffeegrowing highlands northwest or the capital, Luanda, where the concentration of guerrilla fighters is heavier than anywhere else in Angola, uncertainty of purpose and boredom weigh down Portuguese soldiers more than acts of war.

title: Treasury Aides Approved
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) The Senate Finance Committee recommended today the confirmation of Jack F. Bennett and Edward C. Schmults as Under Secretaries of the Treasury.

title: COURT TO PERMIT POLLUTION BY ORE IN LAKE SUPERIOR
description: ST. LOUIS, June 4A threejudge Federal appeals court panel handed down today an opinion that apparently will allow the Reserve Mining Company to continue to pollute Lake Superior from its Silver Bay, Minn., plant for up to five years.

title: Esther Freilich Wed to R. J. Lowy
description: Miss Esther Rose Freilich, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Isaac B. Freilich of Far Rockaway, Queens, was married yesterday to Rudolph Jacob Lowy, vice president of the Lesny Development Corporation, a Los Angeles construction company, of which his father is founder and president.

title: Hyland Urges Stiffer Laws To Hurt Big Drug Pushers
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 4 (AP)  Attorney General William F. Hyland today called New Jersey's narcotics laws unrealistic because they did not set stiffer penalties for bigtime drug pushers than for street dealers.

title: GRUMMAN WILL GET ADVANCE FROM NAVY
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The Navy notified Congress today that it planned to provide the Grumman Aerospace Corpora tion of Bethpage, L. I., with up to $100million in advance payments to assure continued production of the F14 fighter aircraft.

title: Epsom Odds Are Sweet On Nonoalco
description: LONDON, June 4The man who gave the world Mars candy bars has given the 195th English Derby its favorite.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Bookmen Reap Profits in Adversity
description: WASHINGTON, June 4When Col. Alfred M. Worden, the command module pilot for the 1971 Appollo 15 moon mission, began to read softly from his new book of poems, the publishers in the Shoreham Hotel suite around him kept up their cocktail chatter.

title: Brooklyn Fireman Gets Award as 30 Are Honored for Heroism
description: One afternoon in January, 1973, a Brooklyn mother and her two shall children were trapped in an ovenlike atmosphere as fire raged through the apartment below them, their only escape a leap to almost certain death at the base of an interior courtyard.

title: Britain's Reserves Decline
description: LONDON, June 4 (Reuters)Britain's reserves of gold and foreign currency fell by $36million last month to $6.92 billion, the Treasury announced today, after receiving loans from abroad of $124million.

title: RailFreight Rise Seen
description: The nation's railroads were told yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission that they could raise freight rates as much as 10 per cent. The move would cost shippers an additional $1.25billion in railfreight charges in the next 12 months. Page 57.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TOKYO, June 4 (AP)  Oscar Alvarado of Houston knocked out Koichi Wajima of Japan in the 15th round tonight to capture the World Boxing Association junior middleweight boxing title. The knockout came at 1 minute 57 seconds of the Iast round as Alvarado floored Wajima for the third time in the round:

title: Eye Injury Forces Ashbee of Flyers to Retire at 34
description: It's been tough, said Barry Ashbee, an allstar defenseman for the Philadelphia Flyers in announcing his retirement yesterday following injury to his right eye from a puck shot by the New York Rangers' Dale Rolfe last April 28, in a Stanley Cup semifinal hockey playoff game. But it makes me appreciate the Stanley Cup a lot more. A lot of people work all their lives, and at 60 they haven't achieved what they were after. At 34, I achieved it, so I can't be bitter.

title: Advertising: In Self Appraisal
description: WASHINGTON, June 4When the broadcasting industry started Raymond Rubicam believed that it should be supported by a government tax on sets rather than by advertising. Despite a lifetime spent in the agency business he hasn't changed his mind much. But now his concerns are broader.

title: BLOCH AND BAGGER PERFORM SONATAS
description: There is a lot of lovely music in the 18thcentury literature fur violin and harpsichord, so in picking such a program Robert Bloch, violinist, and Louis Bagger, harpsichordist, had a lot going for them Monday night at Carnegie Recital

title: Subversive List Abolished By Order of the President
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) President Nixon has abolished the list of subversive organizations maintained by the Attorney General that was used to screen applicants for Government jobs, the White House and Justice Departments announced today.

title: GENERALS TO SIGN GOLAN DATA TODAY
description: GENEVA, June 4Israeli and Syrian army staff officers completed today the logistic and other practical arrangements for carrying out the accord signed Friday on the disengagement of forces on the Golan Heights.

title: TAX EXPERT CALLS I.R.S. INQUIRY LAX
description: WASHINGTON, June 4  A leading public interest lawyer in the tax field charged today that Congressional in restigators had set aside, without completing it, their investigation of White House interference with the operations of the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Russian Oil Profits From West Climb
description: MOSCOW, June 4  The jump in world oil prices enabled the Soviet Union last year to reap nearly a billion dollars more in oil revenue than a yearearlier, with only a modest increase in exports.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Seattle New Club In N.F.L.
description: The National Football League awarded a franchise to Seattle yesterday, bringing the total number of its teams to 28. The new teams in Tampa and Seattle will begin play in the 1976 season.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: FRANKLIN LAKES, June 4Ramapo Regional High School's tennis team, with 86 consecutive regularseason victories, captured its second straight state championship last Monday at Princeton University's Jadwin Gymnasium with a 4.1 triumph over West Essex.

title: HOWARD H. FOGEL
description: Howard H. Fogel, a freelance writer for trade magazines and former editor of the Hearing Aid Journal, died of cancer yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived at 60 West 13th Street.

title: New School Board
description: The Borough Presidents and Mayor Beame have acquitted themselves well in the selection of the new Board of Education. The retention of a strong nucleus of members who, while serving on the interim board, have been responsible for the difficult transition to school decentralization will help further to stabilize the system.

title: Britain Details Her Terms for Continuing in Common Market
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 4 Britain presented in detail today her demands for better membership terms in the European Common Market but did so in tones suggesting that she really wanted to stay in.

title: ILLNESS A PUZZLE IN RONCALLO CASE
description: The Suffolk County Police Commissioner, Eugene. R. Kelley, said yesterday that he was investigating conflicting stories about the chief Federal prosecutor's mysterious illness during the extortion trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo.

title: James Knowles Leads Seniors
description: RYE, N.Y., June 4A record field of 470 contestants from 32 states turned out for the United States Seniors' Golf Association's annual twoday tournament today.

title: Stars Look for Class in Dress and Talent
description: OAKDALE, L. I., June 4Instant class is the aim at the New York Stars' training camp, where the players bump and run over acres of eass overlooking the Great South Bay.

title: Lefkowitz to Give Plans Today on 4th Term
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, the only Attorney General millions of New Yorkers have ever known, is expected to say today that after 18 years in the job he wants another fouryear term as the state's chief law officer.

title: Penalty for Losing: Owner Shoots Horse
description: PANAMA CITY, June 4 (UPI)Victor Manuel Bustamante was banned from the Presidente Remon race track today by the National Racing Commission for shooting his horse in the nose during a fit of anger Sunday when it failed to win the 10th race. Friends said Bustamante bet a large amount of money on Pedregales.

title: ENERGY FROM SUN SEEN IN 5 YEARS
description: The head of the National Science Foundation predicted here yesterday that solar heating and cooling systems would be commercially available in five years.

title: Remember
description: There will be those who ask what purpose can served by conjuring up the demons of the Nazi death camps. Why inflict those unspeakable horrors once again on the human mind? Why let these visions of death fall particularly across the consciousness of those too young to recall that these terrible shadows were cast by actual events?

title: Mrs. Petrone Leads Eastern
description: FLORENCE, S. C., June 4 (AP)Mrds. Ralph Petrone of Blacksburg, Va., shot a 77, five ovedr par, to take the firstround lead today in the 63d annual women's Eastern Golf Association champion. ship.

title: $80,000 Gold Robbery
description: NORTH PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 4 (AP)More than $80,000 worth of goldabout 60 poundswas stolen from Lee's Manufacturing Company over the weekend, the police disclosed today. Police Chief John T. Leyden said there had been no forced entry at the twostory building.

title: Personal Loan Rate Raised by 2 Banks
description: Two leading New York banks have quietly raised their lending rates on personal loans.

title: Officials Hear Appeal By Cordero
description: Knocked out of action by a sevenday suspension, Angel Cordero Jr. appears ready to seek a court injunction that could enable him to ride Cannonade in Saturday's 106th Belmont Stakes.

title: Reds Get 3 Runs in 10th To conquer Mets by 63
description: The New York Mets and Cincinnati Reds minded their manners again last night, but the Reds were rude enough to score three runs in the 10th inning for their fifth straight victory of the year over the defending National League champions.

title: School Elections: Results on Issues In Suburbs Listed
description: Following are the results of yesterday's school elections in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties. The tax rates in Nassau and Suffolk are for every $100 of assessed valuation and in Westchester for every $1,000 of assessed valuation.

title: Treasury Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) The White House said today that President Nixon had accepted with deep regret John M. Hennessy's resignation as Assistant Secretary of the Assistant for International Affairs

title: Sale of Psychology Test Barred in Plagiarism Case
description: A Federal appeals court enjoined the PrenticeHall publishing company from selling Child Psychology, a textbook that is the target of plagiarism charges by the authors of a competing Harper & Row book, Child Development and Personality.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: BEAME COUNTERS GOLDIN CRITICISM OF CITY'S BUDGET
description: In a politely worded but politically pointed letter, Mayor Beame challenged yesterday what he called errors and deficiencies in Controller Harrison J. Goldin's criticism of his proposed municipal budget.

title: RailFreight Rise Seen
description: The nation's railroads were told yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission that they could raise freight rates as much as 10 per cent. The move would cost shippers an additional $1.25billion in railfreight charges in the next 12 months. Page 57.

title: Arlington to Hold DayNight Racing
description: CHICAGO, June 4 (UPIThe Illinois Racing Board ruled today that Arlington Park Race Track could conduct dual afternoonevening meets this Friday and Saturday and also the weekend of June 14 and 15. But the board said after that, it would try to consider other ways of making up the revenue the state is losing during the contract dispute between horsemen and the management of Sportsman's Park.

title: G.O.P. in California Picks Flournoy for Governor
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 4Houston I. Flournoy, a former college professor, was nominated by the Republicans today for Governor of California. Edmund G. Brown Jr., son of the former Governor, was leading on the Democratic slate.

title: Defender Advances In Women's Tennis
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 4  Topseeded Mrs. Marilyn Aschner Rachleff of Kings Point, L. I., the defender, and Patty Shoolman of Fairport, N. Y., seeded second, moved into the quarterfinals of the New York State women's tennis championship at the Beach Point Club today.

title: Ideology Losing in Soviet Search for Power
description: The chairman of the central bank of the world's leading capitalist economy and the Premier of the world's leading Communist economy sat down in the Kremlin last month for three hours of conversation over tea and biscuits. What did Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Aleksei N. Kosygin, the Soviet Premier and chief economic executive, talk about?

title: Sadat Crosses the Suez Canal, Visits Troops on Anniversary
description: SUEZ CITY, Egypt, June 4President, Anwar elSadat crossed the Suez Canal today and visited Egyptian Third Army troops in Sinai for the first time since before the October war.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your recent reports of the House Judiciary Committee's insistence on receiving the original White House tapes are accurate in stating that this is because they are the best evidence.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Voter Registration Goes Underground

title: Nusbaum Earns Spot In Open Golf
description: DEAL, N, J., June 4A 1967 West Point graduate who broke his neck six weeks after receiving his secondlieutenant's commission and a 21yearold who turned pro just six months ago led the field today as 77 golfers sought the 11 precious United States Open berths available in the final Northeast sectional qualifying round.

title: 2 Cambodian Aides Die in Student Riot
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 4Cambodia's Education Minister and his top assistant were killed today when Government troops stormed a high school where students were holding them hostage in protest demanding educational reforms.

title: KORVETTE CLAIMS FOUND DECEPTIVE
description: The Federal Trade Commission accused E. J. Korvette yesterday of deceptive claims regarding the price, quality and guarantees of its homeimprovement services and prohibited the national chain from engaging in termite control waterproofing services without its approval.

title: BILL FELDHAUS
description: CINCINNATI, June 4 (AP)Bill Feldhaus, a former National Football League allpro lineman, died Sunday in a nursing home here. He was 61 years old.

title: When People Care
description: Conservation and environment and ecology are all good words, but they have lost a part of their meaning by repetition and loose usage. Now and then, however, something is done that brings such words to life without even mentioning them, such as the volunteer effort to clean up the Bronx River through the Bronx Zoo, near Gunhill Road and in the West Farms areas, under Police Department auspices. Nobody used the big words. It was just a cleanup job.

title: MILITANT GUILTY IN 1973 SHOOOUT
description: Robert Hayes, an alleged member of the Black Liberation Army and convicted murderer of a Transit Authority policeman, was found guilty last night by a Bronx state Supreme Court jury of the attempted murder of six police oficers. A second defendant, Melvin Kearney, was acquitted of murder charges in the same case but convicted of possession of a dangerous weapon.

title: Common Market and Italy in Import Pact
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 4The agricultural ministers of the nine members of the Common Market agreed here today on measures to allow Italy to lift recently imposed restrictions on imports of farm products from other countries in the bloc.

title: Nixon Leaves Monday on Mideast Tour
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 The White House today announced President Nixon's itinerary for his visit to the Middle, East next week, saying that he would seek to consolidate, what has been achieved on the road to peace.

title: Riot by Indians' Fans in 9th Forfeits Game to Rangers
description: CLEVELAND, June 4 (UPI)  Hundreds of spectators charged onto the field in the ninth inning of the game between the Texas Rangers and the Cleveland Indians tonight and staged a wild brawl, leading the umpires to order the game forfeited to the Rangers, 90.

title: Aaron Hits 16th GrandSlam Homer To Take Undisputed Lead in League
description: Henry Aaron hit his 16th career grandslam homer last night in Veterans Stadium to add to his record as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 73.

title: $300Million in Two Corporate Debenture Issues Are Received Well in a Heavy Day for Bond Trading
description: A total of $300million in two new corporate offerings were about sold out yesterday as bond market participants threaded their way through another large oneday calendar.

title: GEORGE GOLDBERG
description: George Goldberg, a retired wholesale  meat distributor, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Park Way General Hospital, North Miami Beach, Fla. He was 77 years old and lived in North Miami Beach.

title: Santarelli Quits and Attributes Action to Misleading Reports
description: WASHINGTON, June 4President Nixon accepted today the resignation of Donald E. Santarelli, who said he was quitting as head of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration because of misleading reports about his comments on the President.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 2 Victims Kill, Kidnapper
description: LOS ANGELES, June 4 (UPI)Two kidnapping victims wrested a rifle from their captor early today and killed him with a shot in the back as he tried to flee out the front door of an apartment. The kidnapper was not immediately identified. The police said he was carrying a driver's license of another man from Silver Spring, Md. The two men who jumped their captor, were identified by the police as Tom Leavitt, 17 years old, and Harold Marx, 27.

title: Shippers Would Pay 1.25Billion More Over 12 Months
description: The nation's railroads were told yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission that they could increase freight rates by as much as 10 per cent in a move that would cost shippers an additional $1.25billion in rail charges over the next 12 months. The increase could go into effect as soon as June 20, if a filing is made today.

title: Queens Moth
description: Maria Winley went back to school last fall because it was getting lonely with only eight of her children still around the house.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Books of The Times
description: NAKED IS THE BEST DISGUISE. The Death and Resurrection of Sherlock Holmes. By Samuel Rosenberg. 203 pages. Hobbs Merrill. $8.95.

title: Broadway Producers and Institutional Theaters Air Divergent Views at Stage Congress
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 4Why was this conference held? asked Joseph Papp, the featured speaker in today's plenary session of FACT (First American Congress of Theater). Then he commented, I assume the worst.

title: ILLNESS A PUZZLE IN RONCALLO CASE
description: The Suffolk County Police Commissioner, Eugene R. Kelley, said yesterday that he was investigating conflicting stories about the chief Federal prosecutor's mysterious illness during the extortion trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo.

title: Patient Found Dead in River
description: The body of a 35yearold woman who was a patient at Manhattan State Hospital on Wards Island was taken from the East River by the police yesterday. The police, who believe the death, was a suicide withheld her identification spending notification of survivors.

title: 2 Tapes Seem to Aid Nixon In Controversy Over I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The House Judiciary Committee heard today two White House tape recordings that apparently rebutted charges that President Nixon was aware of a plan by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to contribute to his 1972 reelection campaign when he intervened in an antitrust case against the conglomerate in 1971.

title: 16 Impeachment Panel Members Got Election Aid From Dairymen
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) At least 16 members of the House Judiciary Committee accepted political donations ranging from $100 to $11,000 from the same three dairy farmer cooperatives the panel is investigating as part of its impeachment inquiry.

title: Edith Barenholtz, Founder Of Creative Playthings, 60
description: Mrs. Edith Friedman Barenholtz, a pioneer in educational equipment for preschool children and a founder of Creative Playthings, died on Thursday in Princeton, N. J. She was 60 years old and lived there.

title: A.E.C. Checking if Con Edison Can Keep Nuclear Plants Safe
description: Because of the Consolidated Edison Company's growing financial difficulties, the Atomic Energy Commission has begun an investigation into whether the utility has enough funds to continue operating its nuclear plants safely.

title: WILSON WILL KEEP TROOPS IN ULSTER
description: LONDON, June 4Prime's Minister Wilson ruled out a British troop withdrawal from Northern Ireland today as an emergency debate in the House of Commons ended without evidence of progress toward a resolution of the political crisis there.

title: Marshall Islanders' Surgery
description: CLEVELAND, June 4 (UPI) Two women from Rongelap in the Marshall Islands underwent surgery today at Metropolitan General Hospital for removal of thyroid gland nodules caused by exposure to radioactive particles from a hydrogen bomb's fallout 20 years ago. Of the 89 persons on the island when the fallout occurred, only 25 have not had the operation.

title: Restrictive Policy Favored to Cut Inflation
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 4Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon said today that the United States economy would have to be run at less than full capacity for a considerable period of time in order to squeeze inflation out of the system.

title: Stocks Are Up on Hopes Of LevelingOff of Rates
description: The hopes of investors that interest rates may finally have peaked helped the stock market post its second consecutive broad advance yesterday in heaviest trading in almost months.

title: Center for Study of Democratic Institutions Has New Chief and a Fiscal Crisis
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  The Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions cherishes many ideals, including one that may be indispensable: Robert M. Hutchins.

title: The Issues in Walkout
description: PARTICIPANTSThe Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S. A., representing 750 manufacturers men's and boys' suits, topcoats and overcoats, and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, representing 110,000 machine operators, cutters, markers, button and pocket makers.

title: Clothing Strikes Once Were Common
description: For oldtimers in the industry, the strike of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America awakes memories of 50 years ago when the infant union was struggling for recognition and strikes were a nearly everyday occurrence.

title: PUSHING OF KEYS CAUSED TAPE GAP, EXPERTS ASSERT
Legal Fees Mounting in Rothko Trial
description: There was a pause in the Rothko estate trial in Surrogate's Court yesterday, but legal fees continued to pile up toward an ultimate total large enough to buy several Rothko paintingseven at their highest prices.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago. (RadioWMCA, 9 P.M.)

title: White Sox Trounce Yanks As Allen Hits Slam, 92
description: CHICAGO, June 4The last time the Yankees saw Wilbur Wood they beat him in both games of a doubleheader. The last time they saw Dick Allen they limited him to two singles in 10 times at bat.

title: Charges Against Powers And 7 Union Aides Dropped
description: Criminal Court Judge Richard A Brown dismissed criminal trespass charges yesterday against Bertram A. Powers, the president of Typographical Union No. 6, and seven other union officials.

title: BEINE COUNTERS GOLDIN CRITICISM OF CITY'S BUDGET
description: In a politely worded but politically pointed letter, Mayor Beanie challenged yesterday what he called errors and deficiencies in Controller Harrison J. Goldin's criticism of his proposed municipal budget.

title: Economic Disengagement From Vietnam
description: WASHINGTONThe signing of the Paris peace agreement in January, 1973, marked the official termination of direct American combat involvement in Vietnam. Since then, the United States Government has committed approximately $2.3 billion in economic and military assistance to Vietnam.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: James Knowles Leads Seniors
description: RYE, N.Y., June 4A second field of 470 contestants from 32 states turned out for the United States Seniors' Golf Association's annual twoday tournament today.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE 3D SESSION IN ROW
description: Prices rose again in steppedup trading on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yesterday as more traders became convinced that the round of increases in the prime rate was coming to a halt.

title: Reirson Iowa State Pilot
description: AMES, Iowa, June 4 (UPI) Clair Rierson, 35yearold former college and semipro baseball player, was named today Iowa State baseball coach.

title: RETRENCHMENT SET BY 2 LARGE UTILITIES
description: Two large utilities in Michigan and Arizona announced retrenchments yesterday because of declining activity and rising costs. One of them included the first layoffs that are known to have occurred during the current squeeze on the utilities industry.

title: Furs for Fall: At Those Prices, They'd Better Be Marvelous
description: In a stage whisper that could have been heard in the second balcony, if there'd been one, Anne Baxter, the actress, kept saying, Marvelous, marvelous, at Bonnie Cashin's first fur show for H.B.A.

title: Mrs. Fenwick Edges Out Kean in Jersey Primary
description: Mrs. Millicent Fenwick, the former director of the state Office of Consumer Protection and a former Republican Assemblyman from Somerset County, apparently won an extremely narrow victory yesterday in the Republican Congressional election in New Jersey's Fifth District.

title: Homosexuals Gain Support on Campus
description: After arduous beginnings, student homosexuals have gained widespread recognition, financial backing and often the support of camps heatlh officials at colleges and universities across the country.

title: Nusbaum Earns Spot In Open Golf
description: DEAL, N. J., June 4A 1967 West Point graduate who broke his neck six weeks after receiving his secondlieutenant's commission and a 21yearold who turned pro just six months ago led the field today as 77 golfers sought the 11 precious United States Open berths available in the final Northeast sectional qualifying round.

title: Siderowf Upset, 1 Up, By Scot in British Golf
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 4 (AP)The defender, Dick Siderowf of Westport, Conn., was upset in the second round of the British Amateur golf championship today, but James Gabrielson, a Walker Cup player from Atlanta, lifted America's fortunes with a victory.

title: Kennecott Copper Increases Prices On Some Cathodes
description: The Kennecott Copper Company and the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company joined several other producers yesterday in raising their prices for fullp)att electrolytic copper cathodes produced and sold in the United States by 5 cents a pound to 85 cents, effective immediatel.

title: Ecologists Fight Croton Gorge Ball Park
description: CROTON  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., June 4Local lore has it that more than half a century ago, when the National Film Corporation was planning the first Tarzan movies, they needed a jungle not too far from Times Square. Budgetary problems, it seems.

title: Reirson Iowa State Pilot
description: AMES, Iowa, June 4 (UPI) Clair Rierson, 35yearold former college and semipro baseball player, was named today Iowa State baseball coach. Rierson, elevated to the post by Athletic Director Lou McCullough, succeeds Cap Timm, 66, who retired this year after 36 years as coach. Rierson joined the I.S.U. baseball staff in 1965.

title: ANTACID CONTENTS LIMITED BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration ordered the $117millionayear antacid industry today to stop making exaggerated claims for its products and to limit them to a small set of safe and proven ingredients.

title: Value of Colson as a Watergate Witness Is Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 Charles W. Colson today is a surprise witness for the prosecution in the Watergate affair, but his exact value in that role is a matter of dispute.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: ExMayor Admits Tax Charges

title: Ahumada Is Floored By Sparring Mate
description: McAFEE, N.J., June 4 (AP) Jorge Ahumada of Argentina, training for his world lightheavyweight title fight against the champion, Bob Foster, at Albuquerque, N.M., on June 17, was knocked down today in the first round of a threeround workout.

title: PUSHING OF KEYS CAUSED TAPE GAP, EXPERTS ASSERT
description: WASHINGTON, June 4A courtappointed panel of technical experts has concluded that the only completely plausible explanation for the 18minute gap in a crucial White House tape recording is that the gap was caused by pushing the keys of a normally operated tape recorder at least five times.

title: SCIENTISTS PLAN TO AID CONGRESS
description: One of the nation's leading scientific societies has initiated what it believes to be a novel providing key members of Congress with topquality, nonpartisan scientific advice.

title: Hotel in Newport Bankrupt
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 4 (AP) The financially troubled Hotel Viking, a Bellevue Avenue landmark for years, has fallen into bankruptcy after five months of struggling to stay afloat. The Industrial National Bank was granted permission in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Providence yesterday to foreclose on the hotel's $500,000 mortgage.

title: 15 Die on Ferry in India
description: NEW DELHI, June 4 (UPI)A ferry capsized and sank last night in midstream near Bombay and 15 persons, including 11 women, drowned, police officials reported today. Three persons were said to be missing.

title: Morton Limits Coal Lease for Tribe
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The Secretary of the Interior, Rogers C. B. Morton, announced today the revocation of the most crucial terms of coal leases granted by his department for strip mining on the Northern Cheyenne Indian reservation in easte, n Montana.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WHITHER MIME? Who knows? In the days of the Roman Empire mime was strong stuff. Its pointed topical references were usually centered on adultery. Acts of adultery were performed onstage. Also, when executions were called for, executions were performed, with convicts filling in for the actors.

title: Wife of Employe Held Ineligible For a Seat on Education Board
description: TRENTON, June 4  Even taking into consideration the independence of marriage partners, the Acting State Commissioner of Education ruled today that a married woman should not be a member of a local board of education if her husband is a paid employe of the board.

title: Furrier Gets $3,000 Fine For Paying Union Officials
description: A Manhattan furrier was fined $3,000 yesterday in United States District court on conviction of having made three $150 payments in 1969 to union officials for special treatment.

title: 2 Tapes Seem to Aid Nixon In Controversy Over I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The House Judiciary Committee heard today two White House tape recordings that apparently rebutted charges that President Nixon was aware of a plan by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to contribute to his 1972 reelection campaign when he intervened in an antitrust case against the conglomerate in 1971.

title: Rodino's Panel Intensifies Inquiry on Security Taps
description: WASHINGTON, June 4The House Judiciary Committee has quietly intensified its inquiry into 17 socalled national security wiretaps authorized by President Nixon beginning in 1969, court records showed today.

title: Futures for Silver, Platinum And Copper Stage Price Rally
description: Futures prices of three basics metals  silver, platinum and copperrallied yesterday, recovering virtually all of their losses on Monday. The rise came on a day when the price for gold in London moved downward.

title: Dorothy McKay, 70, Dies; Cartoonist and Illustrator
description: Dorothy McKay, a cartoonist and illustrator who contributed drawings to Esquire magazine for many years, died Monday in Midtown Hospital. The wife of Donald W. McKay, an artist and illustrator, she was 70 years old and lived at 9 Christopher Street.

title: 2 Cambodian Aides Die in Student Riot
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 4Cambodia's Education( Minister and his top assistant were killed today when Government troops stormed a high school where students were holding them hostage in a protest demanding educational reforms.

title: The Money Question
description: Public records show that since the new Election Reporting Law went into effect in April, 1972, the milk cooperatives have contributed a total of $32,000 in campaign funds to nine Democrats and seven Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee, the same committee that is considering allegations that President Nixon raised Federal milkprice supports in exchange for contributions from these same cooperatives.

title: Waldheim Inspects Outposts Along Golan Heights Front
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 4, (Reuters)  Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations today inspected observation posts along the Golan Heights front where United Nations troops will oversee the disengagement of Israeli and Syrian forces.

title: KISSINGER TERMS AID EFFORT VITAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Secretary of State Kissinger, told a Congressional committee today that foreign aid was vital to peace in the Middle East and Indochina and was needed to prevent a split between the developed and developing nations.

title: BASIL WOON, 80 JOURNALIST, DIES
description: RENO, June 4 (UPI)Basil Woon, whose career as a journalist spanned more than 60 years, died today in a Reno hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: CLOTHING LEADERS MEET TOMORROW
description: Negotiations aimed at settling the nationwide strike in men's and boys' clothing industry are scheduled to resume tomorrow in the offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in Washington.

title: ALABAMA OFFICIAL WINNER IN RUNOF
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 4 (AP)Lieut. Gov. Jere Beasley fighting an uphill battle for a second term, won renominatino today by defeating Charles Woods, a millionaire industrialist, in the Democratic primary.

title: DOLLAR DOWN A BIT; GOLD PRICES IN DROP
description: BRUSSELS, June 4 (UPI)The dollar dropped slightly on larger European money markets today and gold prices also showed small losses.

title: India Smallpox Epidemic Fatal to at Least 10,000
description: At least 10,000and perhaps as many as 20,000people in the northeastern Indian state of Bihar have died so far this year from smallpox in what has been described as one of the worst epidemics of the viral disease in recent years.

title: U.S. Troops in Europe
description: Senator Mike Mansfield's renewed effort to force substantial withdrawal of American troops from Europe and other areas overseas is the wrong battle in the wrong place at the wrong time.

title: Labor Unit Opens Hearings On Police and Fire Wages
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) The Labor Department opened hearings yesterday on how to apply new minimum wage and overtime legislation to policemen and firemen, taking testimony from Gerald M. Feder of the International Association of Fire Fighters.

title: German Is Cycling Victor
description: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, June 4 (AP)Heinz Luthringhauler, 43 years old, of West Germany, won the 500 cc. sidecar motorcycle race today with Hermann Hahn as his passenger in a B.M.W.

title: Once Supermarket Dilettantes, Men Shop Seriously Now
description: Harold Miller is no devotee of chicken necks. In fact, he feeds them to the family dog. Which may explain Mr. Miller's chagrin when, home from the supermarket with 10 salepriced fryers, he found the bags contained 15 necks.

title: Peking Identifies Air Force Leader After 3Year Gap
description: PEKING, June 4 (Reuters)China has a new air force commander, succeeding Wu Fahsien, who disappeared at the time of the abortive coup apparently planned by Defense Minister Lin Piao in September, 1971.

title: STEEL CONTRACT SET BY JAPAN AND CHINA
description: TOKYO, June 4Japan and China have signed a contract in Peking for constructing a large steel plant in China. Shipments will begin a year from now and trial runs will begin in January, 1977.

title: Padres Expected To Draft Shortstop
description: Baseball will conduct its summer free agent draft beginning today and the San Diego Padres, leading off the lottery, are expected to choose Bill Almon of Brown University, a shortstop.

title: FREDERIC DAVIDSON, LED SUGAR CONCERN
description: Frederic A. Davidson, retired president of Refined Syrups and Sugars, Inc., and former president of the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Board of Education, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 9 Keogh Lane in New Rochelle.

title: Russian Oil Profits From West Climb
description: MOSCOW, June 4  The jump in world oil prices enabled the Soviet Union last year to reap nearly a billion dollars more in oil revenue than a yearearlier, with only a modest increase in exports.

title: Rev. Patrick Miller, 74, Dies; Led Presbyterians in South
description: DECATUR, Ga., June 4 (UPI) The Rev. Patrick G. Miller, a leader in the Presbyterian Church of the U. S., died last night. He was 74 years' old.

title: Personal Loan Rate Raised by 2 Banks
description: Two leading New York banks have quietly raised their lending rates on personal loans.

title: LOCKHEED'S BANKS SEEN PARING RATE
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's bankers are expected to reduce their interest rate temporarily on Lockheed loans from the current 12 per cent maximum to 4 per cent as part of a proposed deal with Textron, Inc., for the financial overhaul of the troubled aerospace manufacturer.

title: On Trial
description: The judgment to be handed down shortly in a Sudanese court extends far beyond the fate of eight confessed murderers brought to trialthe Palestinian fanatics who kidnapped and killed three diplomats, a Belgian and two Americans, in March of last year.

title: Lawyer Gets Year Suspension For Conveying $20,000 Bribe
description: TRENTON, June 4 (AP)A lawyer who conveyed a $20,000 bribe to former Jersey City officials was suspended from practicing law for one year today by the State Supreme Court

title: Sports Stars Get Acquainted on the Court
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 4 The longest reign in the history of sports celebrity tennis  Hank Greenberg's three straight championship yearsended today as Rick Barry and Kyle Rote Jr. defeated Greenberg and Bob Klein in doubles in the final match of a twoday frolic at the Riviera Hotel.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: New State Law Frees the City Of Subway Fiscal Restraints
description: ALBANY, June 4A measure that would delete statutory requirements calling for about $600million from the 1967 Transportation Bond Issue to be used for specific subway projects in New York City has been signed into law, Governor Wilson's office reported today.

title: A Felicitous Setting for Brubeck Is Provided by His Three Sons
description: The case for zero population growth will not be helped by the current goingson at the Rainbow Grill. Dave Brubeck, who has not played in a New York nightclub since 1961, is appearing there with a group built around his three sonsDarius, 26 years old, on electric keyboard; Chris, 22, on electric bass and trombone, and Danny, 19, on drums. They give him the kind of felicitous setting that Mr. Brubeck never, really found with the quartets of nonrelatives he has led for 23 years.

title: U.S. Regrets Break in Talk on Men Missing in War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4The United States Embassy today expressed frustration and disappointment at the refusal of the Vietcong and the North Vietnamese to attend discussions on the search for men missing in action.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Six in Family Die in Fire
description: PITTSBURGH, June 4 (UPI) A fire in a home early today claimed the lives of a woman and her five children, the police said. The victims were Mrs. Sandra Hendricks, 32 years old; Crystal, 10, Donna, 8, Allan Jr. and Lucille, both 5, and Olivia, 3.

title: G.O.P. Leader Bids Democrats Endorse 2 for Appeals Court
description: Richard M. Rosenbaum, the State Republican chairman, said yesterday that his party would endorse Associate Judges Harold A. Stevens and Samuel Rabin for full terms on the Court of Appeals and that if the Democrats did not, it would be a major campaign issue.

title: Saigon Reports the Capture Of Village After 5Day Fight
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 (UPI)  Government troops recaptured An Dien village, 24 miles north of Saigon, early today after a five  day battle, military sources said.

title: Newsprint Mill Venture Set
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 4, (UPI)Bato Company, Inc., announced today that its Canadian subsidiary, F.F. Soucy, Inc., had entered into a partnership with the Dow Jones Newsprint Company, Inc., and the Refor Corporation to build a $40million newsprint mill in Quebec. The new mill wil be ocated at the Soucy mill site in Rivire du Loup, Quebec.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: ALGERIA RAISES EUROPEAN HOPES
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 4Although Arab oilproducing states have decided to maintain their embargo against the Netherlands and Denmark, officials attending a meeting of the European Common Market here see a good sign in the fact that Algeria sought to end the boycott.

title: Bridge:  Use of a False Card Shows Belladonna's Brilliant Play
description: If bridge players were awarded brilliancy prizes chess players, Giorgio Belladonna of Italy would have qualified for an award on the diagrammed deal from the world championship finals Venice last week. He found the right moment for a simple but highly effective false card that diverted Eric Murray of Toronto from a winning line of play into a losing one.

title: Weaver Gets Spot in U.S. Open on 137
description: DeWitt Weaver, a 34yearold pro whose biggest victory was in 1971 at the United States match  play championship, coasted to a seven  under  par 137 yesterday to lead six golfers qualifying for the United States open at Canongate Golf Course near Atlanta.

title: JUROR IN MISTRIAL IS NOT CHARGED
description: TRENTON, June 4 (UPI)The juror responsible for the mistrial of former State Treasurer Joseph M. McCrane Jr. and two Republican fund raisers will not be prosecuted for alleged deliberate attempts to mislead the court during jury selection, the Attorney General's office said today.

title: Stage: A Moliere First
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 4The 22d Stratford Festival opened at the Festival Theater last night and will run for 23 weeks through Oct. 26. This is the sixth and last Season that Jean Gascon has been artistic director and, appropriately enough, the season opened with his own staging of Molire's The Imaginary Invalid.

title: G.M. and Ford Ask New Delay On Mandatory Air Bags
description: DETROIT, June 4 (UPI)The nation's top two auto makers are seeking another delay in making air bags mandatory safety equipment on 1977model cars.

title: Poland Gives Priority to Ambitious Housing Program
description: WARSAWSomehow, Poland must build more than seven million apartments.

title: 19 in East Side Drug Plan Leave Facility on 68th St.
description: From the ornate fivestory town house at 35 East 68th Street, 19 youthsclassified as potential drug abusersmoved out mattresses yesterday to be trucked to a dingy loft building at 150 Spring Street.

title: ROBERT D. ROOT
description: CHICAGO, June 4 (UPI)Robert D. Root, director of press relations for the American Medical Association, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 47 years old.

Kellogg Company, a division of Pullman, Inc. The contracts call for design and construction of three largescale ammonia plants valued at about $125million. A Mexican contractor was awarded the balance of the contract.

title: Notes on People
description: After meeting for more than three hours yesterday with Leonid I, Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, W. Averell Harriman, the retired diplomat, said that he told Mr. Brezhnev he could count on a stable United States Government over the next two years even if President Nixon were impeached. I told him he could feel confident [to] move ahead on all fronts in relations with the United States, the 82yearold Mr. Harriman reported as he boarded for Paris.

title: 30 Pakistanis Dead in Clashes of Moslem Sects
description: LAHORE, Pakistan (AP) At least 30 persons have been killed, more than 200 injured and 2,000 arrested in five days of Moslem warfare in Pakistan's Punjab Province, authoritative sources report.

title: COURT TO PERMIT POLLUTION BY ORE IN LAKE SUPERIOR
description: ST. LOUIS, June 4A threejudge Federal appeals court panel handed down today an opinion that apparently will allow the Reserve Mining Company to continue to pollute Lake Superior from its Silver Bay, Minn., plant for up to five years.

title: Reid Hints at Quitting Race If Panel Doesn't Back Him
description: Representative Ogden R. Reid yesterday raised the possibility for the first time that he might drop out of the Democratic race for Governor after the Democratic State Committee designates a candidate next week.

title: Negro Ensemble Stages Fuller's Deepest Sleep
description: IN THE DEEPEST PART OF SLEEP, a play by Charles Fuller. Directed by Israel Hicks; settings and costumes by Mary Meese Warren; lighting by Susan Chapman; production stage manager, Harrison Avery. Presented by the Negro Ensemble Company, Douglas Turner Ward, artistic director. At the St. Marks Playhouse, 133 Second Avenue.

title: Brewers' Beer Night Limits Drinks
description: MILWAUKEE, June 5 (AP) The Milwaukee Brewers decided today to have a beer promotion, night after all, despite a similar affair in Cleveland that ended with a baseball park melee.

title: Nixon Tape Is Said to Link Milk Price to Political Gift
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The House Judiciary Committee heard today evidence suggesting that President Nixon conditioned his 1971 decision to raise Federal milk price supports upon a reaffirmation bydairy industry leaders of a pledge to raise $2million for the President's reelection campaign.

title: Critic of Junta Honored at Chile Mass
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 5Several thousand Catholics crowded into the city cathedral last night to attend an emotional mass honoring Raul Cardinal Silva Henriquez, who has come under increasing attack from rightwing followers of the military junta.

The N.F.L. plans to set up a satellite league of six teams next spring. The teams would be the Istanbul Conquerors, the Rome Gladiators, the Munich Lions, the Berlin Bears, the Vienna Lipizzaners and the Barcelona Almovogeres.

title: Court Rules Inheritances Be Shared in Divorces
description: TRENTON, June 5In a unanimous decision, the State Supreme Court today upheld and amplified New Jersey's threeyearold divorce reform law by ruling that gifts and inheritances acquired by either partner during their marriage must be included in the equitable distribution of property in a divorce settlement.

description: The Beame administration said yesterday that its allocation of Federal revenuesharing money in the coming year would be virtually identical with the Lindsay administration's allocation last year.

description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market rose yesterday as more traders became convinced that rising bank prime rates have peaked. Volume, however, declined slightly in both markets.

description: In the wake of Tuesday's nearriot on Beer Night in Cleveland, Lee MacPhail, the president of the American League said yesterday, we can't afford to take any chances, and indicated that he probably would order a halt to certain baseball giveaway promotions.

Jersey, Atlanta Golfers Gain in British Amateur

title: Article 3  No Title
description: In our time, roleplaying is the favorite word of psychiatrists, and scenario the favorite word of publicrelations men. The word image runs a good second with both groups and is for me, a student of theater, an equally theatrical term: Theater is a sequence of images. Now whatever else Richard M. Nixon is, no one will deny that he is a child of our time, a student of theater in the style of our time: He is preoccupied with the image, with roleplaying.

title: White House Said to Curb Ehrlichman Access to Data
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 Highly reliable sources said today that the White House, apparently breaking a specific agreement worked out two days ago with a Federal judge, had refused to permit John D. Ehrlichman and his attorneys to have full and direct access to Mr. Ehrlichman's personal notes of Presidential meetings.

title: ' One Eye' and 'O'Neil' Partners in Crime:The Casts
description: "Dirty O'Neil" and "They Call Her One Eye" arrived at local theaters yesterady to illustrate once again that a shallow, unappetizing double dish of crime, violence, ersatz sex and ersatz cops is certainly no better than one helping. For the record, "Dirty O'Neil" is American-made and "One Eye" is a Scandinavian, English-dubbed entry but neither does much for either girl-watching or crime-watching.Credit "Dirty O'Neil" with a rudimentary sense of humor about sex and cops, if not crime. Morgan Paull, as its titular, young, small-town police officer in California may be bored by his job but admits liking what he does, which is largely a dizzying series of quick dalliances with well-endowed local chicks. He may turn serious momentarily by knocking off three killers who have raped one of his willing girlfriends but in the end he is happily ready to return to the carefree amorous life.On the other hand, Christina Lindberg, has every reason to be grim as the ill-used, brunette beauty known as "One Eye." She's been rendered mute after having been raped as a child and things don't improve after she naively falls into the clutches of a notorious pimp (Heinz Hopf), who turns her into a dope addict and viciously blinds her to keep her in line.Naturally, Miss Lindberg can't be faulted for hating her "clients" and the malevolent boss and for becoming expert in karate and other handy talents, which she uses to destroy them systematically.Of course, Miss Lindberg, who is easy to look at, is constantly doleful since most of what occurs in "One Eye" is dreary. However, she brings one unique, cheerful fashion note to this rough, somber tale by wearing eye patches to match the color of each of the ensembles she appears in. It could start a trend.

title: House Insists, 270 to 103, On Firm Antibusing Stand
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The House insisted tonight, by a vote of 270 to 103, on its stronger version of an antibusing bill that goes tomorrow to a conference with the Senate.

Javits has also made it official. He will seek a fourth term in the United States Senate. And Louis J. Lefkowitz has put himself in the running for a fifth term as State Attorney General.

description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 5President Nixon, who will meet with Soviet leaders in Moscow later this month, declared today that his policy of dtente precluded interference by the United States in the domestic affairs of other nations.

description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 5 (AP)  A proposal by the Federal Reserve Board to regulate foreign banks in the United States on the same general terms as American banks aroused sharp controversy here today at a meeting of International bankers.

With their fairytale stories of goodness rewarded, their use of providence rather than fate and their piquant mixture of popular masque and yet with the poetic mystery of their writing, they stand apart from the rest of Shakespeare's plays as opaque and challenging.

Fledgling artists draw their inspiration from, among other sources, the work of artists already familiar to us. In our first encounters with new work, we cannot help drawing comparisons between the original and the adaptation, and it is the latter that usually suffers.

title: Today's Epidemics Have a Common Carrier the Jer
description: An Indian Government report of an epidemic of 75,000 smallpox cases, including at least 10,000 deaths, in the northeastern state of Bihar has renewed interest in the hazards of the spread of communicable diseases around the world. When news breaks about an epidemic anywhere, inevitably concern arises about changing travel plans to avoid the infected area. But, according to officials of the World Health Organization in Geneva, whose responsibility it is to help stop epidemics before they become global plagues, if a traveler is properly vaccinated, he should not let the smallpox epidemic him from visiting India.

Jenkins performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Presbyterian Church in IrvingtononHudson, N. Y.

title: Screen: Lustful Sicilians:Sex Dominates Malice in Comic 'Malizia' The Cast
description: "Malizia," the title of Salvatore Samperi's new Italian comedy, is translated as "malice" but the real subject is lust. It's lust in the various comic disguises that Italian film makers seem to associate particularly with Sicily where Marcello Mastroianni once sought desperatelyand hilariouslyto murder his wife in "Divorce, Italian-Style.""Malizia," which opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie, is a softer, less satiric comedy, but its preoccupation with sex is often very funny. It's also reassuring: There's at least one place on earth today where, because of societal taboos, the pursuit of sex can still be a satisfactory, full-time avocation.The object of all the plotting and counterplotting in "Malizia" is Angela (Laura Antoneili), an extraordinarily gifted housekeeper who is not only pretty, young, gentle, wise and pliant (up to a limit) but also a first-rate cook, sewer and washer-up.Angela is almost too good to be true. She represents the sacred, the profane and the practical, especially to the head of the family, Don Ignazio (Turi Ferro), newly widowed and not at all sure he wants his dead wife's beneficent spirit hanging around the house, as the priest has promised. The spirit gets in the way of his pursuit of Angela. Antonio, the 18-year-old son, makes passes at Angela, and 9-year-old Enzino accepts her as a huge improvement over the mother he lost without visible unhappiness.The most deeply smitten is 14-year-old Nino (Alessandro Memo), who begins by presenting Angela with an anonymous rose every day. When his father announces his intentions of marrying Angela, Nino's courtship evolves into a curious cat-and-mouse game, though the roles of cat and mouse are reversed in midgame.Nino effectively plays on Angela's good heart to grab a quick feel or two, then uses these indiscretions to blackmail her into going about her housework fully clothed but without her bra. Underwear and its removal play a big part in Nino's fantasies, which somehow don't extend to consummated sex.There's a good deal of malice on Nino's part. This adds a dimension of cruelty to the comedy that expresses the intensity of the boy's frustrations, though it doesn't quite match the tone of the rest of the comedy. "Malizia" is at its best when it's examining the rituals of middle-class Sicilian life (a funeral where everything goes wrong and the corpse is almost burned up) and when it is leering at its sexually driven characters.Because Mr. Samperi has shot the film so close up, both literally and metaphorically. I suspect he's less interested in society than in psyches. "Malizia" is fairly murky in this department though the performers are true and precise.Miss Antonelli is angelic enough to be properly shocking when she begins to supply Nino with fetishes, and Turi Ferro is fine as the lustful but ever practical father. It's a role that became a principal resource for Italian comedy of this sort, which reached its peak in the nineteen-fifties and sixties, but is still nice to have around.

title: People in Sports
description: It's just fantastic to be back and I will do whatever I can to help the team again, said Johnny Kerr, the midfielder who rejoined the New York Cosmos yesterday. Kerr, from Scotland, was sold to Club America of the Mexican League after New York's North American Soccer League championship in 1972. The Cosmos signed him after 21 months of effortcables, telephone calls and other expenses totaling about $30,000.

Both sides are heading toward a nuclear warfighting capability that may replace the stability of mutual terror with shootfirst nuclear nervousness.

title: Seoul Antiaircraft Downs A U.S. Army Helicopter

Now, as his local reports seem more infrequent, Mr. Rivera is attempting to expand his celebrity to the national level.

After a 2,000mile night flight from Moscow, the Soviet Ilyushin18 airliner touched down in central Asia just as the early morning sun was putting orange on the majestic snowcapped peaks of the AlaTau and Tien Shan ranges that decorate the skyline of this capital of Soviet Kirghizia.
