title: Ginsberg Foursome Wins
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 5 Roger Ginsberg, the Muttontown professional, and Arnold Cohn. Edward Lustbader and Peter Claman, amateurs, had a net bestball of foursomes of 59 over the 6,717yard, par35, 3570, Old Oaks Country Club course today in the second annual Albert Einstein Medical College charity golf tournament and won first place on a match of cards. Allan Senior of Old Oaks with Robert J. Eigen, Asriel Rackow and Leonard L. Steiner also carded a net of 59.

title: Kean Will Contest 85Vote Loss to Mrs. Fenwick
description: Thomas H. Kean, the Assembly's Republican minority leader, will ask for a recount of the Somerset County votes cast in Tuesday's Congressional primary election in New Jersey's Fifth District, where he lost the G.O.P. nomination by razorthin margin to Mrs. Millicent Fenwick, former director of the State Office of Consumer Protection.

title: Notes on People
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay has turned down Hunter College's offer to make him a Distinguished Professor for the academic year 197475, it was announced yesterday. Mrs. Jacqueline Wexler, president of Hunter, said that Mr. Lindsay had informed her that other plans prevent him from entertaining the offer. At the same time, Mrs. Wexler announced that Robert Penn Warren, the poet and novelist, had accepted a visiting professorship for 197475.

title: Syria Says She Influenced U.S. Policy
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 5In a major statement of her new policy toward Washington, Syria described the United States today as a country that understands Syrian attitudes and whose friendship must be cultivated as a way of weakening Israel.

title: Sly of Rock Group Weds in the Garden
description: Sylvester (Sly) Stewart, of Sly and the Family Stone, married Kathy Silva last night in front of a nearcapacity crowd of almost 23,000 yelling, screaming, stomping people at Madison Square Garden.

title: Ford Reports Its Volume In May Was Down by 19%
description: DETROIT, June 5The Ford Motor Company reported today it had sold 221,575 cars in May, off 19 per cent from the 261,177 cars sold in the 1973 month.

title: Senators Back Plea for Action On Lies by ExChief of S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The Senate Appropriations Committee agreed today to ask the Justice Department to consider filling perjury charges against G. Bradford Cook, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who admitted he lied under oath on five different occasions.

title: Going Out Guide
description: DIG WE MUST The Indians sold the Dutch a Manhattan Island consisting of 9,800 acres. Now, Manhattan is 14,300 acres, and still growing. Some of this growth, 100 acres of it, is taking place in the North River on the southwestern side of the island at Battery Park City, a $1.1billion new town in town, they say down there.

title: Duryea Promises to Support Wilson
description: MONTAUK, L. I., June 5Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea today promised strong support for Governor Wilson, but at the same time expressed concern that, with the Governor absent from the state most of the week, the rest of the Republican ticket had not jelled as the nominating convention approached.

title: Books of The Times
description: HARRY AND TONTO. By Josh Paul Mazursky. 183 pages. view Press/Dutton. $5.95. Greenfeld and Saturday Review Press/Dutton. $5.95.

title: 10Cent Beer
description: Surely the nation needs a good 5cent cigar but baseball doesn't need 10cent beer.

title: Wining and Dining From Floor to Floor
description: Give or take a few floors, guests had the run of the store. But, as one woman said, a little wistfully, it's like water, water, everywhere and not a drop to drink.

title: California Returns Viewed As Reaction to Watergate
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 5The impact of the Watergate scandals on voter attitudes seemed clearly reflected in the California primary election returns todaymost vividly in the overwhelming approval voters gave to a stringent campaign reform measure.

title: EARLE N. BISHOPP,U.S. COMMISSIONER
description: Earle N. Bishopp, retired United States Commissioner for the Southern District of New York, died Tuesday in the Elmwood Manor nursing home in Nanuet, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Pearl River, N.Y.

title: Nixon Tape Is Said to Link Milk Price to Political Gift
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The House Judiciary Committee heard today evidence suggesting that President Nixon conditioned his 1971 decision to raise Federl milk price supports upon a reaffirmation by dairy industry leaders of pledge to raise $2million for the President's reelection campaign.

title: A MILITARY UPRISING CRUSHED IN BOLIVIA
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 5, (Reuters)  Troops loyal to President Hugo Banzer Suarez swiftly crushed a military uprising against the rightwing Bolivian regime today, but the rebel leaders escaped.

title: School Proposals Put to Vote In Four Counties in Suburbs
Teamsters Pension Fund Plans To Back Las Vegas Hotel Deal
description: A Teamsters Union pension fund has agreed to lend $62.7million to Allen R. Glick, a realestate developer, to finance tender offer for the stock of the Recrion Corporationformerly the ParvinDohrmann cornpanywhich owns and operates two hotelcasino properties in Las Vegas.

title: People in Sports
description: It's just fantastic to be back and I will do whatever I can to help the team again, said Johnny Kerr, the midfielder who rejoined the New York Cosmos yesterday. Kerr, from Scotland, was sold to Club America of the Mexican League after New York's North American Soccer League championship in 1972. The Cosmos signed him after 21 months of effortcables, telephone calls and other expenses totaling about $30,000.

title: THEATER PARLEY HEARS MERRICK
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 5 At the final plenary session FACT, the First American Congress of Theater, unanimously voted to ask its steering committee to hold a second congress within one yearFACT to be followed by SACTand to form an ad hoc committee to follow up suggestions and proposals made during the first Congress.

title: Contract Awards
description: The FMC Corporation has received a $15million Army contract for M113 armored personnel carriers.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: ERITREANS RELEASE PILOT, SEIZE FARMER
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 5 (UPI)  Eritrean guerrillas have released a Canadian pilot they held for 10 days but kidnapped an Italian farmer in northern Ethiopia, the police) said today.

title: Ashe and Gorman Gain As French Open Starts
description: PARIS, June 5 (AP)Arthur Ashe and Torn Gorman led a 10man American challenge into the second round of the French open tennis championships today, but six other Americans lost and four more had their matches suspended by rain.

title: People and Business General Foods Selects Ferguson as Chairman
description: James L. Ferguson, president and chief executive officer of the $1.7billion General Foods Corporation, will also become its board chairman on July 1 to succeed C. W. Cook who has reached mandatory retirement age of 65. Mr. Cook has been chairman since 1966.

title: EUROPEANS GIVEN A SPACE LAB PACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The European Space Research Organization announced today in Paris the award of a $226million contract for a reusable space laboratory to be carried; aboard the space shuttle now being developed by the United States at a cost of more than $5billion.

title: Madison Hight Alumni Mark 50 Golden Years
description: Actually classes began 1925, but the cornerstone was laid in 1924, and that's 50 years ago, and 50 is a nice round number, so the alumni of James Madison High School threw a 50th birthday party last evening.

title: Precautions on Oil Urged
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) The Interior Department proposed today special requirements to protect the environment during oil and gas development in the Ocala National Forest in central Florida. An application by the Amoco Production Company to begin exploratory drilling has been held up by the department since 1971 while it studies the environmental issues.

title: A LOCKHEED MERGER DOUBTED AT TEXTRON
description: The chairman of Textron, Inc., G. William Miller, said yesterday that he did not foresee or contemplate ever merging with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, the financially ailling aerospace giant in which Textron has tentatively agreed to invest $85million.

title: SILVER FUTURES CLIMB BY LIMIT
description: A sharp rise in the price of gold in London and elsewhere attracted buy orders from speculators in silver, platinum and copper futures in New York yesterday.

title: Pleas Made to Block Execution Of Bulgarian Who Was at. U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 5A hurried effort has begun to save the life of a former United Nations official sentenced to death by firing squad in Bulgaria after being convicted as a spy.

title: Guards in Manhattan Buildings Are Linked to Police by Radio
description: Over the ultrahighfrequency radio waves yesterday went the following conversation:

title: Rumania Is Seeking U.S. Coal Partner
description: The Rumanian Government is looking for an American company that would enter into a joint venture with one of its stateowned economic bodies for production in this country of metallurgical coal and coke.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Today, June 6

title: Watergate Defense to Get A List of CoConspirators
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The Watergate special prosecutor agreed today to turn over to defense attorneys in the Watergate coverup conspiracy case the names of any unindicted coconspirators whose names were missing in the March coverup indictment.

title: Demolition Ammonia Fumes Send 80 Newark Pupils to Hospitals
description: NEWARK, June 5  More than 80 children required hospital treatment here today after workers demolishing the old P. Ballantine & Sons brewery accidentally ripped into an ammonia line and sent the fumes billciwing through the St. Aloysius parochial school less than 200 yards away.

title: 9 Starters Expected In Belmont
description: The field for the Belmont Stakes on Saturday will be defined today with the names of nine horses expected to go through the entry box. The list is most likely to include one suppleAt the mentary entrant Race and when the field gets away Tracks for the 106th running of the 1 event for 3yearolds, the gross value will be $169,200. The winner will earn $101,520.

title: Personal Finance: Protein Cost
description: Meat prices, especially for beef and pork, have been dropping in recent weeks. But prices of cheaper sources of proteins have risenand much faster than many housewives realize.

title: State Medicine Board Finishes Hearings in Dr. Jacobson Case
description: The New York State Board for Medicine yesterday completed 14 months of closed hearings in the case of Dr. Max Jacobson, 73yearold Manhattan physician who was charged with 11 counts of professional misconduct and fraud in connection with his use of amphetamines and other drugs.

title: LOUIS DEN
description: Louis Den, an executive of Freiheit, a Yiddishlanguage newspaper, was pronounced dead in Fordham Hospital yesterday after having suffered a heart attack on a subway train. He was 76 years old and lived at 2776 Jerome Avenue, Bronx.

title: Nuclear Atom Plant Reopens
description: VERNON, Vt., June 5 (AP)The Vermont Yankee Nuclear Plant resumed operation today after having been closed for 11 days. The power plant had been shut down when a work crew discovered water in the dry well shielding the nuclear reactor. During the shut down, the plant emitted radioactive gases, but plant officials maintained that they posed no hazards.

title: Cleveland Bishop Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) The Most Rev. Clarence G. Issenmann, 67 years old, has resigned as head of the Roman Catholic diocese of Cleveland because of poor health, the United States Apostolic Delegate's office announced today. Pope Paul VI named the Most Rev. James A. Hickey, rector of the North American College in Rome, to succeed Bishop Issenmann.

title: Venezuelan Treasury Gets Oil Concerns' Tax Payments
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 5 (UPI)The Venezuela Treasury has received tax payments from oil companies operating here for a total of $1.1 billion, Government spokesmen said today.

title: House Insists, 270 to 103, On Firm Antibusing Stand
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The House insisted tonight, by vote of 270 to 103, on its stronger version of an antibusing bill that goes tomorrow to a conference with the Senate.

title: Fumes in Newark Send 80 Students to Hospitals
description: NEWARK, June 5  More than 80 children required hospital treatment here today after workers demolishing the old P. Ballantine & Sons brewery accidentally ripped into an ammonia line and sent the fumes billowing through the St. Aloysius parochial school less than 200 yards away.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 6, 1974

title: Peace With Honor: II
description: BOSTON, June 5Whatever their views on Vietnam, most Americans would agree that the way we got into that war was a disaster. We were taken in by deceptionby leaders who falsely assured us that we were only responding to a Vietnamese request, that our troops had a limited role, that victory was around the corner and so on.

title: Johnson, an ExF.C.C. Member, Loses House Race by 43 Votes
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, June 5Nicholas Johnson, former Federal Communications Commissioner, has apparently lost in his attempt to win the Democratic nomination for Congress in Iowa's Third District

title: Two Share Prize In Hochster Golf
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 5 Nick Giachino of Tamarack and Peter Nisselson of Hampshire tied with 152 today in the 41st annual Hochster Memorial tournament at Quaker Ridge Golf Club. There will be no playoff.

title: U.S. Immigration Agency Lists 37 in Inquiry on Nazi War Cremes
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it was investigating 37 persons  including a Germanborn scientist who worked on the United States space program  on charges that they were Nazi war criminals.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON WIDE REFORMS FOR U.S BUDGETS
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 SenateHouse conferees unanlmously approved today a bill revolutionizing the way Congress processes the Federal budget and decides how to spend the money.

title: J. Knowles Captures Senior Golf
description: RYE, N. Y., June 5America's premier golf event for the nation's more seasoned players came to a sunlit close today with two of its winners completing their twoday, 36hole treks on a note both considered a little frustrating.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: JORDANIANS DEMAND JERUSALEM SECTOR
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June (Reuters)Jordan, has declared that there can he no peace in the Middle East unless israel returns the eastern, Arab sector of Jerusalem to Arab sovereignty.

title: U.S. Cites Foul Play
description: According to the official court transcript of the trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo, Thomas P. Puccio, head of the criminal division of the United States Attorney's office for the Eastern District of New York, spoke to Federal Judge Edward Neaher in his chambers on Friday, May 10, with defense counsel present. Excerpts of what Mr. Puccio, said follow:

title: Counce Has Surgery
description: ST. LOUIS, June 5 (AP)Dan Counce, a rookie on the Boston Minutemen of the North American Soccer League, underwent surgery today to set a cheekbone fractured last week. Counce is expected to be sidelined from three to five weeks.

title: CAMBODIA SLAYING LINKED TO GUNMAN
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 5 (UPI)  An American teacher who witnessed the killing of Cambodia's Education Minister and his top assistant yesterday said today they had been shot by a lone gunman who managed to get into a school held by rioting students but was not a student himself.

title: Coal Interests Rumania
description: The Rumanian Government is looking for an American company that would enter into a joint venture with one of its stateowned economic bodies for production in the United States of metallurgical coal and coke. Details on Page 63.

title: BRITISH BANKS STUDY FRANKLIN
description: LONDON, June 5Interest by British banks in the financially troubled Franklin National Bank of New York was reported today.

title: Rockefeller Denies. Nixon Belittled Ford
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller denied here yesterday a report in Newsweek magazine that President Nixon had belittled Vice President Ford at a meeting with the former New York Governor.

title: Homer M. Carter, 72, Dies; Led West. PointPepperell
description: Homer M. Carter, president of the Pepperell Manufacturing Company from 1961 to 1965, when he became president of its successor by merger, West PointPepperell, Inc., died yesterday in Atlanta, where he had been living in retirement. He was 72 years old.

title: Governor Signs Bill to Finance Expansion of Roosevelt Hospital
description: ALBANY, June 5Governor Wilson has approved a measure that would authorize the State Dormitory Authority to sell bonds for the construction of a new building for Roosevelt Hospital in New York City and to acquire an existing building in the hospital complex and lease it hack to Roosevelt, the Governor's office announced today.

title: EVONNE RAE
description: Evonne Rae, editor in chief of Dell Purse Books, a division of Dell Publishing Company, died Sunday night in an automobile accident In East Hampton, L. I. She was 46 years old and lived at 361 East 50th Street.

title: Troy Says Manes Drive Is Floundering
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Queens Democratic leader, declared yesterday that the campaign of Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens, whom he is supporting for the Democratic nomination for Governor, was floundering.

title: ROBERT BENNETT
description: Robert Bennett, who retired in 1955 as corporate secretary of the St. Joseph Lead Company, now the St. Joe Minerals Company, died yesterday in hospital in Dallas.

title: Insko Gets A Welcome At Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 5Del Insko went back into the harnessracing business today.

title: California Returns Viewed As Reaction to Watergate
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 5The impact of the Watergate scandals on voter attitudes seemed clearly reflected in the California primary election returns todaymost vividly in the overwhelming approval voters gave to a stringent campaign reform measure.

title: Parable of the Daughter
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.There was in the land a certain rich man, richer by far than most men of his time. He had several daughters, one of whom was clearly his favorite, though before the age of twenty she moved from his house to live with friends in neighboring town. But the rich man did not grieve, for he knew his daughter was happy, and she took comfort in his love.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 5Freed from the pressure of sub4minutemile string, Tony Waldrop will chase a national title in the 53d annual National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships starting here tomorrow. The North Carolina senior, a runnerup to Dave Wottle last year, had recorded nine consecutive sub4minute races before fading to a 4minute5second effort at the Modesto (Calif.) Relays.

title: Javits Wins Support Of Liberal Party Units
description: More than 500 representatives of clubs and trade unions affiliated with the Liberal party called on the party's state committee yesterday to endorse Senator Jacob K. Javits for reelection when it meets on June 15.

title: Karl Hagedorn's Wry Paintings at Gimpel
description: The word new is all over the town this week. If it doesn't fit, send out for some elastic was the order of the day, as one gallery after another prepared its entry for the 1974 New Talent Festival. There must, in this sense, have been more elastic around Madison Avenue than at any time since the heyday of the girdle. But even so the words most often were only an approximate fit. When it comes to the new, New York has exacting standards, and nothing that I saw this week was new in the sense that Matisse was new when Alfred Stieglitz showed him in New York in 1908 or that Frank Stella was new when Dorothy Miller showed him at the Museum of Modern Art in 1960

title: Sets Defeated By Denver Team
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., June 5Led by Tony Roche and Francoise Durr, the Denver Racquets rolled away from the New York Sets, 2621, in World Team Tennis match tonight at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Indians Quiet Their Restless Tribe With a Barrage of Five Home Runs
description: All was quiet on the midwestern front in Cleveland's Municipal Stadium last night.

title: C. so. For Lots of Minor Sncceises Smyslov Forgoes Big Time Q
description: Vasily Smyslov, world champion from 1957 to 1958, when he lost the return match to Mikhail Botvinnik, later said that he had no further desire to fight the arduous battle through the Candidates Matches for another crack at the title. Yet his ambition for tournament successes has scarcely slackened, as his first prize in Reykjavik recently evidenced.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While very comforting, your May 25 editorial A New Middle East bears hardly at all upon the reality.

title: Fluor Earnings Soar by 201%; Other Concerns Issue Figures
MRS. WALTER FOWLER
description: Mrs. Sara Ferris Fowler, who had taught at the Rippowan School in Bedford, N. Y., for 43 years, died Monday in Mount Dora, Fla. She was 68 years old, the wife of Walter G. Fowler, retired head of the Fowler Engineering Corporation in Mount Kisco, N.Y., and lived in Cross River, N.Y., and Mount Dora.

title: Gibson Bids Class At Queens College Erase City Mess
description: Deputy Mayor Paul Gibson Jr. urged the 50th graduating class' at Queens College not to abandon the problems of New York City.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 6, 1974

title: LARRY CABRELLI
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP)  Larry Cabrelli, a former player and assistant coach for the Philadelphia Eagles football tealm, died today at Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 57 and lived in Havertown, Pa.

title: Jamaica Approves a Rise For Her Levies on Bauxite
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 5 (UPI)The Jamaican Parliament approved an eightfold increase last night in bauxite royalties to be levied against United States and Canadian companies.

title: Currency Rumors Lift Price of Gold
description: BRUSSELS, June 5 (UPI)Rumors of a realignment of the West German mark and the French franc raised the price of gold today in Zurich and London by up to $8.50 an ounce. The dollar declined in London, Zurich and Frankfurt but made gains in Paris and Brussels.

title: Kissinger Cites Soviet Pledge on Jews
description: WASHINGTON, June 5Secretary of State Kissinger told three Senators today that he had received assurances recently from Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko that emigration of Jews from the Soviet Union would be further eased, according to Senate aides.

title: A FRIEND OF NIXON LINKED TO OFFER
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 Elmer H. Bobst, the drug company executive who is on of President Nixon's closes friends, wrote in 1971 to Join N. Mitchell, who was then At torney General, that an uni dentified close friend woult contribute more than $100,000 to Mr. Nixon's 1972 campaign in exchange for a more favorable attitude by the Federal Trade Commission on a pending case.

title: Mead of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The last major move that Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger needed to make to establish his control over the Pentagon was to place his own type of man as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He has succeeded in doing this with the confirmation today by the Senate of President Nixon's nomination of Gen. George Scratchley Brown of the Air Force to the nation's highest military post.

title: Debra Farber Wed To David J. Stone
description: Miss Debra Lynn Farber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Farber of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday evening to David Joseph Stone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Stone of Hull, Mass. Rabbi Robert Blumstein performed the ceremony at the Fort Hill Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Chemical Is Joining Banks Raising Rate On Personal Loans
description: The Chemical Bank disclosed yesterday that it would raise personal loan rates but had not yet determined by how much. It would he the third major bank, after the Bankers Trust Company and the First National City Bank, to raise such rates in the last month.

title: Cleveland Bishop Named
description: CLEVELAND, June 5 (AP)The Most Rev. James A. Hickey, rector of the North American College in Rome, was named Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Cleveland Clarence G. Issenmann, who resigned because of poor health. The appointment by Pope Paul VI was announced by the United States Apostolic Delegate's office in Washington.

title: Simon Opposes Proposed Tax Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon said today that enactment of the tax reforms that are being pushed by a group of Senate Democratsor even their serious consideration by Congresscould cause an economic slowdown and higher unemployment.

title: SADIE KLEIN
description: Mrs Sadie Siegel Klein, who appeared on the Yiddish stage here with her late husband many years ago as Sadie and Isidore Klein, died yesterday in Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center, where she established the Miriam Klein Research Foundation. She was 91 years old.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, June 5Girls' track in New Jersey is growing. Evidence will be at Rutgers Stadium Saturday when the girls will have their allgroup championships along with the boys' allgroup meet.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: In Holdrege, Neb., Where Weather Leads Watergate as a Topic, Nixon Is Strongly Backed
description: HOLDREGE, Neb.In 1972 President Nixon tallied more than 82 per cent of the vote in this bustling southcentral Nebraska community. That was even better than Leland Swenson did in his bid for a position on the Phelps County Weed Control Commission.

title: Moyers's Departure Jeopardizes WNET Shows
description: Bill Moyers's sudden decision to leave public television a month ago is held by many in the system to be a reason for the poor showing thus far of WNET/Channel 13, in the new station program cooperative of the Public Broadcasting Service. The cooperative was lictelevision stations to vote their own financial support for certain national programing.

title: Public Service Asks a 5.68% Rate Rise
description: NEWARK, June 5  The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility, today requested interim increases of 6.05 per cent in electric rates and 4.82 per cent in gas rates in an effort to gain $73 million more in revenues from the company's 1.8 million customers.

title: G. THOMAS LORE
description: G. Thomas LoRe, retired supervising referee of the State Unemployment Insurance Board and a former Brooklyn Assemblyman, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital on Staten Island. He was 66 years old and lived at 1100 Clove Road in the Sunny Side section of Staten Island.

title: Moscow Summit ...
description: The unfortunate concurrence of the Watergate investigation and President Nixon's third annual summit conference this month with Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has stirred a confused debate in Washington over the wisdom of the President's trip to Moscow and the dangers involved.

title: ExVietnarn P.O.W. to Face McGovern In Race for South Dakota Senate Seat
description: PIERRE, S. D., June 5 (AP)  South Dakota Republicans have nominated a former prisoner of war, Leo Thorsness, to challenge Senator George McGovern's bid for a third term. Mr. Thorsness, who is 42 years old, spent six years in a North Vietnam prison camp and announced his intention to seek Mr. McGovern's seat shortly after returning to the United States last year.

title: Opera: New Dan at Met
description: There were several new facets to Tuesday night's Don Giovanni at the Metropolitan Opera, chief among them the first appearance of Thomas Stewart in the title part. The stalwart baritone, still a onedimensional Don in this initial effort, sang robustly and cut a handsome figure.

title: PRICES OF GAS HERE RISE A CENT A GALLON
description: Two agencies that keep an eye on the prices consumers pay again reported overall price advances yesterday.

title: Rodino Reported to Order A Study of Roncallo Case
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, instructed his staff yesterday to investigate the circumstances surrounding the indictment last winter of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo of Long Island and certain activities of the United States Attorney's office for the Eastern District of New York.

title: Gone but Not Forgotten
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.Almost without exception colleges and universities, public and private, keep a roster of alumni. To the small, private institutions lacking large endowments such a roster is vital: It represents dollars, actual or potential.

title: FitzGibbon Heads State Tennis Field
description: A record field of 210 players was announced yesterday for the New York State men's claycourt tennis championship at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens. Herb FitzGibbon of New York, former nationally ranked star who won the tournament several years ago, was seeded first. He was followed by Neil Edwab of Roslyn, L. I., the defending champion; John James, an Australian now living in Katonah, N. Y., who won the Westchester and Long Island men's titles; Steve Ross of Brooklyn, and Bob Barker of Port Washington, L. I. Play starts tomorrow at 4 P.M.

title: PERIL IN TROOP CUT SEEN BY KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 Secretary of State Kissinger, in a letter made public today, warned that troop reductions overseas being considered in the Senate would have a destabilizing effect on European allies and would seriously undermine negotiations with the Soviet Union on mutual troop reductions.

title: LILCO Again to Raise FuelAdjustment Rate
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 5 (AP)The Long Island Lighting Company will raise its electricity fuel adjustment rate by 10.5 per cent this month, increasing the average monthly electric bill by 83 cents.

title: Operetta
description: Victor del Corral and Manolo Alonzo, partners in VicMan Productions, think there is a sizable public here for Spanish  language musical theater, and they are exploring the dimensions and tastes of that public this week with an ambitious production of Lehar's The Merry Widow will be audiCenter 55th Street Theater.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Both clothing manufacturers and their striking employes expressed the hope yesterday that today's resumption of negotiations in Washington would lead to a settlement of the nationwide walkout of 110,000 workers in the men's and boys' clothing industry. Top negotiators for the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America are scheduled to meet this afternoon at the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service offices in Washington in a new effort to resolve differences over wages, costofliving adjustments and improved benefits.

title: Soviet Defense Chief Says West Pursues Arms Race
description: MOSCOW, June 5Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, the Soviet Defense Minister, has told a Moscow election rally that the West is pursuing the arms race and the Soviet Union is doing everything necessary to modernize its defense system.

title: In Parkchester, Old Tenants Fear Condominium Plan...
description: Throughout the country, landlords and builders are turning increasingly from rental housing to cooperatives and condominiums, two alternatives that shift the costs and responsibilities of ownership to the consumer. In Forest Hills, a coop plan is viewed as promoting stability. In Parkchester, residents are fighting condominium conversion as a danger to stability. These two articles report on those situations.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Sugar Act Is Killed By House
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The House killed the Sugar Act tonight, freeing the market for the first time in 40 years from Government subsidies, import quotas, and complicated pricing formulas.

title: Mime: Kipnis Vignettes
description: Mime is an ancient art but Claude Kipnis knows very well how to adapt it to today's audience. Bravos, laughter and people filled the house all evening Tuesday when the Claude Kipnis Mime Theater performed at Kaufmann Concert Hall.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 128th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2:13 P.M. (RadioWHN, 2:15 P.M.)

title: BACK OFFICE PLAN TINTED BY BROKEP
description: Hornblower & WeeksHemp hill, Noyes, Inc., indicated yes terday that it hoped it couk combine back office operatiom with another firm.

description: WASHINGTON, June 5The European Space Research Organization announced today in Paris the award of a $226million contract for a reusable space laboratory to be carried aboard the space shuttle now being developed by the United States at a cost of more than $5billion.

description: WASHINGTON, June 5 SenateHouse conferees unani mously approved today a bil revolutionizing the way Congress processes the Fedora?? budget and decides how ?? spend the money.

description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Newark Man Indicted on Tax Count

title: Business Briefs
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 6 (AP)The Federal Government accepted nearly $1.5billion in high bids on 102 tracts of oilrich seabottom off the Texas coast today but rejected bids on 21 other tracts as too low.

title: Aussie Tells of System For Judging
description: Good judging is the concern of every fancier around the world.

title: Goodyear and Oil Shale Plan Scrap Tire Salvage
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Oil Shale Corporation announced yesterday plans for a program to apply the corporation's oil shale technology to recover energy and reusable materials from scrap tires.

title: Saigon Releases Chau, Former Aide Imprisoned as Spy
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 6 Tran Ngoc Chau, a principal architect of the anti  Communist pacification program and a former member of the National Assembly, was temporarily released from prison yesterday, the Saigon Government announced this morning.

title: Veto of MassTransit Bill Seen lithe Cost Runs to $24Billion
description: WASHINGTON, June 5Nixon Administration officials, concerned over inflaton, have told leaders of the House Public Works Committee that they would urge the President to veto a masstransit bill if it provided $24billion over six years.

title: MEDICAID ERRORS ASCRIBED TO CITY
description: ALBANY, June 5 After what he called the most extensive audit ever undertaken of Medicaid administration, the State Social Services Commissioner, Abe Lavine, today reported that New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation had wrongfully charged 527million for hospital services to the stateadministered program.

title: OTB to Take Stakes Bets
description: The city's 128 Offtrack betting offices will take wagers on the Belmont Stakes Aiming at 7 A.M. tomorrow and will continue to accept them until closing at 9 P.M. On Saturday the OTB offices will also open at 7 but will close at 4:30, almost an hour before the race is scheduled to go off. Win, place and show bets at OTB and its telephone betting center will be accepted in denominations of $2, $5, $10, $50 and $100.

title: Corporate and TaxExempt Bond Markets Improve
description: Participation in the corporate and taxexempt markets reported yesterday that a discernibly better tone appeared that was reflected in modest price increases in new and recently marketed obligations. The pace of new offerings slowed from Tuesday's heavy calendar, but specialists reported mostly satisfactory receptions for the few newcomers to market yesterday. They also reported mostly good followup interest in several of Tuesday's offerings.

title: Health Manpower Legislation Is Proposed in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  A Group of prominent Senators introduced today health manpower legislation that would have profound effects on the supply and distribution of American physicians.

title: SEOUL OPENS TRIAL OF OPPOSITIONIST
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 5 Kim Dae Jung, the opposition leader who was kidnapped in Tokyo by South Korean Government agents last August, went on trial in a tumultuous courtroom here today on charges of election violations three years ago.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest percentage gains on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:

title: New Schedules on L.I.R.R. Causing Many Complaints
description: Commuters on the Port Washington branch of the Long Island Railroad have expressed, sharp dissatisfaction with the rushhour service under the new schedules that went into effect May 20. Despite the addition of two new trains since, then, Jarrett Glanz, head of the Great Neck Commuters Committee, reported yesterday that 78 per cent of 1,425 riders responding to a questionnaire continued their complaints.

title: NIXON BROTHERS SAID TO BALK AT INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (??)  President Nixon's two brothers appeared under subpoenas today before staff investigators of the Senate Watergage committee and declined to answer some questions, Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, said.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS POLICY OF DETENTE EARS INTERFERING
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 5President Nixon, who will meet with Soviet leaders in Moscow later this month, declared today that his policy of dtente precluded interference by the United States in the domestic affairs of other nations.

title: THE HOLOCAUST: DID GOD WANT IT?
description: Was it God's will that six million Jews should die in the Holocaust?

title: Wriston's Rate Forecast Spurs Stock Market Gain
description: A prediction by a leading banker that the prime rate would decline sharply by yearend was the main factor in enabling the stock market to finish higher yesterday in slower trading.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Being handicapped in New York City means having to pay more for transportation because you are crippled or 10 times more for telephone service if you are deaf than other consumers pay.

title: Flunking in Art, Student Bests Top Cartoonists
description: A 19yearold Brooklyn student who failed his college drawing class has won the highest award in a cartoon contest, beating some of the nation's leading professional cartoonists.

title: A Jury in Camden to Investigate Police
description: CAMDEN, June 5  The Camden County prosecutor announced today a fullscale grand jury investigation of the Camden Police Department.

title: Dent Describes Economy As House in Good Order
description: Citing 10 basic strengths in the American economy, Secretary of Commerce Frederick B. Dent yesterday told an appareltextile industry audience here that a careful examination shows that our economic house is in good order.

title: COURT HEARS A PLEA ON HOFFA'S RELEASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)  Ah attorney for James R. Hoffa argued in Federal Court today that no President in history had ever imposed the type of condition that was placed on Mr. Hoffa by President Nixon in releasing the former teamster Union chief from jail. The judge took the case under advisement.

title: ARAFAT PRESSING FOR GENEVA ROLE
description: CAIRO, June 5Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine, Liberation Organization, told the movement's representatives here tonight that he was willing to go to the Middle East peace conference in Geneva if the Palestinians gave him a mandate.

title: Smaller Capital Outlay Rises Planned; April Consumer Credit Up $1.5Billion
description: WASHINGTON, June 5Businesses have revised downward somewhat their plans to invest this year in new plants and equipment but they still expect to increase these outlays by 12.2 per cent over the 1973 level.

title: ...but in Forest Hills, Some See. Coop as a Stabilizer
description: Hope, resignation, fatalism and anger were commingled this week among residents of the Forest Hills section of Queens after they had learned that the lowincome housing project that had stirred so much bitter controversy was to become a cooperative. The project will become the first large coop in the nation under a lowrent publichousing program.

title: Oil Concerns Lose Antitrust Clearance
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The Justice Department announced today the termination of a highly controversial clearance given to United States international oil companies to negotiate jointly with oilproducing countries without fear of prosecution under the antitrust laws,

title: A Lawyer Goes on Trial Here, Accused of Theft of Attache Case
description: A prominent Washington lawyer and businessman who had sought to make a forcible exchange of a $600 attach case he had purchased at a midtown shop went on trial in Criminal Court here yesterday on charges of assault, grand larceny and harassment.

title: WORLD IS WARNED ON RESOURCE USE
description: SPOKANE, Wash., June 5World Environment Day was marked at the World's Fair here today with a United Nations spokesman warning that the energy crisis had not brought any international dawn of sanity in the use of resources.

title: Shattered Pattern
description: When a union like the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America calls its first nationwide strike in a halfcentury, the explanation goes beyond the surface fact that dynamic new leaders have taken over from the septuagenarians of the Sidney Hillman era. Murray H. Finley, the new president of this respected union, and Jacob Sheinkman, its general secretary, are both lawyers devoted as their predecessors to its long tradition reliance on the ways of reason and compromise to arrive at settlements fair to workers, manufacturers and the consuming public. That tradition had made the men's clothing industry a model of civilized labormanagement relations.

title: Israelis on Heights Destroy or Remove Material and Forts
description: JERUSALEM, June 5 (AP)Israeli toops dynamited Syrian military installations today in the Golan Heights bulge captured in 1973 and moved equipment behind the new lines delineated in a disengagement of fforces agreement, the Israeli state radio said.

title: Hughes's Office Ransacked on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5A security guard in Howard R. Hughes's Hollywood message center and office building was bound and gagged today by a group of men who then ransacked private papers and opened two safes, where they stole about $60,000.

title: Open Interest
Wholesale Prices Of Coffees Raised By Maxwell House
description: The Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing wholesale prices on its ground, instant and freezedried coffees immediately. The new prices will be 6 cents a pound higher on regular ground coffees, 4 cents a pound on ground decaffeinated and 1 cent an ounce on instant and freezedried coffees.

title: Theater: Love's Labour's Lost  Given in Ontario
description: STRATFORD, Ont., June 6  Things went very awry lastnight at the Festival theater, where the company presented a new production of Shakespeare's Love's Lahour's Lost that only chariity could term adequate.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Rizzo Tax Veto Overridden
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP) By a vote of 12 to 5, the Philadelphia City Council has overridden Mayor Rizzo's veto and approved an increase in real estate taxes. Mr. Rizzo has pledged not to raise taxes during his first administration. The extra revenue will be used to reduce the school budget deficit.

title: Rutgers University To Compensate 210 For Bias on Salary
description: Rutgers University has agreed to pay more than $375,000 in compensation to women and ethnic minoritygroup faculty members who have been receiving lower salaries than their white male colleagues, university and Federal officials said today.

title: Mets Top Reds, 43, on Milner Homer
description: Having been beaten in all five of their previbus meetings with the Reds this season, the Mets yesterday broke that spell with a late rally.

title: Student, 80, at Yeshiva U. Gets M.A. and Now Plans for Ph.D.
description: An assiduous student who received his high school diploma five years ago, at the age of 75, stepped forward yesterday to receive his master's degree in modern Jewish history at Yeshiva University.Manhattan, who celebrated thir second anniversary yesterday by reeciving Ph.D's at the school's main center, at 185th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. At 23, she was the youngest in the university's history to receive a Ph.D. Her degree was in mathematics, her husband's In medical sciences.

title: N.F.L. Clubs Dispel Myths of Big Profits
description: The Management Council of the National Football League, currently engaged in labor negotiations over a new contract with the Players Association, yesterday released data purporting to show that pro football teams do not make as much money as a lot of people, including players, may believe. The 26 N.F.L. teams in 1973, for example, averaged a profit after taxes of $472,500 a club, or 7.6 per cent of total income.

title: Barker Named Coach
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., June 6 (UPI)Richard Barker, a former assistant tennis coach at Texas A&M, will succeed Omar Smith, the retiring head coach the school announced today.

title: AMTRAK ORDERING 200 RAIL COACHES
description: Amtrak, the quasipublic national rail passenger system, said yesterday that it had signed a contract for 200 new passenger cars worth $81million and called it the largest order for intercity rail coaches in this country since 1949.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his May 18 letter, Columbia University Prof. William Vickrey gave faint praise to the current Staggered Work Hours program in Manhattangood as far as it goesand argued strongly instead for the installation of a subway farecollection system which would add a penny a minute to each passenger's fare beginning at 4:15 P.M. and reaching a maximum at 5 o'clock. In weig ping his cause and ours on the scale of practicality, one could easily be persuaded that the Staggered Work Hours program is considerably less complex and has a much greatar immediate payout in red Icing transportation congestion.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Daily News Is Increasing Newsstand Price to 150
description: The newsstand price of The Daily News in the city and suburbs will be increased from 10 to 15 cents on Monday, it was announced yesterday by W. H. James, the paper's president and publisher.

title: Books of The Times
description: EINSTEIN AND THE GENERATIONS OF SCIENCE. By Lewis S. Feuer. 374 pages. Illustrated. Basic Books. $12,95.

title: Woman Vice President of the Auto Union
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6The union and my family have been my life, Odessa Komer, who was elected today as a vice president of the United Automobile Workers, observed after being asked what she did in her spare time.

title: About New York
description: Mrs. Ruth Kaplan got on a bus in Greenwich Village the other day, taking with her a package that held, among other things, her rsum. She was on her way to a job interview at CBS, and after carefully putting the package on the seat next to her, she rode uptown to Broadway and 57th Street, got off the bus and forgetfully left the package behind her.

title: Explanation: Impeachment and National Security
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Early in President Nixon's first term, he and his aides became concerned that investigative agencies such as the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency were incapable of coping with what were perceived as internal threats to the, national security.

title: Miss Wolf Is Bride Of Edwin Chester
description: Miss Sharon Verna Wolf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wolf of Roslyn Heights, L. I., was married last evening to Edwin Paul Chester, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Graham Chester of Shawnee Mission, Kan. The Rev. David C. Brown of the Community Church of East Williston, L.I., performed the ceremony in the gardens of the Old Westbury (L.I.) Golf and Country Club.

title: JUDGE TO RESIGN; CITES LOW SALARY
description: Judge Arnold Bauman, who was named to the United. States District Court for the Southern District of New York in January, 1972, said yesterday that he would resign from his lifetime appointment on Aug. 15 because he could no longer live on his $40,000ayear salary.

title: Giants' Rookie Captures N. C. A. A. Heat
DEMOCRATS STUDY SENATE HOPEFULS
description: Only a week before the Democrat State Committee designates statewide candidates, the contest for the party's nomination for the United States Senate is so unsettled that a designee will not emerge until the fight for the gubernatorial nomination is resolved.

title: CHARLES E. M'CARTHY
description: Charles E. McCarthy, who had served as publicity and advertising director of Paramount Pictures and 20th CenturyFox Films, died, apparently of a heart ailment, at his home in Riverside, Calif., on Tuesday. He was 83 years old.

title: McNamara Exhorts Churchmen to Help Poor Around Globe
description: ASPEN, Colo., June 6 Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, today urged American religious leaders to inspire public support for aid to the poverty stricken around the world.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions

title: The Longest Day Relived in Normandy
description: SAINTE  MERE  EGLISE, France, June 6As so often in Normandy, as on that day exactly 30 years ago, people shivered under rain and a heavy overcast today as they marked the anniversary of the largest landing operation in military history.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
description: June 6, 1974

title: OilCash Recycling Plans Vary
description: PARISThe quadrupling of oil prices at the end of last year has caused economic and financial upheaval in the world. The petroleumexporting nations are accumulating money at a rate that has been put at $6billion a month.

title: Kidnapping Suspect Leads Jersey Police To Two Girls Bodies
description: BRIDGETON, N. J., June 6A 20yearold factory worker was jailed today onmurder charges after he led, the police tothe bodies of two localteenaged girls whose parents had reported them missing in March and April.

title: MUSIC AND MUSINGS BY DIZZY GILLESPIE
description: Dizzy Gillespie, who led big band in the nineteenfifties and a quintet in the sixties, is now down to a quartet this week at the Half Note. These reductions are not necessarily a bad thing because the smaller the group, the more one gets of Mr. Gillespie.

title: OLIVER L. REISER, 78, PHILOSOPHER, DEAD
description: PITTSBURGH, June 6  Dr. Oliver L. Reiser, professor emeritus of philosophy at the University of Pittsburgh and former head of its philosophy department, died today at his home here. He was 78 years old.

title: Donoughmores' Son Offers A Reward in Kidnapping
description: DUBLIN, June 6 (ReutersThe family of the kidnapped Earl and Countess of Donoughmore offered a substantial but unspecified reward today in an effort to break the ominous silence surrounding their disappearance.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS June 6, 1974
description: New York869243

title: EXCONVICT IS KILLED IN OMAHA SHOOTOUT
description: OMAHA, Neb., June 6 (AP) A shotgunwielding former convict was killed by the police today as he emerged from a burning rooming house after shooting to death a policeman and wounding 10 other persons.

title: Advertising: Sip of May Wine
description: Monsieur Henri Wines, and the E. A. Korchnoy, Ltd. ad agencythe powers behind Yago Santgria, the best selling imported wine  are about to put their marketing efforts behind Weber May Wine, available but unpromoted for a dozen years.

title: JURY NAMED NIXON A COCONSPIRATOR BUT DIDN'T INDICT
description: WASHINGTON, June 6President Nixon was named last February by a Watergate grand jury as an unit dicted coconspirator in the alleged attempt to cover up the Watergate burglary, his lawyer, James D. St. Clair, confirmed today.

title: Dow Average Up 15.17 Volume Is Moderate
description: The stock market soared to a 15.17point gain yesterday, prompted by the announcement of a drop in the prime lending rate by a Miami bank and prediction of another decline in this key rate by a leading banker.

title: Syrians and Israelis Storm Airports to Greet P.O.W.'s
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 6Women howled, men old and young wept and fathers kissed bewildered children they had not seen for eight months. The return of 382 Arab prisoners of war today brought thousands of excited Syrians to the airport for a scene of noise and joy.

title: Franklin Withdrawals Slowing
description: Depositors continued to withdraw their money from the troubled Franklin National Bank during the last week, but at a siower rate than previously, the New York Clearing House disclosed yesterday. The bank has now lost nearly onefifth of its deposits in the four weeks since news of its financial losses broke into the open.

title: Stock Index Up 15.17
description: Stock prices soared yesterday, sending the DowJones industrlal average up 15.17 points. The gain was stirred by a drop in the prime lending rate to 11 per cent from, 11 per cent by the First National Bank of Miami. Details on Page 47.

title: HUSBAND INDICTED IN DEATH OF BRIDE
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 6Claudius J. Giesick Jr., the husband of the New Jersey bride, who died under bizarre circumstances on her honeymoon in New Orleans in midJanuary, and Samuel Corey, who performed the couple's marriage, ceremony, were indicted on, seconddegree murder charges by an Orleans Parish grand jury here today. It deliberated less than five minutes.

title: Kissinger Reassures Soviet. Of Continued Mideast Role
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Secretary of State Kissinger tried today to reassure Soviet leaders about their continuing role in the Middle East.

title: Kissinger Again Denies Initiating Taps
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Secretary of State Kissinger, repeatedly questioned today about Watergate at his first news conference since the successful Middle East negotiations, denied again, that he, had played a direct role in the wiretapping of his aides and insisted anew that he had had no knowledge of the White House plumbers operation.

title: Court Voids Jersey Agency's Gag Rule
description: TRENTON, June 6A threejudge Federal court today struck down a State Health Depart. ment regulation governing the public statements of its officials on the ground that it was an overly broad restraint of freedom of speech.

title: Rangers Win as Johnson Haunts Indians With Bat
description: Alex Johnson, who played for Cleveland two seasons ago, came back to haunt his former teammates last night in Municipal Stadium.

title: Capital of Cambodia Is Quiet Despite Fears of More Protests
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Tune 6With high schools and universities closed and about 103 student protesters still in jail, Phnom Penh remained devoid of student demonstrations today. But diplomats, Government officials and even some students wondered which way the protests would turn next.

title: In Bhutan, Both Reunion and Tension
description: THIMBU, Bhutan, June 6 Like a feudal court drama, the coronation of the 18yearold King of Bhutan has reunited the divided royal family, but at the same time tensions have been stirred by violent threats to the monarchy.

title: Guide GOIN OUT
description: SENTIMENTAL Shortly after World War II the big bands were through. Benny Goodman, Harry James, Woody Herman, Les Brown, Jack Teagarden, Benny Carter, Ina Ray Hutton and Tommy Dorsey all announced in December, 1946, that for each it was over, Mr. Dorsey got a group together a little later, but the Sentimental Gentleman of Swing had already made most of his history.

title: DR. JEROME WEINSTOCK
description: Dr. Jerome A. Weinstock, assistant professor of philosophy at Lehman College of the City University, died of complications of arteriosclerosis yesterday in Maimonides Hospital. He was 30 years old and lived at 3840 Orloff Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Striking Cabbies Jam Newark Traffic
description: NEWARK, June 6Several dozen striking Newark cab drivers snarled downtown traffic during this evening's rush hour as part of their attempt to win from taxi owners a decrease in rental fees.

title: India Rushes Health Teams Into Smallpox Epidemic Zone
description: NEW DELHI, June 6A spokesman for the Ministry of Health said here today that several teams of health officials and workers had, been sped to Bihar and adjoining states in an effort to control a smallpox epidemic that has killed 15,000 people. The Indian officials are assisted by experts from the World Health Organization.

title: Blanche Yurka, Actress, Dead; Rose to Stardom in Wild Duck
description: Blanche Yurka, the Broadway star whose acting career spanned more than half a century, died yesterday of arteriolosclerosis at Mount Sinai Hospital. Miss Yurka, who was 86 years old, lived at 325 East 72d Street.

title: Ballet: Worth the Wait
description: The 300seat Newman Theater of Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival is obviously a small house. But the new Eliot Feld Ballet has done so well there in its debut season that it will perform for five weeks in place of the scheduled three.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: FICTION
description: A Silence in Bilbao, by Margare Shedd (Doubleday, $6,95), The Basque nationalists against the Spanish police.

title: McNamara Exhorts Churchmen to Help Poor Around Globe
description: ASPEN, Colo., June 6 Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, today urged American religious leaders to inspire public support for aid to the poverty stricken around the world.

title: N.Y.U. GRADUATES 2,300 IN GARDEN
description: New York University graduated more than 7,500 students yesterday at its 142d commencement exercises.

title: Premier's Party in Tel Aviv Swept Aside by Prisoners Surging From Aircraft
description: TEL AVIV, June 6  More than 1,000 men, women and children swept past airport barriers today to welcome 56 Israeli prisoners before they could get off the plane that brought them from Syria.

title: JOHN A. KEBLER
description: John Armstrong Kebler, retired chairman of the board of the Ward Leonard Electric Company of Mount Vernon, N.Y., died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 50 years old and lived at 33 Homesdale Road in Bronxville.

title: Prospects for Fishing In Surrounding Waters
description: AREA ABlues and striped bass are abundant near the top of the waters outside Barnegat Inlet, keeping fishermen with bucktails and plugs busy. Blues ranging from 7 to 12 pounds are being caught in large numbers at the Ridge and the Klondike with bunker backs and smelts. Although it is a bit early in the season for fluke, the warming waters have produced some catches of up to 3 pounds with smelt, squid and fluke belly as bait. Live shrimp are attracting weakfish from 2 to 8 pounds in Barnegat Bay, where occasional striped bass are also showing up. Surf fishing is generally slow, although near Seaside Park, N.J., some blues and striped bass up to 20 have been taken on the diamond jigs.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., June 6They call Seton Hall's baseball team the Mighty Mites, but perhaps Stealers or BaseRobbers would be more appropriate.

title: Kissinger Holds Reception For NATO Parliamentarians
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Secretary of State Kissinger held lavish reception this evening for parliamentarians of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to make amertds, as he said, for the altercations he caused in the Atlantic Alliance earlier this year.

title: BOND PRICES RISE IN LATE TRADING
description: Prices of Federal, state and localgovernment issues as well as corporate bonds all rose smartly in late trading yesterday, with some Treasury issues advanced by nearly a point.

title: Burden of Oil Money Worries Bankers
description: WILLIAMSBURG, June 6Two leading Bankers expressed deep reservations today over how long the international banking network could carry the burden of recycling th?? vast flows of money resulting from the huge jump in oil prices.

title: Rutgers Compensates
description: Rutgers University has agreed to pay more than $375,000 in compensation to women and ethnic minority faculty members who have been receiving lower salaries than their white male colleagues. It was said to be the largest such payment made by any university in the nation. Page 39.

title: City U. Graduate Center Hears Plea to Back Soviet Dissenters
description: Richard C. Wade, the historian, pleaded with the academic community yesterday to demand freedom for dissenting Soviet scholars.

title: Bronx Man, 77, Slain in Effort To Save Wife From an Assault
description: A 77yearold retired businessman was shot to death yesterday when he came to the aid of his 70yearold wife, who was being gunwhipped by two men in their home in the Wakefield section of the Bronx.

title: DIP IN PRIME RATE BUOYS THE AMEX
Industry Sees Price Rises
description: Sugar industry sources predicted here yesterday that the defeat for the Sugar Act by the House of Representatives would tend to increase sugar prices, already on the rise. However, there was some conjecture, particularly among sugar brokers, that Congress would pass compromise legislation that would protect sugar producers.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 2.9 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 219.8 from 216.9 last week.

title: Crafts: Collections and Obsessions
description: Crafts collectors, it seems, will give up just about anything if it means getting an object they covet.

title: 900 Frenchmen Say Thanks Here on 30th Anniversary of Allied Invasion
description: More than 900 Frenchmen and women gathered at the foot of the Statue of Liberty yesterday to commemorate the 30th anniversary of DDay, which opened the Allied invasion of France in World War II.

title: Lord Arlen Suffolk Victor
description: BOSTON, June 6 (AP)Lord Arlen, ridden by Don Meade, won the featured $5,000 allowance race by 2lengths today before 6,616 fans at Suffolk Downs. He paid $4.20 to win.

title: Bridge:
description: A pleasant surprise for the American contingent in Venice last month was the striking victory of the American women's team over the Italian world champion women's team.

title: Data on Politicians Traced To Wiretaps for Security
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The White House obtained some political information about President Nixon's opponents but no evidence of national security leaks from 17 wiretaps secretly undertaken in 1969 against Government officials and reporters, members of the House Judiciary Committee disclosed today.

title: Knightly Way Dies At Westbury Track
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 6 (UPI)Knightly Way, richest and fastest threeyearold trotter of 1973, died today at Roosevelt Raceway of undetermined causes.

title: Saigon Offers Concessions To Vietcong for New Talks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 7The Saigon Government announced tonight that it was restoring the diplomatic privileges of the Vietcong delegation hereincluding access to the pressin the interest of a new start for the frozen talks on carrying out the ceasefire.

title: Olivieri Off and Running For Lieutenant Governor
description: Assemblyman Antonio G. Olivieri, who has been roving the state for a year in search Of support for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, formally announced his candidacy yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Apparently fearing a chemical explosion, the police removed 200 people from their houses near a tunnel in Haverstraw, N.Y., where a Penn Central freight train derailed and caught fire yesterday. They also closed State Route 9W, which runs through Haverstraw on the west bank of the Hudson River, about 15 miles north of New York City.

title: Lord Arlen Suffolk Victor
description: BOSTON, June 6 (AP)Lord Arlen, ridden by Don Meade, won the featured $5,000 allowance race by 2lengths today before 6,616 fans at Suffolk Downs. He paid $4.20 to win.

title: Woman Gets Rights Post
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)  Patricia Sullivan Lindh, a Republican national committeewoman from Louisiana who has been active in the equal rights movement, was named today as White House special assistant in charge of women's programs. She will take over a post vacated last March by Jill Ruckelshaus.

title: Some Shocking Revelations, With Oodles of True Facts, About GoingsOn at Colleges!
description: In August, 1941, I was, drafted after my junior year of college and didn't go back to a college until recently. What I went back for was to make a documentary film for television.

title: Slater, Walker Securities Sells 2 German Holdings
description: LONDON, June 6  Slater, Walker Securities, Ltd., the London financial house that considers cash the best investment at present, has sold more of its holdings.

title: F.B.I. Theorizes Schlam Himself or Father Administered the Drugs
description: The Justice Department is leaning toward the belief that the drugs that made Assistant United States Attorney Peter R. Schlam ill during the trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo were selfadministered or were administered by his physician father.

title: Schlam: Eager to Succeed
description: Peter R. Schlam's ambition was to be a trial attorneygetting at the facts, finding witnesses and winning his case brilliantly in the courtroom.

title: Court Rules 18YearOlds Must Be Given Police Jobs
description: TRENTON, June 6  The State Suupreme Court today explicitly lowered the minimum age for a policeman in New Jersey from 21 years to 18 years.

title: Allman Brothers Open Summer Pop Season
description: Resistance by townships, property owners and law enforcement officials has limited the number of postWoodstock outdoor rock festivals of the 300,000people sort. But lessambitious events, both outdoors and indoors, still abound, and the New Jersey summer pop season will get under way tonight and tomorrow night with concerts by the Allman Brothers Band at the Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City.

title: JUDGE IS CRITICAL OF RIGHTS LAWYER
description: A United States District Court judge has attacked what he calls a deliberate attempt to downplay the role of blacks in the history of public school integration.

title: Red Smith
description: Having an Illusion shattered is never a pleasant experience, and it is especially painful when someone or something near and dear is involved, like the woman a guy lives with or the newspaper he works for. Thus the discovery that the dear old New York Times, that citadel of exactitude, could err in the field of baseball history came as a blow yesterday. While it is true that the Old Lady of Fortythird Street has never claimed infallibility in matters of faith or morals, it was the devout belief that she couldn't possibly be wrong in an area where records are preserved and venerated like the bones of a saint.

title: Campus Ground Broken At Manhattan Community
description: In an unusual ceremony combining an academic commencemont and the groundbreaking for a new campus, the Borough of Manhattan Community College presented 1,685 degrees yesterday inside a colorful, 5,000seat circus tent pitched at the foot of Chambers Street, at the Hudson River.

title: The New European Leaders
description: In his latest press conference, Secretary of State Kissinger took a somewhat more optimistic line about future relationship between the United States and Europe, an?? said, that President Nixon was planning to meet soon with the new leaders of Britain, France and West Germany.

title: Kissinger Reassures Soviet Of Continued Mideast Role
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Secretary of State Kissinger tried today to reassure Soviet leaders about their continuing role in the Middle East.

title: Executive's Kidnapped Wile Freed, $60,000 Ransom Back
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP) Mrs. Annette Friedland, wife of the president of the Food Fair supermarket chain, was kidnapped today from her Main Line estate by three gunmen. She was released unharmed three hours later.

title: Satellite Launched on Coast
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 6 (UPI)  A satellite was launched today aboard a Titan 3B Agena combination at the Air Force Space and Missile Test Center, No other details were released by the Air Force.

title: Sperry Rand Lifts Dividend
description: Directors of the Sperry Rand Corporation declared yesterday an increase in the quarterly dividenud to 19 cents a share of common stock from the current 161 cents a share. The holders of record July 1. Sperry dividend is payable Aug. 15 to raise its quarterly dividend 1 cents a year ago.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.7 billion tonmiles, 1.2 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period, which included the Memorial Day holiday, totaled 491,767 cars, 2.2 per cent below the corresponding holiday week of 1973. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 2.1 per cent below last year.

title: TROOP OUT ABROAD BARRED IN SENATE; MANSFIELD LOSES
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The Senate today rejected proposals for reducing the number of American troops overseas, giving the Nixon Administration a major foreign policy victory.

title: NOW Attacks VolunteerismBut Others Rally, to Its Defense
description: Volunteerism, a cornerstone of the American way of life, is under fire. A number of feminists believe that volunteer labor for all social services is km extension of unpaid household work and that the practice reinforces economic dependence of women by preventing them from earning money of their own.

title: OUTCRY REPORTED ON NIXON STYLE
description: Representative Elizabeth Holtzman told a graduating class of 5,839 and their relatives and friends at Brooklyn College yesterday that an outcry had been raised about President Nixon's intellectual style and that it was heartening.

title: People in Sports
description: Despite the fact that some of the things she hears at World Team Tennis matches are not so flattering, Mrs. Billie Jean King said yesterday she liked the enthusiasm shown by crowds attending W. T. T. matches.

title: HUSBAND INDICTED IN DEATH OF BRIDE
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 6Claudius J. Giesick Jr., the husband of the New Jersey bride who died under bizarre circumstances on her honeymoon in New Orleans in midJanuary, and Samuel Corey, who performed the couple's marriage ceremony, were indicted on seconddegree murder charge by an Orleans Parish grand jury here today. It deliberated less than five minutes.

title: FRANK M'KENNETT
description: Frank McKennett, a retired International Business Machines Corporation employe who led the development in the nineteenthirties of the proof machine that sorted, listed, endorsed and proved bank checks, died Tuesday in Nassau Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 4 Mulford Place, Hempstead.

title: Budget Revolution
description: Two ill windsthe worst inflation in this country's peacetime history and the overweening growth of Presidential powerappear to be blowing some good by way of Congressional reform. SenateHouse conferees have unanimously approved a bill that would revolutionize the way Congress deals with Federal spending and taxes.

title: Gulag, in Huge Quantity, Goes to the Stores Early
description: Almost 2 minion copies, an usually high number, of The Gulag Archipelago by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn have been printed and are being distributed to stores around the country, Harper & Row, the publishers, said yesterday. Thousands of copies have already appeared on retailers' shelves although the formal publication date is June 24.

title: $375,000 Will Be Given By Rutgers for Bias in Pay
description: Rutgers University has agreed to pay more than $375,000 in compensation to women and ethnic minoritygroup faculty members who have been receiving lower salaries than their white male colleagues, university and Federal officials said today.

title: Detective Leuci Weaving Complex Web
description: At 5 P.M. on May 28, Federal Judge Arnold Bauman received a letter from Paul J. Curran, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, summing up information that Detective Robert Leuci had given Federal prosecutors in the last month about corruption in the Police Department's narcotics division before 1971.

title: GOVERNMENT ROLE IN OIL QUESTIONED
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Executives of two major international oil companies, Mobil and Exxon, told Congress today that the Government would be unable to negotiate cheaper or more secure crude oil supplies than the companies arrange if it supplanted them in dealings with foreign producing countries.

title: President's Grip Found Looser on Bureaucracy
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Last Jan. 2, President Nixon signed a bill to establish an eightmember board to conduct an emergency study of failing railroads in the Northeast and make recommendations to the Government by Oct. 29.

title: Westchester Builder Offers Tax Cuts
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, N. Y., June 6 A builder tonight proposed a solution to the commonly voiced suburban objection to a new housing development: that it will impose insupportable school tax burdens on the community.

title: Bold Poetry by Voznesensky Electrifies S.R.O. Moscow Crowd
description: MOSCOW, June 6Even before it began, the evening had the earmarks of a special event.

title: 8 Reported Killed by Tornado in Arkansas Town
description: FORREST CITY, Ark., June 6 A tornado tore through sections of this eastern Arkansas town toni ght, and a deputy sheriff said eight, persons had been killed. At least 200 persons were reported injured.

title: Malaysia's Top Policeman Shot to Death in His Car
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Friday, June 7 (AP)Malaysia's Itop policeman, Abdul Rahman Hashim, was shot to death last night as he rode in his official car in downtown Kuala Lumpur, the police said today.

title: William Bittman Quits Law Firm in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 William O. Bittman, the first defense attorney for the Watergate conspirator E. Howard Hunt Jr. and the former Government prosecutor who won convictions of James R. Hoffa and Robert G. Baker, has resigned from his sevenyear partnership in one of Washington's largest law firms, Hogan & Hartson.

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT LIMITS VOICE PRINTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals here ruled today that voiceprints could not be introduced as evidence in criminal trials. It was the first Federal appellate ruling on voiceprints.

title: Time Hides All but the Memories of DDay
description: In 1945, the first year after, it was still recognizably real.

title: PAN AM AND T.W.A. FAIL ON AN ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines announced today the collapse of their Governmentapproved talks on consolidation of some or all their transAtlantic services.

title: Plan Weighed for Loans Against Monetary Gold
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 6A new idea for making use of the world's presently immobilized monetary reserves of gold has surfaced at the international monetary conference here. It may be agreed upon next week in Washington at the meeting of finance ministers of the Committee of 20 nations negotiating world monetary reform.

title: Jury's Action: What It Means to Nixon and 6 Defendants
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The naming of Richard M. Nixon as an unindicted coconspirator in the Watergate coverup is not, legally, the intrinsically significant act that his indictment would be Unlike an indictment, it gives President Nixon no new clearcut rights and duties, no right, to a trial, for instance, no duty to plead to the accusations.

title: President's Grip Found Looser on Bureaucracy
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Last Jan. 2, President Nixon signed a bill to establish an eightmember board to conduct an emergency study of failing railroads in the Northeast and make recommendations to the Government by Oct. 29.

title: Squatters Carry Protest To Cathedral of St. John
description: About 40 of the 200 squatters who, for four years, have been occupying a group of tenements owned by Morningside House, Inc., in Morningside Heights, sat in last night at the Bishop's house at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, demanding the intervention of the Episcopal Bishop in the squatters' battle against eviction from the tenements.

title: Fee Fund Reported For Nixon ExAides
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The Senate Watergate committee has heard secret testimony alIeging that Charles G. Rebozo controlled a $400,000 fund that could be used to underwrite the legal defense of President Nixon's two former highest aides, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: TRANSPORT STRIKE SET IN ITALY TODAY
description: ROME, June 6The transport workers' unions will stage a fourhour walkout tomorrow morning that will bring traffic to a standstill throughout Italy and cut off the country front the outside world.

title: Barker Named Coach
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., June 6 (UPI)Ridhard Barker, a former assistant tennis coach at Texas A&M, will succeed Omar Smith, the retiring head coach the school announced today.

title: Weiskopf Courses Too Easy
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June 6 Shortly after John Schlee took the firstround lead in the IVBPhiladelphia golf classic with a sixunderpar 66 at the Whitemarsh Valley Country Club today, Toni Weiskopf, winner of the tourney last year, strongly criticized this course in particular and the professional tour courses in general for being too easy.

title: Spain On The Brink
description: MADRIDLong lines of people are forming these days in the Paseo del General Martinez Campos to see the new Carlos Saura movie, La Primera Angelica, at the Cine Amaya. The film is about a man's recollections of the Spanish Civil War, and of the families broken along the sharp political lines of that time; it deals frankly with a boy's sexual awakening and it has some satirical scenes about the Falange, the official party of Francisco Franco's insurgency in the 1930's.
