title: Detective Leuci Weaving Complex Web in Role as Undercover Agent Investigating Police Corruption
description: At 5 P.M. on., May 28, Fed eral Judge Arnold Bauman received a letter from Paul J. Curran, the United States At torney for the Southern District of New York, summing up information that Detective Robert Leuci had given Fed era! prosecutors in the last month about corruption in the Police Department's narcotics division before 1971.

title: GRACE SPOFFORD, 87, WAS MUSIC DIRECTOR
description: Grace N. Spofford, director emeritus of the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement, died Wednesday in Amsterdam House. She was 87 years old.

title: Data on Politicians Traced To Wiretaps for Security
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The White House obtained some political information about President Nixon's opponents but no evidence of national security leaks from 17 wiretaps secretly undertaken in 1969 against Government officials and reporters, members of the House Judiciary Committee disclosed today.

title: Trade Bill Rider Studied
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Supporters of sugarcontrol legislation seemed stunned today following their surprise defeatin the House of Representatives but determined to find ways to fight back, and their opponents were under no illusion that they had scored a knockout.

title: Swiftly Changing Fashions Cost Jobs
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 6Sharon Baker of Canton, Ohio, used to make women's suits. Now she makes pants, blouses, skirts, tops, jackets and other odd pieces that customers can pick off a store rack and put together as they will. It's fashion, she explained. It seems to be changing faster and faster, so no one knows where she is at these days. Not the customer or the manufacturer. It hurts us because if you don't catch it right, you lose. If we don't fill an order and ship it out right away, we're stack with it. No one will want to buy it.

title: LEGISLATOR FINDS 2 TERMS ENOUGH
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Representative Walter E. Powell, an Ohio Republican who once said he wished to spend 30 years in Congress, is retiring from the House in disillusionment at the age of 43, when many politicians are just starting a career.

title: The Pop Life
description: Anybody over the age of 19 who goes to a rock concert must feel like an explorer who has stumbled upon some alien mass tribal celebration. Concerts remain a preserve of teenagers, and when you ask young people why they go to them, they are as likely to give you sociological answersit's what everybody doesas musical ones.

title: Oil and Money
description: The petroleum exporting nations are accumulating money at a rate of $6billion a month. A number of plans have been offered to recycle their surplus funds into productive uses to avoid reductions in consumption and even a world recession. Details on Page 49.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Rockwell International Corporation received a $12.5million Navy contract for navigation equipment for nuclear submarines.

title: Theater Parley Has a Happy Ending
description: PRINCETON, N.J., June 6Although it was spontaneous and unrehearsed and had an enormous divisive cast of characters, FACT, the First American Congress of Theater, assumed the shape of dramathree acts (days) of rising and falling action, which ended, happily, yesterday with a demonstration of serious concern about mutual survival.

title: Chapter X Motion Delayed On Interstate Stores, Inc.
description: A motion by bank lenders and some investors in Interstate Stores, Inc., to transfer the retail chain into Chapter X bankruptcy proceedings was adjourned here yesterday for one week by Federal Judge John M. Cannella to permit him to review a report from the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Town Votes Impeachment
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 6 (AP)By a town meeting vote of 218 to 31, citizens of this western Massachusetts community called last night for the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: City College Graduates Its First Open Enrollees
description: City College awarded degrees yesterday to its first openadmissions graduates, and Dr. Robert E. Marshak, the college's president, declared that the City University's admission policy had made free higher education in this city broader and richer than ever before.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Inflation Termed Near Crisis Stage
description: A panel that included nine prominent economists warned yesterday that inflation in the United States and the rest of the world was approaching the crisis stage. They also said that the prospective rate of inflation over the next several years posed an overriding threat to economic, social and political stability in the developed world.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: San Carlos, Calif.Ray Lunny 3d. 134 pounds, Redwood City, Calif?? outpointed Miguel Mayon, 135, San Diego, 10 rounds.

title: Two School Guards Shifted After Fight
description: Two security guards at Benjamin Franklin High School in East Harlem were temporarily transferred yesterday after a fight with a student on Wednesday over whether he had displayed proper identification for admittance to the building.

title: Critique of System Is Singapore Best Seller
description: SINGAPORE, June 6A book that calls Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew dictatorial and says his rule in Singapore is reminiscent of Mussolini's Italy has soared to the top of Singapore's bestseller list. The Prime Minister reportedly allowed the book into the country as a conscious attempt to rebut one of its thesesthat freedom of expression has been stifled.

title: OUTLOOK UNCLEAR ON OIL TAX DEVICE
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The outlook for repeal of the oil depletion allowance became uncertain today, as warring factions in the House of Representatives reached an impasse on the procedures for considering the measure.

title: Stock Index Up 15.17
description: Stock prices soared yesterday, sending the DowJones industrial average up 15.17 points. The gain was stirred by a drop in the prime lending rate to 11 per cent from 11 per, cent by the First National Bank of Miami. Details on Page 47.

title: 20 Firemen Are Hurt In South Bronx Blaze
description: Twenty firemen were hurt, eight of them seriously, in a burning sixtory tenement in the South Bronx last night.

title: STATE G.O.P. SEEKS TO FILL OUT SLATE
description: State Republican leaders are considering the possibility of seeking candidates in such nonpolitical fields as education or business in an effort to complete a strong ticket, Richard M. Rosenbaum, the state party chairman, said yesterday.

title: Labor Nominee Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Jane 6 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Betty Southard Murphy of Annandale, Va., to be administrator of the Wage and Hour Division in the Labor Department.

title: Notes on People
description: Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the 59yearold Army Chief of Staff, yesterday underwent surgery for lung cancer at Washington's Walter Reed Army Medical Center and it was announced afterward that all visible evidence of the malignancy has been removed. The operation lasted four hours, a spokesman said, and General Abrams tolerated surgery well. Asked whether the malignancy had spread from its base in the left lung, the spokesman said some was seen in local lymph nodes and removed. The general, described as a moderate cigar smoker, entered Walter Reed on May 23. Before moving into his job in the Pentagon, he had served as commander of United States forces in Vietnam at the peak of this country's involment there.

title: SEOUL GUNNERS FIRE ON U.S. HELICOPTER
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 6 (AP)South Korean antiaircraft gunners fired on a United States Army helicopter flying over Seoul today and wounded two officers, the United States Army said.

title: Texaco Raises Prices For Variety of Fuels
description: Texaco, Inc., said yesterday it was increasing wholesale prices of diesel and tractor fuels, home heating and residual fuel oils, effective immediately. The company added that no changes in wholesale gasoline prices were expected at this time.

title: The Last Rite of Spring: Bible Schools in the South
description: CHARLESTON, Ark., June 4A piano deep inside the First Free Will Baptist Church sounded the opening chords of Onward Christian Soldiers at 8:35 A.M., five minutes late.

title: CAPTAIN CLEARED OF BRIBE CHARGE
description: MORRISTOWN, June 6 After 55 hours of deliberation, Capt. Joseph M. Esposito, the chief of detectives in Paterson, was acquitted today of accepting bribes to protect a gambling operation.

title: Santarelli Speech, Assailed by Police, Led to F.B.I. Check
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The Federal Bureau of Investigation made inquiries about what Donald E. Santarelli, a Justice Department official who has resigned, said in a speech at Williamsburg, Va., last January.

title: JURY NAMED NIXON A COCONSPIRATOR BUT DIDN'T INDICT
description: WASHINGTON, June 6President Nixon was named last February by a Watergate grand jury as an unindicted coconspirator in the alleged attempt to cover up the Watergate burglary, his lawyer, James D. St, Clair, confirmed today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 7, 1974

title: Aid for Blind Venders
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) The Senate Labor Committee has approved a bill to provide that 25 per cent of the proceeds of automatic vending machines in Federal buildings be used to aid blind persons who operate stands in the buildings. Sponsors said the automatic machines had taken away much of the business that formerly went to the blind venders.

title: Retail Milk Cost to Drop 2 Cents a Quart July 1
description: TRENTON, June 6 (AP) The state announced today that retail milk prices would decrease 2 cents a quart on July 1, the, second decrease in two months.

title: St. Clair Says Subpoena Filed By Ehrlichman Is Too Broad
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 The White House moved today to quash what it termed a broad spectrum subpoena for national security documents filed last week by John D. Ehrlichman, one of four defendants in the plumbers case.

title: Business Briefs
description: Spokesmen for Texaco; Inc., and the Standard Oil Company of California said yesterday their oil production in Nigeria had been halted by the Nigerian Government on May 8.

title: RETAIL SALES RISE AT 15MONTH HIGH
description: Business in the city's biggest department stores in May recorded its largest monthly gain in 15 months, continuing strong spring uptrend after more than a year of erratic consumer shopping.

title: F.C.C. Asked to Review Transfer of TV Antennas
description: The Port of New York Authority has petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to reconsider its decision of April 30 to grant eight New Yorkarea television stations permission to move their transmitters and antennas to the World Trade Center. The petition argues that to save the expense of moving all the stations, including the six that received conditional grants, the commission should designate a mode for only two of the station, so that tests could be run to determine whether television reception was substantially improved by their move from the Empire State Building to the taller towers of thetrade center.

title: The Grand Jury's Vote
description: Confirmation that the Federal grand jury which indicted seven White House campaign aides last March also voted unanimously to name President Nixon as a coconspirator in the Watergate coverup represents another shock for a nation that has had too many.

title: Clothing Negotiators Relume Talks Over Issue of Money
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, June 7Representatives of the striking Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and of the men's clothing industry resumed negotiations yesterday under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in an effort to settle the fourdayold strike, which involves 110,000 workers.

title: Market Place: The Big Board And Dumping
description: It seemed to be almost an afterthought. Here was the New York Stock Exchange responding to the most critical problem on the trading floor in this generation with the appointment of an advisory committee to look into the impact of institutions On the market and doing it, in the words of the Big Board's chairman, James J. Needham, in the interest of all investors  large and small.

title: 2 Americans in British Golf Quarterfinal
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 6 (AP)  Jimmy Gabrielsen and John C. Owens beat fellow Americans in impressive style today and charged into the quarterfinals of the British amateur golf champion

title: RETAIL SALES RISE AT 15MONTH HIGH
description: Business in the city's biggest department stores in May recorded its largest monthly gain in 15 months, continuing a strong spring uptrend after more than a year of erratic consumer shopping.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Big 8, Orange Bowl Reach Accord

title: 12 Named to Race in Belmont; Cordero's Suspension Upheld
Governors Elect Rampton
description: SEATTLE, June 6 (AP)Gov. Calvin L. Rampton of Utah, a Democrat serving his third fouryear term, was elected yesterday as chairman of the National Governors Conference. He succeeds Dan Evans, a Republican from Washington, under the conference policy that rotates the annual chairmanship between the two parties.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Congress May Act Against Budget Unit In Rift Over Agency
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) A threat of Congressional retaliation has been raised against a Federal agency that stripped the Customs Service of its major responsibility for combating narcotics smugglers.

title: TROOP CUT ABROAD BARRED IN SENATE MANSFIELD LOSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The Senate today rejected proposals for reducing the number of American troops overseas, giving the Nixon Administration a major foreign policy victory.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: San Carlos, Calif.Ray Lunny 3d, 134 pounds, Redwood City, Calif., outpointed Miguel Mayon, 135, San Diego, 10 rounds.

title: April Deficit Grew From YearAgo $39Million
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 More than twice as many New York Stock Exchange member firms lost money during April as showed a profit, James J. Needham, the Big Board's chairman, said today after a meeting of the exchange's directors.

title: Drivers Test Reaction At Roosevelt
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 6 At 7:55 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, Carmine Abbatiello stepped into the sulky behind Adum, a 3yearold pacer, and said, Boy, I wish I had some ear plugs now.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The Department of Commerce re ported today that departmen store sales last week were at estimated $981million, up 1] per cent from the yearearlier $886million. Total retail stort sales were about $10.289billion up 6 per cent from last year's $9.739billion.

title: EASTMET PLANS A LATROBE OFFER
description: The Eastmet Corporation of Baltimore, Md., will make cash tender offer for at least 51 per cent of the common stock of the Latrobe Steel Company. Directors met after the close of the market and approved the proposal. J. J. Zeren, financial vice president, said terms would not be made until today when the company files a statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: He Sings for His Supper During Yours
description: I'm of two minds about Onde's, at 945 Second Avenuea lunch mind and a dinner mind, the latter marked by a certain unease as the result of a temperamental vagary all my own.

title: E.E.C. Won't Seek Higher Gold Price
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 6 The European Common Market, in a conciliatory gesture toward the United States, decided today against pressing its case for a higher official gold price at international monetary meetings in Washington next week.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Metropolitan Opera's season of eight free concerts in the city's parks will begin June 25 with a performance of Puccini's Turandot on the Sheep Meadow in Central Park. All together, there will be, four performances of Turandot and four of Puccini's La Bohme.

title: Bomb Hurts Postal Worker
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., June 6 (AP)  A postal employe was injured last night by an explosion in Lubbock's main post office. Investigators say they believe the blast may have been set off by a pipe bomb in a parcel post package. The injured employe, Humberto Hernandez, 25 years old, was treated at a hospital for cuts on his face and neck and released.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Church Group Names New General Secretary
description: The executive committee of the Consultation on Church Union announced yesterday the election of the Rev. Dr. Gerald F. Made as general secretary.

title: Rangers Will Get Sanderson In Deal With Bruins, Seals
description: Derek Sanderson, once described by the Rangers' coach as a little S.O.B., but I'd love to have him, will be coming to the Rangers, a team once promised a bounty if they could beat him up.

title: End of Foreign Aid
description: America's future role in the world would be hetter served if the phrase foreign aid could be dispensed with. Outmoded in its origins and implications, the notion thus expressed gives a misleading impression.

title: Higher Moral Value Urged at Richmond College
description: Decrying the selfcontradiction of building a society on division and selfinterest, Dr. Timothy W. Costello, president of Adelphi Universty, called last night for a new age of values at the sixth commencement of Richmond College on Staten Island.

title: Effects of Open Admission Stir New Dispute at City U.
description: Four years after dropping its meritadmissions system to guarantee entrance to all of the city's highschool graduates, the City University this week is conferring degrees on the first class it received under its historic openadmissions policy.

title: The Screen:' Herbie' Rides Again to Defend Landmarks
description: Walt Disney Productions' "Herbie Rides Again," which opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, is a movie that takes a firm stand for the defense of architectural landmarks and against real estate developers like mean, greedy Alonzo Hawk (Keenan Wynn), the sort of man who, when he sees Rome's Colosseum, dreams of replacing it with a shopping center.The problem with comedies as witless as this is that the villains are much more appealing than the good guys. One winds up rooting for the fellows who would tear down the Plaza to put up a 100-story, glass-and-brass breadstick."Herbie Rides Again" is set in San Francisco and in that never-never land suggested by bad trick photography, when foreground objects have no visible relation to backgrounds. The film brings back the leading character of that earlier Disney box-office smash, "The Love Bug." Herbie, a 1963 Volkswagen sedan, is as bright and stanch as Lassie and 20 times as fast.In the course of the movie he has a major part in the successful campaign of a Nice Little Old Lady, to ward off Alonzo Hawk's wreckers to save her home; an old firehouse on top of a San Francisco hill.As played by Helen Hayes, the Nice Little Old Lady seems to be ineligible for sainthood only because of a minor technicality: she's still alive. She won't hear ill of anyone, she sees good in almost everything and she is able to converse with inanimate objects that, in addition to Herbie, include a retired San Francisco cable car and an ancient, upright music box.The film was directed by Robert Stevenson and written by Bill Walsh, who also collaborated on "Mary Poppins" and "The Love Bug." There's nothing harmful about "Herbie Rides Again"; it's simply not very good. All the technical and economic resources of the Disney empire cannot bring sincerity to a machine-made paean in praise of little-guy pluck.Of course, I felt the same way about "The Love Bug" and it earned $21-million in the United States alone. "Herbie Rides Again" may make only $15-million.

title: Proxmire Calls U.S. Banking Envy of the free World
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)  Senator William Proxmire said today that the American banking system is the envy of the free world.

title: Saving Power
description: Relieving the demand for electricity in New York City and Westchester is as important a contribution to the area's energy problems as increasing the supply. Awaiting action by the state Public Service Commission is massive report on energy conservation prepared over the last eighteen months by retired Commissioner William K. Jones; it calls for farreaching restrictions to reduce electricity consumption, at least until more secure and efficient means of generating it can be found.

title: People and Business.
description: Abe Fortas Former Supreme Court Justice said at a meeting of the Conference Board in New York yesterday that when negotiated rates in the securities industry become fully effective in April 1975, there will be an even greater rash of failures and consolidations in the brokerage business.

title: SMALL L.I.R.R. UNION THREATENS A STRIKE
description: A small union representing civil engineers and draftsmen on the Long Island Rail Road threatened yesterday to strike on Monday, but a spokesman for the line sald that a walkout would be illegal and that it did not expect any general strike that would stop operations.

title: Government in Lisbon Showing Strains
description: LISBON, June 6A week of political barnstorming around Portugal by the provisional President, Gen. Antnio de Spinola, has strengthened the impression that the military structures underpinning the new Government are undergoing some considerable internal strains.

title: Parts of the Book Censored by the C.I.A.
description: Following are excerpts from a forthcoming book, The CIA and the Cult of Intelligence, by Victor Marchetti and John D. Marks. Mr. Marchetti worked for the Central Intelligence Agency for fourteen years as a Sovietmilitary specialist and executive assistant to the deputy director. Mr. Marks was an analyst sand staff assistant to the intelligence director in the State Department.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: OILRICH LANDS LIFT EXCHANGE RESERVES
description: WASHINGTON, June 6, (Reuters)the world's oilproducing countries have increased their foreign exchange reserves this year by about 43 per cent, according to official statistics released here today.

title: Coors to Appeal Order
description: DENVER, June 6 (AP)  The Adolph Coors Company said today it plans to appeal an order by the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit to stop alleged wholesale and retail pricefixing and other illegal anticompetitive business practices.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State Bars 9 Janitorial Concerns

title: LONDON EXCHANGE SEEKS PAYMENTS
description: LONDON, June 6The London Stock Exchange told its 4,700 members today that each must contribute the equivalent of $480 to the exchange's Compensation Fund to cover potential losses from three memberfirm collapses.

title: C.I.A. Bruised by Vietnam and Watergate, Is Undergoing Quiet Changes Under Colby
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 Bruised by the domestic politics of the Vietnam conflict and the Watergate affair, its influence in the White House broken by the practitioners of dtente, the Central Intelligence Agency is undergoing a major, perhaps fundamental, transformation.

title: GOLD PRICE OFF; DOLLAR IS MIXED
description: BRUSSELS, June 6 (UPI)The price of gold fell today in trading in London and Zurich as the rumors that helped push the price up sharply yesterday subsided. The dollar drifted in foreignexchange trading, weakening in Frankfurt, Zurich and Brussels and gaining in London, Paris and Tokyo.

title: Sweet Surprise
description: The scream of the outraged consumer has finally penetrated the storm cellar in which Congress has been hiding from the hurricane called inflation. With a considerable assist from makers of candy, soft drinks and other confections, consumer groups succeeded this week in persuading the House to junk the intricate structure of subsidies, quotas and excise taxes that has kept the price of sugar artificially high for forty years.

title: Miss Hearst Named As a Bank Robber In U. S. Indictment
House Votes to Authorize DeepWater Port in State
description: WASHINGTON June 6The House of Representatives, after three hours and 15 minutes emotional debate approved and sent to the Senate a bill tonight that would make it possible for a deepwater port to be situated off New Jersey.

title: Woman of Ganges'
description: Stiff as uncooked asparagus, the figures who stalk through Marguerite Duras's "Woman of the Ganges" don't have to act, since the movie is narrated in English by two invisible women with lush French accents. "Soch loff, soch dee-sire!" they repeat, as they warble away about a middle-aged man who's returned to a seaside town to kill himself; there, he encounters a woman he loved long ago. The picture is playing at the First Avenue Screening Room today and tomorrow.Above a wintry beach, gulls wail obligingly, while the disembodied voices whimper as they evoke lost loves  "Izzat rrreally her by ze edge of ze sea?"  and it becomes quite difficult to tell who's alive or dead in this movie. (All of the performers behave like zombies, but some are probably supposed to be ghosts.) It's also very hard to know who did what to whom in the past.Amid all the pacing through corridors, there's little spoken dialogue and barely any action. So it's an event when two characters bid each other good evening, when sand dribbles between someone's fingers, or when a muslin curtain stirs in the wind. There's some pretension to significant imagery here, but the result makes you want to yell or weep with boredom.Meanwhile, the narrators sluggishly state their passion for one another  "You're so yonk, and I loff you ssso moch"  and some of the others say that they've lost their memories. Since Marguerite Duras neglected to give them any perceptible emotions, the response seems healthy.

title: Kerr, at New School, Deplores Ebbing Confidence in Schools
description: Clark Kerr told the graduates of the New School for social Research yesterday that American confidence in educational institutions had declined, reflecting the spectacular decline of confidence in the most visible and powerful institution the Presidency.

title: SILVER FUTURES SHOW SLIM GAIN
description: Silver futures on the Commodity Exchange here showed some small price gains yesterday after a session marked by wide swings in price.

title: Garment Union to Limit Aides' Terms
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 6The convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union today adopted a constitutional amendment that in three years' time, if not sooner, will end the administration of President Louis Stulberg, who is 73 years old and ailing.

title: TEAMSTERS START FARM UNION LOCAL
description: MONTEREY, Calif., June 6  Frank Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, presented a charter today to the union's first farm workers local at a news conference in the Del Monte Hyatt House here. Security at the conference was rigid.

title: 12 Named to Race in Belmont; Cordero's Suspension Upheld
description: A dozen horses, including three sets of entries and a supplementary entrant, were named yesterday for the Belmont Stakes, which will have its 106th running at Belmont Park tomorrow. The draw for post positions in the 1 mile race took place at a breakfast several hours before the New York State Racing and Wagering Board announced that the sevenday suspension handed Angel Cordero last week would stand, despite the jockey's appeal.

title: Smith Upset In Paris by Japan's Ace
description: PARIS, June 6 (AP)Jun Kamiwazumi, Japan's topranked player, eliminated Stan Smith, 36, 64, 86, in a major firstround upsdt today in the French open tennis tournament.

title: Eastern College Tennis FINAL STANDING OF THE TEAMS
FEMINIST CLEARED IN TRENTON CASE
description: TRENTON, June 6The Appellate Division of State Superior Court, citing a lack of evidence, today set aside the disorderly conduct conviction off, a woman arrested during a scuffle with a state trooper in the State House last year.

title: Yanks, Medich Triumph
description: CHICAGO, June 6Playing on a field that more closely resembled a tributary of the Chicago River, the Yankees waded past the White Sox, 51, tonight in a game that sent the teams plodding past midnight for the second straight night.

title: Effects of Open Admission Stir New Dispute at City U.
description: Four years after dropping its meritadmissions system to guarantee entrance to all of the city's highschool graduates, the City University this week is conferring degrees on the first class it received under its historic openadmissions policy.

title: W.H.O. Confident Smallpox Can Be Erased in Year Despite India Epidemic
description: Despite a smallpox epidemic in India, the World Health Organization still believes that the preventable viral disease will be wiped off the globe in about

title: Money Supply Declined in Week, Apparently Showing Fed Policy
description: The nation's money supply took a steep $2.6billion decline in the week ended Wednesday, tentatively signalint that the tight monetary policy of the Federal Reserve Board aimed at reducing the rate of inflation might be taking effect.

title: NIXON WELCOMES A HIGH SAUDI AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Saudi Arabia's Prince Fand Ibn Abdel Aziz, a Deputy Premier and a half brother of King Faisal, was warmly welcomed today at the White House by President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Washington lawyer was acquitted yesterday of grand larceny and asault charges in connection with what the prosecution said was the forcible exchange of a $600 attach case purchased at the Hunting World shop in midtown Manhattan last year. A misdemeanor jury of four men and two women deliberated five hours before announcing the verdict to Judge Alfred Kleiman in Criminal Court. After the verdict, the 35yearold lawyer, Timothy Jenkins, shook hands with the jury.

title: Conferees Agree to Ban Research on Live Fetus
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Senate and House conferees have agreed on legislation to impose a temporary ban on research involving the living human fetus, a subject of great controversy in recent months.

title: Bouncing Fare
description: Hang on to your straps, mass transit riders, here we go again.

title: JOE PRICE
description: Joe Price, executive secretary of the Professional Dance Teachers Association, died Wednesday at the Presbyterian Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Governor Signs TeacherProbation Bills
description: Governor Wilson yesterday signed into law two bills reducing from five to three years the probationary period that publicschool teachers are required to serve before being considered for tenure.

title: Westchester Post Filled
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 7 (AP) County Executive Alfred B. Del Bello of Westchester announced today the appointment of Vincent A. Matrone, 31 years old, as County Commissioner of Finance, with a yearly salary of $34,285. Mr. Matrone will succeed Anthony N. Catalano who is retiring.

title: Irish Sisters in British Jail End 3Week Hunger Strike
description: LONDON, June 7The British Government announced that two Irish sisters on hunger strike in a London jail had taking light liquid food.

title: B.P. AND SOHIO RAISE INTEREST IN PIPELINE
description: LONDON, June 7 (UPI)The British Petroleum Company, Ltd, and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), in which BP has a 25 per cent interest, have agreed to raise their share in the Alaskan pipeline now under construction from 28 to 50 per cent, British Petroleum said to. day.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Goodyear and General Tire Prices Up
description: Prices of truck and other heavy tires are moving up again.

title: 4,000 Nurses Start Strike at Hospitals In Coast Bay Area
description: SAN PRANCISCO, June 7 (UPI)  More than 4,000 nurses struck today at 40 major hospitals and clinics caring for thousands of patients.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The possibility that Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson exceeded the legal spending limit in last month's mayoral election by funneling money to other candidates is being investigated by the State Election Law Enforcement Commission.

title: CNA TO ASK LIMIT ON SHIFT IN STOCK
description: CHICAGO, June 7The CNA Financial Corporation, which being sought by two other companies, said today it would take legal steps to limit the Accident and Casualty Insurance Company's acquisition of CNA stock to 20 per cent.

title: Homer Defeats Mets, 10
description: HOUSTON, June 7Manager Preston Gomez of the Astros received added reason to feel more complacent about his pitching staff tonight, Don Wilson pitched to an impressive 1to0 victory over the New York Mets in providing Houston with its second shutout victory in two game's.

title: Turmoil Engulfs U.S. Attorney's Office
description: Six months of turmoil in the office of the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York began last Dec. 4 with the suicide of the man who had held the job for two and half years.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, June 7, 1974.

title: Hearings Wind Up in Suit Asking Hospital Abortions
description: TRENTON, June 7A weeklong hearing on a lawsuit seeking to compel private voluntary hospitals in New Jersey to open their facilities for women electing to have abortions ended in State Supreme Court today.

title: Academy Command Shifts
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., June 7 (AP)Rear Min. William A. Jenkins assumed command of the United States Coast Guard Academy today, relieving Rear Adm. Joseph J. McClelland, who, as a Vice Admiral will command the Coast Guard, Pacific Area. Admiral Jenkins has been operations chief at the Coast Guard's Washington headquarters.

title: Argentine Executive Is Slain After Wife Eludes Kidnapping
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 7 (UPI) The head of a Buenos Aires supermarket chain was shot and killed today in the second attempt to kidnap him in less than six months, his family reported.

title: Miss Jacquelyn Friedman Is Married
description: Miss Jacquelyn Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Byron Friedman of Evanston, III., was married yesterday to David Friedlander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Friedlander of Manhasset, L.I. Rabbi. Andrew J. Robins performed the ceremony, in his study at Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: $100 Fine, 30Day Term Suspended for Kleindienst
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, weeping openly, received today a suspended sentence for misleading a Senate committee that was invstigating the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation case.

title: Tanker Explodes, in Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June (UPI)  One person was missing and 23 were injured today when a 550ton South Korean tanker exploded at a shipyard in the southern port city of Pusan, the police said.

title: Two Soviet Dancers Reported Free to Go After Long Struggle
description: MOSCOW, June 7The Soviet authorities have decided to let the ballet dancers Valery Panov and Galina Ragozina, his wife, emigrate to Israel, unofficial Soviet sources reported today.

title: Communists Reaffirm Faith in BlueCollar Worker
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2The traditional Marxist mystique that manual labor is the most important and uplifting pursuit of man is under such heavy social pressure throughout Eastern Europe that worried governments are calling for a return to the purity of basic Marxist values.

title: Cordero's Court Case Scratched
description: The winning jockey in today's 106th Belmont Stakes will get $10,300 as his share of the loot, but it won't be Angel Cordero.

title: Portuguese Arrest a LeftWing Editors
description: LISBON, June 7In its first major action against extreme leftwing groups here, the Portuguese Government today arrested the editor of a weekly newspaper.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los Angeles  Yosh Ogawa, 138 pounds, Japan, outpointed Nacho Castenada, 138, Mexico, 10 rounds.

title: $100 Fine, 30Day Term Suspended for Kleindienst
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 Former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, weeping openly, received today a suspended sentence for misleading a Senate committee that was invstigating the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation case.

title: Lykes Estimates 86.9% Rise in Its Profits
description: The LykesYoungstown Corporation's estimated earnings for the first half of this year should reach $40million after taxes, J. T. Lykes Jr., chairman, announced yesterday. The rise would come to 86.9 per cent above the $21.4million net income shown in the corresponding six months of 1973.

title: Talks to Settle the Strike Of Clothing Union Continue
description: Negotiations aimed at settling a nationwide strike of men's and boys' clothing workers continued yesterday at the offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in Washington.

title: Robin Tieken Has Nuptials
description: Miss Robin Tieken, daughter of Mrs. Robert Tieken of Chicago and the late Mr. Tieken, was married yesterday to John W. B. Hadley of Chicago, an independent investor. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Hadley of New York. The Rev. Martin E. Marty, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom.

title: A MOUNTAIN MAN TO GET LAST WISH
description: LOS ANGELES, June 7Seventyfour years after his death in a Los Angeles home for soldiers, John (Liver Eating) Johnston is returning to Cody, Wyo.within sight of the Absaroka Mountains he once roamed.

title: Motives of Rent Strikers Are Deplored by Gibson
description: NEWARK, June 7Mayors Kenneth A. Gibson said today that the tenants conducting al rent strike at the Stella Wright Housing Project had rejected efforts to resolve the dispute over living conditions at the highrise project because they simply want to live rentfree.

title: 100MILLION ASKED FOR CITY'S TRANSIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 Senator Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Transportation Subcommittee of the Senate Public Works Committee, introduced masstransit legislation today that would give New York City $100million this year  half its operating deficit.

title: New L.I.R.R. Times Give Riders Fresh Complaints
description: The pain at Great Neck, L. I., is mainly on the train these morningsspecifically the new 8:15 for Manhattan, which is already packed when it rolls into the station, bound for the city.

title: Reg Jones Outs prints Williams in 9.18 Final
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 7Another new face sped into America's crowded sprint picture tonight.

title: TV NEWS VIEWING IN 5MONTH DROP
description: Weariness with the Wategate story and with the snowballing problems of the Nixon Administration are, thought some network officials to be the reason for a decline of more than 2 per cent in the audiences for television network news over the first five months of this year.

title: MotelRoom Fire Fatal
description: PENNSAUKEN, June 7 (AP)  A 24yearold Philadelphia woman died early today when a fire swept her room at motel in this Camden County community, police said. The victim, in the fire, at the Penn Motor Inn, was Eleanor J. Broderick.

title: Prime Rate Drops To 11 at Citibank
description: The First National City Bank, second largest in the nation, cut its prime lending rate yesterday by one quarter point to 11 per cent effective immediately. The move sparked optimistic speculation that soaring interest rates may have finally peaked.

title: SEX on License Plates Is Among the Taboos
description: ALBANY, June 7 (AP) SEX, LUV and JOY are banned on New York State license plates. So are WOW, EEK and NUN.

title: REV. WILLIAM GARDNER
description: The Rev, William E. Gardner, pastor of the First Baptist Church of East Elmhurst, Queens, died Tuesday at Hampton, Va., where he was attending a ministers' conference, He was 68 years old and lived at 10944 Ditmars Boulevard, East Elmhurst.

title: Notes on People
description: J. Paul Getty, one of the world's richest men, is most unhappy about the British Government's plans to tax the worldwide income of foreign residents, and he's threatening to quit Britain: For about 20 years he has operated from Sutton Place, his mansion in Surrey, running an empire so wealthy that he doesn't know its value.

title: Screen: Lilies Bloom
description: An endearingly simple, honest and moving film like Where the Lilies Bloom would be welcome any time. Arriving now on a screen splattered with violence and sex, this beautiful little movie is like a cool, clear dip of mountain spring water.

title: Ritha Devi, in 2 Hours of Solos, Is a Guide to Indian Dance Styles
description: Ritlia Devi provided an invaluable compendium of classical Indian dance styles Thursday at Carnegie Recital Hall, both in, her wise and funny commentary and in her demanding 2hour solo recital. She is an artist who must be seen.

description: BASEBALL

title: Political Trial of 67 in Chile Nears End
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 7The courtmartial of 57 air force officials and 10 civilians accused of sedition moved into its final phase with the end of public hearings today.

title: Pakistan Disputes India on AArms
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 7Pakistan charged in a United Nations committee today that India was at work on a delivery system for nuclear weapons.

title: People and Business
description: Glenn W. Johnson has been named president and chief operating officer of Sterling Drug, Inc., a major pharmaceutical and consumergoods company, effective July 1. He will succeed David J. Fitzgibbons, who is retiring. W. Clarke Wescoe, 54 years old, continues as chairman and chief, executive officer.

title: CRISIS IN ECONOMY DEEPENS IN ITALY
description: ROME, June 7  Premier Mariano Rumor and his key ministers met throughout the day today to discuss Italy's deteriorating economic situation amid speculation that the lira would soon be devalued.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  The House of Representatives, after three hours and 15 minutes of emotional debate, approved and sent to the Senate last night a bill that would make it possible for a deepwater port to be situated of the Atlantic Coast.

title: U.S. IS READY TO PUT ARMS AID TO ISRAEL ON A ANGER BASIS
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Sec retary of State Kissinger said today that the United States had agreed to negotiate future American military assistance to Israel on a long  term rather than yearly basis.

title: Bridge: Ruffing of Dummy's Loser Poses Question of Timing
description: A delicate playing decision often arises when a player aims to ruff a loser in the dummy and has an extra winner in the suit.

title: U.S. Donates Park Land
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  A White House spokesman said today that 17 parcels of land in 12 states were being transferred from Federal ownership to state and local governments for park and recreation use under the Administration's Legacy of Parks program. The 17 properties include 723 acres and have an estimated market value of $5.1million, the spokesman said.

title: Eberle Calls Ties Of U.S. to Market Exceptionally Good
description: BRUSSELS, June 7William D. Eberle, President Nixon's special trade representative, ended two days of intensive talks with officials of the European Economic Community here today. He said at a news conference that economic relations between the United States and the ninenation Common Market were exceptionally good.

title: Antiques: Quality Quilts
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's recent venture into purchasing quilts has produced a collection that, although modest in size, is exceptional in quality. In the exhibition Twelve Great American Quilts From the American Wing a baker's dozen are shown (one arrived too late to make the catalogue and change the name of the show).

title: U.S. SAID TO WARN EUROPE ON ARABS
description: BRUSSELS, June 7  The United States warned the Common Market countries, in a letter sent to each last week, about the political danger of the proposed European dialogue with Arab states, informed sources in Brussels said today.

title: The Dance: Watermill and Scherzo
description: There is a fine and wild variety to the New York City Ballet repertory. What other company would, or even could, juxtapose Jerome Robbins's somber and opaque theater piece Watermill with that brilliant, delicious Russian Easterpresent of divine triviality, George Bal. anchine's Scherzo a la Russe. Both turned up, for the first time for a couple of seasons, at the New York State Theater on Thursday night.

title: Eager Pickers Find Berried Treasure As L.I. Farmers Open Fields to Public
description: WADING RIVER, L. I., The legs start to wobble and the back starts to ache after an hour. This is why there are usually enough strawberries to go around when the public plays migrant worker for a few weeks each June.

title: Auto Union Executive Board Is Voted New Powers
description: LOS ANGELES, June 7At one point, during the 24th annual convention of the United Automobile Workers, Douglas Eraser, a Nice president, vrarned the delegates: You can push too far. You know this is a delicate balance.

title: Dance: Creating Pictures
description: Lynda Gudde, very much an original choreographer, continues to work tenaciously and fruitfully outside the mainstream of current moderndance modes. Her company, the Gudde Dancers, presented four works, including two premieres, Thursday night at St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street. The program will be repeated today and tomorrow.

title: City Council Head Says Camden Jury Will Find Police Department in Chaos
description: CAMDEN, June 7What a Camden County grand jury will find when it investigates the Camden Police Department next month, City Council President John R. Marini said today, is chaos.

title: NO. AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: $1 OILRATE RISE IS UNDER DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 Ralph Nader made public today internal documents of the Cost of Living Council and said that they showed lack of justification for the Administration's Dec. 19, 1973, increase of $1 a barrel, to $5.25, for the ceiling price of crude oil.

title: Schlam's Father Insists That Drugs Were Given Nefariously
description: The physicianfather of Peter R. Schlam, an assistant United Slates attorney, said yesterday that the drugs that felled his son during the trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo last month had been administered without the victim's knowledge over a period of several days by someone, with hostile intent.

title: Scanner Is AssemblyLine Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Apparatus that sees objects passing before it is proving an effective assemblyline aid for a large pharmaceutical company. Patent 3,814,521 was granted this week to. John M. Free of the applied sciencestechnical divisionat HoffmannLa Roche, Inc., Nutley, N.J. Dr. Free's invention is not only capable of considering two dimensions of an object, as shown in a photograph or television screen, but of analyzing its full threedimensional properties.

title: Many Calls, but No Clues, In Killing of Library Aide
description: For the last two weeks, 10 detectives have been combing the East Side neighborhood where a 23yearold library researcher was raped and strangled in her apartment, but they say they have not turned up any clues as to the identity of the killer.

title: Tornadoes Are Reported In Arkansas and Texas
description: Tornadoes were reported yesterday in Arkansas and Texas and thunderstorms and hail pounded the nation's midsection, United Press International reported.

title: Missing Man, 84, Found
description: TEMPLE, Me., June 7 (UPI)An 84yearold man who had been missing for two days in Maine's rugged western mountains was found, about four miles from his home. The authorities said that Earl Oberton was dazed but appeared to be in good condition. He was, taken to the Franklin County Hospital for observation.

title: What This City Got For Three Days Was A Good 5Cent Cone
description: Dover Delicacies, at 144 East 57th Street, is a place where one can find 14ounce tins of Beluga caviar for $90 and where celebrities line up for sandwiches when they visit in New York. It is a place that has been asked to send fruit to Florida, cold cuts to a Democratic national convention in Atlantic City and ice cream toCalifornia.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Appearing on demand before the City Council's Finance Committee yesterday, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd defended the program to increase the police force by 1,440 new men and the need for $29million in the budget for this purpose.

title: Hirshhorn Paintings Recovered in Deal On a Plea Bargain
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 7 (AP)Six stolen oil paintings worth $500,000 were returned to the multimilliondollar art collection of Joseph H. Hirshhorn today following a secret rendezvous in a Federal courthouse.

title: CASO SEEN AHEAD ON WILSON TICKET
description: Governor Wilson has indicated that Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, will be his choice for running mate as Lieutenant Governor, state Republican leaders said yesterday.

title: U.S IS READY TO PUT ARMS AID TO ISRAEL ON A LONGER BASIS
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States had agreed to negotiate future American military assistance to Israel on a long  term rather than yearly basis.

title: Mile Tunnel Flooded to Fight Train Fire
description: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., June 7 Rockland County fire and emergency officials tonight began flooding a milelong railroad tunnel, the scene yesterday of a derailment just south of here, in an effort to subdue the acrid inferno inside.

title: ROBERT L. BLANCHARD
description: Robert L. Banchard, whose tents and survival gear were used in Adm. Richard E. Byrd's early polar exploration work and in the 1963 American Mount Everest expedition, died here Monday, apparently of a heart attack while driving his car. He was 79 years old and lived at 180 Central Park South.

title: P.O.W.'s Back in Israel Charge Cases of Brutality
description: TEL AVIV, June 7Israeli prisoners of war who returned from captivity in Damascus said in interviews today they had been brutally treated by their Syrian jailers.

title: LOSS LISTED BY BOND AND BY ALEXANDER'S
description: Alexander's, Inc., and Bond Industries, Inc., reported yesterday losses in their most recent fiscal quarters, despite increased sales in the period. Alexander's is a leading New York area retailer while Bond operates apparel stores in number of cities.

title: Rockefeller Is Out, but He's in Touch
description: Oh, no, no, no, no, no!

title: Garment Workers ReElect Top Aides And Cheer Stulberg
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 7The convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union today reelected the union's four top officers to new threeyear terms and wound up week of deliberations with bannerwaving, confettithrowing demonstration of affection for the union's 73yearold president, Louis Stulberg.

title: Byrne Offers 2 IncomeTax Proposals
description: TRENTON, June 7Governor Byrne proposed today two alternative plans for imposing a graduated state incometax on New Jersey residents to raise $750million that is need ed to refinance the state's public schools and to aid counties and municipalities.

title: Sonata Hill Wins Roosevelt Trot
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 7Sonata Hill, driven by John Chapman, held off a late bid by C Bs Frank last night and captured a $20,000 Class AA trot at Roosevelt Raceway.. The winner's time was 2:032/5.

title: Portugal, Spain And Greece
description: PARISThe disappearance of Portugal's dictatorship in the wake of a military coup has been regarded with fear and fascination by Europe's remaining rightwing regimes, Spain and Greece. The Governments in power tend to emphasize the fear; their opposition, which includes a majority, stress the fascination.

title: Miss Hearst on Tape Says Fight by S.L.A. Continues
description: LOS ANGELES, June 7A voice said by her family to be that of Patricia Hearst stated in a taperecording broadcast here today her commitment to the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army and her determination to continue the terrorist fight.

title: SIRICA LIFTS BAR TO DATA ON NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Federal Judge John J. Sirica lifted today the protective order that has kept secret for almost a month the court papers describing President Nixon as an unindicted coconspirator in the Watergate coverup.

title: Mrs. Ellsberg's Doctor Reports His Office Was Searched in '71
description: WASHINGTON, June 7A Manhattan psychoanalyist who treated Mrs. Daniel Ellsberg has disclosed that his office was searched by intruders in November, 1971, less than three months after the attempt in Los Angeles by the White House plumbers to steal Dr. Ellsberg's medical records from the office of his former psychiatrist.

title: Judge, at L.I.U. Commencement, Urges Education to Avert Gangs
description: State Supreme Court Justice Franklin W. Morton Jr. said yesterday in an address to graduates of the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University that adult, not juvenile, education was needed to combat the revival of street gangs in Brooklyn.

title: 13 Indicted on Stock Theft and Counterfeit Counts
description: NEWARK, tune 7A grand jury today indicted 13 men, involved in three separate cases, on charges of stealing $520,000 in securities and conspiring to counterfeit $4million in stock certificates.

description: Music

title: Yanks Beaten, 32, By Twins' Blyleven
description: The most menacing attack the New York Yankees could muster in their 32 defeat to Minnesota last night at Shea Stadium turned out to be the threatening gestures Lou Piniella made toward Bert Blyleven, the Twins' righthander in the seventh inning.

title: Kurd Chief Asks U.N. For Aid Against Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7 (AP)The leader of the Kurdish minority in Iraq accused the Baghdad Government today of waging a war of genocide against the 2.3 million Kurds.

title: Green's 137 Leads Golf By Stroke
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June Johnny Miller, who will defend his United States Open golf championship next week, came charging to within two strokes of the lead in the IVBPhiladelphia classic toclay, but it was Hubert Green who charged to the top.

title: Dave Anderson
description: All week Angel Cordero has been in the headlines but he won't be in the saddle for the 106th Belmont Stakes today. Cordero was unable to escape his sevenday suspension and Jorge Valasquez will be the jockey on Cannonade, the Kentucky Derby winner. The horse might be better off. So might the horseplayers. Cordero has been in a slump. Velasquez, a boyish 27yearold Panamanian with arms as. slender but as strong as leather thongs, has been the leading rider at the New York racetracks this year. He has never been the winning jockey in a Triple Crown race but he has never been on a 3yearold with Cannonade's credentials. Wearing a bathrobe of light blue velvet with a maroon satin collar over a white turtleneck and white breeches, he sat on a bench in the jockeys' room yesterday at Belmont: Park and disctissed his opportunity.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: MERCENARY THREAT REPORTED IN GUINEA
description: DAKAR, Senegal, June 7 (Reuters)  The. African nationalist movement, in Portuguese Guinea said today that a force of African mercenaries in the pay of foreign powers was heading toward the territory's capital of Bissau in two ships.

title: Bank Cuts Prime Rate
description: The nation's second largest bank, the First National City Bank, cut its prime lending rate yesterday to 11 per cent from 11 per cent. In reaction, the stock market climbed, pushing the DowJones industrial average up 8.37 points. Page 39.
