description: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., June Rockland County fire and emergency officials tonight began flooding a milelong railroad tunnel, the scene yesterday of a derailment just south of here, in an effort to subdue the acrid inferno inside.

title: Suspect in Girls' Slayings Questioned on Other Cases
description: MAYS LANDING, June 7A 20yearold factory worker suspected of slaying two high school girls and charged with kidnapping two women at knifepoint was being questioned today in connection with a number of missingpersons cases in South Jersey.

title: Doctors Say Hayes Had Heart Attack
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June (UPI)  Doctors confirmed today, that Ohio State's football coach, Woody Hayes, suffered a heart attack early yesterday at his home. His condition was described as stable.

title: EQUITY IS SEEKING THREEYEAR PACT
description: The Actors Equity Association has entered into negotiations with the League of New York Theaters on terms for a new threeyear contract covering basic minimum wages for Broadway and touring performers.

title: Governor Is Said to Favor Caso as His Running Mate
description: Governor Wilson has indicated that Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, will be his choice for running mate as Lieutenant Governor, state Republican leaders said yesterday.

title: Japan Under Pressure
description: A very gentle lobby paid a call upon the office of Premier Tanaka in Tokyo the other day. Girls from the United States, Canada and Sweden presented 75,000 letters from children around the world urging Japan to agree to a tenyear moratorium on whaling.

title: FED SAID TO GET PLAN ON FRANKLIN
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 7 (Reuters)A group of New York banks led by the First National City Bank has submitted to Government author; ities a plan to aid the troubled Franklin National Bank, according to banking sources here.

title: People in Sports
description: The Kansas City Scouts, one of the two new National Hockey League franchises that will begin operation next season, made it official yesterday and named Bep Guidolin as coach. The 48yearold Guidolin resigned May 27 as the Boston Bruin coach after his team was beaten by the Philadelphia Flyers in the Stanley Cup final. Guidolin said at the time that he was leaving the Bruins because of their failure to give him a fiveyear contract. Boston charged the Scouts with tampering, which Guidolin denied. If I had signed with any club, he said, they would have filed. Boston has nothing to stand on, everything is legitimate. Guidolin received a contract which he described as a fiveyear job.

title: Bank Cuts Prime Rate
description: The nation's second largest bank, the First National City Bank, cut its prime lending rate yesterday to 11 per cent from 11 per cent. In reaction, the stock market climbed, pushing the DowJones industrial average up 8.37 points. Page 39.

title: Unholy Burial
description: The ghostly relic of an era to be remembered only national shame and embarrassment was buried this week with the issuance of President Nixon's Executive order abolishing the 27yearold Attorney General's list subversive organizations.

title: BETTER MILEAGE IN '75 CARS SEEN
description: The fuel economy of 1975 cars will be much higher than had been expected with the (new catalytic converters to control pollution, Russell E. Train, administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, said yesterday.

title: EMMINGER CITES DOLLAR STRENGTH
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 7 The United States dollar has again emerged as a strong currency but the world will not return to a dollar standard, a leading European central banker said today.

title: USM Fights Alleghany
description: The USM Corporation, which recently rejected a bid by the Alleghany Corporation for control, said yesterday that, since Alleghany would not give assurances that it will not add to its present holding of 30 per cent of USM's stock, USM had directed its counsel to take action as may be necessary to protect the corporation and its shareholders from Alleghany.

title: DualPurpose Funds
description: Following Is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable in the capital shares of dualpurpose Investment comDenies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices of best overtnecounter dollartodollar asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount on premium) between the net asset value and the asked prices of the capital shares.

title: LILCO Downgraded
description: The bond credit rating of the Long Island Lighting Company has been downgraded from doubleA to singleA by Standard & Poor's Corporation, which rates corporate and municipal bonds, Details on Page 45.

title: 4 MORE MINISTERS RESIGN IN CAMBODIA
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 7 (Reuters)  more Government ministers resigned today, informed sources said.

title: Mansfield Stalls a Jackson Trade Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Shortly after the Senate session began this morning, Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, whispered to Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, that he had a little, amendment that would just take a few minutes.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, June 7, 1974

title: Environmentalists and the Court
description: While the environmental revolution is tending to force ordinary citizens to become amateur lawyers if they want to know what is going on, new ground rules by the Supreme Court will not impede them from courtroom campaigning on behalf of the quality of life. Last week the United States Supreme Court laid down new ground rules for classaction lawsuits in Federal courts, requiring that all identifiable parties to a suit be notified. Until then, a lawyer with a single client could sweepingly list as coplaintiffs thousands or even millions of anonymous people of the litigation.

title: Signal Is Offering $24 Each For at Least Million Shares
description: A tender offer was made yesterday by the Signal Companies, Inc., to purchase at least 1 million shares of its common stock for $24 a share

title: Suspect in Girls' Slayings Questioned on Other Cases
description: MAYS LANDING, N.J., June 7 A 20yearold factory worker suspected of slaying two high school girls and charged with kidnapping two women at knifepoint was being questioned today in connection with a number of missingpersons cases in South Jersey.

title: Fathers Day Proclamation
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)  President Nixon today formally proclaimed June 16 as Fathers Day. His proclamation said 1974 is an especially poignant time to celebrate Fathers Day since this year no young American soldiers are being sent to fight anywhere to the world.

title: GRANT G. SIMMONS OF MATTRESS FIRM
description: Grant Gilbert Simmons, retired head of the Simmons Company, manufacturers of mattresses and home furnishings, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 80 years old.

title: Music: A French Finale
description: The New York Philharmonic's final Promenade program of the season, which will be given its last performance tonight, is devoted to French music and has Mignon Dunn, mezzosoprano as soloist in two groups of songs and arias. The first consists of Mon coeur s'ouvre  ta voix from SaintSans's Samson et Dalila, Duparc's L'Invitation au voyage and Phidyl and Bizet's Ouvre ton coeur. The second comprises four excerpts from Offenbach operettas and, for an encore, aria from Carmen.

title: U.S.Sandi Talks Reportedly Set Up Wide Cooperation
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The United States and Saudi Arabia agreed today to work together on economic, social, security and financial problems, informed sources reported tonight.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Premier Mariano Rumor of Italy and his key ministers held long meetings to discuss the country's worsening economic crisis. Meanwhile, there were reports in financial circles that the Government would officially devalue the lira by 20 per cent, and newspapers and politicians speculated that Premier Rumor's Cabinet might collapse. [1:1.]

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I should like to clarify the position of the office of the Chancellor in the matter of the allegations regarding corporal punishment at J.H.S. 22 in the Bronx. The facts are as follows:

title: Unequal Justice
description: Blessed though compassion may be, it can hardly be said that confidence in equality of justice has been fortified by the gentle sentence administered to former Attorney General Kleindienst.

title: W. R. Grace & Co. to Build Ammonia Fertilizer Plant
description: W. R. Grace & Co. announced yesterday that it would build a $70million ammonia fertilizer production facility on a site three miles west of Woodward, Okia. The 1,200tonperday plant is scheduled to go into operation by the middle of 1977.

title: OPEC CALLED OPEN TO PRICE DIALOGUE
description: PARIS, June 7The head of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countriesthe cartel of foreign oil producerstoday expressed greater willingness for a dialogue with consumer countries on the problems created by higher oil prices.

title: Bankers Will Sue on Savings Service
description: The New York State Bankers Association, meeting in Miami Beach, voted unanimously yesterday to take legal action to prevent savings banks in the state from offering payment order accounts. The new service, currently available at several savings banks in New York State, resembles checking accounts in nearly all respects.

title: It's a Lot for the Money
description: Obviously, the furriers' almanac is predicting a cold and freespendingwinter. As three more fur houses showed their collections, the Message seemed to be: give the lady a lot of fur for her money. If she's going to spend a lot, let it look like a lot.

title: Syrian Prisoners Allege Mistreatment by Captors
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 7 (AP) Wounded Syrian prisoners charged today that Israelis had mistreated them and failed to give them proper medical treatment.

title: Soccer in New York: Cosmos Unable to Mix With Melting Pot
description: There are nearly a million soccer fans in the ethnic melting pot of New York, but fewer than 3,000 turn out for the bigleague games of the Cosmos.

title: 2 Palestinian Hijackers Sentenced in Netherlands
description: HAARLEM, the Netherlands, June 7 (AP)  Two young Palestinians who hijacked a British Airways jet to Amsterdam in March were sentenced yesterday to fiveyear prison terms.

title: ScaledDown Plans for Kennedy Library Unveiled; Cost, With Glass Pyramid Gone, Put at $15Million
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 7 Scaleddown plans for the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library were unveiled here today amid continuing controversy over the project in the city that contributed so much to his mystique.

title: RULING FOR BARRIOS IS APPEALED BY U.S.
description: The United States Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on a Government motion to reinstate an indictment thrown out by a lower court after the defendant charged he was being prosecuted only because he supported Senator George McGovern against President Nixon in the 1972 campaign.

title: Little Curren, Cannade Are Belmont Picks
description: The Belmont Stakes will have its 106th running today, at Belmont Park, and the lineup for the 1mile contest embraces 11 thoroughbreds. There is a strong chance, though, that there may be further withdrawals before post time at 5:40 P.M., but regardless of change, the strong horses remain the same, Little Current of the Darby Dan Farm's entry with Covered Portage, and John M. Olin's Cannonade.

title: Rockefeller Is Out but He's in Touch
description: Oh, no, no, no, no,, no! Nelson A. Rockefeller let a wisp of frown mix with his crinkled grin as he rejected the suggestion that he might suffer pangs of regret at not having the dominant role to play at the Republican state nominating convention next week.

title: Airport Lot Workers Strike
description: Parking lot attendants at Kennedy International and LaGuardia Airports went on strike yesterday after separate negotiations for a new contract with concessionaires broke down. Teamsters Local 917, which represents 145 attendants at Kennedy and 70 at La Guardia, put up picket lines in the parking lots and in front of terminals shortly after 2 P.M.

title: BODY OF AN LTV AIDE IS FOUND IN DALLAS
description: DALLAS, June 7 (UPI)The body of a corporation executive, Dan Burney, missing since he drove out of a downtown parking tower May 21, was found today in a grassy area on the southeast side of the city, the police said.

title: Canadian Mining Suffers From Prosperity Woes
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 5  Canada's mining industry is suddenly sufferingas a result of too much prosperity.

title: Music: A French Finale
description: The New York Philharmonic's final Promenade program of the season, which will be given its last performance tonight, is devoted to French music and has Mignon Dunn, mezzosoprano as soloist in two groups of songs and arias. The first consists of Mon coeur s'ouvre  to voix from SaintSagns's Samson et Dalila, Duparc's L'Invitation au voyage and Phidyle and Bizet's Ouvre ton coeur. The second comprises four excerpts from Offenbach operettas and, for an encore, aria from Carmen.

title: Sinatra Aids O'Neill Project
description: WATERFORD, Conn., June 7 (UPI)Frank Sinatra has contributed $25,000 to the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center here to help fund a floating children's and community theater plan in New York City, The Norwich Bulletin reported today. A center spokesman confirmed that the singerentertainer had made the donation, his first to the center, at the end of May.

title: Art: Welcome Tribute to Mark Tobey
description: WASHINGTON, June 7It will not have escaped the student of such matters that the art market has at last caught up with Mark Tobey, and that his name now figures on the list of painters most sought after by unnamed investors. Doubtless, this would have happened years ago, had it not been for the fact that Mr. Tobey is the most steadfast of absentees from his native country. This has caused him to cut a oneline figure in the standard histories of modern art; nor can it be said that the great American museums have stood in line for the honor of mounting a fullscale Tobey retrospective of the kind now often accorded to artists well under half his age.

title: Curb on Presidential Staffs Approved by a House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) Legislation aimed at curbing and realigning Presidential staffs and abolishing the President's discretionary $1million emergency fund has cleared a House committee.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CLEANLINESS IS ... Evidence indicates that there are a lot of dogs in New York. And a valid statistical inference is that many of those dogs are dirty. Unkempt. Fleabitten. Smelly.

title: Two Moves by Saigon Reported To Court Approval in the U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam June 7  The Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu has made two significant gestures in the past two days that foreign and Vietnamese analysts say are rather clearly intended to improve its image in the United States.

title: Woman Found Stabbed to Death In Bathtub in Queens Apartment
description: A middleaged woman was found dead of multiple stab wounds in a Flushing, Queens, apartment last night by police officers investigating a report of a woman's scream for help.

title: With president's Grip Ever Tighter, Seoul Is Jumpy and Confused
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 6 An American helicopter has been shot down over Seoul by nervous South Korean gunners in ad action that is taken here as underscoring the jumpy and confused mood of the city.

title: Verrazzano College Will open in Fall
description: Verrazzano College, the ItalianAmericansponsored institution first conceived of more than 10 years ago, will finally open next fall on a readybuilt campus in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. With a president, some office workers and the beginning of a faculty, all it needs now are students.

title: WILSON'S PAST JOB BRINGS MANES SUIT
description: Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, charged yesterday in a suit filed in Federal District Court that Governor Wilson, while Lieutenant Governor, violated the law by representing as a lawyer companies subject to state regulation.

title: Evacuation of Area Occupied in Syria Is Begun by Israel
description: TEL AVIV, June 7 (UPI)Israel began today a 19day phased evacuation of Syrian territory occupied in last October's war, and military sources said United Nations troops had begun demarcation of the new Golan Heights buffer zone they will man.

title: Justice Department Asks F.B.I. Reason for Inquiry on Santarelli
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The Justice Department today asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation why an agent had questioned a newsman about what the head of another branch of the department had said in a speech.

title: Contract Awards
description: Northrop Worldwide Aircraft Services, Inc., received a $23.2million Army contract for maintenance Of fixedwing aircraft and helicopters for fiscal 1975 at Fort Rucker, Ala., it was announced yesterday.

title: FORD CONCERNED BY GESELL ACTION
description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 7 Vice President Ford said today that the possibility that President Nixon might be cited for contempt of court is a matter of major consequence.

title: POLITICAL SPENDING IS LINKED TO SHULTZ
description: HOUSTON, June 7 (UPI) Former Treasury Secretary P. Shultz tacitly approved a secret plan to distribute $1.4billion in Government funds to create the most favorable impact on President Nixon's reelection campaign, The Houston Post reported in a copyrighted article yesterday.

title: Temple Picks Bolen
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP)John Bolen, a former allAmerican soccer player at Temple, was named the university's head soccer coach today, succeeding Walter Bahr, now at Penn State.

title: S.E.C. Action on Firm
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had instituted public administrative proceedings against Dixon Dolce & Co. of New York City and four of its employes. The commission said it would hold hearings on alleged violations of the antifraud, brokerdealer registration and other provisions of the securities laws.

title: 3 IN PHILADELPHIA HELD IN KIDNAPPING
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) The teenaged son of a police lieutenant and two other youths were charged today with the kidnapping of a woman from the garden of her fiveacre estate.

title: ALAN J. ZUCH
description: Alan J. Zuch, proprietor of the Williamsville Inn near Stockbridge, Mass., died here Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in Stockbridge.

title: Jamaica's Senate Passes Bill Lifting Levies on Bauxite
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 7 (AP)The Jamaican Senate approved a bill today that will more than quadruple the money Jamaica receives from companies operating there for bauxite, the raw material of aluminum.

title: A Little Help for Our Friends
description: As part of its new friendship with the Arabs, the United States has agreed to redesign the camel.

title: N.F.L. Data On Profits Disputed
description: The National Football League Players Association disputed yesterday claims by the club owners that the teams in 1973 averaged profits of $472,500, or 7.6 per cent, after taxes.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Despite All That Fun, They Manage to Get in Some Studying
description: SANTA CATALINA, Calif.  Richard Wheeler, who will become headmaster of the Catalina Island School on July 1 was visiting the school recently when a wild buffalo stalked calmly across campus.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CLEANLINESS IS . . . Evidence indicates that there are a lot of dogs in New York. And a valid statistical inference is that many of those dogs are dirty. Unkempt. Fleabitten. Smelly.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, June 5  When Princeton University's women's sailing team returns from a trip to California later this month, it hopes to bring back what most of its male athlete friends at the college have failed to achieve  a national championship.

title: FUTURES IN CORN REGISTER ADVANCE
description: Weather dominated trading in grain futures once again yesterday. Traders talked of a forecast of rain over Oklahoma this weekend and the Mississippi River being about five feet above flood stage at Alton, Ill.

title: New Library Plan: A Response to the Critics
description: The new version of the Kennedy Library has been designed to meet all objections to the original, says the architectural firm of J. M. Pei and Partnersand that is just the building's problem.

title: WINE TALK
description: In the days when the English ruled Bordeaux and most of Acquitaine, the Mdoc was covered with marshes and bogs and its wine was often thin and weak. To give it body and strength, it was often blended with a deep, powerful wine from the upcountry. That wine was Cahors, one of the legendary wines of France.

title: Dublin Police Express Fear Donoughmores Were Killed
description: DUBLIN, June 7 (UPI)The police said today they know who kidnapped the Earl and Countess of Donoughmore and expressed fears that the elderly Protestant couple may have been murdered.

title: Once upon a time, Con Edison made a big mistake Jean Stafford's gas bill. Well, she's a writer, and relishes good fight. But wait, let her tell it in her own words:
description: EAST HAMPTON, N. Y. On quitting New York City in 1957 where I had been living under the name Jean Stafford, I asked Consolidated Edison to send my final bill. Instead of a bill, I received a check for six cents, which represented, I supposed, what was left of my deposit. I kept it, partly as a curio, partly in the hope that in a wee way I could bollix up the company books, and partly because I thought it might come in handy some day in oneway or another. Eleven years later, thanks to my meanspirited foresight, I was able to use it as a tactical diversion in a battle I fought with and won from Con Ed.

title: AUSTRIA AND SOVIET IN ECONOMIC TALKS
description: MOSCOW, June 7The Kremlin has dispatched a negotiating team to Vienna for economic talks following Austrian Chancellor Bruno Kreisky's failure last week to win Soviet agreement to step up oil supplies to his country.

title: Tigers Rally in 9th to Beat Angels, 54
description: Jim Northrup, who has won his share of games with his bat during 11 seasons in a Detroit uniform, provided the hit for another victory last night in Tiger Stadium.

title: Conferees Agree to Ban Research on Live Fetus
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 Senate and House conferees have agreed on legislation to impose a temporary ban on research involving the living human fetus, a subject of great controversy in recent months.

title: ... and How to Resolve It
description: Despite its seeming complexity, the gold issue is not insoluble. Americans and Europeans should not find it hard to agree that the present official price of gold at $42.22 is meaningless and that it would be desirable for nations to be able to use their gold reserves to cover deficits. Agreement should also be possible on the dangers, under present conditions of world inflation and floating exchange rates, of trying to fix a new official price for gold. On that basis, a foundation clearly can be established for willingness by both sides to agree to wipe out the official price altogether and let the price of gold be determined in the free market.

title: ExProsecutor Denies Threats To Partner of Accused Officer
description: A former Queens prosecutor yesterday denied at the murder trial of Police Officer Thomas J. Shea that any threats had been made against Officer Walter Scott, who was the patrol partner of the defendant. Officer Shea is charged with the slaying of 10yearold Clifford Glover.

title: LILCO BOND ISSUES ARE DOWNGRADED
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, which rates corporate and municipal bonds, reduced the bond credit rating yesterday of the Long Island Lighting Company from doubleA to singleA.

title: 4 Rob Canarsie Bank
description: Four bank robbers held up the Canarsie branch of the National Bank of North America in Brooklyn yesterday and fled in a red car with $7,600. After entering the bank, at 901 East 107th Street, the robbers took the guard's gun and trained it on the 13 people inside. Two of them vaulted the counter and emptied two tellers' drawers.

title: Saxbe Warns Business To Stop Cutting Corners
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, June 7 (UPI)Attorney General Wil liam. B. Saxbe warned the nation's businessmen today that free enterprise may be wrecked if they do not face up to personal Watergates and stop cutting corners with the law.

title: Gabrielsen Gains British Amateur Final
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 7 (AP)Jimmy Gabrielson, a United States Walker Cup player from Atlanta, charged into the final of the British Amateur golf championship with two victories today.

title: Pew Interest Involved
description: Negotiations are being conducted by the International Paper Company for a possible merger of the General Crude Oil Company, a Houstonbased independent producer of oil and gas, as a wholly, owned subsidiary, of the paper concern. The negotiations are with the Glenmede Trust Company of Philadelphia, which is trustee for the Pew Memorial Trust and a majority stockholder in General Crude. Glenmede Trust, which also as trustee for the Pew Memorial Trust owns 18 per cent of the voting power in the Sun Oil Company, favors the proposal involving General Crude and International Paper. The Pew Memorial Trust owns the greater part of the Pew family's extensive holding and is administered Glenmede.

title: Cadillac Sales Defy Lag and Set Mark
description: DETROIT, June 7Defying the sales slump that still afflicts the rest of the auto industry, the Cadillac division of General Motors is selling its luxury cars in record numbers once more.

title: Ashe, Riessen Advance In French Open Tennis
description: PARIS, June 7 (AP)Arthur Ashe and Marty Riessen led a fiveman American challenge into the third round of the $200,000 French open tennis tournament today in which the top European favorites also advanced with ease.

title: Screen: Lilies Bloom
description: An endearingly simple, honest and moving film like Where the Lilies Bloom would be welcome any time. Arriving now on a screen splattered with violence and sex, this beautiful little movie is like a cool, clear dip of mountain spring water.

title: CLERICS HOPEFUL ON WORLD CRISIS
description: ASPEN, Colo., June 7With a statement of conscience and some plans for action, religious leaders ended today a fourday seminar on a crisis that they agreed was awesome and complex: hunger, poverty and injustice in the world.

title: JUDGE DENOUNCES REFUSAL OF NIXON TO GIVE UP PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Federal Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, weighing the possibility of citing President Nixon for contempt of court, said today that Mr. Nixon's rejection of a courtapproved procedure for producing White House documents in the plumbers case was offensive and borders on obstruction.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON INTEREST CUT
description: The stock market finally got the good news it has been waiting fora cut in the prime rate by a major bankand moved upward yesterday.

title: Prosperity Woes
description: Canada's mining industry, which has been revitalized by soaring world metals prices, is suddenly suffering as result of too much prosperity. Details on Page 41.

title: News Tidbits Are Gems At House Panel Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 7At a recent break in the House Judiciary Committee's closed hearings, Representative Wayne Owens, Democrat of Utah, was besieged by clamoring reporters as he emerged from Room 2141 and walked down the hall.

title: Portuguese Wants to Keep His Angola Roots
description: CASSOALALA, Angola, June 3  Vicente Duarte Gomes came to Angola 23 years ago because Portugal did not provide enough work for him as a bricklayer in and around Lisbon. He was a construction worker for three years, making a living. Then he came to this region more than 100 miles southeast of the capital, Luanda, to help in the restoration of the ruins of a 300yearold foundry.

title: Bank Held Up in Queens
description: A Chemical Bank branch in Long Island City, Queens, was held up yesterday by an armed robber who escaped with $4,000. A teller in the branch, at 29.09 Bridge Plaza North, gave the robber the money after he handed her a threatening note and showed a gun.

title: KISSINGER REBUTS NIXON ON WIRETAP
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Secretary of State Kissinger said today that President Nixon was apparently under a misapprehension in reportedly suggesting that he had requested the wiretapping of Government officials and journalists beginning in 1969.

title: Conflict Over Gold ...
description: One of the key issues that will be confronting representatives of the major financial powers at the final session of their monetary conference in Washington next week will be how to resolve the conflict between the United States and several European countries on the future role of gold.

title: Merged Polytechnic Institute Awards First 1,000 Degrees
description: The Polytechnic Institute of New York, which was created by the merger of Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute and the New York University School of Engineering last summer, awarded its first degrees yesterday to nearly 1,000 engineers, mathematicians and others in the science fields.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Dispute Marks Northern Tennis Upset

title: Codd Appears on Council Demand to Defend Budget Plan for 1,440 More Police Officers
description: The City Council's Finance Committee yesterday demanded that Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd appear before it in person to defend his budget and a proposed 1,440man increase in the police force.

title: 20Month Boy Falls 8 Floors to Canopy; Suffers Swollen Lip
description: A 20monthold boy survived without serious injury yesterday when he fell from an eighthfloor apartment window on Madison Avenue between 83d and 84th Streets and landed, apparently unharmed, on a street canopy of a travel agency.

title: Eager Pickers Find Berried Treasure As L.I. Farmers Open Fields to Public
description: WADING RIVER, L. I., The legs start to wobble and the back starts to ache after an hour. This is why there, are usually enough strawberries to go around when the public plays migrant worker for a few weeks each June.

title: German Couple Held In Cocaine Smuggling
description: A young German couple accused of hiding about 6.6 pounds of cocaine in their baby's crib and babyfood boxes as well as in their baggage were arraigned before a Federal magistrate in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday ins:

title: Two Soviet Dancers Reported Free to Go After Long Struggle
description: MOSCOW, June 7The Soviet authorities have decided to let the ballet dancers Valery Panov and Galina Ragozina, his wife; emigrate to Israel, unofficial Soviet sources reported today.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP TO 5.2% FROM 6%
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 Unemployment rose somewhat in May but remained in the general range that has prevailed since the start of the year, the Labor Department reported today.

title: PRICES RISE AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices continued to rise on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yssterday as the trend toward lower prime interest rates was given impetus by the First National City Bank, which cut its rate from 11 to 11 per cent. A few smaller banks followed suit.

title: Baby Falls 8 Floors, Lands on a Canopy, Suffers Swollen Lip
description: A 20monthold boy survived without serious injury yesterday when he fell from an eighthfloor apartment window on Madison Avenue between 83d and 84th Streets and landed on a street canopy of a travel agency.

title: Ashe, Riessen Advance In French Open Tennis
description: PARIS, June 7 (AP)Arthur Ashe and Marty Riessen led a fiveman American challenge into the third round of the $200,000 French open tennis tournament today in which the top European favorites also advanced with ease.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOLY FOOLS IN MOSCOW. By Yuri Kuper. 230 pages. Quadrangle/The New York Times Book Co. $7.95.

title: CRISIS IN ECONOMY DEEPENS IN ITALY
description: ROME, June 7  Premier Mariano Rumor and his key ministers met throughout the day today to discuss Italy's deteriorating economic situation amid speculation that the lira would soon be devalued.

title: GEORGE T. M'SPEDON
description: George T. McSpedon, a trade union official, died yesterday morning at Yonkers General Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 187 Morsmer Avenue, Yonkers.

title: Atlantic Richfield Price Up
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that it had increased the wholesale price of gasoline by 2 cents a gallon, in all marketing areas, effective immediately.

title: Nixon Defense Fund for Aides Is Denied
description: WASHINGTON, June 7A White House spokesman said today that President Nixon had expressed a willingness to help two close former aides, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, meet their Watergaterelated legal expenses but that the President had never provided any such help.

title: JUDGE DENOUNCES REFUSAL OF NIXON TO GIVE UP PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Federal Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, weighing the possibility of citing President Nixon for contempt of court, said today that Mr. Nixon's rejection of a courtapproved procedure for producing White House documents in the plumbers case was offensive and borders on obstruction.

title: Dr, Zelda Sobel Mapper, 51, Child Psychologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Zelda Sobel Klapper, chief psychologist in the children's evaluation and rehabilitation clinic of the Rose F. Kennedy Center of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died of cancer Thursday. She was 51 years old and lived at Gerlach Place, Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Senate Aides See Bureaucracy Use For Political Gain
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) The Nixon Administration used the Federal bureaucracy for political profit and apparently violated several criminal statutes in the process, according to a Senate Watergate committee staff report.

title: Art: The Reinhardt Style And Theater Era Evoked
description: Exhibitions designed to evoke the splendors of distant theatrical achievements are, by their very nature, exercises in magical suggestion. Like archeologists reconstructing the life of a lost civilization, the organizers of such exhibitions must cast their spell by marshaling recovered fragments and elusive myths into a coherent and persuasive image. Everything depends on how vividly a legend can be temporarily invested with an air of reality.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Penelope Poor, Peter J. Dolara Plan to Marry
description: The engagement of Miss Penelope Elizabeth Poor to Peter Joseph Dolara, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Dolara of Montevideo, Uruguay, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Barton Poor of Garden City and East Hampton, L. I.

title: Miss Ramsing, Donald Byrne Wed in Jersey
description: The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Wrightson Ramsing to Donald Coleman Byrne took place in Holmdel, N.J., yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Arthur Joice, a minister of the United Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony at Cheeca Farm, home of Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Twitchell, uncle and aunt of the bride.

title: U.S. Set to Spend Millions to Upgrade Foreclosed Housing
description: The Federal Government is stepping up its efforts to dispose of 4,000 residential properties in the metropolitan area that have come into its possession through mortgage foreclosure.

title: Rothko Art, Mostly Unseen, Is Ensnarled in Web of Intricate Suits
description: When Mark Rothko was young painter he had to teach to help support himself. As his stature in the art worldand his priceswent up, he began to hoard his paintings, and tried to see that those he solo were hung in special places separated from the work of other artists.

title: Defeating Troop Cuts
description: The decisive defeat of the Mansfield amendment requiring withdrawal of 125,000 American troops from overseas is a victory for common sense. The Senate vote, thirty years to the day after the American landing in Normandy that began the liberation of Nazioccupied Europe, was a vote for responsible American policy in the world, a vote against unilateral disengagement.

title: Epilogue
description: The handwritten note that Dwight L. Chapin recently sent to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, apologizing for Mr. Chapin's connection with dirty tricks during the last Presidential campaign, contained some words that have not been much in use this last year. This is a long overdue letter of apology, President Nixon's former appointments secretary wrote. Don Segretti's acts are my responsibility to bear. It is recognized how very wrong I was and that my actions jeopardized a system I love and respect. Mr. Chapin, who resigned Feb. 28, 1973, was the White House contact with Mr. Segretti, who was in charge of the dirty tricks operation in the 1972 reelection campaign. Mr. Chapin was convicted of lying to a grand jury when he denied knowledge of Mr. Segretti's activities. Last October Mr. Segretti told the special Senate Watergate Committee that he had distributed a phony letter accusing Senator Humphrey and Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, of sexual misconduct. Mr. Segretti also wrote a note of apology to Sen. Humphrey, and apologized in person as well.

title: Panovs Expected to Settle in U.S. or Britain
description: MOSCOW, June 8The Ballet dancer Valery Panov was officially informed by Soviet visa authorities today that he and Galina Ragozina, his wife,. have permission to emigrate to Israel and must depart from the Soviet Union in five days.

title: Paris Has Gone Mad Over Movies
description: AN American in Paris for the first time in several years was less likely to be impressed by President Valry Giscard d'Estaing's wellpublicized walk to the Elyse Palace 10 days ago than by the easy availability of frais du bois so early in the season and of movies, of a larger number and a greater variety than one is apt to see in a year in New York.

title: Ideas &Trends Mathematics, Communications, Theology
description: Federal Bench Is HurtBy Low Wages

title: Living With Inflation Falls Short of Living Well
description: The cost of living in the metropolitan area has gone up nearly 10 per cent a year's time. Here is how rising prices, especially for food and fuel, have affected the lives of three families with moderate Incomes.

title: 1.5Billion Loss Laid To Arson for Profit;
description: NEW BRUNSWICKDelegates to the 11th annual Arson and Fire Investigation Conference here last week were told that arson for financial gain was constantly increasing and that its financial toll throughout the country amounted to more than $1.5billion a year.

title: Drug Abuse Parley Is Slated in Bergen
description: MAHWAHThe fifth annual Bergen County Drug Abuse Seminar will be held June 1721 at the Police and Fire Training Academy on Campgaw Road. The seminar is open to all professionals working in the field of drug abuse, to municipal officials and interested lay persons.

title: The Political Hopefuls Are Squaring Off
description: State Senator Carol Bellamy is expected to begin a lively primary fight tomorrow with a fellow Brooklyn Democrat involving such forces as the Hasidic community, the feminist political movement and for those who see life that wayman against woman.

title: Loretta Williams Wed To Eddie L. Franklin
description: Miss Loretta Audrey Williams and Eddie L. Franklin, publicschool teachers in Atlanta, were married there yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Norman Rates, chaplain of Spelman College, performed the interdenominational ceremony on the lawn outside the college chapel.

title: Morristown Baha'i to Hold Unity Day
description: MORRISTOWNRace Unity Day will be held here this afternoon under the sponsorship of members of the Baha'i Faith. The program, an outdoor symposium, will take place in Burnham Park on Washington Street, starting at 1 o'clock.

title: AnNett McGee Silva Wed to K. S. Littlefield
description: Miss AnNett McGee Silva, daughter of Mrs. John Thaxter Watson of Lexington, Mass., and Richard L. Silva of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Kenneth Sprague Littlefield.

title: A Colombian Plane With 38 Crashes; All Believed Killed
description: CUCUTA, Colombia, June 8 (UPI)  A plane with 38 persons aboard crashed near the Colombian  Venezuelan border tonight and reports from the scene said there were no survivors.

title: Tania LawsonJohnston Bride Of Mark Tassie in Princeton
description: In Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N. J., yesterday afternoon, Miss Tania Orman LawsonJohnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter O. LawsonJohnston of Princeton, became the bride of Mark Tassie, son of Mrs. Brogan Tassie of Princeton and John Tassie of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Whittemore.

title: Book Review: Yogi And the Harmonica
description: Well, I thought, if my exroomie, Jim outon, can write three books, I'm sure can write a book review. Besides, ??es me a chance to plug Mr. Laffs ??d use one of Yogi's witticisms: No. ??y goes there anymore. It's too ??owded.

title: To the Class of '74 With Love
description: Art Buchwald's lighthearted message to this year's college graduates was that we've given you a perfect world, so don't louse it up, but most of the other commencementday speakers seem to have been in a decidedly pessimistic mood.

title: Inquiry on Tire Law Asked
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, says he has asked the General Accounting Office to investigate the delay in carrying out a law designed to help tire buyers. Mr. Nelson said Wednesday that legislation he sponsored in 1966 directed the Secretary of Transportation to prescribe within two years a uniform quality grading system for motor vehicle tires. Why has nothing been put into effect by this time? he asked.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Police to Hire Handicapped
description: ALBANYPhysically handicapped persons are expected to play a major role in answering emergency telephone calls to Suffolk County's Police Department under the terms of a bill signed into law last week by Governor Wilson.

title: To Cure Inflation
description: Here in the United States and throughout the world, inflation has become a problem of unexpected intensity and baffling complexity.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Tennessee Wins Title In N.C.A.A.
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 8This was definitely not U.C.L.A.'s year in athletics.

title: Dance
description: HOW many famous dramatists are there in the world? How many famous painters? How many famous poets, or novelists, or composers, or sculptors? I don't mean the moderately wellknown, with local reputations. I mean the internationally accepted. Take film directorshow many? Fifty, a hundred, even two hundred? More? No, hardly more, but there are perhaps a hundred or so film directors whose names and works are familiar to an international audience whose interest is not specifically in film.

title: Hagon 4:07.8 Mile Sets Scholastic Mark
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 8Mike Hagon of Suffern High in Rockland County captured the onemile run today with the nation's fifthfastest scholastic clocking of the season in the state intersectional track and field championships.

title: The Sweet Smell of Success
Why Group W Couldn't Sell Television Documentaries
description: SIX years ago, I naively believed that the television stations around this country would welcome an additional source of investigative TV documentaries. I was wrong. I discovered I was wrong over a period of six years ending late last year when Group W (Westinghouse Broadcasting Company) gave up its $2.5million effort to reach a wide national audience with a regular series of such programs.

title: What Sank the Dallas Symphony OrchestraAfter 74 Years?
description: SHOCK waves were felt throughout the music world some weeks ago when the 74  year  old Dallas Symphony Orchestraone of the six oldest orchestras in the United Statessuddenly suspended performance. Jack Vandagriff, then president of the Dallas Symphony Association, explained to the local press that management was no longer able to pay the 86 musicians their salaries and, accordingly, he was cancelling the remainder of the season in order to avert the financial collapse of the organization.

title: Horseowner's Tenants Picket at Belmont Park
description: Seven tenants of a luxury East Side apartment building picketed outside Belmont Park yesterday afternoon to protest the action of their landlord, Sigmond Sommer, the owner of a horse, Rube the Great, that was running in the Belmont Stakes.

title: Bland Jackson Marries in Capital
description: Miss Frances Bland Jackson of Washington and Hastings Keith of Washington, Brockton and Marion, Mass., who served as a United States Representative from Massachusdtts from 1959 to 1972, were married yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church in Washington by the Rev. David Pollack.

title: Plan to Win Voters Loses Candidates
description: BALDWIN  There have been few dull moments in the school board campaign here lately, but although a local citizens' group set out late last year to combat apathy toward the election, its efforts apparently proved a bit too successful.

title: Plea to Drill for Uranium Deferred by Pennsylvania
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 8The Exxon Corporation wants the privilege of drilling for uraniudi on 23,000 acres of land now set aside for game in Luzerne and Carbon Counties.

title: Discotheque Becomes a Supper Club
description: JERSEY CITYWhen Dr. Jonathan C. Gibbs Jr., a surgeon and gynecologist who also is active in local civic affairs, decided to open a discotheque here a little more than a year ago, it was, he felt, natural to call it The Womb.

title: MANSFIELD SEES NO BAR TO TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 8Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, said today that neither the elections this fall nor the probability that some lameduck Senators might sit as jurors should interfere with any Senate impeachment trial of President Nixon.

title: Nancy H. McKee, Surgeon, Wed to Arthur Condliffe
description: Dr. Nancy Hunt McKee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence McKee of North Bay, Ontario, was married in Toronto yesterday afternoon to Arthur John Condliffe, son of Mrs. Jane Rosenthal Condliffe of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Vineyard Haven, Mass., and John C. Condliffe of Union City, N. J.

title: Maple Syrup
description: The maple trees are In full leaf now, their time saprun two months past. The spiles and sapbuckets traditional syrupmakers are washed and stowed for another year, and the plastic hose and sap bags of the newfangled technique in the sugar bush have been flushed out and put away. The evaporating pans have done their job. The jugs have been filled and sent market. Now the figures are in for the 1974 season, and New York State is the top maple syrup producer. Vermont is a close second.

title: Uganda Bans Some Papers
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, June 8 (UPI)  President ldi Amin today banned what an Information Ministry spokesman described as imperialist newspapers. They include four London papersThe Daily Telegraph, The Times, Sunday Observer and Sunday Express, and all newspapers from Kenya.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, June 8All three Irish hungerstrikers in British jails ended their fast today, following the lead of the Irish Price sisters last night.

title: Camera World
description: AS SOON as the beginning photographer starts to progress beyond the simple snapshot stage, his first interest usually lies in getting a more sophisticated camera, one which will permit him or her some controland nowadays this almost always means a modern 35mm single lens reflex camera. However, in order to choose a camera he must know something about basic camera controls and operation, and a new book just published by Amphoto (Garden City, N.Y.) provides practically all the answers to the questions that might be asked. Entitled You and Your Camera, by William R. Hawken ($4.95 in largeformat paperback) this volume clearly explains and illustrates camera functions in easily understood nontechnical language. The drawings and photographs illustrate all (Continued on Next Page)

title: Ballet: Tomasson Takes on Role of the Prodigal
description: One is guessing perhaps, yet it seems that no role in the New York City Ballet repertory is so jealously guarded as that of the eponymous hero in George Balanchine's The Prodigal Son. So far as memory serves  and the service is always liable to disruption since the ballet Was first introduced into the company repertory in 1950 it has been danced by only Jerome Robbins (whom I did not see), Francisco Moncion, Hugh Laing and Edward Villella. There have been othre Prodigals with a few other companies, including David Wall and Rudolf Nureyev for Britain's Royal Ballet, but with City Ballet the part has for years been the exclusive preserve of Mr. Villella, who ha made it into one of his greatest characterizations.

title: Letters: L.I.R.R. Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: Vermont Blue Cross Ruling
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., June 8 (AP)  The state's Supreme Court has ruled that the Department of Banking and Insurlance may set separate rates for Vermont subscribers of the New HampshireVermont Blue Cross hospitalization plan.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Paperbacks
description: It is hard to think of Tarzan without thinking of one's own childhood. Yet that immortal myth of the abandoned child of civilization who survives to become Lord of the Jungle was not written for children at all  as I keep explaining to my 9yearold son whenever he snatches from my desk the volume I am currently reading. Look, I tell him, the only two books Burroughs ever deliberately wrote for kids are lousy. Stupid. And besides, I add, your teenage brother and your mother are next in line after me. Then you. But in some sense he has the prior claim. Certainly I was his age when I began the series, and I am his age still when I return to it now. Or rather, I realize returning to it that, at my deepest level of response, I have remained faithful to the dream which move me then.

title: School to Give West End Ave. A Modish Look
description: The staid apartment buildings on West End Avenue are getting an architecturally flamboyant neighbor.

title: Governor General Taken To a Hospital in Canada
description: MONTREAL, June 8 (UPI)  The Canadian Governor General, Jules Leger, collapsed during a dinner at the University of Sherbrooke tonight and was rushed to a hospital, a spokesman said.

title: The Theater Means Transformation
description: THE question is: what would you like to be turned into? A lithe and prancing cougar? Your own father? A house animal scratching in the dirt? A Currier and Ives New Englander? This last choice may be difficult if you happen to be born Chinese.

title: The Nation/Continued
description: WASHINGTONRichard Nixon never planned to preside over a Government similar to that of the second term of Woodrow Wilson, when the President lay ill for many months and Cabinet members ran their departments as they saw fit with only occasional instructions from the First Lady. The first Nixon term saw power centralized under the White House as it had never been before, and plans for the second were for the President to consolidate even further his control of the bureaucracy.

title: Buerkle Resolves Conflict With 4:01.9 A .A. U. Mile
Food: Old Hand at Italian Specialties
description: TENAFLY  The Italian Gourmet, a delicatessen here, carries only one kind of food. Italian, naturally.

title: Who Makes Music
Mother of U.S. Open Stays a Year Ahead, Nursing Tournament to Life
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 8  There is a policeman at the entrance of the Winged Foot Golf Club checking identification, and security men are on the course in places you cannot see. Multicolored tents are all about the club grounds and a long row of blue portable toilets waits to be placed at 70 strategic locations over the otherwise sophisticated West Course, where the 74th United States Open golf tournament will be played starting Thursday.

title: BIDDER GLADLY PAYS $8,050 FOR $200 ITEM
description: BRIDGEWATER, Mass., June 8A 35yearold collector and dealer of Americana here has made a rare buy.

title: Island of Grenada Applies For Membership in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 8The tiny Caribbean island of Grenada has applied for membership in the United Nations.

title: UNION AIDE SCORES SOME PRINCIPALS
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 8  The president of the union that represents New York City's 4,000 school supervisors charged today that some Spanishspeaking persons who could barely speak or write English had become acting principals of city schools in recent years as the result of school decentralization.

title: Annual Irish Fete To Be Held June 30
description: HOLMDEL  Outstanding performers from both sides of the Atlantic will blend the traditional and contemporary worlds of Celtic entertainment at the fourth annual Irish Festival, which will be held at the Garden State Arts Center on June 30.

title: Prickly and Slimy TastePleasers of the Sea
description: WANTAGH  Few fishermen expect a hero's welcome after a day on the water and only a bagful of eels or a bucket of blowfish to show for it. A few days ago, however, the Long Island State Parks and Recreation Commission held a clinic at Jones Beach designed to help anglers transform blowfish into sea squab and eels into several tasty dishes.

title: People and Business
description: The disposal of residential trash promises to become big business for the Vorik Corporation of Sparta, which has developed and patented a new compactor for home refuse. Vorik asserts that the unit can reduce seven pounds of waste material in a paper bag to onetenth its original volume. The time required is less than two minutes.

title: Will the thundering herd ever return to Wall Street?
description: A celebrated anecdote of the nineteentwenties has to do with a rustic visiting Manhattan, who is proudly shown the great brokers' yachts moored on the East River. Where, inquires the yokel, are the customers' yachts? In an updated version, the rustic is exposed to the griping in a brokerage house board room, and his question is, Where are the customers?

title: Carol Bancker Has Nuptials
description: Miss Carol Bancker, daughter of Mrs. William D. Bancker 4th and the late Mr. Bancker of Port Washington, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Alexander Wellman Vietor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander O. Vietor of New Haven and Old Lyme, Conn., and Edgartown, Mass.

title: Court Challenged on Pornography
description: TRENTONThe State Supreme Court has before it the opportunity to draft standards for outlawing pornography in New Jersey, despite indications that it might be reluctant to do so.

title: DIPLOMAT'S SEIZURE LINKED TO EXP.O.W.
description: SAN DIEGO, June 8, (UPI)A man who turned up as the only civilian among American prisoners of war released by North Vietnam has been indicted on charges that he set up the kidnapping of an American diplomat in Hermosillo, Mexico.

title: Italian Cabinet Split in Financial Crisis
description: ROME, June 8Government leaders today continued emergency talks on Italys deepening financial crisis, but political conflicts delayed urgently needed measures to pull the nation back from the brink of insolvency.

title: House Panel Up to No. 26 In Volumes of Nixon Data
description: WASHINGTON, June 8On the desk of each member of the House Judiciary Committee when it resumes impeachment hearings Tuesday will be a black looseleaf binder. It will contain evidence.

title: Nigeria Debates Creating New States
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, June 7 New census figures, showing that Nigeria had a population of 79,758,969 last December, have enlivened a national political debate on whether the country should be redivided into a larger number of states.

title: Aid Sought for Medical School
description: TRENTON  An organization composed of some of New Jersey's most prominent business and civic leaders has begun a fund  raising drive to help the state's College of Medicine and Dentistry undertake programs of financial aid to needy students and to underwrite community  health and scientific  research projects.

title: Justice Aide Quits
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) Horace S. Webb has resigned as deputy director of public information for the Justice Department and plans to open a public relations firm in Washington. Mr. Webb's resignation was announced by the department on Monday.

description: THE time: Last fall.

title: MRS. EDMUND B. WILSON
description: Mrs. Anne Maynard Kidder Wilson, widow of Edmund Beecher Wilson, professor or biology at Columbia University, died in St. Petersburg, Fla., on Tuesday. She was 93 years old and had lived previously in New York and Woods Hole, Mass.

title: INVESTING
description: Investing money, which always involves difficult choices, seems an almost unsurmountable task these days as inflation soars at rates in excess of 10 per cent a year. With this in mind, The New York Times asked four specialists to advise some hypothetical citizensa retired couple, a middleaged widow and a junior executivehow to invest various sums to best meet their particular circumstances.

title: What's Doing in SULLIVAN COUNTY
description: THE SETTINGSullivan County, a fivesided political unit lying 100plus miles from New York City, can hardly be described as alpine. But it's lofty enough in spots to be the place that most lowlying New Yorkers mean when they say they are going to the mountains. The mountains are the Sullivan County Catskills only a small part of the Catskill range, but the part that has established itself in the minds of city dwellers as the resort area, the epitome of summer escapism. It's the place where New Yorkers over the years have had their pick of nightclubs, lavish hotels, summer cottages, children's camps, summer theaters, shimmering lakes, woodland trails and a wide selection of sports, including hunting, fishing and boating. And all this while getting their full of fresh air and meals.

description: Whirling skirts. Twirling capes. Tentlike coats and dresses. Full skirts with longer hemlines.

description: MADISONIf a prediction by Ted Monica, director of athletics at Madison High School, materializes, the National and American Basketball Associations will have a female counterpart within five years. At present, there are professional barnstorming quintets manned solely by women.

title: CANADIAN UNION ENDING U.S. LINK
description: OTTAWA, June 8The Canadian branch of the United Paperworkers International Union, the largest organization of industrial workers in Canada, completed plans this week to break away from the American parent organization, accelerating a controversial nationalist trend in Canadian labor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The thinking outlined in the article Top Planner Hints A Zoning Overhaul [May 19] indicates that it will never be possible to construct a building in New York City without applying to the City Planning Commission for approval.

title: ... Magic Word For Democrats Is Silence
description: WASHINGTONDemocrats in Congress had a clear claim on the networks for time to answer President Nixon's television performance of April 29 in which he pointed to a stack of edited transcripts of White House tape recordings, announced he was releasing them to the world and declared the President has nothing to hide.

title: Government of Laws?
description: President Nixon now dwells in the shadowy borderland between the legal and the illegal. If the Government of the United States is to remain a government of laws and not of men, it is only a question of time until Congress and the courts call his conduct to account. In view of the reckless and defiant quality of his conduct, that time of final judgment cannot come too soon.

title: State Opening Inquiry on Phone Solicitation for Handicapped
description: TRENTONThe State Commission of Investigation will hold a threeday public hearing this week on what has become a nuisance to many residents: telephone solicitation for the sale of household articles, ostensibly on behalf of the handicapped.

title: Sealing Off Train Fire in Tunnel Urged After Flooding Fails
description: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., June 8Attempts to drown a dangerous and persistent fire in a railroad tunnel just south of here failed today, and firemen suggested that the tunnel be sealed to smother the blaze, now in its third day.

title: Alexandra Pietrasanta Is a Bride
description: Miss Alexandra Maria Pietrasanta, daughter of Mrs. Donald Canmore Malcom of Monte Carlo, Monaco, and the late Colint Vittorio Pietrasanta of Genoa, Italy, was married to Peter Henry Rose, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rose of New York. The Rev. Theodore St. Onge performed the ceremony in Christ the King Roman, Catholic Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: France and Germany, A Necessary Friendship
description: PARISThe circle has come almost full turn for Europe, after more than a decade of exalted language and a series of exploding boobytraps underfoot. The trend toward economic and political unification that began 10 years ago, and which has been in trouble recently, has been given new hope with the advent of new leaders in France and Germany who are eager to cooperate.

title: Bridge
description: Whether to finesse or play for the drop is often a crucial decision and may make a difference of several tricks. The maximum in this connection is 13 tricks, and such a deal was described recently in the South African Bridge Bulletin. The author is Norreys Davis of Kitwe, who gets a high rating as an entertainer but does not qualify as a nonfiction writer. Indignant readers who are reaching for pens to complain about the diagram for this column are asked to postpone actionuntil they have finished reading.

description: DENVER, June 8  The business of prostitution, embracing modern marketing techniques and skirting the law, is branching out from its downtown closet into Middle America.

description: Pindar L. Roraback, former president of the Federation Bank and Trust Company (now Franklin National), died on Thursday at the Mary Hitchcock Hospital in Durham, N. H. He was 69 years old and had lived in Durham since his retirement in 1966.

title: EastWest European Meetings Reported Stalled on All Issues
description: GENEVA, June 8A 35nation effort to draft a charter hailing a new era in EastWest relations has become stalled on all key issues nearly a year after it was officially started.

description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne's proposal for the state to take over, and assume the cost of operating, all courts in New Jersey has revived hopes for a streamlined judicial system.
