title: World Cup Soccer to Start Thursday In West Germany With a New Format
description: Soccer's showcase gets under way in Frankfurt, West Germany on Thursday when Brazil, the defending champion, takes on Yugoslavia in the opening game of the 10th World Cup. And by the time a new world champion is crowned in Munich on July 7, the impact of this competition ma?? equal anything that has occurred in sports before.

title: Coast Women Win Job Gains at Bank
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 8The Bank of America, the largest commercial bank in the orld, has announced what as described as a farreaching bettlement of a classaction suit rought on behalf of its female employes.

title: Boating Industry Is Humming
description: TRENTONInflation and the energy crisis are apparently having no effect on New Jersey's $200million boating industry, according to figures compiled by the state's Division of Marine Services.

title: Southern Gothic, Southern color
description: A Cry of Angels is a delightful blend of literary influences: the openfaced charm of Huckleberry Finn, the White Trash humor of early Erskine Caldwell novels, a sprinkle of Faulknerian symbolic menace. Its plot roars into high gear immediately and races through twists and turns and strange developments very sentimentalbut never mawkish. All its violence and bloodshed somehow dissolve into a warm triumph of humanity. Evil is resoundingly defeated; good scores a tiny advanceit is an enormously comforting book.

title: The king is dead, long live the people
description: Posterity, both liberal and conservative, has generally been hostile to the French regicides of 1793, accusing them of mean fanaticism, of inhumane and ruthlessly implacable logic, in their judgment of Louis XVI. In contemplating the creation of modern republics, posterity has preferred the more reassuring Founding Fathers of America, patricians unstained by judicial murder.

title: Nancy Tabas Engaged To Philip H. Goldstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Tabas of BalaCynwyd, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Tabas, to Philip H. Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron A. Goldstein of Penn Valley, Pa.

title: Clothing Workers Reach Accord With Management
description: A settlement was announced last night in the weeklong nationwide strike by 110,000 workers in the men's and boy's tailored clothing industry.

title: Sally Phipps Becomes Bride
description: Miss Averyl Sarah Phipps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Huntington Phipps of Villanova, Pa., and Nonquitt, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Danilo Marc deDominicis of Paris, where he is in international marketing. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dante deDominicis of Nice, France.

title: Risky Tasks in Cambodia Anger U.S. Copter Pilots
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 6After risking their lives for a decade in Indochina, a number of privately employed American helicopter pilots are expressing bitterness and resentment over a United States Government contract that requires them to fly what they term dangerous, paramilitary missions into Cambodia without extra pay and with little chance of being rescued if they go down.

title: Homer Beats Gabrielsen, 2 Up, Gains British Title
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, June 8 (AP)  Trevor Homer of England held off the late charge of Jim Gabrielsen of Atlanta and won the coveted British Amateur golf championship, 2up, in the 36hole final today.

title: KISSINGER LINKED TO ORDER TO F.B.I. ENDING WIRETAPS
description: WASHINGTON, June 8Henry A. Kissinger's National Security Council office was directly responsible for ordering the Federal Bureau of Investigation to end the 17 socalled national security wiretaps on newsmen and officials that began in 1969, highly placed sources said today.

title: Miss Simpson Wed to Grover O'Neill
description: Miss Laura Knickerbocker Simpson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Kelly Simpson and a greatgreatgranddaughter of John D. Rockefeller, was married in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday afternoon to Grover O'Neill 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Neill Jr. of New York and Nantucket, Mass.

title: Tax Reform: How? When?
description: TRENTON  Both houses of the Legislature will reconvene here Thursday to begin considering Governor Byrne's proposed taxreform program. As outlined last month, the Governor has suggested a state income levy that would enable New Jersey to assume a major share of local education costs and thereby reduce local property taxes by more than 25 per cent.

title: Widow
description: The word widow comes from the Sanskrit, Lynn Caine tells us, and means emptya word akin to void. Nun and widow, null and void: words that assert that a woman is nothing, empty, without a man. And, it seems, frighteningly, many women still do feel just this way. Our society is set up so that most women lose their identities when their husbands die, writes Mrs. Caine. We add ourselves to our men, pour ourselves into them and their lives. We exist in their reflection. And then ...? If they die? And yet, a great percentage of women must face exactly this contingency. Statistics show that men die before their wives much more often than the other ways arounda bitter paradox when you consider that the wives have, in a sense, so much more to lose: not only their loves but their very definition of themselves.

title: Wolhuter Again Sets World Mark in 880
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 8 (AP) Rick Wolhuter, who came to Eugene, Ore., to break his own world record in the 880yard run, did just that tonight, winning the event in 1 minute 44,1 seconds at the Hayward Field Restoration track and field meet.

title: Ox Ridge Is the Next Hurdle for Jenkins
description: The 45th edition of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show gets under way for five days in Darien, Conn., Wednesday with Rod Jenkins against the fieldand sometimes against himself. After riding the winners of six championships at the Devon show eight days ago, it would appear that Jenkins has run out of worlds to conquer.

title: Malefactors
description: ACROSS

title: CRIME IN HOTELS CONTINUES HERE
description: Two murders and a stabbing that were reported last week highlighted a continuing pattern of violent crime in singleroomoccupancy' facilities on Manhattan's West Side.

title: Fire Kills Hotel Resident
description: A 51yearold woman died yesterday morning when her bed caught fire in her apartment in an Upper West Side residential hotel, the Fire Department reported. A spokesman said the fire was listed as being of suspicious origin since the woman, Winifred Miller of the Park Plaza Hotel, 50 West 77th Street, was not a smoker. No one else was reported injured.

title: The Kean Estate Mirrors Family's
description: UNIONLiberty Hall, a preRevoluionary War mansion that was built for the state's first Governor, has been dedicated as a National Historical Landmark, thus focusing attention on the family that has continued to occupy it for six generations.

title: A Refresher Course for Nurses Is Planned in Middlesex
description: EDISONRegistered nurses who have left the profession for careers as, say, housewives will have a chance again this summer to update their skills and perhaps return permanently to medical work.

title: Melissa Sands Wed To Ford K. Boveroux
description: Miss Melissa Marsh Sands, daughter Of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Evans Sands 3d of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Ford Kent Boveroux, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Leonhard Boveroux of Essex Fells, N.J.

title: Music
description: JUDITH BLEGEN, the young soprano from Missoula, Montana, who will appear tomorrow in the Met's new production of Gianni Schicchi as Lauretta, the lass who sings one of opera's most celebrated arias (Oh mio babbino caro), is given to harsh selfexamination. I never thought I had a fabulous voice, she said during an interview last week. And I don't want any discussion about it because you have no choice but to say, Oh, but you do, Miss Blegen! I also never thought I was going to set the world on fire because of the sheer beauty of my voice. In other words, I'm not a Tebaldi. So I've always wanted to develop every other aspect of myself because I really love music and want to perform it. But I never thought I had a career coming to me either, and therefore I've always assumed that unless I do an enormous amount of work, I'm not going to get anything.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Patricia Sheeran Bride of John Atwood
description: Miss Patricia Ann Sheeran, daughter of Mrs. James Parker Haney of New York and Rumson, N.J., was married, yesterday afternoon to John Rawson Atwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rawson Atwood of Rumson, in the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity in Fair Haven, N.J..

title: Four Girls Here Explore Bigotry, Real or Imagined
description: Four 16yearold girlsone from Pakistan, one black, one Protestant, one Catholic sat in a row in a classroom in Queens the other day, discussing the problems they'd faced coming to terms with themselves.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: 4 Pain Killer Drugs Coming From China Recalled by the U.S.
description: The Food and Drug Administration has instituted a nationwide warning against four Chinese herbal medications after the death of one person in San Francisco and serious blood poisoning in four others elsewhere during the last five weeks.

title: Headliners
description: The coronation last week of Bhutan's new King, 18yearold Jigine Singhi Wangchuk, permitted a glimpselinto a nation seldom open to the rest of the world, and that glimpse revealed court intrigues as well as pageantry. Bhutan officals disclosed during the threeday celebration that a plot to assassinate the new king had been thwarted. The plot was said to involve Tibetan exiles anxious to use Bhutan as a staging ground for operations into their homeland, and a former concubine of the King's late father who wanted a return to power.

title: Indemnity Up for Beekeepers
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) Beekeepers will get higher indemnity payment rates from the Government if their colonies are killed by pesticides, the Agriculture Department has announced. Under the increased indemnity rates, growers will get $22.50 for a destroyed colony, up $7.50 from the present level.

title: Stamps
description: THE sessions of the Continental Congress that moved, reluctantly but with gathering resolve, to break with Britain and finally to proclaim the Declaration of Independence are being commemorated on this year's stamps for the Bicentennial of the American Revolution.

title: She Sees to It That Ambassadors Don't Have to Worry About Bare Walls
description: For several years, when her husband was Ambassador to Italy and then High Commissioner to Austria, Mrs. Llewellyn Thompson thought how nice it would he, as she looked at bare walls in the official residences in Rome and Vienna, if the State Department, which had provided the furniture, would also provide paintings.

title: Arts
description: WASHINGTON, D. C.

title: Television Did They Upgrade the Emmysor Downgrade Them?
description: FOLLOWING the 26th annual entation of the Emmy Awards recently, the audience watching the ceremonies in the theater and on television reached remarkable agreement on one question: What in the name of Sennonettes were those Best of the Year awards all about? Given the imposed gravity of the occasion, would like to go directly to some literature released earlier this year by the National Academy of Television Arts and Science, creators and perpetrators of the awards.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Middle States Wins Merion Tennis Special to The New York Times

title: 13 Men and Women To Attend Harvard As Nieman Fellows
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 Four women and nine men have been named as Nieman Fellows in journalism to study at Harvard University for the 297475 academic year.

title: Moira Smith Bride Of William Tully Jr.
description: Miss Moira Virginia Smith and William Joseph Tully Jr. were married at noon yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Evangelist in Mahopac, N. Y.

title: Golf Writers Will Honor Gary Player
description: Distinguished members of the golf world, past and present, will be honored at the 2d annual awards dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association tomorrow evening at the Americana Hotel.

title: Mackenzie to Stay As Medical Dean
description: NEWARKDr. James W. Mackenzie has agreed to remain as dean of the Rutgers Medical School until Jan. 1, pending a search for his successor, it has been announced by Dr. Stanley S. Bergen Jr., president of the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Stocks advanced sharply last week as reductions in the prime interest rate.

title: T.V.A. Rates to Rise
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 8 (AP)  The Tennessee Valley Authority board of directors has ordered a rate increase beginning in August. The T.V.A. said Wednesday that the first month increase was expected to add about 60 cents per 1,000 kilowatt hours used in homes.

title: In Search of God at Auschwitz
description: The evil of the Nazi concentration camps defied reason and tested faith. Where was God when six million Jews were killed, when few prayers, except for death as release from suffering, were answered?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To Avoid SinoSoviet Jungle

title: Byrne, Princeton '49, Is Host to 200 in Class
description: PRINCETON, N.J., June  Governor Byrne invited 1,000 people to drop into the Governor's mansion here today to celebrate the 25th anniversary of his Princeton graduating class.

title: When Cape Cod Becomes a Playground, Increases in Rent Force Winter Tenants Out
description: HYANNIS, Mass., June 5The wild roses are blooming pink in the dunes and the traffic is showing the first signs of clogging the MidCape High way. Fresh paint is being applied to the trim around the weathered cedar shingles of restaurants and private clubs.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: These are progress reports based on Times inquiries into some unfinished news events.

title: Depailler Gains Pole In Sweden
TAPE SPURS HUNT FOR MISS HEARST
description: LOS ANGELES, June 8The search for Patricia Hearst resumed with new vigor today as the authorities examined her latest taped message for clues to what she and her two companion fugitives might do next.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Weakfish
description: WARWICK, R. LJouncing on the windwhipped waves of Narragansett Bay close to the northwest shore of Prudence Island, we cast our lures for squeteague, or northern weakfish, a species that until a few years ago had been absent from Rhode Island waters since shortly after World War II.

title: The Nation
description: With the House of Representatives edging closer to a decision on whether to impeach President Nixon, every significant election around the country is being assessed primarily in terms of the effect of the Watergate scandals on voter attitudes. The results of the round of primaries held last week suggests that the impact that showed up clearly in elections earlier this year Is, to say the least, not diminishing.

title: Chinese Carp Come to Jersey
description: MONTGOMERY TOWNSHIPWhat is about two feet long, weighs three pounds, swims and likes to eat grass?

title: Mrs. Seebohm Married in London
description: The marriage of Mrs. Caroline Seebohm, a staff writer for House & garden magazine, to Walter H. Lippincott Jr., an editor With the New York publishing house of Harper & Row, took place in London yesterday.

title: ESSAYISTS DISCUSS HUMANIZING CITY
description: People do not go to the cityeither as dwellers or as visitorsto look at trees, flowers and rocks, however beautiful these may be. They go to the city for the sake of the human encounter...

title: RECITAL FOR GUITAR BY MICHAEL DADAP
description: Michael Dadap, a Philippine guitarist who has studied at Mannes College of Music, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night under the sponsorship of the Philippine Forum of New York. He played works by Bach, De Vise, Diabelli, Sor, Albeniz and Villalobos, among others, and also a group of his arrangements of works based on Philippine folk tunes.

title: Rediscovering the Classic Swing of Jelly Roll Morton
description: NOW THAT Scott Joplin has been raised from obscurity to an Oscar Award (for the score of The Sting which was based on his compositions), Jelly Roll Morton also seems to be on the way to rediscovery. Morton never suffered the depth or length of oblivion that Joplin went through. While Joplinand piano rags in generalseemed to have been wiped from the memory, of man during the quarter century between the end of World War I and the Traditional Jazz Revival that occurred in the midforties, Morton was hitting his peak with a celebrated series of recordings by his Red Hot Peppers between 1926 and 1930. And even while he suffered through years of obscurity in the thirties, Morton was a seminal (but unknown) contributor to the Swing Era when his tune, King Porter Stomp, became the first and most readily indentifiable swing classic.

title: Construction in the Capital
description: WASHINGTON, D. C. ABOUT 4,500 architects and allied professionals met last week in the nation's capital for the annual convention of the American Institute of Architects. Washington suspended its May sultriness for a few days of the kind of weather that makes it a dream city of clear skies, caressing sun and lush green in which no architects' mistakes seem beyond redemption.

title: New Post for Truesdale Likely to Be in Racing
description: Larry Truesdale, who had been general manager of racing for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company since 1966, resigned at the end of May. The move was unexpected, and coming right after the big racing jamboree at Indianapolis it was especially surprising to those of all racing categories who participated. To many of them, Truesdale was Mr. Racing. His resignation, it turns out was timed. He had the satisfaction of seeing the first six finishers wear Goodyear tires.

title: Barbara Laudenslager Is Bride
description: Miss Barbara Laudenslager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Laudenslager of Kennett Square, Pa., was married in Greenville, Del., yesterday afternoon to Peter Brooke Mosley, son of the Right Rev. J. Brooke Mosley, president of Union Theological Seminary in New York and former Episcopal Bishop of Delaware, and Mrs. Mosley.

title: Bonn Watches a Crucial State Election
description: WILHELMSHAVEN, West Germany, June 7  A legislative election this weekend in the northern German state of Lower Saxony has become a crucial national test of whether the new Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, can keep the voters' confidence in his Social Democratic party.

title: Ford Rejects Advice: Won't Sit Down and Shut Up
description: LOGAN, Utah, June 8Vice President Ford said today that he had been advised by friends and others to sit down and shut up like a good Vice President should but had no intention of doing so.

title: Montana Summer: Rainbows and a Promise of Fertility Fulfilled
description: IF spring comes reluctantly to Montana, summer explodes, rushesgallops breakneck across the gap, bridging frost, fertility and late frost. Plants and animals gather themselves for the leap from newborn to mar maturity; and miraculously, if the capricious weather is kind, they achieve it.

title: S. J. Dorn Weds Marilyn Gulin
description: Miss Marilyn Gulin and Steven J. Dorn were married yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn by the Rev. Peter J. Dexnis. The ceremony took place in the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd. A recetion was held at the Richmond County Country Club in Dongan Hills, S. I.

title: Whites File Suit on Police Hiring
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.  Seven white men filed suit in State Supreme Court here the other day, charging that they were better qualified to become Suffolk County policemen than some Hispanic men whom the county's Police Commissioner wants to hire.

title: JOHN A. BENNETT
description: John A. Bennett, a lawyer in New Jersey for more than 50 years, died on Thursday at his home, 530 Valley Road in Upper Montclair, N. J. He was 77 years old.

title: W. Howard Keenan Jr. Marries Miss Pamela H. Carmichael
description: Miss Pamela Hastings Carmichael, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Scott Carmichael of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, was married last evening to W. Howard Keenan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Keenan of Houston. The Rev. William D. Shively performed the ceremony in St. Christopher's bytheRiver Episcopal Church in Gates Mills, Ohio.

title: LETTERS
description: Readers

title: GENEVA ROLE SET BY PALESTINIANS
description: CAIRO, June 8The Palestine National Council voted overwhelmingly today for policy platform enabling its leaders to participate in the Geneva peace talks on the Middle East, provided that what they describe as the national rights of the Palestinian people are recognized as an issue at the conference.

title: Food
description: Strawberry ice cream

title: Boston Establishes Pornography Area Under Zoning Law
description: BOSTON, June 8 (AP)The city that once made banned in Boston a household phrase is zoning a district that will be the exclusive domain of pornography shops, sex films and girlie shows.

title: State Is Eyeing Inn for Offices
description: TRENTONA shortage of office space in the State House is prompting the Legislature to glance down the street at the bankrupt Holiday Inn.

title: Beame Orders Agericy Antigraft Units
description: Mayor Beame directed the heads of all city agencies yesterday to establish permanent units to investigate complaints of possible corruption of municipal employes or allegations of improper conduct involving private individuals or business concerns dealing with the city.

title: Geothermal Power Huntedin Montana
description: MARYSVILLE, Mont. Four miles west of this old mining town, now largely deserted, the United States Government is about to start drilling a hole that could lead to treasure far greater than the $60million worth of gold extracted from this part of the Rocky Mountains before the turn of the century.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Jim Kiick, after the first $1million installment on the contract he, Larry Csonka and Paul Warfield signed with Memphis of the World Football League, was delivered: It didn't make me feel rich. I never got to see the money. It went right to Mark McCormack [the agent for the three players] and what made me feel good was talking to the investment counselors and listening to the way the money was being invested.

title: GEORGE D. CAMPBELL
description: George D. Campbell, for many years a contractor in the Poughkeepsie, N. Y., area, and Mayor of that city from 1922 to 1923, died Friday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 89 years old and had made his home in Florida since retiring in 1951.

title: Fire Kills Hotel Resident
description: A 51yearold woman died yesterday morning when her bed caught fire in her apartment in an Upper West Side residential hotel, the Fire Department reported. A spokesman said the fire was listed as being of suspicious origin since the woman, Winifred Miller of the Park Plaza Hotel, 50 West 77th Street, was not a smoker. No one else was reported injured.

title: Westinghouse at a Glance
Grow Columbines from Seed
description: COLUMBINE has been a popular garden flower since Elizabethan days. The various species are native to North America, Asia and Europe. Some have long spurs with upfacing blooms, while others are shortspurred and nodding.

title: Some Areas Plan to Give Repeaters Long Terms
description: TRENTONRapists, muggers and other convicted criminals with a history of repeating serious crimes may be facing extralong sentences in some areas of New Jersey.

title: Chess:  Andersson, Oft Too Mild, Mows Down Foes in Cuba
description: Ulf Andersson scored his greatest success by winning the 11th Capablanca Memorial Tournament in Camaguey, Cuba. The Swedish grandmaster, who will be 23 this month, had previously been hampered by his unwarlike, contemplative approach to the game, but that was nowhere in evidence this time.

title: Rebecca Hoke Bride in Dallas
description: The marriage of Miss Rebecca Corbin Hoke to Melvin Gail Hollen took place yesterday morning in the garden atrium of the Highland Park Presbyterian Church in Dallas. The Rev. Mike Renquist performed the ceremony.

title: The Quest for the Ultimate Roller Coaster
description: SUMMER madness has set in. A thundering roar, a chain of screams, and another roller coaster drops its passengers over a 90foot precipice. It's all clenched teeth and looknohands grins and willImakeitbackalive shrieks, fallen wigs and wallets. Operators keep their secret: There's a fortune under coasters.

title: What's At the Movies?
description: THAT'S ENTERTAINMENT, written and directed by Jack Haley Jr., got 15 favorable reviews (Nora Sayr?? Times; Ann Guarino, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Bernard Drew, Gannet News Service; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Gene Shalit, NBC; Jeffrey Lyons WPIXTV and WCBSRadio; Cage Ames, Newsweek; John Simon, Esquire; Penelope Gilliatt, New Yorker; Judith Crist, New York; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/World) and 2 mixed (Frank Rich, New Times; Stefan Kanfer, Times).

title: Green's 203 Leads Golf; Miller Is 2d
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June 8After Hubie Green shot a 66 in the third round of the IVBPhiladelphia golf classic today to stay in the lead at 203, 13 under par, he said, If I don't break the tournament record I'm not going to win it tomorrow.

title: NO CHEAPER OIL FOR AFRICA LANDS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 8African countries meeting in Mogadishu, Somalia, were told today that they would not recalve petroleum from Arab oil states at reduced prices.

title: But Industry Says It Imperils Supply
description: In 1954 the United States Government imposed price controls on natural gas sold in interstate commerce. Under the administration of the Federal Power Commission, these price controls remain in effect today.

title: STATE TO MONITOR JUDICIAL CONDUCT
description: ALBANY, June 8  A measure creating a ninemember Temporary State Commission on Judicial Conduct, composed primarily of nonjudges, with power to investigate complaints against a judge with regard to his conduct, performance, fitness and qualifications has been signed into law, Governor Wilson's office announced today.

title: DROUGHT
description: BOUTILIMIT, Mauritania. We are living in catastrophe, said Dr. Moustapha Siddatt. Last year, the babies started to die in May when the measles came. This year, they started to die in March, with the flu. We are all that much weaker this year.

title: Florida Seeking Racial Mixture In Colleges by Lowering Scores
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 8 Florida's Board of Regents adopted a plan last week to improve the racial mix of nine state universities.

title: Photography
description: THE phrase private realities is one of those phrases like incorpore al bodies that should make people think twice, but usually does not. It is also the name of a recent photography book and exhibition that should make some sustained attempt to clarify themeaning of this solipsistic phrase, but they do not.

title: Sadecki Victor, 65
description: HOUSTON, June 8Just when Manager Preston Gomez was beginning to think he boasted a pitching staff that was rapidly rounding into shape, along came the New York Mets to give the Astros' skipper reason to believe a rapid reassessment is in order.

title: Queens Councilman Vows To Fight Against Purging
description: The purge of Councilman Arthur J. Katzman by Queens Democratic district leaders last week has touched off open warfare between the Queens Democratic chairman, Matthew J. Troy Jr., and the New Democratic Coalition.

title: Guns for Retired Policemen
description: DALLAS, June 8 (UPI)A, policeman can now buy his pistol when he retires. Retiring officers can buy the weapons at reduced prices under a new policy by the Dallas Police Department, which is trying to get rid of an oversupply of used police guns. Used weapons are never given to new officers.

title: Child to de Rothschilds
description: A daughter was born Thursday to Mr. and Mrs. Evelyn de Rothschild in St. Mary's Hospital, London. Mrs. de Rothschild is the former Miss Victoria Lou Schott of New York. Her husband is a director of N. M. Rothschild & Sons, the London merchant bankers, founded in 1804 by his greatgreatgrandfather, Nathan Meyer Rothschild. The child has been named Jessica,

title: Repetition: The Gravy In Which Art Floats
description: WHEN a composer's ox has been deeply gored, he has the right, even the duty, to rise and say foolish things. Not long ago, Gian Carlo Menotti rose in these very pages to gore back at a critic who, 25 years after its first performance, persists in hearing nothing deathless in his opera The Consul. Menotti pointed to what he described as 25 years of uninterrupted triumphs of The Consul all over the world, and suggested that this should have weighed heavily on the critic's appraisal, as if age and popularity sanctified. But Abie's Irish Rose, in its time, had a great many more performances than The Consul, and nowadays there is no 25yearold movie so terrible that someone will not bring it back and subject it to indecent reexposure.

title: Bruce Haring Marries Miss Anne Van Vleck
description: In St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Montclair, N. J., yesterday afternoon, Miss Anne Thomas Van Vleck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Russ Van Vleck of Verona, N. J., formerly of Montclair, became the bride of Bruce Warren Haring. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wdrren Frederick Haring of Verona and North Haven, N. Y.

title: Home Improvement
description: USUALLY referred to as locking pliers, the hand tools pictured on this page are probably one of the most versatile group of tools available to mechanics and craftsmenyet comparatively few home handymen or women are really familiar with them.

title: Design: The red dot kitchen
description: My family believed in Eating Out, Ordering In and, in times of crisis, Defrosting. On majorfeast holidays, we all went to Aunt Lucy's, where a pot roast had been roasting in a pot since the last majorfeast holiday and a homemade pie had been purchased for the occasion from Horn and Hardart's.

title: Public Hearings Listed
description: City Council committees have scheduled the following sessions open to the public this week:

title: Migration to 9 Counties Is Decelerating
description: The massive migration of people from New York City and elsewhere into the ninecounty metropolitan region of Northeast Jersey is throttling down to halfspeed, according to a new population study made by the Port Authority.

title: CRIME IN HOTELS CONTINUES HERE
description: Two murders and a stabbing that were reported last week highlighted a continuing pattern of violent crime in single  room  occupancy facilities on Manhattan's West Side.

title: M. J. VON DER HEYDE
description: M. Jennings von der Heyde, I chairman of the Johnston Mutual Fund, Inc., died yesterday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 128 West Hills Road, New Canaan, Conn.

title: Nostalgia! Heroics! The Great Burro Race
description: OF course, Edna Miller says, you better get to know your burro mighty well, because if you don't, like as not he'll just up and quit on you and he'll do it at the top of the pass where the weather's the worst. You can talk to him, yell at him, or beat him with a branch of a tree, but if he doesn't know you, you're just wasting your time.

title: Linda M. MacIsaac, D.L. Underhill Wed
description: Miss Linda Marie MacIsaac and David Lovejoy Underhill were married yesterday morning at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Marblehead, Mass., by the Rev. George Westerberg, assisted by the Rev. Francis Kelly of St. Ambrose Roman Catholic Church in Boston.

title: The Playful Improvisation of West Coast Ceramic Art
description: THE attractive space of the Whitney Museum Downtown Branch, a peculiar and interesting new art institution, is currently occupied by a peculiar and interesting art exhibition called Clay. The show brings together 83 works in various ceramic mediums by 28 mostly West Coast artists, surveyingfrom 1960 to the presenta vigorous art phenomenon that has received scant public attention in New York. It will run to July 4.

title: Gunman Dies in Seoul Siege
description: Soul, South Korea, June 8, (Reuters)A 23 yearold deserter held a family of five at gunpoint for two hours in their house today before committing suicide with his automatic M16 rifle, authorities said, The soldier, assigned to an army unit near Seoul, broke into the house and resisted army and police troops that had surrounded the home to avoid searchers from his unit.

title: Amanda Fowler Bride in Sharon
description: Miss Amanda Skouras Fowler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Anderson Fowler of Sharon, Conn., was married yesterday at noon to Frederick Burnham Stimson 3d, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Stimson, also of Sharon.

title: Nadjari Rebuffed in Soviet In Seeking Facts on Jews
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special New York State prosecutor, said yesterday that his attempts to intercede on behalf of Soviet Jews accused of crimes following their requests to emigrate to Israel had been spurned by Soviet prosecutors he sought out during a twoweek trip to Russia in late May.

title: Families of Convicts Helping Each Other to Cope
description: HEMPSTEADThe middle of the night...A knock at the door...The house in Valley Stream was surrounded; a gun was thrust in her face; and the Federal Bureau of Investigation was taking away her husband.

title: A Green Thought in a Black Shade
description: Digged in the Dark, a novel of botanic possession, whose movie rights have been sold to Plantamount Producttions for an undisclosed sum, begins in mood of deceptive calm with the apparently innocent activities of the Turtle Bay African Violet Club. The club's foundersnow president and treasurerare Rhonda and Brad De Brodie, an attractive, happily married young couple with two children, 800 Saintpaulia Ionanthas and a growing collection of rare cacti. At the book's opening they are about to move, at the urgent suggestion of their landlord, to a larger apartment with a conservatory.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendment requiring the Central Intelligence Agency to submit an annual report to Congress showing the amount of funds requested for the following year, which was rejected, 55 to 33, June 4.

title: Colson Would Do Anything, But Will He Say Everything?
description: WASHINGTONIt may prove to be the biggest break yet in the case against President Nixon. But then again it may not. Despite all the speculation since Charles W. Colson copped a plea last Monday and promised to testify freely, no one on the outside seems quite sure what he will say. But the President's supporters and critics alike agree on one thing: Of all those now cooperating with the Watergate special prosecutor and the House impeachment lnqwry, no one else was nearly as close to the President as Chuck Colson. No one else is in as good a position to provide testimony that could prove the President's culpability exonerate him.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Krupp Gives Harvard 2Million To Bolster U.S.European Ties
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 A generation after the Krupp industrial empire helped to build the Nazi war arsenal, the Krupp Foundation of West Germany, which now owns the Krupp company, has given $2million to Harvard University as a gesture toward the strengthening of relations between America and Europe.

Raymond Donohue.

title: Trials for America's Cup Are Decided (in Theory)
description: The long brick building is low and windowless. A sign above the single unlocked door warns, Visitors By Appointment Only. A guide leads officially approved persons through a labyrinth of hallways that end in front of a body of water on which the 1974 America's Cup trials have already been decidedin theory. The wellguarded body of water (a swimming pool) is one of Pete DeSaix's testing tanks.

title: Klein's Aide Speaks Softly With Force
description: HAUPPAUGE  Not so long ago, Arthur Bergmann, Suffolk's Chief Deputy County Executive, ordered a sign that read: The Buck Starts Here. The wooden sign now rests conspicuously on a shelf next to Mr. Bergmann's desk.

title: Copyright Revision Bill May Affect Sports TV
description: Legislation of great longrange importance to what America's sports fans may see on television and in person over the next decade or two is coming up for consideration Tuesday in the Senate Judiciary Committee in Washington.

title: Miss Palmer Keeps Lead In Desert Golf on 71211
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 8 (AP)  Sandra Palmer scrambled to card a twounderpar 71 today, increasing her lead to three strokes after three rounds of the $100,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Desert Inn classic.

title: Nassau Democrats See Opportunity for Victory
description: MINEOLA  For the first time in many years, Nassau County Democrats are preparing for the fall elections with a glimmer of hope.

title: Dave Anderson
description: For more than three decades, the .400 hitter has been an extinct species in baseball. But suddenly Rod Carew of the Minnesota Twins has emerged as a miniature brontosaurus in the tiny type used for the top 10 batters. Rod Carew was batting .403 atfer yesterday's game with the New York Yankees at Shea Stadium, but his good start is not the reason he might hit .400 this season. His style is. The slender der second baseman swings for singles. Other players could be hitting .400 now but, as free swingers, they inevitably would go into a disastrous slump sooner or later. Those disastrous slumps don't exist for Rod Carew because his style prevents them. Almost hauntingly, he possesses most of the attributes that such .400 legends as Ty Cobb, Bill Terry and Ted Williams (the last with .406 in 1941), once predicted were necessary for the return of the species.

title: Fateful Day On Which 1,030 Died Is Recalled
description: On a warm, sunny morning in June, 1904, the steamboat General Slocum began an, excursion up the East River that would end in fire, horror, and the deaths of 1,030 passengers, mostly women and children.

title: Book Ends
description: Call Me Mrs. Just to show that feminism isn't totally sweeping the country, a book that takes a distinctly prohomebody stance is currently having respectable sales. The book is The Total Woman, by Marabel Morgan, a Miami, Fla., housewife (and proud of it), mother of two girls and a former beauty queen at Ohio State University. The book is a spinoff of a Total Woman course that Mrs. Morgan taught, which is now being given in 36 states by alumnae. The book's publisher; Fleming H. Revell, a small, venerable religious publisher out in Old Tappan, N. J., heard about tho course and asked Mrs. Morgan to write a book about it. Now sales are perking along quite nicely and the company admits it was surprised at the response thus far, 64,000 copies sold, 100,000 in print and sales at the rate of 35,000 a week. Mrs. Morgan's message for her gals, as she calls them, includes obedience to one's husband, as well as lots of praise and admiration (try oohing and ahhing over his muscles, for example, as one gal did) quoting from the Bible (frequently), Dr. David Reuben, Ann Landers and Calvin Cooligde and tossing off apothegms such as Sex is as clean and pure as cottage cheese, Mrs. Morgan ladles out advice and class assignments aimed at putting the sizzle back in one's marriage. Among the assignments: dress up in something exotically sexy and meet your husband at the door (Mrs. Morgan once employed a baby doll nightgown and white boots: Mr. Morgan chased her around the diningroom table). There is also advice on bringing up childrenMrs. Morgan is a disciplinarianand the final chapter urges a decision for Christ. Just to show that Christians don't have to be dull, one gal who took the Total Woman course at her local Southern Baptist Church was inspired to welcome her better half at the door dressed solely in black mesh stockings, high heels and an apron. He took one look and shouted Praise the Lord! If all this sounds tailored for the Bible Belt, it should be pointed out that the book is selling well in the New York City area. Mrs. Morgan's courses probably help publicize It, but it also spreads by word of mouth. Total Woman grads include singer Anita Bryant, Mrs. Jack Nicklaus and several Miami Dolphin wives. Generally, The Total Woman seems to appeal to young affluent matrons of a conservative bent.

title: Youth, 17, Accused in Neighbor's Death
description: A 17yearold youth was charged yesterday with the knife slaying of his nextdoor neighbor, a 50yearold spinster, in a Flushing, Queens, housing project.

title: Roses and Courses
description: JUNE, the rose month is spawning some local activities. On Wednesday, the annual June Garden Show of The Horticultural Society of New York will be held at the society's headquarters, 128 West 58th Street.

title: Upward mobilitywith a vengeance in Japan, Inc.
News of the Screen
description: The account of man's triumph over tragedy and adversity as set down by Piers Paul Read in Alive: The Story of the Andes Survivors, published by the a. B. Lippincott Co. in April, is now headed toward the screen. United Artists and Palomar Pictures have jointly acquired rights to the book for approximately $350,000 and other considerations, according to Edgar J. Scherick of. Palomar.

description: Miss Patricia Jeanne McGannon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. McGannon of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Frank Holland Hampshire of Durham, N.H.

Sponsors of the twoweek session, which begins on June 17, are the university's Center for Humanistic Studies, the Institute of Social Relations of the Newark Roman Catholic Diocese and Global Education Associates.

description: SEATTLE, June 8 (UPI)Robert S. Mansfield, a former Boeing Company official and University of Washington journalism professor, died Thursday at the age of 79.

description: SUFFERN, N.Y., June 8Alan Severinson rode the winners of two championships and captured the Medal Class in the equitation division today in the first outdoor show of the season at the Catamount Hunt Club.

title: Good Times Roll Again With Allmans in Jersey
description: JERSEY CITY, June 8 Gregg Allman, Dicky Betts the rest of the Allman Band opened the New York area's summer rock season here last night at Roosevelt Stadium and in so doing they managed to exorcize the lingering lugubriousness of Mr. Allman's recent solo appearances at Carnegie Hall in New York.

title: Primary: Losing Without Pain
description: TRENTON  State legislators from both major parties have traditionally coveted Congressional nominations. Thus, it is not surprising that 11 of the 30 major party candidates nominated in last Tuesday's Congressional primary are either former or present members of the State Senate or Assembly.

title: Miss Bisceglia Wed To Lieut. D.H. Zacherl
description: Miss Marianne Bisceglia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Bisceglia of Long Beach, L. I., was married there yesterday afternoon to Second Lieut. Donald H. Zacherl, U.S.A., son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Zacherl of Columbus, Ohio, The Rev. Charles Pappa performed the ceremony in the St. Ignatius Martyr Roman Catholic Church.

title: Musical Punkisin, or, the What, where and why of the Who
description: THE English rock group, the Who, creates music which is crude and selfindulgent and whose lyrics express feelings which range from violence and rage ens frustration and despair. It is a narrow range, but a singularly powerful one, earning the. Who a huge and adoring following of people from ages fourteen to thirty. Five out of its nine recordings are certified gold, a recordindustry label applied when the public spends more than a million dollars buying copies of a particular album. Its concerts, rowdy and tumultuous affairs, are among the best attended in rock's history.

title: About Percentage Tennis
description: One of the oldest of all athletic axioms holds that you've got to play the percentages to win. Most sports fans are familiar, to some degree, with the merits of percentage baseball, or the percentage play in football. But all too few tennis players know about percentage tennisor how to apply it to their games.

title: Is the Tide Now Rising For Stocks?
description: The most interesting question facing the investor today is not why the stock market is so deeply depressed but rather what one can do about it.

title: Fugitive
description: While I thoroughly enjoyed the boisterous A Cry of Angels, I was confused and alienated by Fugitive. It is difficult, crabbed, full of halfdisclosed meanings. This is its first sentence; Certainty: the death of love, and so of poetry, since It is the death of the possible or probable. The whole novel reads more or less like that.

title: C.I.A. CHIEF SEEKS SECRECY POWERS
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 William E. Colby, the director of Central Intelligence, is seeking legislation that would give him powers to enforce the protection of intelligence secrets and provide a penalty of 10 years in prison or a fine of $10,000 for violations.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The brain and the organs of speech are the distinguishing qualities of the human animal. The fossil record suggests that the two are intimately related: the emergence of language paralleled the transformation of Homo erectus into Homo sapiens a million yeat ago. And, in fact, each of the four great steps forward in human communications, speech, writing, printing and telephone and radio, has brought a major change in the circumstances of life.

title: Ishimatsu to Defend
description: TOKYO (AP)  Guts Ishimatsu of Japan will defend his, World Boxing Council lightweight title against Tury Pineda of Los Angeles in Sapporo Japan, Aug. 8.

title: ASSEMBLYMAN HELD ON ASSAULT CHARGE
description: Assemblyman Calvin Williams of Brooklyn and a gypsy taxicab driver he employs were arrested last night on assault charges based on complaints the men filed against each other, the police reported.

title: Movie Buffs Still Thrills Than Ever
description: EVERYTING is nostalgia today, Mister. It's a big snowball that keeps rolling into the past. Nostalgia is here to stay. All those inovies about teenagers growing up in the forties keep generating themselves. The Way We Were expressed the, whole trend right in the title. Look at Gatsby. Look at The Sting. Look at Mame. Last week alone, I saw two movies and each of them had a scene the Palm Court of the Plaza Hotel in thirties. That's where people want to away from Watergate and taxes and inflation. Lots of people wish they were hack in the Palm Court in the thirties, they come in here and buy pictures their idols from the past. They've me jumping. biggest names have voluntarily joined the ranks of the stuntmen.

title: Democrat Wins Recount
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 (UPI)  John Burton, a Democrat, is still the winner in San Francisco's special election in the Sixth Congressional District after a recount of the votes. He had to obtain 50 per cent of the vote in Tuesday's balloting to avoid a runoff. In the first count he received 34 votes over the minimum, in the second count, 38.

title: MARKETING POINT OF VIEW
description: Demarketing is a term that is popping up with increased frequency at meetings of people in the oil industry, the utility industry, the paper industry and other industries facing problems of tightening supplies. It is also attracting, for quite different reasons, the interest of citizens' groups and government bodies unhappy about too much demand for certain public services and facilities.

description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx and Miss Diane Blossom Schulder, a lawyer specializing in women's matrimonial law, plan to be married in the autumn.

It doesn't subscribe to Ms. It doesn't get high on The New York Review of Books. thinks Rod McKuen is a poet rather than an industry. Its numbers run into the millions and sometimes include intellectuals on the bum as well as consumers of plots, yarns, yearnings and assorted fears and feelgoods.

Instruments of optimism, he and his orchestra packaged jazz in a highly appealing and accessible mannerthoroughly danceable, but a bit revolutionary for those used to the saccharine sweetness of most dance bands.

title: Beyond DDay
description: Half of today's world was not yet born when that first communiqu was issued by Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Expeditionary Forces thirty years ago: Under the command of General Eisenhower, Allied naval forces, supported by strong air forces, began landing Allied armies this morning on the northern coast of France.

title: Red Smith
description: They ran the 106th Belmont Stakes yesterday. It was the seventh time the race had been contested at Beautiful Belmont II, having returned to that site in 1968 after boarding out at Aqueduct for five years while Beautiful Belmont was torn down and rebuilt Beautiful Belmont I had been the scene of 56 renewals starting in 1905. Inaugurated in 1867, the stakes spentits first 23 years at Jerome Park, which had been the Bathgate estate in Fordham, part of Westchester County not yet annexed by the Bronx. In 1887, when the city decided to build a reservoir at the quarterpole, Leonard Jerome and John A. Morris bought 330 acres of Westchester parkland about two miles away and Morris Park served as home of the Belmont from 1890 through 1904. Just to tie up loose ends, Leonard Jerome was Winston Churchill's grandfather.

title: CONTROL TO TIGHTEN ON U.S. STUDENT AID
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare says it is instituting tighter controls to prevent unwise use of Federal aid to medical and dental students.

title: When Foreigners Vote
description: PARISThroughout most of our history foreign policy has played a relatively slight role in American political debate on the ground that foreigners don't vote. Of course, when debate involved going to war, diplomatic aflairs assumed far greater interest, But even then, as with Woodrow Wilson and Franklin Roosevelt, there was a tendency to disguise the Government's actual intentions until crucial balloting was over.

title: Rider Gets Doable Dose Of Hard Luck on No. 8
description: Each horse wore No. 8 on his saddlecloth, each was ridden by Daryl Montoya, each went to the post at odds of 121 and each wound up with a slipping saddle yesterday in the daily double at Belmont Park.

title: MILESTONE PACT IS SIGNED BY U.S. AND SAUDI ARABIA
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The United States and Saudi Arabia today signed a wideranging military and economic agreement that both said heralded an era of increasingly close cooperation.

description: NEVADA, Iowa, June 8The price of farm land almost anywhere in the country is soaring like an overheated balloon.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: FIRST NATIONAL CITY BANK, the nation's second largest bank, lowered its prime lending rate to 11 per cent from 11 per cent, the first reduction in that bank's prime rate in three months. The. Michigan National Bank lowered its prime rate to 11 per cent from 11 per cent. Earlier in the week the First National Bank of Chicago lowered its interest rate to 11.6 per cent from 11 and the First National Bank of Miami lowered its rate to 11 per cent from 11.

title: Suffolk Completes Schlam Investigation, Saying Any Drugging Occurred Outside County
description: The Suffolk County police have ended an investigation of the mysterious illness of Peter, R. Schlam, an assistant United States attorney, during the extortion trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo last month, saying that his alleged drugging if it took place at alloccurred outside the county.

title: Pierre Pellizza, Tennis Star, ExFrench Champion, Is Dead
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June (AP)Pierre Pellizza, a former French national tennis champion, died here yesterday at the age of 56.

title: They're Really One Big Polluted Body
description: Pollution has long been the common denominator of the world's largest fresh water reservoir, the Great Lakes. And last week's decision by a Federal appeals court permitting a mining company to continue to pollute Lake Superior was yet another setback to people interested in rescuing these waters. But the problem is under attack at many levels of government, and, though Hiawatha's pristine shining big sea water may well be gone for good, some very encouraging progress has recently been made.

title: She Was the Last of the Founders to Rule
description: JERUSALEMAt 7:15 P.M. last Monday, the former Golda Meyerson of Milwaukee rose from the Premier's chair in the Knesset, walked quietly to a seat among the Labor party's benches and thus concluded a halfcentury of public service that began shortly after she immigrated to Palestine in 1924.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The East Coast meets the West Coast in both leagues this week as the California Angels face the Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers meet the Mets in Shea Stadium. The Yankees play the Angels tomorrow night and Tuesday night at 8 and Wednesday at 2 P.M. The Mets meet the National League's Western Division leaders Friday night at 8:05 and Saturday at 2:15 P.M.

title: 4 GUERRILLAS SLAIN BY ISRAELI PATROL
description: TEL AVIV, Isreal, June 8 (Reuters)  Israeli security forces today killed four guerrillas near the Lebanese border, an army spokesman announced. No Israeli casualties were reported. The spokesman said that a patrol had spotted the four guerrillas early today near a kibbutz shortly after they had infiltrated from Lebanon. The patrol opened fire and killed them, he said.

title: Gardens
description: TEN years ago, the more colorful species of butterflies had all but disappeared from New York City parks. The depressing decline started in the 1950s  at least that is when my nature  walk notes first recorded a scarcity of swallowtails, monarchs, painted ladies, red admirals and other more or less common species.

title: Barrie Orr Bride Of John Mason Jr.
description: Miss Barrie Walden Orr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thdmpson Decker Orr of East Islip and Quogue, LI, was married yesterday afternoon to John Montgomery Mason Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mason of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Donald S. McPhail performed the ceremony in St. Peter's bytheSea Episcopal Church in Bay Shore, L.I.

description: PRINCETONIf you think that you, and perhaps the rest of the people where you work, are hi the wrong business, chances are that you are right.

title: What Size for L.I.'s Colleges?
description: If Long Island were a separate state, officials of the State University at Stony Brook sometimes say to dramatize what they consider the region's shortage of higher educational facilities, it would be 26th in population and 51st in its ability to accommodate its college students.

title: An aide to Dwight Eisenhower finds the Nixon Presidency joyless and aimless, a gray fortress
description: There appears one cryptic sentence in the 1,254 pages of the White House transcripts on Watergate that might be read as a symbolic summary of all their more than 200,000 words. The scene is the Oval Office, the time is 6:04 in the evening of April 27, 1973, and President Richard Nixon about to receive Assistant Attorney General Henry Petersen and White House press secretary Ronald L. Ziegler. The first words spoken are Mr. Nixon's, and he greets the two officials with what sounds like the muttering of some stray and hazy thought, without context or clarity. He simply says: Come in. As like all things, some substance, some falsity.

title: Bhutan Makes Music
description: BHUTAN, an ancient Himalayan kingdom where archery tournaments remain the most popular sport and dancers in stag masks perform shamanist rituals dedicated to aboriginal demons, is perhaps the .... most remote and impenetrable Asian culture.

description: WASHINGTON, June 8The National Bureau of Standards has released a report recommending that the emphasis on fire protection in highrise buildings be directed toward structure design and occupant behavior as well as firefighting techniques.

description: Last Friday marked the 20th anniversary of a 53 Supreme Court decision that established the principle of Federal rate regulotion of natural gas sold in interstate commerce handed down June 7, 1954, in the case of the Phillips Petroleum Company v. the State of Wisconsin.

description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

I., and New York. The ceremony was per. formed by the Rev. Dr. Bradford Hastings.

description: New York State is bidding for new business and industry by doubling the tax credit for investment to 2 per cent.

title: A Convicted Slayer Too Long in Prison Is Getting a Parole
description: BUFFALO, June 8 (AP) Earl Haymon is finally gaining his freedom after spending 42 years in prison  22 of them by mistake.

title: Long Shots Triumph in Split Stakes
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., June 8 Silver Florin and Hat Full, a pair of outsiders, emerged as winners of the split Long Branch Stakes today at Monmouth Park before a crowd of 23,517.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: A HEADLINE in Newsday, the most worldly newspaper in the New York suburbs, proclaimed last week that London's giant Barclays Bank was interested in acquiring a Long Island bank. The bank in question was the Franklin National Bank, and only a suburban Long Island newspaper would call it a Long Island bank these days.

title: Saigon Regime Bars Newspaper Survey Of Opinion on Nixon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 6The South Vietnamese Government has ordered an opposition newspaper to abandon a survey of readers' attitudes on whether President Nixon should he impeached.

title: Customer Bugging Leads To Fine for Car Dealer
description: BALTIMORE, June 8 (UPI) A Federal judge fined a suburban automobile dealer $7,500 for bugging his showroom to eavesdrop, on customers.

title: The World
description: Now the Sabras Take Their Turn in Israel

title: Tocks Dam Needed, Engineer Warns
description: PALMYRALewis A. Caccase, chief of operations for the Philadelphia District of the Army Corps of Engineers, is a 57yearold civilian engineer who is convinced that technology often enhances the environment.

title: R D. Gove 2d And Nancy Ives Wed in Capital
description: Miss Nancy McNeil Ives, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Skinner Ives of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday morning to Reyburn Dermott Gove 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Gove of Pittsburgh. The ceremony was performed in the Little Sanctuary of St. Alban's Episcopal School in Washington by the Rev. Roger Bowen. He was assisted by the Rev. John Ansler.

title: U.S. SOUNDING OUT EUROPE ON NIXON
description: PARIS, June 8The United States has made informal inquiries in Paris, London and Bonn about the possibility of visit by President Nixon on his way to or from Moscow later this month, according to authoritative diplomatic sources.

title: INSURGENT WINS P.B.A. PRESIDENCY
description: An insurgent Brooklyn policeman, who had charged the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association with talking tough while letting his colleagues' professional standing and pension rights be fritteredaway, last night won the presidency of the powerful 27,000member unio.

title: Parent and Child
description: I recently attended a meeting set up as a consequence of the decision of our local Y.W.C.A. chapter to discontinue its swimming classes for children under 3. (A decision, incidentally, taken some twoplus years after the governing board of the national Y.W.C.A. had recommended against such classes. Therefore, no hasty decision.) The hall was packed with more than 200 parents who had come to be heard. They wanted the classes reinstated and heatedly dismissed all factual arguments supporting their discontinuance. A few, very few, had also come to learn.

title: 35 BRITONS EXPOSED IN NUCLEAR ACCIDENT
description: LONDON, June 8Thirtyfive men were exposed to substantial airborne contamination in a radiation leak at the Windscale Atomic Energy Plant, Cumberland, according to a board of inquiry.

title: New Cape MayLewes Bayliner to Be Christened
description: CAPE MAY  Four years ago, the Delaware River and Bay Authority was seriously contemplating closing down the Cape MayLewes (Del.) ferry run because of what appeared to be insurmountable financial problems, inchiding an annual bill of $500,000 for dredging.

title: Numismaties
description: THE old Baying about yesterday's trash bacoming tomorrow's treasure has come true in another area of the numismatic hobby. The collecting of coin and paper money errors is no longer an activity limited to a few eccen trice.

title: Joey
description: Joey Gallo was an inordinately difficult man, especially for a gangster. Gangsters are commonly dispassionate, vigilant of the distinction between personal matters and business, inveterate practitioners of those small civilities that depersonalize extortion, assault and battery, and murder, even for the victim. To lose one's temper in a professional matter, even under severe provocation, is to call into question one's judgment and prudence, and that can be fatal. Joe Gallo had no judgment at all, lost his temper frequently, and, on the morning of April 7, 1972, was shot to death for his deficiencies. Now he is memorialized for them.

title: Solomons Dancers Offer 5 Premieres At the Theater Lab
description: Backed by one of the strongest companies he has ever assembled, Gus Solomons Jr. spread a glittering assortment of new dances before us Friday evening at the American Theater Laboratory. The only complaint is that it is difficult to appreciate the special merits of five new works in a concentrated burst, although the total mix was excellent.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Recordingg
description: MY idea of a heaven evening is to stay at home and listen to Preiser historical recordings, confesses Terry McEwen, vice president of London Records and certainly one of today's great fans of the singing voice. Not that Preiser is McEwen's personal discovery. The label has been available in the United States for at least two years in the betterstocked shops, and for several years before that collectors were returning from Vienna laden with the product of this most unusual company.

title: 2 MEN GET $600,000 FROM ARMORED CAR
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June 8 (AP)Two armed men hijacked an armored WellsFargo truck tonight, tied up the driver and escaped with about $600,000 in cash and checks, the police said.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Slugs are at it again. Put out shallow pans filled with beer (at night); they crawl in and drown. ... Spray mums with zineb to control leaf spot. ... Feed lawns once more. ... After blooms fade, overgrown rhododendrons can be pruned quite hard. ... Use benlate (benomyl) for rose back spot.

title: Paying Jobs Drain Volunteer Groups
description: TEANECKNow that women are going professional, what effect is it having on the myriad of clubs, charities and civic activities whose member and volunteer strength has traditionally stemmed from the housewife?

title: School Mirrors the World
description: NEWARK.  Americanborn children travel throughout the world just by walking the halls of Mount Vernon school, says Anthony D'Agostino, principal of what must be one of the most unusual schools in Newark, if not the state.

title: Recycling Center Begun in Queens
description: Sanitation crews have begun collecting newspapers for recycling in a broad area of southern Queens as part of their regular pickups.

title: News of the Stage
description: Joel Grey, the songand. dance man who captured an Oscar for his role as the highpressure master of revels in Cabaret, has teen signed for the starring role in Goodtime Charley, a new musical by Sidney Michaels who wrote the book, Larry Grossman, music and Hal Hackady, lyrics.

title: Prisoners Get Certificates
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., June (UPI)  Seventeen inmates at the Texas State,Prison have received engineering technician certificates following completion of the first course ever offered in a United States prison in construction technology.

title: TV Mailbag
description: I HAVE just finished reading Caryl Rigers amusing article about women and TV commercials (How to Be Spotless, Sexy and Loved, April 28). While I couldn't agree more with her and with John Kenneth Galbraith's analysis of housewives as managers of consumption, the article's final paragraph dismayed me Mrs. Rivers declares that she is immune to the spotless house commercials due to a streak of bonedeep laziness. I believe this is precisely the conclusion that less progressive forces would have us believe  that if we are not obsessed with cleanliness in our homes, we are lazy. Whoever heard of a man being described as lazy because his floors didn't shine?

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Kent Paper Company, a manufacturer of stationery and a division of Williamhouse Regency, Inc., has leased 160,000 square feet of space at 1710 Flushing Avenue, in Maspeth, Queens, for 15 years at an aggregate rent of about $5million.

title: Nixon in Apparent Conflict on Hush Fund
description: WASHINGTON, June 8President Nixon's mentioning in a conversation in the Oval Office on March 21, 1973, of a Cuban committee that might have served as a conduit for money to some of the original Watergate suspects appears to conflict with Mr. Nixon's public assertions that he had no knowledge of any payments to the defendants before that date.

title: Miss Anne B. DePiano Is Married
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More here yesterday morning, Miss Anne B. DePiano was married to G. Malcolm Holderness, a partner in the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph J. Granato, cousin of the bride, assisted by the Rev. Anthony F. Granato, another cousin.

title: Kathleen Metz Wed To John D. Hatch 3d
description: Miss Kathleen Emlen Metz and John Davis Hatch 3d were married yesterday noon in the Meeting Grove of Pocono Lake Preserve, Pa., in accordance with the custom of the Society of Friends (Quakers). The. Right Rev. Anson Phelps Stokes, retired Episcopal Bishop of Massachusetts and uncle of the bridegroom, gave a blessing.

title: The Importance of Fetal Research
description: Current efforts to prohibit or significantly limit research involving fetuses and infants seriously jeopardize the health and welfare of our children and of our children's children.

title: Editors' Choice
description: General

title: Con Ed Steps Up Electricity Nonpayment Cutoffs
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 5 Three months ago, the Consolidated Edison Company was beset by a protest movement initiated in Westchester by owners of allelectric houses.

title: Poll Finds Drinkers at New High in Per Cent, That Is
description: The proportion of adults who drink alcoholic beverages is at its highest point in 35 years, the Gallup Poll reports. Roughly 12 per cent of those surveyed said that liquor had been cause of trouble in the family.

title: Westinghouse Airs Its Problems
description: PITTSBURGHThese days the stock of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation is a nono with many investors and security analysts.

title: Charity Unit Seeks to Fit Jews' Changing Needs
description: Amid the poverty and chaos that was the Lower East Side in the late spring of 1894, a cluster of welltodo New York women opened a small refuge for immigrants on Orchard Street. It was a home founded to keep single girls from the hands of the white slavers.

title: Italy to Hear Sound of Princeton Music
description: PRINCETON  The Princeton University Glee Club and the Westminster Choir, representing schools that lie only a halfmile apart, will travel more than 3,000 miles this summer to give their first joint performance.

title: Jersey Artists Are Saluted
description: TRENTONTo judge from the State Museum's ninth ninth annual competition for local talent, aspiring New Jersey artists have largely turned their backs on abstraction, pop and other avantgarde forms of expression.

title: HotAir Ballooning Proving Popular
description: PRINCETON  Robert L. Waligunda describes himself as a pilot, aeronaut, adventurer, actor and businessman. He also is president of Sky Promotions, a local hot air enterprise that Mr. Waligunda predicts will gross over a million dollars this year.

title: Storms in 3 States Leave a Toll of 16, Hundreds Injured
description: Tornadoes and flash floods smashed through Oklahoma and Kansas and more than 12 inches of rain pounded Arkansas yesterday, killing at least 16 persons and injuring several hundred. The threeday death toll from storms stood at 20.

title: Opening the Door A Bit in Spain
description: MADRIDIn 1971, Spain's feared state police, the Guardia Civil, took into custody a worker who had been distributing political propaganda. Somehow, a Guardia Civil gun went off; the worker was killed; and the matter was recorded as an accident.

title: The Region
description: With the state committees of both major parties about to endorse candidates, the political exhibition season is ending with the usual number of failed rookies, retiring veterans and returning regulars. Here are some of last week's major developments:

title: Study Finds Sex Bias Persisting in State Colleges
description: TRENTONDespite efforts to eliminate sex discrimination in the state colleges and in the state's Department of Higher Education, a study by an organization of academic and business women contends that many of the old inequities still exist.

title: Peaceful Journey
description: Bolstered by a sweeping new agreement with Saudi Arabia, the President of the United States leaves today for a tour of the Middle East. Even with full recognition of the domestic political pressures that undoubtedly made President Nixon so eager to seize this moment, a Presidential visit to Israel and four Arab countries holds genuine and dramatic importance across the sweep American foreign policy.

title: Major League Baseball and Standings

description: PARIS, June 9  President Valry Giscard d'Estaing dismissedd JeanJacques ServanSchreiber from the Cabinet tonight for public criticism of the Government's decision to hold nuclear tests soon.

title: Vesco Sued in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., June 9 (UPI)Robert Vesco, the fugitive financier, has been sued for $44.8million by one of Puerto Rico's largest real estate developers. The action was taken yesterday in United States District Court, by EHG Enterprises, a locally incorpo rated concern that has large holdings; in Puerto Rico and Florida. The suit alleges that Mr. Vesco and codefendants defrauded EHG in business transactions.

title: Music: Songs of India
description: A reminder of the great gap between Western music and, the traditional music of India was provided at the Cubiculo on Saturday night, when Ustad Hafeez Ahmed Khan sang a program of Hindustani music accompanied by Pandit Subhash Jauhari on the tabla (a twodrum percussion instrument) and Alaknanda Patel on the tam boura (drone).

title: London Demonstrators Greet Bolshoi Ballet
description: LONDON, June 9 (UPI)The 150member Bolshoi Ballet flew in from Moscow today and about 50 demonstrators chanted and waved banners in behalf of Soviet Jews when the company arrived at a hotel.

title: Jane Gilman. Bride of Henry R. Hoke 3d
description: The marriage of Miss Jane Fenwick Gilman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Manuel Alan Gilman of Garden City, L. I., to Henry Reed Hoke 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoke Jr., also of Garden City, took place yesterday afternoon.

title: Westchester Makes Way for the Bicycle
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 9  A twomile section of the Bronx River Parkway was closed todaythe first such closure of the world's oldest automobile parkway  to dramatize the start of a major bikeway construction program in Westchester.

title: Evers Says He Could Back Wallace for Vice President
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 9 (UPI)Charles Evers, the civil rights leader, says Gov. George C. Wallace has changed over the years to the degree that he could support the Alabama politician as a VicePresidential candidate on the national Democratic ticket in 1976.

title: Fire in Rail Tunnel Quelled on 3d Day; Next, Big Cleanup
description: HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., June 9A threeday fire in a railroad tunnel south of here was extinguished today, according to Joseph Spreng, assistant general manager of the Penn Central railroad.

title: Desert. Flowers. Work. The Duke Is Dead.
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.Let me try and tell you about the desert. I have become a part of it in the last three months, living alone at the south end of Palm Springs in a cheery room and on a sunny patio where marigolds flourish in summer heat.

title: TORNADO TOLL. RISES TO 20 IN TWO STATES
description: Rescue workers pulled four more bodies from the rubble in tornadoravaged Oklahoma yesterday, raising to 20 the number of persons killed in the storms that struck Oklahoma and Kansas.

title: Consumer Notes
description: If State, Insurance Commissioner John J, Sheeran has his way, automobile insurance companies will start making an effort to strip absurdities out of rating classifications under which some motorists are charged much more than others for the same kind of coverage.

title: Aid to Poor Lands Totaling $3Billion Urged by Experts
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  A report prepared by three economic experts proposes that the industrial nations of Europe, North America and Japan join the oilproducing nations in contributing $3billion to aid some 30 poor countries that have been hard hit by higher oil and food prices.

title: FORD DENOUNCES CRITICS OF POLICE
description: CLEVELAND, June 9Vice President Ford said tonight that it was immoral to condemn crime by government officials while condoning clime by. urban guerrilla revolutionaries.

title: Calling Brooklyn From Paris for 0 Francs ($0)
description: PARIS, June 9The glorious free longdistance phone in the Post Office at 22 Rue des St. Peres here has finally been repaired, but it was a good thing while it lasted.

title: Mercury Poisoning Is Linked in Report To Some Laxatives
description: A number of laxatives sold over the counter in this country can cause mercury, poisoning, according to a report in the current issue of the Archives of Neurology.

title: Anthony Retains Pin Title
description: DOWNEY, Calif., June 9 (UPI)Earl Anthony of Tacoma, Wash., the leader since play began last week, defeated Mark Roth of New York, 218 to 188, today to defend his BrunswickProfessional Bowlers' Association national championship.

title: Simon favors Tax Incentives for Business Expansion to Avoid Shortages
description: WASHINGTON, June 9Secretary of the Treasury Willam E. Simon disclosed today that he had talked with key members of Congress about legislation that would provide special taxi breaks for industries that need to expand if the nation is to avoid more shortages.

title: City Faults Auction Houses on Pricing
description: Many New York auction galleries, including the most respected, appear to be violating the city's administrative Code by failing to make certain disclosures to bidders, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Police Unions Held on Rise
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)  The chief federal mediator, W. J. Usery Jr., said today that the unionization of the police was increasing and that communities refusing to deal with the issue were asking for trouble. Police unions must be recognized and accorded their legitimate rights, Mr. Usery said in a speech at the openin of a symposium on police labor relations.

title: Donation to Governor of Oklahoma Under Inquiry
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, June 9 Gov. David Hall of Oklahoma received a $25,000 postelection payment from Loeb Rhoades & Co., the Wall Street brokerage concern that he subsequently recommended as underwriters on $74million in bonds for a new turnpike, according to wellinformed sources.

title: Inquiry on Forgery Clouds Status of Passaic Regime
description: PASSAIC, June 9  A state grand jury is investigating a charge that voter signatures on petitions for a change of government in Passaic two years ago were forged, although the County Prosecutor said he could find no evidence of forgery. PASSAIC, June 9  A state

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ENCYCLOPAEDIA BRITANNICA, 15th Edition. 30 volumes, 33,141 pages. Standard edition $598. Other editions at higher prices.

title: A Poison Quarantines Cows and Hens
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., June 9  The Michigan. Department of Agriculture has quarantined 115,000 laying hens, 3,000 dairy and beef cattle and 150 pigs that were fed tons of animal feeds accidentally contaminated with a toxic flame retardant.

title: TOP BONN PARTIES WIN A STATE VOTE
description: BONN, June 9Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democrats and their partners in the governing coalition, the Free Democrats, won a narrow victory in hotly contested state legislative elections in Lower Saxony today, according to, incomplete results.

title: Jet Makes First Test Flight
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 9 (AP)The YF17, the Northrop Corporation's lightweight jet fighter prototype, made its first flight today, staying aloft over this desert flight test center for 60 minutes. The Air Force said that Hank Chouteau, Northrop's chief test pilot, flew the plane at speeds of up to 610 miles an hour, and to an altitude of 18,000 feet.

title: Meredith Monk Paris/Chacon Danced by Her and Ping Chong
description: Is it theater? Is it opera? Is it dance? Meredith Monk's work always raises questions as to which art form she is engaged in. Does it matter?

title: Noted Chef's Widow Gets a Signal Honor
description: LYONS, France, June 9The number of female luminaries in the field of French gastronomy is nearly as rare as truffles that thrive in the sands of the Sahara. One of the rare exceptions is Mado Point, the elegantly styled widow of Fernand Point, who died 20 years ago. Mr. Point was, of course, patronchef of the celebrated Pyramide restaurant in Vienne and one of the undisputed geniuses of French cookery.

title: Summer Camp Safety: Voices of Concern
description: A year ago Dr. Glenn Haughie, a physician in Rochester, N. Y., sent his 8yearold son to a summer camp run by a friend of the family. Five days later his son was taken on an overnight hike. While the other campers slept, the boy walked to the edge of a nearby cliff and fell more than 100 feet to his death. The conjecture is that he was sleepwalking.
