He is the son of Joan Edwards, a pianist and composer, who was a vocalist on the radio show Your Hit Parade, and Julius Schachter a violinist. Rabbi Gerald A. Goldman performed the ceremony.

title: ITALY SAID TO SEEK A $1BILLION LOAN
description: ROME, June 9Italy is urgently seeking a big loanpossibly of more than $1billionfrom the United States or West Germany to bail her out of a grave financial crisis, diplomats here said today.

title: 22 Killed in Burmese Clash
description: RANGOON, Burma, June 9 (AP)  Twentytwo persons have been killed and 73 injured in clashes between strikers and troops, officials said today. The strike, which started at a stateowned railway workshop last Monday, spread to 42 stateowned factories and workshops during the week.

title: Attica Revolt Trials
description: The first of 61 defendants charged with crimes in the Attica prison revolt is scheduled to go to trial in Buffalo today. But a complexity of legal entanglements still surrounds, the cases nearly three years after the revolt, and the series of trials may not actually get under way for some time. Page 61.

description: Dr. Victor C. McCuaig, for many years director of otolaryngology at St. Luke's Hospital and former president of the New York Otological Society, died yesterday at his home in Brookville, L. I. He was 79 years old.

description: A Parable's Tail. The Treasure Pot. Yesterday. The Silver Lion. The Solarium. A collection of short stories? Or popular songs? No; it's a complex of new shops soon to be united under a single sign reading Chelsea Antiques Center.

description: HOUSTON, June 9Any firm believer in first impressions in the crowd of 16,880 witnessing this afternoon's finale in the weekend series between the Mets and the Houston Astros certainly received cause to revise his attitude.

description: AUGUSTA, Me., June 9Six Democrats and four Republicans will seek their parties' governorship nominations Tuesday.

title: Green Is Golf Victor by 4 Shots on 271
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June 9Hubert Green increased his 1974 earnings to $156,165 by picking up the winner's check for $30,000 in the 1VBPhiladelphia golf classic today after shooting a record 17underpar 271 for the 72hole event.

description: The great ritualdancetheater tradition includes productions that literally go on for days and others that only seem to.

title: Chris Evert Gains 3d Round in Paris
description: PARIS, June 9 (AP)Chris Evert dropped the first two games today in her match against Virginia Ruzici of Rumania but then came back strongly to win, 62, 63, and join the last 16 in the French open tennis tournament.

title: Other Galleries Comment
description: Seven auction houses other than Sotheby Parke Bernet, Inc., were queried about their policies on telling bidders about house ownership and reserves.

title: Miss Weiss Bride in Rye
description: Miss Jacqueline Mara Weiss and Judson Michael Reiss were married yesterday evening in the gardens of the Hilton Inn in Rye, N. Y. Rabbi Chaim Stern of Temple Beth El in Chappaqua, N. Y., performed the ceremony.

title: ISRAEL DENOUNCES SYRIAN BRUTALITY
description: JERUSALEM, June 9 (Reuters)The Israeli Government today denounced what it called inhuman treatment accorded by Syria to defenseless prisoners captured during the war last October.

title: Seton Hall Game Off
description: OMAHA, June 9 (UPI)For the second time the Seton HallSouthern Illinois baseball game at the college world series was postpone by rain tonight. The team were scheduled to meet to morrow morning in the first of a fourgame card.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Mending a break that occurred more than 50 years ago, Portugal and the Soviet Union established diplomatic relations. Portugal's new democratic Government, which has begun a general move toward the resumption of relations with Communist countries, agreed to exchange ambassadors. [1:67.]

title: Red Smith
description: The horses were parading for the Belmont Stakes when Jimmy Conway, the noted authority on men's fashions who moonlights as a trainer, presented a gold watch Sam Smith Jr., a tailor's model who moonlights as a groom. In an effort to gussie up its gambling hells so's to draw the clientele out of Paul Screvane's Offtrack Betting dens, the New York Racing Association gives a prize to the man who delivers the most handsomely groomed horse to the paddock for a major stakes, provided he also the bestgroomed groom. The Darby Dan pair was a shooin, said Mr. Conway, Saturday's judge. Little Current and Sam Smith Jr. are the pair from Darby Dan Farm, and when Miguel Rivera took over from Sam it became clear that Little Current was also the best race horse.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state has ordered advertisers to stop charging persons who want to become notaries $5 for application forms that are available free from the Secretary of State Attorney General William F. Hyland said that advertisers who refused to comply with the order would be subject to prosecution under the state's consumer protection laws.

title: ANN MAZER
description: Ann Mazer, former advertising manager of the National Jewish Monthly, died yesterday of a heart attack at her home, 300 East 40th Street, She was 56 years old.

title: ERVIN STAFF SEES WHITE HOUSE PLOT IN '72 NIXON DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, June 9A concerted and concealed effort by White House officials in 1972 to divert resources of the executive branch to help President Nixon's reelection campaign may have amounted to a criminal conspiracy to defraud the United States, according to a draft report by the staff of the Senate Watergate committee.

title: P.B.A. Vote Upset Called Desire for a New Image
description: The new president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday attributed the upset victory he and his entire insurgent slate scored late Saturday to the erosion of the professional and economic status of New York's police officers.

title: Jobs Are What Ulster's Struggle Is About
description: Northern Ireland sits on the upper corner of Ireland like a wet history book. The killing, which has gone on through a couple of centuries, seems to be the product of frightening complexities, but the struggle going on in the streets today is clear enough to anybody with a family to feed: It is all over the only political word I ever understood, which is jobs.

title: Jane Friedlaender Bride of W. J. Neumann
description: Miss Jane L. Friedlaender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Helmut N. Friedlaender of New York and Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon at her parents' home in Wilton to Wolfgang J. Neumann, son of KarlAugust Neumann and Mrs., Archimbold Skjoldenbrand of Stockholm. Phylipp Dilloway, First Selectman of Wilton, per formed the ceremony.

title: Ethnic Fairs Offer Food, Musicand El Al Panty Hose
description: Amid an ocean of bagels and pizza, up bobbed Raja Vatti yesterday, selling deepfried Indian wheat pancakes called poori to his neighbors in Coop City in the north Bronx.

title: 75,000 Here Celebrate Israel's Founding
description: With emphasis on the theme Peace for Israel, 75,000 men, women and children paraded up Fifth Avenue yesterday in celebration of Israel's 26th anniversary as a nation.

title: Obscenity Statute Upset in California; County Will Appeal
description: BUENA PARK, Calif., June 9 Officials in this conservative Orange County community say they will appeal a Federal court decision that ordered them to return copies of the xrated film Deep Throat they had seized from a theater owner here.

title: Duke of Gloucester, 74, Dies at Home in Britain
description: LONDON, Monday, June 10 (Reuters)The Duke of Gloucester, the only surviving brother of the late. King George VI, died during the night following an illness. He was 74 years old.

title: WALD WICK DEATH IS RULED MURDER
description: The death of a 34yearold New York computer executive at his Waldwick home last week has been ruled a homicide by the Bergen County Prosecutor's office.

title: Vote Upset Called Desire for a New Image
description: The new president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday attributed the upset victory he and his entire insurgent slate scored late Saturday to the erosion of the professional and economic status of New York's police officers.

title: CAMBODIA EXTENDS CLOSING OF SCHOOLS
description: PHNOM PENN, Cambodia, June 9  Phnom Penn rematned quiet this weekend as the Government extended until Wednesday its order closing all schools and universities.

title: Hazards Fail to Deter Americans on New Road in Baja California
description: TIJUANA, MexicoOrville A. Belt, on a Memorial Day trip from San Diego down Mexico's new Baja California Road of Dreams, stopped to admire the sun  dappled Pacific Ocean from the cliffs at San Quintin, and was shot to death from ambush.

title: Bridge: Screens to Avert Impropriety Tested in Switzerland Match
description: Many experts, but not all, rely considerably on their table presence, or table feel. Consciously or subconsciously, they gather and utilize minute clues from the behavior of their opponents, which the laws allow, and from the behavior of their partners, which the laws do not allow but cannot control.

title: Nixon Said to Reject PublicTV Funding
description: A longpromised bill from the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy for the longrange financing of public television has been flatly rejected by President Nixon, without discussion or explanation, according to sources close to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: Orange: The Home of the OrangeCrate Derby
Las Vegas Got To Mrs. Carnes
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June (AP)  Mrs. Joanne Carne rallied from three strokes b?? hind today to overtake Sa?? dra Palmer and win her thi?? tournament in four weeks b?? capturing the $100,000 Dese Golf Classic. A final thre underpar 70 for 284 earn?? her a onestroke victory ov Carole Jo Skala.

title: Happy Ending In Horse Story
description: PARIS, June 9The Derby Story of a former Mexicanmovie queen, Maria Felix Berger, had a happy ending today when one of her colts won the French Derby.

title: The President's Mideast Gamble
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 President Nixon's trip to the Middle East is meant to symbolize America's sudden emergence as a major influence in the Arab world, but even before his, Air Force jet takes off tomorrow morning, Mr. Nixon's mission has inevitably become caught up in controversy.

title: Outspoken Soviet Priest Yields to Church Demand for Apology
description: MOSCOW, June 9The Rev. Dmitri Dudko; a Russian Orthodox priest who attracted large crowds of young people to his unusual, candid questionandanswer sessions on Christianity and Soviet society, has apologized to the church hierarchy for his outspoken opinions, friends said today.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Dance: True Modernist
description: The Viola Farber Dance Company, which performed Saturday night at the Cunningham Studio in Westbeth, would be clased as avantgarde anywhere beyond the cultish New York definitions of dance.

title: Disciplined Schechter Takes Swedish Grand Prix
description: ANDERSTORP, Sweden, June 9  Jody Scheckter, who frightened rival drivers with madcap tactics as much as thrilled spectators last season while capturing the Formula 5000 series title in the United States, drove one of the most disciplined races of his young life today and won his first grand prix.

title: Katharine Cornell Is Dead at 81
description: Katharine Cornell, one of the great actresses of the American theater, died of pneumonia early yesterday at her home in Vineyard Haven, Mass., on Martha's Vineyard. She was 81 years old.

title: Prudence by, Bankers Foreseen For Financings Related to Oil
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 9In the coming tug of war between the prudence of bankers and the desperate need of national governments to borrow money to pay for the higher cost of imported oil, the prudence of bankers is likely to prevail.

title: Africans Accept $200Million Offer From Arab Nations
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, June 9Delegates to the meeting of the Council of Ministers of the Organization of African Unity agreed today to accept an offer by Arab oilproducing countries of $200million for poor African states hard hit by the rising costs of oil.

title: New Deal Pays Off in Vols' Track Title
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 9A few years ago, the most pub3icized track and field statistic at the University of Tennessee was the length of Bill Skinner's red handlebar mustache.

title: ...Budget Blue Note
description: The city's police officers have decided to follow the firemen in electing militant new union leadership. That is certainly their right in a democratic society, but it will be bad news for New Yorkers if the police union change is translated into the kind of policies that led to the recklessly irresponsible strike of firemen last Elec. tion Day.

title: Four in Democratic Governorship Contest Debate, Disagreeing on City Fiscal and State Power Problems
description: The four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Goverhor joined yesterday in the only television debate of their preconvention Campaign and disclosed wide differences on how to deal with the financial problems of New York City and the power needs of the state. They agreed on the value of an open nominating conventon this week but also expected a Sept. 10 primary contestwhich Representative Hugh L. Carey later suggested would helf overcome a normal summer lull in political interest. All four said any of them could defeat Governor Wilson.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: A VERITABLE MINE Hitler's signature, Hermann Goerings's, George Washington's Farewell Addressthe first of 139 editionsMata Hari's signature, Mussolini's, Disraeli's, Gen. William (Billy) Mitchell's, Nehru's, the Treaty of Paris, printed by Benjamin Franklin in 1783, deeds for slaves, signatures of the American Revolutionary War Generals Pulaski and Francis (Swamp Fox) Marlon, Walt Whitman manuscript notes and the last letter Abraham Lincoln wrote on the day he was assassinatedall items from the 496piece autograph collection of Harry J. Sonneborn that is on view today and goes on saleby auction tomorrow at the Sotheby Parke Bernet gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The strike by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, its first in over fifty years, ought not to be considered a simple industrial dispute between labor and management. Rather, it bears the unmistakable marks of a structural crisis, exacerbated by imports, in which the union is defining the options.

title: Beame Assistants Unsure of Duties
description: The problem of the municipal laundry on Roosevelt Island is like a lot of the pesty problems that come up in city government. It sounds simple but ends up being complex. It is too important to be ignored by City Hall, but not quite important enough to occupy the highest officials.

title: Nicklaus Reno's Open Pick
description: RENO, Nev., June 9 (AP)Reno oddsmakers made Ja?? Nicklaus a 51 favorite tod?? to win the 1974 United Stat?? Open golf championship the week at the Winged Fc?? Golf Club in Mamarones?? N. Y. Johnny Miller, the ?? fending champion and I Trevino were second choice ??.

title: Therese J. Calabrese Wed to Sharokh Safaii
description: Miss Theresa Jean Calabrese, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alphonse F. X. Calabrese of Muttontown, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Sharohk Safaii, son of Dr. and Mrs. Javad Safaii of Teheran, Iran. The Rev. William Karvelos performed the ceremony in the St. Edward the Confessor Roman Catholic Church in Syosset, L. I.

title: Action on Blue Ridge Dam Is Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, June 9Action by the Federal Power Commission regarding a license for the Blue Ridge hydroelectric project on the New River has been held up while Congress completes work on a bill designed to place a 70mile stretch of the river in the Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: Cairns in Wyoming Seen As SunObservation Site
description: An American astronomer has calculated that the position of stone cairns built in a cluster centuries ago high in the mountains of Wyoming could have served Plains Indians as an astronomical observatory not unlike England's Stonehenge.

title: Miguel Angel Asturias, 1967 Nobel Laureate, Dies
description: MADRID, June 9 (UPI)Mi guel Angel Asturias, the Guatemalan novelist, poet and diplomat who won the 1967 Nobel Prize for literature, died here today in a hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: David Barensfeld Weds Wendy Herlands
description: Miss Wendy Alison Herlands, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Herlands of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to David Evans Barensfeld son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Barensfeld of Ellwood City Pa.

title: Stage
description: People often ask whatefer happened to the revue. Last night, at Stage 73 of the Manhattan Theater Club, they received at least a partial answer. It is a new revue called Some People, Some Other People and What They Finally Do. It is described by its author, Jordan Crittenden, as a revue with hardly any music, but this is only the first of its deficiencies.

title: PURCHASERS FIND RAPiD PRICE RISES
description: More than 40 per cent of purchasing agents participating in a broadly based survey said prices rose faster than they had anticipated after the Government's controls program expired nearly six weeks ago. They also said industrial price increases continued during May at the fastest rate in nearly 25 years.

title: Irving Excerpts
description: Washington Irving's Knickerbocker's History of New York took the development of the place from the beginning of the World to the end of the Dutch Dynasty. Two samples follow:

title: Yarborough Is Victor at Riverside
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., June 9 (UPI) Cale Yarborough from Timmonsville, S.C., scored his sixth NASCAR Grand National victory of the year and his second here in six months today by outdueling Eobby Allison in the Tuborg 400.

title: 3 Years Later, Attica Cases Remain Snarled
description: Nearly three years after the bloody Attica prison revolt that left 43 men dead, a complexity of legal entanglements still surrounds the indictments of 61 present and former inmates who have been charged by a special grand jury with crimes ranging from murder to coercion.

title: New U.S.Arab Oil Tie
description: The unmentioned word in the economic and military agreements reached this past weekend between the United States and the Saudi Arabian Governments was oil. But oil was the catalyst that precipitated this new special relationship between the Saudis and the Americans.

title: Democratic Aspirants Face a ShakeOut
description: There are 15 Democrats vying for four of the party's statewide nominations: Four for Governor, four for Lieutenant Governor, two for Attorney General and five for United States Senator. But by Political the end of this Notes crucial week in the electoral process, the list will be considerably reduced.

title: Maurice Roberts Jr. Marries Martha Fain
description: Miss Martha Ann Fain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Myron Fain of Providence, R. I. was married there yesterday to Maurice Arthur Roberts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts of Fairlee, Vt. Judge William Goldberg of the Rhode Island Family Court performed the ceremony at the Fain home.

title: PRESIDENT VOWS HE'LL DO NOTHING
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 President Nixon told a wildly cheering group of ardent supporters today that a strong Presidency was needed to achieve peace in the world and pledged that I shall do nothing that will weaken this office.

title: Moscow and Lisbon Open Ties After Half a Century
description: LISBON, June 9  Portugal and the Soviet Union established diplomatic relations today, ending a rupture that has lasted since the Russian Revolution in 1917.

title: Mexican Festival At Garden Sticks To the Traditional
description: Continuing proof of the potency of Latin music could be found yesterday afternoon when the first New York Festival of Mexican Song made its bow. The festival lasted four hours before a packed Madison Square Garden audience, with a similar event held in the evening.

title: Las Vegas Golf To Mrs. Canner
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June ?? (AP)Mrs. Joanne Carne?? rallied from three strokes be hind today to overtake Sandra Palmer and win her thin tournament in four weeks b?? capturing the $100,000 Dese?? Golf Classic. A final three underpar 70 for 284 earn?? her a onestroke victory ov?? Carole Jo Skala.

title: Mary Bartlett Cowdrey, 63, An Art Historian, Is Dead
description: Mary Bartlett Cowdrey, of Passaic, N.J., an art historian, died there Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital. She would have been 64 years old next Sunday.

title: DebtRidden Budget
description: Despite Mayor Beanie's bristling retort to criticism from Controller Goldin, the Mayor's $11.1billion expense budget has emerged relatively unscathed from three days of public hearings.

title: PRESIDENT VOWS HE'LL DO NOTHING TO WEAKEN OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 President Nixon told a wildly cheering group of ardent supporters today that a strong Presidency was needed to achieve peace in the world and pledged that I shall do nothing that will weaken this office.

title: Nixon Said to Reject PublicTV Funding
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL Yankees vs. California Angels, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (Radio  WMCA, 8 P.M.)

title: Grandstand Bus
description: In reaffirming its own earlier surrender to President Nixon's antibusing rhetoricthis time by a vote of 270 to 103the House of Representatives has engaged not in legislative action but in a demagogic attempt to dictate to SenateHouse conferees Just as they start their search for compromise on the important measure that will determine the scope of Federal school aid.

title: Moscow and Lisbon Open Ties After Half a Century
description: LISBON, Portugal, June 9Portugal and the Soviet Union established diplomatic relations today, ending a rupture that has lasted since the Russian Revolution in 1917.

title: Kate McNeil Bride Of Alan G. Brauner
description: Miss Kate Adele McNeil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Anthony McNeil of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon in St. John's Roman Catholic Church to Alan Gordon Brauner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Brauner of Los Altos, Calif. The Rev. Pierre Botton performed the ceremony.

title: Research Center Burns
description: PRINCETON, June 9, (UPI) A generalalarm fire extensively damaged a building tonight at the Princeton Research Center, but there were no immediate reports of injuries. The fire, first reported at 5:30 P.M., completely enveloped a twostory frame building housin gthe Fifth Dimension Inc., according to the state police here.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
4 in Democratic Governorship Race Debate on TV, Disagreeing on City Fiscal and State Power Problems
description: The four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor joined yesterday in the only television debate of their preconvention campaign and disclosed wide differences on how to deal with the financial problems of New York City and the power needs of the state.

title: Lady of the Theater
description: The great ones have a little something extra. To their love of the theater, to their intelligence and their willingness to work, they bring a personal incandescence that cannot be explained. Katharine Cornell was one of these. Something electric happened when she stepped on the stage.

title: A CALYPSO PROGRAM BY MIGHTY SPARROW
description: The Mighty Sparrow, heralded as the last of the calypso singers, made his annual, ritual, airlinesponsored visit to Madison Square Garden on Saturday, headlining a concert designed to present most of the forms of musical entertainment available in the West Indies. Thus steel bands pinged, limbo dancers undulated, traditional carnival costumes glittered (better than any currently trendy rock star) and the Sparrow sang his calypso.

title: Marchi Says He'd Bar School Beatings
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 9State Senator John J. Marchi said today that he would introduce a bill at next year's session of the Legislature to prohibit corporal punishment in all public schools throughout the state.

title: Toni Kruman Wed To Jerold L. Zaro
description: Miss Toni Kruman, daughter of Mayor Daniel Kruman of Deal, N. J., and Mrs. Kruman, was married yesterday to Jerold Lorin Zaro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Zaro of Fort Lee, N. J. The ceremony was performed in the garden of the Hollywood Golf and Country Club in Deal by Rabbi Sidney Schulman of Temple Beth El in Asbury Park, N. J.

title: Phils Stage a New Giveaway, but It's a Hit for the Reds in 147 Victory
description: Eight pitchers from the Cincinnati Reds and the Philadelphia Phillies staged new kind of giveaway yesterday. The Phillies could have advertised it as Hit Day.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Bhutan Puts on a Show for Visitors
description: THIMBU, Bhutan, June 6 The Indian Airlines plane from Calcutta to Baghdogra, in the West Bengal plains, was packed with guests for the coronation of the King of Bhutan. An elderly American woman, with a shaved head and wearing a Buddhist monk's saffron outfit, wandered up and down the aisle. A French television crew excitedly photographed cows near the runway, and the puzzled and eager Bhutanese youths, waiting at the airfield to check everyone in, fed the visitors and placed them on minibuses for the fourhour ride to Phuntsholing, just over the Bhutanese border. The temperature was 110. The Bhutanese smiled.

title: Sara Holtz and Ridhard Paisner Of Harvard Law Are Married
description: Miss Sara Holtz, a member of the class of '75 at the Harvard Law School, was married at noon yesterday to Richard Paisner, who will receive his degree from Harvard Law on Thursday. The ceremony was performed at the Harvard Club of Boston by Rabbi Joel Zaiman.

title: Hero Who Planted Marijuana to Enter A Mental Hospital
description: FAIRFIELD, Ill., June 9 (AP) A Medal of Honor winner who said he could not adjust to being a hero and was growing marijuana as part of his fight for personal freedom his been admitted to a mental institution for observation.

title: Chris Evert Gains 3d Round in Paris
description: PARIS, June 9 (AP) Chris Evert dropped the first two games today in her match against Virginia Ruzici of Rumania but then came back strongly to win, 62, 63, and join the last 16 in the French open tennis tournament.

title: Graduate Police Classes Set by Leary at Trenton
description: TRENTONFor the last two years Howard R. Leary, former police Commissioner of New York and of Philadelphia, has been quietly teaching courses in criminal justice at Trenton State College.

title: Secrecy and Freedom
description: Three years ago this week The New York Times began printing the record of official arrogance, deception and blundering that came to be called the Pentagon Papers. The Nixon Administration went to court to try to stop it. Two weeks later, after much frantic legal activity, the Supreme Court ruled out an injunction.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Baseball or football? Willie Wilson of Summit High School made his decision yesterday.

title: Nixon Off Today on Trip To Five Mideast Nations
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 President Nixon leaves on a nineday trip to the Middle East tomorrow, in an atmosphere of controversy in Washington and expectation in the Arab world.

title: Supporters of Political Reform On Coast Will Spread Cause
description: LOS ANGELES, June 9The victorious backers of the California Political Reform Act of 1974 are gearing up to spread their cause across the nation in the hope of capturing voters in a postWatergate reaction.

title: Antioch Trustees Name Chancellor For Ohio Campus
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 9Francis X. Shea, former president of the College of St. Scholastica in Duluth, Minn., has accepted appointment as chancellor of Antioch College's main undergraduate campus at Yellow Springs, Ohio.

title: 3 NATIONS DIFFER IN EXPO DISPLAYS
description: SPOKANE, Wash., June 8If you asked an American, a Russian and a Japanese to talk about environmental problems, Oat would they say?

title: Ruth Kissin Wed to Law Student
description: Miss Ruth Felicia Kissin and Edward Kleinbard, who both graduated last year, magna cum laude, from Brown University, were married yesterday in the BethEl Chapel of Temple EmanuEl by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel.

title: Pathet Lao Takes the Lead Over Partners in Coalition
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 5In the two months since the formation of the new coalition Government in Laos, the Communistoriented Pathet Lao has taken a clear lead over its disorganized rightist and neutralist competitors.

title: Congress Faces Its Biggest Turnover Since 1933
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 With the Congressional elections still five months off, the Senate and House of Representatives are heading for the largest turnover of seats this year since the Franklin D. Roosevelt sweep of 1933.

title: Rev. Robert J. Clarke, 74, Was Cabin Boy on Lusitania
description: The Rev. Robert J. Clarke, former rector of Good Shepherd Episcopal Church in Fort Lee, N. J., and a survivor of the sinking of the liner Lusitania, died Saturday at his home in State College, Pa. He was 74 years old.

title: Personal Finance: SmallBuyer C.D.
description: Investors with at least $100,000 have little difficulty these days earning 10 per cent a year or so on their funds.

title: Diplomatic Pas de Deux
description: The Soviet decision to grant exit visas to ballet stars Valery Panov and his wife, Galina Ragozina, is a welcome concession to world opinion, clearly timed to ease this week's goodwill visit by the Bolshoi Ballet to London and President Nixon's forthcoming trip to Moscow. Soviet authorities rightly deduced that their shoddy treatment of this talented couple, which had attracted broad international concern and censure, could compromise their diplomatic objectives.

title: ARMENIANS DOING THEIR OWN THING
description: YEREVAN, U.S.S.R.  While the radio offered a Tschaikovsky concerto, several browsers in a Yerevan bookstore discussed a philosophical question: When would the principies of Lenin take root in Armenia?

title: Advertising: Copy Hall of Fame
description: The One Show, which is a joint effort of the Art Directors Club and the Copy Club of New York and is the most important event in the creative area of advertising, was held for the second time Friday.

title: P.B.A. Vote Upset Called Desire for a New image
description: The new president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Asso ciation yesterday attributed the upset victory he and his entire insurgent slate scored late Saturday to the erosion of the professional and economic status of New York's police officers.

title: Environmentalists Study, Growth of Urban Areas
description: PISCATAWAY TOWNSHIP, June 9A twoday conference on energy, the environment and land use in the United Stares was opened in Tillett Hall on the Livingston campus of Rutgers University here tonight to explore the future of America's urban growth.

title: U.N. Aide Calls Golan Pullback Smooth
description: ON THE SASSAQUNEITRA ROAD, Syria, June 9The field commander of the United Nations Disengagement Observer Force stood at a point between Israeli and Syrian front, lines today and said that the separa tion of the two armies and their equipment was going smoothly.

title: MRS. GWEN MICHAELS
description: Mrs. Gwen Michaels, chairman of the music department at Manhattan High School for Boys, died Saturday in Harlem Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. She was 52 years old and lived at 235 West 139th Street.

title: Police Union's PresidentElect Joseph Kenneth McFeeley
description: All through the afternoon at the 71st Precinct in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday, young officers wandered down the dowdy halls of the station house to congratulate the new president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: Palestinian Moderates on Council Gain
description: CAIRO, June 9  The Palestine National Council ended a nineday session here today by electing a new enlarged executive committee, in which the moderates, led by Yasir Arafat, will be stronger than in the outgoing body.

title: Nixons Cruise on Potomac
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) President and Mrs. Nixon went for a dinner Cruise on the Potomac River this evening with their daughters, Mrs. Edward F. Cox and Mrs. David Eisenhower. The cruise, aboard the presidential yacht Sequoia, gave the Nixons a chance for a parting family chat before the President and his wife depart tomorrow for Salzburg, Austria, on the first leg of their trip to the Middle East.

title: Tighter Restrictions Set on Consumption
description: BASEL, June 9The Governments of most Western countries have held to a restrictive economic course to try to squeeze inflation out of their systems, and some, notably Free and Italy, are preparing even stronger curbs on consumption.

title: Garment Union Board Approves Pact as Members Start Voting
description: The general executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America yesterday unanimously endorsed the proposed threeyear contract that would end the nationwide strike against 750 manufacturers.

title: Cosmos Triumph on Penalty Kicks Before 8,005
description: It has been mostly a summer of discontent for the New York Cosmos, but on a hot day yesterday they not only won a soccer game, but also attracted some fans.

title: A Panel to Oversee Multinational Companies Is Urged
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9A United Nations panel, after nearly a year of studying multinational corporations, has unanimously recommended the creation of a permanent commission that would seek to harmonize the global companies' activities with the economic plans of developing nations and to help develop a code of conduct for relations between the companies and government.

title: Eagleton Poll Finds Residents Still Back A State Income Tax
description: A proposed state income tax tied to a reduction in local property taxes is still supported by Jersey residents, although by narrower margin than in the last few years, according to poll conducted by the Eagleton Institute of Rutgers University.

title: On Solzhenitsyns in Reverse
description: REDDING, Conn.The story of civil rights abuses in the Soviet Union, with Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn and other dissenters the lone voices of the Russian people, fills our newspaper columns and television screens.

title: Nixon Off Today on Trip To Five Mideast Nations
description: WASHINGTON, June 9President Nixon leaves on a nineday trip to the Middle East tomorrow, in an atmosphere of controversy in Washington and expectation in the Arab world.

title: Nurses Strike Continues
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 (UPI)Striking nurses picketed 40 Northern California hospitals today in support of their demand for less work and more pay. Entire floors of some hospitals were shut down in the third day of the walkbut.

title: Percy Urges a Crackdown On Hearing Aid Industry
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)  Senator Charles H. Percy called today for a Government crackdown on the hearing aid industry that would limit sales to prescriptions only and bring an end to what he described as immoral prices and profits.

title: Freed Irish Earl and Wife Link Kidnappers to I.R.A.
description: DUBLIN, June 9The Earl and Countess of Donoughmore, who were freed early this morning after being held four days by kidnappers, said here today that they thought the masked gunmen who guarded them around the clock in a hideout were members of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: CONSORTIUM ISSUES GUARANTEE ON BONDS
description: A consortium of nationally known insurance companies has issued a policy guaranteeing the payment of principal and interest on an issue of municipal bonds of Carbondale, Illinois, thereby raising the rating of the issue several notches to the highest level or AAA.

title: Mood in Italy Is Likened to Dancing on the Titanic
description: ROME, June 9  A thin elderly mart who tried in vain to cross through heavy lateevening traffic on the Corso Vittorio Emanuele raised his walking stick and shouted: Crisis? Where is the crisis? Why don't you all walk?

title: Soviet Offering West the Memoirs of Sotzhenitsyn's First Wife
description: Soviet representatives have been quietly offering the purported memoirs, of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's first wife to Western publishers in an apparent effort to discredit the exiled author.

title: Green Is Golf Victor by 4 Shots on 271
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June 9Hubert Green increased his 1974 earnings to $156,165 by picking up the winner's check for $30,000 in the 1VBPhiladelphia golf classic today after shooting a record 17underpar 271 for the 72hole event.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following Is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold. (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Our Man From Andorra Works at Lincoln Center
description: John W. Mazzola is managing director of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, but his heart is in the highlands of Andorra, the tiny Pyrenean principality that lies athwart the FrancoSpanish border.

title: A TRIAL FOR NIXON MAY CURTAIL ARTS
description: An impeachment trial in the Congress could delay or affect Federal funding to the country's arts organizations, representatives of 200 dance companies were told here at their annual convention, which closed yesterday.

title: Parochial Schools Get Relief In 2 Bills Signed by Governor
description: ALBANY, June 9Governor Wilson has approved two meaures aimed at giving additional financial relief to private and parochial schools and to some students attending them.

title: Twins Beaten, 43, by Nettles Hit on Bat Day
description: In the top of the ninth inning at Shea Stadium yesterday, with the Yankees losing to the Minnesota Twins, a pair of teenage boys jumped out of the stands near first base, raced across the field and clambered over the rightfield fence before they could be apprehended by security police.

title: Irving: Man of Many Worlds Is at the Main Public Library
description: That merriest of mild melancholiacs, Washingain Irving, is starring in a new revue here that seems as sprightly a romp through early American letters as anything so thoroughly, posthumous can be.

title: 3 Milk Coops Amass $2Million for Fall Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 The three large dairy cooperatives whose heavy contributions to President Nixon's reelection campaign are under scrutiny in the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment inquiry have a political war chest of more than $2million for the Congressional campaigns this year, according to reports on file here.

title: Oil Managers Scored on Facing New Challenges
description: The capability of management in the oil industry has failed to keep pace with the increasing challenges facing it, in view of a broad spectrum of professional observers.

title: New Bond Offerings Are Set as Hopes For Prime Cuts Rise
description: This week's comparatively modest calendar of new taxempt offerings and a somewhat fuller corporate slate will be coming to markets that developed discernible buoyancy last Thursday and Friday amid more talk of a possible peaking in interest rates. Last week's discussion of this subject mostly concerned reductions in commercial banks lending or prime rate. A week ago today, the First National Bank of Chicago trimmed its socalled corporate base rate to 11.60 per cent.

title: Missile Danger
description: Almost unnoticed by the country and little debated in the Congress, a dangerous and drastic transformation of American nuclear strategy is in the making. From longstanding policy of deterrencebased on a stable, secondstrike, retaliatory forcethe Pentagon is now seeking a silokilling capability that the Soviet Union may perceive as a firststrike force.

title: STATE PROTECTION OF PRIVACY SEEN
description: SEWELL, June 9 (AP)  Attorney General William F. Hyland said today that the Byrne administration was considering legislation to curb the unrestricted gathering of information about the New Jersey citizens.

title: ERVIN STAFF SEES WHITE HOUSE PLOT IN '72 NIXON DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, June 9A concerted and concealed effort by White House officials in 1972 to divert resources of the executive branch to help President Nixon's reelection campaign may have amounted to a criminal conspiracy to defraud the United States, according to a draft report by the staff of the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Amid an ocean of bagels and pizza, up bobbed Raja Vatti yesterday, selling deepfried Indian wheat pancakes called poori to his neighbors at Coop City.

title: Major Bills In Congress
Keeping Quarry's Head Together
description: McAFEE, N. J., June 10On the seventh day before the fight, Jerry Quarry rested. He will oppose Joe Frazier next Monday night at Madison Square Garden, but today he sat in the shade of the trees by the pool at the Playboy ClubHotel at Great Gorge instead of sparring inside the big greenandwhite striped tent on a grassy hillside. The scene at his workouts are a semithrowback to those sepia photos of Jack Dempsey training in an outdoor ring in the woods somewhere. The difference here is that some of the spectators perch in golf carts under the rolledup side flaps of the tent. And when the workout is over, everybody returns to the 674room hotel where Playboy bunnies perch on high heels. It's not the type of nature that fight managers ordinarily like their gladiators to commune with. But Gil Clancy appears content. So does Jerry Quarry, perhaps because he's accompanied by his blond wife Charley, who displays the symmetry of the Miss Indiana she once was.

title: Central Asia Enfolds Ethnic Russians Who Came as Catalysts for Change
description: DUSHANBE, U.S.S.R.When Vera I. Zapryagayeva, an enthusiastic and idealistic young student, first came to Soviet Central Asia from Leningrad, it took two weeks by train  primitive, terrible, is the way she recalls that ride.

title: People and Business
description: Norman L. Campbell has been named president and chief executive officer of the National Life Insurance Company. He succeeds John T. Fey, who will shortly join the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

title: I.M.F. IN AGREEMENT ON S.D.R. VALUATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (Reutecs)The executive directors of the International Monetary Fund have reached agreement on, the interim valuation of the Special Drawing Rightthe I.M.F.'s specially created reserve asset, monetary sources said here today.

title: MARY GREENE, 66, PUBLISHING FIGURE
description: Mary V. Greene, a figure in magazine and bookpublishing circles for many years, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital in Morristown, N. J., apparently of a stroke. Miss Greene, who in private life was Mrs. Arthur Pincus, was 66 years old and lived at 325 Central Park West and in Long Valley, N. J.

title: Gloucester, Queen's Uncle, Last Son of George V, Dies
description: LONDON, June 10The Duke of Gloucester, uncle of Queen Elizabeth H, died today at his home, Barnwell Manor, in Northamptonshire. He was 74 years old.

title: The Dance: 2 New Leads for Dybbuk
description: Jerome Robbins's Dybbuk was given Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater by New York City Ballet. For the first time the leading roles were taken by Gelsey Kirkland and Bart Cook.

title: A's Set Back by Red Sox, Tiant, 41
description: When we last left the Oakland A's, they were doing their usual best to dispel a longtime baseball belief: that harmony among team members is a key ingredient to winning.

title: Ashe Is Eliminated by Orantes In Three Sets at French Open
description: PARIS, June 10Arthur Ashe, the thirdranked American and one of the world's great players, was beaten today by a score that defied credibility.

title: People in Sports
description: The Seattle SuperSonics yesterday signed their No. 1 draft pick, Tom Burleson of North Caroline State, a 7foot4inch center, which meant that Kareem AbdulJabbar of Milwaukee would finally have someone to look up at in the Natinal Basketball Association. Financial terms were not disclosed, but the contract was for five years with a nocut provision. Burleson, who helped the Wolfpack win the National Collegiate title last season, had also been drafted by the Indiana Pacers of the American Basketball Association.

title: WILSON PICKS CASO FOR RUNNING MATE
description: UNIONDALE, LI., June 10Apparenty assured of secondline support from the Conservative party, Governor Wilson today formally chose County Executive Ralph G. Caso of Nassau as his Republican runningmate for Lieutenant Governor.

title: Dana Corp. Shows Record Sales and Profits
Taxi Dilemma
description: Anybody who drives a car would find it difficult to dispute the contention of the operators of New York's fleetowned medallion cabs that the costs of running their vehicles have risen steeply during the past year. Whether the cost increases justify the 20 per cent fare rise that the Taxicab Board of Trade has asked for is a question currently under study by the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Mets to See a New Fastball From Old Teammate Tonight
description: ATLANTA, June 10At a time when most of their starting pitchers seem to be floundering and their hitters seem unable to produce runs with consistency, the New York Mets woke up here today to find that Buzz Capra has become one of the hottest properties in the major leagues.

title: CITY EDUCATORS DEFEND BUDGETS
description: Officials of the city's educetional bureaucracy spent the day at City Hall yesterday defending their budget requests for next year's operations against sharp probing by members of the City Council's Finance Committee.

title: Nixon and St. Clair Are Able to Confer During 9Day Trip
description: WASHINGTON, June 10President Nixon and James D. St. Clair, his special counsel, plan to be in frequent communication on legal developments if necessary during the President's nineday trip to the Middle East, White House aides said today.

title: 3 EXSCHOOL AIDES PLEAD GUILTY HERE
description: Three former members of Harlem's District 5 community school board yesterday pleaded guilty to charges of thirddegree conspiracy in the illegal use of public funds for their reelection campaign in May, 1973.

title: Coal at a Price
description: The bill to regulate strip mining which has emerged from the House Interior Committee is not an environmentalist's dream, but it is not a nightmare either. At least, it commanded the vote of every environmentally minded Congressman on the committee; while the fifteen Representatives who opposed it are overwhelmingly oriented toward the mining industry, which wants no bill at all.

title: No Decision on Public TV Made, White House Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI)The White House denied today reports published in The New York Times that President Nixon had rejected a plan for longrange financing of public television and that he had suggested a scaling down of Federal support.

title: WALLACE G. CORWIN
description: Wallace G. Corwin, a retired Mobil Oil Company executive, died yesterday at his home, 13 Forest Hill Road, Darien, Conn., at the age of 78.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: STOCKS RISE AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the, overthecounter market rose again yesterday as traders continued to be optimistic about the possibility of further reductions in the prime interest rate. Volume, however, dropped on both markets.

title: WINNIFRED KEAY, 86, HEADED A AGENCY
description: Mrs. Winnifred H. Keay, said to be the oldest living graduate of the Roosevelt Hospital School of Nursing and a former advertising executive, died yesterday at the hospital. She was 86 years old and lived at 315 East 68th Street.

title: Senate Endorses New Nixon Policy On Better ICBM's
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Senate today endorsed the Nixon Administration's decision to develop more powerful, more accurate intercontinental missiles capable of attacking Soviet missiles in their underground silos.

title: President Signs Bin for Rise Of $769Million for Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPIPresident Nixon signed legislation today authorizing additional Federal spending of $769million for military procurement and weapons development.

title: Text of Letter to Rodino From President Refusing to Furnish Subpoenaed Evidence
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Following is the text of a letter to Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, from President Nixon in which the President declined to furnish material subpoenaed by the committee:

title: NIXON TO APPEAL DECISION ON TAPE
description: WASHINGTON, June 10President Nixon announced today that he would appeal Federal Judge John J. Sirica's decision to give a grand jury a portion of one of the disputed Presidential tape recordings.

title: Justices Back a High Tax To Cut Downtown Parking
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Cities may levy a high tax on private downtown parking lots and garages in an effort to reduce urban congestion and divert commuters to public transportation, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Market Place: A Social Fund And Its Failure
description: Two and a half years ago, a couple of earnest young brokers, each of whom had been earning upwards of $50,000 a year at Smith, Barney & Co. Inc., decided to strike out on their own and build a mutual fund on the theme of social responsibility. They had the idea in an era of considerable public concern over corporate moralityparticularly in terms of what appeared to some observers to represent a callous disregard for the environment.

title: College World Series
description: GIVE SUMMER TO A CHILD. THE FRESH AIR GUND.

title: Wilson Signs Bill to Save Energy in Construction
description: ALBANY, June 10Governor Wilson has approved a measure that would allow for revision of the state's building code to develop new energyconservation measures in construction work.

title: Dissembling Intelligence.
description: Diplomatic triumphs notwithstanding, Secretary State Kissinger continues to be haunted by revelations of wiretapping operations against members of his own staff, allegedly conducted with his knowledge and cooperation. The origin and purpose of these invasions of privacy remain ambiguous but there can be no ambiguity about their implications.

title: Manes Out, Backs Carey for Governor
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens bowed out of the Democratic gubernatorial race yesterday and endorsed one of his rivals, Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: OAKLAND (A.)

title: Prosecution Ends Its Case In Sudan Terrorist Trial
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan, June 10 (UPI)  The prosecution concluded its case today in the trial of eight Palestinian terrorists charged with the murders of two American diplomats and a Belgian diplomat during a 60hour siege of the Saudi Arabian Embassy here in March of last year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Rule on Teacher Dismissals Is Upset

title: Justices Back a High Tax To Cut Downtown Parking
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Cities may levy a high tax on private downtown parking, iota and garages in an effort duce urban congestion and divert commuters to public transportation, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Teachers Termed Entitled To Reasons for Dismissal
description: TRENTON, June 10The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a nontenured teacher could no longer be dismissed summarily without being given a reason for the ouster.

title: Manes Out, Backs Carey for Governor
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens bowed out of the Democratic gubernatorial race yesterday and endorsed one of his rivals, Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn.

title: DROP CONTINUES IN CATTLE PRICES
description: The long slide in live beef cattle futures continued yesterday with all deliveries on the Chicago Mercentile Exchange setting contract lows. The declines reflected overabundant marketings of the animals by feeders in the face of lower consumer demand because of still high prices at retail levels as well as substantial imports of beef.

title: Heroin Traffic Into U.S. Is Reported Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) After two years of decline, heroin traffic into the United States is reported on the upswing, with Mexico replacing Europe as the primary source and conduit for the narcotic.

title: Woman Declared Winner Of Nebraska G.O.P. Race
description: LINCOLN, Neb., June 10 (UPI)The State Canvassing Board certified today the results of the May 14 primary.

title: Women Police Officers Called the Equal of Men
description: Women police officers are Just as effective on patrol duty as men are and in some instances are better, the ranking woman in the city's Police Department said yesterday.

title: Sabres May Foil Rangers
description: MONTREAL, June 10The New York Rangers ran into a roadblock today on their wellpublicized but tortuous path toward acquiring Derek Sanderson from the Boston Bruins. Though few people expected the notsosecretive transactions to fall through, a surprise claim by the Buffalo Sabres at the National Hockey League's intraleague draft caused Clarence Campbell, the league president, to call a special board meeting tomorrow to consider the matter.

title: Lawyer Seeks Reid Seat
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 10 (AP)  J. Russell Clune, a lawyer, said today that he would enter the Republican Congressional primary in the 24th district, in Westchester County. The seat is now held by Representative Ogden R. Reid, who is seeking the Democratic party's nomination for Governor.

title: Computers Call the Tune at the Kitchen
description: The whole idea of computer, music used to scare the more conservative humanists, who would conjure up visions of soulless squeaks squawked by machines that were inhuman by definition.

title: To Nixon Loyalists in the South, Right or Wrong, He's There
description: JACKSON, Miss  The surface differences diminish year by year. The River Hills Club would fit as comfortably in Hartford or Schenectady as it does in Jackson.

title: Senate Endorses New Nixon Policy On Better ICBM's
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Senate today endorsed the Nixon Administration's decision to develop more powerful, more accurate intercontinental missiles capable of attacking Soviet missiles in their underground silos.

title: Most Members of Panel Reject Nixon's Argument
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Most members of the House Judiciary Committee rejected today President's Nixon's argument that he had the constitutional authority to withhold subpoenaed tapes and documents from the impeachment inquiry.

title: Gary Player Is Given Golf Writers' Gold Tee
description: Gary Player, Sammy Davis Sr. and three former caddies were among the honored guests at the annual awards dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers' Association at the Americana Hotel last night.

title: Ben Reese of PostDispatch, Pulitzer Winning Editor, Dies
description: Ben Reese, hardhitting and widely respected Midwestern newspaperman, died yesterday at Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune City, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: Foreign Exchange
description: Monday, June 10, 1974 Selling Prices, New York Market

title: Summaries in French Open
description: Tomas Koch, Brazil, defeated Toshiro Sakai, Japan, 61, 67, 46, 61, 64; Onny Parun, New Zealand, defeated Pierre Barthes, France, 26, 36, 61, 62, 64; Harold Solomon, Sliver Spring, Md., defeated Zeliko Franulovic, Yugoslavia, 57, 76, 46, 63, 62.

title: Regan Bids Wall Street Seek Sears's Efficiency
description: Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., indicated yesterday that the firm sees itself eventually as a Sears, Roebuck of the investment business.

title: 20 Indicted in Brooklyn as Part of Amphetamine Ring
description: A lettercarrier who allegedly made illegal deliveries of synthetic drugs and a city employe with a. Ph.D. in biochemistry were among 20 persons whose indictments as part of a major criminal ring dealing in amphetamine and methamphetamine were announced yesterday.

title: May Retail Sales Increased by 1%
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (Reuters)Retail sales rose 1 per cent in May to a seasonally adjusted $44.38billion after a downwardrevised 0,2 per cent gain in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A Crippling Nerve Disease Defies Researchers
description: After being tested against 65 diseasecausing agents, the slowgrowing virus that causes the crippling, incurable disease of the central nervous system known as kuru is still a mystery.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Mr. Nixon, Past and Present
description: At this stage of the impeachment effort it is imperative that we scrutinize President Nixons own feelings and his past conduct in order to understand his present alleged Misbehivior.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PARADISE Noted for its Birds of Paradise, the Pacific island of New Guinea is the world's second largest island (after Greenland), and its northeast regionalong the 700mile Sepik Riveris home to a number of ethnic groups with similar characteristics but different languages.

title: Regan Bids Wall Street Seek Sears's Efficiency
description: Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., indicated yesterday that the firm sees itself eventually as a Sears, Roebuck of the investment business.

title: Weeden & Co. Posted Profit Last Month
description: Weeden & Co., a securities firm specializing in trades that take place outside the nation's stock exchanges, said yesterday it had earned a profit of $122,000 last month, compared with a loss of $251,000 in May, 1973.

title: Areas in Oklahoma and Kansas Ruled Eligible for Disaster Aid
description: Parts of Oklahoma and Kansas were declared Federal disaster areas yesterday as Government officials and storm victims surveyed the ruins left by weekend tornadoes and flooding in four states. Twentythree persons were dead and estimates of the damage topped $50million.

title: Soviet Scores Mideast HalfMeasures
description: MOSCOW, June 10Foreign Minister. Andrei A. Gromyko, charging that Israel had not yet proven her peaceful intentions in the Middle East, warned today against accepting halfmeasures of disengagement favored by Israel and her backers.

title: Intrepid Arrives in Newport
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 10 (AP)The 12Meter yacht Intrepid, winner of two America's Cup competitions, has arrived to prepare for trials later this month for the right to represent the United States in this year's race.

title: Seton Hall Eliminated In Baseball
description: OMAHA, June 10 (AP)Seton Hall was eliminated from the College world series today when it was beaten twice in the doubleelimination baseball tournament, bowing to Southern Illinois, 51, in a morning game and to Texas, 122, in the afternoon.

title: Wood, Field & Stream Audubon Calls for Boycott
description: The National Audubon Society, one of the nation's largest, oldest and most respected conservation organizations, has asked its 300,000 members and the general public to boycott Japanese and Soviet goods until those nations cease their needless slaughtering of whales.

title: Prolific Kudzu Vine Plagues the South
description: ATLANTA, June 10Once upon a time, back around the turn of the century, there was a farmer named C. E. Pleas who lived in a little town called Chipley in the Florida Panhandle.

title: State to Look Into Ruling Of Florida Court on Child
description: TRENTON, June 10 (AP) New Jersey's court administrator says he will look into a Florida judge's implication that an alleged babysnatching was justified because New Jersey's courts are too slow in deciding child custody cases.

title: STASIS FORESEEN FOR URBAN AREAS
description: PISCATAWAY TOWNSHIP, N. J., June 10  Four leading theoreticians about the future of the nation's urban areas agreed today that in the next 25 years there would be a continuation of the trend toward suburban sprawl and that a national commitment to rebuild the cities would not develop.

title: Saudis to Increase Their Share In Aramco From 25% to 60%
description: The Arabian American Oil Company and Saudi Arabia have reached an agreement whereby the Saudis will take majority ownership 60 per centof the company's concessions and assets, it was announced yesterday.

title: Yanks Beat Angels With 2 in 8th, 75, As Murcer Sparkles Afield and at Bat
description: While the newest highpriced Yankee watched from a box seat next to the dugout, the highest priced Yankee of all time showed signs of resuscitation last night by playing perhaps his best game of the lethargic New York season.

title: Notes on People
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has agreed to be oncamera host and consultant for an hourlong television special filmed in Kenya, and to serve in a similar capacity for a series of 26 halfhour programs designed to test the ability of an American urban youth in wildlife situations on his own in an African society.

title: Aussie Yacht Stirs Cup Hope
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 10  Up and down the Eastern coastline of Australia. there is an undercurrent of excitement among the yachting set because this just might be the year for Australia to win the America's Cup.

title: Sets Beat Banners With LineUp Shift
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., June 10 A change in the lineup paid off for the New York Sets tonight as they beat the Baltimore Banners, 2927, for only their third World Team Tennis victory before 1,454 fans in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: POLICE KEEP WATCH ON S.L.A. INFORMER
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10 (UPI) The police kept a woman under observation for her safety tonight after she had been named by the remnants of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army as a collaborator who gave away the location of the hideout where six members of the terrorist group died.

title: SCHMIDT SET BACK IN GERMAN ELECTION
description: BONN, June 10 (UPI)Official results of the state election in Lower Saxony this weekend, delayed until dawn today by a computer breakdown, showed that Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and his Social Democratic party held the state, but suffered a setback in numbers of votes.

title: PRICES IRREGULAR IN BOND TRADING
description: Prices were mixed and trading quiet yesterday in credit markets on a day marked by more talk than action on the closely watched interestrate front. The First National Bank of Chicago announced it was reducing, effective today, its socalled corporate base rate to 11.50 per cent from. 11.60 per cent. The decline of 10 basis points (hundredths of a percentage point) brought this bank's equivalent of the prime rate in line with rates currently prevailing at other moneycenter banks.

title: Frank D. Schroth, 89, Publisher Of The Brooklyn Eagle, Is Dead
description: Frank D. Schroth, publisher of the nowdefunct Brooklyn Eagle from 1939 to 1955, died yesterday at a New Milford, Conn., nursing home at the age of 89.

title: Vehicle Decline Is Seen
description: CHICAGO, June 10 (Reuters)  The Recreational Vehicle Instittute said today it expected 1974 shipments to drop 40 to 45 per cent form last year's level Shipments in 1974 are estimated at 511,100 units, down from the 725,100 units shipped in 1973.

title: 2 BIG BOARD FIRMS CENSURED ON TRADES
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Two New York Stock exchange member firms were censured by the Securities and Exchange Commission today for illegal insider trading.

title: PRESIDENT DEFIES HOUSE SUBPOENA FOR MORE TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 President Nixon, apparently moving closer to a constitutional confrontation with Congress, said today that he must draw a line and refuse to provide the House Judiciary Committee with additional Watergate evidence.

title: Plainfield Bank Robbed
description: PLAINFIELD, June 10 (AP)Two masked men, one armed with a shotgun, held up the North Plainfield State Bank here today, the police said. Therobbers escaped with an undetermined amount of cash in a car driven by a third man.

title: S.E.C. Reaccused of Allowing Job Bias
description: Two church groups, a women's organization and a securitiesindustry publisher have again charged the Securities and Exchange Commission with knowingly sanctioning employment discrimination within the securities industry on the basis of race and sex.

title: Books of The Times
description: EXTREME REMEDIES. By John Hejinian. 342 pages. St. Martin's. $7.95.

title: Scarce, Costly Mortgages Thwarting Home Buyers
description: A rapid cycle of increases in the cost of home mortgages and a rapid decrease in their availability have combined as a result of Federal monetary policies to make homebuying difficult or impossible for thousands of families, rich or poor.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Newark Acts Against Wreckers

title: MURRAY G. CROSBY, ENGINEER, 70, DIES
description: Murray G. Crosby, a pioneer in the development of multiplek FM stereo broadcasting, died Saturday at his home, 93 Muttontown Road, Syosset, L.I, He was 70 years old.

title: Nixon, While President, Has Visited 23 Nations
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Following is a list of the 23 countries President Nixon has visited since taking office in 1969:

title: 2 BELIEVE EGAN GOT DRUG FUNDS
description: Two detectives from the Special Investigations Unit of the Police Department's Narcotics Bureau testified yesterday that they had been led to believe that the commander of the nowdisbanded unit, Lieut. John J. Egan, had shared in thousands of dollars seized from narcotics traffic suspects.

title: A STUDY EXAMINES REVENUE SHARING
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Preliminary data from a study by the Brookings Institution show that the larger cities and counties use less of their revenuesharing funds on new parograms than do smaller cities and counties.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering stiffer disclosure requirements for foreign corporations selling stock in the United States, according to its chairman, Ray Garrett.

title: Lawyers' Watergate
description: Watergate has had a profound effect on the legal profession. Hardly a week passes without the revelation that another lawyer has, in one way or another, violated the law and the public trust. This situation has caused anguish within the profession and a steady stream of mail to law school deans demanding that courses in ethics be made mandatory for all law students.

title: Record 95 Buckles Roads Here
description: The hottest weather of the yeara maliciously muggy, 95degree record at its midafternoon worstbaked the city and wilted its inhabitants yesterday as roadways buckled, electricpower demands soared and dehydrated tempers occasionally flared.

title: Men's Lib: An Unorganized But Significant Movement
description: If it is not an infant in swaddling clothes, then it is scarcely more than a toddler, still staying close to the sometimes reassuring, sometimes rather overwhelming presence of its mother: the women's liberation movement.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: CENTRAL RANKERS ASK COOPERATION
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 10 A call for reinforced international monetary cooperation through more closely managed exchange rates, greater balanceofpayments discipline and constructive action on gold was issued today at a meeting of the world's leading financial authorities.

title: Dropping Rates Continue To Spur Rise in Market
description: The stock market scored its sixth consecutive advance yesterday in much slower trading. Prices again were buoyed by investors' growing confidence that interest rates had peaked.

title: Rosenberg Takes Westchester Medal
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 10William Rosenberg of Ridgeway, playing his home course, won medalist honors today in qualifying for the 55th annual Westchester County Golf. Association amateur tournament with a 39, 3574

title: A Cattleman Sues A. &P. and Safeway On Prices of Meat
description: LINCOLN, Neb., June 10 (UPI)  A Nebraska cattleman filed a $1.5billion suit today against two of the nation's largest supermarket chains charging them with conspiracy to fix meat prices.

title: State Hearings on Charity Funds Begin
description: TRENTON, June 10  About $5million to $6million in New Jersey, and perhaps as much as $50million across the country, is being siphoned off from donations to legitimate charities by profitmaking organizations posing as benefactors of the handicapped, James Amico, coordinator for charitable organizations of the State Division of Consumer Affairs, said today.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Foster Wheeler Corporation received $52.8million contract for a 575,000kilowatt steam generator and related equipment from the Omaha Public Power District. The order included electrostatic precipitators to capture ash and particulate matter.

title: Wallace Scores Income Tax
description: ATLANTA, June 10 (AP) Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that an oppressive Federal income tax pressed solely on the brows of the middle class will become an increasingly important political issue in this country. But he told an agribusiness group here, I'm not a candidate except for Governor of Alabama.

title: Science and the White House: Support Is Growing for Restoration of a TopLevel Voice to Define Policy
description: Less than a year ago the Oflice of Science and Technology an agency in the White House teas dismantled amid wringing of hands within the scientific community and dire predictions about the consequences of such demotion of nilence in the Federal establishment. The predictions have not come to pass, but there is nevertheless a growing amount of support for some form of restoration.

title: Challenge to School Board Member Is Dismissed
description: Justice Peter A. Quinn of the State Supreme Court has dismissed a classaction suit challenging the eligibility of Martin Rubin, a new board member of Community School District 1 on the Lower East Side.

title: PRESIDENT DEFIES HOUSE SUBPOENA FOR MORE TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 President Nixon, apparently moving closer to a constitutional confrontation with Congress, said today that he must draw a line and refuse to provide the House Judiciary Committee with additional Watergate evidence.

title: Infant Dies After Falling Out Car Door Into Puddle
description: A fourmonthold Queens boy was killed yesterday  apparently drowned  when he fell from his mother's parked car to the cobblestone roadway into a twoinch puddle of water.

title: RUMOR'S CABINET RESIGNS IN ITALY
description: ROME, June 10  Premier Mariano Rumor and his threeparty coalition Cabinet resigned tonight, unable to agree on urgent measures to cope with a threat of national inIsolvency.

title: Environmentalists Hail California Vote Results
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10Environmental activists have claimed credit for narrow victories in two key Congressional contests in the California primary, on top of other successes in the state that added impetus to conservationists' national campaign efforts.

title: S. Klein Expected To Close 6 Stores
description: S. Klein, the discountstore pioneer, is expected to close six of its suburban stores in the New York area because they are losing money, informed sources said yesterday.

title: Earth Tremors Shake Buildings Along Shore
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 10 (UPI)A series of earth tremors shook buildings and broke windows in an area of the New Jersey Shore from Absecon to Wildwood today, the National Weather Service reported.

title: Bangladesh Gains at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 10Bangladesh was recommended for Membership in the United Nations, by the Security Council today, clearing the way for her admission by the General Assembly in the fall.

title: SONG DEBUT IS MADE BY AWILDA GRAYSON
description: Awilda Grayson's debut recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night suggested that with the right program she could be a modestly successful soprano. Miss Grayson, who was born in Puerto Rico but has studied and performed in this country for some years, proved to be an amplevoiced singer with a brighteyed charm that seemed to endear her to the large audience.

title: Food Costs for Families Down In April, First Time Since Fall
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department said today that a lowcost menu for a fourmember family, including two school children, cost $43.40 a week in April, down 0.7 per cent from $43.70 in March. But it was up 18 per cent, or $6.70 a week, from the figure for April, 1973.

title: MEAT FORECAST IN U. S. IS CUT 5%
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) Farmers will harvest 5 per cent less winter wheat this year than expected one month ago, mainly because of deterioration of the crop in the Great Plains, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Inching Toward Peace
description: The Mozambique Liberation Front, Frelimo, and the Government of Portugal seemed to have made an excellent beginning the other day toward peace in southeastern Africa. Meeting in Lusaka under the auspices of the Zambian Government, Samora Machal, president of Frelimo, and Mario Soares, Foreign Minister of Portugal, talked like men intent on ending a war. But the next day they suspended their discussions, apparently because they could not agree on whether a ceasefire or independence was to be the first item on their agenda.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: 100 Dance Critics Form Association

title: BAN AT L.I. PARKS IS INVESTIGATED
description: The City Corporation Counsel's office said yesterday that it was actively trying to determine whether the exclusion of New York City residents from Nassau County beaches and parks was illegal and that it would bring suit if it was.

title: Beame, an Alumnus, And Saxe Honored By Baruch College
description: Mayor Beame received an honorary doctorate from Bernard M. Baruch College, his alma mater, yesterday and urged this, year's 1,813 graduates to work for the orderly future of the city.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: JAMAICA AND GUYANA TO MAKE ALUMINUM
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad June 10 (UPI)  The world's second and third largest bauxiteproducing nations will be producing their first aluminum within about three years, according to Trinidad and Tobago's Industry and Commerce Minister, Errol Mahabir.

title: Over There Lies Peace for All
description: One imagines the President and Secretary Kissinger emitting vast sighs of relief as they soared out of their homeland for foreign shores in pursuit of the generation of peace. There is little here any longer to encourage them to dwell upon their nobility. Beset by sheriffs, prosecutors, querulous scribes and a sullen populace, what great man would not welcome a grand tour abroad, accepting the salute of cannon and the deference of sheiks to remind them that dishonor in the homeland is of prophethood?

title: REELECTION FUNDS TO PAY STANS' BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)  The trustees of President Nixon's leftover campaign funds have agreed to pay nearly $400,000 in legal expense of former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans, The Washington Post reported in Tuesday editions.

title: Funds Sought for V.A.
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI)  President Nixon asked Congress today to appropriate an additional $179.5million for the Veterans Administration and an additional $6million for the Agriculture Department.

title: ProAbortion Groups Prepare Extensive Statewide Campaign
description: TRENTON, June 10  Proabortion forces in New Jersey, feeling the need to combat the antiabortion drive that they say threatens to make abortions illegal once again, met here tonight in preparation for what promises to be a new round of bitter and divisive legal and legislative battles.

title: PUERTO RICAN DENIED VOTE FOR PRESIDENT
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., June 10 (AP)A Federal District Court judge threw out a petition today asking that resident Puerto Ricans be allowed to vote for the President of the United States.

title: Portugal's Delicate Balance
description: LISBONWhen Portugal's leading businessmen and financiers were recently entertained at lunch at the United States Embassy here, a hush fell on the room when Dr. Vasco Viera de Almeida, the new Minister of Economics, walked in. Dr. Viera de Almeida was known to be a centrist, and has been respected as a Portuguese banker; but no one knew quite what to expect from him in his new role, or from the provisional Government that had just put an end to Portugal's 48year dictatorship.

title: RUMOR'S CABINET RESIGNS IN ITALY
description: ROME, June 10Premier Mariano Rumor and his threeparty coalition Cabinet resigned tonight, unable to agree on urgent measures to cope with a threat of national insolvency.

title: Business Records
description: JOHN A. WEILL, individually and doing business as the John A. Well Company 499 North B'way, White Plains, N.Y. Liabilities, $227,823; assets, $1,250.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, JUNE 11, 1974
description: President Nixon arrived, in Salzburg, Austria; list night on his way to the Middle East, declaring that he is on a mission for peace not only for those nations directly involved but for the entire world. He was accompanied by Mrs. Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger. [1:5] In Bonn, Common Market foreign ministers decided to propose, despite American objections, a broad program of economic, technical and cultural cooperation with 20 Arab countries. [5:1.]

title: Staten Island Zoo, on Birthday, Plans for New Growth
description: The Staten Island Zoo marked its 40th anniversary yesterday with an announcement of a $1,275,000 enlargement and modernization program.

title: NIXON, IN AUSTRIA, SAYS MIDEAST TRIP HAS GLOBAL COAL
description: SALZBURG, Austria, June 10 President Nixon arrived here tonight on his way to the Middle East, declaring that he was on a mission for peace not only for those nations directly involved but for the entire world.

title: Iran Ordering More Grumman Planes
description: Iran has increased from 30 to 80 the number of Grumman F14A Navy fighter planes she intends to buy, reliable sources in Washington said yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A citizens' commission headed by former Family Court Judge Justine Wise Polier was established to investigate charges of corporal punishment at a Bronx junior high school and throughout the city school system. The commission was established by the Metropolitan Applied Research Center, headed by Dr. Kenneth B. Clark and the New York Civil Liberties Union and cosponsored by the Puerto Rican Legal Defense Fund and the Legal Defense Fund of the NAACP.
