title: BOY SCOUTS REPORTI PADDED ENROLLMENT
description: CHICAGO, June 10 (AP)The Boy Scouts of America has found that some of its staff have been cheating on membership rolls, the organization's head said today.

title: CENTER HEARINGS ASSAILED BY U. S.
description: The city's environmental hearings on the proposed new convention center on the West Side finally opened yesterday and were immediately denounced as unsatisfactory by the Federal Government, which said it would hold its own hearings.

title: OilImporting Nations' Cooperation
description: First signs now are beginning to emerge of cooperative policies and actions by, the main oilimporting nations to meet the critical eneriy, trade and Monetary problenis created by the price increase's and the limitations on output by the oilproducers' cartel.

title: African Bloc Urges Angola Rebels to Unify for Talks
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, June 10Delegates to the Council of Ministers of the Organization of African Unity, meeting here, are urging four guerrilla factions in Portugal's largest and richest African territory, Angola, to organize themselves for negotiations with the Portuguese.

title: People in Sports
description: The Seattle SuperSonics yesterday signed their No. 1 draft pick, Tom Burleson of North Caroline State, a 7fobt4inch center, which meant that Kareem AbdulJabbar of Milwaukee would finally have someone to look up at in the Natinal Basketball Association. Financial terms were not disclosed, but the contract was for five years with a nocut provision. Burleson, who helped the Wolfpack win the National Collegiate title last season, had also been drafted by the Indiana Pacers of the American Basketball Association.

title: 2 Trucks Hijacked by 5 Men
description: WALTHAM, Mass., June 10 (AP)  Two trucks, one containing $50,000 in pennies and the other $100,000 in camera equipment, were hijacked today at the Associated Transport terminal, the police said. The trucks, owned by Associated Transport, were taken by five men wearing ski mosks.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Foreign Students Assail U.S Curb on Summer Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Foreign college students and their advisers have strongly criticized a recent policy change of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service that bars most foreign students from summer jobs.

title: Cominco Plans Complex
description: Cominco, Ltd., a unit of Canadian Pacific Investments, Ltd., said yesterday that it would build a $112million fertilizer complex at a site about 25 miles east of Calgary, Alberta.

title: Ailing Rock Island Line Sees Signs of a Rescue
description: CHICAGO  The Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad better known as the Rock Islandholds two unenviable records.

title: Railroad Explains Costs Kept It Out of Amtrak
description: The Rock Island is one of three of the nation's railroads that did not turn over its passenger train operations to. Amtrak the quasiGovernmental agency that took over most railroad passenger train services more than two years ago. The Rock Island said it would cost too much.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
$3.9Million Motor Vessel In Cape May Ferry Service
description: LEWES, Del., June 10The Cape May ferry line went modern today with dedication of the streamlined $3.9million motor vessel Delaware.

title: Canada's Productivity Up
description: OTTAWA, June 10 (Reuters) Canada's gross national product increased during the first quarter of 1974 at a seasonally adjusted rate of 4.9 per cent, Statistics Canada said today, The rate of increase was itself up from the 4.4 per cent reported for the fourth quarter of 1973, the agency said. In the first quarter, the G.N.P. totaled $132milion, up from $125million for the 1973 fourth quarter and compared with $112million for the first 1973 quarter.

title: FRANCE TO LOWER VOTING AGE TO 18
description: PARIS, June 10The French Government proposed today that the voting age be lowered from 21 to 18.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD F.P.C. ON GAS RATES
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Supreme Court upheld today the Federal Power Commission's authority to revise courtapproved schedules of rates for natural gas produced in the Southern Louisiana area, which serves a third of the nation.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Citizens' Group Formed To Study School Beatings
description: A citizens' commission, headed by former Family Court Judge Justine Wise Polier, was established yesterday to make an independent investigation into charges of corporal punlishment at Jordan L. Mott Junfor High School 22 in the Bronx and elsewhere in the city school system.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: The Morris County major baseball league opened its 40th season June 2 with three additionsthe North Jersey Nationals, the Sparta Streakers and the designatedhitter rule.

title: Where Nixon Is Staying
description: Salzburg, the central Austrian provincial capital that is acting as host to President Nixon, is a city of 128,000 astride the Salzach River in a broad valley hemmed in from the south by jagged Alpine cliffs and on the north by the West German and Czechoslovak borders.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: LONDON METAL MARKET

title: College World Series
description: GIVE SUMMER TO A CHILD. THE FRESH AIR FUND.

title: Belgian Coalition Strengthened By Addition of a Walloon Party
description: BRUSSELS, June 10  Belgium's twoparty minority Government became a majority coalition today with the addition of the Frenchlanguage federalist party, the Walloon Rally.

title: Geneva Conferees Split On Timing of Next Talks
description: CAIRO, June 10Egypt and the United States are in agreementoqn seeking a delay in the nexqound of the Geneva peace conference on the Middle East at least until the end of September or early October, according to highplaced sources.

title: Pro Transactions
How the Teams Stand Today
description: Tuesday, June 11, 1974

title: Jury Gets Shea Murder Case Today
description: Calling the murder charge against Police Officer Thomas J. Shea an inversion of justice in which this policeman became the victim, his defense lawyer, Jacob Evseroff, told the jury in State Supreme Court, Queens, yesterday that I speak for every man in blue who walks the streets of New York in asking for a verdict that speaks the truth for law and order and justice.

title: BENJAMIN DANCERS OFFER 2 NEW WORKS
description: Fred Benjamin returned to the Kaufmann Concert Hall with his company for the first time in several yeas, on Sunday evening. The program featured two premieres, Vein Melter and Concupiescence, as well as familiar works from repertory.

title: Carey and Rivals List Campaign Funds
description: The Democratic candidates for the nomination for Governor depended heavily on their families and their own bank accounts in paying for the Preconvention stage of their campaigns, according to figures they filed yesterday with the party's state committee.

title: Nixon Reasserts Authority To Limit Ehrlichman Data
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 President Nixon insisted again today that only he had the right to determine which White House documents could made available to the defense of John D Ehrlichman in the plumbers case.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: DEMOCRATS ANSWER WOMEN'S QUESTIONS
description: The three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor committed themselves last night to a wide range of profeminist positions, lat a meeting of the Manhattan Women's Political Caucus.

title: MOZAMBIQUE HOLDS SECRET POLICEMEN
description: The following dispatch was provided to The New York Times by The Argus Africa News Service of Johannesburg, South Africa.

title: Riders Repelled as Heat Brings Out Bus Roaches
description: Cockroaches, those pests that normally confine their mischief to the kitchen, swarmed up from nesting places in the motors of the city's buses yesterday and drove New Yorkers, already suffering in the hotbox heat of the often poorly ventilated vehicles, out of their seats.

title: D.C. Campaign Funding Bill Passed by the House, 27156
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  The House passed a campaign financing bill today governing this fall's first District of Columbia elections.

title: Rivera's Ride to Stardom As Jockey Started Slowly
description: As far as Miguel Rivera is concerned, the 30yearold Puerto Rican jockey has no more worlds to conquer. I'm satisfied that I have reached my goal, I've accomplished my mission, he said in genuine seriousness yesterday. Resting in the comfortable, airconditioned jockeys' room at Belmont Park, the hero of the Preakness Stakes of three weeks ago and the Belmont Stakes on Saturday talked willingly, if unsmilingly, about a career that brought him from poverty and obscurity to a top position among the continent's leading riders.

title: Team Tennis Is Hopeful TV Will Strengthen Gate
description: Will television exposure prop up World Team Tennis?

title: AUTO PRODUCTION SLOWS IN EUROPE
description: BRUSSELS, June 10Slack demand in Europe for new automobiles during the first quarter of 1974 has forced many European car manufacturers to slow production this spring. So far, Americanaffiliated companies seem to be the hardest hit.

title: Inclement Weather Has Put a Damper On Outlook for Canada's Wheat Crop
description: REGINA, Saskatchewan, June 6  At a time when buyers all over the world are looking to Canada's prairies as a source of badly needed wheat, it now appears that this year's crop will be no better than average at best.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: CHASE CONSIDERS LOAN RATES RISE
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank is seriously considering an increase in personal loan ratesincluding a rise in auto loan rates. If it raises such rates across the board, it would become the first to do so for automobile loans.

title: Chess: The Fischerless U.S. Team Gets. Off to a Wobbly Start
description: NICE, June 9The United States squad, competing in the 21st international team tournament here, got off to a wobbly start by barely achieving a 22 tie with Canada in the first round of the preliminaries.

title: Ford Warns Against Unilateral U.S. Troop Cuts
description: Vice President Ford last night warned against any unilateral reduction by the United States of its troops overseas.

title: USM CORP. SUES ALLEGHANY CORP.
description: The USM Corporation filed suit yesterday against its largest known stockholder, the Alleghany Corporation, and against an Alleghany vice president, Paul Woodbury, who has been a USM director since January.

title: Beaches That Are Safe And Unsafe Are Listed
description: Dr. Lowell E. Bellin, the Health Commissioner, yesterday listed public beaches in the city that are approved and disapproved for swimming. He said the Health Department's program of beachwater sampling, which began April 16, would continue throughout the summer. The list follows:

title: RICHARD R. DAVIDSON
description: Richard R. Davidson, a mealber of the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, died of a heart attack Saturday at Doctors Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived 165 East 94th Street.

title: Opera: 2 Met Premieres
description: Just as there are culinary possibilities other than meat and potatoes or ham and eggs, so there are alternatives to Cav and Pag, opera's once inescapable double bill. The Metropolitan Opera discovered a workable combination last night in its new production of two oneacters, Bluebeard's Castle and, Gianni Schicchi. The former and more profound work proved disappointing visually, but more of that later.

title: NEW BID TO ARABS MADE BY MARKET
description: BONN, June 10  The nine Common Market foreign ministers decided today, despite American objections, to make an offer of broad economic, technical and cultural cooperation to 20 Arab countries.

title: Record 95 Buckles Roads Here
description: The hottest weather of the yeara maliciously muggy, 95degree record at its midafternoon worstbaked the city and wilted its, inhabitants yesterday As roadways buckled, electricpower demands soared and dehydrated tempers occasionally flared.

title: EXCHIEF IN SEOUL TIED TO PROTEST
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June A former President of South Korea was secretly arrested and interrogated recently for having helped to finance antiGovernment student demonstrations in April, according to authoritative Korean and foreign sources here.

title: Robinson, Angel Pilot Are Battling
description: Frank Robinson, one of baseball's genuine superstars who has played in five World Series and 10 AllStar games, is now engaged in a silent war with Manager Bobby Winkles and could wind up on another team in the next five days.

title: S. Klein Expected To Close 6 Stores
description: S. Klein, the discountstore pioneer, is expected to close six of its suburban stores in the New York area because they are losing money, informed sources said yesterday.

title: Allocations of Gas For June Average 90% of '72 Levels
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The Federal Energy Administration allocated to each state today at least 90 per cent of its June, 1972, gasoline supply, adjusted for growth.

title: Tennis Results
description: N.Y. STATE MEN

title: Peking Appears Disappointed In Results of AntiLin Campaign
description: HONG KONG, June 10In the summer of 1968, when fighting between factions of the Red Guards raised the specter of anarchy, large detachments of workers were dispatched to Chinese universities to restore order and serve as arbiters on all political and even on educational issues. These Worker Propaganda Teams, as they were known, were never formally withdrawn from the campuses, but in recent years they seemed to have faded away, making room for a more conventional kind of academic administration.

title: Treasury Bills Off At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Yields on threemonth and sixmonth United States Treasury bills were lower in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Garment Workers Continue to Vote On Tentative Pact
description: Striking workers in the men's and boys' clothing industry continued voting yesterday on a new contract that would provide $1 an hour in wage increases over three years, a costofliving escalator provision and a minimum monthly pension of $100 in 1976.

title: ADMIRAL MANSFIELD, NAVY DOCTOR, DEAD
description: Rear Adm. Raymond J. Mansfield, U.S. Medical Corps, retired, died yesterday at Stamford, Conn. He was 80 years old and had lived in nearby Darien.

title: More Planes for Iran
description: Iran has increased from 30 to 80 the nthiber of Grumman F14A Navy fighter planes she intends to buy, reliable sources in Washington said yesterday. The Iranian order would be a boon for the economy of Long Island Grumman, which builds the planes at Bethpage and Calverton, is the island's largest employer. Page 6.

title: Why Are These Women Interested in Your Credit Card?
description: Six socially prominent women from all dyer the country schlepped over to the elegant La Cirque restaurant on East 65th Street yesterday to do a little drumbeating for the merchandising wave of the future.

title: TV: CourtMartial of Gen. Yamashita
description: ABCTV's Jtidgment series, being produced by Stanley Kramer, tonight presents the second of its dramatic trial recreations with The CourtMartial of the Tiger of Malaya  General, Yamashita. The 90minute program begins at 8:30.

title: Lafayette Nine Wins P.S.A.L. Crown, 73
description: Mrs. Lillian Legree has had a busy year watching high school championship games. In the fall, she saw her son, Chris, quarterback South Shore into the Public Schools Athletic League football championship game, in which the Vikings lost to Bayside.

title: U.S. Fitness Program in Need of Aid
description: The United States must set a positive direction toward sports and physical fitness, Casey Conrad, the executive director of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, said yesterday.

title: Natural Gas Line Explodes
description: BEALETON, Va., June 10 (UPI)A natural gas line exploded near a rural air park late yesterday, sending flames almost a mile into the sky before officials capped the line and the fire died out There were no reports of injuries.

title: FASHION TALK
description: If you can skip the sequins and the diamonds  by  the yard, the fall collection Halston showed yesterday was understated, even by Halston's standards. These are the clothes he sells in his shop on East 68th Street to women who can afford custom  made clothes. They're different from the styles mass  produced on Seventh Avenue and shipped to stores all over the country.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, June 10, 1974

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Text of St. Clair Letter to Judge Gesell
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Following is the text of a letter from James D. St. Clair, special Presidential counsel, to Judge Gerhard A. Gesell regarding the dispute over the personal papers of John D. Ehrlichman:

title: World Team Tennis Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Nixon Reasserts Authority To Limit Ehrlichman Data
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 President Nixon insisted again today that only he had the right to determine which White House documents could be made available to the defense of John D. Ehrlichman in the plumbers case.

title: Roadblock in Texas Brings 24 Arrests On Drug Charges
description: OZONA, Tex., June 10Explaining that they were hunting for Patricia Hearst, now a fugitive, Texas law enforcement officers recently set up a roadblock near here and arrested 24 persons for possession of marijuana after searching their vehicles.

title: BANKS PREPARED TO HELP ITALIANS
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 10 Leading central bankers said today that they were prepared to arrange for large credits for Italy.

title: Israelis and Syrians Meeting With U.N. Aides on Golan Front
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June The United Nations Disengagement Observer Force said today that its representatives had been meeting for several days with Israeli and Syrian officers inside the salient of Syrian land that Israel captuned in the war last October.

title: Attica Trial Delayed Again; Inmate and Lawyer Absent
description: BUFFALO, June 10 (UPI) The initial trial stemming from the 1971 riot at Attica State Correctional Facility was delayed again today when the defendant, Vernon La Franque, and his lawyer, Frederick Hayes, failed to appear in State Supreme Court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hohenberg Unearths Sidelights in Pulitzer Prize
description: AQUEBOGUE, L.I., June 7 John Hohenberg is poring over the galleys of The Pulitzer Prize, which will be his eighth book, and he is already talking about the three others he is researching and preparing to write.

title: Elmer Hardenbergh Dies; Lawyer, Retired General
description: Elmer P. Hardenbergh, a retired Army brigadier general and a legal and financial expert, died Sunday in Walter Reed Hospital, Washington. He was 73 years old.

title: Scarce, Costly Mortgages Thwarting Home Buyers
description: A rapid cycle of increases in the cost of home mortgages and a rapid decrease in their availability have combined as a result of Federal, monetary policies to make homebuying difficult or impossible for thousands of families, rich or poor.

title: Roncallo and Duryea Renamed By Suffolk G.O.P. Amid Cheers
description: BLUE POINT, L. I., June 10In an atmosphere of restrained enthusiasm, the Republicans of Suffolk County tonight nominated candidates for Congressional, state and county elections.

title: Dissenters Warned by Italian Bishops
description: ROME, June 10Italy's Roman Catholic bishops today warned those priests and monks who dissented from the hierarchy's stand on the referendum on divorce last month that there will not be space in our churches for arid and corrosive protest.

title: Bridge: Indonesian Team Develops As Top Mystery at Venice
description: The mystery team of the recent world team championships in Venice was unquestionably Indonesia. One problem was that the Indonesians used some exotic bidding methods, and their English was not always good enough to explain them. One of their anchor pairs, for example, Lasut and Aguw, played onediamond opening bid to show either one long minor suit, or a minor twosuiter, or a majorminor twosuiter with at least five cards in the major. In response to this, one heart promised clubs, and one spade promised diamonds.

title: Toscanini's Players Recall the Awe
description: They gathered in little groups, laughing, drinking Lambrusco and eating pannetone in a redcarpeted room at the Manhattan School of Music, and going back in time. It was as though they were waiting for Toscanini, not witnessing a presentation of his death mask to the school.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: More Planes for Iran
description: Iran has increased from 30 to 80 the number of Grumman F14A Navy fighter planes she intends to buy, reliable sources in Washington said yesterday. The Iranian order would be a boon for the economy of Long Island. Grumman, which builds the planes at Bethpage and Calverton, Is the island's largest employer. Page 6.

title: LEWIS O. BREWSTER 3D
description: Lewis Oakley Brewster 3d, a master at the Lawrenceville, (N. J.) School and its assistant director of admission, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home on Main Street in Lawrenceville. He was 51 years old.

title: Soviet Jews Find Liberty and Problems Here
description: They find freedom in New York. But they also find, in New York, that freedom alone is not happiness.

title: Monaco Stops Camora
description: Domenico Monaco, a native of Naples, Italy, now fighting out of New York, was awarded a technical knockout over Ricky Camora of Buenos Aires last night after three rounds of a scheduled 10round lightweight fight at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum. Camora, 135 pounds, who entered the fight with a 160 record, suffered an injury to his left elbow in the first round.

title: Suspect in Murder Of Bride Gives Up To Police in Texas
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 10Samuel Corey of San Antonio indicted here last week for seconddegree murder in the death of a New Jersey bride who was killed on her honeymoon in New Orleans, surrendered to Texas authorities this morning, the Orleans Parish District Attorney's office said today.

title: STEEL OUTPUT FELL 1.3% IN JUNE 8 WEEK
description: Steel production in the week ended June 8 slipped to 2,862,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was down 1.3 per cent and left the production index at 117.3. A week earlier the industry poured 2,901,000 tons for an index of 118.9.

title: Extension Is Being Sought On U.S. Crime Insurance
description: The Insurance Company of North America, which no longer wants to serve Federal crime insurance in eight states and the District of Columbia, has been asked to give the Government 90 days to work out something else.

title: Safecrackers Get $100,000 in Jewels, Miss Bigger Hoard
description: Burglars working with acetylene torches robbed a safe in a downtown jewelry concern of about $100,000 worth of jewelry early yesterday morning but missed a bigger hoard nearby, while another weekend burglar in a banking office got away with a load of paper money  most of it in Italian lire, the police reported.

title: GRACE IS SEEKING REAL ESTATE DEAL
description: W. R. Grace & Co. is expand. eing its interests in the realestate business through the pro. posed acquisition of certain realestate assets and proper. ties of A. S. Development, a subsidiary of American Stand ard, Inc. Terms of the cash transactions were not disclosed yesterday but trade sources estimated the deal to involve in excess of $10million. The agreement in principle made through the W. R. Grace Land Corporation Os subject to approval of Grace's board of directors a: well as the execution and de livery of a definitive agree. ment.

title: I.S. Allots Housing Aid To Projects in 32 Areas
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today an allocation of $100million to public housing authorities in 32 communities, ineluding New York, Newark and Jersey City, for physical impavements and better security and services for residents of Housing projects.

title: Plisetskaya Will Tour 8 Cities With Bolshoi
description: The Bolshoi Ballet, with Maya Plisetskaya, will make an eightcity tour of the United States, beginning in Boston on Aug. 12 and ending here with a week's engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House from Sept. 17 through Sept. 22.

title: Advertisin: Merger Madness
description: Having had the weekend to mull it over, executives of the countrys' top, ad agencies still had trouble yesterday believing that Doyle Dane Bernbach and Wells, Rich, Greene had been having conversations about merging.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 10 (UPI)  The International Football Federation, overruling European objections, has decided to expand the number of teams for futureorld Cup soccer finals from 16 to an eventual 24, Argentine and Uruguay officials  said today. Washington Cataldi, Uruguay's F.I.F.A. delegate, said the executive committee decision would be announced tomorrow at the General F.I.F.A. Congress, two days before the 10th World Cup tourney opens.

title: NIXON, IN AUSTRIA, SAYS MIDEAST TRIP HAS GLOBAL GOAL
description: SALZBURG, Austria, June 10 President Nixon arrived here tonight on his way to the Middle East, declaring that he was on a mission for peace not only for those nations directly involved but for the entire world.

title: UNION OIL DEVELOPS NEW SHALE PROCESS
description: The Union Oil Company of California has developed a new process for oil and gas recovery from shale that is expected to increase the company's reserves by 15 per cent, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: WILLIAM R. SANDS
description: William R. Sands, a campaign manager for the Advertising Council, died Friday of a heart attack while on the way to his office in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Elizabeth, N.J.

title: SCHOOL VOTE LOW IN A HARLEM AREA
description: A light turnout of voters and quiet at the polls characterized yesterday's election board in community school board in Harlem's District 5.

title: Advertising: Esty's President
description: The perfect Esty man or woman, said Paul Rogers Dooling, a confirmed Esty man, is more of a salesman than an ad guy. And by salesman I dont mean flashy or the lifeoftheparty type, but a guy who believes in selling products and has the capacity to pass that to the creative people and transmit it to the clients.

title: 3 Homers by Red Sox Topple A's 109
description: The streak from last place to first in the American League East by the Boston Red Sox in the last few weeks has been credited to Mighty Joe, Bernie Carbo's stuffed gorilla.

title: City Officially Dons Summer Festival Garb as Beame Crowns Queen
description: New York City officially assumed its Summer Festival role yesterday, as it has done with varying gusto every June for the last 21 years.

title: Senate Votes $21.9Billion For Weapons Procurement
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The Senate approved today a $24.9billion military procurement bill after having narrowly rejected a further reduction in, military aid to South Vietnam.

title: Contract Awards
description: The General Atomic Company Said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent with the Chicago Bridge and Iron Company worth more than $100million for the construction of eight carbon steel liners for nuclear power plant reactor vessels. The liners would be used as membrane seals for prestressed concrete reactor vessels for eight large high temperature gascooled reactors that General Atomic anticipates to sell to electric utilities in the United States.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (Reuters)  The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today it would require Weekly moneysupply reports from 178 commercial banks that are not members of the Federal, Reserve System.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: A Nation of Mac Milquetoasts
description: EDINBURGH, ScotlandThe American Revolution was the first blow struck against the British Empire. The 200th anniversary of this great event might easily see the coup de grace dealt by England's oldest colony.

title: Chilean Junta Unable to Rein Inflation, and Even Some Supporters Complain
description: SANTIAGO, Chile; June 11A blanket of snow gave the stark, brutal Andes a majestic glow. But not far from the foot of the mountain range, an icy rain churned the unpaved alleys of Lo Hermida into a morass.

title: Gunman Holds 2 Hostages In Queens Housing Project
description: An exmental patient with long criminal record, including manslaughter, took a 5yearold girl and her stepfather hostage at gunpoint early yesterday in a lowincome housing project in Queens.

title: CITY UNIT SCORED ON RELIEF FRAUD
description: A Manhattan grand jury harshly criticized the Department of Social Services yesterday about its management of a welfare photoidentification system, charging that the system was promoting fraud rather than preventing it.

title: 6Session Market Rise Ended by Profit Taking
description: Profit taking ended the stock market's sixseason advance yesterday as prices finished lower in quiet trading.

title: Drug Test Proves Jauf fret Defeated Kodes Cleanly
description: PARIS, June 11The specter of drugtaking, which often has affected other sports, reared up at the French open tennis championships today when Jan Kodes, who was surprisingly beaten late last night by Francois Jauffret, asked that a drug test be taken on France's No. 1 player.

title: House Unit Backs Funds For Developing Countries
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (Reuters)  A House Banking subcommittee approved a bill today authorizing a $1.5billion contribution for low  interest loans to developing countries and sent it to the full Banking Committee.

title: New Bonds Off to a Moderate Start
description: This week's round of new obligations got off to a moderate start yesterday in the taxexempt credit market, where New York State auctioned $900million of taxexempt notes and Massachusetts auctioned $125million of various purpose bonds. The bulk of the New York State notes were not reoffered. The maturities that were reoffered were reported to be fairly well received but not yet sold out late yesterday.

title: The U.S.Egyptian Links
description: CAIRO, June 11The feelings of affection for the United States that will be poured out by thousands of Egyptians along President Nixon's path tomorrow will be at once real and orchestrated. They will be real because, all through the years, the United States has preserved an amazingly large reservoir of goodwill among Egyptians, who, from their Presidents down, have been constantly on the lookout for a gesture that would allow them to be friends with the Americans once more.

title: Shea Jurors Retire Without a Verdict
description: The jury deliberating the murder case of Police Officer Thomas J. Shea, the first New York City policeman ever charged with committing murder while on duty, failed to reach a verdict last night and will resume its efforts this morning.

title: Senate Votes $21.9Billion For Weapons Procurement
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 The Senate approved today a $21.9billion military procurement bill after having narrowly rejected a further reduction in military aid to South Vietnam.

title: Complaints Over Telephone Taps Put at 10,000 a Year
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 About 10,000 Americans complain to the telephone company each year that their telephones are tapped, and subsequent investigation has found their suspicions valid in about 2 per cent of the cases, a telephone company official said today.

title: Time for Caution
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is performing its proper function in reexamining the sworn testimony given by Henry A. Kissinger prior to his confirmation as Secretary of State, in light of ambiguous new allegations about the wiretapping of several of his staff. Restraint and caution are essential, however, to avoid interference with the Secretary's diplomatic functions during President Nixon's current Middle Eastern tour and the forthcoming visit to Moscow.

title: EHRLICHMAN WINS A DELAY OF TRIAL IN PLUMBER CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, citing President Nixon's refusal to provide White House documents, ordered today that a separate, delayed trial be held for John D. Ehrlichman in the plumbers case.

title: Episcopal Church Installs Leader
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)The Right Rev. John Maury Allin was formally installed today as the 23d presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church during ceremonies at the Washington Cathedral.

title: HOUSE VOTE KILLS BILL ON LAND USE
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The House of Representatives voted today, 211 to 204, to kill a highly controversial land use bill that would have given Fedaid to states seeking to halt runaway real estate development.

title: Paul Gerard Daly, 82, Lawyer And Hero in Bode Wars, Dead
description: Paul Gerard Daly, a lawyer and a muchdecorated hero in both World Wars, died Monday evening at his home in Southport, Conn. He was 82 years old.

title: EMOTIONAL PLEA
description: SALZBURG, Austria, June 11 Secretary of State Kissinger in an extraordinary news conference at which he appeared choked with hurt and anger, said today he would resign unless he was cleared of allegations that he participated in illegal or shady activity in Government wiretapping of individuals.

title: Sol Pincus, Civil Engineer, 81; Former City Health Officer Dies
description: Sol Pincus, a sanitary engineer who served as the city's Deputy Health Commissioner from 1935 until 1946, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 270 Lee Avenue, Yonkers, N.Y.

title: SENATORS WILL ACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee agreed unanimously today to accept Secretary of State Kissinger's request for a review of his testimony on national security wiretaps.

title: Mortgage Loans Rate Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 The effective interest rate on conventional home mortgage loans closed in May rose slightly from the previous month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The effective rate for the purchase of newlybuilt homes rose to 8.72 per cent from 8.67 per cent, reflecting an increase of five basis points in the contract interest rate to 8.52 per cent and a rise of one basis point in initial fees and charges to 1.22 per cent.

title: Bribery Is Charged To Iowa Beef House As Trial Opens Here
description: The prosecution in the bribery conspiracy trial of Currier J. Holman, cochairman of the board of Iowa Beef Processors, Inc., the nation's largest beef company, said yesterday that Mr. Holman authorized close to $1millon over a twoandahalfyear period to pay off union officials and supermarket officers in order to sell the company's boxedbeef products in the New York City area.

title: Italy's President Consults On Choice of New Premier
description: ROME., June 11  President Giovanni Leone tonight started the traditional round of consultations preliminary to designating a new Premier to succeed Mariano Rumor, who resigned with his coalition last night after it failed to agree on how to deal with Italy's financial emergency.

title: ANSWERS SOUGHT ON SIX PRINCIPALS
description: School Chancellor Irving An ker said yesterday that he would ask district school authorities to respond to charges that they had appointed some acting prin cipals who were illiterate in English and thus unfit for their posts.

title: 2 Musicians' Jobs Stir Coast Conflict
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 The San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, which became one of the leading brchestras in the United States under such musical directors as Alfred Hertz, Pierre Monteux, Issay Dobrowen and Josef Krips as well as the current one, Seiji Ozawa, is today being torn by an internal conflict and public controversy whose repercussions may extend across the country.

title: Atlanta Wins, 43, on Error
description: ATLANTA, June 11.  A crowd of 45,295, attracted by the prospect of a pitching duel between one of the superstars and one said to be in the making, almost was shortchanged tonight as the Mets opened a threegame series with the Braves.

title: MRS. HAROLD DUFFY
description: Mrs. Corinne L. Duffy, the mother of James E. Duffy, president of ABCTV, died. Saturday at her home in Princeton, Ill. She was 75 years old. Her husband, Harold, died last year.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Why the Threat by Kissinger?
description: WASHINGTON, June 11How could the most popular member of the Nixon Administration think of resigning?

title: Cambodian Premier Expects to Keep Post Despite Difficulties
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 11Premier Long Boret declared today that despite the resignation of six Cabinet ministers, he had been asked by President Lon Nol and the governing Social Republican party to remain in office.

title: Bid to Nixon Hoped ForBriton Sees I.M.F. Sales Tie
description: WASHINGTON, June 11Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon told Congress today that he hoped to recommend to President Nixon before the end of this year that Americans be allowed to buy, sell and own gold.

title: Bill Filed to Take Profit Out of Clinics Offering Methadone
description: A, bill that would impose strict controls on methadonemaintenance programs was introduced in the City Council yesterday after a yearlong investigation of present treatment, methods by the Council's Committee on Health.

title: Law Against Piracy
description: In imposing fiveyear prison terms on two Palestinian guerrillas who hijacked a British aircraft to Amsterdam list March, the Netherlands courts have set a badly needed example in the maintenance of international law and the safety of the airways.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: U.S. to Help Restore Public Housing

title: President Reportedly Confident On Departure for Middle East
description: WASHINGTON, June 11President Nixon departed for his travels in the Middle East confident that his legal position on impeachment and public feeling about the Watergate scandal had stabilized, according to White House aides close to the President.

title: Vandetbilt Tells of Board Vote To Refuse Stalls to Jacobson
description: While one of his horses was winning easily at Belmont Park yesterday, Alfred G. Vanderbitl spent the afternoon testifying, in court.

title: Flatbush Ave. to Be Repaved
description: A threeblock stretch on the east side of Flatbush Avenue from Atlantic Avenue to Bergen Street will be closed for a repaving project starting at 10 A.M. today. In the morning hours there will be two northbound lanes leading into Marihattan and one southbound lane open. In the evening hours there will be two southbound lanes and one northbound lane open. From 9 P.M. to 6 A.M., There will be one lane open in each direction.

title: LENDING ABROAD SEEN RISING IN U.S.
description: Robert V. Roosa, former Under Secretary of the Treasury and now a partner in Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., predicted here yesterday that borrowings in this country by foreign governments and foreign government entities in 1974 would total $10billion. Loans to foreign borrowers last year were approximately $5billion.

title: Poems on Happy Things Win Prizes for 20 Pupils
description: Twenty pupils from the slumridden East New York section of Brooklyn were awarded prizes yesterday for poems about flowers, butterflies, the moon, the seashore and streaking.

title: RENTRISE ROLLBACK APPROVED BY BERME.
description: Miyor Beame signed into law yesterday a City Council bill that repeals and rolls back rent rises; of up to 4 per cent a year representing laborcost increasesin many of the nearly one million rent  controlled apartments here.

title: Sari Greenfield Is Bride
description: The marriage of Miss Sari Lynn Greenfield to Ari D. Bacon was performed yesterday evening at the Statler Hilton Hotel by Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik, professor of Talmud and Jewish philosophy at Yeshiva University. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Myron Greenfield and Isaac Bacon, dean of Yeshiva College, and Mrs. Bacon, all of Monsey, N.Y.

title: Pennsylvania Paper Sold
description: JEANNETTE, Pa., June 11 (AP)The Jeannette Publishing Company, publisher of The NewsDispatch, has been sold to James A. Muscia and group of associates, J. Graff Bomberger, publisher and editor of the paper, announced today. The NewsDispatch has circulation of 11,000, mostly in Westmoreland County in southwestern Pennsylvania.

title: Head of Torch, in Rebuttal, Assails Charities Inquiry
description: TRENTON, June 11  The head of Torch Products Cor poration of West Orange, one of several profitmaking organizations under official scrutiny for allegedly posing in telephonesales solicitations as charities benefiting the handicapped, attacked the State Commission of Investigation today for what he called distortions, exaggerations and misrepresentations.

title: Mr. Nixon's Line . . .
description: In notifying Chairman Peter W. Rodino that he has drawn the line on furnishing any further information for the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment inquiry, President Nixon said that a proceeding such as the present one places a great strain on our constitutional system. Mr. Nixon is right about that; but it is his arguments and his tactics, not the committee's or the courts', that are placing the greatest strains on the Constitution.

title: Capital Investment Focus Is Needed, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON, June 11A longterm analysis by Government experts shows that the economy will not be able to grow as rapidly in the next decade as it has in the past, according to Roy L. Ash, Director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Power Plant Uncertainty
description: Because of recent changes in the energy situation, the factors that in recent decades have spurred ever bigger power plants may now be inoperative, according to Dr. H. Guyford Stever, director of the National Science Foundation. Details on Page 63.

title: Rep. Mitchell to Run Again
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) Representative Donald J. Mitchell, Republican of upstate New York, today announced he would be a candidate for reelection in the 31st Congressional District. Mr. Mitchell, former Mayor of Herkimer, was first elected to Congress in 1972.

title: Robbery Victim Is Killed, Bystander Shot in Battle
description: NEWARK, June 11One man was killed and a bus passenger was seriously injured this afternoon during a shootout involving a crowded bus in the city's North Ward.

title: 2 New Clubs Sadly Study N.H.L. Draft
description: MONTREAL, June 11  It was easy to sympathize with Milt Schmidt and Sid Abel today as they watched the National Hockey League's superstars accept awards for the outstanding performances of the 197374 season.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: TWO HORSES FOR SALE QUARTER HORSES $1,000

title: LEO NUNES, FENCER WHO WON 16 TITLES
description: Leo G. Nunes, an importer who won 16 national fencing titles, died yesterday at his home, 249 East 73d Street. He was 81 years old.

title: SILVER SUPPLY TIED TO COPPER DEMAND
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., June 11The world's recoverable silver ore reserves may be used up by 1990, Thomas P. Mohide of the Ontario, Ministry of Natural Resources said here today.

title: Feliciano Captures P.S.A.L. Net Title
description: Billy Feliciano of South Shore won the Public Schools Athletic League tennis singles championship yesterday with a 61, 6.1 rout of Dave Cooper of Newtown in the final at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

title: Books of The Times
description: MY DAYS. By R. K. Narayan. 186 pages. Viking. $8.95.

title: Music: Bassoon Quartet
description: Bassoon quartets are rare. Even rarer is one made up of women. On Monday night in Carnegie Hall, such an ensemble, calling itself, the New York Bassoon Quartet, made its debut.

title: 1,506 Get Princeton Degrees In Setting of Trees and Humor
description: PRINCETON, June 11Princeton University today granted 926 bachelor and 580 advanced degrees at the 227th commencement ceremonies beneath the shady oaks and maples in front of Nassau Hall.

title: BROKERS ASSAY SMALL INVESTOR
description: The bedrock upon which Wall Street has been struggling to rebuild the sagging market was called a marsh yesterday. The individual investor is inconsequential to the market's for tunes, one speaker said at an industry conference here, and another produced new research to show that despite the conventional wisdom, small investors do care about commissions.

title: South Vietnam and Vietcong Resume Meetings in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11The Saigon Government and the Vietcong resumed talks today in the forum charged with carrying out the provisions of the ceasefire and agreed to discuss further the issue of the Communist delegation's diplomatic status.

title: Sports Nevus Briefs
description: PITTSBURGH, June 11 (UPI)The Pittsburgh Triangles filed an official protest today with the World Team Tennis commissioner, George MacCall, over a disputed call in last night's 2219 loss to the Detroit Loves at Detroit.

title: Aid for Franklin Bank
description: Eleven large New York banks have agreed to lend the financially pressed Franklin National Bank $250million, apparently with the backing of the Federal Reserve Board. Page 61.

title: HOUSE BACKS EASING OF CLEAN AIR DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)The House passed today and sent to the Senate compromise legislation that would slow clean air efforts in an attempt to conserve scarce fuels.

title: ...And So Are Problems World's Craftsmen Face
description: TORONTO, June 11The commanding problem facing today's craftsmen, whether they're professionals or artisans in villages and the bush, is economic, not cultural, the 1,200 delegates to the World Crafts Council were told yesterday.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: StockTrading Plan Of Banks Is Backed
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The Controller of the Currency ruled today for the second time that banks might engage in buying and selling of corporate stocks for their depositors.

title: 35 Rothkos Sold for 1.3Million To Pay Legal Fees, Lloyd Says
description: After Frank Lloyd, head of Marlborough Galleries, learned from his lawyers that a suit to recover 100 Rothko paintings he had bought from the Rothko estate might last a very long time and cost a fortune, he got on the telephone at his home in Nassau and sold 35 of the paintings for $1.34million, he testified yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

title: PENNZOIL CHAIRMAN SCORES U.S. INQUIRIES
description: J. Hugh Liedtke, chairman and chief executive, of the Pennzoil Company, charged here yesterday that current investigations by Federal regulatory agencies relating to Pennzoil's spinoff last March of its United Gas Pipe Line subsidiary comprised a highly orchestrated attack upon the company.

title: FRENCH MILITARY ACCUSED ON TESTS
description: PARIS, June 11 (Reuters) JeanJacques ServanSchreiber, who was dropped from the French Government in a nuclear policy dispute, today accused the French military of using pressure and intimidation to force President Valry Giscard d'Estaing into authorizing a new series of nuclear tests.

title: Passed Ball in 7th Leads to 54 LossSlam by Sudakis
description: Forget the electrifying grandslam home run by Bill Sudakis, Forget the dramatic outfield catches by Elliott Maddox and Bobby Murcer.

title: 4 Teamster Officials Quit
description: ST. LOUIS, June 11 (UPI)Four Teamsters Union officers, rebuffed by the United States Supreme Court in an appeal of their embezzlement convictions, resigned today and prepared to begin serving prison terms. The four officers of Local 600  Donald Lane, president; Clyde Goad, vice president; Daniel Mahany, secretarytreasurer, and Michael Ryan, recording secretary  submitted their resignations at a union meeting and appointed their own successors.

title: Toronto Crafts Show Is Enormous ...
description: TORONTO, June 11A summerlong crafts feast, with pots to look at and pots to make, with quilts to view and quilts to sew, opened here today as part of the 10th anniversary conference of the World Crafts Council.

title: Miss Deussen Wed To Frank W Schiff
description: Miss Erika Deussen was married yesterday to Frank W. Schiff of Washington, vice president and chief economist of the Committee tor Economic Development. The civil ceremony took place in Dtisseldorf, Germany.

title: $306Million More Allotted To Summer Jobs for Youths
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) President Nixon has signed legislation providing an additional $306million in Federal funds to create jobs for young people this summer, according to the White House.

title: Court to Rule on Allowing. Concorde at Boston Airport
description: BOSTON, June 11 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circit, agreed today to decide whether the supersonic Concorde jetliner should be allowed to land Thursday at Logan International Airport.

title: Kodak Sets 5% Pay Rise
description: ROCHESTER, June 11 (AP)The Eastman Kodak Company announced today that most ?? its 70,000 United States em ployes would be given a specia?? pay increase of about 5 per cen?? (next Monday. This special pa?? increase recognizes the realitie?? of the economic environment.

title: L.I. Students Rejoice in Signing Of Bill to Protect Carmans River
description: SQUASSUX LANDING, L.I., June 11  Elizabeth Shreeve stood on the banks of Caymans River this afternoon and looked out toward the wetlands border.

title: House Votes Year Extension, Of CopperDuty Suspension
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The House voted today to extend for a year suspension of duty on certain forms of copper.

title: EHRLICHMAN WINS A DELAY OF TRIAL IN PLUMBER CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell, citing President Nixon's refusal to provide White House documents, ordered today that a separate, delayed trial be held for John D. Ehrlichman in the plumbers case.

title: The Schmidt Victory
description: Local elections rarely have international as well as national importance; but the narrow victory of West Germany's new Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, in the state of Lower Saxony is an exception to the usual rule.

title: Seychelles Forms Link With Africa Unity Bloc
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, June 11  The Seychelles, a British colony of 92 islands in the Pacific Ocean 1,000 miles east of Kenya, has applied for affiliation with the Organization of African Unity, which is meeting here this week.

title: Packer Suffers Phlebitis
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., June 11 (AP)Jim Carter, Green Bay Packers' middle linebacker, is being treated for phlebitis resulting from a tennis injury suffered month ago, the National Football League team announced today.

title: Pastor Told Not to Use Money Offered as MurderCase Bail
description: In a stormy court hearing, a Harlem pastor was directed yesterday to keep his hands off $50,000 he had tried to post as bail in a murder case.

title: HINTS AT SUIT ON POLLUTION RULE
description: TRENTON, June 11  The State Department of Environmental Protection questioned today whether what was good for General Motors was good for New Jersey.

title: Businesses, Pinched for Pennies, Offer Customers Bonuses for Coins
description: Penny, penny, who's got the penny? Some say the copper speculators, some say the kids, some say just the average citizen who has let them pile up in a drawer at home.

title: Senate Unit Kills Cable Sports Curb
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)  Professional sports leagues suffered a setback today when the Senate Judiciary Committee killed legislation to black out most of the distant sports on cable television.

title: Tornado Victim Dies
description: TULSA, Okla., June 11 (UPI)  Henderson Smith, 82 years old, injured by a tornado that wrecked a nursing home on Saturday, died today, increasing to 16 the number of persons killed during weekend storms, the Red Cross said.

title: Two Arrested in Slaying Of Seton Hall Professor
description: MONTCLAIR, June 11Two young men, arrested following a highspeed chase through Newark city streets today, were held in connection with the stabbing murder of a Seton Hall University law professor in his home early Sunday morning.

title: New Books
description: The Diviners, by Margaret Laurence (Knopf, $7.95). A woman reminisces on her family's past and her present to find a meaning to life.

title: JAPAN'S ECONOMY IN A DEEP SLUMP
description: TOKYO, June 11The Japanese economy, suffering now from the worst effects of the Arab oil cutbacks last fall, is in its deepest slump since the postwar recovery 20 years ago.

title: Phosphates Price to Jump 50% in Morocco by July
description: RABAT, Morocco, June 11 (UPI)The price of Moroccan phosphates will jump 50 per cent beginning July 1 in another example, of world raw materials booming in cost. The price rise will mark the second increase this year. In January the price of phosphates tripled from $14 to $42 per ton. Next month the price will reach $63 a ton.

title: ANKER CONFIRMS BRONX PADDLING
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker said last night that a district investigation had found that corporal punishment of students was practiced at the Jordan L. Mott Junior High School 22 in the Bronx and that punitive action was warranted, against the offenders.

title: Who's Basics Overpower Some Snags
description: On the standard of past Who performances, the first of the band's four New York dates at Madison Square Garden Monday night was a little disappointing. There was no new material. The ensemble wasn't as tight as it should have been. The sound systern was poorly balanced and prone to feedback. And the pace and tension of the group's long, 100minute set tended to wander a bit toward the end.

title: COMMERCIAL BANKS ASK RATE EQUALITY
description: Commercial banks, in a continuing effort to quash the introduction of savings bank payment order accounts here, urged the Federal Doposit Insurance Corporation yesterday to equalize the interest rates they can pay on savings accounts with the rates now paid by New York State savings banks.

title: EDGAR ELLINGER JR.
description: Edgar Ellinger Jr., who had been a securities analyst and financial executive with Lionel D. Edie & Co., Lazard Frres and other Wall Street houses, died on Monday at his home in Mountain Ranch, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: PowerPlant Outlook Held Hazy
description: Because of recent changes in the energy situation the factors that in recent decades have spurred ever bigger power plants may now be inoperative, according to Dr. H. Guyford Stever, director of the National Science Foundation.

title: AUSTRIAN LEADER AND NIXON CONFER
description: SALZBURG, Austria, June 11 President Nixon met with Austria's Chancellor, Dr. Bruno Kreisky, today as part of his preparations for the beginning of his Middle East tour tomorrow.

title: C.A.B. Announces Plans to End Subsidy to Profitable Allegheny
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board announced yesterday that it intended to discontinue a Federal subsidy to Allegheny Airlines because the carrier showed an operating profit of $22million for the year ended last March 31.

title: SILVER FUTURES OFF DAILY LIMIT
description: Silver futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday dropped the 20centanounce limit. The July delivery for silver futures closed at $5.06 an ounce, down from $5.26 Monday. With contracts down the limit, trading dried up during the session and volume amounted to only 2,536 contracts.

title: Jordan Solidifies Control Over Politics in Hudson
description: TRENTON, June 11  Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City extended his political control over Hudson County tonight with the election of Bernard Hartnett Jr., a close friend and political ally, as chairman of the Hudson County Democratic organization.

title: Golfers Discovering U.S. Open Course
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 11The word got around as effectively as a message on the jungle telegraph: Don't shoot past the hole.

title: John V, Cassidento, Judge Of Connecticut Court, 47
description: Circuit Court Judge John V. Cassidento, who had been a lawyer for Alfred Baldwin 3d, a Watergate figure, before his elevation to the Connecticut bench last year, died while undergoing heart surgery in YaleNew Haven Hospital on Monday evening. He was 47 years old and lived in Hamden.

title: MRS. JULIO DEL VAYO
description: Mrs. Luisa Graa de Alvarez del Vayo died May 28 in Geneva at the age of 76, it was learned here yesterday. She was the wife of Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Foreign Minister of the Spanish Republic until its overthrow in 1939.

title: Two Fireme Killed
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass., June 11 (AP)Two firemen were killed last night When a burn, ing wall collapsed on them in a fire at the Arrow Paper Corporation. Nine other firemen, a policeman, and a resident of the area were injured. Killed Were Robert Brickley, 32 years old, of Melrose, and Joseph Reilly, 55, of Somerville.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Gunman Holds 2 Hostages In Queens Housing Project
description: An exmental patient with a long criminal record, including manslaughter, took a 5yearold girl and her stepfather hostage at gunpoint early yesterday in a lowincome housing project in Queens.

title: Nixon Asks Court Ruling On CoConspirator Issue
description: WASHINGTON, June 11President Nixon wants the Supreme Court decide whether he should have been named an unfitdicted coconspirator in the Watergate coverup, his lawyers disclosed today.

title: People in Sports
description: At 27 years old, Charlie Walters has seen his dream of a major league pitching career pass him by. The former Minnesota Twins' bonus baby has settled for being the team's batting practice pitcher, His pay is $15 for throwing batting practice for approximately 15 minutes. Walters, who was on the Twins' roster for two months in 1969, said at a recent batting practice session:

title: BREAKINSLINKED IN PANEL EVIDENCE
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The House Judiciary Committee reportedly heard evidence today suggesting that concern about the possible disclosure of a burglary at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist was a principal reason behind the alleged Watergate coverup.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 12, 1974

title: MRS. CLEMENT DESPARD
description: Mrs. Jessie Van Rensselaer Bond Despard, widow of Clement L. Despard who was chairman of Despard & Co., Inc., marine insurance brokers, at his death in 1957, died Monday in Essex, Mass., where she had been living. She was 77 years old.

title: EMOTIONAL PLEA
description: SALZBURG, Austria, June 11 Secretary of State Kissinger, in an extraordinary news conference at which he appeared choked with hurt and anger, said today he would resign unless he was cleared of allegations that he participated in illegal or shady activity in Government wiretapping of individuals.

title: Bingham Seeks Hartford Job
description: HARTFORD, June 11 (AP)State Representative James F. Bingham of Stamford today, announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for State Attorney General. At a news conference here, the 49yearold Mr. Bingham said he was persuaded to enter the race after meeting during the last few months with various legal, civic and political groups.

title: Brazilian Is Elected World Soccer Head
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 11The World Cup doesn't start until Thursday, but the South American countries won a big battle today as Joao Havelange of Brazil was elected president of soccer's international governing body, FIFA.

title: HOUSE VOTE KILLS DILL ON LAND USE
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The House of Representatives voted today, 211 to 204, to kill a highly controversial land use bill that would have given Federal aid to states seeking to halt runaway real estate development.

title: 2 New Clubs Sadly Study N.H.L. Draft
description: MONTREAL, June 11  It was easy to sympathize with Milt Schmidt and Sid Abel today as they watched the National Hockey League's superstars accept awards for the outstanding performances of the 197374 season.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: Delightful Belmont, not breakfast. Breakfast at the race track is on paper plates, with plastic spoons, knives and forks; plastic orange juice and plastic coffee cups. The food itself survives.

title: G.O.P. Platform, Offering Broad Appeal, Is Adopted
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 11 The platform adopted today by the Republican State Committee without a murmur of dissent appeared designed to ?? something for virtually everyone in the state much as its balanced statewide ticket did.

title: DEL MAURO PLEADS GUILTY IN TAX CASE
description: NEWARK, June 11 (AP)James J. Del Mauro, the former chief magistrate of Newark who was mentioned in the telephone conversations of the mobster Angelo DeCarlo, pleaded guilty today to income tax fraud.

title: FISCAL RESTRAINT PLEDGED BY RUSH
description: WASHINGTON, June 11President Nixon's White House economic adviser said tonight that, in contrast to the last 10 years, the Government planned now to stick with fiscal and monetary restraint for as long as needed to bring down the rate of inflation.

title: U.S. WEIGHING SHIFT ON CRIME INSURANCE
description: The Government is exploring the possibility of selling crime insurance by mail or through local post offices, George K. Bernstein, Federal Insurance Administrator, disclosed yesterday.

title: NURSES ON COAST STILL ON STRIKE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11A strike by 4,000 nurses in northern California went into its fifth day today with no end in sight.

title: Calypso Finds Brooklyn A Home Away From Horne
description: Francisco Springer, who is better known as the Mighty Sparrow, calls himself the calypso king of the world. The city's West Indian community agrees, by and large, and when he performs here, as he did on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, the hard grind for the Yankee dollar is forgotten for a while.

title: MRS. MARCELL M. HOLZER
description: Mrs. Gertrud Blum Holzer widow of Marcell M. Holzer who founded American. Union Transport, Inc., shipowners and operators, on coming to this country from Germany in 1935, died yesterday in Switzerland, where she had been living. She was 88 years old.

title: LISBON INDICATES SELFRULE POLICY
description: LISBON, June 11Portugal's provisional President offered today to let the nation's African territories decide their own future once a climate of freedom and democratic institutions are established there.The President, Gen. Antnio de Spinola, also insisted on the perfect functioning of these institutions.

title: Kissinger Threat Culminates Long Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Secretary of State Kissinger moved today to bring to an by his threat to resignthe 13month controversy in Washington over his involvement in the wiretapping of Government officials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971 and the formation of the socalled White House plumbers unit.

title: Albatross to the House
description: WASHINGTONThis is going to be a hard year for Republicans on the campaign trail. But observers are saying that it may also prove to, be a tough year for incumbent voter, is in: discriminately antiincumbent.

title: Panel Told Defective Infants Are Allowed to Die
description: WASHINGTON, June 11(UPPSeveral thousand mentally and physically defective babies are left to die each year when medical treatment is withheld, two physicians testified today.

title: DELAYS IN REPORTS ON GIFTS CHARGED
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI)A Washington columnist says the wives of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, former Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Senator J. W. Fulbright received gifts not immediately reported to the Government.

title: Rugby Fans Battle Over Racial Issue
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, June 11 (AP)  White spectators attacked antiapartheid demonstrators who delayed a British Lions Rugby Union game today.

title: Theater: Lenny Bruce
description: A perfectly good actor named Frank Speiser came out on the stager of the Players Theater is MaeDougal Street last night and gave an impersonation, quite a skilled impersonation as it happens, of Lenny Bruce. His oneman show is called The World of Lenny Bruce, and two vital things occurred to me  the first sociological, the second artistic.

title: Newsmen and Officials Targets of Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON, June 11Following are the names of 13 Government officials and four newsmen whose telephones were tapped by the Nixon Administration at various times and for varying periods between May, 1969, and February, 1971, and their affiliations at the time they were tapped:

title: NEWS INDEX
Reid Is Expected to Bow Out of Gubernatorial Race Today
description: Representative Ogden R. Reid is expected to bow out of the Democratic gubernatorial race today but will not endorse one of, his rivals, sources close to the Westchester County Congressman said last night.

title: Hasidic Groups File Suit to Bar Redistricting as Gerrymander
description: More than 100 Jewish organizations in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn filed suit in Federal District Court yesterday to block implementation of the new legislative and Congressional districts enacted by the Legislature on May 29.

title: MRS. OLIN M'K. JONES
description: Mrs. Pauline Williams Jones, widow of the Rev. Dr. Olin McKendree Jones, a Presbyterian minister who later taught at Hofstra College, died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived here.

title: Trudeau Seeks Support in West
description: REGINA, Saskatchewan, June 6In a small farming community north of here, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau looked down from the stage of a high school auditorium at a crowd that included at least a sprinkling of political opponents.

title: Join Ramirez and Nastase Among 8 Survivors
description: PARIS, June 11  Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md., ranked 15th and a claycourt specialist, became the only American in the men's singles quarterfinals of the French tennis championships today. But until the waning moments of this long sunny afternoon, it seemed possible that Erik van Dillen might be there as well.

title: . . . and Judge Gesell's
description: Judge Gerhard Gesell has been forced to sever John Ehrlichman's case from that of the others accused in the Ellsberg burglary and to postpone his trial. In ordering the severance, the judge said, The President flatly refuses to make documents available . . . and thus makes it impossible for the court to properly perform its duty.

title: New Interne Guidelines Spur a Dispute in A.M.A..
description: WASHINGTON, June 11A major dispute is developing within the ranks of the American Medical Association over new guidelines that have been denounced as a big step toward unionization of all doctors and defended as a means of halting the association's loss of young doctors.

title: Wilson Picks May of Rochester As the Candidate for Controller
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 11After a show of dissatisfaction from Republicans loyal to Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, Governor Wilson today filled out his state ticket with an upstater, former Mayor Stephen May of Rochester, as candidate for Controller.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Although there was a public outcry when the State Legislature approved a onecent increase in the city sales tax, only 10 spectators and not a single speaker against it showed up yesterday when the City Council Finance Com mittee took up the controversial budget item at a public hearing.

title: Counsel for House Panel Charges Justice Agency With Cover Up of Corruption in Immigration Service
description: WASHINGTON, June 11counsel of a House subcommittee has charged the Justice Department with a coverup of corruption in the Southwest region of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, a branch of the Department.

title: zed Tap Requests To Kssinger or Gen. Haig
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Some of the original requests for wiretaps placed on 17 Government officials and newsmen came from Henry A. Kissinger or Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., according to a summary of an inquiry last year by the federal Bureau of Inveitigation.

title: Notes on People
description: Robert S. Ingersoll was named by President Nixon yesterday to he top aide to Secretary of State Kissinger, replacing Kenneth Rush, who recently became an adviser on economic policy to the President.

title: SENATORS WILL ACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 The Senate Foreign Relations. Committee agreed unanimously today to accept Secretary of State Kissinger's request for review of his testimony on national security wiretaps.

title: Transcript of Kissinger Statement and Answers to Questions at News Conference
description: SALZBURG, Austria, June 11Following is a transcript released by office of the White House press retary here of Secretary of State Kissinger's statement and his remarks in response to questions at a news conference.

title: Red Smith
description: Police were setting up barricades around Duffy Square when John Condon of Madison Square Garden climbed into a boxing ring pitched in the triangle where Broadway and Seventh Avenue converge at 46th Street. the triangle is named in honor of Father Francis P. Duffy of the Fighting 69th in World War I, but to a younger generation it is known as Needle Park, where junkies nod in the sun. Yesterday squatters were displaced long enough for Condon to remind the noonday crowds that Joe Frazier and Jerry Quarry would be fighting in the the Garden next Monday night.

title: INFORMER TELLS OF ZEBRA DEATHS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (UPI)Members of a black militant group took pictures of each other murdering whites in order to win promotions, according to grand jury testimony by an informer in the San Francisco Zebra killings case.

title: Report of Watergate Committee Staff Cites Plan to Use Federal Funds to Gain Black Support for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Reelection efforts on behalf of President Nixon included a plan for using Federal funds to induce black leaders such as the Rev. Jesse Jackson and James Farmer to remain neutral or support the President in 1972, according to a draft report by the stiff of the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Vanderbilt Tells of Board Vote To Refuse Stalls to Jacobson
Students and Jobs.
description: An estimated 17,000 foreign students out of the 150,000 who are enrolled in American colleges face financial difficulties this summer if the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service enforces its recent order prohibiting these students from accepting temporary employment. Unless the immigration authorities are generous in their promise to make exceptions in hardship cases, some students may actually have to cut their studies short and return to their home countries if they are prevented from supplementing their funds during the vacation period.

title: EURICO DUTRA, 89, BRAZILIAN LEADER
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 11 (UPI)Marshal Eurico Gaspar Dutra, the grand old man of Brazil's armed forces who spearheaded the overthrow of Getulio Vargas and served as president from 1945 to 1951, died today of a lung infection. He was 89 years old.

title: Zorila, Nisselson Gain In Westchester Amateur
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 11  Two former champions, Greg Zorila of Briar Hall and Peter Nisselson of Hampshire, were among the survivors today after the opening two rounds of the Westchester County amateur golf championship.

title: EDWARD J PIERCE, BANKER, 68, DEAD
description: Edward J. Pierce, retired board chairman of the Harlem Savings Bank, died Monday in his home at 22 Bacon Road, Old Westbury, L.I. He was 68 years old.

title: Outgoing P.B.A. Aides Get a Year's Expenses
description: Delegates of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association voted yesterday to pay their outgoing president, Robert M. McKiernan, and the other 12 outgoing board members a year's expenses, as the P.B.A. describes the payment made above regular police salaries.

title: Quinn in Bay State Race
description: WILBRAHAM, Mass., June 11 (AP)  Attorney General Robert H. Quinn tdday announced his candidacy for Governor of Massachusetts, Mr. Quinn, a Democrat, criticized the mismanagement and ineptitude of the Republican administration and said it had caused the crippling of the stete's economy.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Take It Easy, Henry
description: Henry Kissinger's threat to resign Is the silliest thing he has done since he came into the Government and is not really to be taken seriously.

title: Ford Offers WNET Loan of $7Million
description: The Ford Foundation has agreed to make a longterm loan of $7million to the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, the licensee of WNET/13, for the establishment of a permanent home for the station at the Henry Hudson Hotel on West 57th Street.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
LEGAL COSTS CUT 1972 NIXON FUND
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 The last of President Nixon's giant 1972 campaign chest is being whittled down sharply by legal fees and settlements associated with the Watergate affair.

title: Aid for Franklin Bank
description: Eleven large New York banks have agreed to lend the financially pressed Franklin National Bank $250million, apparently with the backing of the Federal Reserve Board. Page 61.

title: TransAtlantic Air Fares Expected to Go Up Again
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June 11The cost of an airline ticket, to Europe, which has taken off like a jet plane this year, appears certain to climb even more, international airline representatives said today.

title: Women Gain a Backer
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) Senator Hugh Scott, Repubican of Pennsylvania said yesterday that for the first time he will accept applications from women seeking nomination to any of America's service academies.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Senate Unit Kills Cable Sports Curb
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)  Professional sports leagues suffered a setback today when the Senate Judiciary Committee killed legislation to black out most of the distant sports on cable television.

title: NEW RULES ARE SET ON G.S.A. CONTRACTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) New rules for the awarding of Federal contracts for public buildings have been designed to eliminate potential conflict of interest, a Government official has announced.

title: Court Asked to Declar'e Cocaine a Non Narcotic
description: NEWARK, June 11  Contending that cocaine is simply not a narcotic drug, Roger Lowenstein, the Federal public defender for New Jersey, today asked a Federal district court to declare the substance a nonnarcotic.

title: Whirlpool Warns of Shock From Trash Compacters
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI)The Whirlpool Corporation has notified the Government that some of its trash compacters might pose a shock hazard because of an improperly assembled power cord.The company warned the Consumer Product Safety Commission of what it called a possible problem. It said it did not know how many of the units were on the market or in possession of consumers.

title: A Tackler of Controversial Issues Gerhard Alden Gesell
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 In his six years on the bench, controversy has been routine for United States District Court Judge Gerhard A. Gesell. The 63yearold judge is now hearing pretrial motions in the case of the breakin at the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatristand making headlines for his stinging rebukes to James D. St. Clair, President Nixon's lawyer.

title: Stockholder Sues Shubert for Losses
description: Suit was begun yesterday by a stockholder in a Shubert theater organization company, charging 11 persons associated with the chain of improper acts from which they have personally profited.

title: NEW RADAR PLANE AIDS SIXTH FLEET
description: The Navy's tactical air forces have attained added capability with the marriage of the new E2C Hawkeye, the most advanced early warning aircraft now in operation, to the F14 Tomcat and F4 Phantom fighters.

title: Brigham Young Tops Poll
description: DENVER, June 11 ((UPI) Brigham Young University, which claimed conference crowns in outdoor track, golf and swimming as well as the northern division baseball title, was named the Western Athletic Conference allsports champion today in a poll conducted by United Press International.

title: 3 SEIZED IN ERITREA SAID TO FACE TRIAL
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 11 (UPI)The rebel Eritrean Liberation Front plans to try three of the five North Americans kidnapped 10 weeks ago on charges of exploiting the natural resources of the province in northern Ethiopia, diplomatic sources in Addis Ababa said today.

title: PAPER COMPANY SETS ACQUISITION
description: Directors of the International Paper Company approved yesterday a proposed $437million acquisition of the General Crude Oil Company, a Houstonbased independent producer of oil and gas. General Crude's board will vote on the proposal at a meeting in Houston today. The deal would then require approval of a majority of both the preferred and common stockholders. There are 8,816,102 common shares and 224,443 preferred shares outstanding.

title: Democrats Choose Candidates to Mahe Westchester Race
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 11Westchester County Democrats convened in high spirits tonight to designate county, state and Congressional candidates for what one of them described as victory in our year.

title: Cox Scores Ervin Pael On McCarthy Like Tactics
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 (AP)  Archibald Cox, the former special Watergate prose cutor, today compared some of the tactics of the Senate Watergate committee to those used by the late Senator Joseph McCarthy in the nineteen fifties.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following Spot primary prices for the week ended June 4.

title: Bridge: Challenging Problems Given In Book for the Connoisseur
description: On the great majority of deals, the play and defense problems are routine. A player of average experience or better can get satisfactory results by drawing on his experience. Relatively rarely he will meet a challenging problem, and unless he is an expert he will probably fail to solve it.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LIVINGSTON, June 11Sure, we'd like to play them for marbles, a trophy; anything.
