title: ANDRE MARIE, 76, A FRENCH PREMIER
description: PARIS, June 13  Andr Marie, a former French Premier and many times a Cabinet Minister, died yesterday at his home in Rouen, Normandy. He was 76 years old.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: OCEANPORT, June 13The likefatherlikeson adage is quite evident in New Jersey thoroughbred racing, courtesy of the Boulmetis family of Cherry Hill.

title: Books of The Times Syllogisms Debased by Agony
description: I came away from John Le Carre's new novel with the feeling that spyingwhich once was a practical matter of selfdefense and elementary precaution has gotten out of hand until it is now autonomous and paranoid. Instead of increasing national security, his spies appear to gamble with it in a contest of vanities. No compulsive neurotic ever evolved so many rituals as they do. Pomp and circumstance have degenerated into spiralings of subterfuge. The urge to engage in conspiracy seems as intense as certain forms of sexual perversion.

title: Buzhardt in Hospital With Pains in Chest; Condition Serious
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 J. Fred Buzhardt Jr., one of President Nixon's two key Watergate defense lawyers, suffered an apparent heart attack early today and was rushed to a hospital.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF; OTC ISSUES RISE
description: Prices fell yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but rose slightly in the overthecounter market.

title: LEFKOWITZ WINS RENTFUND CASE
description: Landlords were ordered by Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz yesterday to pay tenants accrued interest on security deposits held before Sept. 1, 1970.

title: Panel Reportedly Hears Nixon's Aides Tried to Use I.R.S. for His Political Benefit
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The House Judiciary Committee reportedly heard extensive evidence today of efforts by White House officials to use the Internal Revenue Service for President Nixon's political benefit.

title: Shea Verdict Causes Jamaica Violence
description: Bands of black youths injured two policement and several white civilians in random attacks and shattered the windows of a halfdozen cars in South Jamaica, Queens, last night in apparent anger at the acquittal of the policeman who shot and killed 10yearold Clifford Glover in the neighborhood last year.

title: Jeans: Casual At $10Or $500
description: There are blue jeans and there are blue jeans.

title: Western Union Is Revising PrivateLineService Rates
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) The Western Union Corporation announced today that it would tentatively put into effect tomorrow its revised rates for voicegrade, privateline services pending an investigation of their legality by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: City Accused of Lagging On West Side Road Job
description: Tempers and radiators were boiling yesterday over the West Side Highwayor the lack of it.

title: Prince Charles Speaks in Lords
description: LONDON, June 13Prince Charles, saying that he stood with some degree of fear and trembling, made his maiden speech from the floor of the House of Lords today, the first such speech by a member of the royal family in 90 years.

title: New Kidney Center Is Open in Brooklyn To Aid Transplants
description: The first regional, nonprofit kidney center in the country was dedicated yesterday in a twostory building at 184 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, a few yards from the Grand Army Plaza.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Prince Charles Speaks in Lords
description: LONDON, June 13Prince Charles, saying that he stood with some degree of fear and trembling, made his maiden speech from the floor of the House of Lords today, the first such speech by a member of the royal family in 90 years.

title: Kaneb Is Seeking Transcontinental Oil
description: Kaneb Services, Inc., executed yesterday a letter of intent proposing to acquire the Transcontinental Oil Corporation for stock valued at $20.7'million. Terms call for 1.15 million shares of Kaneb common stock to be exchanged for all the outstanding common and preferred shares of Transcontinental. A portion of the Kaneb shares would be reserved for the satisfaction of certain Transcontinental options and warrants. The proposed transaction is subject to a definitive agreement, approval of both boards and Transcontinental shareholders plus receipt of favorable tax rulings and other conditions.

title: New Auto Tax Barred
description: The Administration disclosed that it would not ask Congress to impose a weight or horsepower tax on autos or to write gasoline efficiency standards. Page 15.

title: Bankruptcy Changed
description: Judge John M. Cannella of the United States Court for the Southern District of New York ruled yesterday that the voluntary Chapter XI bankruptcy proceedings of Interstate Stores, Inc., be dismissed and replaced by an involuntary Chapter X proceeding. Details on Page 48.

title: Brazil and Yugoslavia Play Scoreless Tie
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 13Before 2,000 children on their knees, two helicopters roving overhead, 62,000 fans inside the stadium and camouflaged tanks outside, the former president of West Germany, Dr. Gustav Heinemann, opened the 10th World Cup soceer tournament today without an incident.

title: Public TV's Future
description: The 254 public broadcasting stations in the country have a chance to make a great leap forward if the Federal Government finally recognizes that they are not a threatening force but a national resource. This is the moment when the independent Corporation for Public Broadcasting, a major source of funding and also of immunization from local political pressure, can be assured of the longterm financial stability essential to intelligent programing.

title: Don Cherry Named Coach of Bruins
description: Don Cherry, who led the Rochester Americans to the best overall record in the American Hockey League last season was signed yesterday as the new coach of the Boston Bruins, Stanley Cup runnerup, in the National Hockey League. Cherry replaced Armand [Up] Guidolin, who resigned May 27 because the Bruins wouldn't give him a longterm contract.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: 71 Die in Philippines Storm
description: MANILA, June 13 (UPI)The sweep of a typhoon across the Philippines today killed 71 people, Red Cross officials said today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Warren H. Slough, a layman who helped a doctor perform an abortion and was convicted under a state law that has been ruled unconstitutional, was ordered released from prison yesterday. The 52yearold prisoner, who lived in a Camden suburb before going to prison five years ago, was convicted in 1967 in Camden County Court.

title: Portugal and the Guinea Nationalists Resume Negotiations for a CeaseFire
description: LISBON, June 13Foreign Minister Mario Soares flew to Algeria today to resume ceasefire talks with the African nationalists who have been waging war for 11 years in Portuguese Guinea.

title: Secret Deals Protect Established Teams in the N.H.L.
description: MONTREAL, June 13The National Hockey League completed its business for the season today, but, for all intents and purposes, the real business went on under the table, behind the back and out of earshot.

title: Zorila 1Up Winner in Golf Final
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 13Greg Zorila of Briar Hall was a tired but happy young man today after winning the Westchester County Golf Association's amateur championship for the third time.

title: WHOLESALE COSTS SURGED IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 The Wholesale Price Index continued to rise sharply in May despite the, third straight monthly decline in food prices and continued tapering off in price increases of fuels and power.

title: Dutch, Yielding to NATO Pressures, Renounce Troop Cuts
description: BRUSSELS, June 13  The Netherlands, under pressure from her North Atlantic allies and domestic political groups, promised today to make no immediate cuts in the size of her armed forces.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A young man threatening to jump from the roof of a 15story building at 55 West 42d Street at the height of the evening rush hour was pulled to safety by the police as thousands of spectators watched from the street.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Cambodian Leader's Seek Way Out of Cabinet Crisis
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 13 (AP)Cambodia's factiontorn Cabinet met for two hours with President Lon Nol today in what was described as an effort to find a new formula on how to work out a new government.

title: Red Smith
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 13On the 17th green Arnold Palmer ran down a 25foot putt for a birdie, and a blind man within earshot might have thought he was back in 1960 on the Cherry Hills course at Denver. It was there 14 years ago that Palmer started the last round seven strokes back and charged through the field to the United States Open golf championship, and that rabble called Arnie's Army came into being. The army has dwindled since those days, from thousand's to hundreds, but at 44 its leader still has that special personal quality that can move his idolators to rapture. Chances are there were no more than 500 spectators at the 17thincluding two girls wearing buttons that read, Miller's Killers, identifying them as followers of the defending championbut when the putt went down their cries could be heard clear across the Winged Foot Club's West Course. He did it and I didn't see it! wailed a member of the ladies' auxiliary on the fringe of the crowd.

title: ... Stopgap Solution
description: The agreement reached in Washington among the ten major financial powers to let those nations suffering balanceofpayments deficits use their official gold stocks as collateral for loans would do nothing to mitigate the inflationary effect of the Simon plan to permit American citizens to buy gold bullion.

title: NEW CANCER CASES LINKED TO CHEMICAL
description: A diagnosis of angiosarcoma of the liver, a rare and fatal cancer that has been linked to vinyl chloride exposure, has been confirmed in six of the eight cases reported to the Connecticut Tumor Registry, the Center for Disease Control reported yesterday.

title: Track Site In Suffolk Is On Way Out
description: YAPHANK, L.L, June 13The developer of the Suffolk Meadows quarterhorse racing complex disclosed today that he was on the verge of abandoning the $22million project.

title: SEARS IS PLANNING $40MILLION CENTER
description: FLANDERS, N.J., June 13A $40million semiautomated and computerized distribution warehouse on a 246acre plot in Mount Olive Township is being planned by Sears, Roebuck & Co.

title: Reports of Rape Rise 16%; Changing Attitude Is Cited
description: The number of rapes reported to the police in the city during the first four months of this year was 16 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year, indicating what was called an increased willingness of victims of sexual assaults to file complaints.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: MONETARY FUND AGREES ON REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 The 20 nations negotiating world monetary reform agreed today on an eightpoint package of interim arrangements to promote financial harmony in the world and help the less developed countries pending an eventual return to more stable currencyexchange rates.

title: City Fireman Who Cared Aids An Injured CoWorker in Death
description: A week ago today, three days after Fireman Harold J. Hoey Jr. was decorated by the Mayot for saving two lives, he cooked five turkeys in Ladder Company 17's South Bronx fire. house and took them to a din. ner he had organzied for the senior citizens' club at Mott Haven Community Center.

title: Goodman's Music Starts Fans Stompin' at the Park
description: Benny Goodman was supposed to appear with his sextet at the opening concert of the ninth annual Schaefer Music Festival at the Wollman Rink in Central Park on Wednesday evening. But the sextet gradually expanded as the program progressed until Mr. Goodman had a nineman band on stage. And as the band grew and the sound shifted from combo to something close to big band, the interchange of enthusiasm between audience and musicians became increasingly apparent.

title: WHOLESALE COSTS SURGED IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 The Wholesale Price Index continued to rise sharply in May despite the third straight monthly decline in food prices and continued tapering off in price increases of fuels and power.

title: NIXON SAYS SADAT WILL COME TO U.S. LATER THIS YEAR
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, June 13  President Nixon announced today that Premier Anwar elSadat had agreed to visit the United States later this year.

title: 2,100 Police Personnel at Frankfurt Soccer
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 13Spurred by the bombing of the Chilean consulate in West Berlin and by the, arrest of five Palestinian extremists, police in West. Germany drastically tightened security today for the World Cup soccer tournament.

title: Covering Nixon in Arab Lands Runs Up Costs for the Networks
description: Because television in the Arab countries is in the early stages of its development, the American networks have run up some unusual costs in covering President Nixon's visit to the Middle East, most of them related to relaying the television picture.

title: Seagrams, Ltd., Sets Record 75.6% Quarterly Gain
description: Distillers CorporationSeagrains, Ltd. reported yesterday record earnings and sales in the three and nine months ended April 30. The Canadianbased company, which is the world's largest distiller, does 86 per cent of its business in the United States.

title: Barr of Giants Beats Cubs, 10
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 (AP)Jim Barr scattered six Chicago hits and Gary Thomasson singled home the only run of the game in the seventh inning today to give the San Francisco Giants a 1.0 victory over the Cubs.

title: Merrill Lynch Acquisition To Put Firm in Insurance
description: Merrill Lynch & Co., parent of the nation's largest brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it planned to enter the insurance business through a merger. While many brokerages already sell insurance, Merrill would be the first Wall Street firm to own an insurance company.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 14, 1974

title: Palestinians Link Attack to the Visit by Nixon
description: JERUSALEM, June 13Four Arab guerrillas attacked a kibbutz in northern Israel today and murdered three women before being killed themselves in a gun fight with the men of the kibbutz.

title: PETER WARNER
description: Peter Warner, general manager of Houlders World Holiday, an international tour operator with headquarters in Britain died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Morocco, where he had been on a business trip. He was 54 years old and lived in Surbiton, Surrey.

title: Yankees Are Playing DialaDeal as Trading Deadline Approaches
description: You know the old Irving Berlin number, Gabe Paul was saying yesterday. And in his best musical voice, which can best be described as vintage Fred Flintstone, he crooned, all alone by the telephone.

title: Love Marks Higgins Photos of Blacks
description: When Chester Higgins Jr. took up photography in 1968, it was largely out of a feeling that the portrayal of blacks in the print and electronic journalism did not properly convey the range or diversity of black lifestyles.

title: Avoiding a Gold Rush...
description: Secretary of the Treasury Simon has said that he plans to recommend that President Nixon terminate by the end of this year the ban on the ownership of gold bullion by United States citizens. He predicts that the President will probably do so. Thus a ban that was imposed forty years ago, in a time of depression when the Government was trying to discourage hoarding, may be removed in a period of breakneck inflation. Mr. Simon suggested that removal of the goldownership restriction might have an antiinflationary effect.

title: Gould Lifting Price Of Batteries July 1; Rising Costs Cited
description: Gould, Inc., announced yesterday in Chicago that its automotive battery division planned to raise prices of automotive and heavy duty batteries by 8 to 10 per cent on July 1. The company said the increases were due to substantial increases in the cost of all major components used in. the batteries. The new prices will apply to batteries sold for both original equipment and replacement use for passenger cars, trucks buses and diesel trucks.

title: Textile Mills in a Scramble for Synthetics
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C. (UPI) Southern textile mills are involved in a mad scramble for synthetic fibers, which have been in increasingly short suply since last fall's shortage of petrochemicals, the basic building blocks for synthetics.

title: Miss Scanlon Net Victor
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 13Debbie Scanlon of Wantagh, L. I., a University of Southern California sophomomore, defeated Mimi Kanarek of Hastings, N. Y., the topseeded player, 63, 57, 62, to win the Long Island women's tennis championship today at the Great Neck Tennis Center. Miss Scanlon and Miss Kanarek won the doubles title, defeating Yoko Abematsu and Kit Knight of Locust Valley, L. L, 64, 63.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: Soviet Atom Aide Says U.S. Leads In Nuclear Plants
description: MOSCOW, June 13  A top Soviet atomic energy official reported today that development of atomic energy was proceeding more slowly in the Soviet Union than in the United States because the Russians enjoyed an abundance of other organic fuels.

title: The Indefatigable Senator Javits, Jumping lack of Nation's Capital
description: WASHINGTONIt is 12:20 on a Tuesday morning, and Senator Jacob K. Javits is in the Phoenix, Ariz., airport after a threeday Memorial Day weekend at John Gardiner's tennis ranch. It had been 113 in the shade, but the 70yearold senior Senator from New York played tennis three hours each day and found the key to his net game.

title: Wagner Heads Settlement Houses
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner was elected president yesterday of United Neighborhood Houses of New York, a federation of 35 settlement houses here. He will serve a oneyear term.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales last week were an estimated $1.063 billion, up 71 per cent from last year's $989million. Total retail store sales were about $10.547billion, up 6 per cent from last year's $9.966billion.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.6 billion tonmiles, 1.1 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago, Carloadings in the same period totaled 540,116 cars, 3.3 per cent below last year.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: Prospects for Weekend Fishing in Area Waters
description: Presently, there seems to be better than average angling for this time of year for mediumtolargesized striped bass from northern New Jersey to Cape Cod and the offshore islands.

title: ARNOLD GALAMBOS, INTERNIST, 90, DIES
description: Dr. Arnold Galambos, a specialist in internal medicine who had held staff appointments at the Hospital for Joint Diseases, Mount Sinai Hospital and Postgraduate Medical School and Hospital, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at 1199 Park Avenue.

title: KISSINGER BACKED BY 52 SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 A majority of the Senate today was backing a resolution that Secretary of State Kissinger's integrity and veracity are above reproach as the Foreign Relations Committee pressesd the Administration for documeats on his role in the wiretapping of 17 officials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971.

title: Royals Conquer Brewers, 5 to 4
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 13 (AP)John Mayberry hit a tworun homer in the first inning and Vada Pinson's home run triggered a threerun second inning tonight as the Kansas City Royals won, 54, from the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: An Explanation: The Allegations Nixon's I.R.S. Interference
description: WASHINGTON, June 13Those who seek, the impeachment of President Nixon have long believed that one of his greatest areas of vulnerability may be his alleged interference for both political and personal motivewith the operations of the Internal Revenue Service. They have two main reasons for thinking so.

title: Mrs. Meir Hospitalized
description: JERUSALEM, June 13 (Reuters)Israel's former premier, Golda Meir, 76 years old, has been hospitalized here for a series of tests, a hospital spokesman said today. The spokesman said Mrs. Meir entered the haematology departmeat of Hadassah Hospital and would be discharged tomorrow.

title: Expansion Rosters
description: KANSAS CITY

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
Gesell Puts Off Ruling on Ehrlichman Case for a Day
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 Federal Judge Gerhard A. Gesell delayed today for 24 hours the issuance of a formal order reinstating John D. Ehrlichman as one of four defendants in the plumbers case, pending a challenge by Mr. Ehrlichman to a crucial White House affidavit filed yesterday.

title: Pacemakers Cited in 2 Deaths
description: At least two patients have died from faulty heart pacemakers, and the manufacturer, General Electric Company is recalling the particular model.

title: Aborted Reform
description: After five years of study, the Temporary State Commission to Revise the Social Services Law came up last February with an admirable plan for basic reform the chaotic structure that now mixes income maintenance, Medicaid and social services in wasteful confusion.

title: A Stamp Plan for Travel Is Tested in West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 13Mrs, Julia Woodruff, a tiny, 74yearold woman who lives alone in a rural West Virginia hill town, turned over. $5 to state officials today and was given a book of stamps worth $8 to, buy tickets for buses, taxis, trains or planes.

title: The Indefatigable Senator Javits, Jumping Jack of Nation's Capital
description: WASHINGTONIt is 12:20 on a Tuesday morning, and Senator Jacob K. Javits is in the Phoenix, Ariz., airport after a threeday Memorial Day weekend at John Gardiner's tennis. ranch. It had been 113 in the shade, but the 70yearold senior Senator from New York played tennis three hours each day and found the key to his net game.

title: Argentina Loan Arranged
description: An international banking group has arranged a $100million eurodollar loan to Argentina. The money is to be used in the country's development program. The loan will be for eight years at a floating rate. Members in the group include Bankers Trust Company, EuropeanAmerican Bank and Trust Company, and Socit Generale de. Banque, S.A., of Brussels.

title: Philip F. MacGuire, 55, Dies; Stockbroker and Sportsman
description: Philip F. MacGuire, a stockbroker and sportsman, died yesterday of cancer at his home on Cedarhurst Avenue, Lawrence, L. I. He was 55 years old.

title: Italian Premier's Resignation Rejected
description: ROME, JUNE 13President Giovanni Leone rejected late tonight, after three days of formal consultations, the resignation that Premier Mariano Rumor and his ministers tendered on Monday.

title: A School Program Designed To Help Pregnant Teenagers
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  In this age of the pill, Planned Parenthood clinics, liberated women and legalized abortionall of which exist even in Calvinist and Catholic Connecticutteenage schoolgirls continue to have babies.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Friday, June 14, 1974

title: Policeman Indicted In Killing of Student In Central Brooklyn
description: The indictment of a policeman in the killing of a college student last year was announced yesterday by District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn.

title: RESEARCH CENTER ENDOWED AT DUKE
description: DURHAM, N.C., June 13A biomedical research institute meant to be comparable to New York's Rockefeller University will be established at Duke University through a gift of a New York industrialist, it was announced here today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Negotiations between the National Football League Players Association and the league's Management Council apparently have broken off after yesterday's talks ended with some angry words. The Management Council called the breakoff, a walkout by the Players Association, but Bill Curry of the Houston Oilers, president of the players' group, denied that charge.

title: The Land of the Free
description: LISBONWhile planning the coup that overthrew Portugal's 48yearold dictatorship on April 25, the young army officers primarily responsible had no intention of letting the United States have the faintest inkling of what was afoot. They were convinced that if the Central Intelligence Agency knew a coup was even being talked of, the agency would promptly inform the D.G.S., Portugal's secret police, with which the C.I.A. had close and cordial ties.

title: Turcotte Gets a Triple at Belmont
description: Ron Turcotte made three visits to the winner's circle at Belmont Park yesterday. The most important triumph was the one that he scored on Milton Ritzenberg's Flightoletti, inasmuch as that 4yearold won the feature event on the card, returning $4.80 for $2 after beating Yule Log by a nose in the sixfurlong sprint.

title: IMPOUNDED FUNDS FOR ROADS FREED
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 The Nixon Administration, under legal and political pressure to release impounded funds, freed $500million today in transportation funds that had been impounded.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: DESALTING PROJECT ON COLORADO VOTED
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI)Legislation calling for construction of the world's largest desalting plant to help clean up the Colorado River before it flows into Mexico was cleared today for President Nixon's signature,

title: Oil Shale Rush Altering a Colorado Town
description: RIFLE, Colo.  The City Manager, Stanleigh J. Megargee, was on the phone. Sure, well, yes I know, he sputtered, trying to make it a twoway conversation. Yes, I see, well what you need is one of those little office safes. Look in the Sears catalog or check Ward's Right. Fine. Okay now. Bye. He turned to a visitor.

title: Alexandria: A Delight for the Visitor
description: As travelers and writers ranging from Lawrence Durrell to E. M. Forster and the obscure Islamic Alexandriaphile, Ibn Dukmak, have noted for centuries, Egypt's ancient Mediterranean port offers a visitor special rewards and fascinations.

title: Bauxite Venture in Brazil Begun by Consortium of 8
description: LONDON, June 13 (AP)Alcan Aluminium Ltd., said today work would start immediately on developing a major bauxite mining operation at the Trombetas reserves in the Amazon River Basin of Brazil.

title: New Tax Law Eases RentRise Threats
description: ALBANY, June 13Tenants in 28 housing  redevelopment company projects, including and Stuyvesant Town and Riverton houses, will be spared substantial increases in their rents under, the terms of a bill signed into law by Governor Wilson today.

title: JOHN T. M'ALLISTER, NEWSWEEK OFFICIAL
description: John T. McAllister, publicaffairs manager for Newsweek magazine, died yesterday at New York Hospital of complications following a heart attack some days ago. He was 64 years old and lived at 71 Charles Street.

title: The Pop Life
description: The subject this week is ducks. An unlikely topic for a column on rock, you might think. Yet all of a sudden we seem to have been deluged by duck bands, live or on records. Two of them are very good and two others, very good indeed.

title: Byrne Tax Proposal Appears in Trouble; G.O.P. Is Opposed
description: TRENTON, June 13Governor Byrne's taxreform program was reported in deep trouble this evening only hours after he had formally presented it to a skeptical and unresponsive joint session of the Legislature.

title: Court's Data Indicate Knowland Owed $900,000 at His Death
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 13 (UPI)William F. Knowland, the former Senate majority leader and publisher of The Oakland Tribune, was financially insolvent at the time of his death and owed more than $900,000 in personal bank loans, court documents showed today. Mr. Knowland died from a selfinflicted gunshot wound last Feb. 23,

title: Winged Foot 1, Nicklaus 0... but It's Far From Over
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 13On the green of the 446yard first hole at the West Course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today, Jack Nicklaus was confronted with a 25foot birdie putt, but his ball slid past the cup and down a slope. He was now 28 feet away on his par putt. And he missed it.

title: Japan's Payments Balance Rose to $990Million in May
description: TOKYO, June 14 (Reuters)Japan's balance  of  payments deficit rose to preliminary $990million in May from $760million in April, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: Antar Takes Open Jump At Ox Ridge
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 13Not many horses achieve instant stardom in the showjumping world.

title: Magruder Comments On Edited Transcripts
description: Jeb Stuart Magruder says the Watergate transcripts indicate to him that President Nixon and his top aides were ill informed or were trying to put something on the tape for their own uses:

title: First National Bank of Maryland To Write Off Loss From London
description: The First National Bank of Maryland, an $864milliondeposit bank that ranked 101st in size in the country at yearend, announced yesterday that it would write off a $2.24million loss from a London merchantbank affiliate in the second quarter.

title: WIRETAP INQUIRY IS SAID NOT TO AIM AT KISSINGER ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, June 13Highly reliable sources said today that Secretary of State Kissinger was not a target of the special Watergate prosecutor's investigation of the Nixon Administration's wiretapping operations.

title: Nastase Out As Solomon Pulls Upset
description: PARIS June 13Ilie Nastase of Rumania, the favorite, was harried and harassed for 3 hours 10 minutes on center court and incredibly beaten by Harold Solomon in the French open tennis tournament today.

title: Volkswagen Is Paying Some Workers to Quit
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, June 13 (Reuters)Volkswagen is trying to pay some of its workers to quit. The giant West Germany auto company said today that it was offering lumpsum payments of up to $3,600 to workers quitting their jobs this month.

title: The Dance
description: Carolyn Brown was once, if she will excuse the phrase, the prima ballerina assoluta of the modern dance. For some years she was Merce Cunningham's leading woman dancer, and it is curious how, although she was a modern dancer, the clarity of her line and the Iimpidity of her movement often suggested the classic ballet.

title: The Art and Style Of Resigning
description: The art of resigning from political officewhether to slip or sneak away or go out with a banghas declined rather seriously in this country in recent years. The people who should resign won't, and the people who shouldn't, threaten to do so.

title: Posters in Peking Cite Shortcomings Of City's Leaders
description: PEKING, June 13 (Reuters) The Peking city leadership came under attack today in series or handwritten posters pasted on walls opposite the white fourstory municipal headquarters.

title: Holdup Man Holds Child, 3, as Shield To Disarm Officer
description: An armed robber shot and wounded a police officer and disarmed another officer by using a 3yearold girl as a shield during a holdup yesterday in a discount store in Glen Oaks, Queens.

title: Muslim Gives Version of Siege in Williamsburg
description: A holdup man who had been besieged with three alleged accomplices for three days in a Brooklyn sporting goods store gave his version yesterday of the 1973 police siege in which a police officer was killed, two others and a gunman were wounded and a dozen persons held hostage.

title: Harrelson's Injury Adds Gloom to Mets' Rainout
description: ATLANTA, June 13Bud Harrelson, the Mets' flashy shortstop, returned to New York early this afternoon with his right hand in a ??ast to provide additional gloom in the ranks of a club that has been finding it difficult to win.

title: Calley's Freedom On Bail Is Ended By Appeals Court
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 13 (AP)A Federal appeals court today ordered an end to former First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.'s freedom on bail while his conviction for the My Lai slayings is argued in civilian courts.

title: Bond Prices Are Off in Dull Trading
description: Prices declined in quiet trading yesterday in the corporate, taxexempt and Government bond markets as participants gave only lukewarm receptions to two new utility offerings in the corporate sector. On a day that saw prices slip oneeighth to a full point in the secondary market of recently issued corporate obligations, yesterday's two newcomers on the utility list were said to be only about onethird sold.

title: Venezuelan Quake Kills 3
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 13 (UPI)Dozens of houses and part of a village hospital collapsed in an earthquake that left at least three persons dead and several injured in the eastern provinces of Venezuela, official sources said.

title: Crockett GreatGrandson
description: DALLAS, June 13 (AP)David W. Crockett, greatgrandson of one of the heroes of the Alamo, died Monday at the age of 74. His greatgrandfather, Davy Crockett, came to Texas from Tennessee and died in 1836.

title: Mayor Promotes Walk and Talk By Going Just That
description: Mayor Beame forged his way through thick crowds in the Flushing and Jackson Heights sections of Queens last night accompanied by dozens of children, politicians add merchants, paving the way for a reunion between Godfrey Cambridge, the comedian, and Mr. Cambridge's English teacher at Flushing High School.

title: Market Place: How J. B. Fuqua Built a Gable
description: This is a saga of J. B. Fuqua, who gained fame in the conglomerate era as architect and builder of the fastmoving Fuqua Industries.

title: Two Siberian Tiger Cubs Are Born in Jungle Habitat
description: WEST MILFORD, June 13The birth of two Siberian tigers was reported here today at Warner Bros. Jungle Habitat, where one was born May 28.

title: Pepsico to Be Importer Of Russian Champagne
description: Pepsico, Inc., has signed an agreement to be the sole United States importer of a Russian champagne called Nazdorovya, the company announced yesterday.

title: JULIUS EVOLA
description: ROME, June 13 (UPI) Julius Evola, considered the top ideologist of Italy's extreme right, died at his home Tuesday. He was 76 years old.

title: A New Zoning Law
description: New York has learned a great deal about itself since the new zoning law was passed in 1961so much so that a new new zoning ordinance is under consideration now.

title: Market Is Mixed at Close As Selling Tempers Gains
description: The stock market finished narrowly mixed yesterday in lethargic trading as some late selling erased many earlier gains.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS SELECT SAMUELS FOR TOP OF SLATE
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., June 13Howard J. Samuels easily won the Democratic State Committee designation for Governor tonight, but Representative Hugh L. Carey won enough support to force a fight in the September 10 primary.

title: Cup Soccer Telecast at Garden Draws 9,541 Bipartisan Fans
description: The lure of World Cup soccer drew a highspirited and diverse crowd of 9,41 to Madison Square Garden yesterday to watch a scoreless tie between Brazil and Yugoslavia on closedcircuit television from Frankfurt, West Germany.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: REX REED IN THE SOHO WKLY NEWS. At Your Newssland. Ask For Il.Advt.

title: Syria Likens Israeli Treatment Captives to Nazi War Crimes
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 13 The Government held a news conference today to charge that Israel, in the treatment of Syrian prisoners, had committed war crimes that do not differ in their brutality from the Nazi crimes during World War II.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Company was awarded a letter of intent to supply a 1.2millionkilowatt nuclear steam system and associated nuclear fuel to the Power Authority of the State of New York. The contract, valued at about $100million, is for a nuclear power plant to be built at one of two siteseither Athens or Cementonin Greene County, south of Albany. The plant is scheduled for completion in 1982.

title: WILLIAM HYMAN, 41, HARPSICHORD MAKER
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., June 13 (AP)William Hyman, a maker of harpsichords, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 41 years old.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS SELECT SAMUELS FOR TOP OF SLATE
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., June 13Howard J. Samuels easily won the Democratic State Committee designation for Governor, tonight, but Representative Hugh L. Carey won enough support to force a fight in the September 10 primary.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.9 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price, index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 218.9 from 219.8 last week.

title: Beaming Panov Quickly Obtains Visas for Israel and Austria
description: MOSCOW, June 13Valery Panov, the former Kirov Ballet star, obtained Israeli visas today but voiced fears that a lastminute hitch involving his motherinlaw could delay his plans to leave for Vienna Friday with his wife, the dancer Galina Ragozina.

title: Advertising: Visual Radio Urged
description: Radio is the most visual advertising medium  that was the surprising contention of Robert C. Pritikin, a San Francisco adman who yesterday urged a crowd of copractitioners to enlist the radio listenner as coauthor since he must paint in the details of commercials.

title: Bill Benefiting Westmoreland Is Blocked by Proxmire
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 Senator John G. Tower almost succeeded today in getting the Senate to consider legislation that would have permitted Gen. William G. Westmoreland to retain his military retirement pay if elected Governor of South Carolina.

title: Nastase Out As Solomon Pulls Upset
description: PARIS June 13Ilie Nastase of Rumania, the favorite, was harried and harassed for 3 hours 10 minutes on center court and incredibly beaten by Harold Solomon in the French open tennis tournament today.

title: Infant is Killed in Fire In Jefferson Township
description: JEFFERSON TOWNSHIP, June 13 (UPI)  A 1yearold child burned to death and a fireman was injured today in a fire that destroyed a onestory home here, the police reported. The infant, Steven Lucas, perished in the back bedroom of his family's home at 4 Sun Valley Park in the Morris County community despite repeated rescue attemps by the child's father, firemen and the police.

title: No Voice of Dissent To Mar Nixon Visit
description: CAIRO, June 13By the time he leaves Egypt tomorrow afternoon President Nixon will have been seen and cheered by several million Egyptians.

title: Bridge:3 Women Have Key Roles In Greater New York Unit
description: Complaints about lack of executive opportunities for women certainly cannot be leveled at the Greater New York Bridge Association, which guides the tournament destinies of some 7,000 players in the metropolitan area. The current administration has no fewer than three women in key roles: Estee Griffin as president, Gail Moss as administrative vicepresident and Betty Pearly as secretary.

title: The Italian Slide
description: ROME, June 13What would happen if Italy really went bankrupt? the Budget Minister in the outgoing Government, Antonio Giolitti, was asked earlier this week. Mr. Giolitti, a Socialist, replied that the nation would lack the money to buy the oil it needs, the raw materials for its industry and even the food that it has been importing in rising quantities.

title: Screen:soviet 'Golden Calf' Offers Some Smiles
description: Deception had better ??? charmingat least, in the movies. When you want ??? quick breather from the b??? er questions of political ???eit, pictures like "The Stin??? ???r "The Golden Calf" (from Russia) can be refreshing. In ???ese scenarios, the victims ???ave committed larger crimes ???an those who prey on them, ???nd the con men are harm???ess clowns. Meanwhile, Mik???ail Shveitser, who made ???'The Golden Calf," seems to ???avor the fantasy of charming crooks almost as much ???s we do. title: Not Deadly, but Wrong
description: In pledging to introduce legislation to prohibit corporal punishment in the state's public schools, Senator John J. Marchi is courageously facing an issue that has persistently defied all efforts at reform. Legislators, and many conservative professional educators and parents, have perpetuated the myth that rod, paddle or strap are fundamental to maintenance of school discipline.

title: TV: The Palestinians Documents Timely Subject
description: In another documentary drenched with timeliness, television tomorrow night at 10 will take an unusual indepth look at The Palestinians, the people many consider the key to peace in the Middle East. The CBS News portrait, in the style of an established CBS series that has examined the Japanese, Vtalians and the Israelis, is produced, directed and written in masterly fashion by Howard Stringer. The reporter is Bill McLaughlin.

title: NEWAUTO SALES OFF 24% JUNE 110
description: DETROIT, June 13  Newcar sales of United States automobiles were down 24.2 per cent in early June.

title: World Bank Backs Loans Of $81Million to 3 Nations
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) The World Bank and its affiliate, the International Development Association, approved today $81.1million for development loans to Chad, the Philippines and Tunisia.

title: About New York
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 13The Queens leader was standing around today, saying that he had not polled his delegation, that Howard J. Samuels was having gastrointestinal difficulties, and that it was, of course, an open convention. The Queens leader, Matthew J. Troy, Jr. was not necessarily telling the truth, but then it hardly mattered. Everyone was satisfied, anyway.

title: Saudi Arabia Seeking Bigger World Role
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 12Saudi Arabia, the oil colossus of the Middle East, which President Nixon will visit Friday, is ready to play a world role in energy and finance and is eager for United States help in building a modern industrial economy.

title: NEW BOARD VOTES TO OUST MEMBER
description: The recently elected board of Community School District 1 voted last night to remove a member of the board's minority faction on the grounds that she war not eligible for the position.

title: People and Business
description: C. Arnholt Smith, a friend of President Nixon and formerly a major financial figure in southern California, was senterihd yesterday to an indefinite term in jail on seven counts of contempt of court.

title: VERMONT UTILITY DEFERS DIVIDENDS
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., June 13 (AP)After hearing the company's president describe its financial position as precarious, directors of the Green Mountain Power Corporation voted today to postpone action on a secondquarter dividend on the common stock. The directors of Vermont's second largest electric utility did declare the regular dividends on preferred stock.

title: Date on Shipment of Rothkos A Mistake, Says Gallery Head
description: Mark Rothko paintings sent by Marlborough Gallery from New York by ship leaving June 30, 1972, and by air July 1, 1972, somehow arrived at a Zurich airport June 29, 1972, according to documents introduced into evidence in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: YET WAVES The United States flag is 197 years old today, having been adopted by Congress in 1777. In observance, Gimbels department store, at Broadway and 33d Street, has invited the All City Concert Choir in for an hour of choral flagwaving.

title: About New York Politicking at the Falls
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 13The Queens leader was standing around today, saying that he had not polled his delegation, that Howard J. Samuels was having gastrointestinal difficulties, and that it was, of course, an open convention. The Queens leader, Matthew J. Troy, Jr. was not necessarily telling the truth, but then it hardly mattered. Everyone was satisfied, anyway.

title: Retail Sails on Rise
description: CHICAGO (UPI)  The Illinois Retail Merchants Association says retail sales in Illinois this year could top those of 1973 by 10 to 15 per cent depending on the impact of fuel and product shortages.

title: BUSINESS LOANS ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Business loans at New York and Chicago banks increased sharply during the week ended Wednesday, and some key shortterm interest rates rose. The developments at least partly deflated the hope that the worst was already over for the credit markets.

title: Sawhill Bars an Auto Tax. And Gas Efficiency Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 The Administration disclosed today that it had decided not to ask Congress to impose a weight or horsepower tax on automobiles or to write gasoline efficiency standards into law.

title: SILVER FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Silver futures prices on the Commodity Exchange declined yesterday by the daily permissible limit of 20 cents an ounce. The decline was attributed to a selloff by speculators.

title: Beame Group's Proposal to Raze Tweed Courthouse Is Expected to Evoke Dissent
description: A special task force appointed by Mayor Beame to improve the Civic Center area has prepared a preliminary report urging that the 102year old Tweed Courthouse on Chambers Street, behind City Hall, be demolished and replaced with a City Hall annex.

title: Impeachment Battle on 4 Fronts
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The President's lawyers laid down barrage of motions, affidavits, letters and memorandums this week in four forumsthe Supreme Court, the House Judiciary Committee and two courtrooms of United States District Court. Some of the moves seemed contradictory; the total effect seemed scattershot and tangled.

title: Pamela Caliber, 24, Assistant To City U. Vice Chancellor, Dies
description: Pamela Galiber, the older daughter of State Senator Joseph L. Galiber of the Bronx, died suddenly yesterday apparently of a ruptured blood vessel. She was 24 years old.

title: New P.B.A. Officers Seek To Stop Pay for Incumbents
description: The newly elected officers of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association obtained a showcause order yesterday, A spokesman said, directing the association to show cause why it should not be enjoined from paying outgoing officers and board members a year's salary or expenses.

title: Security Officials Employing Softer Approach at Open
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 13The bouncer guarding the world's best golfers at the United States Open is a 118pounder who wears loop earrings and Shalimar perfume.

title: LEGISLATIVE PLAN ON SCHOOLS GIVEN
description: TRENTON, June 13  In an effort to erase the disparities in the quality of education in New Jersey's school districts, the Joint Education Committee of the Legislature proposed today to limit the expenditures for each pupil in affluent districts while encouraging poor districts to increase their spending.

title: City Accused of Lagging On West Side Road Job
description: Tempers and radiators were boiling yesterday over the West Side Highwayor the lack of it.

title: BRITISH ECONOMY HELD IMPERILED
description: LONDON June 13As Britain repotted another record trade deficit for May the Bank of England warned today that the British economy was in great difficulty.

title: MONETARY FUND AGREES ON REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 The 20 nations negotiating world monetary reform agreed today on an eightpoint package of interim arrangements to promote financial harmony in the world and help the less developed countries pending an eventual return to more stable currencyexchange rates.

title: Palestinians' Mirage, and Egyptians' Reality
description: LONDON The Palestine National Council has met in Cairo and adopted another of those resolutions that take the place of politics in the Middle East. On the one hand there will be no Palestinian delegation to the Geneva peace conference, but on the other hand there might be, if suitably invited. Again, a Palestinian state on the West Bank or in Gaza is to be sought, but no such state would satisfy aspirations.

title: Sanderson in New York: A Ranger in Name and Style
description: His blue eyes, as usual, were laughing.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Ponge, Poet, to Get The Neustadt Prize
description: The third Books Abroad/ Neustadt International Prize for literature will be presented to Francis Ponge, the French poet, at the University of Oklahoma's Norman campus tonight. Mr. Ponge, who is 75 years old, will receive $10,000, a scroll and a silver eagle feather, the symbol for the award. The scroll will be presented by Paul F. Sharp, president of the university, and a membet of the Walter Neustadt family will present the feather.

title: Bazhardt in Hospital With Pains in Chest; Condition Serious
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 J. Fred Buzhardt Jr., one of President Nixon's two key Watergate defense lawyers, suffered an apparent heart attack early today and was rushed to a hospital.

title: Bertha Carp, 88, an Officer Of U.S. Consulate in Istanbul
description: Bertha Carp, who never quite retired from the American Consulate General in Istanbul, which she joined when it was the American Embassy early in World War I, died, in Istanbul Wednesday. She was 88 years old.

title: U.S. Planes to Take Grain To DroughtStricken Mali
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)  United States Air Force planes, will start a 90day relief operation to Mali in West Africa on June 15, the Pentagon said today.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
New Auto Tax Barred
description: The Administration disclosed that it would not ask Congress to impose a weight or horsepower tax on autos or to write gasoline efficiency standards. Page 15.

title: WIRETAP INQUIRY IS SAID NOT TO AIM AT KISSINGER ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, June 13Highly reliable sources said today that Secretary of State Kissinger was not a target of the special Watergate prosecutor's investigation of the Nixon Administration's wiretapping operations.

title: A Bronx Boy, 13, Drowns While Swimming in Zoo
description: A 13yearold boy drowned yesterday while swimming with three playmates in the Bronx River near a waterfall in the Bronx Zoo, the police reported.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Jury Studying MinorityAid Spending
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 The Watergate grand jury is investigating charges that Nixon Administration officials illegally used funds earmarked for minority programs to attract for the President the election support of blacks and Spanish. sources Americans in 1972, sources close to the investigation reported today.

title: ALASKA PIPELINE LETS. CONTRACTS
description: The Alyeska Pipeline Service Company announced yesterday the awarding of between $500million and $600million of contracts for construction of the $4billion TransAlaska pipeline. The awards for the six segments of the line went to five contracting groups. They are:

title: Music: Young Fans for a Boulez Rug
description: The New York Philharmonic's Rug Concert on Wednesday night seemed almost too good to be true, but these are the facts: Webern's Concerto (Op. 24), Varese's Octandre and Ligeti's Aventures and Nouvelles Aventures were performed, one after the other, in the second half of the program, and at the end the audience stood up to cheer. A big Philharmonic audience at Avery Fisher Hall!

title: OPTIMISM VOICED AT G.O.P. DINNERS
description: State Republicans gatheredt more than 5,000strong and $800,000generous last night toy hear exhortations from Governor Wilson and other state candidates that they abandon any electionyear pessimism.

title: Assembly to Debate Antiabortion Bill
description: TRENTON, June 13The Assembly Conference Committee agreed today to bring a highly controversial abortion bill, supported vigorously by antiabortion groups, to a vote on the assembly floor during the current special legislative session.

title: Zorila 1Up Winner in Golf Final
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 13Greg Zorila of Briar Hall was a tired but happy young man today after winning the Westchester County Golf Association's amateur championship for the third time.

title: Beame Group's Proposal to Raze Tweed Courthouse Expected to Evoke Objections
description: A special task force appointed by Mayor Beame to improve the Civic Center area has prepared a preliminary report urging that the 102year old Tweed Courthouse on Chambers Street, behind City Hall, be demolished and replaced with a City Hall annex.

title: Boy Edges Out Girl for U.S. Marbles Crown
description: WILDWOOD, June 13A boy and a girl squared off for the national marbles championship here today, and, as had been expected, the boy wonbut just barely.

title: Good Food, With None of the Expensive Flimflam
description: La Rotisserie, a new place at 153 East 52d Street, goes in for good French fare at moderate prices and no attention to expensive flimflam.

title: Player Cards Lone Par in Open Leads by Stroke
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 13Sometimes a man whose ox is gored may holler louder than the ox itself.

title: Sholom Seconda Is Dead; Composer, Song Writer
description: Sholom Secunda, who achieved fame as an 8yearold cantor and went on to write some 60 operettas and more than 1,000 songs, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived at 590 Fort Washington Avenue.

title: Explosion Damages Gulf Headquarters After Phone Threat
description: PITTSBURGH, June 13 (AP) An explosion rocked the upper floors of the Gulf Oil Corporation's international, headquarters tonight, moments after a telephone caller claiming to be from the radical Weather Underground warned that a bomb had been placed in the building.

title: JAMES A, CLARK
description: James A. Clark, who retired in 1959 as vice president of the Creole Petroleum Company and as a producing executive of its parent, the Exxon Corporation, died, apparently of a heart at tack, at his home in Clayton, Mo., Wednesday. He was 80 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If Vietnam has taught us anything, it should be to be aware of danger before we walk heedlessly into it. It is easier to avoid a catastrophe by forethought than to extricate oneself from a disaster after it has occurred.

title: Focus on Baseball: The Dodgers Dodging Away From the Field
description: Two things will reach the New York sports scene this weekendthe baseball trading deadline and the Los An geles Dodgersand the Mets won't be overly thrilled to see either.

title: PERON WILL KEEP CABINET INTACT
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 13President Juan Domingo Pern today rejected the resignations offered by his Cabinet ministers last night in the wake of a growing economic crisis.

title: Florida's Press Law Raises Fundamental Questions
description: MIAMI, Fla., June 13  On Sept. 28, 1972, Pat L. Tornillo Jr., union leader and political candidate, walked into the office of The Miami Herald with a complaint against the newspaper.

title: Survey Finds a Majority Now Want Nixon Removed
description: The latest Harris survey, conducted nationwide among a crosssection of 1,413 adults, showed for the first time that a majority of the American people favored the impeach ment of President Nixon and his removal from office.

title: A Stamp Plan for Travel Is Tested in West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 13Mrs. Julia Woodruff, a tiny, 74yearold woman who lives alone in a rural West Virginia hill town, turned over $5 to state officials today and was given a book of stamps worth $8 to buy tickets for buses, taxis, trains or planes.

title: Prospects for Weekend Fishing in Area Waters
description: Presently, there seems to be better than average angling for this time of year for mediumtolargesized striped bass from northern New Jersey to Cape Cod and the offshore islands.

title: Franklin Bank Loss In Deposits Climbs To About 24% Total
description: The outflow of deposits from the Franklin National Bank increased somewhat during the week ended Wednesday. As a result, the bank has now lost nearly 24 per cent of its deposits since its troubles first came to light on May 10.

title: Beame Keeps Hands Off On Samuels and Carey
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 13  Mayor Beame promised today to stay hands off in a primary election for the Democratic nomination for Governor. The Mayor publicly cited the need for party unity and privately told associates that neither of the candidates supported him last year, so why should he support them this year.

title: Zoo to Go to Children In a Hospital in Bronx
description: Miscellaneous small animals, reptiles and birds will be taken to the pediatrics ward of Fordham Hospital in the Bronx one day a month starting at 10 A.M. June 25.

title: Beirut Says Israeli Fire Damages 3 Villages
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 13Three Lebanese villages on the eastern slopes of Mount Hermon were struck by Israeli artillery fire today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Country Music Fans Have Fans, Too
description: NASHVILLE, June 13The bugs invaded Music City this weekmore than 12,000 of them, armed with cameras, pens and tape recorders.

title: SAWHILL TO EASE SOME FUEL CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, June 13John C. Sawhill, the Federal energy administrator, told Congress today that he planned to phase out controls on supply allocation and prices of some Nei, but keep gasoline and heating oil under regulations for some time.

title: Der Rosenhavalier With Best as Ochs Is Sung at the Met
description: The performance of Der Rosenkavalier offered Wednesday evening by the Metropolitan Opera had its intermittent charms, no doubt. But it was presented as part of the Met's June Festival, and it hardly measured up to the festive standards suggested by the word festival.

title: FRENCH AUSTERITY STIRS UP ANXIETY
description: PARIS, June 13The austerity program that the French Government proposed yesterday brought expressions of anxiety today from both unions and business circles but for different reasons.

title: Military in Yemen Ousts Government And Sets Up Junta
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 13The army in the Republic of Yemen has seized power in an apparently bloodless coup.

title: Feedlot Cattle Fattening Down, But Effect on Supply Is Unclear
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 Operators of cattle feedlots in seven leading states, who have suffered through a prolonged period of financial losses, curtailed their operations sharply last month, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

title: Liquifin Group Is Seeking to Replace Ronson's Board
description: NEWARK, June 13Shareholders of the Ronson Corporation, a major producer of cigarette lighters, were asked at the annual meeting here today to replace the ninemember board of directors with a new team.

title: A City Panel for Industry Is Pressed
description: An appeal for the creation of a New York City industrial development agency, which is authorized by a bill now awaiting action by Governor Wilson, has been made by the New York Urban Coalition as a major part of a new program to halt the decline in employment here.

title: GuineaBissau Head Named To African Unity Group Post
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, June 13 (Agence FrancePresse) Luis Cabral, leader of the selfproclaimed independent country of GuineaBissau, was elected a deputy chairman of the Organization for African Unity today.

title: INTERSTATE TOLD TO CHANGE PLAN
description: A United States District Court judge ruled yesterday that the voluntary Chapter XI bankruptcy proceedings of Interstate Stores, Inc., be dismissed and replaced by an involuntary Chapter X proceeding.

title: NIXON SAYS SADAT WILL COME TO U.S. LATER THIS YEAR
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, June 13  President Nixon announced today that President Anwar elSadat had agreed to visit the United States later this year.

title: Foreign Investment Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (Reuters)The Senate approved legislation today ordering a $3million study of both direct and portfolio investments in the United States by foreigners. The bill now goes to the Houser.

title: FIRE RIPS THE SITE OF E. SIDE BLAST
description: A persistent, smoky threealarm fire flared yesterday in the 25story commercial building on East 46th Street that was ripped by a gas explosion on April 22.

title: E. B. Stahlman Jr., 76, Dies; Aide of Nashville Paper
description: NASHVILLE, June 13 (AP)E. B. Stahlman Jr., former executive vice president and co publisher of The Nashville Banner, died last night at his home. He was 76 years old.

title: Iowa House Race Unsettled as Judge Backs Indians' Suit
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, June 14  United States District Judge Edward McManus ruled today that a group of Indians were denied their right to vote in the June 4 primary, a decision that leaves undecided who won the Third District Democratic nomination for United States Representative.

title: ATOM ENERGY ACT WITH ISRAEL SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, June 14President Nixon will probably follow up the nuclear energy agreement with Egypt with a similar accord with Israel when he arrives in that country on Sunday, key Congressional leaders said today.

title: Italy Seeking to Rebuild a Government
description: ROME, June  14 Premier Mariano Rumor started wearily today to put together again a Government that had fallen apart on Monday.

title: New Jersey Sports flaking Tracks
description: NEW MILFORD, June 14Bill Monaghan has decided that 14 years as track coach at New Milford High School is enough.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: Horses and Equipment 3995

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Pacemaker Users Affected by Recall Are Notified
description: About threequarters of the 94 patients affected by the General Electric Company's recall of a defective heart pacemaker have been notified about the possible need to change the unit, a spokesman for the company said yesterday.

title: U.S. AND PARTNERS APPEAR TO AGREE ON NEW NATO PACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 The United States and its North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies have virtually agreed on a formal declaration that will be issued next week during a NATO foreign ministers' meeting in Ottawa, marking the 25th anniversary of the alliance.

title: Soul and The Advocates Join Fall Casualties on Public TV
description: Behind the Lines, Soul, Washington Connection, The Advocates, Day at Night and The Special of the Week are among the casualties of the public television industry's first attempt at creating a national program schedule by vote of its 153 station licensees, who represent more than 250 stations.

title: 1973 Was Krupp's Best Postwar Year
description: ESSEN, West Germany, June 14The Krupp empire, risen from partial dismemberment after World War II, recorded its most successful postwar year in 1973.

title: Mrs Liebolt Married to Dr. John North
description: Mrs. Eugenia Davis Liebolt of Dallas, formerly of New York, was married here yesterday to Dr. John Paul North, a widower, also of Dallas. The noon ceremony in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. Frederick Hill.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The City of Trenton decided to withhold: the final $150,000 payment for construction of a downtown mall following the indictment of, the contractor on bidrigging charges. The company, Ralph Barone and Sons of Kenilworth, and a second concern, Michael LaMorgese and Son, Inc., of Newark, were charged Thursday with conspiracy, bidrigging and attempted fraud in connection with a neighborhood improvement project unrelated to the mall. Also charged by the special Mercer County grand jury were Joseph R. DeLuca of Mountainside, vice president the Barone Company, and Michael LaMorgese Jr. of Short Hills, president of the LaMorgese concern.

title: U.S. Will Rely on Controls On Military Nuclear Uses
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Officials said today that in extending nuclear assistance to Egypt the United States would rely on international controls as well as special American safeguards to insure that none of the nuclear materials are diverted into the production of atomic bombs.

title: Nixon and Sadat Sign Sweeping Accord on Cooperation
description: CAIRO, June 14President Nixon and President Anwar elSadat announced today that the United States had agreed to provide Egypt with nuclear technology for peaceful purposes.

title: Belmont Phase of Mets' Owner's Day Is Fruitful
description: Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson had a busy sports day yesterday. She attended the races at Belmont Park for the first time this season in the afternoon, and at night went over to Shea Stadium to see her Mets perform against the Dodgers. I hope I enjoy tonight, as much as I did this afternoon, Mrs. Payson said after the seventh race. Her enjoyment was based on the performance of Hatchet Man, who races in the silks of the Greentree Stable, owned by Mrs. Payson and her brother, John Hay Whitney.

title: Peking Pressing Drive
description: China's ideological campaign has moved into a new phase after orders from Peking barring local Communist party units from interfering with anyone who wants to put up a wall poster denouncing officials or policies he finds objectionable. As a result, some party officials are under poster attack for blocking revolutionary mass criticism. Page 3.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Katharine W. Frisch Bride of George Malin
description: At Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N. Y., yesterday afternoon Miss Katharine Ward Frisch, a student at American University, was married to George Bromley Malin, who attends George Washington University. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Brinton Webb Woodward, head chaplain at the Kent (Conn.) School, from which the couple graduated in 1971. Canon Wendell Phillips assisted.

title: FELIX GREENFIELD, A WARNER PUBLICIST
description: Felix Greenfield, a publicity man for 34 years with Warnez Bros., the motionpicture company, died of cancer Thursday in Lakeside Hospital, Capiague, N. Y. He was 57 years old and lived at 9707 63d Road, Rego Park, Queens.

title: Mrs. Liebolt Married to Dr. Paul North
description: Mrs. Eugenia Davis Liebolt of Dallas, formerly of New York, was married here yesterday to Dr. Paul North, a widower, also of Dallas. The noon ceremony in the chapel of St. James' Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. Frederick Hill.

title: 4 Regents Tests Canceled Alter Discovery of Thefts
description: The State Department of Education yesterday canceled four statewide high school Regents examinations scheduled for next week and postponed two others after it found that the answers had been stolen and were being sold in the metropolitan area.

title: Fireworks Ban Delay Asked
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Fireworks manufacturers in China and the United states urged the Government today to delay its proposed ban on firecrackers until after the Fourth of July.

title: Articles About Kissinger Spur Attacks on Leaks
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The leak, that system of transmitting information without seeming to do so, was denounced with unusual vehemence this week by the Nixon Administration.

title: Test for the Mayor
description: The Beame administration's commitment to achieve nondiscriminatory representation of minorities in the construction unions appears at this juncture to be highly equivocal.

title: Suspended U.S. Aide Is Indicted on Graft And Other Charges
description: NEWARK, June 14A suspended United States law officer was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of extortion and other illegal acts performed in his duties as a special agent of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The Winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: 28.9% of Dairy Coop Donations Returned Recently by Politicians
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)  Political candidates have returned nearly 30 per cent of the campaign contribuions given them by the three ciggest dairy cooperatives ??ince Watergate investigators began looking at milk money, according to campaign finance reports.

title: Reinecke Charge Disputed By Senate Panel's Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Watergate prosecutors filed in court today a sworn statement from the chief counsel of the Senate Judiciary Committee disputing Ed Reinecke's assertion that the committee was not a competent tribunal at the time he allegedly committed perjury before it.

title: Music Hall Disbanding Its Corps de Ballet
description: Radio City Music Hall is disbanding its 27member corps de ballet, which has been a part of its stage spectaculars for 42 years. The Hall's stage shows, featuring the Rockettes precision dancers and a symphony orchestra, will continue.

title: MORE FIRE DEVICES FOUND IN 4 STORES
description: Seven incendiary devices, six of them smoldering, were found in four major department stores in the busy 34th Street shopping area yesterday. Six of the devices were found between 1 and 2 P.M.

title: Peking Pressing Drive
description: China's ideological campaign has moved into a new phase after orders from Peking barring local Communist party units from interfering with anyone who wants to put up a wall poster denouncing officials or policies he finds objectionable. As a result, some party officials are under poster attack for blocking revolutionary mass criticism. Page 3.

title: Esposito Presence Is Felt, Even in Absence
description: NIAGARA FALLS, June 14  So Machiavellian is the reputation of Meade H. Esposito, the powerful Brooklyn Democratic leader, that even his momentary absence from the floor was able to upset the state Democratic designating convention here leading to the collapse of a deal to give an upstate Assemblyman the party's designation for Lieutenant Governor.

title: 150 CHILE CONCERNS ARE DENATIONALIZED
description: SANTIAGO, June 14 (Reuters) A spokesman for the ruling military junta in Chile said today that 50 private companies taken over by the leftwing Government of the late President Salvador Allende would be returned to private ownership.

title: Ballet: Divertimento
description: George Balanchine's Divertimento from Le Baiser de la Fe had Its first performance of the current New York City Ballet season at the New York State Theater on Thursday night. The leading male role was danced, for the first time by JeanPierre Bonnefous, partnering Patricia. McBride, who created the role when it was new two years ago.

title: Too Few Americans Found Immunized
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 Too few Americans are immunized against polio, diphtheria and other serious communicable diseases to protect the public from the risk of epidemics, a Government agency has reported to Congress.

title: VENEZUELA BARS CUT IN OIL PRICES
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 14 (UPI)Venezuela announced today opposition to any rollback of oil prices and said the Government would support increasing taxes levied against foreign oil companies.

title: ATOM ENERGY PACT WITH ISRAEL SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, June 14President Nixon will probably follow up the nuclear energy agreement with Egypt with a similar accord with Israel when he arrives in that country on Sunday, key Congressional leaders said today.

title: MRS. SIDNEY LEBOST
description: Mrs. Helen Kaye Lebost, who had been a teacher in the city school system for more than 30 years, died at Montefiore Hospital yesterday. She was 63 years old and lived at 3224 Grand Concourse.

title: MEDICAL AIDE HURT BY COBALT60 RAYS
description: PARSIPPANY, June 14 (AP) The chief of radiation operations for a concern that sterilizes medical equipment was in guarded condition in a hospital today after accidentally exposing himself to deadly cobalt60 rays.

title: TB Suspected in Hospital Aide; Tests Advised for 1,200 Babies
description: The parents of more than 1,200 bobies born in the last six months at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn have been advised to have the infants tested for tuberculosis, because a nurse's aide in the hospital's nursery has been found to have a possibly infectious case of the disease.

title: Albany Forecloses On Own Courthouse
description: ALBANY, June 14 (AP)Albany County foreclosed on the State Court of Appeals building and its own courthouse todayto the embarrassment of County Attorney Robert Roach.

title: U.S. UNIT CAUTIONS ON TV AND WIRING
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission issued some advice today on how a person could protect himself from faulty television sets and aluminum wiring in homes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: At this moment, mental health services for New York City stand in peril. The press, including your newspaper, reports almost daily problems related to mental health needs ranging from tragic stories of child abuse to the plight of over 30,000 mental hospital patients discharged from state hospitals and set adrift in New York City.

title: GLOUCESTER BURIED IN ROY AL CEREMONY
description: WINDSOR, England, June 14 (UPI)Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester, the last surviving grandson of Queen Vctoria and Queen Elizabeth II's beloved Uncle Harry, was buried today in the royal mausoleum at Frogmore wtih only the royal family present. The 74yearold Duke, an invalid for seven years, died Monday.

title: Lucine Amara Replaces Ill Star After Turandot 1st Act at Met
description: Soprand Lucine Amara stepped in to replace AnnaMoffo after the first act of Puccini's Turandot at the Metropolitan Opera last, night, when Miss Moffo said she could nit continue because of a case of bronchitis.

title: Suffolk Aide Bars Lifting Of Track Tax
description: YAPHANK, L.I. June 14Just a day before he disclosed that he was on the verge of abandoning the $22million Suffolk Meadows quarterhorse racing complex, Ronald Parr, the developer of the complex, had actively lobbied state and county officials for assistance.

title: Reynolds Reports Workers Rejected Union in Election
description: WINSTONSALEM. N. C., June 14 (AP)The R. J. Reynolds Company, the largest tobacco company in the United States and the only major one not unionized, announced today that its workers had voted almost 2 to 1 against the A.F.L.C.I.O. Tobacco Workers International Union.

title: People in Sports
description: John Shumate, the 6foot 9inch allAmerica center from Notre Dame, signed multiyear contract yesterday to play for the Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association. Shumate was the Sun's firstround draft choice.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. AND PARTNERS APPEAR TO AGREE ON NEW NATO PACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 The United States and its North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies have virtually agreed on a formal declaration that will be issued next week during a NATO foreign ministers' meeting in Ottawa, marking the 25th anniversary of the alliance.

title: Beame Moves Up Razing of East End Of Jamaica Ave. El
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday a revised plan for a quicker demolition of nearly one mile of the easternmost portion of the Jamaica Avenue elevated line to give Queens' largest business district a new lease on life.

title: House Panel Scores Amtrak As It Votes $125Million
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)  The House Appropriations Committee approved $125million for the federally backed Amtrak rail passenger system yesterday after sharply criticizing the agency for constantly running in the red.

title: Realism on World Money
description: I accept the universe, said the American transcendentalist Margaret Fuller, and Thomas Carlyle observed, By God, she'd better.

title: NIXON ESTABLISHES ENERGY COMMITTEE
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Establishment of a new Cabinetlevel Committee on Energy to advise the President on energy policy was announced today by the White House.

title: Police in the Dock
description: Until this year, no New York City police officer ?? ever been tried for murder while on duty. Now, a day after the acquittal of one officer on murder charges, a second has been indicted for an onduty killing. ?? swift succession has inevitably raised questions about whether members of the police force are exercising sufficient discretionin using guns to enforce the lawquestions made more intense by the fact that in both cases those killed were black and the officers white.

title: Dodgers Conquer Mets, 32
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers checked into New York with all those glittering statistics last night and promptly added to the glitter with a 32 victory over the bruised Mets.

title: Judge Orders Ehrlichman To Stand Trial on June 26
description: WASHINGTON, JUNE 14 Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell formally ruled today that the White House had fully satisfied its legal requirement to provide documents the plumbers case and set June 26 for the start of the trial of John D. Ehrlichman and three other defendants.

title: Maurice A. Gilmartin Jr., Securities Partner Here
description: Maurice A. Gilmartin Jr., senior partner in Chas. E. Quincey & Co. New York securities concern, died at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center on Thursday. He was 69 years old and lived at 575 Park Avenue.

title: AMEX PRICES FALL IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Prices fell again on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market in sight trading yesterday as investors searched in vain for bullish news.

title: Wilson May Get Conservative Support
description: J. Daniel Mahoney, state chairman of the Conservative party, predicted yesterday that the party would designate Governor Wilson for election to a full fouryear term, but he stressed that it was up to the State Committee to decide.

title: BREZHNEV SEEKING NEW ATEST CURBS
description: MOSCOW, June. 14Leonid I. Brezhnev declared today, that the Soviet Union was ready to reach an agreement with the United States on limiting Underground nuclear tests, leading to their complete cessation on an agreed timetable,

title: Palmer Cards 70 to Share Open Lead With Player, Irwin and Floyd at 143
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 14Well, hello, Arnie. It's so nice to have you back where you belong.

title: Industrial Production Up Again, With a 3 Per. Cent Gain by Autos
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Industrial production rose in May for the second straight month, following four months of decline, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: W. Germany Tops Chile, 10
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 14 Looking weak and not particularly proud, Helmut Shoen, the West German soccer coach, told the people of this nation tonight what they already knew.

title: Robert Bartly Smallwood, 80, ExChairman of Lipton, Dead
