description: Robert Bartly Smallwood, who retired as board chairman of Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., in 1960, died Wednesday of leukemia in Doctors Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 465 Park Avenue.

title: Firehouse Wedding Upset
description: TIFTON, Ga., June 14 (AP)Fireman Danny Parks decided to marry Barbara Lindsey, at the firehouse. Just as the ceremony ended yesterday, the alarm sounded.

title: Concorde Sets Record In BostonMiami Trip
description: BOSTON, June 14 (AP) Fresh from 2 hour 57 minute supersonic round trip to Miami, the Anglo French Concorde set down at Logan International Airport today for a weekend stay.

title: Funds for Ehrlichman Trial
description: DALLAS, June 14 (AP)Otis Davenport, a leader of the National Committee to Support the President, said today that $2,500 to $3,000 had been raised in Dallas for the defense of John D. Ehrlichman, a former Presidential aide.

title: Wilson Signs Bill Allowing Aid To Students at Private Colleges
description: ALBANY, June 14Governor Wilson signed into law today a bill that provides tuition assistance of up to $1,500 for most students, whether they attend public or private colleges in the state.

title: Stock Unit Closing
description: The Exchange Firms Information Corporation, a consumer reporting agency founded in 1961 to keep data on investors' creditworthiness, is expected to go out of business by the end of this month. Page 42.

title: Police in Drug Raid Kill Man Who Killed 3 Relatives in '66
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) A man once convicted of killing, three persons with a hammer was shot and killed by the police yesterday because, they said, they thought he was going to attack them with a hammer.

title: U.S. WILL PROVIDE EGYPT THE NUCLEAR TECHNOLOGY FOR PEACEFUL PURPOSES
description: U.S. WILL PROVIDE EGYPT THE NUCLEAR TECHNOLOGY FOR PEACEFUL PURPOSES

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Dave Anderson
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 14Near the eighth tee on the West Course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today, a chubby middleaged man in green and white plaid slacks nudged his buddy.

title: 2 Art Shows, 2 Contented Dumases
description: There was nothing wrong with life as it presented itself in the eighteenfifties to Alexandre Dumas pre. With The Three Musketeers and The Count of Monte Cristo well established as two of the most popular books of the century, and with his memoirs coming out just as fast as he could commit them to paper, he could afford to be what he naturally was: one of the most openhanded authors on record.

title: Cyclops Lifts Steel Prices 3%; Latrobe Raises Cost of Alloys
description: The UniversalCyclops Specialty Steel division of the Cyclops Corporation announced yesterday that it had raised prices by about 3 per cent on cold rolled stainless steel strip and sheet products, effective immediately.

title: Serpico Returns and Nominates Clark for Senate
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Saturday, June 15Frank Serpico returned from Switzerland yesterday and nominated Ramsey Clark for the Senate at the Democratic State Committee meeting early this morning.

title: 11 % Prime at Citibank
description: The First National City Bank said yesterday it was holding its prime lending rate unchanged at 11 per cent. The action had been widely expected despite the rise in business loans reported Thursday for the latest bank statement week by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Curbs on Water Pollution Are Set for Steel Makers
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency announced today it was requiring steel makers to reduce their water pollution by mid1977 and make further improvements by mid1983. The agency said it was setting series of detailed guidelines for 12 separate segments of the steel industry.

title: Gods of Golf Stumble to Mortality, and Gallery Loves It
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 14I love to see these guys take a beating, a weekend golfer named Nick Quinn said today at the United States Open. You can identify with them.

title: JOSEPH J. HAMMER
description: Joseph J. Hammer, who retired in 1971 after more than 40 years as a lawyer for the Mobil Oil Corporation, died Thursday in Calvary Hospital, the Bronx. He was 67 years old and lived here and in Canaan N. H.

title: SAVINGS BANKS GET OFFER ON CHECKS
description: The Chemical Bank disclosed here yesterday that it was willing to help savings banks break into the lucrative checking account business.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: CHARLES T. HILL
description: Charles T. Hill an investment banker with Schmidt, Roberts & Parke here and in Philadelphia, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Chesnut Hill, Pa. He was 68 years old.

title: Nixon's Economic Adviser Won't Testify
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) President Nixon's new chief economic adviser claimed executive privilege when asked by a Congressional committee to discuss the nation's economy, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: Israelis Quit Part of Zone Taken From Syria in '73
description: TEL SHAMS, Syria, June 14 Israel evacuated her forces today from approximately onethird of the salient captured from Syria during the war of last October.

title: 3 Premieres Given By Group in Which All Create Dances
description: Creamy movement with precise pauses for emphasis is the stuff from which the Greenhouse Dance Ensemble shapes its dances. Everyone in the company choreographs and on Thursday evening Beverly Brown with Anthony LaGiglia presented Morning Call, Robert Yohn showed Day in the Lee of April and Lillo Way offered Tryptych for the first time at the Theater of Riverside Church.

title: Arab Says Aid to Africa Exceeds Rise in Oil Cost
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, June 14An Arab League leader said here today that the combined total of the grants, loans and investments that Arab oilproducing countries were providing or planning to provide to poor African nations was far higher than the estimated annual increase they face in the cost of petroleum.

title: Paying for Justice
description: United States District Judge Arnold Bauman announced recently that he is going to resign the judgeship to which he was appointed only two years ago. Over in New Jersey, U.S. District Judge Frederick B. Lacey said that he intended to resign his judgeship by the end of the year unless Congress increased Federal judges' salaries.

title: Losses Listed by Associated Mortgage
TB Suspected in Hospital Aide; Tests Advised for 1,290 Babies
description: The parents of more than 1,200 babies born in the last six month at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn have been advised to have the infants tested for tuberculosis, because a nurse's aide in the hospital's nursery has been found to have a possibly infectious case of the disease.

title: Egan Denies Receiving Drug Bribes
description: A retired police lieutenant who commanded a special investigations unit of the department's narcotics bureau denied vigorously from the witness stand yesterday that he had ever taken money for not arresting suspected drug peddlers.

title: Striking Phone Employes Return to Jobs in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, June 14Some 3,300 striking electrical workers returned to their jobs today, ending a fiveweek labor dispute against Hawaiian, Telephone Company, a subsidiary of General Telephone and Electronics.

title: Feminists Here Split Over an Endorsement of Kuh
description: A group of feminists, asserting that Lenny Bruce was; a sexist dirtyjoke come; dian whose material was demeaning to women, have; endorsed Manhattan District; Attorney Richard H. Kuh, who won prominence prosecuting; the late M. Bruce on obscenity charges in 1964, for election to the post he was appointed to by Governor Wilson.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Transit System Uses Magnetic Propulsion
description: WASHINGTON, June 14A new means of highspeed transportation, invented at the General Motors Research Laboratories, Warren Mich., employs magnetic propulsion and levitation. The vehicle moves above a roadbed in which coils are embedded. John K. Dukowicz, Lyle O. Hoppie and T. C. Wang, research engineers at the laboratories, were awarded Patent 3,815,511 this week.

title: This Is Burlesque
description: Most people who have given up reading the news from Washington, which is to say most of the last sane people left in the country, are probably baffled by Henry Kissinger's sudden entry into the general farce down there. It is like seeing Othello wander into the second act of Hair, stripped down to blue jeans, and start climbing the scenery.

title: Greening of Winged Foot Is Defended
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 14Sometime around midnight last night, an automobile was driven across the first green of Winged Foot's West Course, possibly the most difficult putting surface in the 74th United States Open golf championship.

title: GOODRICH TO GET MAKER OF LATEX
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that it would acquire on July 1 a 40 per cent interest in Ciago Belgie, N. V., that is held by AKZO, N. V. Goodrich at present has a 60 per cent interest in the company. In making the disclosure at a meeting of financial analysts and investment managers, O. Pendleton Thomas, chairman, said that Ciago's annual sales exceed $40million. Ciago was formed in 1958 for the production of synthetic rubber and latex.

title: Formal U.S.Syria Tie Expected Soon
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 14Knowledgeable Syrian Government and American diplomatic sources said tonight that it was likely that Syria and the United States would resume formal diplomatic relations during or shortly after the visit of President Nixon to this country.

title: Fulbright Unit to Get Data On Kissinger Rote in Taps
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Federal District Judge John L. Smith gave. the Department of Justice permission today to give the Senate Foreign Relations Committee documents relating to Henry A. Kissinger's role in the wiretapping of Government officials and newsmen.

title: College World Series
description: AT OMAHA, NEB.

title: MRS. R. E. LESSER
description: Mrs. Diana Hansen Lesser, who had peen in public relations representative for the Muscular Dystrophy Association from 1969 until last February, died of cancer at St. Vincent's Hospital on Tuesday, She was 50 years old and lived at 200 West 14th Street.

title: Flag Day Ceremony Captures a Period of History
description: In June, 1782, Congress voted an expression of gratitude to an innkeeper named Samuel Fraunces for his assistance to American prisoners during the Revolutionary War. Yesterday, the Sons of the Revolution remembered that period of history as they celebrated Flag Day in front of the redbrick tavern, at Broad and Pearl Streets, which Samuel Fraunces opened and which continues to bear his name.

title: Music: Love Medleys
description: Given the variety of worthy projects that might suggest themselves to those who want to do something different in musical theater, it is difficult to understand why anyone would choose to make soap operas out of songs by Schumann and Wolf, but that, alas, is what the Masterworks Laboratory Theater adopted as its most recent project.

title: DEMOCRATS NAME CUOMO TO 2D SPOT
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 14Divided, confused and frustrated, the Democratic State Committee finally designated Mario M. Cuomo of Queens, as the party's official candidate for Lieutenant Governor today.

title: The Senator Is oddLine Jump Victor
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 14When The Senator returned from the Man and His World horse show in Montreal just a year ago, he was limping badly.

title: Agency That Kept Credit Data on Investors Is Closing
description: An investor ordered some stock sold one day four years ago, and five days later, as required by New York Stock Exchange regulations, he went to his broker to deliver his stock certificates. By then, the broker was required to have a check ready to pay for the stock.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE FIGURE FINAGLERS. By Robert Reichard. 274 pages. McGrawHill. $8.95. Not long ago, there were cries of outrage when Con Edison announced that rate increases would mean a certain amount more on the average electric user's bill because it was hard, if not impossible, to find anyone with that average bill, and many a consumer suspected that Con Edison was making it all up. Robert Reichard, in The Figure Finaglers, explains why: As useful as an average is, it can provide only a limited amount of information. Sooner or later we will want to know something about the spread around the average. For all those consumers whose increase was much larger than the average cited by Con Edison, it seemed clear that the average was not enough.

title: In a Cyprus Village, Amity and Antipathy
description: APHANIA, Cyprus  When the Greek Cypriotes of Aphania were boys, they used to go to the Turkish coffeehouse and watch the shadow plays. Now, when night comes, armed guards patrol the Turkish quarter. The boys do not go to the plays any more.

title: GEORGE FRAZIER, WRITER, 63, DIES
description: George Frazier, a prose stylist of wit, pungency and elegance whose work appeared in magazines and newspapers here and abroad over the last 40 years, died Thursday of lung cancer in Mount Auburn Hospital, Cambridge, Mass. He was 63 years old and lived at 52 East 81st Street. He also had homes in Boston and Nantucket.

title: BREZHNEV SEEKING NEW ATEST CURBS
description: MOSCOW, June 14Leonid I. Brezhnev declared today that the Soviet Union was ready to reach an agreement with the United States on limiting underground nuclear tests, leading to their complete cessation on an agreed timetable.

title: 4 Regents Tests Canceled After Discovery of Thefts
description: The State Department of Education yesterday canceled four statewide high school Regents examinations scheduled for next week and postponed two others after it found that the answers had been stolen and were, being sold in the metropolitan area.

title: Stocks Slump as Hopes For Interest Cuts Fade
description: The stock market made broad retreat yesterday in lackluster trading as hopes for an immediate reduction in interest rates continued to fade.

title: Reserve Mining Permitted To Continue Lake Dumping
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The Justice Department has decided to accept a Federal Appeals Court decision allowing the Reserve; Mining Company to continue dumping allegedly hazardous wastes into Lake Superior pending development of a cleanup plan.

title: Antiques: The Dollhouse
description: To collectors of dollhousescale antiques, whose numbers are estimated to have swollen to 300,000 In recent years, the scholarly questions that excite or trouble those who acquire the fullscale masterpieces of the great cabinetmakers, are of secondary importance or no concern at all.

title: Building Plan Stirs Orient Point Residents
description: ORIENT POINT, L. I.A hard wind was blowing and Louis Demarest shivered a bit as he walked through the weeds toward the eastern tip of Long Island's North Shore. He came to a point beyond which there were just the waves of a choppy Atlantic Ocean. He turned around, looked at the property he had just walked through, and said:

title: Connecticut Police Explain Conversion To New Ammunition
description: HARTFORD, June 14 (AP)We don't use the gun to slow a person downwe shoot person to kill him, State Police Commissioner Cleveland Fuessenich said today in explaining the department's use of hollowpoint bullets.

title: SummerAnd Tie Men Are Hot Under the Collar
description: On April 26, the federal energy chief, John C. Sawhill, suggested in public that one way to conserve fuel this summer would be to lower office airconditioning. This would be more tolerable, Mr. Sawhill made the mistake of saying, if office workers came to work without ties.

title: People in Sports
description: John Shumate, the 6foot 9inch allAmerica center from Notre Dame, signed a multiyear contract yesterday to play for the Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association. Shumate was the Sun's firstround draft choice.

title: Herndon Leaps To Meet Mark
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., June 14.  Jerry Herndon of U.C.L.A. broke the meet record in the long jump and Gene Mancino of the New York Athletic Club won in the hammer throw as fieldevent finals held the spotlight today in the National amateur Athletic Union Junfor meet.

title: U.S. Negotiator on Arms Quits, Citing the Effects of Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Paul H. Nitze resigned today from the American negotiating team at the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks, asserting that the depressing reality of Watergate makes prospects for slowing the nuclear arms race unlikely.

title: Mrs. Findlay Wed To A. M. Vagliano
description: Mrs. Sarah G. Findlay, a freelance artist and writer, was married at her apartment here yesterday afternoon to Alexander M. Vagliano, a senior vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

title: Art: Sculpture Beside a Lake
description: PARAMUS, N. J.The outdoor sculpture show is rapidly becoming a badge of community aspiration in the arts. Although such exhibitions are a nightmare to organize, requiring the logistical genius of a field marshal, the diplomatic skills of a seasoned politician and the fundraising wiles of a veteran i mpresarlo, more and more communities outside the main cosmopolitan centers are developing an appetite for these openair sculptural extravaganzas. Apparently, the combined appeal of civic and esthetic delight is irresistible.

title: Employes Give Harper Monday Strike Deadline
description: An organization representing more than 300 of the 600 New Yorkbased employes of Harper & Row reaffirmed at a meeting yesterday a decision to start a strike against the giant publishing concern on Monday unless agreement on a new employment contract is reached by then.

title: The Senator Is OddLine Jump Victor
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 14When The Senator returned from the Man and His World horse show in Montreal, just a year ago, he was limping badly.

title: People and Business
description: Mrs. Virginia H. Knauer, President Nixon's consumer affairs adviser, asked the country's bankers yesterday to mail coin wrappers to their customers as a way to help end the penny shortage.

title: Nuptials for Miss Carrington And Stephen Koplik Bierman
description: The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Carrington to Stephen Koplik Bierman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel D. Bierman of New York and Norwalk, Conn., took place here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Ralph Warren Jr. of St. James' Episcopal Church performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Claiborne Carrington of New York and Barbados, W. I.

title: BIG BROKER FIRMS NEIGH INSURANCE
description: Merrill Lynch & Co's announcement Wednesday that it planned to buy a life insurance company may accelerate similar moves by the other big retail brokerage firms. Several indicated yesterday that thrl were actively considering similar acquisitions or were planning to bolster their largely tentative efforts to sell insurance for major carriers.

title: Reward in Bomb Death
description: PASCO, Wash., June 14 (UPI) The Post Office Department authorized a reward of up to $10,000 today for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the person or persons who mailed a pipe bomb that killed Judge James Lawless here June 3.

title: Gross Is Sentenced To 2 Years in Jail On Perjury Charge
description: NEWARK, June 14  Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman and Nixon Administration official, who was convicted of tax fraud and perjury stemming from his activities as chairman of the 1969 gubernatorial campaign of William T. Cahill, was sentenced, today to two years in jail and fined $10,000.

title: CYPRUS BOMBS HIT AGENCIES AND SHOPS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 14 (Reuters)Ten bombs exploded early today in Famagusta, in eastern Cyprus, damaging Government offices and cooperative shops. No casualties were reported.

title: Role of Franklin National In Securities Case Studied
description: Senate investigators are studying the possibility that the financially troubled Franklin National Bank has served as a conduit, perhaps unknowingly, for stolen Government securities, according to wellinformed sources.

title: Legislators Are Invited To Mental Hospitals
description: TRENTON, June 14 (UPI)Ann Klein, the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Institutions and Agencies said today that the doors to the state's mental hospitals are open to legislators who want to tour the facilities.

title: In Nixon's Orange County, He Still Rates High Marks
description: LAGUNA HILLS, Calif.The courtly man from Michigan confided that although he had always admired Richard M. Nixon, he secretly wished the House Judiciary Committee would vote articles of, impeachment against the President.

title: Jobs and Recreation Funds For the City Are Increased
description: New York City will receive $26.5million$2.9million more than last yearfor its summer programs providing young residents with jobs and recreation, the Labor Department in Washington disclosed yesterday.

title: Gross ls Sentenced To 2 Years in Jail On Perjury Charge
description: NEWARK, June 14  Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairthan and Nixon Administration official, who was convicted of tax fraud and perjury stemming from his activities as chairman of the 1969 gubernatorial campaign of William T. Cahill, was sentenced today to two years in jail and fined $10,000.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)The National Football Lague Players Association said today the union was quite serious about a strike and would do all it could legally to prevent rookies and free agents going to training camp. We hope we can avoid a strike, Ed Garvey, union executive director, told a news conference: We don't think it is good for the players, the owners or the fans. He said a strike, if it comes, would begin July 1, a few days before the training camps open.

title: Run, Don't Wait
description: When the Metropolitan Transportation Authority introduced the system of alternate stops for buses in the midtown area, the aim was to make the buses run faster. In fact, the system seems mainly to make the passengers run faster. Since many of the numbered signs, indicating which line honors a particular stop, have long since disappeared along with the route maps, the only way to beat the arrangement is to stand between stops and begin sprinting as soon as it appears likely that the desired bus will stop at a given corner.

title: OUSTER BY BOARD SCORED AS RACIST
description: The Hispanic and Chinese minority faction of the new community school board in District 1 yesterday attacked as racist and as an invitation to community violence a move by the board's white majority to oust the board's only Asian member, a supporter of Superintendent Luis Fuentes.

title: Yanks Bomb Holtzman, Defeat A's, 51
description: OAKLAND, June 14After the Oakland A's spent 20 minutes before the game going over the Yankee hitters tonight, Ted Kubiak turned to Ken Holtzman and said jokingly, There are interesting meetings.

title: The Screen
description: THE MIDNIGHT MAN, directed and produced Jointly by Roland Kibbee and Burt Lancaster; screenplay by Mr. Kibbee and Mr. Lancaster, based on David Anthony's novel The Midnight Lady and The Mourning Man; director of photography, Jack Priestlevy editor, Frank Morriss; music, Dave Grusin; distributed by Universal Pictures. Running time: 117 minutes. At the Lyric Theater, 42d Street, west of Seventh Avenue, and other theaters. This film has been rated R.

title: Bridge: Doubling Against Fair Hands Can Have Several Dangers
description: Doubling the opponents in a game that they clearly expect to make is usually unprofitable, although it may be; highly tempting. There, is the danger that the double will give away the position and help the declarerperhaps even help him to make the contract. There is also the danger, admittedly a very slight one, that the opponents will be able to switch profitably into another contract.

title: WINE TALK
description: Those friendly folks who bring you all that delicious wine had a field day in Washington earlier this week battling over just what size bottles you should be allowed to buy. And guess whose interests were hardly involved at all? Yours.

title: Miss Evert Gains Final At Paris Net
description: PARIS June 14  Chris Evert is in the final of the French open tennis tournament, which she nearly won a year ago, although it took minutes of struggling on this slow red surface today to subdue Mrs. Helga Masthoff, 75, 64, with the loser from Germany near exhaustion at the finish.

title: TRADING IS SLOW FOR COMMODITIES
description: Commodity futures trading yesterday was marked by relatively slow trading and few significant price changes.

title: Graduation, College Plans Unfazed by Cancellations
description: The cancellation of four Regents examinations because of the theft of test answers, will disrupt neither the graduation later this month of qualified high school seniors nor their plans, if any, for attending college next fall.

title: Symington Returns to Work
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)  Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, spent part of today at his Senate office for the first time since a hernia operation on June 4. Mr. Symington, 72 years old, will return to fulltime duties on Monday, a spokesman said. Last year, the Senator had an operation for a prostate ailment.

title: 7 ASK REVERSAL IN BREAKIN CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Lawyers for the seven men convicted in connection with ?? breakin at Democratic National Headquarters in the Watergate office building argued today in the United States Court of Appeals for ??w trials or dismissal of the charges against them.

title: Defector to Soviet Union No Longer a U.S. Citizen
description: MOSCOW, June 14 (UPI)An American defector to the Soviet Union who Wants to return home is no longer an American citizen, United States Embassy officials said today.

title: Lisbon Assumes Control Of Nation's TV Network
description: LISBON, June 14 (AP)Portugal's new Government announced tonight that it was taking control of the country's statesubsidized television network. Press sources speculated that the takeover was the first step in a crackdown on the country's news media.

title: Role of Franklin National In Securities Case Studied
description: Senate investigators are studying the possibility that the financially troubled Franklin National Bank has served as a conduit, perhaps unknowingly, for stolen Government securities, according to wellinformed sources.

title: City Highway Office Asks for Overtime On West Side Route
description: One day after three demonstrators were arrested during a protest over the long delay in repairing the West Side Highway, the city's Highway Department again asked for authority to pay overtime rates to speed up the job of inspecting the deteriorated elevated structure.

title: CATTLE RAISERS BACKED BY BURNS
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged Reserve banks in major cattleraising areas to use their influence to help maintain the flow of credit to ranchers and feedlot operators.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: KINGS COUNTY Brooklyn artists who haven't made the inside of the Brooklyn Museum will be displayed on the fence; there will also be a steel band, a choral group, a rock group, handicrafts, food, book exhibits, a variety, of games, boutiques and frolickingall of that at the fourth annual Crown Heights cultural festival tomorrow between 1 P.M. and 6 P.M. The festival, at Eastern Parkway between Grand Army. Plaza and Washington Avenue, is put together by the Brooklyn Library, Museum and Botanic Gardens, along with local Crown Heights groups on behalf of an area that is home for 230,000 personsmostly West Indians and Hasidic Jews. . . . In Queens, tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clockthe Store Front Museum presents Gospel in the Park, one of the free outdoor Clifford Glover Summen Concerts held in King's Park, at Jamaica Avenue and 152d Street, across from York College. (Rain chases the concert into the Store Front Museum, at 16202 Liberty Avenue, Jamaica). Five gospel groups are scheduled to appear, Including The Thrashing Wonders, The Gospel Raindrops and The Mount Carmel Youth Choir, giving listeners a chance to hear the musical link between spirituals and rthythm and blues.

title: High School Notes
description: Gregory McMillan, a 16yearold 10thgrader at Food and Maritime Trades High School, will leave his home in the BedfordStuyvesant secion of Brooklyn today for a 10week stint as a cook at a camp in Winthrop Me.

title: DR. MINER C. HILL, 94, PEDIATRICIAN, DEAD
description: Dr. Miner C. Hill, a Long Island pediatrician, died yesterday at his home in Oyster Bay, L.I., at the age of 94.

title: Secret Tests Find Police Lax in Recovering Drugs
description: Secret tests conducted by the Police Department to determine whether its officers were turning in all of the narcotics they had seized have revealed few instances of corruption, but a great many instances of poor police work.

title: Two Soviet Dance Stars Arrive In Vienna on Way to Israel
description: VIENNA, June 14  The Soviet ballet stars Valery Panov and Galina Ragozina, his wife, who lost their positions with the Leningrad Kirov Ballet when they applied to emigrates from the Soviet Union two years ago, arrived here today, on their way to Israel.

title: Text of NixonSadat Statement
description: CAIRO, June 14 (Reuters) Following is the text of the joint statement issued today by President Nixon and President Anwar elSadat under the title Principles of Relations and Cooperation Between Egypt and the United States:

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: EDITOR IS WARRED BY TWO ROBBERS
description: The police were searching yesterday for two selfstyled Mafia enforcers who invaded the offices of Screw magazine Thursday afternon, coupling bizarre robbery with a stern underworld warning.

title: 3 in Show Business Honored by Elizabeth
description: LONDON, June 14 (UPI) Five new life peers were created and public, sports and show business figures from Britain and the Commonwealth were honored to day by Queen Elizabeth in the traditional birthday honors ceremony, Buckingham Palace announced.

title: Yemen Coup Chiefs Tighten Grip But Promise Return of Civil Rule
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 14Yemen's new military rulers reportedly suspended the constitution, dissolved the Legislature, and disbanded the country's sole political organization today, but promised to reestablish civilian rule as soon as possible.

title: Multiple Housing Change Is Pressed by State Unit
description: TRENTON, June 14A key state commission today urged Governor Byrne and the New Jersey Legislature to approve series of measures aimed at opening up suburban areas in the state to multifamily housing.

title: Industrial Production Up Again, With a 3 Per Cent Gain by Autos
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Industrial production rose in May for the second straight month, following four months of decline, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Saudi Arabia at a Glance
description: Role in IslamTo the 500 million adherents of Islam in the world, Saudi Arabia is a special land, for one of her cities is Mecca, the birthplace The Saudi ruler, King place of the Prophet MohamFaisal, is considered the chief defender of Islam. He is also the secular head of a largely desert land that is the world's leading exporter of oil.

title: PRESIDENT NAMED BY KLEIN STORES
description: S. Klein Department Stores announced yesterday the election of a new president and executive vice president but declined to make any statement on reports that it planned to close six stores that were losing money.

title: F.P.C. Approves Power Project; Opponents in Congress Angered
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Federal Power Commission today issued a license to the Appalachian Power Company to construct the controversial Blue Ridge hydroelectric project on the New River in western Virginia and North Carolina.

title: Grades for Tire Quality Proposed by U.S. Agency
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)  The Government proposed today a rule designed to grade automobile tires for traction, tread wear and highspeed performance. The uniform tire quality grading standard would be effective May 1, 1975, and was proposed by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Peking Bars Interference In Criticism of Officials
description: HONG KONG, June 14 The ideological campaign in China has moved into a new phase as a result of orders from Peking barring local Communist party units from interfering with anyone who wants to put up a wall poster to denounce officials or policies he finds objectionable.

title: Soviet Seeking U.S. Help In Industrial Biochemistry
description: The Soviet Union, in pursuing its search for advanced Western technology, has turned to the United States for aid in the highly complex area of industrial biochemistry.

title: Aaron Connects as Braves Defeat Cardinals, 6 to 1
description: Henry Aaron hit the 724th home run of his career last night putting more distance between himself and Babe Ruth (714) as the Braves took a 61 victory over St. Louis in Atlanta.

title: Market Place: Margin Quality Is Deteriorating
description: The quality of credit in the stock market deteriorated dramatically in May, putting a larger portion of total customer debt in jeopardy of margin calls than at any time in the nine and a half years the New York Stock Exchange has tabulated the figures.

title: Women's Privileges Widened at Yale Club
description: Dining room and bar facilities as well as use of the squash courts were extended this week to women at the Yale Club, at 44th Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, for the first time.

title: POET DENIES TARGET WAS SOLZHENITSYN
description: MOSCOW, June 14Yevgeny Yevtushenko has angrily denied that his major poem published last month included a veiled attack Aleksandr I. Solzhentisyn.

title: Rock by Heartsfield Has Inventiveness; Isis Also Performs
description: Heartsfield, which opens the show for Quacky Duck through tomorrow at Max's Kansas City, is a most attractive country rock sextet. The group comes from Chicago, but the idiom it works in is so close to the various Los Angeles bands associated with country rock that it's a little hard to understand why Heartsfield doesn't move there itself.

title: 4 Historic Sites Listed
description: BOSTON, June 14 (AP)The Suffolk County Courthouse in Boston is among four sites that will be added to the National Register of Historic Places, the Massachusetts Secretary of State, John F. X. Davoren, has announced. The others are the Phipps Burying Ground in Boston's Charlestown section, believed to be the site of John Harvard's grave; Gloucester's Front Street block, and Springfield's Quadrangle  Mattoon Streets district.

title: Loan Rates Raised By Chase Manhattan
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that effective July 1 it would raise its interest rates on personal, homeimprovement and auto loans.

title: Notes on People
description: The White House confirmed yesterday that J. Fred Buzhardt Jr., who has been working as a member of President Nixon's Watergate, defense team since May, 1973, had suffered a heart attack and said he would be out of action for at least two months.

title: SOLAR ENERGY USE SHOW IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGOA home heating and cooling unit that uses solar energy was demonstrated here recently by the Institute of Gas Technology. The institute contends that the unit would cut home fuel consumption by onethird.

title: Trotting Is MacDonald's World
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 14 Duncan MacDonald was bent over in the stall this morning doing groom's work pitching hay and getting lunch ready for Armbro Ouzo.

title: On Safeguarding the Right of Privacy
description: ARMONK, N. Y.  Writing in The Harvard Law Review of 1890, Louis D. Brandeis warned of mechanical devices that would threaten the solitude and privacy of the individual.

title: DEMOCRATS NAME CUOMO TO 2D SPOT
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Saturday, June 15  Divided, confused and frustrated, the Democratic State Committee finally designated Mario M. Cuomo of Queens, as the party's official candidate for Lieutenant Governor yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal, ruled yesterday that Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi of State Supreme Court must stand trial for perjury, but the court rejected a motion by Maurice H. Nadjari, the Special State Prosecutor, to reinstate two counts of a fourcount indictment against the justice.

title: Egg Farms in the State Buffeted By Low Prices and Falling Sales
description: WOODBOURNE, N. Y.Empty chicken houses with broken windows and overgrown weed patches at the doors testify to the decline of the small egg farmer in Sullivan County, but eggs are still a big business here.

title: Contract Awards
description: The aircraft engine group of the General Electric Company has received a $19million addition to an Air Force contract for the Northrop F5E fighter.

title: 2 Hurt in Blast at Factory
description: MILFORD, Conn., June 14 AP)An explosion at the Conoecticut Aerosols, Inc., plant tonight injured 12 employes, the police said. Two of the workers suffered severe burns and were taken to YaleNew Haven Hospital. The others were treated at Milford Hospital. The explosion occurred Stortly before 8 P.M.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE FIGURE FINAGLERS. By Robert Reichard. 274 pages. McGrawHill. $8.95. Not long ago, there were cries of outrage when Con Edison announced that rate increases would mean a certain amount more on the average electric user's bill because it was hard, if not impossible, to find anyone with that average bill, and many a consumer suspected that Con Edison was making it all up. Robert Reichard, in The. Figure Finaglers, explains why: As useful as an average is, it can provide only a limited amount of information. Sooner or later we will want to know something about the spread around the average. For all those consumers whose increase was much larger than the average cited by Con Edison, it seemed clear that the average was not enough.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Hispanic and Chinese minority faction of the new District 1 Community School Board attacked as racist and as an invitation to community violence, a move by the board's white majority to oust the board's only Asian member, Janice Wong, a supporter of Superintendent Luis Fuentes. The ouster vote came at a closed board meeting Thursday, the first since its election May 14. The basis of the ouster move was a charge that Miss Wong was not a registered voter in the district, but she later said she had registered before the election. Chancellor Irving Anker said the board could not remove a fellow member without drawing up specific charges and resorting to the Central Board of Education and the courts.

title: Miss Evert Gains Final At Paris Net
description: PARIS June 14  Chris Evert is in the final of the French open tennis tournament, which she nearly won a year ago, although it took 90 minutes of struggling on this slow red surface today to subdue Mrs. Helga Masthoff, 75, 64, with the loser from Germany near exhaustion at the finish.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The Government proposed today that officials of each national bank be required to keep on file at the bank a record of their loans and other business interests outside the banks. A spokesman for the Controller of the Currency said the information would not be available to the public, but the proposal would provide bank examiners and possibly other lawenforcement officials with the most detailed look yet at the web of financial transactions emanating from Federally chartered banks.

title: So. Calif. Nine Again in Final
description: OMAHA, June 14 (AP)Southern California scored five runsthree unearnedin the first inning tonight and eliminated Southern Illinois, 72, to earn a chance for a record fifth straight College World Series title.

title: 1.4Billion Pledged To India by West
description: PARIS, June 14The industrial nations of the West today pledged $1.4billion to India over the next year to help ease her out of a precarious economic situation caused in part by soaring oil prices.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesAlberto Davila, 116 pounds, Los Angeles, outpointed Tanny Amancio, 117, The Philippines, 10 rounds.

title: Excerpts From Brezhnev Address on U.S. Relations
description: MOSCOW, June 14Following are excerpts from Leonid I. Brezhnev's speech today at the Kremlin Hall of Congresses, as translated by The New York Times:

title: PANEL OF 100 ASKS FULL EMPLOYMENT
description: A group of people representing labor, civil rights, church organizations and the academic community took the first step yesterday in a campaign to press for a national full employment policy.

title: Capes: A Different Fall
description: Maneuvering a flowing cape, a load of paper parcels, a tote bag and a handbag may present some problems next fall, especially if somebody asks you for a match. But designers are expecting a lot of women to try.

title: COUNCIL WEIGHING NEWARK TAXI RISE
description: NEWARK, June 14The City Council agreed unaminously today to allow the introduction of an ordinance that would permit the increase of taxicab fares by as much as 30 per cent across the board.

title: Threat Clears Gulf Building After Blast
description: PITTSBURGH, June 14The Gulf Oil Corporation building, rocked by an explosion last night attributed to a radical group that calls itself Weather Underground, was evacuated at noon today by a bomb threat.

title: Thompson Ring Victor
description: BRISBANE, Australia, June 14 (UPI)  Hector Thompson, the commonwealth light  welterweight champion of Australia, gained a 10round decision tonight over Carlos Gimenez of Argentina.

title: YOUTH FARES PLEA REJECTED BY C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Civil Aeronautics Board rejected today a request by Trans World Airlines and 15 other airlines to reinstate cutrate youth fares to Europe tomorrow. But it did not rule out reinstating them later this summer.

title: Westfield Is Big on Being Small
description: WESTFIELDThe sign on Central Avenue reads, Welcome to Colonial Westfield, and never a truer word was posted. As Mrs. Joy Vreeland, the Town Clerk of this Union County municipality of 34,000 put it: We go back a long way as a community, and we want our town to reflect the warmth of America. Most of our stores, churches and town buildings are done in a colonial motif, and we think this is a good place to raise a family.

title: News and Guards in Pact
description: The Daily News reached a tentative settlement yesterday with a teamsters local representing 70 security guards at the newspaper. Sal Tonaselli, president of Local 820, said the proposed contract included substantial wage increases, expanded benefits and management concessions on scheduling.

title: R. ELLIS JOHNSON
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., June 14 (AP)  R. Ellis Johnson, retired president of the Rock Island Railroad, died Wednesday. He was 64 years old.

title: MONETARY FUND OFFERS BLUEPRINT
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The 20 nations that have been negotiating reform of the world monetary system today made public their general conclusions on what a permanently reformed system should look like.

title: SUIT IS PROPOSED ON SHEA VERDICT
description: Residents of South Jamaica, Queens, stunned by the acquittal of Police Officer Thomas Shea, gathered at hastily called meetings yesterday to try to resolve the tense aftermath or the acquittal in the fatal shooting last year of 10yearold Clifford Glover.

title: 2 Killed in Helicopter Crash
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (UPI)A New Jersey pilot and his passenger were killed yesterday when a helicopter crashed into a tree and burst into flams in the northeast, section of this city. The victims were identified as the pilot, Walter Bott, 53 years old, of Riverton, N. J., and his passenger, Arnold Goldman, of Bala Cynwyd, Pa.

title: ORDERS ON U.S. CORN CANCELED BY CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)  An Agriculture Department report showed today that China has canceled orders for United States corn valued at current prices at about $140million but has decided to buy $121million worth of soybeans from next fall's crop. The shift in orders was disclosed in a weekly Agriculture Department report of export listings.

title: Watergate Report Blames President For Dirty Tricks
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)A staff report to the Senate Watergate committee charged today that President Nixon must be held responsible and accountable for systematic campaign of dirty tricks against 1972 Democratic Presidential hopefuls.

title: Regulatory Agencies Scored on Delays
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Most of the Federal agencies that decide such questions as the price of natural gas or who should own a television station have been accused of failing to act to reduce the months and even years of unnecessary delay plaguing the regulatory process.

title: CHINESE TOO BUSY FOR CANADIAN MUSIC
description: OTTAWA, June 14The Authorities in Peking have abruptly postponed a visit to China by the Vancouver Symphony Orchestra until next year, explaining that the Chinese organization in charge of the tour arrangements is too busy to continue with the project at this time.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Nixon and Sadat Sign Sweeping Accord on Cooperation
description: CAIRO, June 14President Nixon and President Anwar elSadat announced today that the United States had agreed to provide Egypt with nuclear technology for peaceful purposes.

title: ROTHKO PROCEEDS DISPUTED AT TRIAL
description: Mistakes that Frank Lloyd, head of Marlborough Gallery, said were caused by typists' errors, resulted in a delay of two and a half years in accounting to the estate of Mark Rothko for its share of the proceeds of sales of some paintings of the abstract expressionist, according to testimony in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

title: Proper Tending of the Fourth Estate
description: More and more there is news about news: The Government blasts the press, charging that it is slanted and irresponsible; the press blasts the Government, accusing it of violating the First Amendment; lawyers' tactics and politicians' ploys are daily frontpage farethe land is pockmarked with credibility gaps.

title: PUBLIC NOTICE
description: NEW YORK STATE

title: Nakamura Leads Golf
description: SAPPORO, Japan, June 14 (AP)Toru Nakamura of Japan posted a fiveuhderpar 67 today, taking a onestroke lead at 138 in the $71,400 SapporoTokyo golf tournament. Fuinio Tanaka and Takashi Murakami were tied for second at 139.

title: Jaworski Asserts Nixon Vainly Attempted to Suppress Court Record of Jury's Linking Him to CoverUp Plot
description: WASHINGTON, June 14President Nixon tried in vain to have the Federal District Court erase from the record grand jury's naming of him as an unindicted coconspirator in the Watergate coverup, according to court papers filed today by Leon Jaworski, the special prosecutor.

title: Hospital Reaches Out to Deal With Troubled Schoolchildren
description: Sara is not a child who disrupts the classroom. She is not hostile or aggressive. She gets along with other children, and for her teacher she professes great love.

title: Ford Urges Support for Peace Mission
description: CHICAGO, June 14  Vice President Ford urged today that the nation let politics and controversy stop at the water's edge to strengthen the hands of President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger on what he called their sacred mission to the Middle East.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 15, 1974

title: Ecology: II No Secret Wars
description: The Caracas conference for the creation of a new maritime legal code cannot avoid the ecological aspects of the seven seas and who controls theme This fact should remind us that while nations focus attention on sharing oceanic wealth and limiting the seas' surface and subsurface military use, it is urgent to safeguard the world against peacetime dangers from scientific advance.

title: Autographs Scarce for Miss Young
description: Sheila Young was having lunch at Manuche's on West 52d Street and the note on the maitre d's reservation list spelled out: VIP! World champion. 12:30 P.M. Nobody recognized Women her when she arrived and few had recognized Sports her earlier at a press conference where athletes had gathered for the United States Physical Fitness Council.

title: New Graduates Seeking to Teach Are Said to Outnumber Jobs by 2 to 1
description: This year's college graduate seeking a teaching job will find the opportunities scarce.

title: A.E.C. Shuts Jersey Plant After a Radiation Accident
description: CHICAGO, June 15 (UPI)An employe's overexposure to radiation has caused the Atomic Energy Commission to shut down two plants of Isomedix, Inc., in Parsippany, N. J., and Morton Grove, Ill., pending an investigation.

title: New & Novel
description: Rachel MacKenzie has performed a small miracle. She has written a family history without prolixity. She evokes an acute sense of time, unrolling in the 1920's and 1930's, by crystallizing the times in one old house in an upstate New York town. The old Henderson House in Pliny Falls is still dominated by the spirit of its departed matriarch, who determined its decor and the decorum of its tenants, her surviving daughters. Mother wanted to keep her girls young and innocent and sweet. And so they are at the ages of 32 and 29, when mother suddenly passes on.

title: Acclaim, But Not Everyone Believes He Has Been Perfect
description: WASHINGTONLast week Secretary of State Kissinger shed a tear and the world wept. Behind the weeping lies an assumption magnified by the positive attention Mr. Kissinger has received from the pressthat he is to American foreign policy as oxygen is, to life. While it is certainly true that few of Mr. Kissinger's critics would like to see him resign, it is equally true that he has responsible critics.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In a recent article Edwin L. Dale Jr. argues against proposed changes in the tax law to neutralize the impact of inflation on the individual's tax bracket and the tax bill he pays (Inflation's Tax Trap, May 15).

title: Three Women Alone, says Cyclops, was about real people, and emotions that TV usually ignores or trivializes.
description: THERE was an extraordinary special on the other Sunday night, just two weeks ago. It didn't cause cavities, like Apple's Way. It didn't anthropomorphize Amazonian jaguars and boa constrictors, like The World of Disney. And it wasn't looking for lint in the cleft of Efrem Zimbalist Jr.'s chin, like The FBI It was, instead, a quiet, thoughtful and disturbing hour about real people.

title: Point of View
description: A news report on these pages May 29 described the plight of a potential home buyer who made a clown payment on a $60,000 house that Golan. Heights Development, Inc., was building in Rockland County. Because of the builder's financial problems, foreclosure proceedings were begun by the holder of the construction mortgage. The head of Golan Heights, Ovadia Porat, said he had insufficient funds to return such deposits. At least a score of buyert fear that. they have lost their homes and deposits. They appear to have no legal remedy.

title: Kidnapping a Love Goddess
description: The belief here is that every publishing house should be blessed with a writer of Irving Wallace's clout: a man or woman who every year or two turns out a blockbuster of best seller. These writers, when you come right down to it, are the last patrons of the arts.

title: The World
description: The time of reckoning for Europe's economies, after last year's crushing rise in oil prices, is apparently at hand. When added to homegrown problems, the nations of Western Europe are experiencing both political and economic trauma.

title: Survivors Mark Slocum Deaths
description: Seventy years ago yesterday the excursion steamer General. Slocum burned in the East River near North Brother Island.

title: New Life for An Old Church
description: LONG VALLEY  Twohundred years old and crumbling, Old Union Church, also known as Old Stone Church, is being resurrected as this Morris County community's personal project for the nation's Bicentennial.

title: Dinner Will Toast Boe
description: Roy Boe, president of the Nets of the American Basketball Association and the Islanders I of the National Hockey League, will be honored June 25 as the Long Island Ad Club's manoftheyear. The group will hold its annual dinner at Salisbury Restaurant in Eisenhower Park, East Meadow, L. I.

title: Mansion Music at Newport
description: THIS is the time each year that report reaches this department from Glen Sauls and John Stranack as to what they have been up to during the winter. The report is in the form of the program for the annual Newport Music Festival, which this year opens on July 25 and runs through Aug. 3. What Sauls, the festival's director, and Stranack, his researcher colleague, have been doing, of course, is digging up forgotten, unusual or rarely performed works to be presented in Newport's great mansions. The festival is one of two in this country speoializing annually in this kind of disinterment, the other being Frank Cooper's Romantic Festival at Butler University in Indianapolis, completed last month.

title: Questions and Answers on the State Rent Law Affecting City and Its Suburb
description: After weeks of fierce controversy, Governor Wilson recently signed into law a major apartmentrent bill that profoundly affects New York City and Nassau, Westchester and Rockland Counties.

title: In College Commencement Talks, It's Watergate, Moref Watergate
description: College commencement speakers across the country, who in years past have groped for relevant subjects, are seizing upon the current political scandals and feeding the Clash of 1974 heaping diet of Watergate, Watergate and Watergate.

title: The Legacy of a Very Personal Collecto
description: APICTURE lives by its legend, Picasso once observed, referring to that little body of fact, gossip, picaresque adventures, mistaken assumptions and critical eyaluations that accumulate about a work of art once it has left the artist's hands. The large and rewarding exhibition of paintings, watercolors, drawings and sculpture from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pearlman, now on view  through September  at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 188 Eastern parkway, has its share of magnificent pictures and a few engaging legends.

title: Curtis Norpell, Susan M. Grehl Wed in Suburb
description: In the Mount Kisco (N. Y.) Presbyterian Church at noon yesterday, Miss Susan Merrill Grehl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Grehl of Chappaqua, N. Y., became the bride of Curtis Edmiston Norpell. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Norpell of Newark, Ohio, and Sanibel, Fla.

title: Annenberg Named Trustee
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) Walter H. Annenberg, United States Ambassador to Britain, has been reelected a trustee of the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Annenberg, the publisher of TV Guide magazine and a former publisher and editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, will leave his Ambassador's post on July 4 and return to private life.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Lest anyone fail to notice, tomorrow marks two years to the day since five welldressed men were caught breaking into the offices of the Democratic National Committee in the Watergate office complex; a caper that one of the President's men early on described as a thirdrate burglary attempt.

title: Ox Ridge Hunter Title Captured by. Riot Free
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 15 For Patti Heuckeroth, today was like a homecoming at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show.

title: Environmentalists Start Land Trust
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON  A new land trust designed to prevent acreage from being developed has appeared on the East End. The South Fork Land Foundation, Inc., is being organized by the Group for America's South Fork, Inc., a private nonprofit environmental protection organization.

title: SimonAfter Shedding the Inc.
description: At the age of 67, Norton Simon, is a brooding figure on the American business Seqtle, a wouldbe messiah of industry and the arts, who moves circuitously and always draws controversy with one grandiose gesture or another.

title: Fair Lawn Offers Art From Russia
description: FAIR LAWNPaintings by two Soviet Jewish artists, one currently in prison and one recently emigrated to Israel; are the subject of To Paint in Freedent an exhibition now at the Fair Lawn Public Library.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: WALLACE FOE WINS STATE PARTY POST
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 15 Robert S. Vance fought off a challenge by his old foe, Gov, George C. Wallace, and won reelection today as Alabama Democratic chairman.

title: Letter: On Dagger of Offshore Drilling
description: To the Editor: A letter from Eugene H. Luntey, executive vice president of Brooklyn Union Gas, appeared in the BQLI section on, May 12. He made statements that are far from accurate and it is important that we tryto set the record straight.

title: Calendar of Horse Shows
description: TodayOx Ridge, Ox Ridge Hunt Club, Route 124, Darien, Conn. Hunter Classic and Boyden International Grand Prix, 9 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S. Sailors in Japan Jump Ship Over Alleged Bias and Severity
description: YOKOSUKA, Japan, Sunday, June 16  Black and white sailors from the aircraft carrier Midway have jumped ship here in protest against alleged racial discrimination and harsh discipline by the ship's officers.

title: JUSTICES AGREE TO DECIDE IF JURY CAN ACCUSE NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a Watergate gland jury had the right to name President Nixon as a participant in the conspiracy to cover up the 1972 political burglary without indicting him for a crime.

title: Claudia Randel Wed
description: Miss Claudia Ann Randel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Victor I. Randel of Kingston, N. Y., was married yesterday evening to George F. Little 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Little of Brookville, L. I. Justice Paul J. Yesawich of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Wiltwyck Country Club in Kingston.

title: More Mansions on Long Island's Gold Coast Fall
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I.When Mabel Brady Garvan made her debut at Roslyn House on June 24, 1934, a thousand people with names like Auchincloss, Rockefeller, Morgan, Frick, Roosevelt, Milbank and Mellon were in attendance. It was no ordinary, shindig.

title: Jack Silverman, Operated Old Roumanian Restaurant
description: Jack Silverman, who retired nine years ago as operator of the International Theater Restaurant, a nightclub, at Broadway and 52d Street, and who had earlier run the old Romanian Restaurant on Allen Street, died yesterday in St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains. He was 86 years old and lived at 10025 Queens Boulvard.

title: Court Speeding Criminal Trials, With Priority for People Jailed
description: The State Supreme Court is conducting a drive here to wipe out a backlog of ciminal cases that have kept hundreds of defendants in jail awaiting trial a year and a half or more.

title: State Keeping Eye on Clams
description: TRENTONState officials are making sure that the clam does not become an endangered species, not only as a source of Income but also. of food.

title: Winged Foot Bares Teeth For the Open
description: MAMARONECK, N Y., June 15 When Arnold Palmer went for the 18th green today in the United States Open, he used a No. 3iron following a fine tee shot. This delighted Ted Horton, the Winged foot Golf Club supervisor, who was becoming convinced he had done his job well in preparing the West Course for the Open.

title: COURT JUDGMENTS GO UNPAID IN CITY
description: Half the judgments won in Small Claims Courts here go unpaid because businesses refuse to pay or because some consumers cannot afford the fees to employ city marshals to act in their behalf, according to testimony at a hearing last week.

title: Maisic
description: The Santa Fe Opera House

title: Katherine Helen Petrides Is Wed
description: Miss Katherine Helen Petrides and Montagnie Van Norden Jr., who graduated last Tuesday from Princeton University, were married yesterday evening in the Princeton (N. J.) University. Chapel by the Rev. Demetrios Constantelos of the Greek Orthodox Church of Toms River, N. J.

title: Bergen Aids BigBand Revival
description: RIVER EDGE  Bergen County is contributing to the bigband revival with an allstar aggregation composed of former members of orchestras led by such greats as Glen Miller, Benny Goodman, Woody Herman, Count Basie, Tommy and Jimmy Dorsey, Stan Kenton, Artie Shaw and Charlie Barnett.

title: TAIPEI UNWORRIED BY JAPANESE RIFT
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanWhen the Chinese Nationalist Government severed its civil aviation relations with Japan in April, ending connecting service by the two countries' airlines, even many supporters of the Government's decision foresaw some resulting hardships. But the difficulties encountered so far appear to be minimal.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: I've been up and down the city, said an irate New York career woman last week, looking for a size 10 dress that suits me. But all the stores seem to be catering to either the young gal who likes kooky clothes or the women who like pantsuits.

title: Miss McGlone Will Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. James WitLiam McGlone of Scarborough, N. Y., have announced. the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stacey Elsa McGlone, to John Henry Gemmill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Gemmill of Washington and Franklin, Me.

title: Solutions for Vegetable Ennui
description: NEW converts to vegetable gardening learn that the biggest problem is not always rabbits, fungus or little green worms. It's what to do with all that produce.

title: Nixon Is Expected to Meet Lisbon President on Azores
description: LISBON, June 15President Antonio de Spinola, in his first international outing, is expected to meet President Nixon probably next Tuesday in the Azores on Mr. Nixon's way back to Washington from the Middle East.

title: What's Doing on MARTHA'S VINEYARD
description: THE ISLANDNatural beauty is Martha's Vineyard's greatest asset: tall cliffs, pine woods and daisy meadows, ponds and shores and thudding sea. Twenty miles long and 10 wide at its widest point, the Vineyard lies five miles off Cape Cod. Fishing, swimming and sailing are leading attractions. The island's six towns are elegant Edgartown; goodtime Oak Bluffs; bustling, businesslike Vineyard Haven (also called Tisbury); rural and rockribbed Chilmark; the laissezokfaire farm town of West Tisbury; and the community of Gay Head, where 60 descendants of the Wampanoag tribe of Indians sake a living fishing and catering to tourists. The permanent population of Martha's Vineyard is 7,000; in summer it swells to 39,000.

title: Scheckter Applies Brakes to Daring Driving Style
description: PARIS  Postcards from abroad: Wish, you were here, To see Jody Scheckter, the curlyhaired kid from South Africa who is not the same driver he was a year ego. Then, while winning the Formula 5000 series in the United States, his style was such that dire predictions were made about his future.

title: Prison Aides Weighing Adoption of Controversial Contract Release Plan
description: TRENTONState prison officials are reportedly considering the adoption of a program under which inmates would be allowed: to contract for their release at a promised and preset date.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Education, Ornithology, Archaeology

title: Letters to the, Editor
description: The article Buyers Hurt, as Builder in Rockland Coun ty Falters [May 26] described a family who lost thousands of dollars in a down payment on a house that was never completed. It has occurred to me that insurance companies are losing thousands of dollars, too, by overlooking this type of coverage.

title: The Righteous Brothers Reunite For a Night of BlueEyed Soul
description: The Righteous Brothers exfisted between 1962 and 1968, when Bill Medley split off to go solo. Since then, Mr. Medley and Bobby Hatfield, the other brother, have been pursuing separate careers with varying success. A few months ago they decided to reunite. They have appeared on television and cut a single, and Friday night at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park they gave their first live concert in six years.

title: Notes From the Land of the Dead And Other Poems
description: Notes From the Land of the Deadmere notes. Ireland's best living poet has brooded himself to pieces. His passion survives in poetic piecing alone. The passionate, he says, might find it maddening. But passionate is in quotation marks that squeeze the word to sand. For who are we, brief meat and brains, to affect passion? We are all vile and We can weave nothing. It was always this way: In squalor and killing and parasitic things life takes its first hold. The Creation? A huddle of mouths. Even the moon: a white face stared from the void, tilted over, her mouth ready . . . The new catechism: Hair, Claws. Grey/Naked. Wretch. Wither. The syntax of our humanity is ungulfed; nightnothing/feeds in and feeds our daylight. The sad dullness, the tedious pain! . . . Would you agree, then, we won't/find truths, or any certainties...?

title: LAST TRIBUTE PAID TO FIREMAN HOEY
description: KINGS PARK, L. I., June 15 New York City's Fire Department paid its final tribute today to Fireman Harold J. Hoey Jr., who died in the line of duty while trying to save two elderly persons from a burning fivestory tenement in the South Bronx.

title: Ava M. Ottman, Surgical Nurse, Is Married Here
description: Miss Ava Marie Ottman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Arthur Ottman, was married yesterday afternoon to Luther Earle Birdzell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Birdzell Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Israel Prepares Strict Security And Large Welcome for Nixon
description: TEL AVIV, June 15The Israeli Government has urged school principals in Jerusalem to get their pupils into the streets tomorrow afternoon to cheer President Nixon on his arrival in the capital and Government offices will close early to enable civil servants to participate in the cheering squads.

title: Evelyn M. Fanning Wed to Daniel Caso
description: Miss Evelyn M. Fanning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Fanning of Ridgewood, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Daniel R. Caso, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carmine Caso of Saugus, Mass.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I am sure that you intended to perform apublic service by printing Jeffrey O'Connell's article (Living with life insurance, May 19); however, in castigating the lifeinsurance industry you really left the reader with one hell of an impression of the lifeinsurance agent.

title: Faith Has Need of All The Truth
description: The late Pierre Teilhard de Chardin and the two Berrigan brothers, Daniel and Philip, have much in common. All three, Roman Catholic priests and, more specifically, members of religious orders, took their religion seriously in a traditional sense but saw consequences of their faith that brought them into conflict with their religious superiors and, to a large extent, their societies as a whole. These books tell their stories and, at their best, offer interesting glimpses into the church's perennial religious problem of how to reconcile inspiration with demands of institutional order.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 15It's not new. One week each year, in the United States Open championship, the world's best Offers must play the game the way everybody else does. Under duress. Out of the rough. In the sand. On greens they can't read. One week doesn't seem to be too much to ask. But for some touring pros it's not easy to accept, because they're not really playing under duress the other weeks. The touring pros usually conquer the course. But at Winged Foot this week, as at every Open site, the course is conquering the touring pros. That demands humility. Significantly, the leaders have learned to accept it. That's why they're leading. Humility isn't something golfers can order, like clubs or shoes, from the equipment manufacturers they endorse. They have to learn it the hard way, as Johnny Miller has had to this week.

title: Rudy May of Angels Bought by Yankees
description: OAKLAND, June 15The New York Yankees announced tonight that they had purchased Rudy May, a 29yearold lefthanded pitcher, from the California Angels.

title: Art
description: WITH the early photographs of the late Edward Steichen, which are currently the subject of an absorbing exhibition at the Scott Elliott Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue, we are once again put in close touch with that legendary eraroughly, the years from the turn of the century to the First World War and its immediate aftermathin which so many of the salient issues of modern esthetic culture were first debated and defined. In a good many of these pictures, the 19thcentury inheritance still wields a surpassing authority, and part of the intensely interesting drama the exhibition holds. for us lies precisely in the way this inheritance is confronted, exalted and ultimately exorcised in the work of one of the leading exponents of the modern Movement.

title: Rate Uncertainty Defects Investors
description: Investors' doubts that interest rates will decline soon; sent the stock market lower last week in sluggish. trading.

title: News Theater
description: A powerful phenomenon has begun to shape the cultural and political events of our time. Let us, for want of a better term, call it news theater. By news theater, I don't mean documentary plays or theater of fact or living newspapers, but rather any histrionic proceeding that results from a collaboration between newsworthy personalities, a vast public, and the visual or print media (television, films, book publishing, magazines and newspapers).

title: Shelling Routs Refugees in Disputed Vietnam Town
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15 (UPI)  Communists shelled the town of Ben Cat, 25 miles north of Saigon while refugees were returning there today, according to reports from the field, and two children were killed in the bombardment.

title: New View of Law on Oil Spills Places Onus on Municipalities
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 15A new legal interpretation of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act makes municipalities responsible for oil spills emanating from their storm sewers no matter where the spills originate.

title: From moonshining to a place in the sun
description: When 40 of the noisiest automobiles in America line up for the 16th annual Firecracker 400 on July 4 at Daytona Beach, Fla., the race will differ in one respect from the 15 previous Firecrackers. It will retain the 400 in its name, but in a deferential (and publicrelations) nod to the fuel situation, its length will be cut 10 per cent to 360 miles, just the Daytona 500 of last February and other important stockcar races have been curtailed this season. Apart from that one change, which is bound to be temporary, other characteristics of the Firecracker and similar races remain immutable:

title: Children on the Beach
description: COLLEVILLESURMER, France Children play football on the sand now. Between them and green bluffs that rise steeply from the beaches, cheap bars and cafs and vacation houses are scattered haphazardly. The only defensive emplacements still to be seenan ugly, concrete box here and therehave been turned into monuments; the old cannon rusting inside them would not be worth much Oren as scrap metal.

title: Law StudentFiance Of Lynne Galanter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Galanter of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynne Galanter, to Mark Hirschhorn. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs, Jack Hirschhorn of Great Neck, L. I.

title: Richard Nixon's Revenge
description: In his struggle for political survival, it is ironical that President Nixon, has relied on the institutions he hates the mostpress, radio and televisionto save him from the slow but damaging dikioure's of Congress and the courts.

title: News of the Stage
description: Last January, Harold Prince picked up an option on an untitled play by John Weidman, a new playwright recently graduated from Yale Law School. Now Mr. Prince has decided to turn it into a musical bearing the title Pacific Overtures.

title: OLD NATIONS FACE DISPUTE ON PRICES
description: QUITO, Ecuador, June 15A fight over continuation of very high oil prices' was brewing among producers today as the world's major oil exporting countries met in Ecuador's highland capital.

title: Esthetics Versus Anthropology in The Art of Africa
description: THERE have been so many exhibitions of African art lately, and so many of them have been so good, that you may not feel all keyed up by the news that the National Gallery in Washington has staged yet another.

title: Brooke Vosburgh to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Lee. Frederick Vosburgh of Plandome Manor, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Brooke Vosburgh, to John Hennessey Ghent, son of Col. Daniel T. Ghent, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Ghent of Atlanta. The future bride is a student at Meredith College in Raleigh, N. C., and her fianc is a graduate student at Duke University. An Aug. 25 wedding is planned. was founded by his grandfather, Philipp Ottman, in 1859.

title: Barbara Ryan Bride
description: Miss Barbara Geraldine Ryan, daughter, of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Ryan of Little Silver, N. J., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday morning to. Edward J. Messinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Messinger of Lincroft, N. J. Msgr. Emmett. A. Monahan performed the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Church in Red Bank, N. J.

title: A Basketball Tale: How a Youth of 74 Made a Million at 22
description: Tom Burleson, 22 years old, from the hill country of North Carolina, became a millionaire because he was 7 feet 4 inches and lucky enough to be drafted on May 28 and signed last week by the Seattle Supersonics of the National Basketball Association, a team in need of a big man.

title: Bristlecone Pines: Longevity in Adversity
description: GENERATIONS of Americans have trooped to California's Sequoia National Park to admire that towering redwood known as the General Sherman  the largest and supposedly the oldest living thing in the world. Somehow it seemed appropriate: the king of trees in size, it should also be the most ancient.

title: Foreign Fishing Crippling New England Industry
description: OVER GEORGES BANK, the North AtlanticIn 1960, the fertile fishing grounds of these waters were worked only by small boats out of New England and Canada.

title: City Council Sessions Scheduled This Week
description: The following public City Council and Council committee sessions will be held this week:

title: Delegates from the nonprofit theater were not ready to support what they had labored so long against and without.
description: PRINCETON, N. J. MIGUEL PINERO, the exconvict author of Short Eyes, the current play about prison life, sat back in his chair, put his bare feet up on the table in front of him and sleepily peeled an orange. Another panelist, Richard Schechner, the director of the Off Off Broadway Performance Group and selfstyled guru Of the experimental theater movement, wondered aloud, Do we really want to help support Broadway, a ship we have been trying to sink all these years? Judith Molina and Julian Beck, founders of the ultraradical Living Theatre, answered, No! Beck a gaunt, hawkish figure ih dungarees and a peasant shirt, began to elaborate calmly, then gradually worked himself into a throbbing rage, and finally dashed from the panel into the sizeable audience shouting, The capitalist pig theater must go! It must die! We rejoice in its death! Beck's host, Broadway producer Alexander Cohen, who looks like your favorite uncle, glanced nervously around like a man about to be thrown into the cauldron by the savages. FACT, the First Annual Congress of Theater, was at work and, in spite of such theatrical fireworks exploding earlier this month here on the otherwise serene Princeton University campus, Piftero finished his orange, Cohen was not devoured at any of the banquets, and something historic was Accoplished.

title: Mary E. Sweeney Wed to Hoyt Taylor
description: Miss Mary Ellen Sweeney, a paralegal with the law firm of Wilkie, Farr & Gallagher, was married yesterday afternoon to Hoyt Weston Taylor, who is working for a Ph.D. in oceanography at the LamontDoherty Geological Observatory of Columbia University.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: What Happens if the State Adopts an Income Tax?
description: When the New Jersey Legislature last week began considering Governor Byrne's proposal to impose a personal income tax, it was taking a tentative step toward a tripartite system of taxation already in effect throughout most of the nation.

title: 2 Gain Final by Default
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., June 15 Cindy Johnson of Spring Lake, and Jane Lennon of Upper Saddle River didn't have to play a stroke today to reach the final of the Anne Cummings New Jersey State girls' tennis championship at the Westfield Tennis Club. Avis Fromer of Westfield defaulted to Miss Johnson and Ruta Gerulaitis of Howard Beach, Queens defaulted to Miss Lennon. Minor injuries caused both defaults. The championship will be played tomorrow.

title: 3 Held as Part of a Ring Robbing. Crime Families
description: The police announced the arrest yesterday of three Brooklyn men who, they said, were leaders of a 40man burglary ring allegedly contracted by one organizedcrime family to steal from other crime families.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: (MOLLY) HASKELL: FROM REVERENCE TO RAPE  Mabel Normand . . . a physical comic, but one of more energy than wit . . . was a star graduate, and teacher's pet, of the Mack Sennett schoolnot of the bathingbeauty line that produced Gloria Swanson, but of the custardpiethrowing division.

title: SPEECH FEES UP FOR ERYIN PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The long months in the limelight have helped members of the Senate Watergate committee to increase sharply their income on the afterdinner speaking circuit.

title: The rights and duties of the governed and the governing
