description: The next President of the United States will face two issues which existed well before the present crisis, but have been illuminated and heightened by it. One is government secrecy: what is the public's right to knowwhat is the government's right to withhold? The other is government control over private citizens: what is the government's right to knowwhat is the individual's right to withhold?

title: GLOUCESTER BURIED IN ROYAL CEREMONY
description: WINDSOR, England, June 14 (UPI)Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester, the last surviving grandson of Queen Vctoria and Queen Elizabeth. II's beloved Uncle Harry, Was buried today in the royal mausoleum it Frogmore wtih only the royal family present. The 74yearold Duke, an invalid for seven years, died Monday.

title: Saudi King Assails Critics Of Nixon's Peace Policies
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 15  King Faisal of Saudi Arabia appealed to the American people today to back President Nixon in his efforts to improve relations with the Arabs.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ON THE surface, it would appear that there were some solid reasons for optimism in the business world these days. The American economy has definitely been improving since its rather disastrous first quarter. Food prices have declined in recent weeks. Major interest rates have stopped rising and some have even dipped from their record peaks. And, over the course of the last month, the stock market came to life again with a snappy 10 per cent rally in terms of the market averages.

title: Foe of Young Adults
description: The National Multiple Sclerosis Society has been making progress in its research efforts against multiple sclerosis, a disabling disease of the central nervous system that usually strikes between the ages of 20 and 40the career and familybuilding years. The cause, prevention and cure of the disease remain unknown, but there is hope that Societysponsored research will conquer this mysterious crippler of young adults. Donations may be sent to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 257 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10010.

title: Palestinians Remain the Key Issue In Mideast
description: JERUSALEMThe photograph that dominated the front pages of most Israeli newspapers last Thursday showed a jubilant Richard Nixon and Anwar elSadat riding into Cairo at the head of a triumphal motorcade. In the background, easily readable even in the fuzzy wirephoto, was a handlettered banner reading: Remember the Palestinians.

title: Girls Applaud Baseball Ruling
description: TENAFLY  When officials of Little League Baseball, Inc., surrendered to the inevitable and announced last week that they would defer to the changing social climate and permit girls to play, it was all over but the shouting. And that is what some 9yearold girls were doing here.

title: College Football on the TV Screen: The Same 7 Teams Get the Exposure
description: The recent announcement of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 1974 football telecasts by the American Broadcasting Company caused barely abbrev ripple in the press.

title: Pro Lacrosse Is Relying on an Old Tradition to Attract New Fans
description: SYRACUSEGaylord Powless, who grew up on the Six Nations Indian reservation near Branford, Ontario, is a professional lacrosse player for the Syracuse Stingers of the new National Lacrosse League. Woven into the gut of his lacrosse stick are red ribbons as a mark of fortune, like a fourleaf clover.

title: Who Did What to Whom, And Why, With the Taps?
description: WASHINGTONMark my words, the angry White House official said early last week, the people indulging in this one are going to be sorry. The country just won't stand for criticism of Henry.

title: Will the Real Norton Simon Please Stand Up
description: The last 12 months have been a chastening experience for the golden boys of American business, particularly those who tied their fortunes to the comet of growth. Inflation, recession, Watergate, uneven economic controls and a bearish stock market have becalmed them in unfamiliar waters.

title: Mailbox: The Positive Side of Boxing And the Negative Side of Pro Hockey
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.C. Nine Takes Fifth Title in Row
description: OMAHA, June 15 (AP)Robb Adolph cracked a tworun homer and Southern California capitalized on two Miami errors for a 73 victory tonight that gave the Trojans a record fifth straight College World Series title.

title: Polls Find U.S. Isolationismon Rise, Hope at Ebb
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Over the last two years isolationism in the United States has more than doubled, to a new high since World War II, and in the Same period internationalist views among Americans have dropped 15 per cent to a post1945 low, a survey of American opinion shows.

title: Seven Appointed by Nixon To Council on Humanities
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) President Nixon has appointed seven persons to the National Council on the Humanities for terms expiring Jan. 26, 1980.

title: Film
description: PARIS.

title: By Any Other Name... Roses Take the Honors
description: WANTAGHShe was tall and gently curved. Her color was warm and glowing. Her grooming was immaculate. And she was in the fullest blush of her beauty as she was crowned queen of the 18th annual Long Island Rose Show at the Rose Kennedy Memorial School last Sunday.

title: Concert: For the Young
description: Nothing has been more heartening in the local music scene, perhaps, than the reception given the New York Philharmonic's Rug Concerts. Friday, night's concert, which was exceptional in many ways, provided further proof that there is an audience among the young, for live symphonic concerts concerts that, moreover, include a large dose of difficult 20thcentury music.

title: FUNDS FOR ROADS ARE UNUSED HERE
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Despite protests against the impoundment of Federal funds New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have failed to use a total of $103million in Federal highway funds available for the fiscal year ending June 30.

title: Suffolk Dream of QuarterHorse Track Vanishing in Fiscal Nightmare
description: YAPHANK, L. I., June 15It began as a big dream two years ago. This week, it was on the verge of collapse because in the end it proved to be too big a dream for Ronald Parr to handle.

title: A Strip Mining Bill Is Pending, and PollutionLevels Are Crucial
description: WASHINGTONCoal has become the mystery fuel in this energyshort nation. There is enough of it in the ground to satisfy the country's needs for two centuries. But a cluster of question marks stand, like silent tipples, over these riches.

title: Eye Trouble Cured For Photographer Hurt During Protest
description: W. Eugene Smith, the photographer who almost lost his sight after being beaten up during an antipollution campaign against a Japanese chemical company, has returned to Japan with his vision apparently restored.

title: Best Seller List
description: General

title: Nakamura Leads Golf
description: SAPPORO, Japan, June 15 (AP)Toru Nakamura of Japan shot a oneunder par 71 for 209 today and clung to a stroke lead over a countryman, Takash Murakami, in the $71,400 Sapporo golf tournament.

title: The Nation/Continued
description: The Senate has endorsed, virtually without debate, a basic change in American nuclear strategy that the Pentagon says is necessary to match the Soviet missile buildupand that critics charge will magnify the dangers and the great cost of the nuclear arms race.

title: Palmer Fan on Course 4 Hours, Sees All Shots
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 15Robert Marks one of the younger recruits in Arnie's Army, had no doubt tonight about the eventual winner of the United States Open.

title: Monument Depicts Holocaust
description: LAKEWOOD  A granite monument in memory of the 6 million Jews who died in the Nazi holocaust has been erected on a grassy promontory on Route 9.

title: SOVIET PUBLISHES PROSTALIN WORK
description: MOSCOW, June 15The most ardently sympathetic literary portrait of Stalin to appear here in years is being given mass national circulation in a literary magazine for young people.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Derek Sanderson, when his trade to the Rangers was officially announced, makes a promise to the Bruins: Now I want to go back into Boston and play as well as I can and help our team win there. They'll regret they traded me. They'll regret it more than any other move they've made in the past years.

title: City Planner Weds Helen N. Halcomb
description: The marriage of Miss Helen Nash Halcomb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Halcomb of Sewickley, Pa., to Halley Isao Moriyama, son of Mr. and Mrs. Iwao M. Moriyama of Bethesda, Md., took place yesterday afternoon in Sewickley.

title: AROUND THE
description: Be alert for black vine weevil on yew and rhododendron. Signs are yellowing, dropping needles and chewed notches on leaf margins. . . . Use cygon for holly leaf miner. . . . Spray fruit trees every week to 10 days. . . . Cut down ripened tulip foliage; pulling it may up root bulbs which should remain for next spring's bloom. . . . Chinch bugs are around; use diazinon for control.

title: A Marchbanks Fondly Recalls His Candida
description: Last week Katharine Cornell died at the age of 81. Burgess Meredith, who played Marchbanks to her Candida in the play by George Bernard Shaw in 1942, recalls their association.

title: Judgments on American judges and justice
description: By John P. MacKenzie. 320 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, $7.95.

title: Willie Smith Belger Gain U.S. Berths
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., June 15Neither the strain of two tough races nor a driving rain could halt Tom Byers today at the National Amateur Athletic Union junior track and field championships.

title: J. M. Armstrong, Leslie M. Nolte Married on L. I.
description: Miss Leslie Moore Nolte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. Nolte Jr. of Oyster Bay, L. I., was married yestoday afternoon to James Franklin Armstrong, son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Armstrong of Mill Neck, L. I.

title: Students Chart Carrnans River
description: BELLPORT  The Carmans River follows a meandering course through the Town of Brookhaven almost as peacefully now as it did when Daniel Webster went fishing here. While the river has always attracted its share of sportsmen and anglers it has in recent years been of growing interest to ecologists.

title: Sandra Post Takes Lead On 71143
description: MEDINA, Ohio, June 15 (AP)Sandra Post, the 1968 L.P.G.A. champion, battled miserable weather to card a oneunderpar 71 today and take the 36hole lead in the $42,500 Medina open.

title: Mr. Nixon's Two Worlds
description: An air of unreality hung over the affairs of President Nixon last week as he appeared to live in two totally separate worlds. Abroad, he was engaged in a triumphant journey through the Middle East; at home, his lawyers returned to a position of intransigence in efforts to frustrate the impeachment inquiry.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe package of agreements reached last week by the 20 nations negotiating world monetary reform will not visibly Or quickly affect the daily lives of foreign traders, tourists or even foreign exchange dealers.

title: Nixon, Kissinger and Haig Reportedly Subpoenaed As Ehrlichman Witnesses
description: WASHINGTON, June 15John D. Ehrlichman has subpoenaed President Nixon, Secretary of State Kissinger and Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the White House chief of staff, as defense witnesses in the plumbers trial scheduled to begin June 26, wellinformed sources said today.

title: Mrs. Sandra R. Williams Wed To Claude Cartier, the Jeweler
description: Mrs. Sandra Rousseau Williams, widow of John Kress (Jake) Williams, a Houston real estate developer, was married in Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday to Claude Cartier, former president of Cartier, Inc., the jevielers in New York. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Amory, stepfather and mother of the bride, by Circuit Judge James C. Knott, who usually officiates at marriages in the Rousseau family.

title: What's a Tourist Attraction Like The Kennedy Library Doing in a Nice Neighborhood Like This?
description: THE new Kennedy Presidential Library design that has just been officially unveiled is about as fitting a marker for a traumatic decade as any building complex could be in the ten years since the plan and the architect, I. M. Pei and Partners, were announced, galloping inflation, an energy crisis and community protest have reduced the project to approximately half its size and half its cost, and completely changed its architectural expression. It is its fate, however, to remain one of the nation's more conundertakings, in any guise.

title: Epilogue A Glance Back at Some Major Stories
description: The recent disclosure that Mrs. Richard Nixon and her daughters had received gifts of jewelry from the Saudi Arabian royal family has prompted a flow of similar valuable gifts into the State Department from other United States officials. Such gifts officially are property of the United States. The latest addition to the State Department's vaults is an eightcarat diamond worth more than $100,000 that has been returned by Sen. Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: AVOCADO THEFTS STIR CALIFORNIA
description: ESCONDIDO, Calif., June 15 California's avocado growers are patrolling their hillside groves with shotguns these nights to protect the ripening fruit against thefts that are running into millions of dollars.

title: 8,245Point Decathlon To Jenner
description: RICHMOND, June 15 (AP) Bruce Jenner of San Jose, Calif., won the Amateur Athletic Union national decathlon championship tonight with 8,245 points, a meet record and the secondbest performance ever turned in by an American.

title: Nancy LeaMond Bride of Stephen Finan
description: Miss Nancy A. LeaMond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund W. LeaMond of Millburn, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen E. Finan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Finan of Short Hills, N. J.

title: There'll Always Be a Wales
description: LONDONThe complaint has been common and worldwide, Central government has grown too big, too remote, too insensitive to the needs of the people, contributing to disenchantment, distrust and a desire for local power.It's a cry that long has stirred the fringes of Britain, the highlands and lowlands of Scotland, the industrial and pastoral areas of Wales, and, to a lesser extent, in England itself. For a variety of reasons, not the least of which is the growing political strength of the nationalists of Scotland and Wales, the cry is finally being heard.

title: Mady Kutsher Sets Wedding
description: Miss Mady Kutsher, a cum laude graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, and Donald Prowler, who expects to receive a master's degree in architecture next June from Penn's Graduate School of Fine Arts, will be married June 30 at Kutsber's Country Club in Monticello, N. Y.

title: 8 Killed and 3 Hurt as Car And Truck Collide Head On
description: ARTESIA, N. M., June 15 (AP) A truck and a car collided head on near here last night, kiling eight persons, including three children aged 10 to 13, and injuring three.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: U. A. W. CONSIDERS A.F.L.C.I.O. MERGER
description: DETROIT, June 15  There is serious talk again about the possibility of the United Automobile Workers union reaffiliating with the A.F.L.C.I.O.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have been deeply distressed by the hysteria; that, has gripped certain people in this country regarding the. Watergate affair. Of course, every responsible citizen is pleased to see dishonesty and highhandedness brought to light and thereby expunged. But this latest and most unreasonable attack against a person of such stature as Henry Kissinger leads me to the conclusion that it was deliberately, hypocritically devised to destroy President Nixon's only strong point, his Secretary of State.

title: Editors' Choice
description: A CRY OF ANGELS, by Jeff Fields. (Atheneum, $8.95.) A sentimental, exuberant novel about an odd lot of denizens of a Southern slum who revolt against their oppressor.

title: Israelis Apprehensive About Dependence on the U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, June 15Addressing the Israeli Parliament earlier this month, Premier Yitzhak Rabin penciled into his prepared text a pointed warning to the United States. Despite the importance of American support, the new Premier said, Israel will cling to what she regards as her vital interests even if our positions are not acceptable to the United States.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The sixstory department store formerly, owned by Ohrbach's on Makket and Halsey Streets in Newark, N. J., has been acquired for about $1million by Moysh Haddad, the president of Haddad & Sons, Inc., which operates apparel stores in Tampa and Miami, Fla., Gretna, La., and Atlanta. The building contains approximately 140,000 feet of space.

title: Conspiracy
description: The Harrisburg conspiracy trial was a curiously unsatisfying event for all concerned. The Government failed to prove its major charges of conspiracy to kidnap Henry Kissinger and to blow up Washington's steam tunnels; the defendants, two of whom were convicted on less apocalyptic charges, and the spectators did not even get the grand theater of other conspiracy trials, but a cautious, defensive struggle in which both sides seemed largely intent on cutting their losses.

title: PoliceinSchool Plan Dropped
description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIPAfter more than a year of planning and controversy, the Franklin Township Board of Educauon has decided to forgo a policemanintheschools program.

title: Miss Geri Anne Rosen Wed to Jeffrey Rubin
description: Miss Geri Anne Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rosen of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married here last evening to Jeffrey Reed Rubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Joseph Rubin of Lincolnwood, Ill. Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple EmanuEl performed the ceremony at the Park Lane.

title: Hugh Eppich Kinggery, Lawyer, Marries Urling Sibloy Cannon
description: Miss Urling Sibley Cannon, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Henry Brevoort Cannon of Hoosick, N. Y., was married yesterday to Hugh Eppich Kingery, a lawyer with the Husky Oil Company in Denver.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The President's Strategy of Delay
description: WASHINGTONA new outline for the intentions of White House strategy in the Watergateimpeachment conflict has begun to emerge through the blur of rhetoric and legal maneuver. The watchwords: delay, avoidance, diversion. The goal: survival, keeping President Nixon In office through the end of his term in 1976.

title: Child to Machnikoffs
description: A daughter was born June 6 at the Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park to Mr. and Mrs. Philip Machnikoff of Forest Hills, Queens. The child has been named Adena Gila.

title: Rubens Adoration of Magi Defaced by I.R.A. Scratch
description: LONDON, June 15Rubens's Adoration of the Magi, one of the world's most famous paintings, has been defaced in King's College Chapel, Cambridge. The initials of the Irish. Republican Army, I.R.A., were scratched in letters two feet high across the center of the large painting.

title: Quarry Bout a Crossroads for Frazier
description: Joe Frazier, who turned 30 last January, is a gapricorn.

title: ALFRED BEROL, 81, OF EAGLE PENCILS
description: Alfred C. Berol, who retired as chairman of the Berol Corpotation, formerly the Eagle Pencil Company, in 1972, died Friday in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He Was 81 years old and lived here and in Cross River N. Y.

title: David McCarthy Weds Mary Sedgwick Hahn
description: Miss Mary Sedgwick Hahn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic H. Hahn Jr. of Weston, Conn., and David Francis McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Foye McCarthy Jr. of Lowell Mass., were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev, Joseph Moore, a Roman Catholic priest, in the garden of the bride's parents' home.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: For the first time in the 96year history of the high school Regents examinations, New York's State Department of Education has canceled four statewide tests and postponed two others: It found that the answer sheets had been stolen and thousands of copies were being sold in the metropolitan area for $20 to $40 a test.

title: Restriction On Homes Opposed
description: HEMPSTEAD  You're kicking us out of this town, a spokesman for Long Islanders for Residential Rights said last week at a stormy meeting in Town Hall here at which the Hempstead Town Board unanimously voted severe restrictions regarding occupancy of onefamily homes.

title: Portugal: A Coup Is Just a Start
description: LISBONTraditionally, Portugal's national holiday on June 10 has been marked with austere military parades and speeches, but this year there was revolutionary singing, poetry, red carnations and an exuberant cortege carrying a coffin labeled Fascism which was heaved into the Tagus River.

title: Busy Slate Is Awaiting Farm Fair Enthusiasts
description: TRENTONThe season for agricultural fairs in New Jersey got under way this weekend with the Union County 4H event in Union. That fair opened on Friday and will conclude today.

title: FUNDS FOR ROADS ARE UNUSED HERE
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 Despite protests against the impoundment of Federal funds, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have failed to use a total of $103million in Federal highway funds available for the fiscal year ending June 30.

title: Lucy L. Collingwood Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Derby Jr. of New York, have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Lucy Lawrence Collingwood, to Sydney Errington Martin 3d, son of Mrs. Charles E. Ingersoll of Penllyn, Pa., and Sydney E. Martin Jr., an artist, of Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Stuyvesant Town, With Tax Reprieve, Enters New Era
description: For 25 years, residents of Stuyvesant Town put it out of their minds. We always thought of it in terms of next year, said one. Now, all of a sudden, next year is here.

title: College World Series
description: AT OMAHA, NEB.

title: The San Francisco Musicians' Revolt is Shaking the Conductor's Podium
description: WHEN you have California, you don't need Jeane Dixon. The place is one immense crystal ball that tunes us in on our own future. What happens in Berkeley, we have come to understand, sooner or later will happen in Bayside and Bronxville. Right nor, in suburbs all across America, hundreds of Pattys lie in darkened bedrooms dreaming of becoming Tanias and spraying shopping centers with machinegun fire.

title: AN APOLLO PROGRAM KEEPS SOUL IN ORBIT
description: Since rock n rollpassing through a somewhat stagnant phase in terms of innovationis looking for a new messiah and has to make do with a revived Dylan, the old faithful, black soul music is making more inroads into the marketplace. And the vitality of black soul can be stressed in the program at the Apollo Theater Black Action.

title: ExDaley Aide Is Indicted
description: CHICAGO, June 15 (AP)A Federal grand jury has indicted Mayor Richard J. Daley's former press secretary on charges that he extorted $6,500 from a psychological testing concern. The 19count indictment yesterday accused Earl Bush of demanding fees from Daniel D. Howard Associates, Inc., in exchange for helping the Chicago company get more than $1million in city contracts.

title: ProImpeachment Forces Consider Their Own Strategy
description: As the House Judiciary Committee has sat through all those hours and days of evidence on possible crimes by President Nixonin the Watergate coverup, I.T.T., enemies lists and so ona feeling has begun to develop that the narrow particulars of the criminal code are not really the stuff of Presidential impeachment, Members of Congress are seldom practitioners of criminal law artd not comfortable with the idea of administering it. But beyond that, among some participants in the committee inquiry and some close observers there is a sense that the impeachment clause of the Constitution was really meant to deal with wrongdoing of a different order.

title: Much More on Why Detroit Is Murder City
description: On April 28 the Week in Review published a story on the high murder rate in Detroit, and on its causes. In response to the article, Werner U. Spitz, M.D., the Medical Examiner of Wayne County, which includes Detroit, wrote the following comment on the hidden role of narcotics in the murder figures.

title: Avis Under the Hammer
description: The International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation has to get out of the rentacar business by Sept. 24.

title: The Uncertain Summer
description: THE face was familiar, and it was, moreover, not hard to look at. It was a face out of the Fifties, framed with blond hair that fell in cascades, splashing on the soft shoulders. Was it . . . ? Could it be . . . ? Ah, yes. It was Bardot. The unforgettable B.B., sex kitten of a more placid time, resurrected from the perfumed mothballs of semiretirement in St. Tropez.

title: A defense of family
description: If the statistics didn't tell us how common divorce has become in America, a stroll through any reasonably wellstocked department store would. The stationery counter now provides divorce announcements, printed cards that say. SPLIT in purple metallic lettering and mention coyly, that  is back in circulation at . The magazine rack carries a swinging new publication for the AllAmerican lifestyle, Marriage and Divorce. The book department is real bonanza, with a wide selection of bright how to books promising that divorce can be made not just bearable, nor even easy, but a treat for young and old alike.

title: Youth Has Way With Bees
description: When the telephone rings in the Brooklyn home of 19yearold Henry Mulzac on these flowering and fragrant June days it frequently means that the city has a bee problem and needs his help.

title: Note: A Peripatetic Presidential Pad
description: IN JANUARY, 1973, when Washington was caught up in the Watergate breakin trial and the inauguration of President Nixon, telephone subscribers in Raleigh, N.C., were receiving copies of their new directory. On the cover in full color was a photograph of the birthplace of Andrew Johnson, the 17th President of the United States and the only Chief Executive to be impeached.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PORTHCAWL, Wales, June 15 (UPI)  Carol Semple, the reigning United States champion from Pittsburgh, won the British women's amateur golf championship at Royal Porthcawl today and then disclosed she had hypnotized herself to become the first American to achieve the title double in 25 years.

title: Growing up and the serious business of survival
description: Maya Angelou writes like a song, and like the truth. The wisdom, rue and humor of her storytelling are borne on a lilting rhythm completely her own, the product of a born writer's senses nourished on black church singing and preaching, soft mother talk and salty street talk, and on literature: James Weldon Johnson, Langston Hughes, Richard Wright, Shakespeare and Gorki. Her honesty is also very much her own, even when she faces bitter facts or her own youthful foolishness. In this second installment of her autobiography, as in her much praised first book, I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings, Maya Angelou accomplishes the rare feat of laying her own life open to a reader's scrutiny without the reflexcovering gesture of melodrama or shame. And as she reveals herself so does she reveal the black community, with a quiet pride, a painful candor and clean anger.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television progrants was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Susan Clark Bride Of Andrew F. Love
description: Miss Susan Gregory Clark, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Elias Clark of New Haven, was married there yesterday afternoon to Andrew Frederick Love, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Love of Pawleys Island, S. C.

title: Dramatic Drop in Air Travel Hurts Newark's New Airport
description: NEWARK  Business is way off, said Aaron Stamper as he surveyed his empty barber shop in the concourse of Terminal A at Newark International Airport.

title: New Orleans Police Ride Buses in Wake Of Four Robberies
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 15The police tightened security measures on public transit buses this week, following the hijacking Wednesday of a bus by two gunmen who robbed the driver and passengers and abducted and raped a young woman passenger. The two men also pistolwhipped a male passenger.

title: A 24Hour Series Of Rocket Firings To Study Weather
description: A 24hour barrage of scientific rocket firings from Virginia, some of which could produce brightly colored chemical clouds visible hundreds of miles away, has been postponed to Friday, at the earliest, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced. The tests had been scheduled to start tomorrow.

title: Going, Going, Gone! Livestock and a Pail of Nails
description: SUSSEXJust as it has since the late Fred Jaeger started it in 1939, Jaeger's Livestock Auction hustles every Monday afternoon and night.

title: Legislators Get Rival Tax Plans
description: TRENTON  Although Governor Byrne's proposed taxreform program dominated the opening of the special legislative session on Thursday, there nevertheless was considerable interest in a number of rival proposals. All were cirdulated in both houses.

title: Nuptials for Anne Helen Hess And Dale Wiehoff, an Apiarist
description: Miss. Anne Helen Hess, greatgranddaughter of Julius Rosenwald, philanthropist who headed Sears, Roebuck & Co., was married at noon yesterday to Dale Wiehoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wiehoff of St. Cloud, Minn.

title: Cocker Spaniel Is Best at Bryn Mawr
description: MALVERN, Pa., June 15The cocker spaniel with the most victories in the United States in 1973 and so far this year was named best of 1,639 dogs today at the 54th annual show of the Bryn Mawr Kennel Club on the grounds of the Radnor Hunt Club.

title: Red Smith
description: The world's greatest baseball team pro tem descended on Shea Stadium Friday evening looking a trifle green about the gills after losing three times in a row to the St. Louis Cardinals, but a couple of hours in the stimulating company of the New York Mets did world of good. Tommy John, the biggest winner among National League pitchers, threw a sixhitter for his 10th victory in 11 decisions; Tom Paciorek, who does clubhouse impersonations of John Wayne and Liberace, did an onthefield imitation of Jimmy Wynn by driving in two runs with a triple and single, and the Los Angeles Dodgers were back on the rails with a wonandlost record of 4319 at 694more than 100 points higher than any other team and higher than any National League pennantwinner in 65 years.

title: Resignation in Protest: Is It Meaningful?
description: An aide once remarked of John Foster Dulles, I saw the Secretary of State sitting in his office, wrestling with his conscience. Of course, he won. American government officials, especially the President's official family, are expected to have their consciences under strict control. Loyalty, not ethical autonomy or resignation, is the name of the game, Paul Nitze's decision to quit the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks negotiating team last week is clearly an exception.

title: Lately, the Playhouse Is the Thing
description: BEFORE the summer's out, some 440,000 people will have made the trip to Stratford, Ont., to take in two, four or six of the plays currently playing or in preparation at the Canadian Shakespeare Festival. Of these, approximately 45 per cent will be from the United States, more than half will arrive either in their own or in hired automobiles, a whacking 80 per cent will have used one or another form of motorized transportwhat with buses making the trek all the way from Texas and California. The phenomenon has been going on and growing, for 21 years.

title: Poland, Italy, Netherlands Score in World Cup Soccer
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, June 15Showing a fast, dangerous offense, but a vulnerable defense, Poland subdued Argentina, 32, here at Nectar Stadium in Group Three competition of the soccer World Cup today.

title: Strip Mining Plan And Prison Project Blocked in Virginia
description: LOUISA, Va., June 15Conservationists have apparently scored a double victory in this rural county in Virginia's Piedmont area.

title: PUPILS GIVE HELP TO FRESH AIR FUND
description: By noon the gymnasium was a mess. Lather was all over the spot where Gunther Hofele, Stephan Braverman and David Stutman were running their Shave the Balloon concession, with David's father's safety razor.

title: 19 Make Bows in Rye At the 36th Cotillion
description: The 36th annual Westchester Cotillion was held last night at the Shenorock Shore Club in Rye, N. Y. Mrs. Edward H. Pennell and Mrs. William H. Todd were cochairmen for the event, at which 19 young women were presented.

title: ABRAHAM KAREN NASA OFFICIAL, 63
description: Abraham Karen, a consultant on technological matters to the New York City Budget Department, died yesterday in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 6.3 years old and lived at 907 Prince Street, Teaneck, N. J.

title: Camera World News: More Courses
description: ASERIES of eightweek courses in photography, all geared to teaching beginners as well as advanced students how to work with professional techniques and equipment, are being conducted by Bernard Hoffman's Photography Workshop in Freehold, N.J. (about on hour's drive from New York).

title: Tigers' Rally In 9th Tops Royals, 119
description: DETROIT, June 15 (AP)Aurelio Rodriguez twoout, threerun homer topped fiverun rally in the ninth inning and gave the Detroit Tigers an 119 victory over the Kansas City Royals today.

title: AARON SKINDER
description: Aaron Skinder, publisher of The New Jersey Law Journal for 35 years, died Friday in Clara Maass Memorial Hospital, Belleville, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived at 173 South Orange Avenue, South Orange, N.J.

title: Thank Heaven for Little Leagues
description: There is Joy in Mudville  Joy Smith, and she is the first baseperson or perhaps the shortstop on the Little League team, courtesy of the march of history as recognized by Little League headquarters in Williamsport, Pa.

title: Wheaton President to Leave
description: NORTON, Mass., June 15 (AP)William C. H. Prentice, president of Wheaton College since 1962, will leave his post at the end of June 1975, the women's college has announced. Mr. Prentice, a former Rhodes Scholar, was also president of Swarthmore College.

title: Nixon Warmly Welcomed On Arriving in Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 15President Nixon was given a arge, friendly welcome here today, and for the first time since the ArabIsraeli war of 1967, the American flag flew in this ancient capital of Syria.

title: Magalen Crane Wed at Home
description: Miss Magalen Ohrstrom Crane, daughter of William Carey Crane Jr. of Barataria, Riverside, Conn., and Mrs. John Carlyle Herbert Bryant of Locust Hill, Middleburg, Va., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to James Frederick Webert, son of Mrs. James Frederick Webert of Lincoln, Neb., and the late Mr. Webert.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Last Week's Tally for Metropolitan Area Senate

title: Mrs. Copp Married
description: Mrs. Madeline Duke Copp of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Ralph Martin, Gibbs of Darien, Conn. The Rev.. Edwin A. Lane of the Unitarian Church of Westport performed the ceremony at the home of the bride, who is the daughter of Mrs. Paul. Duke of Duke Center, Pa., and the late Mr. Duke. The bride and bridegroom have been previously married and divorced, Mr. Gibbs has his own marketing and consulting business.

title: FORD CAMPAIGNS FOR G.O.P. UPSTATE
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 15Heralded by phalanxes of Secret Servicemen and with state troopers posted on roof tops, Vice President Ford helped the fundraising efforts of in cumbent Republican Congress men in three upstate district today, at their request.

title: Word seminar
description: ACROSS

title: Belmont Track Is Firm
description: Just before yesterday's 17th running of the Bowling Green Handicap at Belmont Park, Frank Catrone, trainer of Ada L. Rice's consistent 5yearold stallion Take Off, said all his horse needed to become a top contender was a firm track.

title: The Michelangelo of Bakers
description: SINGAC  Take any Sunday in June, and Joseph Farnese Jr., proprietor of the Farnese Bakery, designs and bakes six to eight wedding cakes before calling it a day. To a baker who sees himself as a sculptor, this month's demands are the most taxing of the year.

title: Big Puddles, $20, Wins at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., June 15 Big Puddles scored a convincing, fourlength victory today in the 10th running of the PostDeb Stakes for 3yearold fillies at a distance of one mile and 70 yards.

title: Radio, TV Hurt Choir In Vienna
description: VIENNAThe cultural effects of radio, television and recordings are hampering an institution that traces its history back to 1498a choral group known as the Vienna Choir Boys.

title: City Hail Marijuana Stolen
description: WEIPPE, Idaho, June 15 (UPI)  The police have confirmed the theft of two marijuana plants that were being grown by the department in city hall so that local residents could learn to identify the plant.

title: Dane
description: ONCE more into the breach dear friends, once more! Eliot Feld is trying again. After an earlier failure to maintain his on dance company, which he started in 1969 and disbanded, some two and a half years slater, Feld is at it once more. Why? Does he have any more chance this time than he had last? Who needs him and his company anyway? These are questions of pertinent impertinence.

title: Political Reform Is Completed by Jordan
description: JERSEY CITY  With the election of Bernard Hartnett Jr. as the new chairman of the Hudson County Democratic organization, a campaign begun by his father 25 years ago has finally been completed. The objective was to topple the bossridden machine created by the late Mayor Frank Hague.

title: New Format Cuts Traffic For Shows
description: It worked beautifully.

title: VACATED SCHOOL A PROBLEM ON L.I.
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I., June 15The PlainviewOld Bethpage school district, which plans to close four school buildings because of dwindling enrollment, has learned that a client who had been expected to lease the first school to be closed had decided not to.

title: Nixon's Gift for Sadaf: A White House Copier
description: CAIRO, June 15 (UPI)President Nixon has given President Anwar elSadat of Egypt one of the White House helicopters, Egyptian officials report.

title: State Is Rushing New Regents' Tests
description: Printers at the State Department of Education were ordered into overtime yesterday to produce thousands of copies of replacements for two highschool Regents examinations  following the disclosure that answer sheets for six Regents tests were known to be widely available for sale in the state.

title: Mansfield Says That Kissinger Is ThinSkinned on Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)  Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, the majority leader, said today that Secretary of State Kissinger was a little thinskinned when it came to criticism.

title: Chancellor: From a Respectable Second to a Tie for First
description: ANY discussion of a TVnews anchorman's image is sensitive. It's a reminder of how certain aspects of the TV news business are rooted in show business. But the discussion is also unavoidable. The anchorman who doesn't prove competitive in the Nielsen ratings is quietly but firmly retired from the scene of his crime. Whatever the nobility of journalistic purpose, the ratings are crucial. That is why one of the more interesting stories of the year so far is John Chancellor.

title: Is Food Dropping Out of the Inflation Parade?
description: For the American consumer, the cost of food has historically been a relatively small part of the cost of liveing. In 1960, for example, food consumed about 20 per cent of the average family's disposable income. Ten years later the figure had dropped to 15 per cent.

title: Makarios Begins Campaign in Cyprus Against Terrorists Advocating Union With Greece
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 10Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, has begun a campaign to rid the island of a terrorist group that advocates union with Greece.

title: Noncontenders Also Have Their Faithful Followers
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 15Long before Arnie's Army, Jack's Pack and Lannie's Fannies started following their heroes today, Bruce's Brigade had covered a lot of ground in the third round of the United States Open.

title: Miss Harding Wed To Fredric Press
description: Miss Susan Fern Harding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cornelius Harding of Winnetka, Ill was married yesterday afternoon to Fredric Alan Press, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Press of New York. The bridegroom is with the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood.

title: Surge Hanover Nose Victor
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 15 Surge Hanover, a 301 shot, earned more money tonight than in his entire previous trotting career with a stirring victory in the $112,380 Dexter Cup at Rooseveit Raceway. His margin was a nose.

title: Center in Santa Barbara Elects Three to Its Board
description: Three new members were elected yesterday to the board of directors of the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions in Santa Barbara, Calif., it was announced by the Center's president, Dr. Malcolm Moos.

title: Headliners
description: They were held captive by members of the Irish Republican Army for four days, and many feared they were dead, But now they're free again and the Earl and Countess of Donoughmore are almost blas about their abduction, The 71yearold Irish peer and his 68yearold wife were released after five sailed I.R.A. members gave up their hunger strikes last week. You are in luck their captors told them. Anyway, insisted the Earl, the experience wasn't terribly unpleasant. Apart from being bashed at the start, he said, we were treated extremely well.

title: ITALY SHAKING UP SECURITY FORCES
description: ROMEThe Italian Government has begun a shakeup of its numerous security forces in the wake of a series of political kidnappings and bombings, many of which remain unsolved.

title: RAIN WASHES OUT CORN CROP RECORD
description: CHICAGO, June 15  Late spring rains of unusual intensity battered cornfields this week along a 100milewide band that stretched across the heart of the Corn Belt.

title: Miss M'Carthy, A Law Student, Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Sheryl Yvette McCarthy, who is entering her second year at the Columbia Law School, plans to be married in August to Clinton Altemont Townsend, an associate with the law firm of Otterbourgh, Steindler, Houston & Rosen here.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE 20 NATIONS negotiating monetary reform reached an eightpoint agreement. It sets up a facility for lending to nations affected by rising energy costs and establishes rules for managing floating currencies... The Group 10 agreed on the use of gold as collateral for government borrowing.

title: Harvard Crew Beats Wisconsin
description: MILWAUKEE, June 15Twice postponed because of rough water, eventually rowed at dusk and shortened to 1,500 meters, the race billed locally as The Race of the Century finally was completed tonight with Harvard's undefeated Eastern, sprint champions defeating Wiscon, sin's intercollegiate champion heavyweight varsity crew by a boat length and 1.2 seconds.

title: Mrs. Gandhi for Test Ban If Everybody Else Agrees
description: NEW DELHI, June 15Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India was agreeable to a ban on all atomic tests if everybody else agrees to it.

title: RETARDED INMATE OF PRISON FREED
description: AMHERST, Mass., June 15An effort by University of Massachusetts students to free a 29yearold mentally retarded man from prison succeeded this week.

title: Catharine Dixie Miller Is Bride Of Joep Marinus J. de Koning
description: Miss Catharine Dixie Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Miller of New Canaan, Conn., and Lyford Cay, the Bahamas, was married in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church, New Canaan, yesterday afternoon to Joep Marinus Johannes de Koning, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johannes H. J. de Koning of Ardenhout, the Netherlands, and Tarragona, Spain.

title: South Korea Trial Strains Japan Ties
description: TOKYO, June 15The senior Japanese official toyed with his lunch a moment, then said thoughtfully and without bitterness: The Koreans broke a promise they made to us, at least in spirit.irritations that jeopardize the relations between the two na. tions. Recent conversations here and in Seoul indicated that the tensions were serious.

title: The World /Continued
description: In the clearest statement yet of Portugal's new policy for the decolonization of her African territories, President Antonio de Spinola last week set out a cautious fourstage process: restoration of peace, accelerated reconstruction and development, establishment of democratic institutions and popular consultation on the ultimate solution. The clear implicationno independence nowis likely to please neither President Spfnola's main supporters at home nor colonial rebel forces.The President said the people of Angola, Mozambique and GuineaBissau would be able to choose from among federation, confederation, commonwealth or the simple existence of totally independent states. It was his first use of the word independent; previously he had spoken of selfdetermination.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 16, 1974

title: Jo Anne Poole Fiancee
description: Miss Jo Anne Poole, a flutist, and Jeffrey Wood Bartlett, who is with the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, plan to marry this autumn. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James J. Poole, parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Bartlett. Both families live in Port Washington, L. I.

title: Accountant Says Nixon Has Filed 1973 Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)  As the 60day extension for President Nixon to file his 1973 Federal income tax return expired today, his accountant said the return had been filed within the last several weeks.

title: James Mumma Weds Miss Boland
description: Miss Joanne Noel Boland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Boland of New York and Spring Lake, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon in Ellicott City, Md., to James Mark Mumma, son of Mrs. Mark H. Mumma of Mount Joy, Pa., and the late Mr. Mumma.

title: Rent Law Explained
description: Nevi York State's new law governing apartment rents is complex and controversial. A series of questions and answers about the law appears on Page 43.

title: QUEBEC AIRPORTS BECOME BILINGUAL
description: MONTREAL, June 15In a controversial move of symbolic importance, the Canadian Ministry of Transport has decided to let pilots flying over some Quebec airports communicate with radio control towers in French as well as English.

title: Television
description: CHARLES Sackrey, a former teacher of economics, is building a cabin in the woods. It is about 25 yards from the twostory home in Haydenville, Mass., which he shares with his family. When completed, the cabin will be exclusively for the use of Sackrey's wife, Pat. It will be a clearing in the woods where Pat Sackrey can retreat to read, to write, to sit around and look at the walls. Such a retreat may make the difference, in Pat's words, between splitting up entirely or living as a regular nuclear family.

title: The Region
description: Republicans, threatened with losing control of the New York State government, and Democrats, with their best chance in 15 years of gaining it, both reverted to form in choosing their candidates last week. The Republicans were all smiles and the Democrats only a little less contentious than usual.

title: Spanish Bus Plunge Kills
description: MADRID, June 15 (AP)A nun, a teacher and a 7yearold girl died yesterday and 48 persons were injured when a bus carrying 70 schoolchildren and their teachers rolled down al 75foot embankment north of here, the police said.

title: 2 PH.D.'S IN TEXAS SEEK HOUSE SEAT
description: KERRVILLE, Tex., June 15Two bachelor Ph.D.'s are getting started on campaigns to succeed Representative O. C. Fisher of San Angelo, who is not seeking reelection after 32 years in the House of Representatives.

title: Pearson on Pole For Today's 400
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., June 15 (UPI)David Pearson of Spartanburg, S.C., who has won the last three NASCAR Grand National stock car races at Michigan International Speedway, took the pole position today for tomorrow's running of the Motor State 400.

title: Ocean Law . . .
description: The Law of the Sea Conference which opens tomorrow in Caracas offers a critical test of mankind's capacity, to submerge traditional divisive national prejudices in common search for law and justice on a global scale. At stake is that 70 per cent of the earth's surface which is covered by water, an area encompassing vast food and mineral resources and providing vital commercial and military links among the nations.

title: Least Said Soonest Mended
description: The real issue raised by Secretary Kissinger's threat to resign was, that of U.S. national security. What means, it is inferentially asked, can justifiably be used to insure that state secrets are not leaked at the expense of the nation's safety or at the risk of embarrassing relations with allies or negotiations with foreign governments?

title: Miss Tower Bride of T.D. Thacher 2d
description: Miss Frances Fell Tower, a descendant of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt and Anthony J. Drexel, the Philadelphia banker, was married yesterday afternoon in the Bedford (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church to Thomas Day Thacher 2d, who graduated with the class of '74 from the Fordham Law School.

title: Atlantic Ave. Zoning Plan Backed at Public Hearing
description: A dozen neighborhood and professional groups from the downtown Brooklyn area gave warm endorsement last week to a proposal before the City Planning Commission to establish special zoning controls over a sevenblock stretch of Atlantic Avenue.

title: Condominium Form Spreading in the City
description: Only a few years after its appearance in metropolitan area residential developments, the condominium concept is spreading to ever more intricate real estate ventures.

title: Morris County Central Is Ready To Roll Again
description: NEWFOUNDLAND  Late last summer, the Morris County Central, a touristhauling, steampowered railroad that had operated out of Whippany for nine years, decided to relocate in this rural North Jersey community. However, since moving here lock, stock and steam locomotives, the little line has encountered resistance from local residents and various regulatory bodies.

title: Photography
description: IN his new book, Drums of Life: A Photographic Essay on the Black Man in America (Anchor, $5.95 paperback), Chester Biggins Jr. extends signincanny the personal documentation he began with his first book, Black Woman.

title: Liechtenstein Needs Police
description: VADUZ, Liechtenstein, June 15 (Reuters)Liechtenstein is advertising for four more policmen to bring her security force up to 40 men, The police must keep order among 22,400 inhabitants in the 62squaremile principality between Switzerland and Austria.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The article, Another Defeat for Dugan (May 26), gives muchneeded publicity to a move by State Senator James P. Dugan, Democrat of Hudson and chairman of the State Democratic Committee, to ram through the Legislature a bill imposing a 50day iraiting period before a voter, on switching parties, could vote in a prirnary his new party.

title: SUMMER BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Despite an uncertain economy and a rapidly growing rate of inflation, swimming pool sales have taken a sharp upturn this season, particularly in the Northeast where gasoline shortages and pollution seem to be discouraging people from traveling to the beaches.

title: Child to Mrs. Landsman
description: A daughter was born on May 16 to Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence Landsman of Waterville, Me., at the Thayer Hospital there.

title: The Long Italian Search For Order
description: ROMEItaly, once the postwar economic miracle of Europe, is now the sick man of Europe. Why?

title: Law School Dean Named
description: STORRS, Conn., June 15 (AP) Phillip I. Blumberg, a professor at Boston University School of Law, has been named dean of the University of Connecticut Law School. Mr. Blumberg will assume his new post next fall, according to the university's president, Glenn Ferguson.

title: Beanie Keeps a Tight Rein on SecondEchelon Jobs
description: Mayor Beanie rarely lets hi administrators pick their own top teams, but he doessome times reluctantly  let ther veto the people City Hall send over.

title: Few States Protect Condominium Buyers
description: WASHINGTON, June 15In all but a handful of states, consumers caught up in the booming condominium market can expect little protection against deception or fraud under the real estate laws.

title: Ryan Fans 19
description: ANAHEIM, June 15 (AP)  Nolan Ryan struck out 19 Boston batters in a 15inning marathon last night and came close to establishing two records  the most striker outs in an extrainning game and a personal mark for number of pitches in a single game.

title: AMERICAN SOCCER LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Johnny Still Can't Read Very Well
description: Those who leave school unable to read well go through life like cripples, not blind, but blinded. Simple tasks, like filling out job applications, writing to a friend, or even deciphering train schedules and street signs, are major hurdles.

title: Liberals Nominate Morrison, ExLindsay Aide, for Governor
description: The State Committee of the Liberal party yesterday chose former Deputy Mayor Edward A. Morrison, a Lindsay aide, as the party's candidate for Governor.

title: Lisbon Imposes Curbs on News Media
description: LISBON, June 15  Greater restraints over Portugal's news media were being instituted today as high Government sources made it clear that the freewheeling and somewhat anarchic days that followed the military coup of April 25 are over and that an effort to instill discipline is under way.

title: Anne C. Price Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warner W. Price Jr, of Smyrna and Rehoboth Beach, Del., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Carroll Price, to David Fielder Eaton. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Eaton of West Simsbury, Conn., and East Orleans, Mass.

title: Free Tests Planned For Blood Pressure
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The Department of Community. Medicine of the Rutgers Medical School will be giving free bloodpressure tests this summer to New Brunswick residents 14 years old and over.

title: Woman Gets H.U.D. Post
description: Mrs. Mary Burke Nicholas, a program analyst, was appointed regional economist of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development yesterday. She is the first woman in the department to hold that position. Originally from Tuskegee, Ala., the 44yearold Mrs. Nicholas has worked for city and Federal housing agencies for 14 years. She lives in Manhattan with a son and daughter.

title: Borg Tops Solomon; Orantes Is Winner
description: PARIS, June 15The string tan out today for Harold Solomon. His astonishing march through the French open tennis championships was halted by Bjorn Borg, the Swedish prodigy, 64, 26, 62, 61, over two hours and yet, for a great part of the way, the courageous little American played better than When he had upset topseeded Ilie Nastase in the quarterfinals.

title: Harbor Policeman Drowned
description: The body of a 44yearold police officer assigned to the harbor unit was taken from the water near Battery Park yesterday after he apparently drowned. The police identified the officer as Thomas Eide, 19year veteran of the force who had been assigned to the harbor unit since 1962. He had gone out alone to work on boat engine at Pier A about 11:30 P.M. His body was recovered near the boat about 2:45 AN., the police said.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time toappear in Section 2:

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, June 15  Leftist demonstrators, trying to prevent a rightist meeting from taking place clashed with policemen in what the police described as the most vicious street battle here in years.

title: Mrs. Reed Is Wed to Clarence Gehman
description: Mrs. Dorothy Willison Reed of Pittsburgh and Wainscott, L. L, and Clarence Harvey Gehman of New York were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Robert Battle in the Bridgehampton (L. L) Presbyterian Church.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Under one name or another, Hugh Pentecost turns out book after book after book. His latest is BARGAIN WITH DEATH (Dodd, Mead, $4.95), and it features th hotel manager Pierre Chambrun. This is about the death of a financier (in Chambrun's hotel, alas), oil deals, a kidnapped heir, missing documents that could alter the balance of power. As are all of Pentecost's books, this is easy to read  and why shouldn't it be? It is written in what amounts to Basic English.

title: Suffolk Politicans Off and Running
description: BLUE POINT  Perry Belmont Duryea Jr. stood in a corner of a room at Republican headquarters here last week and discussed the 1974 election campaign.

title: President's Jet Veers As MIG's Surprise Pilot
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 15 (Reuters)  The pilot of President Nixon's plane took evasive action today after being surprised by two Sovietbuilt MIG's sent out to escort the Presidential jet into Damascus.

title: Women Earn Money by Planting Forests for the Future
description: WISDOM, Mont.  They stood there on the mountainside tall and dark and silent for generations. Some were seedlings when Lewis and Clark trekked through. They were larger during the Indian wars in the valley below. And by the time the highway was built, many were mature pines, their fibers tough and strongand unused.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two persons remained in poor condition and another three in fair condition yesterday after an explosion Friday night at the Connecticut Aerosols, Inc., packaging plant in Milford. Twenty employes were injured, authorities said.Fire Chief William Healey said a fire that touched off the explosion may have been caused by vapors from chemicals used in packaging aerosol products. Timothy Brown, 18 years old, and Michael Robinson, 17, both Milford, were taken to YaleNew Haven Hospital and were on the danger list suffering from severe multiple burns. The police said about 60 people were in the plant when the explosion occurred.

title: Gardens
description: IF one has been an active grandparent for 16 years and more, and reached the dignified age of three score years and ten (we have), one contemplates the many benefits of moving into an apartment or condominium. We did.

title: Nursery At Hofstra To Close
description: HEMPSTEADDespite the outstanding reputation of its nursery program, Hofstra University is closing its Child Development Center, an action that is being strongly protested by the parents of the 60 3, 4 and 5yearolds enrolled in the program as well as state education authorities.

title: ABORTION CURBS SIGNED BY WILSON
description: ALBANY, June 15Governor Wilson signed into law today a bill placing restrictions on the state's fouryearold abortion law.

title: Camden Seeking to Become a Mecca of Verse
description: CAMDEN  This city, known heretofore for its soup output, is trying to become the poetry capital of the world.

title: New Judgeships Have Wide Effects
description: Three newly appointed Court of Claims judges from Queens, Nassau and Suffolk recently went back to law school  Fordham Law for several days of briefings on their new jobs, handling drug cases under the state's stiff new narcotics law.

title: Letters: Of Lemmings And the Midnight Sun
description: To the Editor: The North Cape of Norway is an even more curious place than R. V. Denenberg describes in The Land of the Midnight Tan (Travel Section, June 2). In the first place, it looks like the dumping ground for the debris left over from building a continent  not manmade debris, but odds and ends of stubble and scree and blocks and boulders, as if God had grown tired of building Europe and had shoved all the leftover material onto a remote spot.

title: Brooklyn Hasidim Fighting Districting
description: The 35,000member Hasidic community in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn is strongly protesting the new reapportionment plan passed by the Legislature late last month that would virtually halve the community's voting power.

title: Book Ends
description: R. C. & J. Add new small publishers. This one is called Reed, Cannon & Johnson Communications Company, after its three primemovers, Ishmael Reed, Steve Cannon and Joe Johnson, all of whom are writers themselves. And that is the idea motivating the company: to have writers publishing other writers. Mr. Reed, a novelist (Mumbo Jumbo), feels that commercial publishers are ignoring good writing, especially of the experimental kind; the purpose of R. C. & J. is to remedy that failing. Their first effort is a novel, Francisco, by Alison Mills, a 22yearold black actress (she played the babysitter on the television series Julie). It's in a trade paperback edition that sells for $3.95, and is described as being about the lifestyles and love affairs, put ups and put downs of upper black and white Bohemia on the West Coast. A portion of the novel appeared in Yardbird, a little magazine of which Mr. Reed was a cofounder emanating from California. Yardbird (named after jazz musician Charlie Parker), which comes out twice a year, was started as a vehicle for black writers but Mr. Reed says that the magazine is now interested in publishing writers of all hues and is trying to capture the multicultural makeup of California. The next issue will have AsianAmerican culture as its theme.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The world food problem we are so sharply aware of today shares with most other socalled crises a curious duality: it was at once foreseeable and foreseen but still unrecognizable until the last minute.

title: Two Handicap Plans Offered in Tennis
description: One of these days, when you are waiting to play tennis at a club or park, somebody may come up to you and say, If you need a partner, I'm a 220.

title: Wing South Takes Liberty Bell Feature
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP)Wing South, owned by Mary Kowit and Irv Udell, made one big move leaving the backstretch, then turned the $28,500 Patriot Stakes into a romp at Liberty Bell race track today before a crowd of 12,933.

title: Polly Corroon Married To Kenneth S. Rattner
description: Miss Polly Larkin Corroon and Kenneth Sheldon Rattner were married yesterday afternoon by Msgr. Henri I. Foltz in St. Joseph'sontheBrandywine Roman Catholic Church in Greenville, Del.

title: Village Is the Site Of a Victorian Fair
description: MILLVILLEThe Wheaton Historical Association of Millville is sponsoring a Victorian Fair at Wheaton Village from June 30 through July 7.

title: RADIATION FEARED AT CONED'S PLANT
FirstStrike Threat
description: The 48to37 Senate vote to develop more accurate and powerful strategic missile warheads was undoubtedly motivated by a desire to assure American security. But the new warheads, which could provide a capability for destroying the bulk of Russia's ICBM's in their underground silos, are more certain to reduce American and world security by making nuclear war likelier than ever.

title: Mrs. Apgar Rewed
description: Mrs. Kathryn Hanson Lattin Apgar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Parker Lattin Jr. of Houston, was married yesterday afternoon to John Gates Martin of Hartford and Darien, Conn. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Gates Martin of Rockville Centre, L. I. The Rev. James Wilson of Grace Episcopal Church in Plainfield, N. J., performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Laidlaw of Plainfield. The bride's previous marriage was terminated by divorce.

title: Vandalism Plaguing Schools
description: MANALAPAN TOWNSHIP On opening the Millbrook School here one Monday in April, janitors found the building so badly vandalized that officials hastily closed it and declared an unexpected holiday.

title: Marijuana Penalties May Be Relaxed
description: TRENTONA special legislative commission may recommend this fall the elimination of harsh penalties for the possession of small amounts of marijuana.

title: Labor Department Gives Rules on Pay for Students
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) Colleges and universities may hire students in unlimited, numbers at 85 per cent of the minimum wage, the Labor Department says.

title: Graduates of a Nursing Class Have Varied Backgrounds
description: Ten men, including a middleaged businessman and a veteran, and three women, all licensed practical nurses in their 60's, received their associate degrees in nursing last week, along with 180 other graduates, at Queensborough Community College in Bayside.

title: Fuel Crisis Doubted in Poll
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., June 15 (AP)Sixtynine per cent of the New England members of an auto club who responded to a survey said they thought the gasoline shortage was a hoax. Twentysix per cent who participated in the A.L.A. Auto and Travel Club survey said they believed the shortage was real. The rest were undecided.

title: Fishermen Seek to Curb Foreign Ships
description: TOMS RIVERDrastic depletions in fish stocks are alarming New Jersey commercial and sports fishermen. As a result, they are leading a fight to induce Congress to prevent foreign trawlers from coming any closer than 200 miles to the state's coastline.

title: How to Make New Popping Plug, Nantucket Rabbit
description: The popping plug is, if you will, the surf fisherman's equivalent of the dry fly, a lure fished on the surface that enables him to see the fish strike.

title: People and Business
description: A North Bergen company believes that public concern over the conservation of electrical energy is having a definite impact on the sales of the products it manufactures.

title: The Tribulations of the Father Of a 5 Year Old Hockey Star
description: The alarm clock scrambles my head as if a puck has struck me. I look at the time6:30 A.M. My mouth tastes as if brown paper bags had been wedged in it overnight. But I will persevere. After all, there are 75,000 others like me across the United States. We are going to take our boys to their first hockey clinic,

title: Crafts Show: New and Vigorous, But Tradition's Impact Is Solid
description: TORONTO  It's an awesome exhibition, the largest ever assembled of crafts from throughout the world.

title: Food
description: Crostini dello chef

title: Miss Scott Is Bride Of Edward Webster
description: Miss Patricia Jeanne Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis D. Scott of Greenwich, Conn., and Edward Slater Webster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Webster of Ambler, Pa., were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Jaines R. MacColl 3d in St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Whiteinarsh, Pa.

title: Syria Regains Some Land Evacuated by the Israelis
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 15 The Syrian Army returned today to part of the land lost to Israel in the war last October.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Times
description: Incoming Passenger and Mall Ships

title: Matra first, Porsche 2d At Le Mans
description: LE MANS, June 15They survived an attack by helicopters and a week's case of diarrhea only to be done in by a $2.50 piece of plastic the size of a silver dollar.

title: A's Trounce Yanks, 91, On Rudi, Bando Homers
description: OAKLAND, June 15Even though it was Bat Day and the A's hadn't won too many games in recent days, Oakland Colisuem was a relatively mild place today during and after the A's 91 victory over the Yankees.

title: Sunday Observer
description: One of the last great bargains in the age of 35cent candy bars and 65cent gasoline is crime.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Burlington County K. C. allbreed and obedience, Doughboy Field, Fort Dix, N. J.; 1,483 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Nature Not So Motherly For SkiYachting Races.
description: DENVER, June 15Where inJune in the United States could you plan to ski and sail on the same day? In Colorado's mountains, about 70 miles west of Denver, where the seventh North American skiyachting championship races were held last weekend.

title: Harper & Row Employes Set to Strike
description: Dissident employes of Harper & Row, where a strike is planned for Monday, have begun efforts to get buyers to boycott the company's books, an official of the Association of Harper & Row Employes said yesterday.

title: The image is unclear
description: For those of us who worry that the current preoccupation with American ethnicity, which seems here to stay, may degenerate into ethnocentricity and further polarize the nation, the spate of good books being published in the field by capable (and readable) scholars is a reassuring sign. In this respect, the Italian Americans have fared especially well in recent years, with a number of excellent studies, notably Joseph Lopreato's Italian Americans in 1970 and Alexander De Conde's Half Bitter, Half Sweet in 1971.

title: Watson Takes Over Lead in Open on 69213
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 15The answer was in the mirror all the time. Tom Watson looked at himself in his motelroom mirror and figured it out: He was addressing the ball with too much weight on his right foot.

title: Tribute to Bobby Jones Today on No. 18
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 15Bobby Jones sank a I2foot putt at the 72d hole of the 1929 United States Open to tie Al Espinosa and force a title playoff that Jones won at Winged Foot Golf Club, where the 74th Open is being held this week.

title: Ballet: Shining Promise 16YearOld Nina Fedorov Excels As Sacred Love in Illuminations
description: In ballet, stars are never born, they slowly emerge. But at the New York State Theater Friday night it was impossible not to notice the shining promise of Nina Fedorov. The 16yearold Miss Fedorov joined New York City Ballet this season from the School of American Ballet, and here she was dancing Sacred Love in the season's first performance of Frederick Ashton's Illuminations.

title: Mets Beat Dodgers For Koosman, 41
description: The New York Mets shook off their aches and pains long enough yesterday to score a 41 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers, which is nice work if you can get it these days.

title: GURNEY'S '73 INCOME REPORTED TO DROP
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 15 (AP)  Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, earned $23,348 less in 1973 than he did in 1972, according to a report in a Jacksonville newspaper based on his 1973 income tax returns.

title: Norton Simon at a Glance
description: *In thousands.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONConfronted by what promises to be a record number of bills, the Assembly's Democratic leadership is determined to prevent the special session on tax reform from becoming immersed in any more legislation than is necessary.

title: In Virginia, a Scenic Gift for Passersby
description: WALTER H. MISENHEIMER, 80, is a gnome of a man, goateed, leathertanned and given to philosophizing: Most senior citizenshe pronounces the phrase sarcasticallyspend too much time looking over the fence and thinking things are better somewhere else. There's always something worthwhile in your own backyard.

title: Business Program Shows Gain In Job Placements for Young
description: With two weeks still to go in a drive to place 20,000 young people in summer jobs, the New York chapter of the National Alliance of Businessmen reported last week that 17,000 pledges of jobs had been received.

title: Postscript
description: Paul N. RosensteinRodan has been adviser on development to the governments of Italy and India, as well as to that of Eduardo Frei in Chile. He is Director of the Center for Latin American Development Studies at Roston University. This article is in part a summary of two lectures he, gave at the Center, and published in Challenge, a magazine of economic affairs.

title: Puns and anagrams
description: ACROSS

title: Test of Loyalty
description: This book, the author tells us, began as a project and became a way of life. The trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony Russo Jr., might have remained simply another episode in the history of antiwar dissent. It became much more, due to Governmental ineptitude, Governmental turpitude and Watergatethe last being a classic example of what happens when ineptitude and turpitude join forces.

title: Pilic Sharp as Sets Post 2421 Victory
description: BALTIMORE, June 15 (UPI) Nikki Pilic sparked the New York Sets to a 2421 World Team Tennis victory over the Baltiniore Banners tonight before an announced crowd of 1,709.

title: Magoon Eyes 1,257Mile Offshore Dash
description: Take an open 40foot speedboat with a pair of 500horsepower engines aft; drive it into the Gulf Stream off Miami Beach; head north for New York, 1,257 miles away, and open the throttles.

title: Make a Joyful Noise Unto the Lord!
description: Anyone who ever heard the magnificent voice of gospel singer Mahalia Jackson knows what an inspiring artist she was. Although she died in 1972, at the age of 60, Miss Jackson hasleft us with her message still alive on her recordings. This biography details the course of her life from her early years in New Orleans, where she first impressed people with her singing at age 5, through her triumphs all over the world and her brave participation in the civil rights movement.

title: New poetry made a little less private
description: By Mary Baron. 32 pp.

title: Summit, N.J., Rider Is Off To France
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 15Until four years ago, Michele McEvoy never had ridden a jumper. Today, she departs for France where she will compete in the women's world championships during the LaBaule horse show June 30July 7. And she will be one of the favorites.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, JUNE 16, 1974
description: International

title: In Cold Print: Is Nancy Drew Sexist?
description: Not long ago the morning mail brought three documents. First, a speech by Verne Moberg on the advantages of feminist selfpublishing. Second, an anonymous letter detailing the rough road traveled by black editors in white publishing houses. And third, A Proposal for a New Independent Publishing Venture, The Ramp Company, founded by former Random House editor John Simon.

title: The Nation
description: President Nixon, who has made no Secret of his distaste for most television journalism, may have a particular antipathy for the noncommercial variety: It was public T.V. that carried the Senate Watergate hearings at prime time, and that will probably devote the peak viewing hours to whatever may be televised of the House impeachment debate and, if it comes to that, the Senate trial.

title: Picnic Site Is Sought For the Handicapped
description: All's well that ends well, if it ends well, and that remained unresolved this weekend as city officials and representatives of an organization aiding the handicapped attempted to reach a compromise on a midsummer picnic in Forest Park, Queens.

title: Wilson Faces Fight for Conservative Bid
description: The Conservative party's State Committee designated Governor Wilson yesterday as its candidate for Governor, but he faces the possibility of a fight for the nomination in the Sept. 10 primary.

title: Sue Horrvich Engaged to Alan Loring
description: Miss Sue Horrvich and Alan Gary Loring plan to marry Aug. 4 in Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Peasants know perfectly well where babies come from
description: An imaginary scene: Whacka, whacka, whackathe rhythmic beat of the helicopter's rotor startles the languid cattle wandering on the parched Indian plain. Shankar Ram looks up from the shade of the doorway of his mud but to see the machine growing rapidly as it bears down on the small village of Patala. His eight hungry children scramble past him, and his emaciated wife joins him as they all stare at this visitation from another world. Being illiterate, he cannot read the label on the side of the helicopterChristian Family Planning League of Texas.

title: Planners Back 2 Queens Zones
description: Two of the most highly regarded residential, communities in Queens, one built shortly after World War I ?? other following World War II, were designated for special protection under the ?? zoning law last week.

title: Greenport Gets Fresher Look
description: GREENPORTI see more Cadillacs and Mercedes on the streets these days, meaning people from the South Fork are moving up. But really, except for that and the new stores it's like remember it as a boy. Easygoing and beautiful.

title: Cynthia Watson Bride of T. S. Welch 2d
description: Miss Cynthia Ann Watson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold W. Watson of Westbrook, Me., was married in Portland, Me., last night to Thaddeus Stevens Welch 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Smythe Welch of New York and East Winthrop, Me. The Rev. William A. Irish perfored the ceremony in the Woodfords Congregational Church.

title: State Will Offer Daily Lottery Plan As an Experiment
description: The New York State Lottery, which operates on a weekly basis, will also hold 24 daily drawings next month to attract new bettors and shore up sagging ticket sales. The experiment will be the state's first with a daily lottery.

title: Stamps
description: THE first International AllJunior Stamp and Literature Exhibition, breaking new ground along the traditional, wellbeaten pathways of philately, will be held July 5 through July 7 in New York City.

title: A Question of Honor
description: At the very moment when he might well be the most admired man in the world, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has threatened to leave the government unless the United States Senate formally and decisively erases what he regards as an unjustified stain on his public honor.

title: The Gulag Archipelago
description: Most books about the experience of holocaust, especially those written by survivors, have two purposes. One is to chronicle the full horror of the holocaust, to sear it into the collective consciousness, so that it may never recur. The other is to explain the historical origins and causes of that experience.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: Miss Schlem Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Schlem pf New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Jane Schlem, to Frederic Neal Ornitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Ornitz of Mamaroneck, N. Y. Mr. Schlem is board chairman of Gold Seal Vineyards, a New York State winery.
