Mr. Ornitz, whose father is a certified public accountant, is starting his second year at the New England School of Law in Boston.

title: James MacDonald Minifie Dies; Herald Tribune Correspondent
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, June 15 (UPI)James MacDonald Minifie, former international correspondent for The New York, Herald Tribune who covered Washington for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation for 15 years, died here Thursday at, the age of 74.

title: Hollywood's Lost FilmsAnd Why They Can't Be Found
description: THROUGH all the months and mountains of hype and criticism attending The Great Gatsby, there has been virtually no mention, no showing, no notice of another, earlier Gatsby film shot back in 1949. That Gatsby, starring a slumbersome Alan Ladd and a fidgety Betty Field, is nowhere to be seennot even on television nor in the 16mm rental catalogues. It is a lost movie.

title: Queens Police Head Stresses Prevention
description: Assistant Chief Simon Eisdorfer, the brawny commanding officer of uniformed forces in Queens, derived special pleasure last week from the manner in which the police, without firing a shot, freed a 5yearold girl who had been held hostage for more than 30 hours.

title: Deborah Roller Married Here
description: Miss Deborah Jane Roller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Roller of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to James Stuart Finch, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Finch of Woodbridge, Conn.

title: Recordings
description: ECCENTRICITY is often considered an inborn character trait among the English, sometimes cultivated to an excessive degree. A casual record buyer who stumbles across EMI's new complete Siegfried (Odeon SLS 875, five disks) in one of New York's record stores dealing in imports, is liable to hold it up as fresh evidence of the fact: a live performance from London's Sadler's Wells Opera Company of one of Wagner's less popular works, sung in English, no less, by a cast of British locals, with a man of no international repute whatever leading the orchestramadness. How can a parochial effort like this possibly complete against the starry casts conducted by Solti, Karajan, and Bohm?

title: Greenwich Bridal For Sharon Knopp
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday afternoon. Miss Sharon Knopp and Lieut. Harry George Simmeth Jr., U.S.A., were married by the Rev. Bradford Hastings. He was assisted by the Very Rev. Richards Reid, associate dean of academic affairs and professor of New Testament at the Virginia Theological Seminary.

title: HOUSE VOTE NEAR ON STRIP MINING
description: WASHINGTON, June 15A House bill on Federal regulation of strip mining moved toward a vote this week with a leading advocate acknowledging the bill was in trouble and a leading opponent offering his office as lobbying headquarters against the measure.

title: Daisy Is an Unexpected Triumph
description: DAISY MILLER, ne Annie P. Miller back in Schenectady, goes on and on, nonstop, in a voice trained to a register a little too high to sound completely natural. She chatters literally  the effect is that of a venetian blind rattling in the windabout her mother's dyspepsia, about an English lady named Featherstone once met in a railway carriage, about Europeen hotels, about New York society, about her dreadful little brother Randolph who doesn't much care about old castles like the Chateau de. Chilton.

title: The house is more deadly than the street, yet at home we have more controlor at least the illusion of control
description: Trivial happenings and ordinary conversations: Early on a Saturday morning the telephone rings. is my nextdoor neighbor, her voice panicky: a suspicious looking service man is at the back door, saying he wants to check the meter. I'm alone in the house, she whispers. We agree that I will call her back in a few minutes to make sure that everything is all right. I do, and she is.... That same afternoon, while shopping, I get into a conversation with an elderly saleswoman. Her husband has recently retired and is having trouble figuring out what to do with his time. There's a lovely big park not far from our home, she says, but with everything going on these daysyou knowhe doesn't like taking any chances. So, what can he do? He just sticks to the streets and to the sidewalks.... In the evening, at a party, a journalist friend visiting us in New Haven says: I am more frightened, living on the West Side of New York, than I ever was during my years in Vietnam. There at least you knew where the danger was or where it might be coming from: You could make your own choices about whether to move closer or further away from it. But in Manhattan you have the feeling that anything can happen at any time, day or night, in any part of the city. And these muggers would just as soon kill you as rob you.

title: Sneaking Up on Status
description: Don't call them tennis shoes.

title: Price Odyssey Has Its Ups and Downs
description: New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs responded to complaints about rising food prices last year by establishing a weekly marketbasket survey to monitor the price increases. Lately the survey has shown some prices tumbling, But in its first anniversary report, issued last month, the department found that prices of its 38 survey items had risen 16.3 per cent in 12 months. Here is how some basic products have moved!

title: Shore Rail Line Is Upgraded
description: TRENTONThe state's Department of Transportation is moving ahead rapidly in its efforts to take much of the jounce, rattle and slow roll out of the New York & Long Branch Railroad and thus provide passengertrain speeds of 60 miles and hour.

title: Senate Unit Gets Diluted Bill on Suing Polluters
description: TRENTON  A bill that would give New Jersey residents the right to sue alleged polluters faces new opposition in the Senate tomorrow. A number of amendments designed to weaken the already controversial measure are expected to be proposed to the Energy, Agriculture and Environment Committee.

title: Lois Dublin Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Dublin of Woodmere, L. I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Ann Dublin, to Michael Brent Fingerhut, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Fingerhut of Washington. Miss Dublin is a research assistant with the Brookings Institution. Her fianc is a lawyer with the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: Mary Skorburg, Skidmore '74, Is Bride
description: St. Bede's Chapel on the grounds of the Daycroft School in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage. of Miss Mary Elizabeth Skorburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William David Skorburg of Greenwich, to Robert Andrew Nickerson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs.'Walter B. Nickerson of Potsdam, N. Y.

title: Sharp Rise Noted in Cost Of Urban Living Standard
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) A typical family of four living in an American city would require $12,600 annually to maintain a moderate standard of living, the Labor Department said today. The figure is nearly $1,200 higher than requirements in the previous year.

title: Outcome of Four Conventions For Statewide Spots on Ballot
description: The Republican, Democratic, Liberal and Conservative State Committees have selected their candidates for statewide offices in the election next November. In some cases, however, the designees face primary challenges in September.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge is no doubt the most difficult game of chance ever played. It can certainly be argued that chess and Go are more difficult, but they do not have an element of chance. The obvious example of luck in bridge is the deal in the rubber game, but there are many sophisticated examples in duplicate.

title: Conrad P. Albert Marries Miss Presbrey
description: In St. John the Evangelist's Roman Catholic Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Martin Presbrey was married to Conrad Preston Albert by the Rev. Ignatius Rodrigues.

title: Suzanne Clark Engaged
description: Mrs. Leonard E. Clark of Vero Beach, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Suzanne Clark, to Jo Francis Garner 2d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joe Francis Garner of Dothan, Ala, Miss Clark is a daughter also of, the late Mr. Clark.

title: Mrs. Riley Bride Of J. A. Anderson
description: Mrs. Martha Hartman Riley of Bridgehampton, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Joseph A. Anderson of New York. The Rev. Dr. Benjamin Minifie performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS PICK ALEXANDER FOR SENATE RACE
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., June 15The Democratic State Committee, winding up an exhausting 13hour session early today, designated Mayor Lee Alexander of Syracuse as its candidate for the United States Senate but gave former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein enough votes to force the fight with Mr. Alexander in the Sept. 10 primary.

title: Susan Cunningham Has Nuptials
description: Miss Susan Brann Cunningham, a travel agent with BristedManning Travel Service here, was married yesterday afternoon to Hal Richard Wofford, an assistant trust officer in the personal trust department of the Bankers Trust Company.

title: Fresh Fruits and Vegetables Are Available for the Picking
description: Participants in the annual summer sport of pickyourown have begun to dot Long Island's strawberry patches. Backaches and stained fingers notwithstanding, there is considerable satisfaction in plucking the ripe berries right from the plants.

title: Panov, in Israel, Says, I Have Come Home
description: TEL AVIV, June 15 (UPI)  Declaring, I have come home, the Jewish ballet star Valery Panov, accompanied by his wife, Galina Ragozina, a ballerina, arrived in Israel today after a twoyear struggle to leave the Soviet Union.

title: News of the Screen
description: Maximilian Schell is preparing to turn a multitalented trick again next year by independently producing and directing Half and Half, a screen story that he has written. His sister, Maria Schell (The Brothers Karamazov) will be his star.

title: ...Violets Are Blue: On Father's Day, The Ginsbergs 2
description: This dialogue between father and sonLouis Ginsberg and Allen Ginsbergboth poetsgrew out Of a joint poetry reading at the University of California at San Francisco. It was recorded by Stephen M. H. Braitman for Zenger's, a weekly published by students at San Francisco State College, and is excerpted here.

title: Syria at a Glance
description: Syria has long been the most militant of the Arab countries that border directly on Israel. She has strongly backed the Palestinian groups operating against the Israelis and in recent years has aligned herself closely with the Soviet Union.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: State Releases $41Million for Schools
description: ALBANY, June 15.  More than $41.3million in Federal funds, which have been held in escrow since the summer of 1972, has been distributed to local school districts that have provided special education programs designed to help former, present or potential recipients of welfare, according to Governor Wilson.

title: A Taste or Profits
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  At first, it's difficult to reconcile the reality of Anthony T. Rossi with the steeledged image of a superrich, selfmade corporate tycoon.

description: LINCROFTThe Music Department of Brookdale Community College will hold auditions today for the role of Amani to Amani ant the Night, Visitors. The auditions will be conducted from 2 to 4 P.M. in the college's Applied Humanities Institute.

title: A ThreeHorsepower tour Through Ireland
description: BUS! The chilling cry was passed back by our daughter, who was on horseback up front, acting as outrider, as we trundled along an Irish road. My husband, who was walking behind dur caravan, a sort of roundroofed wagon, sprinted to the front and threw a halfnelson on Apaches head. I was on duty at the reins and I braced myself on the ledge that passed as the driver's seat, and shouted to our son, relaxing with comics inside the caravan. He leaped to the brakes. Then, like some Greek chorus, we all began to chant . . . Easy, Apache, steady now old boy, it's only another bus, while at the same time chivvying him and the caravan to the side of the road.The enormous bus, all glass and domed, bore down on us. Apache snorted, leaped forward and considered climbing the bank but was discouraged by the full weight of my husband hanging on his bridle. Apache then pondered a fast Uturn, but our daughter's friend, who was riding a horse at the rear, spurred forward to head him off. Poor Apache, trembling and snorting, finally stopped. By this time, so had the bus, 100 yards down the road, and a swarm of tourists from Australia were descending, cameras ready, convinced they had come upon real Irish tinkers, the gypsies of ballad and tale, making their colorful way through romantic County Wicklow.I am not sure we ever did convince those Australians that we wera middleclass, middleaged Americans who were on a week's tour with three youngsters in a rented horsedrawn vehicle. The five of us (my husband and I, our daughter Victoria, 16, her friend Wendy, 16, and our son Aaron, 11) had picked up our red, white and green caravan one June day in Laragh, about 25 miles south of Dublin, and were making a leisurely circle through the countryside. We covered about 10 miles a day, pulling in each evening at farms where caravanners are welcome to park. Our fourberth caravan, with its curved wooden roof, was cozy, if somewhat primitive, and often the fields in which we spent the night lacked the usual facilities of a campground.

title: Bill Seeks To Improve Job Status Of Women
description: TRENTON  A bill to create a women's employment resource service within the state's Department of Labor and Industry was introduced in the Legislature last week by State Senator Anne C. Martindell, Democrat of Princeton.

title: UNCERTAIN COURSE ON BIGENTENNIAL
description: CHICAGO, June 14Shortly before his speech to some business representatives here this week, the man who runs the Federal Government's bicentenvial program got lost in the Conrad Hilton Hotel.

title: Miss Sughrue Wed To Robert Crowley
description: Miss Virginia Sughrue, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Stevens Sughrue of Milton, Mass., was married yesterday morning to Robert Emmet Crowley, son of Daniel Emmet Crowley of Kennehunk, Me., and the late Mrs. Crowley.

title: A Clearinghouse of Excellence
description: Thirty years of editing a little mag, almost as surreptitiously for its public reach as samizdat, may not entitle one to special privileges of generalization; but it should provide some vantage point of view. For, if by its nature a little mag attracts a readership infinitesimal according to American standards, it also provides rare freedoms: aside from the fundamental problem of survival and the arduous work entailed for one or two people producing it, such a publication need not worry about advertisers or supplying a multitude with what it wants, that terrible American lust for numbers and steady gross growth. Like the best writing, the little mag is one of the few enterprises left which can address itself to its own ideal.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports
description: June 19National Hot Rod Association match races for fuel dragsters, funny cars and pro stocks at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road, Englishtown, N.J: Class runoffs at P.M., racing at 8. Information: phone (201)4466331.

title: Nude Pictures Permitted
description: LOS ANGELES, June 15 (AP)  A judge has ordered that publications with pictures of nudes can be sold on Los Angeles newsstands despite a city ordinance banning them. Superior Court Judge Campbell M. Lucas issued an injunction this week holding up enforcement of the ordinance until a full hearing on a suit by the American Civil Liberties Union, which argues that the ordinance, adopted last month, made no allowance for works of art.

description: Johnny Rutherford, the winner of the Indianapolis 500 and the Milwaukee championship race that followed, was declared the winner yesterday of the second phase of the Martini & Rossi Driver of the, Year contest. He beat David Pearson in the vote by automotive sports writers.

title: Chess:
description: NICE, June 13  England has knocked the. United States team out of the lead in its preliminary section of the 21st. International Team Tournament here in the Palais de Expositions.

description: Miss Kathleen Mary Goodness and Herbert Wheatley Plimpton Jr. of Brookline, Mass., were married here at noon yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Ascension by the Rev. John C. Rivers.

title: Home Improvement
description: WALLS made of gypsum board or plasterboard (usually referred to as dry wall construction) normally do not crack in the way that plaster walls do, but they sometimes do require repairs due to nails popping out, dents caused by accidental blows or some similar mishap, or because of holes left when an electrical outlet or switch was moved. In addition, seams or joints will occassionally split or cracrk open because of severe shrinkage or warping of structural members or poor design.

The order came from the Interstate land sales office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and was drrected against Joel H. Jankowitz, president of Universal Properties.

title: Fashion
description: Sometimes men like to be off by themselves, justfather and son discussing the issues of the day like ice cream and kites and the firstgrade teacher. Here we show three fathers with their sons and two friends (despite a couple of decades worth of generation gap) all dressed for Sunday fun in the park. The women? Oh, they're off playing softball.

title: Numismatics
description: COIN collecting has rocketed into a heady new world, a highpriced world once reserved for rare paintings, sculpture, gems and even stamps. A United States gold coin was purchased at a public auction late last month for the alltime high price of $200,000 for a single coin. Now the only question is how high the numismatic rocket eventually will go.

title: The Thrush Still Sings
description: Dusk approaches, on a June evening, and you sit and rest after a day in the sun at the shore, in the country, in a lawnandgarden suburb. You sit and sense the evening without really looking or listening, sense birdsong back of and beyond the sound of cars or trucks or children shouting. You sense the evening chorus of robins and orioles and thrashers and wrens and catbirds. A pleasant sound in a somewhat less than ideal world. And no need to try to sort out the singers, even if you can. Birds.

title: The Democratic Way
description: True to tradition and Republican predictions, New York Democrats staged a tempestuous convention at Niagara Falls last week, leaving a litter of broken hopes, bruised egos and bitter memories. The convention also left unresolved the party's final choice for most state offices, virtually guaranteeing the long hot summer of Democratic infighting that the Republicancontrolled legislature gleefully anticipated when it switched the primary date from June to September.

She cracks the champagne across the bow of the new $2.5million Floating Hospital, and immediately the ship will be towed away by tug its normal power source for a fundraising dinnerdance at sea.

description: TROY, Mich., June 16The country's legal, staterun lotteries are barely out of the infant stage. But already they are becoming involved in a struggle with the underworld and the Federal. Government over how the nation's gambling action and profits are to be divided.

Film: Poitier in 2 Roles:Stars in and Directs 'Uptown' Comedy
description: "Uptown Saturday Night" is the sort of film in which Harry Belafonte shows up as an all-powerful but somewhat befuddled black gang boss named Geechie Dan Beauford Geechie Dan looks eerily familiar though nothing like Mr. Belafonte. With those extraordinary, cotton-filled jowls, the pencil mustache and a manner of talking as if through a voice box lodged in his stomach, he is Marlon Brando's Godfather in burnt cork.Like the Belafonte performance, "Uptown Saturday Night" is essentially a put-on, but it's so full of good humor and, when the humor goes flat, of such high spirits that it reduces movie criticism to the status of a most nonessential craft.The star as well as director of "Uptown Saturday Night" is Sidney Poitier, a man "whose way with comedy is reminiscent of Stanley Kramer's in "It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World." It's less instinctive than acquisitive. He himself can't make anyone laugh but he knows people who can. Mr. Poitier has had the good sense to hire a lot of exceptionally talented and funny people, including Richard Wesley, who wrote the screenplay for "Uptown Saturday Night."The film combines blunt, rollicking observations on lifethe kind favored by black comedianswith the sort of fabulous narrative that has always been a staple of American comedy, from today's Woody Allen back through silent comedy to frontier literature.Until recently true black comedy (not to be confused with black humor) has been something of an unknown frontier for most Americans, who didn't have access to Harlem's Apollo Theater, Moms Mabley. Redd Foxx and the other headliners. Today, of course, Moms, Redd and the others are television headliners," and it's now apparent that a lot of the comedy of Freeman Gosden and Charles Correll (Amos and Andy) was a good deal more witty and accurate than it was fashionable to admit in the nineteen-fifties and sixties."Uptown Saturday Night" is an exuberant black joke that utilizes many of the stereotypical attitudes that only black writers, directors and actors can decently get away with. You've never seen so much eye-popping fear and unwarranted braggadocio used in the service of laughs. Yet the result is not a put-down comedy but a cheerful jape that has the effect of liberating all of us from our hangups."Uptown Saturday Night," once it gets started (and that takes a bit of time), is abbut a pair of stupendously illequipped innocents, Steve Jackson (Poitier), a factory worker, and Wardell Franklin (Bill Cosby), a taxi driver, who set out to recover a winning lottery ticket contained in a wallet stolen during the pairs one and only visit to a fancy black after-hours club.The course of their search takes them through a gallery of rogues, dead-beats and affable con-artists: Sharp Eye Washington (Richard Pryor), a down-at-the-heels, doublecrossing private detective who takes their money and runs; Congressman Lincoln (Roscoe Lee Browne), the sort of phony, black-is-beautiful politician who wears Brooks Brothers suits in the privacy of his home; Silky Slim (Calvin Lockhart), a gang boss whose mythic nonchalance is matched only by his greed; The Reverend (Flip Wilson), a rousing orator who almost stops the film with a sermon about loose lips that not only can sink ships but also can get husbands into a peck of troubles.All of these performances are marvelously funny in their short takes, while Mr. Cosby is particularly good as the more skeptical of the two amateur sleuths. Mr. Poitier's intelligence and taste are most noticeable in the film's casting, in the leeway he gives his actors, and in his ability at times to make himself seem physically small and downright intimidated. For a man of his stature, that cannot be easy.The title of the film refers to neither a time nor a place (the setting seems to be Los Angeles, where, as far as I know, there is no uptown). It defines, instead, a film faritasy in which fun needn't have boring consequences, in which gangsters shoot it out without anyone's getting bloodied up, and in which it's possible to have a high old time without fear of a hangover.

title: Victor's Fee May Give Caddie College Start
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y. June (AP)  Hale Irwin's victory in the United States Open golf championship today could mean the start of a college education for the boy who carried his bags, 16yearold Peter McGarey of Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Fred Friendly Warns Networks On Coverage of Impeachment
description: Television will be putting itself on trial covering an impeachment trial of President Nixon, a former broadcast news executive has observed.

title: Early Warning ...
description: Even the most ardent supporters of the weekly Saturday and/or Sunday parade ritual on Fifth Avenue and we are not among them cannot be totally insensitive to the fact that these marches are the cause of infuriating and unnecessary traffic jams. Crosstown arteries become clogged and all but impassible; and as. cars back up, they soon also paralyze an extensive grid of avenues not directly affected by the route of march.

title: Democratic House Winner Spent $182,000 in Michigan
description: BAY CITY, Mich., June 16 (AP)  Representative J. Bob Traxier, a Democrat, says he spent more than $182,000 in his campaign against James Sparling, a Republican, in the special election last spring in the Eighth Congressional District.

title: WATERGATE PANEL TOLD OF AID ABUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 16White House efforts on behalf of President Nixon's 1972 reelection campaign included an extensive plan to politicize programs to aid the elderly, according to, a Senate Watergate committee staff report.

title: POLITBURO MEMBER ASSAILED IN PEKING
description: PEKING, June 16 (Reuters) A member of the Politburo of the Chinese Communist party has been attacked by name, for the first time in the wall poster campaign here.

title: Peron, Back a Year, Appears No Closer to His Goals
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 16The days of shouting, My Life for Pern! have passed, said the President of Argentina last week. We are living moments in which it is indispensable to demonstrate by sincere acts that we are ready to serve the common goals of all Argentines. But in the year since Juan Domingo Pern returned from lengthy exile with the stated intention of uniting his politically divided countrymen and setting this potentially rich nation on the road toward economic progress, common goals and sincere acts apno closer to realization.

title: Police Say Father Killed His Son on Bronx Street
description: According to the police, a 62yearold Bronx man shot and killed his 31yearold, son during an argument over a money debt. The slaying occurred on a street corner in the Tremont section.

title: SAMUELS TO MEET LEADERS ON PLANS
description: Howard J. Samuels, Democratic State Committee designee for Governor, said yesterday that he would meet a variety of leaders in the next few days to explore a course on the party's statewide primary contests.

title: Israel at a Glance
description: Israek the fruition of a Zionist dream that began in Europe in the last quartet of the 19th century, is surrounded by the Arab states of Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and Egypt. Since Israel became a state in 1948, none of these neighbors have recognized her.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Advertising: New Bricklin Auto
description: For some time there has been considerable interest in business and tradepress circles in the new Bricklin automobile, which will make its debut here on June 25 at daylong festivities at the Four Seasons restaurant.

title: Morgan Wing Jr., 62, Dies; Led National Beagle Club
description: Morgan Wing Jr., a past president of the National Beagle Club, died Saturday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 62 years old and a lifelong resident of Millbrook, N.Y., where he was Master of the Hunt of the Sandanona Beagles.

title: French Textile Group Makes Debut Here With Lapidus Boutique
description: Ted Lapidus, an aluminumwalled shop selling unisex chic of a luxurious order, opened quietly last Monday in the heart of Dry. Dock country, pointedly situated across the street from Bloomingdale's.

title: 5 ON U.P.T. SLATE GAIN BOARD SEATS
description: Candidates backed by the United Federation of Teachers have won five of nine seats in a courtordered election held last Tuesday for the District 5 Community School Board in Harlem.

title: TV: Allied Entry Into Russia After World War I
description: The Forgotten War, a documentary on the Public Broadcasting Service tonight at 8 o'clock, is a coproduction of the British Broadcasting Corporation and WENT Channel 13. Deciphering the label, that means the B.B.C. made it and WNET contributed toward the cost. In any case, the program offers a reconstruction of some fascinating history, complete with rare film footage and recent interviews with surviving participants.

title: FIRES TAKE 2 LIVES AND WRECK CHURCH
description: Four separate fires killed a Harlem and a Connecticut resident and heavily damaged a Queens church and a Brooklyn warehouse yesterday morning, fire authorities reported.

title: Candidates Worried About Violations of New Law on Registering Campaign Committees
description: With the political petitions process beginning tansy, candidates  particularly insurgentshave become anxious about the new, more restrictive campaign law. Some complain that they have been searching vainly for the forms needed to register campaign committees properly under the law and fear they are in technical violation already, with $100 fines the possible penalty.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
TALK ON PEAKING OF RATES FADES
description: Talk of a possible peaking in interest rates dried up markedly toward the close of last week. The large $421million bulge reported in commercial and industrial loans by New York banks was one element in the mix that tended to reduce the speculation on interest rates plateauing.

title: Nor Iron Bars a Cage
description: While While n Moscow as members of a delegation to the World Peace Congress, the Rev. Paul Mayer and I were fortunate to be able to speak to a few Russian dissidents and were surprised by their ignorance of American political and economic life. They simply didn't know. Some wanted never to know. (Perhaps they thought, if heaven doesn't exist, how are they to get out of hell?) Others like the Galiches and Sakharovs kindly listened to our views and extended their courage with new sadness.

title: About New York
description: Mrs. Barry Lee Cohen and her daughter Leslie, who is 5 years old, were on a Madison Avenue bus the other day when a nicely dressed, middleaged woman got on, sat down, and said that Leslie was a beautiful child indeed. Then she got a piece of paper, bent it, folded it, and made from it a butterfly that flapped its wings. With a flourish, she gave it to Leslie, and then got off the bus at the next stop.

title: Rain Softens HardHearted Winged Foot but Not Much
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 16There was about an hour of apprehensive weatherwatching at Winged Foot this morning just after the first golfers went off in the final round of the United States Open. Rain increased to a heavy downpour.

title: Jailed Crime Figure Files Suit On Fatal Poison in Wife's Soda
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP, June 16 A reputed organizedcrime figure who has been in jail since refusing to testify before the State Commission of Investigalion has filed suit against the bottler of a soft drink that his wife drank before dying of arsenic poisoning.

title: Lois Rappaport Is Bride
description: Miss Lois Rappaport was married at her home here yesterday afternoon to Raymond Shanfeld by Rabbi David J. Seligson, rabbi emeritus of Central Synagogue. The bride is a daughter of Philip Rappaport of Binghamton, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Margaret Rappaport. Mr. Shanfeld a musician, is a son of Abraham Shanfeld of Philadelphia and the late Mrs. Shanfeld. The bride is a second vice president and manager for personnel policies and practices of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Soviet Voters Elect the Slate in OneSlate Election
description: MOSCOW, June 16 Flowers, red banners, pipedin music, toys to occupy the kids, documentary films for their elders and even a whitecoated doctor in attendance awaited Soviet voters at the polls today in the Baumansky District of Moscow.

title: Dr. Lynne Gradinger Married To Dr. Andrew Besen on L.I.
description: Dr. Lynne Gradinger and Dr. Andrew Besen were married yesterday evening at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Edward T. Sandrow, rabbi emeritus of the temple, performed the ceremony. Rabbi Kalman Max and Cantor Samuel Dubrow assisted.

description: WASHINGTON, June 16William D. Ruckelshaus, former Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, expressed his support today for Secretary of State Kissinger's contention that he was not responsible for initiating wiretaps of 13 Government officials and four newsmen from 1969 to 1971.

title: Marcos Says He Must Keep Martial Law
description: MANILA, June 13President Ferdinand E. Marcos has indicated that he considers it necessary to continue to rule the Philippines by martial law for some time to come.

title: RIGHTS UNIT FIGHTS LONGERLICENSE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Leadership Conference on Civil Rights has pulled together its old coalition of labor, civil rights, religious and civic oranizations to rally opposition to the Broadcast License Renewal Act.

title: U.S.JAPAN REPORT ASKS FREER TRADE
description: Sweeping change in the international economic system to attain maximum trade freedom and cooperation by all countries on monetary, oil, resources and development issues has been urged in a joint statement by American and Japanese business leaders.

title: Red Smith
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 16  Rain was slowing to a stop while Buddy Allin, smallest of the survivors the last round of the United States Open, waited to tee off at the Winged Foot Golf Club today. Scores of 76, 71 and 74 had left him comparatively little chance to overtake the leaders, but, with his 221 for 54 holes he, could, look forward to a respectable slice of the $225,000 puise. For some, he was saying, winning means Number 1, for others it means Number 25. I feel that if I finish anywhere from Number 1 to 25 I've had a good tournament.

title: Cosmos Top Honduras Squad, 41
description: There are two ways to look at the New York Cosmos's 41 exhibition victory over Universidad de Honduras yesterday at Downing Stadium.

title: Study Says New York Has Heaviest U.S. Tax Burden
description: A study of 125 of the nation's largest urban areas shows a wide disparity in their Federal tax burdens, the Tax Foundation said yesterday.

title: Gunmen in Cyprus Kill One, Wound 2; Bombings Continue
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 16 (Reuters)  A Greek Cypriote was killed and two were critically wounded by gunmen early today in a resurgence of guerrilla violence in Cyprus.

title: Bridge: Unsolicited PostMortems A Bad Habit for Many Players
description: Giving unsolicited postmortem lessons to The opponents is a bad habit of many players in rubber bridge as well as tournaments. Even if you are the best player at the table and your analysis is always flawlesstwo substantial ifsfew opponents will be happy at having their errors exposed and discussed. If they ask for your opinion, by all means give it, but do so tactfully.

title: Nets Sweep Sets In W.T.T.,. 3117
description: CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP) The Cleveland Nets, paced by Mrs. Nancy Gunter and her brother, Cliff Richey, swept all five sets for a 3117 World Team Tennis victory over the New York Sets tonight.

title: JOHN D. REVENE
description: John D. Revene, who retired in 1962 as a senior vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at, 372 Forest Avenue, Glen Ridge, N. J., where he was a former member of the borough, council.

title: Personal Finance: Head of Household
description: At a time of high mortgage and high rents, related families have considered living together to share costs. In the case of older parents or relatives there is also the factor of safety.

title: Unarmed Special Force Patrols Newark Housing
description: NEWARK, June 16  The city's 14 housing projects, plagued by rising crime and licking a housingpolice force, are now being patrolled by an unarmed federally financed unit aimed at deterring muggings, breakins and vandalism.

title: Art And Politics
description: LONDON, June 16Lenin liked Beethoven piano music, especially the Appassionata Sonata. He told Maxim Gorky that it made him think what marvelous things human beings can do. But then he added: I can't listen to music too often. It affects your nerves, makes you want to say stupid nice things and stroke the heads of people who could create such beauty while living in this vile hell. And now you mustn't stroke anyone's headyou might get your hand bitten off. You have to hit them on the head without any mercy....

title: U.S. AND SYRIANS TO REESTABLISH DIPLOMATIC TIES
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 16 President Nixon and President Hafez alAssad announced today the resumption of diplomatic relations between the United States and Syria.

title: Counter Stock List Revised For Newspaper Publication
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers has restructured its national newspaper lists of overthecounter stock quotations that appear in financial sections of newspapers, the association said yesterday.

title: Pakistan Detects Fallout
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 16 (AP)Pakistan's atomic energy commission said today that it had detected radioactivity in Pakistan from the underground nuclear explosion in India last month. The commission said the radioactivity was detected by scientists dispatched to various parts of the country just after the explosion in the state of Rajasthan, 40 miles from the border.

title: Mississippi Fire Kills 6
description: UCEDALE, Miss., June 16 (UPI)Fire swept through a wood frame house while a family slept early today, killing a woman and five children. Only the woman's husband and a 4yearold daughter escaped the blaze. Florine Henderson, about 32 years old, was killed along with four of her children and a visiting cousin.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: ... and Less Noise
description: Parades and other traffic: obstacles also contribute another urban indignitythe excessive use of the automobile horn. Noise pollution is a serious affront to city dwellers. While there is no practical way of making New York's streets idylls of serenity, neither is there any excuse for allowing a flagrant and unnecessary assault on the population's ears and nerves.

title: Frazier vs. Quarry: A Psychodrama With a Punch Line Tonight
description: In the crisis world of heavyweight boxing, where every big fight is supposed to signal the start or end of someone's career but seldom does, Joe Frazier and Jerry Quarry will put their show on the crossroad tonight.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OMAHA, June 16 (AP)  Five Southern California players were named to the 1974 college world series alltournament team last night.

title: A Quiet, Disciplined Champion
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 16About an hour before he was to tee off in the final round of the United States Open golf championship today, Hale Irwin was explaining that he has no middle name. I have a middle initial, S., but not a middle name. He said, My father's middle name was Spencer, but I just have S. as a middle initial. That can stand for a lot of things. Sometimes it can stand for Stupid, or sometimes it can stand for Smart.

title: URUGUAY ACCUSED OF USING TORTURE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. June 16The Uruguayan Government was accused today of torturing political prisoners to extract confessions.The charge was made by Amnesty International and the International Commission of Jurists after representatives of the two private organizations made a Joint visit to Uruguay last month.

title: Music: Waning Appeal of Schoenberg
description: If Arnold Schoenberg were alive in this 100th anniversary year of his birth, he might have been depressed by the size of the turnout for the New York Philharmonic's chamber concert of his music Saturday night in its Rug series at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Lima Government Closes Opposition Newsmagazine
description: LIMA, Peru, June 16 (AP) President Juan Velasco Alvarado's military Government closed down the popular opposition newsmagazine Caretas on Friday and ordered the copublisher, Enrique Zileri Gibson, deported.

title: FARM UNION OPENS VILLAGE FOR AGED
description: DELANO, Calif., June 16 The United Farm Workers of America dedicated the nation's first retirement village for farm workers yesterday in this and town, which has been the focal point of the union's struggle to organize the nation's farm workers.

title: Japanese Women Too, Are Breaking Down the Barriers
description: TOKYO, June 16  Five years ago Ryoko Ozawa was, outwardly at least, atypical Japanese housewife. Then she suddenly divorced her husband, left her two children, and ran for a seat on the City Council of the Tokyo suburb where she lives.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: Horses and Equipment 3995

title: Deborah J. Pines Has Nuptials
description: Miss Deborah Jane Pines, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kermit L. Pines of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Laurence Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Friedman of Clayton, Mo.

title: District 26 Has Similarities to Suburban Schools
description: Queens School District 26, tranquil enclave tucked up against the Nassau County line, has more in common with suburban school systems than with most of the city's 32 school districts. Not all of the similarities are advantageous, however.

title: Irwin Takes U.S. Open By 2 Strokes With 287
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 16  Hale Irwin saw it coming three weeks ago. He had dreamed he had won the United States open golf tournament with two putts from 20 feet on the 72d pole.

title: Wile Lands Plane Safely As Man Dies at Controls
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., June 16 (AP)Martha Waite's husband used to explain the controls on the family's singleengine plane when they were aloft. He even let her fly the plane occasionally. But she had never landed the craft.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: U.S. WIRETAP ROLE IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, June 16State and Federal agencies are investigating the possibility that three lawyers representing defendants in criminal cases linked to organized crime may have been the victims of illegal bugging by Federal agents.

title: ALUMINUM AT HIGH IN 1973 SHIPMENTS
description: The domestic aluminum industry shipped a record high $14.56billion pounds in 1973, the Aluminum Association reported over the weekend. This was 20.8 per cent ahead of the previous high of 12.05billion pounds shipped in 1972.

title: Subway Train Kills L.I. Mar
description: A northbound BMT train struck and killed a man on the subway tracks at Eighth AveHue near 62d Street in the Eighth Avenue station in Brooklyn at about 4:35 A.M. yesterday, the police said. He was identified as Thomas Usher, 46 years old, of Lawrence, L.I.

title: S. KLEIN WILL CLOSE 2 JERSEY UNITS FIRST
description: The S. Klein department stores, which reportedly plans to close at least six stores in the metropolitan area, has decided initially to close its doors in East Brunswick and Cherry Hill, N.J., according to informed sources at the weekend.

title: MRS. JAY LAVENSON
description: Mrs. Caroline Wolf Lavenson, former director of the Tripp Lake Camp for girls at Poland, Me., and the mother of James H. Lavenson, president of the Plaza Hotel, died yesterday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Idle Dice Ends a Jinx At the Ox Ridge Show
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 16It had to end sometime. That puzzling jinx that had hounded Idle Dice at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club Horse Show for the last two years ended today.

title: Most Israelis Hail Nixon; Some Cite Watergate Role
description: JERUSALEM, June 16  Israel showered President Nixon with praise and cheers this afternoon when he arrived fresh from conferences with Arab leaders in three countries.

title: Sparkman, as Heir to Fulbright, Says He'll Follow Majority Will
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 Senator John Sparkman, who is scheduled to be the next chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, says his job will be to support Presidential policy and follow the majority will of committee members.

title: Fifth Regents Exam Canceled as Rumors Of Thefts Increase
description: The statewide Regents examination in geometry scheduled for today was canceled last night by the State Education Department, the fifth test canceled because the answers had been obtained by students and were being widely sold throughout the state.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Plans to lower the criminal implications of the use of marijuana are being considered by Attorney General William F. Hyland.

title: WIFE LANDS A PLANE WHEN HUSBAND DIES
description: MCGUIRE Air Force Base, June 16 (AP)  The wife of a pilot who suffered a fatal heart seizure at the controls of his singleengine plane safely crashlanded the craft here yesterday.

title: Irwin Gains World Series
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 16 (UPI)Hale Irwin's victory in the United States Open today qualified him to play in the World Series of Golf this year for the first time. Irwin joins the Masters champion, Gary Player, in the field for the 36hole event, scheduled Sept. 7 and 8 at Firestone Country Club in Akron, Ohio. They will be joined by the winners of the British Open and the Professional Golfers' Association championship.

title: Paris Restaurants: Still as Good as Ever
description: PARISWe first set foot in Paris 25 years ago this month. There were no quickservice restaurants, no pizza parlors, no high rise apartments blackening the landscape and no whatchamaycall'em drugstores in any part of town.

title: Miss MacMillan Wed
description: Miss Harriet Emery MacMilan, who teaches the history of architecture and art at the University of Illinois in Chicago Circle, was married yesterday afternoon to Ran Martin Roberts, a candidate for a Ph.D. in history at the University of Chicago. Rabbi Marc Gellman performed the ceremony at Glessner House, a national architectural landmark in Chicago. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Donald MacMillan of San Francisco and Mr. and Mrs. Irving Roberts of East Hampton, L.I.

title: Petty Beats Pearson In Motor State 400
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., June 16 (AP)Richard Petty defeated David Pearson in the Motor State 400 today, as stock car racing's biggest money winners staged a headtohead duel before 51,500spectators.

title: Borg, Miss Evert Take French Open
description: PARIS, June 16Youth will be served. Chris Evert, 19 years old, won the French open today, and Bjorn. Borg, 18, in one of the great tennis turnarounds, came from two sets down to defeat Manuel Orantes of Spain, 26, 67, 6.0, 61, 61, and capture the men's title.

title: New U.S. Envoy to Cambodia Loses 1.5 Pounds and Gains Some Ground
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 15  With the toughness of a hardnosed colonel and the finesse of a charming conciliator, the new United States Ambassador to Cambodia, John Gunther Dean, has been charging around the country reproaching generals, wooing opposition leaders and searching so far in vainfor some insurgents who are willing to negotiate.

title: Byrne Is Host to Critics Of Income Tax Proposal
description: PRINCETON, June 16Governor Byrne, in a green blazer, checkered pants, white bucks and a club tie, met complaining letterwriters at an informal session on the lawn of Morven today to explain his proposal for a state income tax. After 90 minutes with the Governor, however, many left as skeptical as they came.

title: Stage: Twelfth Night Opens 20th Stratford Season
description: STRATFORD, Conn., June 15  The American Shakespeare Theater is celebrating its 20th anniversary season, which makes it one of the oldest theatrical institutions in the country. The theater building, which is also 20 years old and an ugly place, was the very first of the new American theater buildings of the last two decades. The first and one of the least effective. Nevertheless, the theater, through enormous difficulties, has continued to exist, it has given a lot of people enormous pleasure (and over the years a little critical heartburn now and again) and it is now fruitfully trying to build a quasipermanent company with its own way of approaching Shakespeare and all those other plays essential to a Shakespearean repertory.

title: MRS. JESSE E. DU BOIS
description: Mrs. Ruth Mary Packard Du Bois, a former associate fashion editor of The Ladies' Home Journal and instructor in fashion writing at the Fashion Institute of Technology, died Saturday in Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N. Y. She was 72 years old and lived in New Paltz, N. Y.

description: From the Henry Hudson Parkway, it looks like a twostick icecream bar, halfeaten and 20 stories tall, With windows.

One of those techniques, which has been practiced for some time by a number of commercial banks as well, is the nocharge checking account.

description: TRENTON, June 16Action by Trenton State Prison authorities to recall a highly motivated inmate from a rehabilitative college program just short of his graduation has strained tions between the prison Trenton State College. It may have jeopardized the program throughout the state.

description: Fewer Americans who were polled in early June favored the removal of President Nixon from office than those surveyed the month before. But those who think he should be removed still outnumber those who don't by a narrow margin, according to the latest Gallup poll.

description: To the Editor: I write to call your attention to the massive damage which is being inflicted on the U.S. economy by the injudicious action of the Nixon Administration in ending controls on dollar outflows, including the interestequalization tax and a banking industry creditrestraint program in late January.

description: MADISON, Wis., June 16With no help from the elements again, Harvard's crew defeated Wisconsin today on Lake Monona here. Harvard is unbeaten and the Eastern sprint champion and Wisconsin is the Intercollegiate Rowing Association champion. Their twoday contest was for an unofficial national collegiate title, which Harvard apparently has won with consecutive victories.

title: Dr. Carol Ann Livoti Bride of Richard Topp
description: Dr. Carol Ann Livoti, a gynecologist and obstetrician, was married yesterday noon to Richard D. Topp Rabbi Paul Silbershur performed the ceremony at the Plaza. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Joseph T, Livoti of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Livoti, a physician.

description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 16 The Union Jack flew high over foggy Newport today as Britain's threeboat team of Noryema, Oyster and Marionette won the first race, the Astor Trophy, in the Onion Patch team series.

description: Sy Oliver, who has been the workhorse of the New York Jazz Repertory Company since it opened its season in January, recreating arrangements once played by Jimmie Lunceford, Chic Webb, Don Redman, Erskine Hawkins and Duke Ellington with skill and sensitivity for the fine points of the styles of these bands, outdid himself Saturday evening with a program of Fletcher Henderson arrangements that shared the repertory company's concert at Carnegie Hall with a salute to Bud Freeman, the saxophonist.

description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is preparing to close Tuesday nights during the summer and to shorten its Sunday, hours starting in July unless money is found to preserve the present schedules.

title: New Jersey Sports The Jog Doctor
description: RUMSON, June 16Dr. George Sheehan, a 55yearold cardiologist, runs the roads of this town one hour a day, six days a week and has been doing it for almost 12 years now He does some of his best thinking when he's running. On Tuesdays, for instance, he writes his weekly newspaper column for the Red Bank Register while he's running. On other days, he does medical research.

title: ARRESTS EXCEED 100 AT MOTORCYCLE RACE
description: LOUDON, N. H., June 16 (Reuters)The police reported more than 100 arrests in a weekend of violence here and in the adjoining town of Belmont among more than 50,000 motorcyclists attending the national motorcycle road races.

description: JERUSALEM, June 16  Israel showered President Nixon with praise and cheers this afternoon when he arrived fresh from conferences with Arab leaders in three countries.

description: CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP) Stonewalk won the $100,000 Ohio Derby today, beating Better Arbitor, the Jersey Derby victor, by four lengths.

title: H. A. Johnson, Episcopal Canon, Authority on Kierkegaard, Dies
description: The Rev. Dr. Howard A. Johnson, who served as the canon theologian of the Cathedral. Church of St. John the Divine from 1954 to 1966, was found dead Wednesday in his Long Beach, Calif., apartment, where he lived alone. He was 58 years old.

title: Sardinian Election Likely to Influence Decisions in Rome
description: CAGLIARI, Sardinia, June 16  Sardinians, who feel apart from other Italians in more ways than just geographically, went to the polls today in the knowledge that the entire nation is tensely watching.

title: Screen: 'Gravy Train,' American Style--Almost
description: This continues to be the year for romance between heterosexual males. "The Gravy Train," which opened yesterday at the Beekman and Forum Theaters, focuses on a pair of brothers who are so devoted to each other that there has to be a scene in a massage parlor to show that they have any use for women.Two West Virginia coal miners (Stacy Keach and Frederic Forrest) quit the jobs they loathe to make their fortunes through armed robbery. (Since they hate their factory as well as the work itself, it would have been interesting if their mutinous feelings had been further developed.) They're soon betrayed by their fellow hoods, and the battles within the small gang become the bulk of the picture.There are some substantial intentions here  above all, the effort to make a very American movie, to reflect the native condition. These rebellious workingmen also detest cops, though they're hardly liberal, and the film is sprinkled with racial hatreds.Throughout, there's too much moralizing about materialism: It's obvious that the greedy brothers are going to be punished for pursuing that gravy train, and much of the scrpt seems like a recipe for retribution. The chase scenes and shootouts aren't exciting, despite several falling bodies  whenever the plot sags, one of the supporting actors is deprived of all support, and he falls screaming from great heights. And, although this isn't the bloodiest movie of the month, it's exceptionally brutal  to a degree that numbs your response, makes you feel detached.Mr. Forrest, as a callow sadist who cackles whenever the bullets fly, and Mr. Keach, as a man of manic authority  whose yells of rage or pain evoke Marlon Brando howling "Stella!"  are both fine, even though their parts don't give them much range.All in all, it's impossible to tell whom this movie was meant for. At moments, it seems to be aimed at mid-America. Yet that audience is sneered at when the brothers are caricatured as hicks in a swank city restaurant: It's supposed to be hilarious when they can't pronounce filet mignon or don't know what scampi are.Meanwhile, the preachiness of the script won't beguile those who like money or possessions; although this is meant to be an action movie, it comes off as an Awful Warning to the young men of America.

title: Populist Mayor Shakes Up Utica
description: UTICA, N.Y., June 14Since he took office in January with an order that policemen salute citizens on the street, Mayor Edward A. Hanna and his frenetic populist regime have been flailing at tradition in this depressed mill town.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last. Friday.

title: Miss Haynie Wins Golf In Playoff
description: MEDINA, Ohio, June 16 (AP)  Sandra Haynie shot a par on the fourth extra playoff hole today to beat Gloria Ehret in a rainmarred playoff in the $42,500 Ladies Professional Golf Assocciation Medina open tournament.

description: After deliberating, for more than a year, a group of employes from the PhillipsVan Heusen Corporation who serve as the conscience for their company's $10million pension and retirement fund, have sold 2,350 shares of stohk in the International Telephone and Telegraph Company.

description: Some cattle feeders, who maintain that they are losing money, threatened to withhold their animals from market starting today unless they get what they consider a fair price.

The strong minority opportunity programs adopted by several public agencies here and community group pressure on established builders were beginning to have an impact.

title: FRENCH ABLAST IN AIR REPORTED

description: BARROW, Alaska, June 12 On the North Slope, a countrysized sweep of mountain range, coastline and thinly layered mossy soil atop the everlasting ice on the land, there The Talk are just about 5,000 people and the they are all learning fast the new realities that make up life and work in the Alaskan Arctic.

title: Metropolitan Briefs

Majority Republican leaders predict that as many as half of the vetoes might be overridden at the socalled trailer session required by state law. Minority Democrats would have to join Republicans to provide the twothirds majority of both houses needed to enact a bill over a Governor's veto.

title: That Cold Steel Ball of Fear

I had worked there for thirteen years. In fact, since I got out of college and the Air Force I had been there. In a way it seems like all of my life had been spent there. By the simple act of resigning I have changed all that. A man has been hired to replace me, my seat has been transferred to him, the water rippled and was still again.

description: Dr. Robert R. Sugarman, emeritus professor of law at the Brooklyn Law School who practiced in Manhattan, died Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He would have been 76 years old today. His home was at 441 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: No Song, No Service
description: The only remarkable attribute of the singing telegram is that it lasted for forty years before joining the nation's cluttered attic of obsolete gimmicks. This, small stilled voice will leave no void in the lives of most Americans.

title: Loss of Jobs in City Continues, Rounding Out a 5Year Drop
description: There were 18,700 more jobs in New York City in March than in February, but the total still was 37,000 lower than in March, 1973, indicating a continuing decline in employment here that is puzzling economists and city officials.

title: Bar Acts on Marijuana
description: LAKE GENEVA, Wis., June 17 (Reuters)The Illinois State Bar Association passed today a resolution calling for the legalization of possession and use of marijuana. The association's governing assembly also approved a measure calling for consideration of government licensing for marijuana sales.

title: City and State Move to Correct Brooklyn Redistricting Error
description: State and city officials were busy taking stepe yesterday to correct a legislative reapportionment mistake that redistricted a street in Brooklyn Heights, on a part that no longer exists and simultaneously split an apartment house electorally in half.

title: Accounting Firms Study Peat, Marwick, Mitchell
description: Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. is opening its operations to scrutiny by other accountants.

title: Presbyterian Leader Lawrence Wendell Bottoms
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 17 When the first black Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the United States received a ceremonial Celtic cross on a chain from his predecesssor yesterday, he quipped, It always makes me nervous when a white person puts anything around my neck. The remark was classic Lawrence, said one admirer of the Rev. Lawrence Wendell Bottoms. In an emotional moment, he able to break the tension, cause laughter and at the same time get a barb in.

title: FORD TO HAT ADS DISPUTED BY F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company has agreed to stop running coinmericals contending that its Galaxie and LTD cars have steel reinforcements as strong as highway guard rails, or that the LTD, runs quieter than a glider in flight, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Loser Bloodied by LeftHook Barrage
description: Joe Frazier came out smoking last night and Jerry Quarry had nothing to put out the fire. With a savage burst of fury fueled by pride and the desire to prove his championship fiber, Frazier pummeled the Californian into submission at 1 minute 37 seconds of the fifth round.

title: Profits Slump at Realty Trusts Is Laid to Impact of High Rates
description: The impact of high interest rates on the financial status of real estate investment trusts that specialize, in mortgage lending is reflected in statements released by the trusts in recent days.

title: Fox to Captain Elis
description: Larry Fox, a junior defenseman from Levittown, L. I., has been elected captain of the 1975 Yale lacrosse team. He succeeds Larry Wexler of Fair Lawn, N. J., another defenseman, who was voted the most valuable player on this season's team.

title: NALCOAND LAVYTER SET ACQUISITION
description: The Nalco Chemical Company, a specialty chemicals producer, has reached an agreement in principle to acquire Lawter Chemicals Inc., for stock valued at about $178million, it was disclosed yesterday. Merger Under the proNews posed terms, Nalco would exchange 0.825 share of its common stock for each of Lawter's 7,745,000 outstanding common shares, resulting in issuance of about 6,390,000 Nalco shares. Nalco currently has 19,920,000 shares outstanding.

title: Kalmbach Given Jail Term Of 618 Months by Sirica
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's former personal lawyer, was sentenced today to six to 18 months in prison and fined $10,000, for illegal fundraising activities on behalf of the White House.

title: Ceremony in Damascus Marks Renewal of U. S.Syrian Ties
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 17The United States flag was raised at the American Interests Section of the Italian Embassy here today and by the time it reached the top of the staff the building had become, once again, the Embassy of the United States of America.

title: FOUR MORE TESTS DROPPED IN STATE
description: State education authorities canceled four more Regents examinations yesterday, making a total of nine called off, as Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold said that he now believed that test booklets or answer sheets had been stolen from three schools in the borough and widely distributed.

title: The Possible Dream
description: President Nixon in Jordan today winds up his whirlwind quest for what he had earlier described in Jerusalem as the possible dream of peace in the Middle East.

title: U.S. Panel Delays Firecracker Ban Until After July
description: WASHINGTON, June 171 The Consumer Product Safety Commission voted today not to ban the sale of firecrackers before July 4.

title: Colson Posts Upset. In N.C.A.A. Tennis
description: LOS ANGELES, June 17 (UPI)  Four players from Stanford, the defending champion, advanced at the opening of the National Collegiate tennis, championships today. Only one seeded player in the top 16 was beaten.

title: DR. GEORGIANA M'ENTEE
description: Dr. Georgiana P. McEntee, professor emeritus of history at Hunter College, died Friday in River Edge, N.J., at the home of her sister, Mrs. Melita Pfiefer. She was 78 years old and lived in the Berkshire Hotel.

title: Wake Forest 0101
description: Wake Forest won only one of its 11 football games last season, One game ended in a tie.

title: Chess: U.S. Ties It With England At the Expense of Ecuador
description: United States team overtook England to share the lead in its preliminary section of the International Team Tournament here in the Palais des Expositions by taking a 3 victory over Ecuador.

title: Washington Post Far Off But Melody Lingers On
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 17 (Reuters)  The strains of John Philip Sousa's Washington Post March welcomed President Nixon to Jordan today.

title: LIQUOR AIDE ACCUSED OF TRYING TO EXTORT
description: PATERSON, June 17  A. member of the Paterson board that controls liquor licenses was charged today by the Passaic County grand jury with attempted extortion and misconduct in office.

title: NEW KIDNAPPING STIRS ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 17 (Reuters)  A Germanborn executive in Argentina of the MercedesBenz automobile company was kidnapped here on Friday apparently by leftwing urban guerrillas, police sources said today.

title: One Slain in Cyprus Clash
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 17(Reuters) The police shot and killed one of several men who tried to ambush a police car from another car near Limassol today, authorities reported. The assailants escaped, but their car was found later with a dead man dressed in a camouflage uniform in the front seat, officials said.

title: 3 Tie for Medal In Women's Golf
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 17 Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Baltusrol, the 1970 champion, Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill and Mrs. G. Thomas Aydelotte of Stanwich scored 78's today and tied in the qualifying round of the 71st annual championship of the Women's Metropolitian Golf Association. They will play off for the medal at a later date on this 5,945yard, par 37, 3774 course.

title: Foster in Draw With Ahumada, Keeps Title
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 17 (UPI)Bob Foster, lacking the aggressiveness shown in his 13 previous title defenses, and Jorge Ahumada of Argentina fought 15 rounds to a controversial draw tonight.

title: GRAINCROP OUTLOOK HELD LESS HOPEFUL
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)Prospects for rebuilding the world's grain stockpile by the summer of 1975 are not as bright as indicated three months ago, the Agriculture Department said today. The department's Foreign Agricultural Service said consumption of grain would be larger than earlier believed, while 1974 crop production in some areas will be less than indicated in a similar analysis last March 15.

title: ANNE M. CANAVAN
description: NEWARK, June 17 (AP) Anne M. Canavan, administrative assistant for the last 23 years to Samuel I. Newhouse, head of the Newhouse newspaper chain, died here Saturday.

title: Senate Bill Asks Federal Action To Protect Condominium Buyers
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 Legislation that would require condominium developers to register with the Federal Government and to disclose full details of their offerings was proposed today in the Senate.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Egan Tells Court of Hoard in Small Box
description: A former police lieutenant accused of seizing money from drug suspects testified yesterday in Federal court that he had kept his cash in a little wooden box.

title: Greater New York Fund Names Head
description: Theodore C, Jackson, senior, vice president of the Bowery Savings Bank, was elected president of the Greater New York Fund yesterday at a directors meeting. He succeeds Samuel J. Silberman, president of the Gulf and Western Foundation.

title: St. Joe's Lead Price Up
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation announced yesterday that it had raised its price for primary lead by 3 cents a pound, to 24.5 cents, effective immediately. St. Joe, the nation's largest lead producer, said the increase was necessary to reduce the flow of domestic Iead to overseas markets. The company added that it hoped that its move would bring lead demand and supply into closer balance in United States.

title: Pickets Block School Project Saying Housing Is Needed First
description: About 150 residents of Little Italy protesting the construction of a $7million school in their Lower Manhattan neighborhood yesterday turned back trucks coming to clear the site.

title: Mrs, Rachleff Wins With 61, 60 Rout
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 17Mrs. Marilyn Aschner Rachleff, the East's No. 1 player from Kings Point, L.I., advanced to the fourth round of the Eastern women's claycourt tennis championship today with a 61, 60 rout of Louise. Stolitsky of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a June 5 editorial, The Times describes the Mansfield amendment to withdraw troops from Europe as the wrong battle in the wrong place at the wrong time.

title: Branch D.A.'s Office Is Opened in Harlem
description: Mayor Beame, Manhattan District Attorney Richard H. Kuh and State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday formally opened a branch District Attorney's complaint office at 55 West 125th Street in Harlem.

title: 40 Are Reported Dead In Pakistan Store Fire
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 17 (AP)A fire in downtown Lahore, the capital of Punjab Province, killed at least 40 people today, according to reports reaching here. The blaze gutted an entire building and six families were killed, the report said.

title: U.S. Sewerage Funds Urged
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)  Senator Gaylord Nelson, asked Congress today to appropriate $600million for the Federal share of local sewage treatment plant construction projects started between 1966 and 1972. The Wisconsin Democrat said that, in 1966, Congress entered into an agreement with the nation's cities under which they would pay the Federal share and then be reimbursed. Almost eight years later, the Federal Government has yet to fulfill its promises, Mr. Nelson adde.

title: Wafer Supply Project Is Dedicated on S.I.
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday dedicated the Richmond water supply project and the restoration of Silver Lake Park on Staten Island, calling the projects two important improvements that offer something for everyone to celebrate.

title: 4 LANDS PROTEST FRANCE'S ABLAST
description: PARIS, June 17The French Government maintained official secrecy today on its current series of nuclear tests in the atmosphere in the South Pacific amid protests from Australia, New Zealand, Canada and Japan.

title: Plan for 200Mile Fishing Limit Angering U.S. Tuna Fleet Men
description: SAN DIEGO, June 17Operators of the American tuna fleet have reacted angrily to reports that Washington, after years of defending their freedom of the seas, was preparing to recognize the right of any coastal nation to turn back foreign fishing boats 200 miles from its shores.

title: Thieves Take Radio Tower
description: EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., June 17 (UPI)  A 100foot radio tower was stolen along with a number of other items in a weekend burglary from the Phacker Construction Company, the police reported today. The owner of the company, Floyd Phacker, told the police that he discovered the theft yesterday when he stopped by his office. Value of the stolen items was placed at more than $10,000.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, JUNE 18, 1974
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Fed Agency Voted To Permit Increase In ShortTerm Rates
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted unanimously at its March meeting both to allow shortterm interest rates to rise and to permit the nation's money supply to expand somewhat faster than its longterm target called for, it was disclosed today.

title: Bomb in London Damages Oldest Hall of Parliament
description: LONDON, June 17A bomb exploded today in the most historic part of the Houses of Parliament, damaging Westminster Hall, the 900yearold chamber that has seen much of British history. Eleven people were injured, none seriously.

title: DR. IDA A. JEWETT
description: Dr. Ida A. Jewett, who retired in 1948 as associate professor of English at Teachers College, Columbia University, died Sunday at the Baptist Home for the Aged in Riverdale, the Bronx. She was 91 years old.

title: GUNMAN HOLDS WIFE HOSTAGE 5 HOURS
description: A 27yearold man with a long police record held his commonlaw wife hostage at gunpoint in their Queens gardenapartment for more than five hours yesterday, but surrendered peacefully last night to members of the Police Department's hostagenegotiation unit.

title: High Court Rejects Plea To Review Kerner Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Supreme Court declined to review today the criminal convictions of Otto Kerner that were based on a conspiracy to assist racing interests while he was Governor of Illinois.

title: BLACKS BRIEFED ON MINORITY JOBS
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the city's unpaid labor adviser, met yesterday with city officials and minorities pressing for employment in the construction trades and gave them a status report on the number of minorities employed in the industry.

title: Puerto Rico Planning Shipping Fleet
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP)Puerto Rico is creating a governmentowned merchant fleet, in a move that Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon hopes will hold down ocean freight rates and make the island more tempting to investors.

title: Kalmbach Given Jail Term Of 618 Months by Sirica
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's former personal lawyer, was sentenced today to six to IS months in prison and fined $10,000 for illegal fundraising activities on behalf of the White House.

title: Painting by Vandyke Is Stolen in Florida
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 17 (AP)  A painting by the 17thcentury Flemish artist Anthony Vandyke has been stolen from the Cumrner Gallery of Art, the police said.

title: SENATORS HOLD UP SAWHILL APPROVAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Senate confirmed today the nomination of John C. Sawhill as Federal Energy Administrator, then rescinded the confirmation hours later.

title: 4 Missing Women Climbers Believed Dead in Himalayas
description: NEW DELHI, June 17 (Reuters)Four women climbers, two New Zealanders and two Ind??, who were lost in an avalanche in the Himalayas more than two weeks ago, are believed dead, a leader of the expedition said today.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: RAPIDAMERICAN SHOWS NET DROP
Aaron Gets Reception, Mets Get Trounced, 81
description: Henry Aaron led the Atlanta Braves into town last night for the first time since he became the ranking homerun hitter in baseball, drew a standing ovation from a crowd of 35,994 persons in Shea Stadium and reflected on the clamor of it all.

title: Compassionate Frazier Spares the Punishment
description: Joe Frazier is a compassionate man, which is why he was unable to keep hitting an already demolished Jerry Quarry in the fifth round last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Newspaper Raises Price
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 17 (UPI)  The Oakland Tribune raised the price of its daily editions today from 15 to 25 cents. The price of the Sunday Tribune was increased from 35 to 50 cents.

title: Court Says States Can Bar Job Benefits in Pregnancy
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that states can deny disability benefits to women incapacitated by normal pregnancy without committing unconstitutional discrimination.

title: Sale of One Church To Foster Reunion
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 17  This city's two Presbyterian churches are for sale$700,000 each, including parish houses, trees, rolling lawns, the works. A brochure calls it an opportunity for building developer or industry.

title: Eddy Brown, Violinist, 78, Dies; Prodigy Made Disks in 1920's
description: Eddy Brown, violinist and former music director of radio station WQXR, died in Abano, Italy, last Friday of an embolism. He had stopped at the health resort on his way to Budapest, where he was to speak at the Liszt Academy of Music. He was 78 years old.

title: Senators Seek Review of ExportImport Bank Loans
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Eighteen Senators introduced amendments today that would require a Congressional review of all ExportImport Bank transactions of more than $50million and limit the Administration's ability to extend Governmentbacked credits to the Soviet Union.

title: Jersey Senate Restricts Medicaid for Abortions
description: TRENTON, June 17The State Senate passed today controversial bill that would prohibit the use of Medicaid funds for elective abortions.

title: Bridge: Leading Opponent's Suit In NoTrump Can Pay Off
description: Few players ever have the courage or imagination to lead the opponent's suit for them in a notrump contract, but this surprising maneuver can be profitable on certain hands. It can force the defenders to take their tricks prematurely; it may allow the declarer to gather the information he needs to guide his play in another suit; it can set up a squeeze; and it can confuse the opponents.

title: Not for Children
description: To say that today's children are part of the television generation is to state the obvious. Educators, parents and child development experts will continue to argue the benefits and hazards of growing up with the new dimension of instant visual entertainment and, too infrequently, news and education. But no adult with the interests of children at heart can fail to be concerned over the inherent impropriety of subjecting them to commercial appeals they are unable either to understand or to resist.

title: 4 Are Fatally Shot; 2 ExHusbands Held In Separate Attacks
description: A Jersey City couple were shot to death in their apartment early yesterday. The woman's former husband, a Bronx man, was taken into custody at the scene with a loaded revolver in his hand, the police reported.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Rise
description: Prices of bonds moved up in the Government market yesterday but declined in the corporate sector and drifted lower in the taxexempt segment, where participants were awaiting the outcome of today's sale, via competitive bidding, of $167million of Pennsylvania bonds. The upturn in the Government market was ascribed by several participants to technical elements associated with yesterday's weekly Treasury bill auction. Before the results of the bill auction were known it was being viewed as bullish. Rates on outstanding Treasury bills declined as prices moved up and prices also, rose on intermediatelength Government

title: Court Says States Can Bar Job Benefits in Pregnancy
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that states can deny disability benefits to women incapacitated by normal pregnancy without committing unconstitutional discrimination.

title: AllStar Voting
description: CAICHERJohnny Bench, Cincinnati), 419.447; Joe Ferguson, Los Angeles, 106,156; Manny Sanguillen, Pittsburgh, 102,377; Ted Simmons, St. Louis, 95,318; Bob Boone, Phila. delphia, 58,848; Steve Yeager, Los Angeles, 36,901.
