title: Storm Kills 9 in Acapulco
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico June 17 (AP)The worst hurricane to strike this resort city since 1938 caused landslides that killed nine persons, including four children, the authorities announced today. Thirteen others are missing. The dead all came from poverty areas on the mountain outskirts of the city.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: SPECIALIST CAUTIONS ON ACUPUNCTURE USE
description: The chairman of the Ad Hoc Committee on Acupuncture of the National Institutes of Health says that the widespread clinical use of acupuncture in the United States is unwarranted pending further study.

title: Song Writer Says Soviet Will Let Him Go to Israel
description: MOSCOW, June 17Aleksandr A. Galich, the Soviet song writer and poet, reported today that he had been given permission to emigrate to Israel.

title: In Final Hours of the 30th Day, Wilson Vetoes Bill Easing SundaySales Law
description: ALBANY, June 17In the closing hours of the 30day billsigning period, Governor Wilson vetoed a bill that would have abolished criminal penalties for illegal sales on Sundays, his office announced today.

title: Birth Rates Found Declining the Most For Disadvantaged
description: Births among groups that traditionally have had the nation's highest ferttlity ratesthe poor, black, American Indians and MexicanAmericanshave declined more rapidly since the nineteensixties than births among whites and more affluent Americans, two new studies have shown.

title: Regents Scandal a Shock At Site of the Exam Theft
description: Shock and embarrassment were widespread yesterday at the Solomon Schechter High School of Brooklyn as faculty members and students digested the implications of the involvement of their tiny school in the mushrooming scandal surrounding stolen Regents examinations.

title: Low Turnout Is Expected In Newark Election Today
description: NEWARK, June 17Less than half the city's registered voters are expected to turn out tomorrow for a runoff election in which 10 candidates are seeking three atlarge and two ward Council seats on the ninemember City Council.

title: KISSINGER AFFIRMS RESIGNATION STAND
description: JERUSALEM, June 17  A week after he threatened to resign unless he was cleared of allegations of impropriety in the wiretapping of Government officials and newsmen, Secretary of State Kissinger appeared back in his customary good humor today.

title: Perjury Trial of Ehrlichman Is Scheduled for Aug. 15
description: LOS ANGELES, June 17 (AP)  A trial date of Aug. 15 was set today in the perjury case of John D. Ehrlichman, the former Presidential aide.

title: Earnings Fallat Tiffany Despite Sales Increase
description: Tiffany & Co. announced yesterday a drop in earnings in the first quarter to $221,236 from $230,117 in the period a year earlier. Pershare earnings remained at 10 cents. Walter Hoving, Tiffany's chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting held in the St. Regis Hotel here that the reduced earnings were attributable to curtailed Japanese business because of Japan's energy crisis.

title: WHEAT FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: All wheat futures deliveries closed up the 20centabushel limit yesterday, amid reports of a dearth of farmer selling to local grain elevators. The rain that has delayed harvesting in some areas was one reason that led to a heavy spate of buying by speculators to cover their short positions.

title: No Regrets for Fezler Over Open Finish
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 17Since there is no stopping a golfer, even a slightly disappointed one, Forrest Fezler was on the links for another round today. The 24yearold runnerup in the United States Open said. I was thinking of yesterday on every shot today.

title: ...Collective Interest
description: Only gradually is the reality sinking in that burdensharing between rich and poor nations is not merely a moral imperative or humanitarian preoccupation of idle clreamers; it is the only means of insuring survival of the world economic order.

title: Peking Wall Posters Back Attack on Certain Leaders
description: PEKING, June 17 (Agence FrancePresse)  Eight new wall posters were on view here today in support of earlier posters attacking certain leaders of the Peking Revolutionary Committee.

title: TV: Challenge to PublicBroadcasting Freedom
description: As a television critic, I sometimes find myself traipsing about curious fringes. The total picture goes far beyond primetime formats at thethree powerful networks. The latest offbeat excursion involves a video group that has decided to challenge the concept of freedom on the publicaccess channels of cable television.

title: 14 CITY FOOD PLACES TERMED VIOLATORS
description: The Health Department has named 14 more food businesses for failing their second healthcode inspection and warned that closing orders could result if violations persist upon a final visit by its inspectors. The names of the establishments cited follow.

title: Old Ties to Navy Ease Way For Coast Base
description: BREMERTON, Wash  Riding at anchor among the gray ghosts on the dark waters of Sinclair Inlet is an aging cruiser that once had a special kinship with this Navy town.

title: J.D.L. MEMBER, 17, GUILTY IN ASSAULT
description: By PAUL L. MONTGOMERY A 17yearold member of the Jewish Defense League was convicted in Federal District Court yesterday of assaulting a Soviet diplomat on the testimony of the official who testified as a United States Government witness.

title: Dartmouth Gets Coach
description: HANOVER, N. H., June 17 (AP)  Tom Griffith, former coach at the University of Wisconsin in Green Bay, was named soccer coach at Dartmouth today. The 35yearold Griffith succeeded George Beim, who had resigned.

title: Soccer Ardor at Peak in W. Germany
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, June 17  With the World Cup soccer matches under way in stadiums across the country, the West Germans, favored to win the championship, are in a fervor that pushes their bitter political squabbles to the sidelines.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Soviet Book Goes To BobbsMerrill

title: Mrs. Nixon's Day in Israel: A Tribute, a Kibbutz
description: QIRYAT ANAVIM, June 17  While her husband held political talks with Israeli leaders in Jerusalem this morning, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon visited a kibbutz here and the repository of the bead Sea Scrolls.

title: PHENIX CITY ALA., IS STAYING CLEAN
description: PHEMIX CITY, Ala., June 17 Ma Beachie's Swing Club, a place where thousands of G.I.'s from Fort Benning in Georgia looked for good times but often found rough treatment, no longer stands in Phenix City.

title: Screen:Feminism Is Defended in 'Free Woman'
description: At the Paris Theater, an uncommonly engrossing and wise new German movie, "A Free Woman," records the losing battle a divorced woman in her thirties fights in Munich to attain belated self-fulfillment. The die is cast in a briskly impersonal society geared to male dominance and early training for career women. This attractive, capable young woman, needing love and encouragement, determinedly sidesteps her former slot of housewife, studies voice and dance, takes on subordinate jobs and painfully maneuvers with her former husband (a cold fish who shrewdly remarries) for child custody.All this is quietly and beautifully projected by an unobtrusive camera and stunningly personified by the feeling, low-key performance of Margarethe von Trotta in the central role. The blond star also happens to be the wife of the gifted director, Volker Schlondorff, as well as his co-screen writer.They and the other performers and contributors have forged a fine, thoughtful and stimulating film that observantly mirrors a human condition, the traditional subordination of women with truthful, biting irony. It would be hard to find a more persuasive and appealing proponent of feminism than Mrs. Schlondorff.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FASHION TALK
description: Evening dresses are somehow beyond the daytoday fashion scramble. There's a laissezfaire attitude toward lengths. As for shapes, the more they reveal about the wearer's own shape, the more successful they are.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, June 17  Weequahic High School in 196566 and 196667 had what some observers felt was the finest schoolboy basketball team ever to play in New Jersey, and quite possibly in the entire country.

title: SELMA GUBIN
description: Selma Gubin, an artist, whose work included portraits, landscapes and still lifes, died yesterday at her home here. She was 71 years old.

title: U.N. Said to Find Evidence of Mozambique Massacre
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 17 (Reuters)A United Nations commission investigating reports of atrocities by Portuguese troops in Mozambique has concluded provisionally that a massacre took place at Wiryamu in 1971, reliable sources said today.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: Anglers who are also conservationists  and the combination is becoming more common daily  are often justifiably bewildered by a plethora of organizations, all seeking their support and all espousing worthwhile causes.

title: BAUXITETAX RISE TO BE CONTESTED
description: The major domestic aluminum companies said yesterday that they planned to fight bauxite taxes proposed by the Jamaican Government.

title: Con Edison Submits Rate Data Showing Uneven CostSharing
description: In its pending bid for electric rate increases, the Consolidated Edison Company submitted calculations yesterday indicating that smallhome and officebuilding customers had been paying less than their share of service costs while businesses and apartment buildings had paid more.

title: MRS. STUART PRESTON
description: Mrs. Madeleine O'Brien Preston, widow of Stuart D. Preston, a banker and insurance officer, died Saturday at her home, 125 East 72d Street. She was 88 years old.

title: Naval Exercise Off Coast
description: SAN DIEGO, June 17 (AP) Fifteen United States warships opened a naval exercise off Southern California today in a test of the readiness of ships used to hunt and fight nuclear submarines. Aboard the ships were 5,000 crewmen, including 200 midshipmen of the United States Naval Academy and Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps. The exercise will last a week.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Advertising: Promoting Stamps
description: The United States Postal Service, which certainly hasn't been able to make any money selling its service, is going to try to increase its income from selling its product.

title: WARREN H. WEISZ
description: Warren H. Weisz, president of the Clinton. Mills Sales Corporation, died Monday in Doctors Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 2727 Palisade Avenue in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: AGNES S. LEWIS
description: Mrs. Agnes Stehlik Lewis, former dietitian of the New Lincoln Schools here and secretary general of the Young Women's Christian Association in Czechoslovakia in the nineteenthirties, died Thursday in Mount Kisco, N. Y. She was 82 years old and lived in Bedford Village, N. Y.

title: Jaworski Seeks Denial Of Steinbrenner's Plea
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)The special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, asked a Federal court today to deny motions by George N. Steinbrenner, principal owner of the New York Yankers, to dismiss charges against him in connection with an effort to raise money for campaign contributions.

title: The Work And the Worker
description: AMSTERDAMNot long ago a management expert visited the typewriter assembly plant operated here by International Business Machines and denounced the plant's new production techniques as Communism. He was followed by another outside expert, who looked over the plant and dedared with disapproval that it was producing neocapitalists.

title: P.B.S. Renews Black Journal and Opera Theater
description: Black Journal and WNET Opera Theater, threatened with cancellation during five bidding rounds of public television's Station Program Cooperative, received sufficient support in the sixth round to be renewed next fall by, the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: BEATEN BICYCLIST DEAD OF INJURIES
description: Roger Hane, 36yearold magazine illustrator, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital of injuries suffered Friday evening when he was beaten and robbed of his new bicycle in Central Park.

title: People and Business
description: Monetary policy must be the primary strategic weapon to control inflation, James J. O'Leary, Nice chairman of the United States Trust Company of New York, said yesterday.

title: City Employe Is Reported Target of Burglary Ring
description: The office of the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, yesterday was invesgiaating underworld information that a city employe had hidden in his Brooklyn home graft or bribe money.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Art Places Swap White Elephants

title: NADJARI IS ACCUSED BY EXLEVITT AIDE
description: A former aide to the State Controller who was indicted last year on attempted bribery and conspiracy charges asserted in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday that prosecutors had been trying to coerce him into planting an eavesdropping device in the Brooklyn Democratic headquarters.

title: Jersey Senate Curbs Use Of Medicaid for Abortion
description: TRENTON, June 17  The State Senate passed today a controversial bill that would prohibit the use of Medicaid funds for elective abortions.

title: U.S. Expresses Hope That a Treaty Will Surface at 3d U.N. Conference on Law of the Seas
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Chief United States negotiator on the law of the seas said today that nations seeking to work out a treaty governing the oceans faced tough political choices, but he expressed the belief that they would make those choices to avoid escalating conflict.

title: TRIAL DUE TODAY IN PAYOFFS CASE
description: A sergeant assigned to the Police Department's special anticorruption unit and to joint investigations in the office of the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, goes on departmental trial today, accused of accepting payoffs in 1971 in exchange for disclosing confidential police information to another policeman.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: John A. Kervick, the former New Jersey State Treasurer, was fined $10,000 and placed on probation for three years in Federal Court in Trenton yesterday. The 68yearold defendant, who was a principal adviser to former Gov. Richard J. Hughes, a Democrat, during his eightyear tenure as State Treasurer, pleaded guilty a year ago to bribery and extortion charges. Suffering from cancer, Mr. Kervick has been confined in a Federal prison hospital since last February. Citing the serious nature of his illness, Judge Clarkson S. Fisher said he would Impose no further confinement.

title: Protestant Group in Ulster Suggests Truce With I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 17. (AP)  Leaders of Northern Ireland's Protestant extremist paramilitary groups were reported to have met today to discuss whether to seek a ceasefire with the Irish Republican Army.

title: 2,200YearOld Ship Found Off Cyprus to Be Shown
description: KYRENIA, CyprusAbout 2,200 years ago a merchant ship set oft on a journey through the eastern Mediterranean, stopping at such islands as Samos, Kos and Rhodes, trading in oil and wine, millstones and almonds.

title: Big Rail Union to Demand 35 Per Cent Wage Increase
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)The largest of 15 unions facing contract negotiations this year with the nation's railroads said today that it vvould demand a 35 per cent wage increase.

title: A New Task, A New Rodino
description: WASHINGTON, June 17My granddaughter calls me Mr. Chairman now, Peter W. Rodino Jr. said with a raspy laugh and a quick grimace. But he seems to prize granddaddy more than Mr. Chairman when it comes from Carla, his browneyed, 7yearold granddaughter.

title: ALASKA GOVERNOR FACING EXRIYALS
description: ANCHORAGE, June 16All the Governors the state of Alaska has ever had are running this year in a field that also includes a hunting guide, an Eskimo and a semisecessionist.

title: Mobil Discussing Bid to Acquire Marcor Control at $371Million
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation, the nation's third largest oilcompany, is discussing with the Marcor Corporation a. tender offer under which it would seek 51 per cent of Marcor's stock.

title: G.O.P. Policy Group Set Up
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 17 (AP)Republican leaders from New England have agreed to form a cooperative to develop party policy on regional issues. At a meeting here Satruday, nine party leaders voted to set up a group to examine such issues as the environment, refinery construction, transportation and energy problems.

title: Collective Crisis ...
description: These are days in which seemingly melodramatic forebodings for the world assume the harsh reality of official statistics, of sober projections by reasonable and softspoken professionals not given to excesses of doomsaying. Thus, a task force of economists from North America, Western Europe and Japan have concluded that in the coming months of summer, the lives and fortunes Of large numbers of human beings hang upon the outcome of decisions taken by a small handful of national leaders.

title: Sale of One Church To Foster Reunion
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 17  This city's two Presbyterian churches are for sale$700,000 each, including parish houses, trees, rolling lawns, the works. A brochure calls it an opportunity for building developer or industry.

title: Local Trot Writers To Hail Dauplaise
description: Norman Dauplaise, the 34ranked among the top 10 nationally last year in winners and money earnings, has been voted the Achievement Award by the New York Chapter of the United States Harness writers' Association.

title: Wright Says He Won't Run for Congress
description: A Brooklyn Congressional district that had been reapportioned under a Justice Department order so that a black could be elected will instead very likely have a white representative.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
A WATERGATE JUROR IS ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Mrs. Lucy M. Veda, a member of the second Watergate grand jury, has been suspended and is under grand jury investigation regarding allegations of fraud, according to sources.

title: Swap Day: Clearance for Cultural White Elephants
description: New York cultural institutions, ranging from the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the Magnolia Tree Earth Center of BedfordStuyvesent, held a whiteelephant party yesterday that turned their attic junk into treasure.

title: Boston to Paris and Back In 6 Hours and 18 Minutes
description: BOSTON, June 17Charles A. Lindbergh flew across the Atlantic in 1927 in 33 hours. Jumbo jets now make the trip in approximately seven hours. Today, for the first time, a Concorde supersonic transport flew the Atlantic twice Boston to Paris and backin six hours and 18 minutes.

title: Treasury Bills Off At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Yields on threemonth and sixmonth United States Treasury bills were lower today in the Government's weekly competitive sale of these shortterm securities.

title: 50 Flee Propane Gas Leak
description: NASHUA, N. H., June 17 (A P)About 50 persons were evacuated yesterday after a propane gas leak was discovered in a railroad tank car at the Home Gas Corporation.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: IRVING J. KURZ
description: Irving J. Kurz, a retired trial lawyer, died yesterday in the Florence Nightingale Home. He was 82 years old and lived at 6836 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the hours before the fight, the referee slouched in his elegant suite high in the Park Lane above the midtown office buildings.

title: Murder of L.I. Shop Owner Seen as an Isolated Case
description: MANHASSET, L. I., June 17 If a shop owner had been murdered during a robbery in New York City, the incident would probably have resulted in fear and concern among other shopkeepers and residents in the area.

title: Soviet Docking Protested
description: LONDON, June 17 (Reauters)  A Member of Parliament called today for a strong protest to the Soviet Union over the docking in Glasgow last week of a Soviet weather ship that he said was a spy ship packed with electronic equipment. The legislator said it was outrageous that the ship should have sailed near the American nuclear submarine base at Hely Loch.

title: New Chief On Agenda For N.B.A.
COOP PLAN RULED FRAUDULENT HERE
description: A State Supreme Court justice found yesterday that the conversion of an East Side apartment building into a cooperative had involved fraudulent practices, but he declined to annul the coop plan.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CATTLEMEN TO GET SUPERMARKET AID
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 An effort to reduce meat prices and promote sales was promised today by supermarket spokesmen during a White House meeting of Government and foodindustry officials on the plight of the nation's troubled cattle producers.

title: World's, Foremost Tennis Stage Awaits Its Players
description: All roads lead this week to Wimbledon, the world's most celebrated tournament staged at the AllEngland Club in the suburbs of London.

title: Brandeis Post Filled
description: WALTHAM, Mass., June 17 (AP)  Brandeis University has named Joseph S. Berliner of Lexington as the school's Dean of Faculty. Mr. Berliner, a 53yearold authority on Soviet economics, has been a Brandeis faculty member for 11 years. He will take office Thursday.

title: People in Sports
description: If rumors at the National Basketball Association meetings here are confirmed, the Denver Rockets of the rival American Basketball Association today will sign their top draft choice, Bobby Jones of North Carolina. The Rockets have scheduled a news conference for this afternoon.

title: Prices on Stock Market Fall Across a Wide Front
description: Stock prices continued to decline along a broad front for the second consecutive session yesterday. Trading was light as the absence of favorable economic news kept many investors on the sidelines.

title: 1 Killed, 4 Injured In Roxbury Crash Of Freight Trains
description: WHARTON, June 17 (UPI)One railroad worker was killed and four others were injured today when two freight trains smashed into each other after the brakes on one apparently gave way at a junction in Roxbury Township, the state police said. One of the engines and 21 cars behind it were derailed, some of them knocked over completely.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page 69 Apartments 77 Auction Sales 48 Auto. Exchange 44 Boats 77 Bus. Opp ties 65 Buyers' Wis. 73 Career Training 46 Dogs, Cats & Other Pets 72 Halo Wanted 78 Lost & Found 76 Merch. Off'gs

title: 100 Rebels Reported Killed By Phnom Penh's Forces
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 17 (UPI)  Cambodian Government troops killed more than 100 insurgents today in fighting 11 miles north of Phnom Penh, according to reports from the field.

title: LATE PAYMENTS ON MORTGAGES UP
description: Delinquency Rates Advance to a 20Year PeakWASHINGTON June 17, (UPI) The Mortgage Bankers Association said today that galloping inflation had resulted in the highest number of late home mortgage payments in the last 20 years.

title: Examiner Urges a $2 Fee On Telegrams to Officials
description: A Public Service Commission examiner has recommended that the charge for intrastate telegrams from citizens to public officials be raised from $1 to $2, and not to $3, as the commission announced last week.

title: Kervick Is Fined on Corruption Charges
description: TRENTON, June 17Former State Treasurer John A. Kervick, physically ravaged by cancer, was sentenced in Federal Court today, to three years' probation and fined $10,000 on bribery charges.

title: High Court Backs a Panel For Cosmetics Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)  The Supreme Court ruled today that a dispute between the AlbertoCulver Company and a European cosmetics manufacturer should be settled before an international panel.

title: Bomb in London Damages Oldest Hall of Parliament.
description: LONDON, June 17A bomb exploded today, in the most historic part of the Houses of Parliament, damaging Westminster Hall, the 900yearold chamber that has seen, much of British history. Eleven people were injured, none seriously.

title: MRS. JOHN A. BAKER
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 17Mrs. Adelaide Nichols Baker, founder of the Westport World Affairs Center, died today at Norwalk Hospital. She was 78 years old, and lived at 118 Clinton Avenue here.

title: WILLIAM H. OGDEN
description: William H. Ogden, a former president of the New York Water Service Corporation, died yesterday in Community Hospital at Glen Cove, L. I. He was 68 years old and lived at 38 Thompson Park, Glen Cove.

title: Clark Sues Liberals On Javits Endorsement
description: Ramsey Clark, a contender for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, challenged in Manhattan Federal Court yesterday the Liberal party endorsement of Senator Jacob K. Javits, a Republican.

title: Ore Waste Hearing Put Off
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 17 (AP)  A special hearing over the Reserve Mining Company's discharging of taconite waste into Lake Superior that was scheduled for tomorrow has been postponed until Thursday. Federal District Judge Miles W. Lord, who had requested the hearing in his court, granted the delay so that Reserve officials could meet Wednesday with Minnesota state environmental officials.

title: Twine Hoist Is Used to Supply PowerLess Tenants
description: Shopping bags were being lowered by twine for as much as four floors yesterday to get food and searchlights for commercial tenants at 109 West 38th Street caught in a dispute between the Consolidated Edison Company and the building management.

title: On an Ohio Campus, Chaos Of '74
description: ATHENS, OhioEducators who believe that today's college students are carbon copies of the nowlegendary drones of the nineteenfifties are living in a dream world.

title: OIL CONCERN FACES A DELAY ON PLANT
description: The efforts of the JOC Oil Company to buy 50 acres of land from the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark may temporarily spare Jersey City's divided City Council the political embarrassment of voting on a variance needed for the proposed construction of the concern's controversial oil refining and storage plant.

title: School Board Votes To Discipline Three In Student Paddling
description: The community school board of District 9 in the Bronx voted yesterday to suspend without pay for the remainder of the school term two deans who the board said had used wooden paddles to discipline students at the Jordan L. Mott Junior High School 22. It also voted to reprimand the school's principal.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Court Blocks the Construction Of a Jersey Turnpike Branch
description: TRENTON, June 17A threejudge Appeals Court blocked the construction of a 38mile spur of the New Jersey Turnpike today, ruling that the authority had misled the public by proposing one alignment at a public hearing, then approving another route later.

title: Books of The Times
description: STREET GAMES. By Rosellen Brown. 287 pages. Doubleday. $6.95.

title: Aaron Holds Big Lead in AllStar Vote
description: Henry Aaron of the Atlanta Braves, baseball's alltime homerun king, continued to lead the voting yesterday for the National League AllStar team, the Associated Press reported. He prevented a sweep by Cincinnati and Los Angeles players who led the other seven positions open to balloting.

title: Police Station at Long Branch Strafed From a Passing Car
description: LONG BRANCH, June 17 Police headquarters on busy Broadway here was attacked by one or more armed assailants at 3 P.M. yesterday.

title: Whine May Get Seat, Rezoned for a Black
description: A Brooklyn congressional district that had been reapportioned under a Justice Department order so that a black could be elected will instead very likely have a white Representative.

title: Blacks Return to South In a Reverse Migration
description: ATLANTA, June 17Driven out by racism and lack of economic opportunity, Southern blacks have been migrating North in huge numbers for more than a century, riding the Illinois Central, the Greyhound and the old family Ford toward the promise of Chicago's South Side and New York's Harlem.

title: Free Concert Series Set for Lincoln Center
description: A series of free concerts will be presented on five Wednesdays in the Lincoln Center Midday Miniconcerts beginning at 12:30 on June 26.

title: Staff Interviews Kleindienst
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)  The House Judiciary Committe staff interviewed former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst today to determine whether he should be called as a witness by the panel, The Washington Post reported in its Tuesday editions. The committe special counsel, on impeachment, John boar, led the questioning of Mr. Kleindienst, but the subjects were not disclosed, The Post said.

title: Stage: Romeo and Juliet
description: STRATFORD, Conn., June 16  Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet is the most universal of tragedies. Why? Is it the simple story of starcross'd lovers, or thei maginative reach of Shakespeare's poetry? What gives this single play the power of its passion?

title: '53 UPRISING IN EAST IS MARKED IN BONN
description: BONN, June 17 (UPI)West Germans commemorated the abortive 1953 workers' uprising against Communist rule in East Germany with renewed calls to overcome the division imposed on the nation after World War II.

title: Market Place: If Ban Is Lifted On Gold Bullion
description: There are growing indications that American citizens will soon again be allowed to hold gold bullion. The restriction dates back to 1934 and President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Gold Reserve Act.

title: Primer for the Broke
description: This is a telephone. It is not making a sound. See how quiet the telephone is? See how happy it looks?

title: Harvard Gets U.S. Grant
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)  Harvard University has been awarded a grant of almost $200,000 to continue a study for the Massachusetts Department of Youth Services. The grant, made by the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, will cover the third year of a fouryear analysis by Harvard of the changes in the Youth Services Program since the closing of Massachusetts juvenile institutions in 1972.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Piniella's 2Run Homer Sparks Yanks to Victory Over Angels, 51
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 17  The California Angels found out tonight it's not easy to hold down the rampaging Yankees for long.

title: TAXCUT BACKERS FACE SENATE BAR
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The effort of liberal Democrats to attach a $6billion tax reduction and a package of tax reforms to the pending debtceiling bill appeared likely today to be blocked by a filibuster.

title: Senate Backs Teachers On Contract Bargaining
description: TRENTON, June 17  Organized labor, and New Jersey's public school teachers in particular, won a major victory in the Legislature today when the Senate gave initial approval to a series of amendments that would commit the labor disputes of all public employes to collective bargaining.

title: Newcombe and Mrs. King TopRated at Wimbledon
description: LONDON, June 17 (AP)John Newcombe of Australia and Mrs. Billie Jean King of the United States, the defending champion, were seeded first for singles today in the Wimbledon tennis championship which begins its twoweek run next Monday.

title: WINNERS SELECTED FOR LOEB AWARDS
description: Paul E. Steiger of the Los Angeles Times, Livingston Taylor of the Courier Journal (Louisville, Ky.), Carol J. Lomis of Fortune: Magazine, Henry Wallich of Newsweek and John Brooks, author of The GoGo Years, have been selected asi the winners of the Gerald Loeb awards for distinguished business and financial journalism, the Graduate School of Management of the University of California at Los Angeles announced yesterday.

title: Recapitalization Plan Fails At the LTV Annual Meeting
description: A recapitalization plan for the LTV Corporation failed yesterday at a reconvened annual meeting to win the approval of holders of a required twothirds of the 500,000 shares of the company's Class A preferred stock and the majority vote of the company's AA special stock.

title: LeftWing Gains In Sardinia Shake Position of Rumor
description: ROM, Tuesday, June 18Socialist's and Communists made gains and the dominant Christian Democratic party suffered a stinging setback in regional elections in Sardinia Sunday and yesterday.

title: Moiseyev Captures Wild Tone of Polovetsian Dances
description: Igor Moiseyev, the Soviet ballet master whose troupe will perform the Polovetsian Dances from Prince Igor beginning here tonight, said yesterday that he planned a radical departure from the approach taken earlier in this century by Michel Fokine.

title: Thefts Raise New Questions About Regents
description: Until last week, the state's high school Regents examinations were considered inviolate. Getting the answers beforehand would have been like getting the gold out of Fort Knox. Generations of students growing up in New York were warned by parents and teachers, Just wait till you get to high school and have to take the Regents. Within recent memory, an elaborate ribboncutting ceremony was performed at some schools on the day a Regents examination was given as the tests were removed from sealed envelopes.

title: Jordan at a Glance
description: Jordan has not been the most hostile of Israel's enemies in recent years, and, under King Hussein, has been the Arab country with the closest ties to Washington. For the last decade the Jordanian Government has been under almost constant pressure from more militant Arabs, from Palestinian guerrilla groups and from Israel, which has won sizable parts of Jordan's territory.

title: Saxbe Critical of Nixon On Enforcement of Law
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 UPI)Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today President Nixon either was ignorant of grand jury operations or had a casual attitude about enforcement of laws in connection with the Justice Department investigation of Watergate.

title: Women at a Hearing Here Charge Economic Bigotry
description: Witnesses at a hearing on economic discrimination against women yesterday included a former welfare mother pleading for expansion of subsidized day care  which had enabled her to go to work and to school and a Wall Street financial analyst attacking tax laws that, she said, reduced the $12,000 salary of a working wife and mother to a $1 net increase in the family income.

title: REV. EDWARD W. TROIKE
description: The Rev. Edward W. Troike, spiritual director of the Cathedral Prep Seminary in Elmhurst, Queens, died here Friday. He was 43 years old and lived in Elmhurst.

title: Japanese Shipbuilding Is Hit by Inflation
description: TOKYO (Reuters)Japan's shipbuilding industry, the largest in the world, is losing Its competitive power because of the inflation that has hit the country.

title: Muslims Say Fear Spurred SportingGoodsStore Raid
description: The defense in the trial of four Sunni Muslims charged with murder, kidnapping and roppery at a Brooklyn sporting goods store in January, 1973, portrayed its clients yesterday as formerly peaceful men who had tried to steal guns because they feared for their lives.

title: 2,800 BEGIN DRIVE FOR ROSENBERGE
description: A crowd of 2,800 persons paying from $3 to $50 a ticket, filled Carnegie Hall to capacity last night to help start a nationwide campaign to clear the names of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg the couple executed in 1953 for conspiring to pass atomic secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: Panthers Score S.L.A. Tape
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 17 (UPI)The Black Panther party said today that tapes from Patricia Hearst and two other members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army fugitives who are members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army were an impassioned call for reckless, defeatist, lastditchstand terrorism and insurrection. In an editorial in its weekly newspaper, the party said the position of Miss Hearst and William and Emily Harris was devoid of any consciousness raising program, method or process for social change.

title: School Lunch Plan For Middle Class Approved in House
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)The House of Representatives voted today to increase the Federal share of the cost of free and reducedprice school lunches by $225million. Without such an increase, supporters warned, children in middleincome families would be eliminated from the program.

title: NIXON PROMISES LONGTERM HELP FOR THE ISRAELIS
description: JERUSALEM, June 17President Nixon today concluded a 26hour visit here in which he assured Israel of longterm military and economic assistance and urged the new Government to demonstrate its statesmanship by taking risks for peace.

title: Hope Golf Date Set
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. (UPI) Next year's Bob Hope Desert Classic golf tourney will be held Feb. 5 to 9. Bermuda Dunes Country Club will be host to the 90hole tournament. Other participating clubs are Indian Wells, La Quinta and Tamarisk.

title: Hospital Workers Stage Demonstrations for Pact
description: More than 1,000 union delegates met with hospital and nursing home administrators around the city yesterday as both sides awaited the naming of a panel to break a deadlock in contract negotiations.

title: 2,200YearOld Ship Found Off Cyprus to Be Shown
description: KYRENIA, CyprusAbout 2,200 years ago a merchant ship set off on a journey through the eastern Mediterranean, stopping at such islands as Samos, Kos and Rhodes, trading in oil and wine, millstones and almonds.

title: MRS. DAVID SUSONG
description: GREENEVILLE, Tenn., June 17 (AP)Edith O'Keefe Susong, (publisher of The Greeneville Daily Sun for more than 50 years, died today. She was 84 years old and was the widow of David Susong.

title: RUTH MILLS TEAGUE
description: Mrs. Ruth Mills Teague, an author who was the widow of Walter Dorwin Teague, an industrial designer, died Saturday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. She was 78 years old and lived in Jamesburg, N.J.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: SURVIVORS From more than 150,000 entries whittled down to 8,000, and after some scrupulous sifting and winnowing by panels of judges  most of them about three times the average age of the contestants  the 47th National High School Art Exhibition has culled 454 prizewinning works by students from high schools and junior highs across the country.

title: Spur for Turnpike Is Blocked by Court
description: TRENTON, June 17  A threejudge Appeals Court blocked the construction of 38mile spur of the New Jersey Turnpike todaq, ruling that the authority had misled the public by proposing one alignment at a public hearing, then approving another route later.

title: 4 in Illinois Family Are Slain
description: PARK RIDGE, Ill., June 17 (AP)Four members of a family were found slain today in the basement of their suburban home after a fire broke out, the authorities said.

title: Police Seek Man In 16 Rape Cases Or Serial Assaults
description: HARTFORD, June 17 (AP)Connecticut and New York State police were searching for a man believed responsible for sexual attacks on 16 girls and young women, the last occurring Saturday night in Orange, State Police Commissioner Cleveland B. Fuessenich said today.

title: Padres Win From Cubs In 13th, 75
description: CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) Dave Winfield, who had homered in the sixth inning, drove in the winning run with a single in the 13th today to give the San Diego Padres a 75 victory over the Chicago Cubs. The Padres had trailed at one point, 5.0.

title: Difficulties Said to Remain On New NATO Declaration
description: OTTAWA, June 17 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Jean Sauvagnargues of France said today that difficulties remained to be settled over alliance consultation procedures before a new North Atlantic Treaty Organization declaration can be made final.

title: Foster in Draw With Ahumada, Keeps Title
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 17 (UPI)Bob Foster, lacking the aggressiveness shown in his 13 previous title defenses, and Jorge Ahumada of Argentina fought 15 rounds to a controversial draw tonight.

title: CATTLEMEN TO GET SUPERMARKET AlD
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 An effort to reduce meat prices and promote sales was promised today by supermarket spokesmen during a White House meeting of Government and foodindustry officials on the plight of the nation's troubled cattle producers.

title: A Special Inquiry On Franklin Bank? Jackson Denies It
description: Seenator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, issued a terse statement yesterday in response to widespread published reports that Senate investigators were looking into the financially troubled Franklin National Bank.

title: Prices For City Food Declind
description: A 9.4 per cent decline in the wholesale prices that New York City pays for fresh food for city institutions was reported yesterday by Purchase Commissioner Robert I. Cohen for deliveries for the two weeks starting next Monday. The drop, Commissioner Cohen said, included a 10.1 per cent decrease in beef prices and a 7,6 per cent decline for fruits and vegetables.

title: A World Depression?
description: The hottest socioeconomic story of the moment is the coming crash and the end of civilization as we have known it.

title: Warm Welcome for Nixons in Jordan Includes Drill Team and Jets
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 17 President Nixon received another warm ovation today when he arrived here from Israel on the last leg of his Middle Enstern trip.

title: ATOMIC EXPLOSION SET OFF BY CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, June 17China conducted a relatively large nuclear test early today, the United States Atomic Energy Commission announced.

title: Blacks Return to South In a Reverse Migration
description: ATLANTA, June 17Driven ??out by racism and lack of economic opportunity, Southern blacks have been migrating North in huge numbers for more than a century, riding the Illinois Central, the Greyhound and the old family Ford toward the promise of Chicago's South Side and New York's Harlem.

title: Cutlass Scores at $1 5.80, Minus Telephone Charges
description: Cutlass of the Powhatan Stable won the feature race at Belmont Park, yesterday, to the mild surprise of the crowd of 18,562. The surprise rested on the fact that the Cragwood Stable's Halo, the oddson favorite, not only finished third in the field of seven, but was the subject of a stewards' inquiry which ultimately caused him to be placed last.

title: SENATE STUDY FINDS 858 U.S. DATA BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)  Senate investigators disclosed today they had discovered that 54 executive branch agencies kept 858 Federal data banks, containing more thane 1.25 billion records on Americans.

title: South American Cup Teams Gloomy
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 17In spite of all their natural color, rhythm and soccer experience, the South American teams have found themselves in a collective gloom in this year's World Cup extravaganza.

title: Appeals Court Upholds. Writ Revoking Bail for Calley
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 17 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit upheld today its order revoking the $1,000 bail of former Army Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who was convicted of killing at least 22 civilians in an assault on the Vietnamese village of My Lai. victed of killing at least 22 civilians in an assault on the Vietnamese village of My Lai.

title: A Listing of Books That Have Been Published Recently
description: New Books

title: Stabilization of Apartment Rent Approved by City Council Panel
description: After several hours of paradoxical testimony from landlord and tenant representatives, the City Council's General Welfare Committee voted unanimously yesterday to make the state's new apartmentrentstabilization law effective in New York City.

title: Record Pace Is Reported For Future Contracts
description: Trading in commodity futures contracts continued at a record pace for the period for January through May, according to a report issued by the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms. A total of 11,437,000 contracts, were traded in the periods, compared with 11,154,000 contracts a year ago, which was a record at that time.

title: Health Corps Aids Doctors and Communities
description: DANSVILLE, N.Y.A surprise party was held here a few nights ago for Dr. Richard A. Patt, with 130 friends present to say goodby to the man who has spent the last two years as a family physician in this rural community while a member of the National Health Service Corps.

title: Perry Notches No. 12, Beating White Sox, 43
description: CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP) Gaylord Perry of the Cleveland Indians won his 12th straight game, beating the Chicago White Sox, 43, tonight. Jack Brohamer's runscoring single in the ninth inning provided the victory margin.

title: Notes on People
description: The second annual Lyndon Baines Johnson Foundation Award will be shared by Ivan Allen Jr., former Mayor of Atlanta, and Franklin A. Thomas, president of the Bedfordstuyvesant Redevelopment Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Lady Bird Johnson and Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, cochairmen of a selection panel. Mr. Allen, Mayor of Atlanta from 1962 to 1970, was cited for his leadership during an important period of social and economic modernization in that city. Mr. Thomas was praised for his efforts to revitalize the economy of, the country's secondlargest black community. The award carries a $25,000 stipend.

title: TrainTruck Crash Kills 16
description: CAIRO, June 17 (Reuters)Sixteen persons were killed and more than 50 injured when a train struck a truck on the main CairoAlexandria railroad line about 30 miles north of here today, rail officials said.

title: Slow Cooking: An Evaluation
description: Technology has a way of going to extremes. First there was all that fuss about the microwave oven, which will cook a dish in the blink of an eye. Now comes a trend toward electric pots that cook a dish so slowly you have time for at least 40 winks.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday it had received a commitment valued at about $500million to supply two 626,000kilowatt nuclear electric generating plants to the Government of the Philippines. The plants would be operated by the National Power Corporation. Westinghouse would provide overall management for the project through its power systems projects division.

title: Veto by Meskill on the Erasure Of Arrest Records Is Overridden
description: HARTFORD, June 17  The 4erieral Assembly today overrode Gov. Thomas J. Meskill's veto of a bill providing for the erasure of all police and court records of arrests in Connecticutithat resulted in acquittals, portions, dismissals or decisions not prosecute. Even photographs and fingerprint records will have to be handed over to an acquitted person under the new law.

title: CAPT. E. R. M'CLUNG, NAVAL CONSULTANT
description: Capt. Edgar Raymond McClung, a retired Navy officer who was later a consultant to the State Department, died yesterday in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Simon Cites Two Conditions On Private Gold Ownership
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (Reuters)Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today there were two conditions that would have to be met before he would recommend to the President that the 40year ban on private gold ownership be lifted.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The makeup of the New Jersey State Fish and Game Council as it is currently constituted is unconstitutional, a Passaic Superior Court judge ruled yesterday. In the case of the Humane Society v. the New Jersey State Fish and Game Council, Judge Peter Ciolino handed down a 10page decision stating that the council could no longer limit the selection of its members to sportsmen, farmers and commercial fishermen as it had in the past.

title: MRS. JOSEPH P. RIPLEY
description: Mrs. Florence Albro Ripley, wife of Joseph P. Ripley, reti??d investment banker who was chairman of Harriman Ripley & Co., Inc., died yesterday at their home, 570 Park Avenue. She was 88 years old.

title: REV. DR. MILLS TAYLOR
description: The Rev. Dr. Mills J. Taylor, associate secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the United Presbyterian Church from 1918 to 1948, died Saturday in Drexel Hill, Pa. He was 95 years old and lived in Havertown, Pa.

title: NIXON PROMISES LONGTERM HELP FOR THE ISRAELIS
description: JERUSALEM, June 17President Nixon today concluded 26hour visit here in which he assured Israel of longterm military and economic assistance and urged the new Government to demonstrate its statesmanship by taking risks for peace.

title: White House Used Courts, A.C.L.U. Report Charges
description: WASHINGTON, June 17In a report submitted today to the Senate Judiciary Committee, the American Civil Liberties Union sought to show that the Nixon Administration had subverted the Federal justice system to its own purposes as part of the Watergate coverup.

title: VOLUME ON AMEX HITS 8YEAR LOW
description: Prices fell again yesterday on the. American Stock Exchange as doubts over any immediate decrease in prime interest rates kept so many investors on the sidelines that volume was the lowest in eight years.

title: Ford Voices Hope That Food Prices Will Level or Drop
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 17Vice President Ford expressed a restrained note of optimism here today that food prices would start leveling off soon and perhaps even drop.

title: MAIL STRIKE ADDS TO GINN'S WOES
description: LISBON, June 17Some 25,000 postal workers began a nationwide strike today in defiance of Government efforts to end the social agitation that has become almost chronic here since the military coup April 25.

title: Saigon Will Prosecute 118 Denied Hong Kong Asylum
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17 (AP)  The Saigon Government will prosecute 118 Vietnamese who were denied asylum in Hong Kong and were returned today, a Government source said.

title: Luxembourg Forms Cabinet; Gaston Thorn New Premier
description: BRUSSELS, June 17A new Luxembourg coalition has been formed, with Gaston Thorn, the Foreign Minister in the outgoing Cabinet, as both Premier and Foreign Minister.

title: Steel Production Shows 1.9% Drop From a Week Ago
description: Steel production for the week ended June 15 was at its lowest level this year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It placed the industry's output at 2,808,000 tons and an index level of 115.1. This was a decline of 1.9 per cent from the preceding week when the index stood at 117.3.

title: 4 More Regents Tests Off As Gold Tells of 3 Thefts
description: State education authorities canceled four more Regents examinations yesterday, making a total of nine Called off, as Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold said that he now believed that test booklets or answer sheets had been stolen from three schools in the borough and widely distributed.

title: DR. CLYDE O. FISHER
description: Dr. Clyde O. Fisher, who retired in 1959 as professor of economics at Wesleyan University Middletown, Conn., died Saturday in Middletown. He was 82 years old.

title: Tax Lawyer for Nixon Resigns As Notary in Inquiry on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 17 Frank DeMarco Jr., the tax lawyer who was accused of backdating documents that gave President Nixon a big tax deduction for his donation of prePresidential papers, has resigned his state notary commission.

title: Congressmen Assailed in Soviet For Pressing Emigration Issue
description: MOSCOW, June 17  The Government newspaper Izvestia charged tonight that some American Congressmen were trying to force the Soviet Union to submit to pressures unimaginable even in the coldwar era through restrictions on American trade legislation.

title: ATOMIC EXPLOSION SET OFF BY CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, June 17China conducted a relatively large nuclear test early today, the United States Atomic Energy Commission announced.

title: OIL NATIONS RAISE COMPANIES' COST
description: QUITO, Ecuador, June 17A majority of the world's large oilexporting countries announced today an increase of 2 per cent in royalties levied on Western oil companies after Saudi Arabia, the biggest exporter, had blocked an attempt to raise oil prices several dollars a barrel.

title: Dartmouth Gets Coach
description: HANOVER, N. H., June 17 (AP)  Tom Griffith, former coach at the University of Wisconsin in Green Bay, was named soccer coach at Dartmouth today. The 35yearold Griffith succeeded George Beim, who had resigned.

title: Boston to Paris and Back In 6 Hours and 18 Minutes
description: BOSTON, June 17Charles A. Lindbergh flew across the Atlantic in 1927 in 33 hours. Jumbo jets now make the trip in approximately seven hours. Today, for the first time, a Concorde supersonic transport flew the Atlantic twice Boston to Paris and backin six hours and 18 minutes.

title: NAME DISMISSES AIDE IN INQUIRY
description: Mayor Beame yesterday ordered the immediate dismissal of James D. Norton, acting director of the city's Bureau of Labor Services, who had beer under investigation for misuse of official funds.

title: John Wood, Publisher, Dies; A Kennedy Program Aide
description: KENNEBUNK, Me., June 17 (AP)John F. Wood, copublisher of The York County Coastal Star who served in the Kennedy Administration, died Saturday of cancer in a Portland hospital. He was 45 years old.

title: City vs. the Automobile
description: By ruling unanimously that cities may levy severe taxes on private parking facilities in downtown areas of high traffic congestion, the Supreme Court has put the focus on the need and feasibility of saving urban centers from strangulation by automobile.

title: INDICTMENT CITES GEOTEK EXCHIEF
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17A Federal grand jury here announced today that it had returned a 17count indictment against John P. Burke, former president of the Geotek complex of companies, for a series of offenses he allegedly committed in perpetrating a $30million scheme to defraud more than 2,000 investors in a taxshelter oildrilling fund program set up by Geotek Resources Fund, Inc.

title: It's 61 Miles From the Madding
description: BELLPORT, L.I.Dick Ridge, one of the increasing number of people who havr recently acquired houses here, drove along the streets bordered with white picket fences. Little plastic bags, carefully tied, lined the curbs.

title: 200 at Harper Man the Picket Lines
description: At least 200 of the 600 New Yorkbased employes of Harper & Row went on strike yesterday in the first major labor dispute in recent book publishing history.

title: Music: Success on Rugs
description: The New York Philharmonic's second annual week of Rug Concerts, which closed Sunday night, turned out to be not quite a walltowall success. (a Schoenberg commemorative program was lightly attended). But otherwise even Pierre Boulez, who concocted the idea, must have been startled by the audience's size and passionate enthusiasm. No wonder it has been decided to expand the bargainpriced event next season to two weeks.

title: P.S.A.L. Coaches' Case Is Upheld by Arbitration
description: An arbitrator's decision has averted a mass exodus of Public Schools Athletic League coaches.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: News summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 18, 1974

title: Big Game Hunt
description: After half a century of fruitless stalking, the National Rifle Association and other sports who get their kicks out of killing small animals have finally drawn a bead on Congress in what could be a disastrous game hunt.

title: 6 Die in Mississippi Fire
description: LUCEDALE, Miss., June 17 (UPI)Six persons, including a woman and four of her young children, died yesterday when a predawn fire leveled their home near here. The victims were Mrs. Florine Henderson, 33 years old; her four children Jeffrey, 11, Eddie, 10, Anita, 9, and James, 8and a visiting first cousin, James Hubert Meeler, 9, of Petal.

title: Schlesinger Sees Hope of Pact to Limit Warheads
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that there was a possibility that an agreement in principle to limit the deployment of new Soviet missiles with multiple warheads might be reached during President Nixon's visit to Moscow next week.

title: JUDGE IS CAUTIOUS ON WOUNDED KNEE
description: ST. PAUL, June 17When the trial of two Indian leads of the uprising at Wounded Knee opened last January, the Mississippi River was frozen from bank to bank alongside the Federal Courthouse in downtown St. Paul.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)Exxon U.S.A. filed suit today in United States district court here requesting relief from a Federal Energy Office regulation requiring the company to sell 130,000 barrels of crude oil a day to other refiners.

title: Angels Get 3 Runs in First and Defeat Yanks, 30
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 18 Nolan Ryan, who threatens to pitch a nohitter every time he works, took his right arm out of the California Angels' locked jewel case tonight but put it away again after six innings.

title: Lincoln Center Fete Takes to the Street
description: Fifty free performances of street theater, musical comedy, dance, concert and cabaret events will be produced in Lincoln Center OutofDoors, a festival that is to begin Aug. 20 and run for two weeks.

title: Monday's Fights
description: New York (At Madison Square Garden)Joe Frazier, 212 pounds, Philadelphia, knocked out Jerry Quarry, 197, New York, 5 rounds.

title: PAUL MIRSKY DIES; PRINCIPAL WAS 62
description: Paul Mirsky, principal since 1964 of Mark Twain Junior High School in Coney Island, which is under a Federal court integration order, died there Monday apparently of a heart attack, during lunch. He was 62 years old and lived at 3195 Oceanside Road, Oceanside, L.I.

title: ANEW VIEW URGED ON MINORITY JOBS
description: A more selective approach toward attaining jobs for blacks, Puerto Ricans and other minoritygroup members in the building trades was suggested yesterday by Theodorely. Kheel and Basil A. Paterson, who are serving as advisers to Mayor Beame on the problem.

title: Buckley Refuses to Support Javits Bid
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Senator James L. Buckley, RepublicanConservative of New York, said today that he would neither support nor oppose the reelection campaign of his RepublicanLiberal colleague, Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: NIXON COMPLETES HIS MIDEAST TOUR; TERMS IT SUCCESS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 18President Nixon today completed his weeklong tour of five Middle Eastern countries, terming it a success under his limited set of objectives.

title: Court Voids ChildAid Ban In Cases of Welfare Freud
description: NEWARK, June 18  The cancellation of financial assistance to children whose parents have been convicted of welfare fraud was declared unconstitutional today by a Federal District Court judge here.

title: 5 Held in Protest Over Slow Repairs On West Side Road
description: Residents of the Riverside, Park area stalled traffic during the morning and evening rush hours yesterday to protest the failure of the city to make repairs on the, Henry Hudson Parkway.

title: People in Sports
description: Tony Waldrop, the University of North Carolina's ace miler, said yesterday he would not compete in the Amateur Athletic Union track championships in Los Angeles over the weekend. This means he will not be eligible for the United StatesSoviet Union meet in Durham, N. C., July 5 and 6, since the A.A.U. competition will determine the qualifiers.

title: Sports Goods Store Robbed
description: PENNSAUKEN, June 18 (AP) Four masked gunmen held up Edelman's Sporting Goods store in this Camden County today and escaped with two dozen handguns, an undetermined number of highpowered rifles, 4,000 rounds of ammunition and some cash, the police reported.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Aussie Yacht Rated Even to Win Cup

title: Chase Gets Approval To Open Bank in Iran
description: LONDON, June 18 (UPI)The Chase Manhattan Bank has received Iranian permission to open a new jointventure bank based in Teheran, the bank announced today.

title: Egypt Views Nixon's Visit as Turning Point in U.S. Relations With the Arabs
description: CAIRO, June 18That's it, the Americans admit that we are human, an Arab newspaper editor said here this morning as he reflected on the results of President Nixon's tour of the Middle East.

title: Two City Workers Held in $40 Bribe; Victims Got Receipt
description: Two city workers were arrested late Monday on charges that they had demanded and got a $40 bribe before they would allow two employes of the Offtrack Betting Corporation to pick up a load of printed betting sheets.

title: Saudis Seek U.S. Help to Cut Oil Prices
description: Saudi Arabia is seeking a more active effort by the United States to overcome the opposition of Iran and other large oilproducing nations to a reduction in oil prices.

title: SOVIET MOVEMENT IN GENEVA REPORTED
description: MOSCOW, June 18A Western diplomat said here today that there had been some movement by the Russians at the European security conference in Geneva on the controversial issue of freer EastWes contacts.

title: 5% PRICE INCREASE SET ON SOME DC10's
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising base prices of DC10 airplanes to be delivered after Dee. 31, 1976, by 5 per cent. The increases will not affect existing contracts even though delivery may take place in 1977 or thereafter. Base prices for various models range from $17million to $21million, depending on the configuration and the individual requirements of customer airlines.

title: Met Miscue Paves Way for 61 Loss
description: When you're in last place, little things can get to you. Like last night at Shea Stadium when a foul pop fly would have taken George Stone, the Mets' pitcher, out of the third inning without an Atlanta run scoring. But Darrell Evans's high foul behind the plate with two out was misjudged badly by Ron Hodges, the catcher, and the Braires went on to score five runs in a 61 victory over the hapless Mets.

title: Belmont and Other Fun for Children
description: Horses are a central fact of childhood, rocking and bouncing in the living room, racing through early adventure stories. If you think your child would love to see racehorses in actionbut that the gambling at the track doesn't seem to provide the right atmosphereBelmont has a program called Breakfast at Belmont from 7 9:30 every morning (except Sundays) through July 27.

title: Official Explanation of Rules on Sex Bias
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Following are excerpts from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare's official explanation of its proposed regulations prohibiting sex discrimination under Title. IX of the Education Amendments of 1972:

title: TV: NBC Makes Russian Connection
description: Something happened to Lucy Jarvis's latest documentary on the way to completion. Her subject, Armand Hammer, did not loom as large as she anticipated Originally scheduled to be shown on NBCTV a couple of months ago, The Russian Connection was finally broadcast Iast night, and the lingering impression is that the curious hour might have made a solid halfhour.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Talks between management and drivers for the InterCity Bus Lines and Northeast Coach Lines resumed in an effort to end the sixweekold strike by the United Transportation Union. Negotiations broke off May 30 when the 250 striking drivers rejected what the company had called ifs final offer, The bus lines are operated by the Maplewood Equipment Company, a subsidiary of Transport New Jersey, the state's largest bus company.

title: Du Pont Turns to Bank Loans To Help Meet Domestic Needs
description: For the first time in several decades, E. I. do Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., has gone to banks to finance some of its domestic capital needs.

title: Greenspan Offered Top Advisory Post
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Alan Greenspan, one of the nation's leading business economists, has been offered the chairmanship of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. The 48yearold analyst, who is president and, chairman of the consulting firm of TownsendGreenspan Inc. would replace Herbert Stein, who is slated to leave Washington Sept. 1.

title: Corliss C. Moseley, Pilot Was Air Industry Figure
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18 (AP) Maj. Corliss Champion Moseley, a World War I combat pilot and a pioneer aircraft executive, died yesterday in his suburban Beverly Hills home. He was 79 years old.

title: Postal Service Orders Eastern to Keep Flight
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (Reuters)The United States Postal Service has ordered Eastern Airlines to reinstate its night flight from Boston to New York and Atlanta.

title: Man Guilty in Extortion
description: DETROIT, June 18 (UPI)A Federal court jury yesterday found a Sterling Heights man guilty of trying to extort $11million from the Detroit Lions owner, William Clay Ford, last fall. Otto Ludayni, 52 years old, was charged with writing a letter to Mr. Ford threatening to kill a member of his family if he did not pay the $11million.

title: Two Outstanding Scholars Expelled For Stealing Regents Tests Answers
description: TwO 18yearold students both described as outstanding scholars who had frequently spoken out against immorality in society  were expelled yesterday from the Solomon Schechter High School of Brooklyn, a few days before their scheduled graduation, for having recently stolen answer sheets to the statewide Regents examinations.

title: Scientists Say Refrigerators, for 20% More, Could Be Made to Run for 50% Less
description: Specialists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have concluded that the energy appetite of Amerca's 60 million refrigerators could be cut in half with better insulation and more efficient motors, while keeping the frostfree feature found in most recent models.

title: Not Far From Here, Nixon's Still the One
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I.This is a picture book vacationland. The tourist business is booming. Most motels and summer rentals are booked up through the fall. The tennis courts throb with action, hikers dodge cicyclists in the woods, and in the evening the smells of barbecues, mixed with the sounds of merriment and music, drift lazily over the rich green meadows and the amber beaches.

title: What's This? Good News?
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Good news is such a rare commodity in the tangled affairs of the world these days that it is scarcely recognized when it occurs. Yet a survey of recent events shows some genuine progress in the relations between nations.

title: Women in CrimeQuestions Abound, Answers Are Few
description: Crime? Women are just coming out: housewives and single women. They're doing things they didn't do before. Men used to turn their women out on the street. Now a woman can turn herself out and doesn't have to wait. Now she's keeping everything for herself and the kids. Yes, women are becoming more violent.

title: TREASURY WEIGHS SAUDI INVESTING
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Treasury has had conversations with Saudi Arabia about the possibility of that nation investing some of its potentially huge supply of dollars in special Treasury issues that have been available for years to foreign central banks generally, high officials said today.

title: OutofControl Car in Suffolk Injures 18 Pupils, One Fatally
description: An 8yearold boy died last night, several hours after being struck by an automobile that plunged through a chain link fence and hit a group of children who were on an outing in front of a school in Rocky Point, L. I.

title: Ahumada Draw Stirs Dispute; A Charge of Tampering Denied
description: At least one of the scorecards that resulted in a draw in the world lightheavyweight fight in Albuquerque, N. M., on Monday night was tampered with, Gil Cancy, manager of Jorge Ahumada, charged yesterday.

title: London Stocks Fall
description: The London stock market plunged yesterday to a 12year low and the British pound weakened amid new doubts about Britain's economic outlook. Page 61.

title: Cooperstein Wins Twice In Met Golf
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 18 The defending champion, Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks, and two former titleholders, Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham and Mrs. A. S. Hart of Baltusrol, weathered the opening rounds of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

title: Pass Denied New Trial
description: ERIE, Pa., June 18 (UPI)Albert Pass, former United Mine Workers executive board member, was denied a request yesterday for a new trial of his murder conviction in the 1969 slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter. The ruling was made by a panel of three Erie County judges.

title: REVIEW SYSTEM ON DOCTORS BEGUN
description: WASHINGTON June 18The first contract establishing a professional standard review organization, the federally mandated peer review system for doctors, was signed here today.

title: Candidate Backed by Gibson Wins a Newark Council Seat
description: NEWARK, June 18Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, the city's moderate black Mayor, won another election victory tonight, I although he was not on the ballot, and Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist, lost.Mr. Gibson won reelection in the May 14 city elections by capturing 54 per cent of the vote in a field of five mayoral candidates, and he avoided the necessity of appearing on today's runoff ballot.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID BASES IN LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, June 18Israeli planes resumed the bombardment of suspected Arab guerrilla bases in Lebanese territory today.

title: Kuh Offers Lesser Charge In Small Methadone Sales
description: Richard H. Kuh, the Manhattan District Attorney, an nounced yesterday that smallscale illegal sellers of methadone in Manhattan would be given an opportunity to plead to a drastically lower misdemeanor charge rather than face the mandatory life sentence stipulated by the state's stringent antidrug laws.

title: Issues in Harper & Row Dispute
description: PARTICIPANTS: Harper & Row, the book publishing firm, and the Association of Harper & Row Employes, an independent union that bargains on behalf of 320 editorial, clerical and other workers among the company's 600 New Yorkbased employes. The average wage of the association's constituents is $190 a week.

title: Servicemen in 1972 Are Due Back Pay on Court Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) The Pentagon says it owes back pay to tens of thousands of servicemen who served in October, November and December, 1972 but they must file claims for it.

title: STOCKS ON ANIEX AND COUNTER DROP
description: Prices continued to fall yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market as there was no news that could be construed as bullish for the economy.

title: Muslim Aim Called To Maim and Kill At Brooklyn Store
description: The prosecutor in the trial of four Sunni Muslims accused of murder, kidnapping and armed robbery in a shootout of a Brooklyn sportinggoods store 18 months ago depicted the defendants yesterday as aggressive robbers whose aim was to maim and kill.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Kane Talks at Meeting
description: HUNT VALLEY, Md., June 18 The chairman of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company told shareholders at the annual meeting here today that Safeway Stores, Inc., A. & P.'s closest competitor, was better managed than A. & P.

title: Insurance Company Is Ordered To Halt Its Operations in State
description: TRENTON, June 18 (UPI)State Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran today ordered the Gateway Insurance Company of Philadelphia, which is facing nearly 3,000 lawsuits in New. Jersey alone, to stop doing business in the state.

title: GEN. KEIGIITLEY, LED RAID ON SUEZ
description: LONDON June 18Gen. Sir Charles Keightley, Commander in Chief of the AngloFrench invasion of Suez in 1956, died yesterday in Salisbury, Wiltshire. His age was 72.

title: Cheering Fans Hail Hank Aaron in BabeRuth Country
description: Hank. Aaron circled the bases of Babe Ruth's town yesterday and was welcomed not as a conqueror but as a friend.

title: ROTHKO FACTIONS URGED TO SETTLE
description: Opposing parties in the Rothko estate suit were urged to settle their differences out of court yesterday by Surrogate Millard L. Midonick.

title: C. Arnholt Smith Is Given Stay Of Sentencing in Fraud Case
description: SAN DIEGO, June 18C. Arnholt Smith escaped going to tail today when a California appeals court granted a stay of sentence three hours before he was to be committed for contempt of court.

title: 4 Named by Wilson For Board to Police Campaign Spending
description: Governor Wilson yesterday appointed four experienced organization politicians  two Republicans and two Democrats  to be the new State Board of Elections charged with enforcing the new campaign spending and disclosure limitations.

title: NIXON FOES HELD SOURCES OF LEAKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 Ken W. Clawson, the communications director to the President, said today that leaks from the House Judiciary Committee were part of a purposeful effort to bring down the President with smokefilled room operations by a clique of Nixonhating partisans.

title: Roswell Rausch, 82, Dead; ExOfficer of Scott Paper
description: Roswell H. Rausch, a retired vice president of Scott Paper Company, died Monday at his home, 1001 Rahway Road, Plainfield, N.J. He was 82 years old.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast.
Sterile Censorship
description: When Harvard conferred an honorary degree last week on Dom Helder Camara, the Catholic Archbishop of Olinda and Recife, no newspaper or newscast in Brazil could even mention the event. That same day in Peru the military Government ordered the deportation of Enrique Zileri, one of Latin America's outstanding journalists, and closed his magazine, Caretas, for illintentioned attacks on the Peruvian revolution.

title: JURY IS SELECTED IN SLAYING OF GIRL
description: Jurors for the murder trial of Joseph McGowan, a former high school teacher charged with the rapemurder of a 7yearold Brownie, were chosen in Morris County Superior Court in Morristown yesterday.

title: 76ers Are Negotiating With McGinnis, Cunningham and Barnes
description: Coach Gene Shue worked yesterday at getting George McGinnis and Billy Cunningham into Philadelphia 76er uniforms.

title: Dr. Francis Colligan, 65, Dies; A CulturalExchange Pioneer
description: Dr. Francis J. Colligan, who helped organize the State Department's educational and cultural exchange service, died Sunday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 65 years old.

title: MAGGIE BELL's ROCK WARMS PARK CROWD
description: The occupational hazard of the Schaefer Music Festival, held in the open air at the Wollman Rink in Central Park, struck again on Monday evening. After the opening set by Duke. Williams, a Southernbased rock group that was full of city referencesending with a driving Funky Broadway, no lessdown came lots of rain, transforming the rink into several large pools of water. It was unfortunate that it came during the interval of setting up another group, because, apart from no shelter, there were no distractions from the downpour.

title: Watergate Plea Bargains Are Defended by Jaworski
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Leon Jaworski, responding to the first serious public criticism in his seven months as special Watergate prosecutor, defended plea bargaining today as a fair, legal and necessry way to prosecute Watergate criminals.

title: Son's Death Studied After 4 in Family Are Slain
description: PARK RIDGE, III., June 18 (AP)  Four members of a family were slain sometime last weekend and the key to the killings may lie in a fifth death, that of the elder son, the authorities said today.

title: Red Smith
description: In the fifth round Jerry Quarry's right glove pawed at his expression in a tentative, searching way as if to caress a smashed nose or wipe away the blood oozing into his left eye or perhaps just to see whether his face was still there. His mouth was open, and the place where there should be teeth but aren't was blood red. Joe Frazier, who had drawn the blood, turned his back and walked away. He made a gesture of entreaty toward Joe Louis, but in his corner his managertrainer, Eddie Futch, shouted, Get the job done! Joe Louis kept his distance; when he was fighting, he never sought relief from the referee. Stop it! men at ringside were crying. Joe! Stop it! Gil Clancy, who handles Quarry, was on the ring apron ready to intercede before Louis stepped between the fighters and waved Frazier back. By that time, Quarry's wife, Charlie, was out of the hall and in tears. Recognizing the inevitable long before the referee did, she and Jerry's mother and grandmother had left their ringside seats before the fifth round started.

title: Arab Emirates Contribute $400Million to Aid Project
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 18 (AP)The United Arab Emirates has announced $400million emergency aid program for countries suffering most from food, fuel and fertilizer prices.

title: Pound Weakens on Doubt of Economic Outlook
description: LONDON, June 18The atmosphere of gloom in the British financial community deepened today as the stock market skidded to a 12year low and the pound weakened amid new doubts about the economic outlook.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 19, 1974

title: Screen: Politics and Sex
description: Sexual hypocrisies and political dilemmas rarely flow smoothly onto the screen. But Lina Wertmuller excels in conveying both, in "The Seduction of Mimi," which was made before her "Love and Anarchy." Her films are deeply political, and her characters dwell in realms where politics cannot be escaped  whether in Mussolini's Italy or modern Sicily. "Mimi," a furious farce that won her the best-director award at Cannes in 1972, concerns a young laborer who lurches between the local Mafia and the Communists  when all he really wants is a personal life. The movie opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse.Mimi refuses to vote for the Mafia's candidate in his town's elections, hence he loses his job. He believes in the rights of working people, yet he makes a half-baked Communist because he's eager to earn well, to provide for his child. Meanwhile, he shuns the wife who displeases him in bed and falls violently in love elsewhere. He thinks of himself as "a civilized man."
