But when his neglected wife cuckolds him, all his energies surge into plotting vengeance against her lover  an obsession that has horrendous consequences for Mimi and puts him again at the mercy of the Mafia.In Mimi, Miss Wertmuller has created a sympathetic character who's also capable of barbarity, a likable person who can (and does) behave like a monster. It's her talent to be honest about cruelty; she also specializes in vulnerable people. Of course, the double standards of Sicily are stressed: a man is admired for having a mistress, yet he goes berserk when his wife hits the hay with another man; at the same time, none of his male friends would marry a divorced woman. Throughout, the bitterness is shot with comedy, while the macho code of revenge appears as a disease, and lunacies are committed in the name of "honor."Although Miss Wertmuller emphasizes that women are steadily humiliated in Sicilian society  while showing that men are also victims of their country's traditions  her own feminism seems inconsistent at moments. Some of her scenes and characters embody strictly male fantasies  such as the titillating fight between two prostitutes in "Love and Anarchy," or the transformation of Mimi's girlfriend from a gutsy, independent person into an ideally patient, faithful, adoring handmaiden. And there's a passage of searing brutality when Mimi seduces the fat, aging wife of his own wife's lover. His disgust at the grotesque body  which is filmed from angles that make it all the uglier  makes you wonder if the director occasionally relishes the degradation of other women.But whatever Miss Wertmuller's commitments, "Mimi" is one of the best films of this season. And it's far more substantial than "Love and Anarchy"  a movie that did absorb and touch me, even though I hardly believed a moment of it. (There, the insistence on love at first sight and the oozing innocence of the lovers seemed too artificial to swallow. Yet the absurd romanticism was enjoyable as well.) sistence on love at first sightIn both of the Wertmuller movies, the film maker's harsh judgments of people emerge in a style that's visually delectable. As Mimi, Giancarlo Giannini runs a range of moods from misery to delight or defiance and surpasses his performance in the other picture; a number of the same actresses (especially Elena Fiore and Mariangela Melato) are splendid. "Love and Anarchy" appears as the more commercial work: the splashy sex scenes sometimes seem like an apology for the political discussion. But in "Mimi," politics and sex are so well balanced that all the raw emotions and the devastating jokes ring true.

title: Woman at Y Falls to Death
description: A 25yearold woman guest at the Sloane House, a Young Men's Christian Association residence at 356 West 34eth Street, fell or jumped to her death from a 14thfloor window shortly before 2 P.M. yesterday. The police tentatively identified her as Lillian Cox, address unknown.

title: Morgenthau Nominated For D.A. by Liberals
description: The Liberal party has nominated former United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau as its candidate for Manhattan District Attorney, and, for the first time, voted to support Representative Bella S. Abzug for reelection.

title: JERSEYANS DRAFT A NEW TAX PLAN
description: TRENTON, June 18Some legislative opponents of Governor Byrne's proposed tax program put forth an alternative today: a statewide property tax that would be levied at a higher rate against business and industrial property.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Herman Krausner, who for 50 years spent most of his spare time visiting strangers who were patients in New York City hospitals until he went blind two years ago, was named Volunteer of the Year yesterday by the New York City Department of Social Services.

title: HANOI AND VIETCONG ARE ASSAILED BY U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 18 (AP)The United States accused North Vietnam and the Vietcong today of refusing to honor the Vietnam ceasefire and trying to conquer South Vietnam by military force.

title: Buchanan in Memo Reportedly Fought Attack on Ellsberg
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The White House conducted a campaign to discredit Daniel Ellsberg despite the opposition of Patrick J. Buchanan, according to a 1971 memorandum by Mr. Buchanan, The Washington Post said in its Wednesday editions.

title: MRS. CHESTER ROBERTS
description: Mrs. Ann Meltzer Roberts, who with her late husband, Chester H. Roberts, took over the operation of the Z. & L. Rosenfield Agency, a stenographic service catering to playrights and actors for decades until the firm was dissolved in the nineteenfifties, died Monday in New York Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived at 165 West 66th Street.

title: $5Million in Cotton Burns
description: GALVESTON, Tex., June 18 (LiPI)A twosquareblock pier loaded with $5million in cotton caught fire last nightdestroying the wharf and all the cotton plus thousands of dollars in loading equipment and forcing the mass evacuation of ships out to Galveston Bay. No one was injured.

title: Pickets Gain Support in Harper Strike
description: An official of the Office and Professional Employes International Union, saying the present Harper & Row strike showed an awakening on the part of the people in publishing, declared yesterday that the union had been gaining support at the Macmillan Publishing ComIliany, and added that we're going to organize other publishing houses, too.

title: Councilman Wrong
description: The decision of City Councilman Samuel D. Wright not to run for Congress in Brooklyn's new Fourteenth District but rather to challenge the recently revised district lines pushes reasonable demands for racial justice beyond all reasonable bounds.

title: U.S. Asks Conditions on Oil Pool
description: BRUSSELS, June 18The United States has pro posed that plans to pool emergency oil supplies among the 12 nations of the Washington Energy Coordination Group should be linked to national efforts to conserve energy and main fain large oil stocks in case of crises.

title: Cambodian Regime Slips Economically and in War But Weakness of Insurgents Enables It to Survive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 18The war in Cambodia has become a war of no victories and no defeats, just of a slow, unrelenting deterioration in virtually every facet of the Government side's existencemilitary, economic, political, psychological.

title: QUARTERLY PROFIT OF DEAN WITTER UP
description: Desrrite continued tow trading volume and a decline in revenues, the Dean Witter Organization, Inc., reported yes terday an increase in unaudited thirdquarter earnings to $508,000, or 12 cents a share, from $132,000, or 2 cents a share, a year ago.

title: Amalgamated Bank Plans to Quit the Fed
description: The Amalgamated Bank of New York is planning to leave the Federal Reserve System to take advantage of substantial savings available outside the system, Maxwell Brandwen, president, disclosed yesterday.

title: Rockets Hit Phnom Penh, Kill 4 Near U.S. Embassy
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 18 (UPI)  Communist units fired three rockets into Phnom Penh tonight, one exploding within 200 yards of the American Embassy and two others landing near the presidential palace. The attack killed at least four persons and wounded 18, military officials said.

title: The Year 2000 in India: Experts Paint Grim Picture
description: NEW DELHIIndia in the year 2000: about half the population will be homeless, food will be scarce, the landscape will be bare of trees, the fuel shortage will be acute, the cities will be proliferating.

title: Texas Oil Output at 100%
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 8The Texas Railroad Commission, at its monthly oil proration hearing today, continued 100 per cent production quotas in July for the 28th successive month. Company statements of need for oil came to 3,893,362 barrels a day, nearly 500,000 barrels a day above actual production as shown by April reports, 3,393,037 barrels a day.

title: Cooperstein Wins Twice In Met Golf
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 18 The defending champion, Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks, and two former titleholders, Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham and Mrs. A. S. Hart of Baltusrol, weathered the opennig rounds of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

title: GibsonBacked Candidate Gets Newark Council Seat
description: NEWARK, June 18Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, the city's moderate black Mayor, won another election victory tonight, although he was not on the ballot, and Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist, lost.

title: Security Tight for Queen At Ascot in Bomb's Wake
description: LONDON, June 18  The police authorities tightened security today at the Houses of Parliament and around Queen Elizabeth at the royal race meeting at Ascot after the bomb attack at Parliament yesterday.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Chicago Bridge & Iron Company has been awarded a $50million contract to fabricate deliver and construct permanent tankage for oil storage at the Valdez marine terminal and pump stations for the Trans Alaska Pipeline. The contract calls for some 40,000 tons of steel for fourteen 510,000barrel crude oil storagetanks, three 430,000 ballast treatment tanks and smaller related tanks at the terminal. There will also be oil storage tanks for pump stations ranging from 55,000 to 210,000barrel capacity. The contract was awarded by the Aleyska Pipeline Service Company.

title: MARSHAL RIUKOV IS REPORTED DEAD
description: MOSCOW, June 18Marsha Georgi Konstantinovich Zhukov, who led the Red Army intc Berlin, died today of a heart attack in the Kremlin Hospital unofficial Soviet sources reported.

title: MAN IS ACQUITTED IN HOUSING TRIAL
description: A former appraiser for the Federal Housing Administration was found not guilty of bribery and conspiracy charges last night in the first verdict to come out of an eightmonth Federal Court trial in Brooklyn involving nine defendants and charges that they had participated in a massive housing fraud.

title: Pennsylvania Sells $167Millionof Bonds
EGAN JURY IS TOLD OF $5,700 DEPOSIT
description: The little wood x?? in which a former police lieutenant said heused to keep his cash contained only $1, $5, $10 and $20 bills that he eventually banked, he told a Federal District Court jury here yesterday.

title: More Selectivity Favored on BuildingTrade Bias
description: A more selective approach toward attaining jobs for blacks, Puerto Ricans and other minoritygroup members in the building trades was suggested yesterday by Theodore W. Kheel and Basil A. Paterson, who are serving as advisers to Mayor Beame on the problem.

title: Court Stay of PrimeTime Rule To Force Shift in TV Schedules
description: The television networks apparently will be forced to revise their fall schedules as a result of a ruling here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which in effect granted oneyear stay of the Federal Communications Commission's revised primetime access rule.

title: City Honors Blind Man, 68, Who Calls the Homebound
description: Herman Krausner spent the first 47 years of his working life running a Lower East Side linen supply business with his brother and finding time, every night, to visit strangers who were patients at Veterans Hospital, or Maimonides, or Bellevue.

title: T.W.A. Profit Up In May
description: The international business of Trans World Airlines is still badly depressed by weak traffic and exorbitant fuel prices, but its domestic business is running better than management had forecast, according to Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., chairman.

title: DIET IS STRESSED AS LONGEVITY AID
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Dr. Jean Mayer, the Harvard University nutritionist who headed the White House Conference on Food in 1969, called tonight for a massive effort in nutrition education that he, said could play a major role medicine.

title: Housing Starts and Permits Fell in May
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 Both housing starts and permits for new housing construction fell sharply in May, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Democrats Begin Sharpening Campaign Issues and Introduce New Brain Trust
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Democratic National Committee held a policy conference today to begin sharpening the party's campaign issues this year, and hopefully, in the words of the meeting's moderator, Arthur Krim, the movie executive, to pave the way for a Democratic Administration in 1976.

title: MISS CALIBER DIED FROM AN OVERDOSE
description: Pamela Galiber, 24yearold daughter of State Senator Joseph L. Galiber of the Bronx, died of an overdose of Darvon, a widely prescribed painreliever, Dr. Dominick J. DiMaio, the city's Acting Medical Examiner, reported yesterday.

title: SAWHILL UNHAPPY WITH MOBIL PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 Federal Energy Administrator John C. Sawhill expressed displeasure today with the tentative plan of the Mobil Oil Corporation to buy control of the Marcor Corporation, which controls Montgomery Ward, the big retail and mailorder chain.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page ??

title: NIXON COMPLETES HIS MIDEAST TOUR; TERMS IT SUCCESS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 18 President Nixon today completed his weeklong tour of five Middle Eastern countries, terming it a success under his limited set of objectives.

title: Man Found Dead in Bronx
description: The body of a man about 40 years old was found in the rear of a Bronx restaurant that was the scene of an explosion and fire early yesterday. Fire marshals were investigating the cause of the blaze at Ciro's Restaurant at 2356 Grand Concourse, near 184th Street, in the Fordham section. The dead man was identified as Anton Dosokic, address unknown.

title: COUPLE ARE SEIZED IN DEATH OF INFANT
description: NUTLEY, June 18 (UPI)A New Jersey couple was arrested here today for beating to death their 13monthold son, who had been returned to them from a foster home by court order less than a month ago, authorities said.

title: Pirates Take No. 5 as Reliever Starts
description: All the teams in the National League Eastern Division have been wondering when Pittsburgh would make its move for the top. The Pirates may have made it last night with the help of Dave Giusti, reliever turned starter.

title: Zaretzki Facing a Strong Challenge in Primary From Leichter
description: What Manhattan politicians feel will be a close, hard primary challenge to Joseph Zarefzki, the 74yearold minority leader of the State Senate, was formally opened yesterday with the charge from Assemblyman Franz S. Leichter, the West Side reform Democratic leader, that he had been offered patronage jobs byl the Senator as an enticement not to run.

title: U.S.I. Head Tells of Trades
description: I. John Billera, chairman of U.S. Industries, Inc., disclosed yesterday that on three occasions last year he had sold personal shares of U.S.I. stock at the same time the company was buying large blocks of its own stock. Such transactions are forbidden by Federal securities law.

title: Business Briefs
description: Andersen Plans QualityReview Board

title: H.E.W. PROPOSES RULES TO OUTLAW SCHOOLS' SEX BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare published today its proposed regulations for ending sex discrimination in education. They would ban such common practices as offering home economics courses solely to girls and shop courses solely to boys.

title: Unfit Potatoes Spilled From a Disabled Truck
description: Several thousand potatoes described by the police as unfit for human consumption, spilled from a disabled tractortrailer truck yesterday morning onto a service road of the Cross Bronx Expressway near the Bronx River Parkway exit and were gathered and carried away by passing motorists

title: Bridge: Dropouts From the League Almost Equal Newcomers
description: Each calendar year, the American Contract Bridge League attracts well over 20,000 new members. Each year, unfortunately, an almost equally large number fail to renew their membership.

title: Saudis Seek U.S. Help to Cut Oil Prices
description: Saudi, Arabia is seeking a More active effort by the United States to Overcome the opposition of Iran and other large onproducing nations to a reduction in oil prices.

title: Haitian Banned for Using Drug
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 18Ernst JeanJoseph of Haiti, who played so well at fullback in a 3.1 loss to Italy last Saturday, was suspended today from further participation in the World Cup because it was discovered he had taken an illegal drug.

title: Dance: The Moiseyev
description: The most celebrated folkdance ensemble in the world, the Moiseyev Dance Company, is back in town after too long an absence. It opened a fiveweek season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, with a program stuffed with old favorites, and yet offering one or two novelties.

title: SURROGATE CASES MISSING FEE DATA
description: A 1967 law designed to open to public scrutiny the names and fees of lawyers and other guardians appointed by the courts has been undermined by ape astbunding number of incompletet missing or unrecorded filings, the state's new Office of Court Administration has acknowledged.

title: Senators Accept Veto Plan On Big Loans by Eximbank
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Senate Banking Committee accepted proposals today that would give Congress a veto over all ExportImport Bank transactions of more than $50million, but it refused to set limits on credits for the Soviet Union.

title: NATO Conference Agrees On New Set of Guidelines
description: OTTAWA, June 18The foreign ministers of the 15member North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today on the text of a declaration of principles designed to guide the alliance through its second 25 years.

title: 30 Years of Hiding in Jungle Were Foolish, Japanese Says
description: TOKYO, June 18Three months ago, Lieut. Hiroo Onoda of the Imperial Japanese Army returned to Japan after hiding in a Philippine jungle for 30 years. He told the Japanese he had stayed there because he thought of nothing but accomplishing my duty.

title: Miss Debra Mandelbaum Is Bride
description: Miss Debra Mandelbaum, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Bernard Mandelbaum of New York, was married last evening to Gary Lyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Lyman of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens. Rabbi Fabian Schonfeld performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel in NorthWoodmere, L.I., with Rabbis David Cohen and Haspel Lookstein participating.

title: Going Out Guide
description: IN THE SHELL Once again, like a reliable and comfortable friend, the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts with the Goldman Band are with us, beginning tonight their 57th season at the Guggenheim Bandshell in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park. Guest artist will be Berenice Bramson, soprano, to sing the Jewel Song from Faust, Je veux vivre dans ce reve from Gounod's Romeo et Juliette and Vissi d'arte from Puccini's Tosca.

title: A Jury of Six Decides Against Jacobson On Denial of Stall Space by N.Y.R.A.
description: The damage suit for $8million by Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, once the president of the New York division of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association, was denied by a New York State Supreme Court jury in Mineola, L. I., Monday night. A jury of five men and one woman ruled against the horseman by upholding the right of the New York Racing Association, which controls racing at the state's three major thoroughbred tracksAqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratogato allocate stall space at the plants under its supervision.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Reporter's Notebook: Like Nixon's Old Days
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 18 For President Nixon and his staff the sevenday journey to the Middle East that ended today was like the good old days of 1972, before the Watergate disclosures.

title: A ManySplattered Dream
description: President Nixon's MiddleEastern tour, which has already underscored dramatic shifts in United States policy, brings this country for the first time to actual realization that the flickering idea of Arab unity is inescapable importance to the United States.

title: Foe of Rizzo Keeps Grip on Party Leadership in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 18When a fist fight broke out last night at a gathering of this city's leading Democrats, nobody was really surprised.

title: State Agency Backs Kawaida Project Tax Exemption
description: TRENTON, June 18The State Housing Finance Agency contended before the Appellate Division of State Superior Court today that the controversial, blacksponsored Kawaida Towers housing project in Newark had met all the legal requirements for a 50year tax exemption and the agency's special lowinterest mortgage loan.

title: Italians Seek Austerity Accord In Bid to Save Coalition Cabinet
description: ROME, June 18Leaders of the three parties in Italy's Cabinet and an allied group began a search today for an accord on austerity measures that would permit the coalition to survive.

title: Immunity Is Granted for Hunt and Young
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)Two former White House aides, E. Howard Hunt Jr. and David R. Young, were given immunity today so that they could testify at next week's trial of Ellsberg breakin defendants.

title: Yadavendra Singh, Sikh Leader, ExMaharaja of Patiala, Is Dead
description: NEW DELHI, June 18Lieut. Gen, Yadavendra Singh, India's Ambasador to the Netherlands and former Maharaja of Patiala, died in the Hague yesterday. He was 61 years old.

title: The Way They Were: A Return to the 50's
description: The invitations, sealed with a lipstick's kiss and S.W.A.K., read, In defiance of our thirtieth birthdays, Susan Frances Grad and Laurie Ellen Burrows invite you to regress to the fifties for a Prom/SockHop downstairs at Nathan's.

title: Norwalk Man Dies at 113
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 18Walker Spencer, a retired farmer, died yesterday at the age of 113, two weeks after celebrating his birthday A native of Belhaven, N. C., he had been active until he was 98. He had 24 brothers and sisters. His mother lived to be 118, his aunt 113 and a sister 105. He leaves his third wife, Ella; two sons and three daughters.

title: Democrats Win White Plains Election
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 18Democrats seized political control of White Plains tonight for the first time in the city's history, The upset was recorded in a special election called by Governor Wilson to end the state of legislative paralysis here.

title: TROY IS PRESSING FOR BUDGET CUTS
description: City Councilman Matthew J Troy Jr. said yesterday that the Finance Committee had agreed on $45million to $50 million in budget cuts and that Mayor Beame should cut $17.5million more to make nuisance taxes and a large increase in the realestate tax unnecessary this year.

title: Judge Puts Coach On Year Probation
description: BARRIE, Ontario, June 18 (AP)Don Cherry, new coach of hockey's Boston Bruins, was given a conditional discharge with one year's probation in Provincial Court today.

title: 76ers Are Negotiating With McGinnis, Cunningham and Barnes
description: Coach Gene Shue worked yesterday at getting George McGinnis and Billy Cunningham into Philadelphia 76er uniforms.

title: Kenton Corporation Narrows Deficit for the First Fiscal Quarter
The Voting Results Of Contested Races In Village Elections
description: Following are the results of yesterday's suburban village elections.

title: East Meadow Votes Budget
description: Residents of the East Meadow, L. I., school district yesterday approved a proposed school budget of $28,462,917, with tax rate adjusted to $13.12. The vote was 2,347 to 2,086.

title: DowJones Closes Down 2.97 Points at 830.26
description: The stock market showed no signs of snapping out of its doldrums yesterday as prices finished lower in continued slow trading.

title: Bell Report Offers Strategy on Rulings
description: WASHINGTON, June 18A confidential research report for the Bell System has recommended a national public relations strategy to counter what the report calls the knee jerk reaction of most of the public that economic competition means lower prices and better service.

title: ROBERT L. BURDEN
description: Robert Livingston Burden, head of the science department at the Thomas Jefferson School in St. Louis and a son of William A.M. Burden, financier and former Ambassador to Belgium, was killed in an automobile accident yesterday in Mansfield, Ohio, while driving alone to St. Louis. He was 40 years old.

title: House Acts to Aid Poor On Food Stamp Losses
description: An amendment that would help some 84,000 aged, blind and disabled poor persons in New York State to make up for food stamps lost when they were transferred from welfare rolls to the Federal Supplemental Security Income program won passage in the House of Representatives yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Whitehead Institute at Duke Will Be Major Stockholder
description: DURHAM, N.C., June 18Whitehead Medical Institute, a biomedical research installation that will be established here, and its board of directors will become the ultimate major stockholder of the Technicon Corporation of Tarrytown, N.Y., it was reported here today.

title: The Rosenbergs' Trial: Some Considerations About Justice
description: On June 19, 1953, Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who were convicted of conspiracy to pass atomic secrets to the Soviet Union, were executed. A former United States District Court judge, Simon H. Rifkind, in a recent article that appeared in TV Guide and was reprinted in The New York Law Journal, asked, What is the cause of the recurrent flurry of interest in the Rosenberg trial? and answered, in substance, that there was no reasonable doubt about their guilt.

title: 30 Years of Hiding in Jungle Were Foolish, Japanese Says
description: TOKYO, June 18  Three months ago, Lieut. Hiroo Onoda of the Imperial Japanese Army returned to Japan after hiding in a Philippine Jungle for 30 years. He told the Japanese he had stayed there because he thought of nothing but accomplishing my duty.

title: Bankers Trust Realigns Top Leadership
description: The Bankers Trust Company, the seventh biggest bank in the country, announced yesterday changes in its top management.

title: The U.S. Energy Crisis and Germany's in 1924an Analogy
description: PHILADELPHIA  Few Americans know that there is a precedent in recent history for our energy crisis. Furthermore, the reactions then were remarkably similar to proposals that have been made in response to ours. The ultimate outcome of the earlier crisis and the response to it were unfortunate; it is hoped that a similar situation can be avoided now.

title: Victorian Home for Aged to Be Demolished
description: The New York Victorian building known for nearly a century as the Association Residence for Respectable Aged Indigent Females is to be demolished in the fall.

title: Smith Wins; Ashe, Borg Are Toppled
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 18 (AP)Stan Smith, who is Seeded fourth for the Wimbledon tournament that begins next week, reached the third round of the $100,000 John Player tournament with two victories today.

title: Shipping/Mail
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Small L.I. Community Divided Over Sale of a Farm to School
description: CARLE PLACE, L.I., June 18 Until this year, the old Rottkamp Farm raised corn and potatoes and cabbages. But now the land is lying fallow and the farm is producing only a debate over what to do with its 1.7 acres, which make up one of the last farms in Nassau County.

title: Unprofitable Units to Shut
description: The Allied Stores Corporation plans to close six or seven unprofitable, stores in its 13store AlmartJ. B. Hunter discount chain, Thomas M. Macioce, president and chief executive officer, said after the annual meeting yesterday at the BarbizonPlaza Hotel.

title: Scaramouche First in Bermuda Trial
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 18 On a great race course todaysouthwest wind and lovely Narragansett Bay at its bestScaramouche, from a different pond, Lake Michigan, beat the best.

title: PLAN ON INFLATION GIVEN BY SAMUELS
description: Howard J. Samuels, Democratic State Committee designee for Governor, declared yesterday that inflation and the rising cost of living were having a disastrous effect on working people and that this was the No. 1 issue in the campaign.

title: George Kelly, Playwright, Dies, Won Pulitzer for Craig's Wife
description: George E. Kelly, the Pulitzer Prizewinning playwright, whose acid comedies and scathing satires delighted Broadway audiences for half a century, died yesterday afternoon at the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 87 years old.

title: SILVER FUTURES FALL DAILY LIMIT
description: Silver futures dropped the 20centanounce daily limit on the Commodity Exchange, responding to lower price levels for both silver and gold in London.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As you said editorially June 3, the Supreme Court's class action decision in the Eisen case deals a body blow to the consumer protection movement. Unfortunately an uppercut had long since been dealt the class action concept by a class of lawyers who took advantage of the opportunity not unlike the opportunity offered in traffic cases which you so rightly condemned in your earlier editorial on nofault insurance.

title: National Cancer. Institute Reorganizing 10YearOld Viral Research Program
description: BETHESDA, Md., June 18The National Cancer Institute is undertaking a major reorganization of its special virus cancer program in response to criticism from scientists.

title: Unaccountable Power
description: Kenneth Rush, President Nixon's counselor for economic policy, declined an invitation last week to go up to Capitol Hill to testify before the Joint Economic Committee on the President's midyear economic report. In a letter to Senator William Proxmire, the committee chairman, Mr. Rush claimed executive privilege and said that his obligation to give the President candid and uninhibited advice prohibited him from testifying before Congressional committees.

title: Portugal's Withdrawal From Africa Africa Will Be Long and Tortuous
description: PARIS, June 18Mario Soares, the Foreign Minister of Portugal, is regarded by the liberation movements of Mozambique and Angola as the best friend they have in the Portuguese Government Before leaving Lusaka, Zambia, two weeks ago after the opening round of talks with the Mozambique Liberation Front he said he considered peace and liquidation of colonialism the main goals of both Portugal and the independence movements.

title: Scotland Outplays Brazil In 00 Cup Soccer Draw
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 18Scotland and Brazil fought a fierce but scoreless soccer battle here tonight marked by the presence of the heavily guarded Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain in the stands and by a lot of ungentlemanly conduct on the field.

title: SURROGATE CASES MISSiNG FEE DATA
description: A 1967 law designed to open to public scrutiny the names and fees of lawyers and other guardians appointed by the courts has been undermined by an astounding number of incomplete, missing or unrecorded filings, the state's new Office of Court Administration has acknowledged.

title: Nixon Cited Clearance by I.R.S. After Audit Notice, Paper Says
description: BALTIMORE, June 18 (AP)When President Nixon released his tax returns last December and said the Internal Revenue Service had found them in order, he already had been informed that the I.R.S. was reopening its earlier cursory audit. The Baltimore Sun reported in its Wednesday edi tions.

title: House Unit Questions Date Nixon Heard of CoverUp
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The House Judiciary Committee, exploring President Nixon's possible motive in dismissing the first Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, focused today on when the President first learned of the Water(matter. gate coverup.

title: Labor's Turn at Bat
description: Just a month and a half ago, Administration economist with the overwhelming support of business and labor leaderswere celebrating the end of wage and price controls Controls, said the consensus view had been a dismal failure. Admittedly, labor had demonstrated re, markable restraint. Pay settlements had stayed about in line with the official guideline of 5.5 per cent for wages plus 0.7 per cent for fringe benefits.

title: London Stocks Fall
description: The London stock market plunged yesterday to a 12year low and the British pound weakened amid new doubts about Britain's economic outlook. Page 61.

title: Meteorology Prize Given
description: GENEVA, June 18  The World Meteorological Organization announced today the award of its annual prize for outstanding work in meteorology and international collaboration to Prof. Joseph Smagorinsky, director of the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory at Princeton, N.J.

title: High Tides Around New York
Watergate Plea Bargains Are Defended by Jaworski
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Leon Jaworski, responding to the first serious public criticism in his seven months as special. Watergate prosecutof, defended plea bargaining today as a fair, legal and necessry way to prosecute Watergate criminals.

title: Robbery Suspect ?? In Shootout With the Police
description: A robbery suspect was critically wounded by a policeman yesterday in a shootout that followed the holdup of a jewelry store in Greenwich Village by the wounded man.

title: Nixon Campaign Financing is Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI)  A Senate Watergate committee staff report has concluded that abuses in President Nixon's 1972. campaign spanned the entire spectrum of corrupt campaign financing.

title: Texans Turn to Trull
description: HOUSTON, June 18 (AP)Don Trull, formerly of the Houston Oilers, has signed to return to pro football with the Houston Texans of the World Football League

title: Sister Slain, Parents Shot, Youth Is Accused of Plot
description: A 19yearold youth allegedly killed his sister and wounded his parents early yesterday in what the police in the Bridge. port suburb of Monroe, Conn. called an attempt to inherit his family's house and modest printing business and collect on their insurance policies.

title: 3 Union Aides Plead Guilty; Pledge to Bar Fire Strikes
description: Richard J. Vizzini, president of the 10,900man firemen's union and two union officials pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of reckless endangermeet that stemmed from their calling the first strike in the Fire Department's history.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID BASES IN LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, June 18Israeli planes resumed the bombardment of suspected Arab guerrilla bases in Lebanese territory, today.

title: Advertising: Lorillard Moving
description: The quiet on the accountmovement front was broken yesterday by two large blasts in New York and Chicago.

title: A Sergeant Weeps And Pleads Guilty To Payoff Charges
description: A sergeant assigned to the Police Department's special anticorruption unit wept and pleaded guilty at a departmental trial yesterday to charges he had been in an unlawful sergeants' club and had accepted payoffs for disclosing confidential police information.

title: Global Communicators
description: Weapons of unimaginable destructiveness, global economics and instantaneous communications have thrust nations into a proximity for which they are politically and psychologically unprepared. That observation, made last month by Secretary of State Kissinger in accepting the golden jubilee award of International House, is a measure of the foresightedness shown a full halfcentury ago by the founders of an institution set up to build just the sense of community the world still so conspicuously lacks.

title: LOCKHEED DISCLOSES TEXTRON AID TERMS
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation made public yesterday the full details of the proposed deal under which Textron, Inc., would help restore the ailing aerospace company to financial health with a purchase of $85million of Lockheed stock.

title: Mideast Nuclear Deals
description: The debate aroused by President Nixon's nuclear accord with President Anwar elSadat undoubtedly assures Congressional scrutiny before Egypt receives the promised reactors, fissionable materials and technology.

title: BUDGET OVERHAUL IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Amid declarations that it was passing potentially, landmark, historic and redletter legislation, the House of Representatives approved today a bill revolutionizing the way Congress deals with the Federal budget.

title: Dolphin Forsakes Sea For Dirty Little Creek
description: KEYPORT, June 18A sixfoot dolphin whose normal habitat is the vast expanse of oceans has established a home here in the narrow brackish waters of Matawan Creek.

title: A Jury of Six Decides Against Jacobson On Denial of Stall Space by N.Y.R.A.
description: The damage suit for $8million by Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, once the president of the New York division of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association, was denied by a New York State Supreme Court jury in Mineola, L. I., Monday night. A jury of five men and one woman ruled against the horseman by upholding the right of the New York Racing Association, which controls racing at the state's three major thoroughbred tracksAqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratogato allocate stall space at the plants under its supervision.

title: H. E. W. PROPOSES RULES TO OUTLAW SCHOOLs' SEX BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare published today its proposed regulations for ending sex discrimination in education. They would ban such common practices as offering home economics courses solely to girls and shop courses solely to boys.

title: An Explanation: Cox Ouster Spurred House Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The catalyst that brought about the House impeachment inquiry was President Nixon's dismissal last October of the first Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox.

title: Notes on People
description: Arriving in East Berlin yesterday to take up residence as West Germany's first permanent representative there, West German State Secretary Gnter Gaus said his accreditation marked a new beginning in relations between the two Germanys. The exchange of plenipotentiaries had been arranged as long ago as December, 1972, in the goodneighbor treaty between East and West Germany, but continuing frictions delayed matters.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Songs Associated With Billie Holiday Heard in Highlight
description: The program that concluded this season's monthly Highlights of Jazz series at the N.Y.U. Loeb Student Center on Monday evening was called Billie Holiday Remembered. It was played by a group of musicians who had worked with her in various points in her career.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MONTVALE, June 18  St. Joseph Regional's track coach, Bob Murphy, didn't boast when he said: There isn't a major championship on the east coast, indoors or out, that my teams haven't won at least once.

title: Pamela Britton, Blondie Star, Actress in Musicals, Is Dead
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., June 18 (AP)Pamela Britton, who starred in the Blondie television series and was a regular on My Favorite Martian, died yesterday of cancer. She was 50 years old.

title: Met Stages First FullScale Opera Outdoors
description: WASHINGTON, June 18For the first time in its long history, the Metropolitan Opera last night gave a fullfledged performancesets, costumes and aliout of doors.

title: HOUSE UNIT PASSES GOLD AMENDMENT
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The House Banking Committee took an action today that is likely to lead to the legal right of Americans to own gold by the end of this year.

title: 10 LEAVING SOVIET FOR RABBI STUDY
description: MOSCOW, June 18The So viet Government has given approval for 10 men to take rabbinical training at a seminary in Hungary, the only function ing Jewish seminary in Eastern Europe.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Books of The Times
description: A halfcentury ago, in the days of our innocent madness when Americans were easily beguiled by foreign celebrities, Marie Sklodowska Curie was peddled here like soapflakes as the greatest woman in the world for her discovery of the element radium. The huckstering was performed twiceonce in 1921 and again in 1929by Marie Mattingly Meloney, an editor of The Delineator and then of The Herald Tribune, who was also an assiduous collector of the famous. The Mme. Curie proffered on both occasions was so cloaked in hyperbole and swathed in bathos that little of the real person was visible to observers. Nor was much more disclosed by her daughter's biography 37 years ago.

title: Canada's Output Index Off
description: OTTAWA, June 18 (Reuters) Canada's index of industrial production declined 1.1 per cent to 222.4 in April from 224.8 in March, Statistics Canada reported today. The mines component advanced 0.7 per cent in April but manufacturing and utilities declined.

title: U.S. WILL STEP UP NAT PURCHASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The White House announced today a steppedup program of meal purchases for school lunches an effort, to aid the depresset hog and cattle industry.

title: NEW HEAD NAMED BY PRESBYTERIANS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 18An Albany pastor involved in efforts to reunite his denomination with the Southern Presbyterians was elected Moderator today by delegates of the United Presbyterian Church, which has nearly three million members.

title: Great Neck Plaza Seeks To Enact Rent Control
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 18The Village of Great Neck Plaza declared tonight that it was in a state of housing emergency, a first step toward enacting the new state rentcontrol law locally. The village is the first suburban municipality to do so.

title: Kuh Offers Small Sellers of Methadone Chance to Plead to a Lesser Charge
description: Richard J. Kuh, the Manhattan District Attorney, announced yesterday that smallscale illegal sellers of methadone in Manhattan would be given an opportunity to plead to a drastically lower misdemeanor charge rather than face the, mandatory life sentence stipulated by the state's stringent antidrug laws.

title: About New York A Fool and His Money
description: I. am writing this letter anonymously after consultation with my attorneys, the man said, because I am a foolish businessman who travels regularly to New York and has a wife and family back home whom must protect. He had sent copies of the letter to Abe Beame, the Police Commissioner, the Attorney General and any number of other people, and it was all in the hope, he said, that one of them has a respect for law and order and a hope for morality in New York.

title: Senate Sends Nixon a Bill Raising SchoolLunch Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The Senate completed. Congressional action today on a bill raising the Federal contribution to schoollunch and nutrition programs by $210million in the next fiscal year.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Classified pages distrituted In metropolitan New York and adjacent territory.

title: MISSOURI PORTLAND OPPOSING CARGILL
description: The Missouri Portland Cement Company said yesterday in St. Louis that it had filed a petition for rehearing by the full United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here of its suit to prevent a takeover by Cargill, Inc., a grain and feed company.

title: Foes of Byrne's Proposal Put Forth an Alternative
description: TRENTON, June 18Some legislative opponents of Governor Byrne's proposed tax program put forth an alternative today: a statewide property tax that would be levied at a higher rate against business and industrial property.

title: People and Business
description: Americans should have little trouble obtaining gasoline this summer if they continue reasonable, rather than excess, use of their cars, according to Harry Bridges, president of the Shell Oil Company. He added, however, that a severe winter could result in serious problems in heatingoil supplies.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Man Slain, 2 Women Wounded

title: N.C.A.A. Tennis
description: AT LOS ANGELES

title: A Visible Anchor to Past Would Be Lost in Razing
description: The blocks just west of Central Park above 96th Street are the sort most New Yorkers call to mind when they hear the phrase urban renewal: banal, highrise towers set mainly on superblock sites. What life and color the neighborhood has comes largely from the old walkup apartment houses and institutional buildings left on undeveloped sites.

title: F.T.C. Hits House Unit Action On Business Reporting Shifts
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission attacked the House Appropriations Comittee today for substantially modifying a controversial commission program to force major businesses to report on the profits and sales of the different products they manufacture.

title: Series of Concerts To Benefit Victims Of African Famine
description: John A. Scali, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, announced yesterday that the. United Nations Association, a private group here, was planning a series of concerts for the benefit of faminestricken victims of six countries in subSaharan Africa.

title: KLEINDIENST SAYS ROLE WAS MINOR
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Fornier Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, reviewing the early investigation of the Watergate affair, said today that he had put no pressure on subordinates, could not remember receiving any instructions from the White House and had generally withdrawn from any part in the criminal investigation.

title: House Unit Questions Date Nixon Heard of CoverUp
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The House Judiciary Committee, exploring President Nixon's possible motive in dismissing the first Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, focused today on when the President first learned of the Watergate coverup.

title: Cheering Fans Hail Henry Aaron in Babe Ruth's Town
description: Henry Aaron circled the bases of Babe Ruth's town yesterday and was welcomed not as a conqueror but as a friend.

title: 3 Union Aides Plead Guilty; Pledge to Bar Fire Strikes
description: Richard J. Vizzini, president of the 10,900man firemen's union and two union officials pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of reckless endangerment that stemmed from their calling the first, strike in the Fire Department's history.

title: Laborites Lose Commons Vote As Tories Take Tougher Stand
description: LONDON, June 19The Labor party, which has been governing since last winter's election despite its lack of a majority in the House of Commons, suffered its first important parliamentary defeat tonight.

title: RATES WILL FLOAT ON CITICORP NOTES
description: Citicorp, the holding company that owns the First National City Bank, plans to offer to investors 15year notes that will carry a floating rate of returnone one percentage point above the average rate on threemonth United States Treasury bills calculated semiannually.

title: More European Steel
description: Europeans are selling more steel than ever in the United States at prices 20 to 30 per cent above domestic American levels, according to industry officials in Paris and Brussels. Details on Page 59.

title: Judiciary's Leaks...
description: The House Judiciary Committee, after making appropriately measured start on its impeachment inquiry, now seems to have sprung not just a leak, but a gusher. Over the past week, the public has been treated to the contents of a series of confidential memoranda analyzing portions of the evidence that has been presented by the staff in closed sessions to the committee.

title: Welshman Looks Back On 37 Years of Success
description: By WALTER R. FLETCHERMy mother wanted me to be a doctor, I wanted to be a jockey, so I wound up with dogs, said. T. Hubert Arthur of Gower, Wales. In nearly four decades, he's been one of the most successful breeders and exhibitors in his native land. He had 25 champions in 13 breeds, his dogs won more than 10,000 first places and were best in show at 357 open events.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Suit Assails Property Tax for Schools

title: I.R.A. Warns of a Long Bomb Campaign
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 19Four bombs wrecked shops in Londonderry today as the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army warned that its current attacks would continue until the British declared their intention to withdraw from Ulster.

title: NEW U.N. AID FUND IS OPPOSED BY U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19The United States today pledged emergency help to countries most seriously affected by economic crises but refused to support the establishment of a United Nations special fund for aid and development.

title: Advertising: Bicentennial Help
description: It looks as if the Co Network is very close to having a sponsor for its twoyear series celebrating the bicentennial of America's declaration of independence from. Britain.

title: ARTHUR CLAPHAM, JERSEY EXECUTIVE
description: Arthur R. Clapham, a medicalsupply industry executive who helped make BandAid a household word throughout, the world, died yesterday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. His age was 82 and he lived on Fair Haven Road in Rumson, N.J.

title: COOP CITY PROTEST REBUFFED BY BOARD
description: As hundreds of Coop City residents picketed and chanted We won't pay, the board of directors for the huge Bronx housing project last night rebuffed an attempt by some members to withhold part of the project's mortgage payments starting July 1.

title: Men and Women In One Prison: Realistic Idea Is Given a Try
description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass.At a large, enclosed complex of buildings near here, men and women residents stroll handinhand through the grassy courtyard, dine together, play cards together, watch movies together, and swim in the outdoor pool together.

title: Explanation: 2 Conversations That Weren't Taped And a Defective Recording Concern House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 The House Judiciary Committee is ending its initial examination of the Watergate case this week. Its focus is on whether President Nixon joined or acquiesced in a second coverup of the facts in the case after the first coverup went awry.

title: Jewel Companies Dividend
description: Directors of the Jewel Companies, the nation's fourth largest food chain, voted yesterday a threefortwo tock split and an increased dividend on the spli stock of 30 cents a share for payment Sept. 27 to holders of record Sept. 13 The regular Auarterly dividend of 41 cents voted last March is, payable June 28,

title: Boy, 2, Falls to Death
description: A 2yearold boy climbed to the sill of an open rear window of a fifthfloor apartment at 122 East 111th Street, in upper Manhattan, and fell to his death yesterday, the police repored. Detectives said the incddent occurred around 6:20 P.M. when the boy's mother, Mrs. Margaretta Ruiz, momentarily stepped from her apartment, leaving her infant son, Nathan, unattended.

title: GERALD HOLLAND
description: Gerald Holland, a retired editor of Sports Illustrated, died Tuesday in St. Louis. He was 67 years old.

title: SPERRY RAND CORP. ADDS NEW COMPUTER
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation introduced yesterday a new small computer that is the third member of its new series 90 family of machines.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Canadian National Railways announced yesterday it had placed orders for $95million worth of freight equipment, the largest purchase program in the railway's history. The orders went to to ?? National Steel Car Corporation, a subsidiary or Dominion Foundries & Steel, Ltd.; Hawker Siddeley Canada, Ltd.; Marine Industries, Ltd., and the General Motors of Canada Ltd.'s diesel division.

title: BANGOR SUIT LOST IN SUPREME COURT
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, today that a corporation buying a railroad cannot recover damages from its former owners for waste and mismanagement that occurred before goodfaith sale of its stock.

title: Many Foreign Physicians In U.S. Found Unlicensed
description: A growing medical underground of thousands of foreigntrained doctors is practicing medicine without licenses and often without supervision in many American hospitals, according to a report published today in the New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Saigon Reported to Sink North Vietnamese Boat
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 20 (AP)South Vietnamese patrol craft and jet bombers sank a trawler flying the North Vietnamese flag today off the east coast of South Vietnam just below the demilitarized zone, military sources reported.

title: Mrs. Bower, Mrs. Hart Gain Met Golf Semifinals
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 19 Two former winners, Mrs. Albert Bower of the Pelham Country Club and Mrs. A. Shelburne Hart of Baltusrol, led the way today into the semifinals of the 71st annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament.

title: Evening Papers Oppose 4 P.M. Big Board Close
description: Many of the nation's evening newspapers, particularly those in the East, are urging the New York Stock Exchange not to extend its trading hours by a half hour to 4 P.M.

title: Goldwater Accuses The Washington Post
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)  Senator Barry Goldwater; Repubiican of Arizona, said today that The Washington Post could be prosecuted under at ??east five Federal criminal sta??utes for publishing top secret Government documents.

title: Sculpture Designs at Met Illuminate City's Heritage
description: Public sculpture has had a rough time of it in New York City ever since Joseph Wilton's twoton equestrian statue of King George III of England was overturned by a mob on July 9, 1766, and chopped up to be turned into bullets. (A fragment of this statue was found near Wilton, Conn. in 1972 by an enthusiast with a mine detector; it can be seen, with much of its gilding still intact, in the Museum of the City of New York.) Ball Hughes's 15foot statue of Alexander Hamilton, in the Merchants' Exchange, fared no better when it was destroyed in the great fire of 1835. Frederick William MacMonnies's Boy and Duck, for nearly 50 years a wellloved ornament in Prospect Park, was stolen in 1941 and has never turned up. Over on Brooklyn Plaza, Henry Merwin Shrady's wonderfully melancholic George Washington at Valley Forge has more recently been defaced, like so many other public monuments, with cretinous graffiti. In 1970, Daniel Chester French's Alma Mater at Columbia University, was damaged by a bomb. Altogether, it's a desperate state of affaies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Protect Us. From Detente

title: Revenues and Net Income Of A.T.&T. Rise to Highs
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiaries achieved new highs in secondquarter revenues and net Income, according to the quarterly report released yesterday. Revenues and earnings for the 12 months ended May 31 were also at a new high.

title: Senate lnquiry Chips Away at Rebozo's Apolitical Image
description: WASHINGTON, June 19From the time that President Nixon took office in early 1969, Charles G. (Bebe) Rebozo has been popularly viewed as his closest friend, an apolitical man next door with whom the President, during weekend visits to the Nixon home on Key Biscayne, can retreat fully from the pressures of international and domestic concerns.

title: Fed Rejects Banks' Bids
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) The Federal Reserve's Board of Governors denied today the applications of the nation's two largest banks to move into the insurance underwriting business overseas.

title: Missile Warhead Threat To Silos Is Called Limited
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 The Air Force has concluded that the effectiveness of multiple nuclear warheads in attacking missile silos may be limited by an explosion phenomenon not preiriously known or fully understood.

title: Nixon Gets Bill Postponing Increase in Postage Rates
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (Reuters)  The House completed Congressional action today and sent to the President legislation that would save magazine and book publishers $764million by postponing a scheduled increase in postage rates.

title: COURT WILL REVIEW ORDER ON I.R.S. TAPE
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)  The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia agreed to review a Federal District Court order that a section of a White House tape dealing with political use of the Internal Revenue Service must be turned over to a Watergate grand jury.

title: TRINIDAD TO BECOME PART TEXACO OWNER
description: PORT  OF  SPAIN, Trinidad, June 19 (AP)  The TrinidadTobago Government plans to acquire part ownership of Texaco's oil refinery here, one of the largest in the world, Government sources said today.

title: Lead Is Shared In Jersey Golf
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., June 19The defending champion, Bob Housen of Lakewood, shared the firstround lead with Paul Samanchik of North Jersey and Jeff Liebler of Essex County West today after carding a oneoverpar 73 in the 73d New Jersey amateur champion at the Navesink Country Club..

title: Former Teacher Admits To Killing of Brownie, 7
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., June 19  A former high school teacher unexpectedly pleaded guilty today to fatally assaulting a 7yearold Brownie as she delivered Girl Scout cookies to him 15 months ago.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BEGINS AND ENDS The theater in New York, on Broadway, Off and Off Off, is a series of fits and starts, previews and postmortems, lights and darkness, openings and, alas, closings. Tonight there are beginnings and endings.

title: U.S. CHALLENGING 2 PENSION PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Government filed a lawsuit today against two railroads that will test the legality of company pension plans that impose mandatory retirement at ages younger than 65.

title: Terraced Institution Steps Offer Stage for Tales of Manhattan
description: The great terraced front steps of Manhattan essays in selfflattery written in stone, have, apart from their intended functions, been taking on a life of their own.

title: BAN IS EXTENDED ON WASTE IN GULF
description: TALLAHASSE, Fla., June 19A Federal District, judge extended today until at least July 26 his restraining order prohibiting E. I. duPont de Nemours & Co. from discharging industrial wastes into the Gulf of Mexico off the Florida coast.

title: Portugal's Military Takes Over Full Control of Radio Network
description: LISBON, June 19The Portuguese armed forces tightened their grip over news outlets today by assuming full control over the staterun radio network.

title: Robinson, at 37 Sparking Oriole Drive With Hitting
description: After Brooks Robinsons' performance in the Orioles 65 victory over Minnesota in Baltimore's Memorial Stadium last night some people believe that the aging star is turning back the clock to 1964.

title: AMERICAN POWER SIGNS COAL PACT
description: The American Electric Power Company and the McCulloch Oil Corporation announced yesterday the signing of a longterm coal contract with a total sales value in excess of $1billion.

title: West Side Groups Hold a Rally To Protest Interstate Road Plan
description: Community groups staged an outdoor rally last night at Broadway and 72d Street to protest the possible construction of a sixlane, truckcarrying Interstate System highway to replace the dilapidated and twisting West Side Highway.

title: NIXON, HOME, SEES MIDEAST CHANGED
description: WASHINGTON, June 19President Nixon returned to the White House today after journey to five Middle Eastern countries, declaring that a profound and lasting change has taken place in that part of the world.

title: L.I. Student Lacks a Quarter Unit
description: The State Commissioner of Education has agreed to look into a refusal by a Suffolk County school board to allow a 17yearold girl to participate in graduation exercises because the girl, who wears a body brace, lacks a quarter of a credit for a gym class.

title: After Many A Summer
description: LONDON, June 19Roses, strawberries, cricket: The symbols of an English summer are unchanged. London is still London, with the jumble of roofs and chimneypots against the sky, the flower stall on the corner, the sawdust pub sausage.

He charged a breach of contract and asked the court to order an accounting of the receipts for the fight, in which he was knocked out in the second round. Named among the defendants were Video Techniques and INCMV Telemedia of Panama.

description: WASHINGTON, June 19 Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., implying that Government prosecutors ignored obvious leads that would have broken the Watergate case open two years ago, drew shouted denials today from Henry E. Petersen, the Justice Department official who first supervised the investigation.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

description: BILLIE JEAN. By Billie Jean King with Kim Chapin. 207 pages. Illustrated Harper & Row. $6.95.

description: WASHINGTON, June 19A key White House aide said today that the vote of the 17member Republican minority on the 38member House Judiciary Committee, would be critical in determining whether or not the full House of Representatives, votes to impeach President Nixon.

description: PARIS, June 19The French Government acted today to give more money to the poor, the aged and the handicapped and set in motion a process to improve conditions for workers.

description: ST. LOUIS, June 19 (UPI)The Monsanto Textiles Company said today it planned to increase its synthetic fiber capacity in the United States by more than 70 million pounds annually. The company intends to expand facilities at its Decatur, Ala., plant by 1976, raising United States production of acrilan acrylic and SEF modacrylic fibers to 330 million pounds per year.

title: Futures in Wheat Advance in Price By the Daily Limit
description: Wheat futures for nearby delivery jumped the 20centabushel daily limit yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The more distant deliveries were not far behind with gains of almost 19 cents.

description: Caspar W, Weinberger, Sec??tary of Health, Education and Welfare, said here yesterday that he hoped to present to President Nixon early this fall alternative plans to the present welfare system.

title: The West Side's Future
description: There is more involved in hearings this week and next on plans for the West Side Highway than how to get traffic moving again. Although the five socalled alternate schemes developed by the state and city are the immediate subject of debate, it would be a serious error to look at the matter as anything less than the virtual rebuilding of the city's West Sidewith all of the opportunities and responsibilities that this entails.

description: BATTING

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Policing Atlantic Salmon
description: Maintaining the effectiveness of an international agreement to protect the Atlantic salmon is a frustrating endeavor, says Richard Buck, chairman of Restoration of Atlantic Salmon in America, Inc.

title: Walter Slagle Is Dead at 97; Oldest Ex Major Leaguer
description: SAN GABRIEL, Calif., June 19 (AP)Walter J. Slagle, who at the age of 97 years had been the oldest living former major league baseball player, died here Monday.

title: London Stock Prices Slump
description: LONDON, June 19 (AP) Share prices slumped again today on the London stock mar ket, with The Financial Times industrial index hitting another 12year low. Prices were marked up up at the opening on hopes of a technical rally but quickly slumped under a wave of nervous selling.

title: Mahovlich Signed By Toronto Toros
description: TORONTO, June 19 (AP)Frank, Mahovlich of the Montreal Canadiens said today he had signed a longterm contract with the World Hockey Association's Toronto Toros.

description: U.S. Accuses 4 ToiletSeat Makers

title: Consumer Notes
description: Many people are not aware that costs for checking services differ from bank to bank. Most people maintain accounts near home or office for convenience, with little or no thought to the cost. Now the New York Consumer Assembly has surveyed 13 Manhattan banks and 15 in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and found that differences are greatest between the large banks and the smaller ones. The survey found that the Amalgamated Bank of New York, which offers a checking account with no minimum balance requirements, no service charges and no charge per check, offered the best buy. Stock checks are free; personalized checks for 200.

title: Equal Rights Plan Rejected By Louisiana House Panel
description: BATON ROUGE, La., June 19 (UPI)Led by a woman legislator, a Louisiana House committee rejected today the proposed equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution that would end all discrimination based on sex.

title: Newcombe And Nastase Are Upset
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 19 (AP)John Newcombe and Ilie Nastase, the topseeded players, were upset in the third round of the 8100,000 John Player grass tennis tournament today.

title: Payments Surplus Sets Record
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The United States basic balance of payments showed a record surplus of $2.1billion in the first quarter of this year, though some temporary factors were probably at work, the Commerce Department reported today. Meanwhile, revisions turned last year's originally reported payments surplus into a deficit.

title: C. W. Post Golf Today
description: Approximately 50 foursomes will tee off today in the first C. W. Post invitation golf tournament at the Chatter Oaks Country Club, Muttontown, L.I. Each foursome will comprise a golf professional from the metropolitan area, a collegiate golfer, the foursome sponsor and a celebrity from the entertainment or sports world. Funds raised are earmarked for educational programs of the Undergraduate School of Business Administration.

title: Screen:Buckminster Fuller Is Studied in Depth
description: With the exception of a single student's question that somehow slipped by, Buckminster Fuller's voice is the only one heard during the entire 90 minutes of Robert Snyder's new film on the visionary architect and engineer, "The World of Buckminster Fuller."That is a lot of Buckminster Fuller for anybody, since Mr. Fuller tends to repeat himself frequently and to offer up lessons out of freshman physics as if he'd just invented them himself.He remains, of course, a remarkably compelling figure, if a bit wordy, and Mr. Snyder has captured him wellindeed, careful editing has made this film a lot more coherent than most of Mr. Fuller's lectures. We see him in a variety of settings around the world, rambling and philosophizing about energy (he was, as he does not hesitate to remind us, way ahead of the bandwagon on that question), television, architecture, democracy, mathematics, and social problems.There is some gibberish, like Mr. Fuller's suggestion that housing problems could be solved by finding something else for the middle-class to do and then moving the poor into skyscraper office buildings, and much that makes great sense, like his explanation of his work as "not trying to imitate nature, just trying to find the principles she's using."The most fascinating sections of the film are those that relate to Mr. Fuller's actual built work  his famous geodesic domes, his "Dymaxion" house and car of the nineteen-twenties, indications that he was far more serious about the implications of technology than the early modern architects of the period who talked about a machine-age architecture, but built essentially traditional buildings.The film will be shown at noon and midnight tomorrow and Saturday, and at 10 o'clock Sunday mornings for an indefinite period at the First Avenue Screening Room at 61st Street.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINE HAD MAY PROFIT
description: Although its traffic last month lagged May of a year ago by about 0.4 per cent, American Airlines reported vesterday a $2,2million, or 8 cents a share, consolidated profit for the month. It was the first time since 1969 that American had operated at profit.

title: State Fines a Principal For Cutting Girl's Hair
description: TRENTON, June 19 (UPI) A school principal in Elizabeth was fined two weeks' pay today for clipping a girl's hair.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in holdings by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not make such a list available yesterday.

title: RADIO STATION AIDE JAILED IN CONTEMPT
description: LOS ANGELES (AP)A Federal judge ordered the manager of a radio station to jail today until he answers a grand jury's questions about a tape recording from Patricia Hearst and two members of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: Schoolyard Crash Spurs TrafficLight Demand
description: ROCKY POINT, LI., June 19 Residents and school officials of this village in which a car plowed into a group of elementary school children yesterday, killing one and injuring 17 others, vowed today to fight for traffic lights near local schools.

title: Protesters in Little Italy Agree to Permit Excavation
description: A Board of Education spokesman said last night that a group of Little Italy residents who on Monday blocked trucks clearing a site for a $7million school in the area had agreed to permit excavation at the site pending resolution of the dispute.

title: Irwin Heads Golf Field of 96 in Akron Today
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 19After the United States Open, especially one as competitive as last week's, any golf tournament seems like an anticlimax, but Rubber City, U.S.A. is going to try to do its best to overcome that condition with its 13th American Golf Classic.three runnings of the Professional Golfers' Association championship.

title: Dave Anderson Henry Aaron's Parade Never Stops
description: Henry Aaron looked up as Norm Miller, one of his Atlanta Braves' teammates, approached holding a baseball browned by age.

description: BASEBALL

title: DATA ON CHILDREN DECLARED ABUSED
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Education researchers told Senate investigators today that the scholastic, psychological and medical data collected by local schools on 45 milion American children sometimes find their way into data banks used by the police, banks, employers and credit bureaus.

title: N.B.A. Fails To Choose New Chief
description: Henry Steinman, a 41yearold lawyer from Los Angeles, came within one vote of being named the new commissioner of the National Basketball Association at the league owners' meeting yesterday at the Hotel Americana.

title: CHIEFS SAE STUDIED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Conunission has begun to look info the circumstances surrounding the sale last year of rnore than 4,000 shares of stock by I. John Billera, chairman of U. S. Industries, Inc., well informed sources said yesterday.

We are acutely aware that the critique of a professional kitchen is a highly subjective exercise. description: NEWARK, June 19 (AP)A former bank president and four businessmen were indicted by an Essex County grand jury Wednesday on charges they bilked $390,000 from a bank and several depositors through a complicated checkkiting scheme.

title: Segal Heads the Cast of 'Terminal Man':The Cast
description: The oops-sorry school of medicine is featured in "The Terminal Man," where the psychosurgery intended to make brain-damaged George Segal less violent only serves to make him more so. With a headful of wires and a tiny computer planted in his neck, he runs amok on the conviction that machines are taking over the world. But since the surgeon who operated on his brain is the kind of person whom you wouldn't allow to trim your nails, let alone cut your hair, Mr. Segal's mistrust of science seems quite rational. Based on Michael Crichton's novel, the movie was written, directed, and produced by Mike Hodges; it opened yesterday at Loews State and Tower East.The picture moves as slowly as a glacieran image that's reinforced by the repetitive shots of long, white hospital corridors, white bathrooms and home dcorin fact, it's a white-on-white movie. There's no suspense; the only frightening moments occur when you fear it may last forever, especially during the seemingly endless operation and an interminable manhunt. It's also a bit corrupting for the viewer, since the acting style is so muted that you start longing for a dash of violencethough when it comes, the camera slights the victim, and Mr. Segal mainly succeeds in ruining a perfectly good waterbed.George Segal's resilience, humor, and versatility have redeemed quite a few bad scripts. But this role gives him little chance to act, beyond making like a zombie and rolling his eyeballs back (there's that touch of white again). Still, it's rather refreshing when his bandaged head is covered by a blond wig that pays distinct homage to Harpo Marx.While this movie seems unsalvageable, it might have had some punch if we'd been told more about the Segal character's past, before his operation. Meanwhile, Joan Hackett's talents are wasted as a doctor who's merely required to look patient or perturbedalthough she is permitted an occasional worried smile. And a clumsy attempt to cash in on the shower scene in "Psycho" stresses the poverty of invention that withers this whole nonthriller.

title: Busby's NoHitter Baffles Brewers
description: MILWAUKEE, June 19 (UPI)Steve Busby of the Kansas City Royals aided by a onehanded running catch by his right fielder, Al Cowens, became the first pitcher in history to hurl a nohitter in each of his first two seasons tonight when he stopped the Milwaukee Brewers in a 20 victory. The nohitter was also the first of the 1974 season.

description: In its first visit to the United States since 1965, the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, led by Herbert von Karajan, will play three concerts at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 9, 10 and 11 in Columbia Artists Management's Series of Stars events.

Last night at Michael's Pub, over cocktails and old tales, at a masquerade whose universal disguise was middle age, the painters, singers, physicians, writers, producers and mothers of three tried to match lined brows to youthful yearbook snapshots.

title: HYMAN JAZZ PIANISM COVERS WIDE RANGE

At the Overseas Jazz Club in the Biltmore Hotel on Tuesday afternoon, he covered an impressive array of sources, Including Jelly Roll Morton, Scott Joplin, James P. Johnson, Thelonious Monk, Duke Ellington, Fats Waller, Claude Thornhill, the blues and one of his own settings for a song by Shakespeare, all on piano, as well as a demonstration of the improvisatory potential of a MiniMoog Synthesizer.

title: Cup Soccer Scores
description: World Cup soccer scores will be reported daily in the sports section. Please do not telephone. The New York Times for results. Lufthansa Airlines will provide all scores at 2123578400 in New York, 5164893930 on Long Island, 8006453860 in New Jersey. In other areas, call the tollfree Lufthansa reservations number listed in the telephone directory.

title: Governor Would Sign Ban On Medicaid for Abortion
description: TRENTON, June 19Governor Byrne said today that he would sign legislation pending in the Assembly that would bar Medicaid payments to poor women for abortions.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, JUNE 20, 1974
description: Members of the North Atlantic alliance agreed to wider and more intimate consultations on common problems, including situations outside the alliance area. The agreement was part of azdeclaration designed to guide the North Atlantic Treaty Orangization, through its next 25 years. Under the agreement, European members said they would maintain defense forces sufficient to deter or repel a Soviet attack and the United States pledged not to accept a situation that would expose its allies to external political or military pressure. [1:8.]

title: MEM TARGET: ORGANIZED CRIME
description: Robert R. Meehan, the Democratic State Committee designee for Attorney General, promised yesterday that if he were elected he would be the loader in the war against organized crime and in the wax to restore our civil and consumer rights.

title: N.C.A.A. Tennis
description: ??hird RoundScott Carnahan, California, ?? vine, defeated Jim Delaney, Stanford, 70, 75; Brian Teacher, U.C.L.A., defeated Mark Meyers, Duke, 64, 64; Mark Andrews, Southern Cal., defeated Charlie Ellis, Southern Georgia, 62, 64; George Hardie, Southern Methodist, defeated Doug King, California, 64, 64; John Whitlinger, Stanford, defeated Francisco Gonzalez, Ohio State, 76, 61; Sashi Menon, Southern Cal., defeated Dave Pressly, Florida, 75, 61; Tom Kreiss, U.C.L.A., defeated John Holladay, Southern Cal., 62, 61.

title: Air Force Integrity
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J. After a masscheating ring was discovered at 10:30 P.M., Jan. 18, 1972, and before 6 the next, morning, the Air Force Academy Cadet Honor Committee awakened 15 to 125 cadet suspects who, between lengthy periods when each was held under guard and ihcommunicado, were interrogated by live to twelve cadet investigators for as long as six hours.

title: 5 Youths Arrested in Lowell
description: LOWELL, Mass., June 19 (AP)Five youths were arrested last night after a confrontation between 500 mostly black and Spanishspeaking people at the Bishop Markham Housing Project, the police said. Trouble had been brewing for about three weeks in the project, the police said.

title: Hoodlum Soldier in Japanese Series
description: The idea that the army and war are hellish and not singularly an American concept is starkly illustrated in Hoodlum Soldier, the final, new offering in the Japanese film series that opened yesterday at the Cinema Studio. Yasuzo Masumura, the director, has projected a cynicatty realistic view of the Japanese World War II conscript even though the friendship between two mismatched soldiers is evoked in constant, violent and bloody action.

title: G.I. Freed in Nixon Threat
description: SEATTLE, June 19 (UPI)A Federal court jury last night found Pvt. Gary Joseph Will, 21 years old, of Fort Lewis, not guilty of a charge of threatening the life of President Nixon. The defendant is now expected to face a military charge of threatening the life of his company commander.

title: First Wisconsin Mortgage Sued by S.E.C. on Not Filing
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Securities and Exchange Commission sued First Wisconsin Mortgage Trust today for failure to file an annual report for the period ended Dec. 31 and its quarterly report due March 31.

title: TRIAL OF MUSLIMS GOES TO THE JURY
description: The jury in the trial of four Sunni Muslims accused of murder, armed robbery and kidnapping in the January, 1973, shootout at a Brooklyn sportinggoods store began its deliberations late yesterday afternoon after a long explanation of the charges by Justice Hyman Barshay, in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: SalesTax Cut Seen Tied To Income Levy Support
