description: EAST ORANGE, June 19 Assemblyman Steven P. Perskie, the Atlantic City Democrat who heads the Assembly's Taxation Committee, said today that there was growing legislative support for a plan to link Governor Byrnes proposed incometax program with a reduction in the state sales tax.

title: Tuesday Nights at Met Ended for the Summer
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday that beginning July 1 and continuing through Sept. 30, it would no longer be open Tuesday evenings.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Connecticut's State Beard of Education agreed to seek nearly $100million from the General Assembly next year to spread to the poorer towns to help them support their schools.

title: Senate Confirms Envoys
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) The Senate confirmed by voice vote today the nomination of James D. Hodgson as new United States Ambassador to Japan. Also confirmed was the nomination of David E. Mark as Ambassador to Burundi.

title: TRANSIT FUNDS BILL APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) The House passed 392 to 4, a $3.182billion transportation appropriation bill, tonight providing funds for the Transportation Department and related agencies for the fiscal year that begins next month.

title: ECONOMIC ACCORD REACHED IN ITALY
description: ROME, June 19Premier Mariano Rumor's wobbly Government won a new lease on life tonight when leaders of the four parties that had originally supported it reached an accord on economic austerity.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TENAFLY, June 19  Stu Weinberg has coached basketball and track, but nothing gives him greater athletic pleasure than teaching adults how to swim.

title: Missile Warhead Threat To Silos Is Called Limited
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Air Force has concluded that the effectiveness of multiple nuclear warheads in attacking missile silos may be limited by an explosion phenomenon not previously known or fully understood.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Balks at G.O.P. Accord
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn has put a roadblock in the way of a $775,000 settlement of a lawsuit of the Democratic National Committee against the Committee for the Reelection of the President.

title: School Board and Budget Votes Held in 3 Suburban Counties
description: Following are the results yesterday's suburban school district elections.

title: Networks Appeal Court's Rule on PrimeTime Delay
description: Lawyers representing a committee of film companies and independent producers of network television series said yesterday they would petition the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here to reconsider the opinion handed down Tuesday ordering the Federal Communications Cornmission to delay its amended primetime access rule until the fall of 1975.

title: TENDER OFFER SET BY A.B. ELECTROLUX
description: A. B. Electrolux in Stockholm said yesterday that it would make a tender offer for all common shares of the National Union Electric Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., at $28 a share. National Union manufactures vacuum cleaners and air conditioners in plants in Bloomington, Ill., Napolean, Ohio, and Woodridge, N. J. The company reported sales of $141.2million in 1973.

title: Pax Henrica
description: No one since the eighteenth century has seriously argued the possibility of miracles in the natural world. And nobody in the twentieth, with any sophistication, or historical sensitivity, ought to believe, either, in political or diplomatic miracleworkers. All the more reason why the press should have been modern enough in outlook to refrain from making Henry A. Kissinger some kind of a wonderworker who can divide the Red Sea or make the sun stand still.

title: KSINGER QUOTED ON ORDERING TAPS
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Secretary of State Kissinger said to have told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in secret testimony last fall that either he or H.R. Haldeman, President Nixon's former chief of staff, must have initiated wiretaps on 17 Government officials and reporters.

title: Hostages Held in Simulated Incident to Train Police
Holding Company Seeking Restructure of Bank Loan
description: The Continental Investment Corporation said yesterday. It has seeking to reach an agreement with a group of banks, led by the First National Bank of Boston to restructure a $52million, sixyear term loan, obtained in March.

title: New A10 Jet Is Rated Over A7 For Support of Combat Troops
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) Pentagon evaluators have decided that the new A10 jet is more effective than the older A7 for close air support of ground combat troops.

title: Doctor Says Haitian Took Drug for Lift
description: MUNICH, West Germany, June 19 (AP)Haiti's team physician said today that Ernst JeanJoseph, the player who was suspended from the World Cup yesterday for a drugging offense, had taken stimulants deliberately with the aim of getting up fir Haiti's match with Italy last Saturday.

title: BIKERS INMATE HELD IN DOUBLE SLAYING
description: A man convicted of robbery and being detained at Rikers Island prison for parole violation was charged yesterday) with the slaying last April 12 of two Japanese women in a West Side hotel.

title: Saigon Pcedicab Driver Dies of Burns From Immolation
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 19A pedicab driver who set himself on fire April 29 has died of extensive burns.

title: Physician Sentenced To 2 Years' Service In Clinics on Rikers
description: A physician who pleaded guilty to a manslaughter charge was sentenced yesterday to two years' probation during which he must work during the day in the medical clinics of jails on Rikers Island, treating ailing prisoners for $1 a year.

title: ExTeacher Admits To Fatal Assault On Brownie Scout, 7
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., June 19  A former high school teacher unexpectedly pleaded guilty today to fatally assaulting a 7yearold Brownie as she delivered Girl Scout cookies to him 15 months ago.

title: Yankee Records
Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Funds for Ballet Theater Held Up, Pending Audit
description: The New York State Council on the Arts has indefinitely delayed recommendation of a grant for 197475 to the American Ballet Theater, one of the country's three most outstanding dance companies, and called for an independent audit of the Ballet Theater Foundation, the company's parent unit.

title: Miss Furtseva Loses Her Seat In New Supreme Soviet Alter All
description: MOSCOW, June 19Yekaterina A. Furtseva, politically the most prominent woman in the Sovet Union, has lost her seat in the Supreme Soviet after all, indicating that she is likely to be eased out soon as Minister of Culture.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, June 19, 1974

title: Italy Manages 11 Tie On Argentine Lapse
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, June 19Italy and Argentina quietly played to a 11 soccer tie at Neckar Stadium tonight before a capacity crowd of 73,000 that was lured to this World Cup game chiefly because it had been billed as the toughest and fiercest battle in the tournament. Sports writers and soccer authorities had agreed before the game that perhaps it shottld be covered by war correspondents.

title: William H. Byrne, Engineer, Led Bilbyrne Corporation
description: William H. Byrne, a, consulting engineer, died Tuesday in the Harkness Pavillion. He was 74 years old and lived here and in Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: COAST BANK PAYMENT APPROVED BY F.I.D.C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has approved payment of some $45million worth of disputed letters of credit issued by the defunct United States National Bank of San Diego, it was announced yesterday.

title: 7 Women and 5 Men Fill Jury for Retrial of Brasco
description: A jury of seven women and five men was selected yesterday in the retrial of Representative Frank J. Brasco, Democrat of Brooklyn.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: Mayor Acts to Speed Emergency Repairs On West Side Road
description: Mayor Beame announced a program yesterday to speed emergency repairs to the dilapidated West Side Highway while alternative permanent solutions involving extensive new construction were being argued hotly at a longawaited state public hearing.

title: Figures Don't Lie, Very Often
description: Williarn Roughead, the Scottish criminologist, was asked what adjective he thought best described Miss Lizzie Borden, the lily maid of Fall River, Mass., who either did or did not chop up her momma and poppa with an ax on her lunch hour. In Notable British Trials, Rascals Revived and Reprobates Reviewed, Mr. Roughead wrote eloquently of the gentle art of murder, offering the expiation that: My stories are true, though regrettably bloody. Well, what follows here is regrettably pecuniary, yet in order to see professional football's current labor dispute in perspective some financial discussion is essential. Toward that end, questions were submitted yesterday to the National Football League's management council, questions raised by a financial statement that the council released about 10 days ago.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN ABORTION SUIT
description: HACKENSACK, June 20Two Englewood physicians agreed today to drop their suit against a local antiabortionist group after the antiabortionists agreed to move picket lines away from the offices where the physicians perform abortions, vasectomies and other medical services.

title: $63MILLION LOST BY FRANKLIN BANK IN 5 MONTHS OF '74
description: The Franklin National Bank disclosed yesterday that it lost $63.6million in the first five months of the yearsome $25million more than the bank indicated when its troubles first became public six weeks ago.

title: HOUSING MEASURE IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The House of Representatives approved tonight a threeyear community development and housing bill that would lump a variety of Federal housing programs under bloc grants that localities could use largely as they see fit.

title: Books of The Times
description: WOMEN OF MESSINA By Elio Vittorini. Translated from the Italian by Frances Frenave and Frances Keene. Foreword by Webster Schott. 320 pages. New Directions. $9.50 ($3.75 in paperback).

title: Economic Advisers for Congress
description: WASHINGTON  With increasing frequency and severity, the symptoms of our nation's ailing economy have revealed themselves. Inflation for the first quarter of 1974 is at a staggering annual rate of 11.5 per cent. Real output decreased at an annual rate of 6.3 per cent, the largest quarterly drop in production since the recession of 1958. Unemployment exceeded an unacceptably high 5 per cent and there is every expectation that it will rise substantially later this year.

title: On Mr. Jaworski's Performance
description: PHILADELPHIAWith a great deal of sorrow, I must criticize my fellow prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, for the manner in which he is conducting the investigations and prosecutions arising out of the Watergate and other sordid affairs.

title: 2 Plead Guilty to StockSwindle Roles Involving Use of Franklin Bank's Funds
description: A former supervisor of the financially troubled Franklin National Bank and an independent securities trader have pleaded guilty in Manhattan Supreme Court to participating in a stock swindle, in which, at one point, they used $2.1million of the bank's funds to buy socalled flashy securities on the stock market.

title: Fishing and Boating Outlook for the Area
description: AREA ALarge bluefish are being taken off Barnegat Ridge by trollers and chummers day and night. Fluke fishing remains fair to good in bay and ocean near Barnegat. The fluke are taking live bait and spearing. Surf City reports fair angling for bass, blues and weakfish. Bay waters near Seaside Park are producing very little, but there are a few striped bass and blues in the surf. Point Pleasant reports a few fluke. Friday and Saturday night offshore trips will start this weekend from Ken's Landing at Point Pleasant.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, page 39

title: Lebanese Camps Hit
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 20Israeli planes struck at Palestinian camps in south Lebanon today for the third day, reportedly killing at least 20 people and injuring scores.

title: LawOffice Bugs Laid to Mobsters
description: TRENTON, June 20A highranking law enforcement official disclosed today that state investigators had uncovered evidence that indicated that illegal listening devices had been placed by the mob in the, offices of three criminal lawyers representing clients With reputed ties to organized crime in New Jersey.

title: 2 Cliffside Park Residents Are Killed in Plane Crash
description: SPARTA, June 20 (AP)Two Cliffside Park residents were found dead today in the wreckage of a plane in a heavily wooded area in this Sussex County community.

title: Cleanup Set on Oil Spill
description: EASTPORT, Me., June 20 (UPI)The Irving Oil Company of St. John, New Brunswick, has accepted responsibility for cleanup of an oil spill that washed ashore in this eastern Maine coastal town harbor, the United States Coast Guard announced late yesterday.

title: '74 World Food Prospect Shaky Despite U. S. Hopes
description: This is the first of a series of articles, which will appear from time to time, examining the world food situation.

title: CALLEY GOES BACK IN ARMY STOCKADE
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., June 20Former First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. walked briskly into a military stockade today after surrendering to Fort Benning authorities in compliance with a Federal appeals court order that put him in Army custody.

title: Nixon and House Versions Of the Tapes Differ Widely
description: WASHINGTON, June 20House Judiciary Committee transcripts of some of President Nixon's Watergate tape recordings differ extensively, and in many cases significantly, from the edited transcripts made public by the White House.

title: SAMUELS ANNOUNCES NEW LABOR SUPPORT
description: Howard J. Samuels, the Democratic State Committee's designee for Governor announced additional support yesterday in his bid for the party nomination in the Sept. 10 primary.

title: STATE CHIEF RULING ON DIPLOMA FOR GIRL
description: The State Commissioner of Education, Ewald B. Nyquist, will decide after a hearing today whether a Suffolk County school board can graduate a 17yearold physically disabled girl who lacks a quarter of a credit in a gym class.

title: U.S. DENIES FLYING MISSIONS IN VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, June 20 (UPI)North Vietnam accused American pilots today of flying combat missions over South Vietnam and the United States again charged the Communists with continuing to block the search for the 1,100 Americans missing in the Indochina war.

title: GL Corp. Plans Bid For Stock of Cerro
description: The GL Corporation of Chicago announced yesterday that it would make a cash tender offer to buy 1.5 million shares of the common stock of the Cerro Corporation at $19 a share. The offer, effective next Tuesday, will expire on July 16 and will be contingent on a minimum of 500,000 shares being tendered. Jay A. Pritzker, chairman of the GL Corporation, is a director of Cerro and presently holds 813,000 Cerro shares, or about 10.3 per cent of the common stock.

title: Screen Actors Guild Asks Authorization for a Strike
description: LOS ANGELES, June 20 (AP)  The Screen Actors Guild is asking its 29,000 members for strike authorization. Ballots were sent out this week to learn whether guild members were willing to set a July 1 deadline for reaching a contract settlement without strike.

title: RentStabilization Law Passes Council, 42 to 0
description: The City Council, 42 to 0, gave final local approval last night to making the state's new apartmentrentstabilization law effective in New York City, retroactive to May 29. Mayor Beanie's signature is not required.

title: Portrait of Yachtsman In Bermuda Race Today
Department Store Fired On
description: DALLAS, June 20 (UPI)A young man who said he hates Jews and was a member of the American Nazi party fired a 12gauge shotgun more than 50 times into a NeimanMarcus department store early today causing about $8,000 damage. The incident occurred at about 6 A.M. before the branch store opened for business. The police said an unidentified 25yearold was being held.

title: S. GEORGE LITTLE, 71, PUBLISHER, WRITER
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., June 20 (AP)S. George Little, founder and board chairman of the General Features Corporation and publisher of 10 weekly newspapers on Long Island, died today at his home here. He was 71 years old.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BALTIMORE (AL)Signed Rich Dauer, third baseman, firstround choice in freeagent draft.

title: Police Praised on Shootout
description: LOS ANGELES, June 20 (AP) City councilmen voted yesterday to commend the Police Department for its courage and efficiency in the May 17 shootout in which six Symbionese Liberation Army members were killed. The councilmen also voted to commend residents of the South Los Angeles neighborhood in which the shootout occurred for their cooperation.

title: LawofSea Parley Opens in Venezuela With 5,000 Officials From 148 Lands
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 20Representatives of almost all the world's countries convened the largest international conference in history here today, a summerlong meeting to draft a treaty that would govern man's use of the oceans.

title: Italy Starts to Tackle Financial Problems
description: ROME, June 20  Premier Mariano Rumor and his ministers started tackling Italy's pressing financial problems today after a 10day Government crisis that many critics termed a waste of time and energies.

title: Business Briefs
description: U.S. Finds Japan HandTool Dumping

title: From Men to People
description: CONCORD, N. H., June 20 (AP)References to men in the New Hampshire Constitution would he changed to people under a proposal passed today by the Constitutional Convention.

title: Moslem Rebels Remain Major Problem for Marcos
description: MANILA, June 13 Every few days, and perhaps more often, there is some kind of battle or ambush in the southern islands of the Philippines in which Government soldiers are killed.

title: Moscow Fears Nixon Visit Gets Inadequate Planning
description: MOSCOW, June 20  With President Nixon due to arrive next Thursday for his third meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev, there is an uneasy feeling in some Soviet quarters that the preparations for the conference have not progressed far enough.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
VIBRANT JAZZ PIANO BY CALVIN JACKSON
description: Calvin Jackson is a Julliardtrained pianist who plays jazz with great flair, but seemingly cannot resist reminding his listeners that he has a classical background. He is making his first New York appearance in 20 years at the Cookery, University Place and Eighth Street, where he has settled in for a summerlong stay.

title: LeakedMemos Author
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Bill Dixon smiles shyly, without protest, at the description Nixonhating partisanthe phrase that one White House spokesman used when Mr. Dixon's memorandums on potentially impeachable offenses began leaking out of the House Judiciary Committee.

title: Lebanese Camps Hit
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 20Israeli planes struck at Palestinian camps in south Lebanon today for the third day, reportedly killing at least 20 people and injuring scores.

title: Bus Subsidy and a Depot Voted by Estimate Board
description: The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to allocate $1.3million in state and city funds among 10 private bus lines to help them hold the 35cent fare, and it gave final approval for construction of a $4.6million municipal bus terminal and public parking garage in Flushing, Queens.

title: WIVES FORM UNIT AS POLICE LOBBY
description: SOUTH BRUNSWICK, June 20  A statewide council of policemen's wives was formed here last night with the main purpose of lobbying in Trenton for their husbands and their families.

title: Analysts Divided on Franklin Outlook
description: Some leading investment bankers and banking analysts yesterday viewed the announcement that the Franklin National Bank had lost $63.6million in the last five months as a clear indication that the troubled institution might not be able to survive in its present form.

title: Basketball Merger Crumbles at N.B.A. Meeting
description: A projected new order for professional basketball crumbled on all fronts yesterday when National Basketball Association club owners rejected a proposed modification of the players contract which would have cracked the reserveoption system.

title: Mammoth Task Facing Franklin Bank Chief
description: At age 56, Joseph W. Barr, the new chairman, chief executive officer and president of Franklin National Bank, has probably assumed one of the toughest jobs in the banking community.

title: Principles, Art and Money Form A Background to Rothko Trial
description: Toward the end of his life Mark Rothko went broody. He had every reason to do so. He was sick man. He had private troubles of a torturous kind. People were infatuated with forms of art that he despised. Day after day he would sit in his studio, where the paintings on the wall had a look of huge shattered presences, and he would study them long and hard, as if some question of fundamental importance had still to be settied between himself and them. It pleased him momentarily that to some of his younger visitors a first sight of his studio was what a first sight of the temple at Luxor had been to the Victorian traveler: something that took the name of sublimity and put a new face it.

title: SOVIET REPORTED TO PLEDGE EASiNG OF EXIT BY JEWS
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Secretary of State Kissinger has told several Senators that the Soviet Union is prepared to guarantee in writing that it will permit the emigration of 45,000 Jews a year, according to officials here. This would be 10,000 more than the total allowed to leave in 1973.

title: PAPER IN TRENTON CHANGING HANDS
description: The Washington Post Company has agreed to purchase The Trenton Times and its Sunday TimesAdvertiser for $16million in cash and promissory notes, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Garden Considers Dropping Boxing Bouts
description: Madison Square Garden's new president is considering dropping boxing, the sport that has made the Garden the world's bestknown arena for most of its 95 years.

title: Parents Liable for Graffiti
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 20 (UPI)Starting next year, parents will be financially responsible for the graffiti their children paint on buildings, restrooms and other property in California. Gov. Ronald Reagan yesterday signed a bill that makes the parents financially liable for up to $2,000 in damage.

title: Stocks Off for 5th Day; Dow Average Drops 5.32
description: An increase in the prime interest rate by a Miami bank yesterday sent the stock market into its fifth consecutive decline in continued lethargic trading.

title: Misses Mills and Haynie Share Golf Lead at 69
description: SUTTON, Mass., June 20 (AP)Mary Mills, the defender, closed with a rush in the final threesome and tied Sandra Haynie in the opening round today of the $50,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association championship.

title: LILCO Gets Rate Rise
description: The Public, Service Commission yesterday granted the Long Island Lighting Company an interim electricrate increase of $28.7million a year, effective July 1. New rate schedules are expected to increase the average customer's monthly bill by 13.4 per cent  from $28.84 to $32.02  until September, when lower differentials take effect. Page 75.

title: MORE BROKERS LIFT COMMISSION RATES
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., said yesterday it would raise commissions on most securities transactions valued up to $300,000. White, Weld & Co., Inc., also said it would raise commissions.

title: A Police Lieutenant Slain Going to Work
description: A police lieutenant in civilian clothes was killed yesterday by a man who tried to rob him as he walked to work along a quiet residential street in Queens. Though shot twice in the head, the policeman managed to draw his revolver and fire at his assailant.

title: COMPANY DEMAND FOR CREDIT SOARS
description: Demand for credit by corporations at major New York City banks soared and key shortterm interest rates rose sharply in the week ended Wednesday, data published yesterday by the Federal Reserve System showed.

title: Village Voice Staff Fails to Win Guarantee of Editorial Control
description: Village Voice writers, meeting with the editor of New York magazine, failed yesterday to win a guarantee of continued editorial control for the paper's present editor and publisher under the two publications' merged parent company.

title: ALVAH PARENT
description: Alvah K. Parent, a lawyer here for 50 years, died Wednesday at his home here, 7 Peter Cooper Road. He was 76 years old.

title: Bridge: Expert Play of a Declarer Can Cause Swing in Game
description: At high levels of tournament play, most of the swings result from the bidding or the luck of the lead rather than to the special playing skill of the declarer. On the great majority of deals, one expert will do as well as another in handling the dummy.

title: Corporate Bond Prices Decline; TaxExempts and U.S. Bills Up
description: Prices were mixed in quiet trading in the bond markets yesterday, with recently offered corporate issues losing more ground, taxexempt issues showing some firmness and Treasury bills continuing, this week's technical upturn. I n t e restrate watchers were given several new numbers to add to the current picture including:

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: NEW CREED URGED BY PRESBYTERIANS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 20  The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States accepted today for at least a year's study a controversial new declaration of faith that attempts to set forth doctrine in a contemporary perspective.

title: LawOffice Bugs Laid to Mobsters
description: TRENTON, June 20A high ranking law enforcement official disclosed today that state investigators had uncovered evidence that indicated that illegal listening devices had been placed by the mob in the offices of three criminal lawyers representing clients with reputed ties to organized crime in New Jersey.

title: Golf Results
description: BRITISH VICTORY CUP

title: PERSONAL INCOME ADVANCED IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 20Personal income increased in May by $10.6billion, the largest rise for any month this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Panel Hears I.R.S. Weighed Fraud Charge for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Members of the House Judiciary Committee disclosed today that the Internal Revenue Service had seriously considered charging President Nixon with fraud on his tax returns but had decided instead to make the lesser finding or negligence.

title: A CLINIC ON TASTE AN ISSUE AT N.l.H.
description: WASHINGTON, June 20A controversy is smoldering here over the future of a clink at the National Institutes of Health devoted to studying and treating patients with abnormalities of taste and smell.

title: Music for a While Is a Time Journey
description: The earlymusic ensemble that presents concerts under the heading Music for a While came to Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night with a decidedly recondite occasion to commemoratethe death of Guillaume Dufay in 1474.

title: Adults in Trouble Seek Youths' Aid
description: GREENWICH, Conn. Somewhere in this welltodo Fairfield County town, a middleaged man picked up a telephone the other night, dialed 661HELP and sought advice about venereal disease from a volunteer young enough to be his son.

title: British Labor Party Defeated on Nationalization
description: LONDON, June 20  The minority Labor party Government was defeated in the House of Commons tonight over plans to extend state control over industry.

title: ANTITRUST INQUIRIES ON MOBIL BID URGED
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Senator Adlai E. Stevenson said today that he was urging Federal antitrust agencies to investigate the Mobil Oil Corporation's proposed acquisition of a controlling interest in the Marcor Corporation, the holding company for Montgomery Ward and the Container Corporation. The Senator said he was writing to the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SCORE ADVANCES
description: Continued withholding of newly harvested wheat from markets by farmers was said to be the main reason wheat futures prices gained 17 cents and more a bushel yesterday for nearby delivery. The farmers, remembering $6 wheat some months ago, have not been willing to sell at $4 levels currently.

title: SMOKING BANNED IN SUPERMARKETS
description: The Board of Health yesterday approved a ban on smoking in elevators and supermarkets, but it rejected a proposal to require segregated seating for smokers in restaurants accommodating more than 50 people and in enclosed spaces used for sports or other events for which season tickets are sold.

title: AUTO OUTPUT DOWN BY 20.4% IN A WEEK
description: DETROIT, June 20American auto plants are scheduled to build 138,127 cars this week, a decline of 20.4 per cent from the 173,555 assembled last week, because of a Ford Motor Company stampingplant strike.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 4.1 %
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 18 billion tonmiles, 4.1 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 551,853 cars, 1,3 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 0.7 per cent last year.

title: REPORT DELAYED BY CHASE TRUST
description: Auditors for the Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, one of the nation's largest real estate investment trusts with a portfolio worth $900million, have declined to issue a preliminary report on the trust's fiscal status until it can make a better determination about the value of certain investments in the trust's portfolio.

title: HOUSING MEASURE IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The House of Representatives approved tonight a threeyear community development and housing bill that would lump a variety of Federal housing programs under bloc grants that localities could use largely as they see fit.

title: Family Court Judges Tour Land of Cases
description: At 8:30 Saturday morning, the doors of the Family Court at 283 Adams Street in downtown Brooklyn were still locked. Around back, nine judges had just arrived for an extra day's workbut not on the bench.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS June 20, 1974
description: New York899388

title: Nixon Briefs Leaders of Congress on Mideast Trip
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 President Nixon briefed Congressional leaders today on his Middle Eastern trip and assured them that he had reached no secret agreements or understandings with Arab or Israeli leaders.

title: Civil Defense Biscuits Feed Drought Victims
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20Million of pounds of nutritious biscuits being distributed these days to drought victims in Niger and Chad are one of the tangible benefits of improved SovietAmerican relations.

title: Complaint Filed by Con Edison Against Suppliers' Oil Charges
description: The Consolidated Edison company yesterday became the second major utility to sue its oil suppliers, charging conspiracy in the tripling and quadrupling fuel oil costs over the past nine months.

title: About New York
description: You know who's singing that? the man with one eye said to the woman. She was fat and pleasant, and she was wearing sandals and blue stockings.

title: With His Hayday Over, Feed Merchant Retires
description: JERSEY CITY, June 20 Henry Gunther, a man who professes a love for animals and an abiding faith in mankind, closed down his feed and grain store at 137 South Street here today after 40 years of operation.

title: SAMUEL GLICKMAN
description: Samuel Glickman, administrator of the welfare, penSion and special displacement trust funds of the Graphic Arts International, Union Local 119BPrinters League and vice president of the EduCational Conference of Health, Welfare and Pension Plans, died Wednesday in University Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 620 East 20th Street.

title: National Consumer Protection Organization Is Formed by State, County and City Agency Officials
description: WASHINGTON, June 20In a move reflecting the growing size and importance of consumer protection agencies throughout the country, a national organization of state, county and city consumer officials was formed here today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Wilson dedicated the headquarters of Odyssey House's Parents' Program yesterday in an outdoor ceremony on Wards Island. The program was started three years ago by the drug rehabilitation agency specifically aid addicted mothers, their preschool children and pregnant addicts. It is now housed in the Mabon Building, part of the Manhattan State Hospital complex on the East River island. The redbrick edifice was made available to. Odyssey House through the efforts of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, feller, Senator James L. Buckley and Representative Edward I. Koch.

title: Preemptive Plan
description: JERUSALEM, June 20The intensive Israeli air strikes into Lebanon today were carried out in accordance with a new policy of vigorous preemptive attacks against the Palestinian guerrilla organizations, Government sources said.

title: LEWIS LAURETZ
description: Lewis Lauretz, a director and vice president of Unishops, Inc., a national discountdepartmentstore chain, and a partner in Steinberg & Lauretz, public accountants, died Wednesday in Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived here.

title: Mayor Acts to Speed Emergency Repairs On West Side Road
description: Mayor Beame announced a program yesterday to speed emergency repairs to the dilapidated West Side Highway while alternative permanent solutions involving extensive new construction were being argued hotly at a longawaited state public hearing.

title: Longest Teacher Strike Divides New Hampshire Area
description: PLAISTOW, N. H., June 20The last day of classes in the Timberlane Regional School System began today as had so many others since last Feb. 26 with the teachers on a picket line.

title: Groucho Backin Townfor Animal Crackers
description: While waiting for a limosine to whisk him to a reception held by Angier Biddle Dukeperhaps for a repeat of Mrs. Rittenhouse's house party in Animal Crackers Groucho Marx rambled conversationally the other night.

title: SOVIET REPORTED TO PLEDGE EASING OP EXIT BY JEWS
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Secretary of State Kissinger has, told several Senators that the Soviet Union is prepared to guarantee in writing that it will permit the emigration of 45,000 Jews a year, according to officials here. This would be 10,000 more than the total allowed to leave in 1973.

title: BROKERAGE FIRMS AGREE ON MERGER
description: Shields & Co., Inc., and Model, Roland & Co., Inc., announced an agreement to merge yesterday, confirming a monthlong Wall Street rumor.

title: Police Lieutenant Slain Going to Work
description: A police lieutenant in civilian clothes was killed yesterday by a man who tried to rob him as he walked to work along a quiet residential street in Queens. Though shot twice in the head, the policeman managed to draw his revolver and fire at his assailant.

title: Army Recruiter Pay Raised
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Army has increased special pay for some recruiters to as high as $150 a month. The Army said it hoped the increased payments would attract highly motivated and capable recruiters.

title: Reed's Career Ended?
description: The playing days of Willis Reed appear to be over.

title: Explanation: Intricacies of the Nixon Tax Returns Being Examined in Impeachment Inquiry by House
description: WASHINGTON, June 20Is Richard Nixon a man who cares so much about money that even white President of the United States he kept on the alert for every possible angle that could save him taxes  even some that he knew were illegal?

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
FUENTES IS CITED ON ANTISEMITISM
description: The State Human Rights Commission will hold public hearings on charges that Luis Fuentes, superintendent of School District 1, abetted antiSemitic abuses in one of the districe's schools, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Ft. Lee Bribe Jury to Get Records of 19 Companies
description: NEWARK, June 20A Federal District Court judge today ordered records of 19 Northern New Jersey corporations connected with a criminal investigation of bribery charges to be turned over to a grand jury meeting here tomorrow.

title: CUNNINGHAM DANCE HAS WINNING IMAGES
description: James Cunningham's fine eye for incongruity, produced two winning images in his Apollo and Dionysos: Cheek to Cheek, but over all the production suggested that he and Lauren Persiohetti, his codirector, may have gone to this well of wit once too often. The piece was given its first performance at New York University's School of the Arts on Wednesday evening.

title: Atlantic Declaration
description: Henry Kissinger's April 1973 proposal of a new Atlantic Charter offered the West European allies Blasting recommitment to their security; in return, the Nixon Administration sought more economic cooperation from the European Community, better political consultation, greater sharing of mutual defense costs and improved machinery for joint management of common problems, plus a lofty inspirational reaffirmation common goals.

title: Ervin Criticizes Nixon Choice of Silbert
description: WASHINGTON, Jime 20Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of Mirth Carolina, criticized President Nixon today for nominating Earl J. Silbert, a former Watergate case prosecutor, to be the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia.

title: Paraplegic Motorist Beaten And Robbed by Hitchhiker
description: A paraplegic motorist was beaten, robbed of his car, money and a watch yesterday by a hitchhiker he had picked up in Babylon, L.I. A suspect, was arrested after the police spotted him near the car, a few blocks from the scene of the robbery.

title: A DOMESTIC PEACE IS URGED BY FORD
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 20 Vice President Ford called today for bold domestic diplomacy to negotiate peace for a troubled America.

title: '74 World Food Prospect Shaky Despite U.S. Hopes
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20The new report to a Senate committee that the needy in the United States are hungrier and poorer than they were four years ago has

title: COL. PERCY THOMPSON
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., June 20 (AP)Col. Percy W. Thompson, U.S.A. refired, maternal grandfather of David Eisenhower, died yesterday.

title: A Jug of Wine, A Loaf of Bread And a Brown Bag
description: After a winter hiatus, the brown bag has once again emerged as the summer's most popular accessory. Oh, not the chic brown vinyl satchel that's sprinkled with the designer's initials, but the plain brown paper bagthe kind you carry your lunch in.

title: Abstract Art Outrages Italians Who Wanted Columbus Statue
description: YONKERS, June 20Two years ago, the predominantly Italian Park Hill section here asked the City of Yonkers to beautify Columbus Park, a onesquareblock enclave, and to install a suitable piece. of sculpture.

title: Busby Credits Rojas With NoHit Assist
description: MILWAUKEE, June 20 (AP)  Everything was working, Steve Busby said after wrapping up the second nohitter of his young major league career.

title: Nixon and House Versions Of the T apes Differ Widely
description: WASHINGTON, June 20House Judiciary Committee transcripts of some of President Nixon's Watergate tape recordings differ extensively, and in many cases significantly, from the edited transcripts made public by the White House.

title: People and Business
description: The Federal Reserve System must continue its restrictive credit policies if inflation is to be controlled, accordng to Gabriel Hauge, chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.

title: Kissinger and Petersen
description: WASHINGTON, June 20Six weeks away from Watergate seem to have made no difference at all. Like Old Man River, it just keeps rolling along. Like a river, too, it keeps eating away at its own banks until it appears as if everyone and everything in the vicinity may ultimately be engulfed. Has any episode ever so glaringly disclosed the corrupting nature of power and the tendency toward mass ethical blindness at the heart of modern institutional life?

title: BEAME IS VICTOR IN BUDGET FIGHT
description: Mayor Beame won a smashing victory yesterday when the City Council and Board of Estimate adopted his $11.1billion expense budget virtually unchanged and the Cotincil approved the taxes needed to ballance it.

title: Staub Drives in 2 Runs, Koosman Stops Phils, 21
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 20The New York Mets began the long road back tonight. Pressure pitching by Jerry Koosman, plus a reliable outfield, gave the lastplace New Yorkers a 21 victory over the Eastern Divisionleading Philadelphia Phillies, ending a fourgame losing skein and cutting the distance between them and the Phils to nine games.

title: Delaware River Agency to Bill Some Consumers of Its Water
description: Users of water from the Delaware River and its tributaries will receive notices in the mail soon saying that some of them will have to start paying for water that, until now, has been free.

title: $63MILLION LOST BY FRANKLIN BANK IN 5 MONTHS OF '74
description: The Franklin National Bank disclosed yesterday that it lost $63.6million in the first five months of the yearsome $25million more than the bank indicated when its troubles first became public six weeks ago.

title: People in Sports
description: Moses to Take Commandments from Lefty was the headline in yesterday's Annapolis (Md.) Evening Capital announcing the fact that Moses Malone, the 6foot11inch Petersburg (Va.) high school basketball star and the most recruited player in the country, had signed a grantinaid with Coach Lefty Driesell to attend the University of Maryland.

title: Butz Warns of Retaliation On MeatTrade Practices
description: WASHINGTON, June 20Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz warned both exporting and importing countries today against trade practices that he said were deepening the distress of the United States cattle industry. We may be forced into a retailiatory posture, he said, unless major exporting countries agree to voluntary restraints on shipments to this country and un less other countries, particuarly Canada, reduce barriers to United States shipments.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: McCord Feels Nixon Approved Watergate Entry in Some Way
description: BOSTON, June 20James W. McCord Jr., the convicted Watergate burglar, said today that he believed that President Nixon had personally authorized and set in motion the illegal entry into the Democratic National Committee offices two years ago.

title: The Pop Life
description: She moans, groans, hollers, hisses, begs and demands whn she sings one of her own songs. She struts, shakes, twists, turns and stricks her tongue out lecherously when she performs.

title: SUCREST FOLLOWS RISE IN SUGAR PRICE
description: The Sucrest Corporation, following a move the day before by CPC International, Inc., announced yesterday that it was raising its prices on industrial sugars in a number of Eastern regions by $1.65 per hundredweight, effective today.

title: New Hampshire Candidacy
description: WASHINGTHON, June 20 (AP)  An aide to Representative James Cleveland, Republican of New Hampshire, confirmed today that Mr. Cleveland intends to seek reelection. He said the candidacy would be announced in about two weeks.

title: Wagner Ban Is Ended By Israel Philharmonic
description: JERUSALEM, June 20 (AP)  The Israel Philhramonic Orchestra decided yesterday to end its ban on the music of Richard Wagner. The German composer's works had been ruled out by the orchestra on the ground that he was an antiSemite idolized by Hitler.

title: Wendy Heckler Wed To Drew S. Denbaum
description: Miss Wendy Jeanne Heckler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Heckler of Westbury, L. I., was married in Upper Brookville, L. I., last evening to Drew Steven Denbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Denbaum of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Donald Gluckman performed the ceremony at the Mill River Country Club.

title: Advertising: Reprieve on Rates
description: A wave of relief swept through the harried magazine industry with the news that the Senate bill to delay scheduled postal increases had passed in the House and has been sent to the President.

title: Cubs Halt Pirates, 30, On 12Hitter
description: CHICAGO, June 20 (AP)Home runs by Jose Cardenal and Billy Williams led the Chicago Cubs to a 30 triumph over Pittsburgh today, ending the Pirates' victory string at six games.

title: Sanok, on 148, Leads in Jersey
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., June 20  Chet Sanok of Upper Montclair recorded his second consecutive round of 74 today to take the lead at 148 after two rounds in the 73d New Jersey State amateur golf championship at the Navesink Country Club.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Sol Berg, board chairman of the New York Sets, who has been absolutely aggravated by his team's 515 wonlost record in World Team Tennis, signed Virginia Wade of England to a multiyear contract in London yesterday and promised: New York will not be a loser for long. The New York commodities dealer, who paid $25,000 for negotiating rights, had been trying to sign the former United States Open champion since April.

title: Complaint Filed by Con Edison Against Suppliers' Oil Charges
description: The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday became the second major utility to sue its oil suppliers, charging conspiracy in the tripling and quadrupling fuel oil costs over the past nine months.

title: Black Man, Walk About The Village With Care!
description: At dawn New York's Greenwich Village is reminiscent of Paris in spring, and each morning I used to stroll leisurely through its picturesque streets'Few people were about and the airwithout the exhaust fumes was exhilarating to inhale. I bad a prescribed route that seldom varied, and never once was I accosted, or even vaguely threatened by anyone except the police.

title: 2d Fleet Commander Named
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 20 (AP) Vice Adm. Stansfield Turner, president of the Naval War College here, will become cornmander of the Second Fleet based at Norfolk, Va., the Navy said yesterday. Admiral Turner will replace Vice Adm. John G. Finneran.

title: LILCO Gets Rate Rise
description: The Public Service Commission yesterday granted the Long Island Lighting Company an interim electricrate increase of $28.7million a year, effective July 1. New rate schedules are expected to increase the average customer's monthly bill by 13.4 per cent  from $28.84 to $32.02  until September, when lower differentials take effect. Page 75.

title: An ExPolice Chief Loses Appeal in GunLaw Case
description: TRENTON, June 20A state appeals court today upheld the conviction of the former East Greenwich Township Police Chief, Christopher V. Constantino, for issuing 18 gun permits without carrying out the requirements of the state gunregistration law.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SARI SITE For sore eyes and even hose not yet weary of summer in the city, tonight it will be classicial dancing from India among the Rodins, Moores and Picassos in the Museum of Modern Art's Sculpture Garden. Manju Prasad, who is teaching Indian dance at the New School for Social Research, will present three styles of Hindu dance: Bharata Natyam, which originated more than 2,000 years ago; Kathak, an animated Mogul Court dance, and Pradams, based on Indian love lore.

title: BID IS REPORTED FOR 6 KLEIN UNITS
description: Korvette department stores, the metropolitan area's third largest retailer, is reportedly negotiating with S. Klein Department Stores to acquire six Klein stores in the New York suburban area, according to informed sources.

title: Short Interest Continues to Dip; Big Board Position Falls 4.9%
description: The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange continued to decline for the second month in a row, according to figures released yesterday by the exchange.

title: Hasidic Jews Called Victims in Redistricting Case
description: Representatives of 35,000 Hasidic Jews argued in Federal District Court yesterday that the newly drawn assembly district lines that divide their cornmunity in half discriminate against them in favor of blacks and should be thrown out as unconstitutional.

title: NonSexist Schools ...
description: The proposed Federal regulations to end sex discrimination in education add up to a sensible recognition of the changed status of womenand, for that matter, of menin modern American society. If adopted, these rules would go far toward eliminating some outdated concepts that have long denied women fair treatment at school and college.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX;
description: Page

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: News Summary and Index
description: In his campaign against Senate restrictions on Soviet American trade, Secretary of State Kissinger is said to have told Senators that Moscow is prepared to issue a written guarantee to allow 45,000 Jews to emigrate each year and a statement on harassment of wouldbe emigrants. The Senators have reportedly called the pledge on harassment unacceptably vague. [1:8.]

title: Dr. Alfred Mirsky, Pioneer In Molecular Biology, Dies
description: Dr. Alfred E. Mirsky, the Rockefeller University biochemist who found methods nearly, 30 years ago to isolate the genetic material of animal cells for scientific study, died Wednesday in his home at 350 Central Park West. He was 73 years old.

title: BISHOP PEABODY, LED SYNOD HERE
description: Bishop Malcolm E. Peabody, who headed the Episcopal Diocese of Central New York State from 1942 until his retirement in 1960, died yesterday in Boston. He was 86 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: 13 INDICTED HERE ON CIGARETTE TAX
description: The indictment of 13 persons, including a former police officer and four Brooklyn women, on charges of smuggling four million cartons of cigar rettes a year into the city from North Carolina was announced yesterday by Eugene Gold, the Brooklyn District Attorney.

title: PRICEFIXING IS LAID TO LETTUCE GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission began legal proceedings today alleging that a pricefixing pact in the nation's salad bowl contributed to last summer's soaring lettuce prices. The proposed complaint named 22 growers and shippers who are members of the Central California Lettuce Producers Cooperative in California's Salinas Valley.

title: France's Discount Rate Lifted 2 Points To Highest in Western World at 13%
description: PARIS, June 20The Bank of France raised its discount rate today two points to 13 per cent, the highest in the Western world. The United States bank discount rate is 8 per cent.

title: Music: Goldman Band
description: The notion that New York City is just an enormous small town might be supported by the enthusiasm with which it greets the traditional summer band concerts in its parks. The Guggenheim Memorial Concerts, played by the Goldman Band since 1917, opened their annual season Wednesday night in Damrosch Park, attended by an audience that filled the 2,500 available seats and spread to the wall copings and benches under the trees in the rear.

title: Contract Awards
description: The OwensCorning Fiberglas Corporation said yesterday it had been awarded a $70million contract to supply insulation for the elevated portion of the TransAlaska Pipeline. The order was placed by the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, the organization responsible for the design, construction and operation of the line.

title: 4Star Potential, but a 2  Star Performance
description: Somewhere between three and four times out of five, a favorable review in this column brings a letter from a couple who have had a dreadful time at the restaurant in question. The waiter insults them, the chef tries to poison them, the check bankrupts them, and when they complain to the proprietor he laughs in their faces and throws them out on their ears.

title: Nader, in Court Plea, Calls Milk Price Rise a Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI)Fighting to keep his suit against the Nixon Administration alive, Ralph Nader said today that the 1971 milk price support increase was a massive conspiracy to defraud thc public.

title: Egyptians Due in U.S. Today To Make Nuclear Fuel Deal
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (Reuters)A team of Egyptian atomic energy experts arrives in Washington tomorrow to begin negotiations on a nuclear fuel contract for the atomic reactor promised them by President Nixon during his recent visit.

title: State Agrees to Audit of Ballet Theater
description: Arthur Levitt, the State Cbntroller, agreed yesterday to make a special audit of the American Ballet Theater and its parent unit, the Ballet Theater Foundation, in response to a request by the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: Notes on People
description: A Superior Court judge in Los Angeles yesterday set aside the indefinite jail sentence imposed on William Farr, a Los Angeles Times reporter, for refusing to name his source for a story he wrote during the Charles Manson murder trial.

title: 2d Alternative Proposed To Governor's Tax Plan 3 Democrats From Ocean County Urge a Statewide Property Tax Leaning Most Heavily on Businesses
description: TRENTON, June 20A legislative revenue plan relying heavily on a statewide property tax on corporate and commercial ratables was proposed here today as the second alternative to Governor Byrne's proposed income tax.

title: I.L.O. Criticizes Israel
description: GENEVA, June 20  The International Labor Organization's annual assembly adopted today an Arabsponsored resolution accusing Israel of racial discrimination and violation of trade union rights in occupied Arab territory. The resolution was approved by a vote of 224 to 0, with 122 abstentions.

title: FundRaiser's Sentence Cut
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 20 (AP)A Federal judge today ??ut in half the oneyear prison ??entence imposed on Larry Williams, former fundraiser for Senator Edward J. Gurney, Re??ublican of Florida. United States District Judge Charles R. Scott's brief order stated no ??eason for his action. Mr. Wil??iams, who pleaded guilty to channeling a bribe to a housing official, asked last week that his term be shortened because he expects to spend time a Government witness in trials.

title: Kodes Bows To Tanner; Smith Wins
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 20 (AP)Roscoe Tanner, a 22yearold from Lookout Mountain, Tenn., defeated another big name in tennis today and gained the semifinals of the John Player tournament along with Stan Smith, Marty Riessen and Alex Metreveli.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NORTHVALE, June 20The years have been unusually kind to Althea Gibson. One of greats of international tennisshe won the singles crown at Wimbledon and Forest Hills in successive years (195758), and was voted female athlete of the year in 1958Miss Gibson looks startlingly unchanged today, at age 46.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market continued to slide yesterday in the absence of any news that could be construed as bullish.

title: ETHICS PANEL OF BAR WARNS OF DISCIPLINE
description: CHICAGO, June 20 (APPrompted by lawyers' involvement in the Watergate scandal, a committee of the American. Bar Association advised today that lawyers were subject to disciplinary procedures of the bar for conduct not connected with the actual practice of law.

title: Former J.H.S. 22 Student Testifies to Being Paddled
description: A former student at Jordan L. Mott Junior High School 22 in the Bronx charged yesterday that she had been hit once with a wooden paddle by the school's principal and that later she had been made to sign a statement that this had never happened.

title: Charges Made That Bell System Has Used Economic Retaliation
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Allegations that the Bell System has engaged in economic retaliation against companies that decided to use nonBell telephone equipment were made today by businessmen from across the nation.

title: Portrait Defacer Identified
description: ATLANTA, June 20 (UPI)The portrait of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the Georgia Capitol was defaced by a mentally disturbed black woman who is a great admirer of the late civil rights leader, Gov. Jimmy Carter said yesterday. She had written her name on the portrait just to show people that she had been there and that she admired Dr. King and wanted to associate her name with him, said Mr. Carter.

title: National geographic Is Finally Picketed
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Picketing the National Geo graphic? asked the receptionist in the lobby of the National Geogaphic Society's opulent headquarters. Are you kicding? Who could be mad at us?

title: Floyd Leads On 65
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 20The walking wounded who survived last week's United States Open at Winged Foot found a form of rest and recuperation today in the American Golf Classic.

title: Inertia on Inflation
description: When President Nixon created the Cost of Living Council a little less than three years ago, he pledged that the Federal Government would not abandon the war against inflation until it had been won. This week, with consumer prices going up more than twice as fast as they were then, the Government's total defeat in that war has been signaled by Presidential approval of an order abolishing the council and all the rest of the control machinery set up in 1971 to help stabilize the dollar's buying power.

title: BEAME IS VICTOR IN BUDGET FIGHT
description: Mayor Beame won a smashing victory yesterday when the City Council and Board of Estimate adopted his $11.1billion expense budget virtually unchanged and the Council approved the taxes needed to balance it.

title: Boa Constrictors Keep Rats Away From Food
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20  The Food and Agriculture Organization, which has estimated that up to 25 per cent of foods are destroyed by rodents in many countries, has reported that a Colombian warehouse has found a way of solving the problem.

title: In Defense of Leaks
description: WASHINGTON, June 20Ever since Adamor was it Eve?leaked the news about that tempting apple and other funny business in the Garden of Eden, the human race has been arguing about the wisdom of leaking forbidden news. The latest chapter in this long story is now unfolding here.

title: EASING OP TRADE IS URGED ON BLOC
description: BRUSSELS, June 20  The Executive Commission of the European Common Market has proposed to the nine members of the trade bloc that they substantially increase the generalized trade preferences on industrial goods imported from developing countries.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 6.7 From a Week Ago Level
description: The commodity spot market price index on foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 225.6 from 218.9 last week.

title: Decline Is Found in Support for Schools
description: MIAMI, June 20  A pessimistic picture of declining support for public elementary and secondary education was drawn today by officials attending the annual meeting of the Education Commission of the States, an organization of Governors, legislators and educators from 45 states.

title: ExAtlantic Aide Freed On Extortion Charges
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 20 (UPI)John R. Campbell, former Atlantic County auditor, was found not guilty today on charges of extortion and misconduct. He was accused of having demanded $11,700 in county funds from two county solicitors.

title: TV: Evolution Dramatized, Inflation Examined
description: Evidently tn the minority, judging from boxoffice figures and Nielsen ratings, I find Planet of the Apes and its various progeny rather tedious and uninteresting. Only the elaborate makeup, all that fur and paste covering the actors, generates some curiosity for a few minutes.

title: 6 Youths Held in Murder Of Illustrator in Park Here
description: Six day of oldfashioned detective work coulminated yesterday in the arrest of six youths in the murder of Roger Hane, the magazine illustrator who was fatally beaten by bicycle thieves last week as he rode in Central Park.

title: Multinationals' Role Sparks a Dispute
description: MEXICO CITY, June 20Forty countries meeting here to draft a proposed world economic charter under United Nations auspices are deeply divided over the definition of the proper role of multinational corporations in developing countries.

title: The Brownstone
description: New York has been known for its incubator industries the small businesses that generate ideas, enterprises and successand it also has had its incubator housing. By custom this has been the brownstone, the recycled New York row house that has become the affordable shelter of the young, the ambitious and the talented on their way up; the newly married and the small family; the old and the indigent. It has been housing for the artist, the writer, the scholar and the creative community that contributes to the singular vitality of the city's culture.

title: Ford Raises Prices To Meet Higher Costs
description: DETROIT, June 20 (UFOThe Ford Motor Company said today that it was increasing the average cost of cars and trucks by $10.45 immediately because of increased freight costs.

title: NEW FOOD AGENCY SOUGHT BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, June 20Reorganization of the Federal structure to place all programs dealing with food policy in one agency was proposed today in a report by a panel of specialists to the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs.

title: Wives of Police Protest Women in Patrol Cars
description: I just saw one sitting in a patrol car fixing her hair, said Mrs. Sally Corley, patting her own short red hair, as she walked with Mrs. Jane Wanser from Police Plaza to City Hall yesterday to protest the Police Department's assigning policewomen to patrol cars with male officers.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: CHEMICO TO BUILD 4 SOVIET PLANTS
description: MOSCOW, June 20The Soviet Union today signed a $200million contract with the Chemical Construction Corporation, an American company, to construct four large ammonia plants on the Volga River. The order was decribed as the largest single Soviet contract awarded thus far for American industrial technology.

title: Mrs. Hart, Mrs. Bower In Golf Final
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 20 The 71st annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's match play championship has come down to two former titleholders, Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham Country Club and Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of New Jersey's Baltusrol Club.

title: ERVIN PANEL BARS ENDING SUBPOENA
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The Senate Watergate committee declined Yesterday to quash its subpoenas for some of the personal financial records of Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's friend, and the President's two brothers, Donald and Edward.

title: Bob Wilson Says Jaworski Plans No Move Against Him
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 20 (AP) The Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, has assured Representative Bob Wilson, Republican of California, that no grand jury or court action is being considered against him in the I.T.T. investigation, Mr. Wilson said today.

title: Beame Marks Opening Of Summer Fun Events
description: A puppet named Funston Frog playfully nipped Mayor Beanie yesterday and marked the official commencement of a 1,233event summer entertainment program for the city.

title: Pop: Schaefer Festival
description: Ron Delsener came up with a pretty good set of substitutes for John Sebastian on Wednesday evening at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park. Mr. Sebastian, ill in California with strep throat, will now appear in a special, added Schaefer Festival show Sept. 3.

title: Top Woman Upset In Eastern Tennis
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y. June 20Mary Carillo of Douglaston, Queens, upset Mrs. Marilvn Aschner Rachleff, the topseeded player, 64, 62, today to advance to Sunday's final of the Eastern clay court women's championships at the Orienta Beach Club.

title: PAUL MATTHEWS SR.
description: Paul C. Matthews Sr., who retired five years ago as an Admiralty lawyer here, died Wednesday in Delray Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 78 years old and formerly lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Tingley's 72 Wins Met. Seniors Golf
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., June 20James E. Tingley of the Nassau Country Club won the 47th annual seniors championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association by four strokes today with a 35, 3772 at the Mount Kisco Country Club. Tingley, an insurance man who became eligible for a seniors tournament this year, headed a field of 165 golfers, all 55 years or older, that played the 6,154yard, par35, 3671 course.

title: Screen
description: CHINATOWN, directed by Roman Polanski; screenplay by Robert Towne; produced by Robert Evans; director of photography, John A. Alonzo; music, Jerry Goldsmith; editor, Sam O'Steen; distributed by Paramour Pictures. Running time 130 minute. At the Loews State 1 Theater, Broadway near 45th Street, and Coronet Theater, Third Avenue near 59th Street. This film has been rated R.

title: A Complete Law of the Sea Has Eluded Nations for 300 Years
description: Man the Seafarer roamed the ocean for millenia to barter and battle, to explore and colonize, to harvest and plunder, often to die in the cruel deep but always convinced that the sea was boundless and bountiful.

title: Palestinians Raided Again Under New Israeli Policy
description: Palestinians Raided Again Under New Israeli Policy

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Preemptive Plan
description: JERUSALEM, June 20The intensive Israeli air strikes into Lebanon today were carried out in accordance with a new policy of vigorous preemptive attacks against the Palestinian guerrilla organizations, Govlernment sources said.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Judge Drops Charge Against Playwright And Praises Talent
description: Miguel Piero, author or the prize  winning play Short Eyes, received another good review yesterdayin Criminal Court.

title: USM Shows 3.9% Rise in Earnings
LILCO GETS RISE IN ELECTRIC RATE
description: The Public Service Commission yesterday granted the Long Island Lighting Company an interim electricrate increase of $28,739,000 a year, effective July 1.

title: DONALD R. JAMES
description: Donald Reed James, former publicity director for the American Iron and Steel Institute and an associate editor of its magazine, Steelways, died Wednesday at his home, 86 South Maple Avenue, Greens Farms, Conn. He was 67 years old.

title: Experts Agree on Overpopulation Peril, but Disagree Sharply on Remedies
description: While they agreed that world was perched on the brink of Malthusian disaster, international experts differed sharply yesterday on how to cope with the most crucial factor in the foodpopulation equation  the annual 2 per cent increase in the number of mouths to feed.

title: Market Place: Benefits Found In Bond Funds
description: The closedend bond funds were Wall Street's last great marketing success. Practically every major brokerage firm marketed one or more of them under the sponsorship of major insurance companies and banks.

title: Marc Pincherle Is Dead at 86; Author of Catalogue on Vivaldi
description: PARIS, June 20 (AP)Marc Pincherle, author of a catalogue of the works of the 18thcentury Italian musician Antonio Vivaldi, died today after heart attack, his family reported. He was 86 years old.

title: Postal Workers End Strike in Portugal
description: LISBON, June 20  A strike of some 125,000 postal workers collapsed early this morning, a major victory for Portugal's hardpressed provisional Government and for the Communist party.

title: Sanok, on 148, Leads in Jersey
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., June 20  Chet Sanok of Upper Montclair recorded his second consecutive round of 74 today to take the lead at 148 after two rounds in the 73d New Jersey State amateur golf championship at the Navesink Country Club.

title: A REVIEW IS ASKED ON NIXON EVIDENCE
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The White House asked the Supreme Court today to inspect the minutes and evidence of the Watergate grand jury to help decide whether President Nixon should have been named as an unindicted coconspirator.

title: Jacobsen Is PleaBargaining; Connally Reported the Target
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) Jake Jacobsen, former milk cooperative lawyer and longtime political associate of former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally, is pleabargaining with the Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, his attorney said today.

title: Passing Firemen Help In Arrest of Gunman
description: Firemen returning from a fire last night came upon a large, angry crowd on Clinton Avenue in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn and aided in the arrest of a man whom neighbors accused of shooting another man the firemen found lying wounded on the sidewalk.

title: Details Kept Robinson Out of Yankee Uniform
description: The Yankees, who passed up a chance to get Frank Robinson several years ago because they wouldn't give up Fritz Peterson for him, have passed up another opportunity to get the superstar, this time perhaps over a matter of about $35,000, it was learned yesterday.

title: Wallace's Assailant, in Prison, Remains a Silent, Private Man
description: BALTIMORE  Except for a full reddishblond beard, Arthur J. Bremer shows no other outward changes since he was convicted of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama at a political rally on May 15, 1972.

title: A President for Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 20 (UPI)A spokesman for the Chilean government announced today that the leader of the military junta, Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, would soon assume the title of President. General Pinochet has held the title of president of the ruling fourman military junta since the coup of Sept. 11, 1973, that ousted the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Assembly minority leader, Thomas H. Kean Essex County, conceded defeat yesterday to Mrs. Millicent Fenwick in the race for the Republican nomination for the Fifth Congressional District. He said after a recount in four of the five counties in the district that Mrs. Fenwick had won the nomination by 76 votes.

title: Trust Report Delayed
description: Auditors for the Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, a leading real estate investment trust, have declined to issue a preliminary report on the trust's fiscal status until it can make a better determination about the value of certain investments in the trust's portfolio. Details on Page 53.

title: Bonn's Lower House Backs Czech Pact
description: BONN, June 20A treaty to establish normal relations between West Germany and Czechoslovakia was ratified by the lower house of Parliament today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 15yearold former student at Junior High School 22 in New York testified that she had once been hit with a paddle by the school's principal and later made to sign a statement denying this had happened.

title: COL. ROBERT P. STOUT
description: Col. Robert P. Stout, Army Reserve, retired, who had been a lawyer for the New York Life Insurance Company until 1957, died Tuesday at Centre Manor Nursing Home, New Rochelle, N. Y. He was 79 years old and lived at 248 Monterey Avenue, Pelham, N. Y.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were estimated at $1.158billion, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $1.102billion. Total retail store sales were about $10.67billion, up 4 per cent from last year's $10.241billion.

title: Expert Finds Apathy in Fertilizer Crisis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20  Dr. Norman E. Borlaug, the noted developer of highyield grains, said here this week that during a recent tour of Asia and Africa he found few governments concerned about the need to accelerate fertilizer production.

title: Higher Appalachia Coal Taxes Asked
description: PETROS, Tenn.For decades this small Morgan County community in the mountains of east Tennessee and many others like it have been known for the coal they produce and the poverty they harbor. Somehow much of the fortune of coal mining never reached the multitudes of local citizens the way the poverty did. And in recent months a few of the reasons as to why have come to light.

title: Red Sox Rained Out
description: BOSTON, June 21 (AP)Rain forced postponement of tonight's ClevelandBoston baseball game. It was rescheduled for 8 P.M. tomorrow, following a previously scheduled 2:15 afternoon game.

title: ARABS AND ISRAELIS CLASH AT SEA TALKS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 21 (AP)A clash between Arab countries and Israel today threatened to disrupt the United Nations conference here that is seeking to draft a treaty governing use of the oceans.

title: FLORIDA CONCERN SEEKS COMBANKS
description: First Bancshares of Florida, Inc., in Boca Raton said yesterday that it had renewed its agreement to acqire under revised terms the Combanks Corporation, a sevenbank holding company based in Winter Park, Fla. First Bancshares now proposes an exchange of 2.275 of its common shares for each Combanks share outstanding. The transaction, First Bancshares said, would be worth about $24million. When originally announced last fall, the terms called for an exchange of two shares of First Bancshares for each Combanks share, subject to adjustment depending on market prices that could have resulted in an exchange ratio of 2.44 shares for each Combanks share.

title: Shielding the Public
description: An astute blend of collective bargaining and plea bargaining, supervised by State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts, has given New Yorkers increased protection against strikes in vital public services.

title: Airlines Back a New Rise For TransAtlantic Fares
description: TransAtlantic airlines, which have already put in effect three fare increases this year, agreed yesterday to another 5 per cent rise, effective Aug. 1.

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE 1.1% IN MAY; FOOD IS UP AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Consumer prices resumed their rapid rise in May after some moderation in April, the Labor Department reported today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 22, 1974

title: Contract Awards
description: The Air Force yesterday awarded a $42.8million contract to the Rockwell International Corporation to develop, build and launch three prototype satellites in the Naystar Global Positioning System. When the program is completed, 24 satellites will provide everything from supersonic aircraft to ships and infantry and submerged submarines with their locations within 30 feet day or night in any kind of weather. The joint services program will cost an estimated $150million in its initial phase. It is expected to be operational in the mid1980's.

title: Chessie Expects to Report Higher FirstHalf Earnings
description: Chessie System, Inc. said yesterday it expected to report unprecedented earnings of above $4.25 a share for the first half of 1974 compared with $3.72 in the yearago period.

title: N.B.A. Adds Toronto, Without Owner
description: A pro basketball team is feturning to Toronto, the site of the first major professional game 28 years ago.

title: Margery G. McGraime Is a Bride
description: In the Brookville (L. I.) Reformed Church last evening Miss Margery Gail McGraime, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William McGraime of Upper Brookville, L. I., was married to Peter Elliot Marshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lyon Marshall Jr. of Mill Neck, L. I., The Rev. John Hascup performed the ceremony.

title: Nutrition Study Finds U.S. Lacks a Goal
description: WASHINGTON, June 21A panel of specialists who conducted a fourmonth study told a Senate committee today that they had found government agencies poorly organized to pursue a national food and nutrition policy and said that even a national goal was lacking.

title: COLSON REPORTS URGING BY NIXON; GETS 1 TO 3 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21C.harles W. Colson was sentenced today to one to three years in prison and fined $5,000 after telling a Federal judge that President Nixon had urged him on numerous occasions to commit the acts for which he was being jailed.

title: Strikes Against Peace
description: Steppedup Palestinian terrorist attacks against Israel and Israeli counterattacks against Palestinian settlements in southern Lebanon pose a threat to the promising progress toward peace in the Middle East that was dramatized by President Nixon's recent tour of the region.

title: MRS. J. D. BEHRMANN
description: Mrs. Myra Pratt Behrmann, widow of Julius D. Behrmann, a Pennsylvania Railroad supervisor who died in 1949, died last Saturday in a nursing home in Manchester, N. H. She was 85 years old and had formerly lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: LLOYD JACOBS
description: Lloyd Jacobs, a vice president of the Loews Corporation for construction operations, died Thursday in the Deepdale Hospital, Little Neck, Queens. He was 57 years old and lived in the Hotel Ten Park Avenue, at 34th Street.

title: White House Seen Opposing Soviet Plan to Have Nixon Go to Yalta
description: MOSCOW, June 21A disagreement has developed between the Soviet authorities and the White House advance team over whether President Nixon should go to Yalta during his forthcoming visit, reliable sources reported tonight.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE MAY CALL COLSON
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Members of the House Judiciary Committee said today that Charles W. Colson's courtroom statement implicating President Nixon in possible obstruction of justice made it imperative to call Mr. Colson as a witness at impeachment hearings.

title: Sanok's 296 Takes Jersey Golf by 1
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., June 21Chet Sanok of Upper Montclair, urging his aging legs through a rainspattered final two rounds, captured his fourth New Jersey amateur championship today with rounds of 73 and 75 for a total of 296 at the Navesink Country Club.

title: Indianapolis Mayor Will Oppose Bayh In Race for Senate
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 21Mayor Richard G. Lugar of Indianapolis won today an easy victory for the Republican nomination to the United States Senate.

title: 2 Jewish Groups Denounce Moscow's Numbers Game
