description: Two prominent Jewish organizations, commenting on reports that the Soviet Union was prepared to set a quota of 45,000 Soviet Jews to be allowed to emigrate a year, denounced Moscow for playing a cynical numbers game with human lives.

title: CrossBurning Conviction of 2 Is Reversed by Appeals Court
description: TRENTON, June 21The Appellate Division of State Superior Court today reversed the convictions of two men charged with burning crosses at predominantly black housing projects on the ground that the prosecutor's closing remarks were inflamatory and prejudicial.

title: People in Sports
description: George Foreman, world henvyweight champion, made first tour of the United Nations yesterday. He met with Under Secretary General F. Bradford Morse of the United States and discussed many things, including the Sahelian drought, which has claimed 100,000 lives in the subSahara, and his upcoming title fight with Muhammad All scheduled for September in Zaire, Africa.

title: BIKE ROBBERIES UP IN CENTRAL PARK
description: Bicycle robberies in Central Park, like the attack there last week that led to the death of Roger Hane, a magazine illustrator, have more than tripled over the last year, the police said yesterday.

title: People in Sports
description: George Foreman, world heavyweight champion, made his first tour of the United Nations yesterday, He met with Under Secretary General F. Bradford Morse of the United States and discussed many things, including the Sahelian drought, which has claimed 100,000 lives in the subSahara, and his upcoming title fight with Muhammad Ali scheduled for September in Zaire, Africa.

title: Peking Posters: Testing Limits of Debate
description: HONG KONG, June 21 The big character posters that are proliferating day by day on the walls in Peking and other major Chinese cities are now accusing Communist party officals of seeking to stifle the revolutionary mass criticism that the party is officially encouraging.

title: Budget Under Control?
description: In this period of shaken public confidence in government, the overwhelming approval given by Senate and House to farreaching reforms in the way Congress handles Federal spending and taxes represents an impressive triumph for the legislative process.

title: Foghorns Start Race At Newport
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 21The race to Bermuda began today in fog as 166 yachts groped for the starting line off the Brenton Reef light tower. The breeze was moderate 12 knots from southsouthwest, and once under way the fleet, on starboard tack, was almost but not quite pointed for the little island in the Atlantic Ocean 635 miles away.

title: Stocks on Amex and OTC Fall Again
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market dropped again in dull trading yesterday as many investors became convinced that the end of the increase in the prime interest rate was not yet in sight.

title: The Washington Post March Macabre
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  Senator Goldwater wants The Washington Post prosecuted for printing Government information the Government doesn't want published. At first glance this seems like a good idea if you are one of those people who would just as soon not know what the Government is up toand considering what it has been up to lately, only a masochist would want to be even slightly informed.

title: House Unit Hears I.R.S. Study On Nixon Tax Was Incomplete
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The House Judiciary Committee heard today evidence that the Internal Revenue Service had closed its investigation of President Nixon for possible tax fraud on the basis of an incomplete examination of his case.

title: Second School in Bronx District Charged With Whipping Pupils
description: City School Chancellor Irving Anker yesterday asked the superintendent of Community School District 9 in the Bronx to investigate charges of corporal punishment at a second School in the district, Public School 53.

title: TwoOut Wild Peg by Maddox Leads to a 32 Setback
description: A brief, twoout, ninthinning uprising topped by aYankee throwing error turned what seemed certain victory into defeat for New York at damp Shea Stadium last night.

title: People and Business
description: Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon said yesterday that he will, visit Saudi Arabia next month to continue talks on economic and technical assistance for that nation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, June 21 (AP)The 42nation African Lawn Tennis Confederation issued an official protest today against what it termed the imminent admission of South Africa to Davis Cup competition.

title: F.P.C. AUTHORiZES RISE IN GAS PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Asserting that a national energy emergency exists and will persist, the Federal Power Commission, in what is called a landmark decision, authorized today a large increase in the ceiling price for natural gas sold in interstate commerce.

title: Art: A Prologue to. Revolution
description: WASHINGTONA time there was, Thomas Hardy wrote in one of the most somber of his poems, when all went well. At the time he had in mind, a vast protective insensibility filled the universe, so that nobody felt anything at all and pain and remorse were unknown. But to ourselves, in 1974, it may well seem that all went well just 200 years ago. At that time, Americans of every degree knew what had to be done and went right ahead and did it, quite fearlessly. Some of them may have taken precautions afterward (the population of New York was 25,000 in 1775 but dropped to 5,000 in 1776), but we all know what John Adams meant when he wrote in his diary, on the night of the Boston Tea Party, that This is the most magnificent Movement of all. There is a Dignity, a Majesty, a Sublimity in this last Effort of the Patriots that I greatly admire.

title: Calmness Descends On Franklin Bank; Business Off a Bit
description: Relative calm settled over the Franklin National Bank yesterday after days of feverish activity spent in the preparation of restated earnings and in securing a replacement for Hahold V. Gleason, the Franklin's former chief executive officer.

title: Assembly in Sikkim Approves Move to Closer Tie With India
description: NEW DELHI, June 21 The Assembly of Sikkim approved a new Constitution late last night that reduces the ruler to a titular role and associates Sikkim's political interests more closely with India's.

title: AntiSemitism Reiterated On School in Little Falls
description: Mrs. Francine Feldman said yesterday that her 14yearold daughter, Alyssa, did not attend her eighthgrade graduation ceremony Tuesday and was enrolling in a private school next year because she believes she has been the victim of antiSemitic attacks in the public school in the northern New Jersey town of Little Falls.

title: Francis Leads Way in L. I. Amateur
description: PLANDOME, L. I., June 21 Gene Francis, the defending Long Island amateur champion, hit a fine No. 7 iron tee shot within 30 feet of the pin at the par3 17th hole at Plandome Country Club today. But then he had to wait about an hour before his opponent, Louis Mattiace of Mill River, conceded the hole so that Francis could win the match, 3 and 1, and advance to the quarterfinals of the Long Island Golf Association tournament.

title: H. M. HYNES, LAWYER, IRISH LEADER HERE
description: Harry M. Hynes, a former lawyer and leader in the Irish community here, died Thursday at his home in LauderdalebytheSea, Fla. He was 89 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: WINE TALK
description: By FRANK J. PRIAL Prices on the key London market show that the wine boom has lost some of its steam. The accompanying article fills you in on that. But you don't have to go to London to get a wine bargain: prices are tumbling all over town right here in New York.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TEA AND SUCH The weekend, any weekend in summer, when many New Yorkers flee their city, is a time of uncrowded delight for others, a time for seredipity among the city's parks, restaurants and theaters, a time to stroll through what the city planners like to call the ethnic neighborhoods. These enclaves, such as the Lower East Side, Yorkville, Chinatown, Little Italy, Bay Ridge, East and West Harlem, are everchanging, adapting themselves not only to the whole of the city, but reflecting accurately changes that take place in the various countries of which they are microcosms.

title: Cab Drivers in Newark Return to Work Following a 16Day Walkout
description: NEWARK, June 21 (UPI)Cab drivers returned to work here today after a 16day driver walkout.

title: Soviet Said to Seize Jews As Nixon Visit Approaches
description: MOSCOW, June 21The Soviet authorities are rounding up Jewish activists here, apparently to forestall demonstrations during President Nixon's visit next week.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: WOMEN POLICE CHASE AND SEIZE THIEF HERE
description: Two woman police officers on their first day together as team left their patrol car in midtown yesterday to chase a thief for two blocks and seize him.

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE 1.1% IN MAY; FOOD IS UP AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Consumer prices resumed their rapid rise in May after some moderation in April, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Werker Confirmed as Judge
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 The Senate today confirmed the nomination of Henry F. Werker of Greenville, N. Y., to be a Federal District Court judge in the Southern District of New York. He has served since 1969 as surrogate and Family Court judge of Greene County, New York. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree from New York University in 1942 and earned his law degree at the New York University School of Law.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: CHRYSLER TO RAISE SHIPPING CHARGES
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday it was raising its shipping charges for cars and trucks an average of $10.08 a vehicle, effective Monday.

title: Consumer Index Up 1.1% Here Despite Decline in Meat Prices
description: An 8.2 per cent rise in the cost of produce and substantial increases in other categories of goods and services more than offset a 3.5 per cent decline in the retail prices of meats, poultry and fish in New York area last month, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: S.E.C. PROPOSES RULE ON INTEREST
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today that, for the time being at least, most corporations must charge interest payments against their balance sheets as the payments are made.

title: Willams Equals World 100Meter Mark
description: LOS ANGELES, June 21Steve Williams sped through the twilight of the longest day of the year to cover 100 meters in 9.9 seconds today, equaling the world record and winning the National Amateur Athletic Union championship for the second straight year.

title: Business Briefs
description: DEARBORN, Mich., June 21 (AP)  Ford workers 11 assembly plants will return to their jobs next week following a 10day strike at the auto maker's Chicago Heights Stamping Plant.

title: COLSON REPORTS URGING BY NIXON; GETS 1 TO 3 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Charles W. Colson was sentenced today to one to three years in prison and fined $5,000 after telling a Federal judge that President Nixon had urged him on numerous occasions to commit the acts for which he was being jailed.

title: Israelis. Tried to Hit Only Guerrilla Sites
description: EIN AL HELWEH, Lebanon, June 21The Palestinian refugees at this battered camp on the outskirts of the coastal city of Saida said today that when Israeli bombs began falling here yesterday most civilians had already heard warning sirens and fled from houses that were near buildings occupied by commandos.

title: 11% PRINIE RATE WEAKENS MARKET
description: Rising interest rates again depressed the stock market yesterday in slower trading.

title: George Katele Marries Helen Neafsey
description: Miss Helen D. Neafsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Neafsey of Lattingtown, L. I., was married last evening to George V. Katele, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kasimieras Katele of Melrose Park, Ill. The Rev. Howard Marshall Lowell performed the ceremony in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L. I.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Convicts Egan Of Cheating on Tax In His 1970 Return
description: John J. Egan, the former commanding officer of a special investigations unit of the Police Department's narcotics bureau, who had been accused of accepting money from drug peddlers, was convicted yesterday by a Federal District Court jury of falsifying his incometax return for 1970.

title: McGee, Floyd Tie In Golf
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 21The local boy made good today by catching the leader and joining him in a twoway tie for first place at the halfway point of the American Golf Classic.

title: Sadat Urges Nixon to Restrain Israelis From Raiding Lebanon
description: CAIRO, June 21 (AP)President Anwar elSadat called on President Nixon today to take a firm stand against Israel's repeated aggressions on Lebanon, the newspaper Al Akhbar reported today.

title: Dave Anderson
description: With the romance found in lawbooks and ledgers, Alan N. Cohen has defined his role as the new president Madison Square Garden.

title: One Week at School And One Week at Work
description: The end of the academic year next Wednesday can mean a lot of things besides a vacation for the 130,000 juniors and seniors in the city's public school systema frenzied and frustrating search for a summer job, for instance.

title: A New Look at the Plaza Aims at Spirit of the Old.
description: When James Lavenson's dling the Plaza Hotel's advertising agency was hanaccount, he created an advertisement that envisioned a day when New York had been entirely replaced with glass  except for the Plaza itself, that splendid 1907 French Renaissance pile that, the ad said, would always remain as it was.

title: Mrs. Bower Wins, 2 Up, For Metropolitan Title
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., June 21 She never makes a mistake. She's as steady on the course as any golfer I've ever seen. That was the comment of Charles Beverage, the club pro, after watching Mrs. Albert (Bea) Bower of Pelham win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

title: Yankee Records
Beame Copter Forced Down Off Brooklyn in Storm
description: A police helicopter carrying Mayor Beame and two aides was forced down into the Upper Bay yesterday afternoon at the height of a thunderstorm.

title: A.B.A. May Expand, Resume N.B.A. Suit
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 21  Reacting aggressively to the National Basketball Association's rejection yesterday of a merger proposal, the owners of the American Basketball Association late today made plans to go into next season with 10 teams, the same number as last season, and predicted they would establish franchises in Los Angeles, St. Louis and Cincinnati for the 197576 campaign.

title: OffDuty Officer Shot By Burglar in Bronx
description: An offduty police officer was shot and wounded in the Bronx last night in an exchange of gunfire with a suspected burglar at the home of his inlaws, the police reported.

title: South Africa Is Adopting Floating Exchange Rate
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 21 (Reuters)South Africa will adopt an independent floating exchange rate, effective Monday, a statement issued today on behalf of Finance Minister Nicholaas Diederichs said. Mr. Diederichs is currently abroad on official business.

title: British Prices Up; Strikes Cut Output
description: LONDON, June 21As labor unrest intensified throughout Britain, the Government today reported another big increase in retail prices for May.

title: The Times Sets increases In Most Advertising Rates
description: Next month The New York Times will begin to increase advertising rates in most classifications, Warren Wolfe, advertising director, announced yesterday.

title: Philippine Five Wins
description: HONOLULU, June 21 (AP)  The national basketball team of the Philippines beat a local United States Navy allstar team, 9896, in an exhibition game last night at Pearl Harbor.

title: House Unit Hears I.R.S. Study On Nixon Tax Was Incomplete
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The House Judiciary Committee heard today evidence that the Internal Revenue Service had closed its investigation of President Nixon for possible tax fraud on the basis of an incomplete examination of his case.

title: Chris Evert Favored to Score Triple
description: By JOE NICHOLS

title: Britain Is Easing Plans to Tax Foreigners Who Reside There
description: LONDON, June 21 (AP)The British Treasury announced today that the tax burden on for eigners residing in Britain would not be as great as originally proposed.

title: OnceSleepy Stamford Awakening to New Eminence
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 21 Once a sleepy little city in the heart of Connecticut's affluent Gold Coast, Stamford is now hard at work recreating the urban dream.

title: Controller Delays Reimbursing Convention Center Consultant
description: The City Controller's office has held up reimbursing the West Side convention center corporation for up to $36,164 in consulting fees paid to a realestate law firm.

title: Soviet Said to Seize Jews As Nixon Visit Approaches
description: MOSCOW, June 21The Soviet authorities are rounding up Jewish activists here, apparently to forestall demonstrations during President Nixon's visit next week.

title: Sterling Is Set for Test PayTV in Fall
description: A resolution passed by the Board of Estimate late Wednesday evening has cleared the way for one of Manhattan's two cable systems to experiment with paytelevision for twoyear period, during which it would pay the city 10 per cent of its receipts.

title: ARNIE ROSENWASSER'S Friends wish him a HAPPY 40th BIRTHDAY! Advt.
description: ARNIE ROSENWASSER'S Friends wish him a HAPPY 40th BIRTHDAY! Advt.

title: J. S. Marcus Weds Ellen M. Friedman
description: Miss Ellen M. Friedman and James S. Marcus, both of New York, were married here yesterday morning at the House of Living Judaism by Rabbi Balfour Brickner.

title: PANE WEBBER SELLS BLOCK OF STRUTHERS
description: Paine Webber Jackson & Curtis, Inc., sold a 45,700share block of Struthers Wells common stock yesterday on the American Stock Exchange evidently because a customer failed to meet a margin call.

title: The Mayor's Victory
description: New York City taxpayers have no cause to cheer the smashing victory scored by Mayor Beame this week when the City Council and Board of Estimate adopted his $11.2billion expense budget virtually intact, together with new and higher taxes to finance it. Larded with new debt and other gimmicks to achieve an illusory balance, the new budget is, as one critic put it, characterized by a high level of expediency which can only compound the city's already acute fiscal problems and lead to even more taxes in the future.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Robert C. Sellerole, a former Commissioner of the Bergen County Sewer Authority, was sentenced in New York City to two years in prison for his part in a kickback scheme involving the deposit of authority funds in a Manhattan bank. Judge Edward Weinfeld, noting that bribery by a public ofifcial is a violation of the public trust, imposed the sentence on the charges of bribery and perjury in the Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Bicycle Thieves
description: The murder of a 36yearold magazine illustrator last week while testing his new bicycle in Central Park the most shocking of a mounting wave this year bicycle robberies in the city's parks and streets.

title: How the Teams Stand Today
description: Saturday, June 22, 1974

title: TwoOut Wild Peg by Maddox Leads to a 32 Setback
description: A brief, twoout, ninthinning uprising topped by a Yankee throwing error turned what seemed certain victory into defeat for New York at damp Shea Stadium last night.

title: U.S. DROPS OFFER OF MIGRANT HOMES
description: After offering New Jersern 72 modern mobile homes for migrant farm workers two weeks ago, the Federal Government has suddenly rescinded the offer, citing legal complications,

title: Jaworski Is Called Unfair In Nixon's Brief to Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The White House accused Leon Jaworski today of interweaving the Watergate criminal prosecutions and Congressional imIpeachment proceedings in a way that was manifestly unlfair to President Nixon.

title: CORN, SOYBEANS RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Most corn and soybean contracts closed up the daily limit on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday amid a rush of buying orders. The buying of contracts was attributed to the heavy rains over Illinois and a forecast of more rain over the weekend.

title: At the Northernmost Front, Vietnam's CeaseFire Is Almost Real
description: QUANG TRI, South Vietnam, June 15Stripped to their underwear, four soldiers cannonballed off the gnarled wreckage of the bridge into the flat, clean water of the Thach Han River Their laughter wafted across the river, where two Vietcong soldiers  the enemy were squatting at the water's edge, washing.

title: Racing Tax Reported
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., June 21 (AP)  The eight states that conduct greyhound racing collected $72.4million in tax revenue last year, the National Association of State Racing Commissioners reported today. Florida, with its 1,748 days of racing, topped the list with $39.4million in tax revenue on attendance of 7.7 million and a mutuel turnover of $534.2million.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE INSIDER'S GUIDE TO ANTIQUES, ART AND COLLECTIBLES. By Sylvia O'Neill Dorn. 334 pares. Doubleday. $7.95.

title: EDWARD YORDAN, 71, ENGLISH PROFESSOR
description: Edward L. Yordan, a former New York Times reporter who turned to teaching traffic safety and later became an English professor, died Thursday in Titusville, Fla., where he lived. His age was 71.

title: JEAN WAHL DIES; EXISTENTIALIST, 88
description: PARIS, June 21Jean Wahl, existentialist philosopher and poet, died here Wednesday. He was 88 years old and was on the faculty of the Sorbonne.

title: Foghorns Start Race At Newport
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 21The race to Bermuda began today in fog as 166 yachts groped for the starting line off the Brenton Reef light tower. The breeze was a moderate 12 knots from southsouthwest, and once under way the fleet, on starboard tack, was almost but not quite pointed for the little island in the Atlantic Ocean 635 miles away.

title: L.I. Told Oil and Fish Are Compatible
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., June 21The Governor of Louisiana arrived here today with state officials, four chefs and 30 crates of fish to deliver the message that the two biggest industries in my stateoil and fish are very compatable.

title: 10 Seized in Drug Raids
description: CAMDEN, June 21 (UPI)Seven persons have been arrested on drug charges in two separate raids conducted by the Camden County Narcotics Strike Force. A third raid on a home in Camden early today led to the confiscation of $10,000 worth of marijuana and the arrests of Francis Fabian, 23 years old of Pennsauken and Anthony Johnson 23, and Joanne Cox, both of Camden.

title: 2 BIG BANKS RAISE THEIR PRIME RATES
description: The First National City Bank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company yesterday increased their minimum lending rates to large corporate borrowers to 11 per cent from 11 per cent.

title: A Report Finds Scientific Knowledge Has Declined Among Pupils in U.S.
description: MIAMI, June 21The scientific knowledge of American elementary and secondary school students declined over a recent threeyear period, according to a report released today the Federal Government's National Assessment of Educational Progress.

title: LAWRENCE G. SEIBLE
description: Lawrence G. Seible, who had been a management executive with the Hilton Hotels Corporation for many years, died Tuesday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 55 years old and formerly lived here.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Reformed Church in America, meeting in Hempstead, L.I., took a major step yesterday toward sanctioning the ordination of women as ministers. By a voice vote of the 300 delegates, the denomination's general synod pro posed that the church's Book of Church Order make specific provision for ordaining women by using the phrase, men and women, where appropriate, instead of person, which in practice encompassed only men. The synod's action can not become final before next year's meeting.

title: N.B.A. Adds Toronto, Without Owner
description: A pro basketball team is returning to Toronto, the site of the first major professional game 28 years ago.Toronto. My dealings have been through Paul Snyder [owner of the Buffalo Braves]. We are very friendly and work together on deals and he is looking after my interests. All he has to tell me is how much money I have to post for a bond and I'll give him the money.

title: Miss Palmer's 66 for 140 Leads Golf by 2 Strokes
description: SUTTON, Mass., June 21 (AP)Sandra Palmer went on a birdie spree today and set a women's course record of 66, seven under par, in charging into the halfway lead in the rainsplashed $50,000 Ladies Professional Golfers' Association championship.

title: STATE SUES TO GET POLLUTION FUNDS
description: TRENTON, June 21  New Jersey filed suit in Federal Court here today seeking to force the United States Environmental Protection Agency to release $752million in waterpollutioncontrol funds that were impounded on President Nixon's order.

title: Dance: Armenians Present Armenians
description: One of the extraordinary aspects about last night's opening at Carnegie Hall of the Armenian State Dance Ensemble from the Soviet Union is that the troupe is being presented on its first tour of the United States by representatives of the ArmenianAmerican comunity.

title: Metreveli, Smith Gain Tennis Final
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 21 (AP)Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., and Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union advanced to the final of the $100,000 John Player tennis tournament today.

title: Jury Convicts Egan Of Cheating on Tax In His 1970 Return
description: John J. Egan, the former commanding officer of a special investigations unit of the Police Department's narcotics bureau, who had been accused of accepting money from drug peddlers, was convicted yesterday by a Federal District Court jury of falsifying his incometax return for 1970.

title: PREIS IS FINED; TERM SUSPENDED
description: NEWARK, June 21William H. Preis, the government's key witness in the case against the former state Republican chaircan, Nelson G. Gross, was given a twoyear suspended sentence and a $10,000 fine for perjury by a Federal District Court judge today.

title: BOSTON'S SCHOOLS HELD SEGREGATED
description: BOSTON, June 21  In a sweeping decision, Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. ruled today that Boston's schools were racially segregated and ordered the city to dismantle the dual system forthwith.

title: Ford as the President: Some Hard Questions
description: DURHAM, N. C.Gerald R. Ford is considered likely to be President of the United States soon. What kind of President will he be? A plastic genial Gerry on the Warren G. Harding model, ready to bend with whatever wind is strongest? A Trumantype straightshooter from middle America?

title: 4 Muslims in Store Siege Are Convicted of Murder
description: Four young Muslims were found guilty last night of murder, kidnapping, robbery and other charges growing out of the January, 1973, holdup of a Brooklyn sportinggoods store in which a policeman was killed and a dozen persons were held hostage over a threeday ordeal.

title: MAN SHOT TO DEATH IN ILLINOIS HOSPITAL
description: BERWYN, III., June 21 (AP) A man was shot to death in hospital when a fight that began in a tavern erupted again when the participants met in the emergency room.

title: Boston Told to Integrate
description: A Federal judge has ruled that Boston maintains racially segregated schools and ordered the city to eliminate every form of racial segregation in the school system as quickly as possible, if necessary, by busing. Page 13.

title: GEORGE CARR LEIB; LED BANKING HOUSE
description: George Carr Leib, who retired as board chairman of Blyth & Co., Inc., a major investment banking house, in 1966, died Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 71 East 71st Street.

title: Italy's Opening To Despair
description: RICHMOND, Va.The present Italian crisis has been the worst since World War II. The economy remains on the brink of collapse; the system of law and order has broken down; the curious formula of administering the state with a nongovernment or, in fact, virtually without government has reached a dead end; and the tentative groping for compromise between the two main ideological groups, Catholics and Communists, has ceased.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: Notes on People
description: Helen Delich Bentley, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, denounced yesterday as absolutely ridiculous and untrue reports that maritime lawyers and shipping interests had been solicited for funds to help her run for Senator from Maryland.

title: British Laborites See Gain in Defeats
description: LONDON, June 21  Two Labor party Members of Parliament returned to a dinner party on Wednesday night after slipping out to vote in the House of Commons for a Government proposal. They left the House before the final tally and earned only later that the Labor Government had suffered its first major defeat since the election last February.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 20yearold convicted rapist who posed as a deliveryman to gain entry into his victims apartments was sentenced to 75 years in prison. In State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Justice Alfred M. Ascione imposed consecutive 25year sentences on two rape counts and a 25year term for firstdegree robbery on Marvin Edwards, a wiry, mediumsized man.

title: Beame Copter Forced Down Off Brooklyn in Storm
description: A police helicopter carrying Mayor Beame and two aides was forced down into the Upper Bay yesterday afternoon at the height of a thunderstorm.

title: STATE BACKS GIRL LACKING A CREDIT
description: The, State Commissioner of Education ruled yesterday that 17yearold Roseann O'Brien of Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I., should receive her diploma and take part in the graduation of her class even though she lacks a quarter of a credit for a gym course she had to drop to undergo surgery for a spinal deformity.

title: 3 ExNarcotics Detectives Guilty of Stealing $4,500
description: Three former narcoticssquad detectives were convicted by a State Supreme Court fury in the Bronx late Thursday night of stealing $4,500 from the wife of a man they had arrested. They face up to seven years' imprisonment.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Page 31

title: FREEHOLDER PLAN STIRS STATE UNIT
description: CHERRY HILL, June 21The beginning of what may be the end of a 300yearold form of local freeholder's government in New Jersey was heatedly debated today by officials attending the annual conference of the state's Association of Chosen Freeholders.

title: May Orders Soared For Durable Goods
description: WASHINGTON, June 21New orders for durable goods surged in May, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 7 Elderly Women Join Police LineUp to Aid Case Against Confidence Suspect
description: For Mrs. Louise Esposito, a little, grayhaired woman from Woodside, Queens, it was the first time she had ever been in a police station. Along with six other elderly women, she had answered an appeal by the police to help her community and an elderly victim of a confidence swindle.

title: TV: Youth
description: One of the more glaring television ironies these days is that local commercial stations, pressured by specialinterest groups, are devoting more coverage to minorities than the publicTV stations, which are becoming more interested in the middleclass viewer capable of sending in annual subscription donations. A good example of the commercialTV venture can be found on WABCTV tonight at 7.

title: U.S. Scores Canada For Refusal to Hold Talks on Beef Ban
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI)Canada's reported refusal to compromise Wednesday on terms for lifting a ban on American beef imports is very, disappointing and could escalate into a. United StatesCanadian trade war, a top Agriculture Department official indicated today.

title: Noise Control Rules Planned
description: WASHINGTON, une 21 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency says it plans to propose noise control standards for mediumand heavyduty trucks and for portable air compressors, two of the major sources of city noise.

title: ArabIsraeli Talks A re Reported Put Off To Late Fall to Allow for Consultations
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The United States, Israel and the Arab nations have agreed to put off until the late fall any further ArabIsraeli negotiations for a Middle East peace settlement, American officials said today.

title: Pro Transactions BASEBALL
description: ST. LOUIS (NL)Signed David Boyer, third baseman; William Caudill, William Cowens, Leonard Strelitz, Cam Bonitay, Scott Boras and Leslie Weber.

title: Chase Bank Announces Loan to Egyptian Unit
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday its London subsidiary had arranged an $50million nineyearloan for the Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation. Chase said the money would gotoward financing the SuezMediterranean pipeline.

title: Unity on Presidency of Council Eludes White Plains Democrats
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 21 Earlier this week the Republicans lost control of the White Plains Common Council in a special election called to end a state of legislative confusion and paralysis. Last night the victorious Democrats indicated that the situation may not have changed much.

title: OnceSleepy Stamford Awakening to New Eminence
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 21 Once a sleepy little city in the heart of Connecticut's affluent Gold Coast, Stamford is now hard at work recreating the urban dream.

title: Electronic Controls Devised for SelfService Gasoline Stations
description: WASHINGTON, June 21A very small crew, including women, can now operate a large selfservice gasoline station. The Lockheed Electronics Company, Inc., Plainfield, N. J., received a patent this week for an electronic calculator and control system that keeps track of what the customers pump into their cars or trucks, and displays the amounts they owe. Four Lockheed engineersElmer C. Anderson, John Dow Jr., William B. Gutman and William A. Oetting  were granted patent 3,818,192. The company has sold 300 of the control and readout units, which are in use mostly in California and the Southwest.

title: 500 View U.S. Art at Moscow Embassy
description: MOSCOW, June 21  Ambassador and Mrs. Walter J. Stoessel Jr., Wednesday opened their official residence here, Spaso House, to an exhibition of American paintings from classical studies of American Indians to bright, coloristic modern abstractions.

title: 2 KISSINGER DEALS REPORTED TO AID RUSSIANS ON ARE
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Secretary of State Kissinger, without informing Congress, made at least two secret arrangements with Soviet leaders in 1972 on the number of strategic nuclear missiles on each side, Administration officials said today.

title: Theater: A Robert Wilson at Spoleto
description: SPOLETO, Italy, June 21Robert Wilson continues to amaze. His A Letter for Queen Victoria, which has just had its world premiere at the Spoleto Festival, is a further example of his ability to enchant, intrigue, stimulate, puzzle and disorient his public.

title: The Gernreich Fragrance
description: The newest perfume to sniff is called Rudi Gernreich. It's housed in a long, skinny chemical beaker, it costs $40 for 30 milliliters and it is a mixture of leather, civet, musk, floral and some 21 other chemically reproduced scents.

title: 6 Offices Will Handle Inquiries on Tax Plan
description: TRENTON, June 21 (AP)The Byrne administration announced today that it was settting up six regional offices to handle inquiries about the Governor's incometax program.

title: MRS. GEOFFREY PLATT
description: Mrs. Helen Coate Platt, wife of Geoffrey Platt, architect and former chairman of the City Landmarks Preservation Commission, died yesterday of heart attack at her home in Mount Kisco, N. Y. She was 67 years old.

title: Susan Coons Is Bride Of Thomas De Leone
description: In a ceremony at the home of her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Rothschild of Woodmere, L. I., Miss Susan Margaret Coons, a physicaleducation teacher in Columbus, Ohio, was married to Thomas De Leone, who plays professional football for the Cincinnati Ben

title: Art: Intimacy and the Infinite
description: It is exactly 20 years since Pat Adams first showed her paintings in a solo exhibition in New York. She has had frequent exhibitions, both in New York and elsewhere, during this time, yet her art always has the quality of a surprise. She works, for the most part, in small formats a surface measuring 6 by 14 inches is not in the least uncongenial to her giftsyet the abstract images that are concentrated in these small spaces suggest something vast.

title: WEST SIDE DETOUR LEADS TO SNARLS
description: The first day of Mayor Beame's new plan for speeding West Side Highway repairs and improving traffic flow was characterized yesterday by snarled traffic and community complaints that the emergency repair program was still too slow.

title: BEAME TO RETURN TO SIGN TAX BILLS
description: Mayor Beame will interrupt! a California trip to return tot the city next Thursday to sign new tax laws that will go into effect July 1, his office said yesterday. He will then fly back, to California.

title: POLICE SLAYER GETS A 35YEAR SENTENCE
description: Robert Hayes, a 23yearold reputed member of the Black Liberation Army, was sentenced yesterday to 35 years to life in prison for murdering a Transit Authority policeman and stealing his gun.

title: British Prices Up; Strikes Cut Output
description: LONDON, June 21As labor unrest intensified throughout Britain, the Government today reported another big increase in retail prices for May.

title: POLICE SAY YOUTH EXPLODED 2 BOMBS
description: SOMERVILLE, June 21 (UPI) Juvenile charges have been filed against a 17yearold youth who allegedly exploded two homemade bombs disguised as transistor radios in the cafeteria of the Ridge High School in Barnards Township.

title: Braves Down Reds Behind Morton, 10
description: Los Angeles got off to such a fast start in the National League this season that it has left the Cincinnati Reds playing Ahab to the Dodgers' great white whale of the West.

title: NIXON TAPES DENIED 2 INDIANS ON TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, June 21 (UPI)Federal Judge Fred Nichol turned down yesterday a request by Russell Means and Dennis Banks, leaders of the American Indian Movement, to order a subpoena of White House tapes.

title: Girl Vies to Be Atlantic City Lifeguard
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 21 (AP)A 17yearold girl who wants to be a doctor has made a strong bid to become this resort's first female lifeguard.

title: Police Defer Bid for Bullet In Slaying Suspect's Chest
description: The Police Department decided last night not to press at this time for the removal of a bullet lodged in the chest of a suspect in the murder of an offduty lieutenant in Queens on Thursday.

title: Oil Effects Manageable, Adviser to Reserve Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 21A top Federal Reserve Board economist said today that the unusual world financial problem raised by the explosion of oil prices was manageable for most countries in the world.

title: It's Called, Naturally, The String
description: Is Jones Beach ready for it? The latest bikini is nothing but a pair of triangles held together with strings for the top, and two slightly larger ones for the bottom. It's called the String and makes most other bikinis look like Mother Hubbards.

title: Gesell Sets Hearing on Ehrlichman Plea for White House Notes
description: WASHINGTON, June. 21  Judge Gerhard A. Gesell called today for a hearing Monday on another request by attorneys for John D. Ehrlichman seeking access to personal White House notes of Presidential conversations.

title: Series of Rocket Firings Delayed by Poor Weather
description: A series of more than 50 rocket firings from Wallops Island, Va., that had been scheduled for the 24hour period beginning shortly after noon today have again been postponed because of poor weather prospects.

title: Boston Told to Integrate
description: A Federal judge has ruled that Boston maintains racially segregated schools and ordered the city to eliminate every form of racial segregation in the school system as quickly as possible, if necessary, by busing. Page 13.

title: Italy's Opening To Despair
description: RICHMOND, Va.The present Italian crisis has been the worst since World War II. The economy remains on the brink of collapse; the system of law and order has broken down; the curious formula of administering the state with a nongovernment or, in fact, virtually without government has reached a dead end; and the tentative groping for compromise between the two main ideological groups, Catholics and Communists, has ceased.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Israel Facing Some Hard Facts
description: JERUSALEM, June 21It has taken a few days to sink in, but most Israelis now seem to recognize the significance of the Nixon visit to the Middle East and the dramatic opening to the Arab world that it represents. The sight of an American President being warmly welcomed in four Arab capitals has brought home the realization that major changes are taking place in the geopolitics of the Middle East changes to which Israel will be forced to adapt.

title: R. J. CETTENS DEAD; CURATOR AT FREER
description: Rutherford J. Gettens, an art expert who over the last several decades had played a major role in determining the authenticity of works of art, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Mooers, N. Y., on Monday. He was 74 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Willams Equals World 100Meter Mark
description: LOS ANGELES, June 21Steve Williams sped through the twilight of the longest day of the year to cover 100 meters in 9.9 seconds today, equaling the world record and winning the National Amateur Athletic Union championship for the second straight year.

title: TransCanadian Gas Route Is Reevaluated by Morton
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 21 (AP)  Interior Secretary Rogers C.B. Morton says he is reevaluating his support for a transCanadian routing of natural gas from Alaska's North Slope.

title: BUDGET OVERHAUL PASSED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 The Senate approved a landmark bill today giving Congress new machinery for dealing with the Federal budget and deciding how to spend the money.

title: Wilton Manhoff, 56, Dies; Wrote Owl and Pussycat
description: LOS ANGELES, June 21 (UPI) Wilton Manhoff, a stage, and television writer perhaps best known for his Broadway play, The Owl and the Pussycat, died Tuesday at the age of 56. He leaves his mother and a sister.

title: Prosecutor Reported to Find 26 in CoverUp Plot
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 The special Watergate prosecutors have decided that a least 26 persons, ranging from President Nixon to the original Watergate burglars, conspired to cover up the Watergate breakin, a number of sources disclosed today.

title: Plea Bargaining Debate
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The growing debate over the plea bargaining between Leon Jaworski and the Watergate criminals points up one of the oldest and most troublesome features of the criminal justice systemthe vast amount of power given to prosecutors, partly by necessity and partly by default, and the difficulty in assuring that prosecutors do not abuse that power.

title: Notes on People
description: Helen Delich Bentley, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, denounced yesterday as absolutely ridiculous and untrue reports that maritime lawyers and shipping interests had been solicited for funds to help her run for Senator from Maryland.

title: I.C.C. May Force Rails Into Buying Freight Cars
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission threatened today to force most of the nation's major railroads to buy a total of 70,000 new freight cars to alleviate a persistent freight car shortage.

title: Milner Clouts Two As Ailing Seaver Gets Victory
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 21The Mets are streaking, baby! So sounded the joy in the Mets locker room tonight after they had beaten the Philadelphia Phillies, 31, on three home runs, two by John Milner and one by Rusty Staub. The victory, the second in a row, helped New York jab its needle a little farther into the firstplace Phils' bubble. Three games are lift in the series.

title: 8 STATES' PLANS ACCEPTED BY H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Desegregation plans for statecontrolled colleges and universities in eight states were approved today by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, averting a cutoff of Federal funds.

title: Excerpts From Briefs Filed for Nixon and Jaworski
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Following are excerpts from briefs filed in the Supreme Court today by President Nixon's attorneys and by the special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, on the issues of whether the President must surrender 64 tape recordings and whether the Watergate grand jury had authority to name Mr. Nixon as an unindicted coconspirator:

title: ...Also at a Christie's Auction in London
description: LONDON, June 21  With the rap of a gavel on his elevated podium, the auctioneer calmly sold a dozen bottles of Chateau LafiteRothschild 1955 for $23 each, and scarcely an eyelash flickered in the highceilinged auction room at Christie, Manson and Woods.

title: Flying Manhole Covers Hurt 6 In Brooklyn Sewer Explosion
description: Six persons were slightly intired yesterday afternoon in a rapid series of sewer explosions in Brooklyn's East New York section that sent 40 manhole covers as high as two stories in the air.

title: LAWYER REPORTS BODYDEAL OFFER
description: An upstate District Attorney said yesterday that one of the lawyers for a man on trial for murder in Lake Pleasant, N. Y., told him last Sept. 7 that he had located two bodies and that he would give us the locations of the bodies in return for our accepting a plea of manslaughter seconddegree.

title: Scholars Question Dating of Old Japanese Porcelains
description: Scholars here and in Japan are, raising questions about the dating and origin of many Japanese porcelains, the brilliantly decorated ceramic wares treasured for the inventiveness of their designs by museums and private collectors for decades and now being sold for tens of thousands of dollars.

title: Bridge: 3Team Zonal Playoff Event Will Begin Today in Boston
description: A threeteam zonal playoff will begin today in Boston, with the winners scheduled to compete here next month it the auarterfinal stage of the Grand National Team Championship.

title: McGee, Floyd Tie In Golf
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 21The local boy made good today by catching the leader and joining him in a twoway tie for first place at the halfway point of the American Golf Classic.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NORTHVALE, June 21Because Gay Mayer is the kind of man who won't renege on anything, he's working to give away $100,000.

title: House Votes $13.4Billion Omnibus Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The House of Representatives passed tonight a $13.4billion appropriations bill for agriculture environmental and consumer protection programs, but cut back on food funds for Southeast Asia anddropped college students from the food stamp program.

title: DEBT MORATORIUM DECLARED BY ROME
description: ROME, June 21The City of Rome stopped paying interest today for its mountainous debts in a decision highlighting the disarray of public finances in Italy.

title: Metreveli, Smith Gain Tennis
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 21 (AP)Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S. C., and Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union advanced to the final of the $100,000 John Player tennis tournament today.

title: DOLLAR IS STRONGER; PRICE OF GOLD RISES
description: BRUSSELS, June 21 (UPI)The dollar showed strength today and the price of gold climbed back from a fourmonth low. The dollar faltered at the opening of most money markets but went into an upward trend at weekend closings. A Belgian banking source said the favorable United States trade balance and expectation that the prime interest rate in the United States would now remain at the 11 per cent level shored up the dollar.

title: F.P.C. AUTHORIZES RISE IN GAS PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Asserting that a national energy emergency exists and Will persist, the Federal Power Commission, in what is called landmark decision, authorized today a large increase in the ceiling price for natural gas sold in interstate commerce.

title: World Bank Sets Up A Saudi Bond Issue
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)  The InternatiOnal Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) anhounced today it had arranged for a bond issue in Saudi Arabian currency for the equivalent of $140.8million.

title: Efforts to Stop Whaling Stir Backlash in Japan
description: TOKYO, June 21Pressure by foreign conservation groups to stop Japan from whaling has provoked an angry nationalistic backlash among Japenese and raised charges that Japan is being made the victim of emotional attacks.

title: Mrs. Kennedy in Sanitarium
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) Mrs. Edward M. Kennedy has returned to the Silver Hill Foundation in Connecticut for another week of treatment for emotional strain, her husband's office confirmed today.

title: 2 KISSINGER DEALS REPORTED TO AID RUSSIANS ON ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Secretary of State Kissinger, without informing Congress, made at least two secret arrangements with. Soviet leaders in 1972 on the number of strategic nuclear missiles on each side, Administration officials said today.

title: Market Place: Sucrest: How Sweet It Is
description: The Sucrest Corporation, a company whose earnings have fluctuated widely in the past, reflecting changes in sugar prices, has suddenly struck it rich againor so it appears.

title: State Thruway, After 20 Good Years Finds Finances Taking a Bad Curve
description: SAUGERTIES, N.Y., June 21,  Boosters called the. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway the world's greatest highway. Critics called it Dewey's Upstate Boulevard and a billiondollar pot of political patronage.

title: Celebrity Candidates of Governing Party Running Hardin Japan
description: OKAWA, Japan, June 16One elderly woman wept, a housewife swooned, and all along the route thousands of people rushed out into the street to see and touch the diminutive candidate, running her first race for public office.

title: Bridal for Joan Hull And W. Dale Kelly
description: Miss Joan Hull, a merchandising manager for fiber products at the Celanese Corporation, was married here last evening to W. Dale Kelly, Eastern zone manager for the consumer products division of Magnavox in Teterboro, N. J. The Rev. El ice Higginbotham of the United Church of Christ performed the ceremony at the Princeton Club of New York.

title: Anthony Dancers Bring Out Intensity Of Strong Rooms
description: Anna Sokolow's Rooms has a hot, lonely intensity all its own that was needlessly intensified in the hot airless atmosphere of New York University's temporarily unairconditioned School of education auditorium. Mary Anthony's Dance Theater presented Rooms on Thursday evening along with her own Antiphon and Daniel Maloney's Four Glances, receiving its first performance.

title: Trying Time for Sugar Farmers
description: ON BAYOU LAFOURCHE, La.  Louis leaned against a car and peered through the open window, squinting against the sun.

title: Milner Clouts Two As Ailing Seaver Gets Victory
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 21The Mets are streaking, baby! So sounded the joy in the Mets locker room tonight after they had beaten the Philadelphia Phillies, 31, on three home runs, two by John Milner and one by Rusty Staub. The victory, the second in a row, helped New York jab its needle a little farther into the firstplace Phils' bubble. Three games are left in the series.

title: Inflation Gauge
description: Announcement yesterday that the cost of living took another sharp jump in May punctured the fatuous hope of the Administration that the ending of Federal wageprice controls would not lead to a new burst of price increases. Supermarket prices for food have started back uphill despite lower prices at wholesale. The cost of medical care, clothing and used cars is also climbing.

title: Iceland's Capital Warmed by Geothermal Energy
description: Reykjavik, Iceland, has become the first city in the world to be heated almost entirely by geothermal energy and, in view of soaring fuel costs, other Icelandic communities are rapidly following suit.

title: Miss Du Bois Bride on L.I.
description: Miss Ariantje Du Bois, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Du Bois of Oyster Bay Cove, L. L, was married there yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Bole Eddison, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Eddison, of Lexington, Mass., and Mount Desert, Me.

title: HealthCare Gamble Pays Off
description: PATERSON  A $500,000 gamble that health care for residents of Paterson's inner city could be rendered at a profit is paying off.

title: West German Cabaret Satirizes Nazi Era
description: BERLIN, June 22  Airraid sirens started wailing at the beginning of June at the Reich Cabaret in West Berlin.

title: Busby Has Tendonitis
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 22 (UPI)  Steve Busby, who pitched his second career nohitter last Wednesday against Milwaukee, returned home today suffering with tendonitis of the wrist. The Kansas City Royalsapos; righthander was scheduled to pitch Monday night in Kansas City against the Braves, but now may miss a turn.

title: Blue Cross
description: In the 1960's it was fashionable, for a while, to believe that the American health care system was basically sound but had just neglected the poor and the elderly. We observed that in this most affluent of nations, the poor were likelier to be sick, the sick were likelier to be poor, and the poor grew sicker while the sick grew poorer. We recognized that the middle class could no longer afford to pay for its aging parents' hospital and medical bills.

title: All Hands On Deck for Cup Trials
description: NEWPORT, R. L, June 22 The 12Meter racing yacht, a technological marvel, must still be sailed by man. That fundamental will be reasserted in this summer's America's Cup competition, the first phase of which begins here Monday. This threemonth cup campaign will be a people event, matching sharply contrasting backgrounds, philosophies and styles in conflict at sea.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: Joy Williams Bride
description: Miss Joy Williams, a novelist, and Rust Hills, an author and a former editor of Esquire magazine, were married yesterday afternoon in Stonington, Conn. Justice of the Peace Henrietta Mayer performed the ceremony at her home. The bride, author of State of Grace, published by Doubleday & Co., is a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. W. Lloyd Williams of Old Saybrook, Conn. Her father is a retired Congregational minister. Mr. Hills's parents are the late Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Rust Hills of Brooklyn.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Prices on the. New York Stock Exchange last week continued in the doldrums. Trading was slow as investors' concern over high interest rates weakened the market.

title: Half the fun of writing this critique was becoming totally immersed in the subject matter.
description: THE ASSIGNMENT was the same as hundreds of others I've had in the past. I was to write a critical evaluation on a given subject.

title: Little League Baseball Proving Just a First Step for Girl Athletes
description: When girls muscled their way on to Little League baseball teams in New Jersey this spring, a lot of middleaged men in windbreakers caught a glimpse of the future and didn't like what they saw.

title: Mendlovitz Appointed Head Of Institute of World Order
description: The appointment of. Saul H. Mendlovitz as president of the Institute for World Order, 11 West 42d Street, was announced yesterday by C. Douglas Dillon, the institute's board chairman.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE UNITED STATES balanceofpayments surplus in the first quarter of 1974 was a record $2.1billion. Revised figures indicate that last year's basic balance payments was in a deficit position of $744million instead of a surplus of $1.2billion, as reported earlier.... Franklin National Bank reported a loss of $63.6million for the first five months of 1974. Joseph W. Barr, a former. Secretary of the Treasury, was named chief executive officer to replace Harold V. Gleason, who becomes executive vice president.

title: The Lake
description: Japanese tea gardens are seldom large, but many elements in them conspire, to give you a sense of spaciousness and to keep you from racing through them. The stepping stones, for instance, are often of irregular sizes and shapes, and they are placed so as to impede your progress. You are forced to pause for an instant, look up and enjoy a particular view.

title: House Lift
description: When architect Subhash Paranjpe and his wife, a research biologist, went househunting in the Washington, D.C., suburbs, they were not after looks or status, but a solid, comfortable place to live. The sturdy, brickandclapboard nineteenthirties house in Chevy Chase that they finally settled on was unpretentious, a typical middleclass development house (see below right). And too small. But the price was right ($45,000), and so was the commuting (15 minutes to downtown Washington). They painted the garage doors bright red and ignored the rest of the undistinguished exterior. But insidewell, that was different. There was a general facelifting with fresh paint. And an addition, including a deck, to the living room, which increased their downstairs living area by a third. The cost of the changescosmetic and structural: $19,000. (If he had not acted as his own contractor, it would have cost twice as much.)

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TOMORROW

title: The Battle of Warren: Racket Over a Rocket
description: WARREN, N. H., is a speck of a town in a corner of the White Mountain National Forest about a dozen miles from the Vermont border. In the old days, if you were driving too fast, you were liable to pass through and miss the town altogether. Warren has a charming white Methodist church in its center. Built back in 1818, it's picturepostcard material. Nowadays, if you're driving too fast,, you might miss the church; there's a 70foothigh Redstone missile in front of it.

title: A Sovereign People
description: The White House has now carried its stonewalling defense against impeachment to the Supreme Court. The President's lawyer, James D. St. Clair, challenges both the Federal grand jury's authority to name President Nixon as an unindicted coconspirator and the special prosecutor's right to demand the White House tapes needed for his investigation. He supports that challenge with the argument that the court process is being used as a discovery tool for the impeachment proceedingsproceedings which the Constitution clearly assigns the Congress, not the courts.

title: Ann Nemiah Married to James Conway
description: Miss Ann Keith Nemiah, daughter of Mrs. John C. Nemiah of Belmont, Mass., and Dr. Nemiah, chief of psychiatry at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston and professor of psychiatry at the Harvard Medical School, was married yesterday afternoon to James B. Conway, son of William E. Conway, president of the Nashua Corporation, and Mrs. Conway of Nashua, N. H.

title: John P. Bininger 2d Weds Mrs. Forbes
description: Mrs. Sondra Simone Forbes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Simone of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married there yesterday afternoon to John Pedder Bininger 2d, an independent marketing analyst in New York. Ho is the son of Mr. Bininger of Essex, Conn., and the late Mrs. Virginia Clark Bininger.

title: Epilogue
description: Dr. Howard B. Levy, a former Army doctor who opposed the war in Vietnam, has lost his appeal of a courtmartial conviction for refusing to conduct a training program for Special Forces medical aid men.

title: Putting Antiques Out to Pasture
description: HARDNOSED bargain hunters, incurable hobbyists, unabashed antiques addicts. Three times a year 9,000 of them make the pilgrimage to a 30acre cow pasture in southwestern Massachusetts for Gordon Reid's Famous Antiques Flea Market. Few leave emptyhanded.

title: Private Bus Lines Will Get Subsidies
description: Several private bus lines operating in Queens will receive city and state subsidies to preserve the 35cent fare, marking the first time that private bus operations have received direct fiscal aid from the state or city.

title: STATES EASING MARIJUANA LAWS
description: Call it pot, grass, ganja or Nary Jane, marijuana is still marijuana. And more than a decade after being discovered by the middle class, it appears to have gained a wide acceptance, even though it is still illegal.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: A Brittany Is Best at Rhinebeck
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y., June 22The Brittany is the only spaniel that points his game. Today, at the MidHudson Kennel Club's 31st dog show. on the Dutchess County Fair Grounds, a Britt pointed his way to the bestinshow trophy, leading a field of 1,463.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Fairfield, Fairfield County Hunt Club, Long Lots Road, Westport, Conn. Regular, green, amateurowner and junior working hunters; amateurowner and junior jumpers, ponies, equitation. 10 A.M.

title: Smokeless Shopping Order
description: MIAMI, June 22 (UPI)Beginning July 18, smokers in Dade County will have to do their grocery shopping without their cigarets, cigars or pipes. The county's metro commission has voted unanimously to ban smoking in food stores.

title: 6 Youths Flee Detention Unit
description: Six youths, 14 to 16 years old, escaped yesterday from the Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx. They all were awaiting court action on their cases at the facility at 1221 Spofford Avenue. They were last seen at breakfast, wearing blue dilngarees and white Tshirts.

title: Kissinger Going to Madrid Next Month to Sign Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (Reuters) Secretary of State Kissinger will go to Madrid next month to sign a joint United StatesSpanish declaration of principles parallel to the agreement reached by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization earlier this week, the State Department said today.

title: Scotland Eliminated In Soccer on 11 Tie
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 22  Scotland's soccer team had a sad story to tell here tonight. The Scots were eliminated from the World Cup even though they hadn't lost a game and had goal, scored, by Yugoslavia allowed only one goal. That tonight, tied the Scots and sent them home.

title: Joan Andrews Is Bride
description: Miss Joan Andrews, who was graduated this month from Ohio Wesleyan University, was married yesterday afternoon to Willard Lee Hays, a student at the Ohio State University College of Dental and Oral Surgery. The Rev. Earl Eisenbach performed the ceremony in the bridal chapel of the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont, N.Y. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Houghton Andrews of Eastchester, N.Y. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard C. Hayes of Columbus, Ohio.

title: MARGARETE SCHWABE
description: Dr. Margarete Scharte Schwabe, a general practitioner on the staffs of Sydenham Hospital and the Ithaca Medical Clinic here, died Friday on q visit to Boston. She was 57 years old and lived at 350 Central Park West.

title: Mary Wells Anderson Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Miss Mary Wells Anderson to Jeffrey E. Reichel has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Anderson of New Canaan, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr: and Mrs. Eugene L. Reichel of Wayzata, Minn., and Sanibel Island, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: Nicole Sudrow Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Hopper of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hopper's daughter, Miss Nicole Alexandra Sudrow, to Patrick J. Neilan, son of Mrs. John F. Neilan of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. Neilan. Miss Sudrow was presented in 1963 at the International Debutante Ball and and at the annual dinner dance of the St. Nicholas Society.

title: 7 Are Attendants For Miss Leeds At Her Wedding
description: Miss Constance Brecker Leeds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Henry Leeds of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to William Lauriston Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Franklin Bennett of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Chris Evert Wins Oaks for Triple Crown
Wilson Veto Stirs Debate On Role of Grand Jurors
description: Governor Wilson's unexpected veto of a bill that provided for the random selection of grand jurors has sharpened a longstandini debate about the role of grand juries.

title: Marian W. Stoltzfus Married To Gerard Malcolm Gagnon
description: Miss Marian Woodwell Stoltzfus, daughter of Mrs. George Russell Webster of Princeton, N.J., and James Leck Stoltzfus of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Gerard Malcolm Gagnon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Percival Gagnon of Coudersport, Pa.

title: The Guest Word
description: In olden times when everybody in the middle class had an attic, some of the liveliest reading material in the house was stashed away up under the eaves. There, behind mounds of broken furniture and decaying lampshades, buried under a faltering pyramid of aged textbooks and inspirational religious works lay the longforgotten family doctor book, property of an earlier generation and mother lode to prurient adolescents. This volume, four inches thick, with embossed cloth binding often lettered in gold to rival The Holy Bible, went by various titlesThe Home Medical Advisor, The Complete Home Medical Counselor, etc. (Home lent reassurance in the presence of delicate subject matter.)

title: HOSPITALS ASKED ABOUT CONFLICTS
description: Controller Harrison S. Goldin, in a drive to eliminate possible conflicts of interest, has asked 87 voluntary hospitals for statements certifying that their trustees do not do any business with them.

title: U.S. in Southern Asia: The Military Role Changes but the Stakes Remain Large
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  The United States is gradually reducing its commitments in Asia but rapidly expanding its interests as it gropes, almost in a somnambulant manner, for a new role in the region.

title: L.I. Bookmaking Raids Net 2 Retired Policemen
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 22 Two retired New York City policemen were among 21 persons arrested in a series of raids on Long Island late last night and early today in connection with what authorities described as a $40million bookmaking operation with ties to organized crime.

title: NIXON TRIP TO COVER CRIMEA AFTER ALL
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., June 22 (AP)  The White House announced today that President Nixon would include a visit to the Crimean vacation area during his trip to the Soviet Union starting Thursday.

title: West Routs East, 366, In AllAmerica Football
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., June 22 (AP)Jesse Freitas's deadly passing and the running of Joe Barnes and Dickey Morton led the West to a 366 victory over the East tonight in the 14th annual Coaches AllAmerica football game.

title: Dr. Sandra Rappaport Bride of Jordan Fiske
description: The marriage of Dr. Sandra Joyce Rappaport, a psychologist here at St. Elizabeth's School, to Jordan J. Fiske, special assistant attorney general in the office of the state's special prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, took place yesterday evening. The ceremony was performed in Temple Adath Yeshuran in Syracuse by Irwin I. Hyman, rabbi emeritus, and Rabbi Alexander Goldstein. They were assisted by Cantor Harold Lerner.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Gorman Is Fiancee Of Meredith B. Colket 3d
description: Dr. and Mrs. Bruce H. French of Princeton, N. J., and Bar Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of Mrs. French's daughter, Miss Kathleen Stevens Gorman, to Meredith Bright Colket 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Colket Jr. of Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: New Education Chief Cites Need for Objectives
description: MIAMI, June 22In his first public appearance since taking office nine days ago, Dr. Terrell H. Bell, the new Commissioner of Education, presented a stinging, critique of American education last night at the annual meeting of the Education Commission of the States.

title: Connecticut U.S. Attorney
description: HARTFORD, June 22. (AP)The Chief United States District Court Judge, T. Emmet Clarie, has appointed James Pickerstein Interim United States Attorney for Connecticut until the United States Senate confirms a successor to Stewart Jones, who resigned the post today.

title: PARIS SCRUTINIZES PUBLIC SPENDING
description: PARIS, June 22France has been opening to general scrutiny some of the cobwebbed financial corners of her public administration in order to improve services and get them operating with less waste and graft.

title: Mrs. Florence Robertson Is Rewed
description: Mrs. Florence Bryan Robertson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Tennant Bryan of Richmond, was married yesterday afternoon to John Ellis Knowles Wisner, son of Mrs. Frank Gardiner Wisner of Georgetown, Washington, and the late Mr. Wisner.

title: Horton Again Gets Key Pinch Hit for Houk at Shea
description: Ralph Houk came back to haunt the house again yesterday when his Detroit Tigersfor the second game in a rowrallied in the ninth inning to defeat the New York Yankees, 41, at Shea Stadium.

title: Backus Stopped in 3d
description: BERLIN; June 22 (AP) Eckhard Dagge, the European welterweight champion, stopped Billy Backus, former world champion from Canastota, N. Y., in the third round of a scheduled 10round fight last night. The German was fighting for only the 13th time as a pro. He weighed 152 to Backus's 149.

title: Busing Foe Enters Race
description: PONTIAC, Mich, June 22 (UPI)Irene McCabe, a longtime leader in the fight against courtordered school busing, has filed nominating petitions for a seat on the Oakland County Board of Commissioners with an eye toward a possible race for the United States Senate.

title: Competitive Deflation
description: The world's industrial nations have agreed to avoid competitive devaluations and trade restrictions as solutions to their mounting deficits in oil payments; but they may be heading down a third slippery slope that would prove equally dangerous, the route of competitive deflation. France's new austerity measures, which normally would be welcomed abroad, must be evaluated in this context.

title: Sexual apologetics
description: No apology justifies what I have done writes Kate Millett at the beginning of her preface to Flying, an, autobiographical work of dazzling exhibitionism and of such ingrown confusion that this same preface does not appear until page 81. In attempting to explain herself to the lagging and disoriented reader, she offers first an ominous moral muddle in the proposition that it might ever be possible to justify an action by apologizing for it. As the book proceeds, it becomes clear that she believes absolutely in such a possibility. But in Flying it is not mere justification that Millett seeks. She is after absolution as well, empathy, approval and admiration, and her demanding neediness hounds the reader from the beginning to the end of this marathon essay in selfabsorption. She knows quite well what she is doing. There are few likely hostile thoughts about her work that have not been anticipated by the author. An arm raised to send Flying in flight across the room may be arrested by a sudden aside from Millett announcing disturbing visions of disgusted reader throwing the book on the floor. How dare I take up his time? I see his annoyance with brilliant clarity.

title: Book Ends
description: July. July is, as promised, a slow month in publishing; however, there seems to be a sufficient number of interesting titles dribbling out to keep the people coming into the stores. ... novel that is stimulating a good deal of intratrade word of mouth is Alison Lurie's The War Between the Tates. This is a satire set in academemore properly, in America at the end of the sixtiesand has the familiar theme of professor falls for student. But Alison Lurie has a lot more to say about marriage, children, the late war and human relations... Frederick Forsyth contributes another of his finely machined thrillers with The Dogs of War, set in an African country resembling the late Biafra. Strictly for the hammock is male adventure writer Alistair MacLean's Breakheart Pass, a western... Malcolm Muggeridge continues his wearily elegant putdown of the world in the second volume of his memoirs, Chronicles of Wasted Time: The Infernal Grove. Simone de Beauvoir carries forward her autobiography with All Said and Done, and Anita Loos reminisces in a considerably more bubbly vein about the late film capital in kiss Hollywood Goodbye. Then there astronaut Michael Collins out in space Carrying the Fire, and former New York chief of detectives Albert A. Seedman (with Peter Hellman) on his big cases in Chief! ... Death and rape are currently urgent publishing topics. On the former there is Joyce Phipps's Death's Single Privacy and Living and Dying by Robert Jay Lifton and Eric Olson. Against Rape by Andrea Medea and Kathleen Thompson is feminist and The Charge Is Rape, by Gerald Astor, somewhat masculinist.... Other books of current affairs interest include Political Women by Jean Kirkpatrick, Advice and Dissent by Joel Prirnack and Frank von Hippel, The Vietnamization of America by Alexander Kendrick, Facing Starvation by Lennard Bickel and Perversions of Justice by Peter L. Zimroth. ... Playwright William Gibson studies transcendental meditation in A Season in Heaven and Peggy Anderson takes on the D.A.R. The Daughters. . . . There is another R.F. Delderfield novel, Return Journey and newly translated Colette, Retreat From Love.

title: L.I. Nun Makes Social Needs a Cause
description: OYSTER BAY The pews of St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church were filled on a recent evening with civic leaders and other admirers of Sister Adrian Barrett, who was celebrating her 25th year as a nun.

title: Theater Workshop In Fourth Season
description: MONTCLAIR  Summer Company, a contemporary theater workshop for acting and stagecraft, will begin its fourth season at Montclair Academy tomorrow.

title: Mate U. Job Loss Feared From Pact
description: The nonteaching administrators at the State University's Stony Brook campus are fearful that their victory in a contract battle for tenure may wind up costing them their jobs.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Their Thirst Was for Violence, Not for 10Cent Beer
description: To The Editor:

title: Douglaston Mall Plan Withdrawn Until Fall
description: Plans for the controversial Douglaston, Queens, shopping mall are deadat least until the fall.

title: Pupils Restore Rooms Ina 1700 Farmhouse
description: SPRINGFIELDDuring an anuual trip to Williamsburg Va., by the Gaudineer School seventh grade, faculty members who went along decided that the best way to learn about history was by doing.

title: Silbert Hearings Raise Issue of Special Treatment for Accused Politicians
description: WASHINGTON, June 22At courthouses across the nation stands the statue of the blindfolded woman, holding the scales of justice. The presumption is that she does not see the wealth or position of those before her.

title: Bridge
description: Most players of duplicate bridge gain pleasure in comparing their play on the same deals in a big pairs contest. At the highest level the experts will look for someone to listen to their sad stories. More rarely they will recount their triumphs, and there are opportunities for oneupmanship. At the end of the world pair championship in Las Palmas last month a group of internationallyfamous stars were discussing the deal shown in the diagram. It was played in the last session of the final.

title: DEMOCRATS LEADING IN POLL ON CONGRESS
description: The latest Gallup Poll indicates that if Congressional elections were held now, the Democratic party would gain at least twothirds of the House seats, giving the Democrats statistical eontrol over a Presidential veto.

title: CAMBODIAN REBELS SINK BIG RICE BARGE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 22 (AP)Insurgent gunners fired three rockets into the area around the presidential palace tonight and opened fire on a 20vessel, convoy seven miles from Phnom Penh in their most damaging attack in more than a year.

title: 50 JEWS REPORTED IN SOVIET DETENTION
description: MOSCOW, June 22 (UPI)A secret police crackdown on Jewish activists in advance of President Nixon's visit here has resulted in almost 50 arrests, Soviet Jewish sources said today.

title: E. B. Smith Jr., Maureen Dwyer Are Wed Here
description: Miss Maureen Dwyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Dwyer of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married here yesterday to Edward. Byron Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Europe's Imported Work Force
description: BRUSSELSAt the height of the oil scare last November, German immigration authorities called a halt to the entry of migrant workers from abroad. In the face of recession and with layoffs down the road, 2.5 million foreign workers already in Germany seemed enough. Thousands of Turkish, Yugoslav and other workers waiting to leave for Germany discovered that they would not get entry permits.

title: Recordings
description: IT'S close to two years since James Taylor's last LP, One Man Dog (Warner Bros. BS 2660) was released, a long time to wait for a singer/songwriter who was one of the first artists to be labeled superstar in this decade. From the beginning Taylor charmed the public with a softer sounda refreshing relief after the earsplitting excesses of latesixties psychedelic music.

title: More Poor but Less Food
description: Imagine a highway of grain, 55 feet wide and six feet deep, girdling the earth at the equator. Now imagine adding to it every year a 625mile link (longer than Florida's Atlantic coast) in a second lane of the same width and depth. The highway is the amount of grain needed to feed the world now the new links will be required to feed the 76 million mouths added annually to the world's population.

title: Susan Wilson Is Wed
description: Miss Susan Supplee Wilson and William Jackson Darrow, graduates of the University of Denver, were married at noon yesterday in Aspen, Colo. The Rev. Charles G.
