title: Elizabeth Lewis Is Bride
description: Miss Elizabeth Anne Lewis, daughter of the Rev. Harland G. Lewis and Mrs. Lewis of Farmington, Conn., and Leslie Warren Clifford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Clifford of Deer Isle, Me., were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Howard Smith in the First Church of Christ. Mr. Clifford and his bride graduated June 8 from Bowdoin College and are graduates of the Northfield Mount Hermon School.

title: Thousands have signed a document that says, in effect: If I'm terminally ill, pull the plug
description: A few years ago, at a conference on death and dying at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, I sat next to an attractive young woman whose name tag read, Hi! I'm Betty L. During the coffee break, as we talked, she showed me a Living Will requesting that doctors take responsibility for doing what she herself would be unable to do if she became hopelessly illterminate her life. Although the will was not binding, she hoped that when her time came they would take it seriously.

title: SWISS ARE VOTING ON CANTON TODAY
description: GENEVA, June 22The rough outline of a new Swiss canton is expected to be sketched when the citizens of the predominantly Frenchspeaking Jura region of western Switzerland vote Sunday on whether to break away from the otherwise Germanspeaking canton of Berne.

title: The House That Saved a Cliff
description: MONTAUKThe life and conversation of Peter Beard, the photographer, are dominated, by projects.

title: The Nation
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's threat to resign unless exonerated by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in the wiretaps controversy appears to be having the effect he, sought. The committee is obtaining relevant Justice Department documents and preparing for an inquiry that most observers expect to culminate in vindication for Mr. Kissinger.

title: Flushing to Get Bus Terrninal
description: Downtown Flushing will have a bus terminal for, the first time in 20 years when a $4.8million combined public parking gaage and bus facility is completed next year.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: City Starts To Establish Rent Law Machinery
description: Amid widespread confusion and skepticism, public agencies and industry groups are gearing up for the job of administering the rent law passed by the Legislature and approved May 29 by Governor Wilson.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: SOME constructive developments in the international oil and energy situation during the three months since the end of the Arab embargoespecially in recent dayshave encouraged some economic analysts and seemingly eased the overwhelming pressures that last fall's oil offensive suddenly created throughout the world.

title: Religious Radio Proves a Blessing Even in New York
description: IF ROCK N ROLL lets you down, try a little Rock of Ages. The remedy seems to have worked quite well for WWDJ, a station on the local AM radio band that has forsaken rock for the Gospel truth. WWDJ, 970 on the dial, recently made religion its fulltime business after several faltering years as a rock outlet, and religion may make WWDJ into a solid commercial success.

title: Dr. William Boucher Weds Anne B. Sears
description: Miss Anne Bonney Sears, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Niles Sears of Pomfret, Conn., and Chappaquiddick Island, Mass., and Dr. William Francis Boucher Jr. son of Dr. and Mrs. Boucher of Allentown, Pa., were married yesterday afternoon at the First Congregational Church in Woodstock, Conn., by the Rev. Gibson I. Daniels.

title: News of the Stage
description: A solid schedule of concert bookings has been announced for the $12million Uris Theater, which opened as a legitimate play house in the fall of 1972.

title: Notes: Charter Cheats May Travel to a Cell
description: THE files in the State Attorney General's Office on travelers who have been gypped, frustrated or inconvenienced by promoters of charter flights have been getting bulkier and bulkier these last few summers. They are stuffed with complaints about flights that were supposed to go to, say, Madrid, and landed instead in London. Or flights that were canceled day or two before departure. Or promoters whose telephone numbers were suddenly changed and whose offices were found locked up and deserted when clients arrived to pick up tickets. A party of teachers was stranded in Paris last summer and could not get back to the United States for the start of the fall term because the airline on which they thought they would be flying home had not been paid by the charter promoter. Members of a student group who had each paid $412.50 for a roundtrip charter to Tel Aviv discovered three days before departure that had been arranged.

title: RentControl Law Comes to Nassau
description: As many as 35,000 apartments in Nassau Countymany of them never before subject to governmentimposed tent limits  are potentially eligible for coverage under the controversial new rent stabilization law recently passed by the Legislature and approved by Governor Wilson.

title: Evert and Connors, two young wonders of a booming sport, have had all the advantages
description: Jimmy Connors was playing hurt. His blueuniformed Baltimore Banners of the new World Team Tennis league were whipping a yellowclad Detroit Loves team that featured the colorful, highwheeling play of national badmouth Rosemary Casals (infamous for her scathing remarks about Bobby Riggs). Limping through his set on a pulled Achilles tendon, Connors nevertheless wiped up Detroit's hardserving Australian ace, Phil Dent, 63. His work for the evening finished, funnyman Connors draped a yellow towel over his floppy brown hair and invited the Banners' women's singles star, the Scottish Joyce Williams Hume, to join him under it while cheering the Baltimore mixed doubles team on to an exhilarating 76 comeback victory after they had been down 15. As the tension mounted, Connors the showman was up waving the towel at perspiring Banners coach Don Candy, skillfully drawing laughs from the crowd. Next he was roaming the arena, his injured foot unshod, giving interviews or jawing with his mother in the stands.

title: DR. HARRY J. ROSENTHAL
description: Dr. Harry J. Rosenthal, medical officer of the Bronx General Post Office, died Friday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. His age was 69.

title: The World
description: The world's major oilexporting countries turned the screws a little tighter on consuming nations last week by increasing royalties levied on Western oil companies by 2 per cent even though the principal exporter, Saudi Arabia, opposed the move for fear it would further weaken the world's creaking economy.

title: What's New at the Movies?
description: UPTOWN SATURDAY NIGHT, directed by Sidney Poitier from a screenplay by Richard Wesley, got 6 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Ann Guarino, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Penelope Gilliatt, New Yorker), 6 mixed (Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Judith Crist, New York; Donald J. Mayerson, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/World; Frank Rich, New Times) and 2 negative (Martin Levine, Newsday; Jay Cocks, Time).

title: How a Hockey Star Feels About Quitting To Save His Vision
description: I was playing softball with my 10yearold boy, Danny, and he hit a popup back to me on the mound. I stuck out my gloveand the ball hit me on the toe.

title: Can the Casals Festival Continue Without El Maestro?
description: SAN JUAN, P. R.

title: Suzanne Atkinson Bride of D. T. Lake
description: In St. Ignatius Martyr Roman Catholic Church in Long Beach, L. I., yesterday afternoon, Miss Suzanne Marie Atkinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Anthony Atkinson of Atlantic Beach, L. I., became the bride of Douglas Thomas Lake. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Lake of Dedham, Mass.

title: U.S. SAYS IT PLANS NO SALE OF ARMS TO EGYPT OR SYRIA
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The United States told Israel yesterday that it had no plans to sell weapons to either Egypt or Syria, State Department officials and diplomats said today.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONThe news release from the State Council on the Arts described the informal concert scheduled for last Monday as a welcome respite from the hectic routine of legislative days in the State House. But it never worked out that way.

title: JOHN FARRAND
description: John Farrand, a sales engineer for Plastic Products, Inc., of New York and Norwalk, Conn., died Thursday on vacation at Moosehead Lake, Me. He was 70 years old and lived in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Culture Center Run By Blacks Planned By a Queens Church
description: Plans were unveiled last night for a blackownedandoperated social and cultural facility in southeastern Queens sponsored by the St. Albans Congregational Church.

title: Single Cargo Theft in 1973 Was Fewest Ever in Port
description: The Port of New. York last year established a new cargo security record, with only one container reported stolen.

title: Revisions Proposed In Antipollution Act
description: TRENTON  Contending that a 1972 Federal law is hindering sewageplant construction in the state, New Jersey's waterpollution experts have prepared a threepoint proposal for changing the measure.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 23, 1974

title: Colleges Gear Up for Summer
description: NEWARKSummer at independent colleges and universities in New Jersey is not devoted strictly to vacations. It also is a time for study, whether for college credit or enriching an individual's life.

title: Music: Young Songsters
description: The James Madison High School in Vienna, Va., has had a vocal music program, of high quality for several years, and from time to time its Madison Madrigal Singers have perferined here with great success.

title: An East Orange Warrior of Peace Goes Public
description: EAST ORANGE  Abdul Mfundishi Maasi, who calls himself a warrior of peace, is an employe of the local Recreation Department. He is in charge of the East Orange martial arts program and, as such, is the only civil servant in New Jersey with the title of BandoKarate Instructor.

title: Duluth Gets '76 Bonspiel
description: The host city for the 1976 world curling championship for the Air Canada Silver Broom will be Duluth, Minn. Next year's world event is being staged at Perth, Scotland, from March 17 through 23.

title: Susan J. Constable Bride in Brooklyn
description: Miss Susan J. Constable, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Constable of Brooklyn, was married at noon yesterday to Mark E. Huntley, son of Maj. Jack It Huntley, Chaplains Corps, U.S.A., and Mrs. Huntley of Fort Hamilton Army Base, Brooklyn, and Canton, Ohio.

title: Film
description: PORTSMOUTH, England

title: Everyone Concedes the Burglary Took Place
description: WASHINGTONThe White House plumbers trial is scheduled to begin Wednesday with none the important questions about the group's purpose and exploits seemingly at issue.

title: Kissinger's triumph began in trauma
description: The part called for someone taller, slimmer, more adept at reviewing Arab honor guards, more traditional in his diplomatic style, a connoisseur couscous and Casbah conventions, a WASP. No producer had ever dreamed of Henry of Arabia!

title: Drea Defeats Klecatsky In Schuylkill Crew Race
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 22Sean Drea of Ireland, last year's Diamond Sculls winner, won the featured elite singles event of the Schuylkill Navy regatta today. Drea led shortly after the start, rowing at 36 strokes per minute on the calm Schuylkill River.

title: HAITI LOSING FIGHT AGAINST EROSION
description: PORT  AU  PRINCE, HaitiTropical storms breaking over PortauPrince send violent torrents of thick muddy water rushing down the capital's streets, often carrying boulders and tree trunks with them.

title: Oak Ridge Post Filled
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 22 (AP)  Philip L. Johnson has been named executive director of Oak Ridge Associated Universities to succeed Dr. William G. Pollard. The group is a private, nonprofit educational association of 42 Southern universities and colleges. Its scientists conduct a variety of programs in medical research and education under a contract with the Atomic Energy Commission.

title: 12Meter Yachts: Pretty, But They Cost Too Much
description: Twelve Meters are beautiful boats. Even with their noses clipped, a, la Intrepid, and their transoms reversed, they are long and graceful, tall, powerful and fast. But, beautiful as they are, this year, even more than in the past, many boatmen are wondering if the time, money and talent poured into America's Cup competitors could he better lavished on some other type of yacht.

title: Air America Selling Plant in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 22Air America, the charter airline that has often been linked to Central Intelligence Agency activity in Southeast Asia, is negotiating to sell its highly regarded aircraft maintenance and repair facility on Taiwan.

title: James Hartenstein To Wed Sally Swan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald O. Swan of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Galarneau Swan, to James Christopher Hartenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Hartenstein of Akron, Ohio.

title: House Set on Fire In Test of Materials
description: It is an all too familiar sight. Fire breaks out in one of a series of attached houses in minutes, flames shoot through the upstairs ceiling of the wooden structure. The blaze penetrates the cockloft and quickly spreads to an adjacent house and then to another.

title: The SheridanSmith Show: A Misalliance of Art and Technology
description: THE Museum of Modern Art's latest Projects exhibition of avantgarde workthis one by two Illinois artists, Sonia Landy Sheridan and Keith Smithis an artistic flop. It is interesting, however, as evidence that art that exploits new technical gimmickry is proving to be a remarkably hardy species, especially when it comes to getting museum attention. This phenomenon is worth looking into.

title: Aftermath of a Gift
description: CHICAGO, June 22 (AP)James Callahan, unemployed, spent months scrounging parts from neighbors to build a bicycle for his stepdaughter because he could not afford to buy her one, the police said. On Thursday, Mr. Callahan identified her body at the county morgue. Kimberly Peterson, 10 year old, was killed when she fell from the bicycle and was struck by a truck.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: The Use and Abuse of Art
description: The cultural critic, wrote the late Theodor Adorno, is not happy with civilization, to which alone he owes his discontent. He speaks as if he represented either unadulterated nature or a higher historical stage. Yet he is necessarily of the same essence as that to which he fancies himself superior.

title: LoveHate Relations
description: Crosscultural commentary, once a fine and gentlemanly art, has become a hazardous business. Is America any longer susceptible to the kind of highlevel yet perfectly aimed generalization that Tocqueville, Henry James and Lord Bryce were able to fire off with such splendid confidence and consistency? Even if an excellence of observation of the sort these men brought to the task were possible, would Americans be ready to give it a fair hearing? Or are we instead only prepared to grant the truth of observations about our past and not about the we are now?

title: How to Slipcover a Building, Washington Style
description: ANEW Senate Office Building is about to be constructed on Capitol Hill, and for the first time a major building for the Hill is not being planned behind closed doors. Even for Washington, it is to be a very expensive and important structure, loaded with symbolic values and office space. It will also be very big.

title: Building Boom Is Under Way In Capitol Hill Neighborhood
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  After Thomas Jefferson's inauguration as the nation's third President, he took supper in his modest boarding house on Capitol Hill, and declined a proposal that he sit at the head of the long table in favor of his usual place far from the fire.

title: Democrats Expect to Regain Assembly; G.O.P. Is Confident, but Steps Up Drive
description: Strategists in the Democratic legislative campaign feel the party will take control of the Assembly from the Republicans next fall, and their optimism even ranges to insisting that they have a fair chance of unseating the Republican majority leaders, Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea and Senator Warren M. Anderson.

title: Gail Puglia Has Bridal
description: Miss Gail Barbara Puglia, daughter of Mr: and Mrs. Richard F. Puglia of Trenton, and Glenn Benjamin Stec, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin B. Stec, also of Trenton, were married by the Rev. Louis Kralovich, yesterday afternoon in St. Miphaers Roman Catholic Churck in Trenton.

title: $250,000 Drowning Award
description: MIAMI, June 22 (UPI)The father of a 7yearold elementary school student who drowned while on a school field trip has been awarded $250,000 by a Circuit Court fury. In giving the award, the jury found the Dade County School Board was negligent in caring for Jraquetta Scott, who perished three years ago.

title: Study Hints That Yogurt May Reduce Cholesterol
description: The longstanding popular belief that yogurt is good for you may have a stronger base in scientific fact than has heretofore been realized, according to the accidental findings of a recent nutritional study among primitive African tribesmen.

title: Big Teamster Gift To Nixon Backers Reported by Rabbi
description: WASHINGTON, ON, June 22 (AP) The largest single contribution to the National Citizens' Committee for Fairness to the Presidency has come from the teamsters union, the committee president, Rabbi Baruch Korff, said today.

title: Sand Art ... Sad Tidings
description: ONCE every fall, on a crisp Indian Summer Sunday, resident seagulls are almost crowded off the dazzling arc of white sand at CarmelbytheSea, Calif., by an exercise in human fantasy called The Great Sandcastle Building Contest.

title: Merger Mastermind
description: Virtually unknown to the public, they do their work without fanfare in paneled corporate offices and on clay tennis courts, emerging primarily when the arcane financial deals they fashion make headlines. They are the Investment bankers of Wall Street. Their archtype is controversial 46  year  old whirlwind, Felix G. Rohatyn.

title: Others Argue Reserve Is Now on Right Track And Must Persevere
description: The present state of the money and capital markets is precarious, but that is inevitable if the country is ever going to get back to financial sanity.

title: Caso Data On Beaches Are Held Misleading
description: MINEOLAWaterquality ratings of beaches in Nassau released recently by the County Executive's office were based on figures not representative of the swimming season, according to county Health Department officials.

title: The Region
description: With New Jersey already under a court order expected to result in an alternative to the property tax as the primary means of financing public schools, education officials in New York and Connecticut last week began their own attacks on the inequities of the real estate tax system as the source of funding education.

title: Student Combines Science and Art
description: NEW HYDE PARKA 20yearold chemistry student began fusing science and art three years ago and the glass sculptures that have resulted from that union have achieved such prominence that they have been used to display jewelry ?? VanCleef and Arpels on Fifth Avenue.

title: BikeTesting Device Available
description: PATERSON  The North Jersey Automobile Club has available to communities in Bergen, Passaic and Hudson Counties a piece of equipment that it hopes will promote bicycle safety and eliminate potentially unsafe bikes from the streets. It is called a bicycle testing lane, and it is available tree or charge merely by making a reservation in advance.

title: Outbreak of Heartworm In Dogs Is Called Serious
description: Canine heartworm disease is again reaching serious proportions in parts of the metropolitan area. All dogs should be tested for this disease, as soon as possible, said Dr. J. Lloyd Tait, president of the Veterinary Medical Association of New York City. This is especially true for dogs whose owners are taking them on trips to the southern climes, where it is especially prevalent.

title: Miss Palmer Married in Darien
description: Miss Caroline. Lee Palmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Lee Palmer of Darien, Conn., and John Tompkins Mickle, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Daniel Mickle Jr. of Old Chatham, N. Y., were married yesterday in the chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles P. Henderson Jr. assisted by Msgr. Paul S. Tipton, president of Spring Hill College in, Mobile, Ala.

title: Monmouth Turf Race To Mo Bay
Nuclear Plan Developed By Suffolk
description: Suffolk County officials are seeking final state approvel for a threephase plan to deal with nuclear emergencies, a representative of the county Department of Health Services har reported.

title: Letters to the Edito
description: The article Replacing the [April 21] amused me no end because it was so unrealistic. Having just had a new asphaltshingle roof put on our country house, my advice is the following: if you have a friend who can recommend a roofer count yourself among the fortunate few; if that roofer can be contacted and if he is willing just to come and look at your roof, you are blessed; if he comes to see the roof, don't say a word. Just pray he will do the job sometime, anytime, at whatever price he states.

title: The Lawyer as Confidant
description: It has always been the lawyer's duty to represent the interest of his client, no matter who he is, to the limit of the law. It is the client's interest, not the public interest, that the private lawyer must protect.

title: Tennis Anyone? Lessons Offered
description: HACKENSACK  A free tennis clinic for Bergen County residents 8 to 18 years old will be offered, starting July 1, in Van Saun County Park. The lessons will continue through August.

title: Officials Dismayed at Use Of SecretMarriage Law
description: LOS ANGELES, June 22California's 28monthold confidentialmarriage law, where it takes a court order to divulge the wedding, is resulting in too many of the wrong ties that bind, the head of the Los Angeles county government insists.

title: British Aid for Tanzania
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 22 (AP)Britain is to provide Tanzania with aid for the first time since Tanzania broke diplomatic relations in 1965 over London's handling of Rhodesia's unilateral declaration of independence, Britain's Minister of Overseas Development, Mrs. Judith Hart, said today that during her weeklong visit agreement had been reached on a $24million interestfree loan to be used fort rural development.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Politicians have long suffered the slings and arrows of editorial cartoonists but it's only been fairly recently. that comic strip artists have gotten into the act. Two famous ones are Al Capp, who took on the liberals in Li'l Abner, and the late Walt Kelly, who lambasted demagogues in Pogo.

title: He was part of the American theater
description: Here is the cherries jubilee of theatrical autobiographies. Howard Dietz has written, in the leanest of prose, a witty and at times most touching bridge between the Broadway stage and the Hollywood screen. He was there, he saw it all, he heard it all, he lived it all and he tells the stories like Scheherazade in A Thousand and One Nights.

title: Congress Soon Must Decide
description: The revenuesharing program enacted in 1972 at the urging of the Nixon Administration was meant help return government to the people by giving Federal funds directly to lower levels of government with no or few strings attached. To that end, the national Treasury is paying out $30.2billion over a fiveyear period to 38,000 governmental jurisdictions, from states to tiny villages.

title: Nancy Wieler Has Nuptials
description: Miss Nancy Jane Wieler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Wieler of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., was married yesterday morning to First Lieut. Michael Stewart Woodson, U.S.M.C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Halford Woodson of Alexandria, Va.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: U.S. Study Backs Hempstead Housing
description: MANHASSETThe United States Department of Housing and Done Development reported last week that a highly controversial housing project planned by the Town of North Hempstead Would have little, or no effect on the marshland of Udalls Cove.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section, 2:

title: 4 Catholic Schools Closing
description: A threemonthold controversy over the closing of two Catholic elementary schools in the BedfordStuyvesant area of Brooklyn appears to be sputtering to an end in the wake of a formal order issued by the Brooklyn diocese last week to shut down those schools and two others.

title: The Ax and Older Workers
description: Thousands of employes from the blue collar level to alumni of the Harvard Business School find every year that the words Happy Birthday have a hollow ring. They are the victims of a seemingly indestructible myth that over 40 is an occupational twilight zone where efficiency and creativity can go nowhere but down.

title: Richard Wyatt Marries Rita Ninivaggio
description: Miss Rita Ann Ninivaggio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo C. Ninivaggio of New York and Yorktown Heights, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Thomas Wyatt, son of Mrs. Leon Stylka of Garden City Park, L.I. Msgr. Alexander Markowski performed the ceremony in the chapel of Manhattanvilla College in Purchase, N.Y., the bride's alma mater.

title: Nixons Fate May Hinge On Nine Key Republicans
description: WASHINGTON, June 22President Nixon's fate in the House regarding impeachment may be decided by nine Republicanseight members of the House Judiciary Committee and the committee's special counsel.

title: A nice place to visit
description: Charles Neider, who lives in Princeton and writes novels and criticism and an occasional biography, traveled to the Antarctic on a brief visit in 1969 and was never the same again. Nor will anyone be the same who reads this book while suffering from a latent desire to see the Antarctic, which is the body of land and iceonetenth the land mass of the world and 95 per cent of the fresh water supplythat surrounds the South Pole: It is cold (127 F. has been registered at the Soviet Union's Vostok Station at the geomagnetic South Polepresumably the Russian scientists are studying how to make Siberia colder); lifeless (there is no organic life on the continent) and most awfully beautiful.

title: Nancy Floreen, Law Student, Wed
description: Miss Nancy Marie Floreen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav J. Floreen of Arlington, Mass., and David O. Stewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton D. Stewart of Ward Hill, S.I., were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Donald Wells at the Trinity Covenant Church (Swedish Calvinist) In Lexington, Mass.

title: Improved Education Urged for Retarded
description: TRENTONIn its current special session on tax reform and school financing, the Legislature is being asked to consider a related proposal calling for upgrading the education of mentally handicapped children.

title: News of the Stage
description: A solid schedule of concert bookings has been announced for the $12million Uris Theater, which opened as a legitimate play house in the fall of 1972.

title: How to not make an atomic bomb
description: John McPhee has an eye and an ear and a typewriter that operate like the camera and full crew of a documentary film studio. Give him a theme and he comes up with a picture: edited, crosscut, spliced and orchestrated, specific and full of the facts and the atmosphere of that theme. The picture, like a good documentary, carries its own emotional impact as well as, in this case, an urgent imperative.

title: Good Sam Tries to Ease Fear
description: SUFFERN, N. Y.The pediatrics staff at Good Samaritan Hospital here has instituted a program that is designed not only to remove many of the fears of young patients but also to reassure many parents.

title: The Battle of Waterloo: Sunday Picnics on the Killing Ground
description: IN Belgium there are three square miles of gently rolling, lush green farmland where dairy cattle placidly graze and farmers work their crops this month until 8 or 9 in the evening, taking advantage of the latesetting sun. Here, after a battle lasting only about nine hours, 65,000 men once lay, dead or dying20,000 more than wefts lost by the United States in all the years of the Vietnam War. This is the Battlefield of Waterloo.

title: Black Symphony Society Is Helping New Talent
description: Through the study of music, with all its harmonies, with its chords and dischords, there is a lesson to be learned in human understanding. And, as it takes Many types of instruments to make an orchestra, I think an orchestra can be considered the world in microcosm.

title: FUND CRISIS FACED BY PRESBYTERIANS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 21A financial crisis in the United Presbyterian Church has emerged as the dominant concern of the governing assembly here with news that the denomination has exhausted its usable reserves.

title: Ellington Course Planned
description: SOUTH ORANGEAn 11week radio course on The Music of Duke Ellington will be offered by Seton Hall University this summer. The course, which will provide three college credits, will be conducted by Prof. Jack McKinney on Seton Hall's FM station (WSOU, 89.5) three evenings a week, starting July 2. Each evening's program will be repeated at noon the following day.

title: Caspian Sea Is Yielding Offshore Oil
description: BAKU, U.S.S.R.An unmistakable whiff of oil hangs in the warm, dry airnot an unpleasant scent when it mingles with the fragrance of the lush foliage along the waterfront promenade of this Caspian Sea city.

title: Malone's Route to Maryland Draws Some Heat
description: Moses Malone will play college basketball at Maryland, and the several hundred other colleges that tried to get him are beginning to ask questions.I fully expect an N.C.A.A. [National Collegiate Athletic Association] investigation, said Lefty Driesell, Maryland's head coach. It doesn't affect me at all. I welcome it. I've been in this profession for r 15 years and you've never seen one of my teams on probation and you never will, When I get so I have to cheat to win, I have other ways to make a living.Despite those words, some kingsized headaches are already starting for Driesell regarding his kingsized star. Two N.C.A.A. investigators arrived in Richmond last Friday, the day after Malone signed, and questioned him about violations by two of the unsuccessful schools involved in the recruiting war. The N.C.A.A. can now put players as well as schools on probation.

title: 3 Burlington Towns May Merge Police
description: MOUNT HOLLYWhat is believed to be the state's first regionalized police department is in the planning stage in northcentral Burlington County.

title: Early Pregnancy Found No Handicap to Athletes
description: In the 1956 Olympics at Melbourne, Australia, three goldmedal winners were pregnant, Mary Ann Beattie of the Detroit Loves played club tennis right up to the final week of her pregnancy. The Victorian notion that a pregnant woman must be shielded from physical and emotional stress has broken down. Early pregnancy does not seem to hamper a woman competing in sports, according to four prominent United States doctors, who participated in a recent symposium for The Physician and Sportsmedicine magazine.

title: Wohlhuter's 1 :43 .9 Is 800Meter Mark
A Nursery Class Is Bugged
description: PARAMUSGeorge Jockish's classroom at Paramus High School is bugged. And one of the people listening in on George is his mother.

title: Report of British Nuclear Blast Set for Nevada Stirs Left Wing
description: LONDON, June 22A report that an underground nuclear test is to be carried out in Nevada for the British Government aroused some leftwing Labor Members of Parliament today.

title: Henry A. Fletcher, 84, Dies; A Music Publisher, Writer
description: MIAMI, June 22 (AP)Henry Archie Fletcher, a retired music writer and publisher, died Tuesday at the age of 84.

title: Mitsubishi, a Giant of Japan, Branches Out
description: TOKYO  It had a turnover of $22billion last year, equivalent to almost half of Japan's national budget. It raises chickens, builds rockets, imports onethird of Japan's iron ore, and is planning to industrialize New Guinea. And it does all this by borrowing 97 per cent of its investment and working capital.

title: Chutists Get Ready to Dare Forest Fires of Northwest
description: MISSOULA, Mont.In 1934 the idea was abandoned as harebrained scheme, a risks suicidal plot by publicityloving daredevils and crackpots.

title: $100 Million in Bonds Proposed By Wilson to Ease Mortgages
description: Governor Wilson proposed yesterday the issuance of $100million in bonds by a state agency to help alleviate critical shortage of funds for home mortgages.

title: New York Vacates Bull Pen as Fans Toss Fireworks
Somali Schools to Close a Year So Students Can Teach Nomads
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, June 16  Mohamud Moallin, a nomadic herdsman, rode a camel into Mogadishu eight years ago when he was 24 years old and illiterate.

title: Druses of Syrian Area Granted Israeli Asylum
description: TEL AVIV, June 22Israel has granted asylum to 20 Syrian Druses whose village, captured in the war last October, is now reverting to Syrian rule under the disengagement pact.

title: INQUIRY STARTED AT CITY COLLEGE
description: An investigation or possible abuses of academic freedom in City College's longtroubled history department has been begun by a fivemember committee, including two professors from other institutions.

title: followUp on the News
description: These are progress reports based on Times inquiries into some unfinished news events.

title: What's Doing in LONDON
description: THE MOOD  London's ageold sense of aplomb goes on, despite 15 per cent inflation, the after, effects of labor strikes and the violence in Ulster. Unpleasant events hit the headlines but the stiff upper lip reduces them to civilized proportions; and for the tourist, only rising prices are apparent. An unconscious turning away from economic and other troubles is reflected in a host of nostalgic items in the entertainment field.

title: Stamps
description: AT this time of year, on stamps as in nature, flowers have burst into bloom, birds and butterflies are on the wing, and fish ripple through the water.

title: Dave Anderson
description: When the New York Mets went to Philadelphia this weekend, they had the worst wonlost record in the major leagues. That was an embarrassing comedown for the National League champions. But their manager, Yogi Berra, was surviving with patience instead of snapping with panic. Yogi Berra had survived a similar crisis last season. His patience was a factor in the Mets ascending from last place in the sixteam Eastern Division as late as Aug. 28 to first place, to the pennant, and to a World Series loss with honor, He was rewarded with a threeyear contract. If his tenure wasn't quite so secure now, he might not be quite so patient now. But he's as frustrated as he was last season.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Kissinger and Schlesinger Deny Rift in October War
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 Secretary of State Kissinger and Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger today denied reports that they fought a weeklong battle over moving military supplies to Israel during the war in October.

title: Bobby Unser Wins The Pole at Pocono
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., June 22 (AP)Bobby Unser drove his Olsonite Eagle 10 miles at a speed of 182.5 miles an hour today and captured the pole position for the June 30 Schaefer 500mile championship race.

title: Tight Money Is Not Enough
description: There is a growing realization that the 4 per cent. growth rate to which the United States has become accustomed is going to have to be slashed to an average 2 or 2.5 per cent for this year and the two following years.

title: 2 Public Hearings Set By Council This Week
description: The following City Council committee public hearings will be held this week:

title: Chess Affiliation Is Asked
description: NICE, France, June 22 (Agence FrancePresse)China and Egypt have asked to become members of the International Chess Federation. Their affiliation will be decided during the federation's congress to. be held during the current 21st Chess Olympiad here. Admittance of these two countries would raise the federation's membership to 88 countries.

title: Bonnie MacMillin Wed
description: Miss Bonnie Sue MacMillin, daughter of the late Mr, and Mrs. Norman MacMillin of Highland Park, Ill., was married yesterday afternoon to David Joseph Slobedien, son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Stobodien of Metuchen, N. J. Mayor Donald Wernik of Metuchen performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: POPE ASKS EFFORT ON PALESTINE
description: ROME, June 22Pope Paul VI in an address to the Sacred College of Cardinals today urged world leaders to seek a solution to the problem of the Palestinians.

title: Scholarships Set By Ballet School
description: NEWARKScholarship for 75 to 100 students will be awarded by the School of the Garden State Ballet this summer as part of an expanded aid program made possible through the National Endowment for the Arts and the state's Council on the Arts.

title: Miss Smolian Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Smolian of Redding, Conn., and Winhall, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Jean Smolian, to Georges Christophe Megroz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Megroz of Mamaroneck, N. Y., and Bondville, Vt. The couple plan to marry Aug. 4 at the Redding home of the prospective bride's parents.

title: R. R. McNerney Marries Phyllis Lawes

title: Shore Towns Reluctant To Ban Group Rentals
description: TRENTON  When the United States Supreme Court ruled on April 1 that a Long Island community could prohibit group rentals, it was expected that a number of New Jersey shore towns would draft zoning regulations aimed at excluding young people from living together for the summer.

title: AROUND THE
description: Prune summerflowering shrubs as soon as blooms fade.... Diazinon will control chinch bugs which cause yellow spots turning brown on the lawn.... Be sure summering house plants outdoors are watered properly; pots dry out quickly.

title: NEW PRODUCT WARNS OF IMPENDING TROUBLE
description: AN electronic watchman that can help protect the family home when everyone is away on vacation can now be inexpensively installed by anyone by simply plugging into a telephone jack or connecting to the junction box near the phone. Called the Caretaker, and priced at $129.50, the unit is made by Dytron, Inc., 223 Crescent Street, Waltham, Mass. 02154. To use, the dials on the front panel are set to any phone number that the owner desires notified in the event an alarm is needed, and the phone plugged in. Builtin sensors will detect heating system failure, high temperature (fire) unauthorized entry and other potential hazards, and will automatically dial the preset number. When the phone is answered one of two signals will be heard, indicating either an immediate hazard, or a potential hazard. If no one is home, or if the line called is busy, the instrument will continue dialing at regular intervals until someone responds. That person can then call the local police, fire department, or similar agency. The unit is powered by batteries, and can be connected to, and activated by, an existing burglar alarm system.

title: Submarine a Popular Lure
description: HACKENSACKThe Submarine Memorial Associationis maintaining and offering ing tours of the U.S.S. Ling, a World War II submarine that is moored at 150 River Street. The vessel has attracted 60,000 visitors in the year that she has been opened to the public.

title: David Condliffe And Jane Falk Plan Marriage
description: Miss Jane Falk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Falk of New York, plans to be married July 6 at her parents' home to David Charles Condliffe, son of Mrs. Jane Rosenthal Condliffe of Riverdale, the Bronx, and John. C. Condliffe of Union City, N.J.

title: An Aggressive Mood at the F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON  When Lewis A. Enginan moved from the White House staff to the chairmanship of the Federal Trade Commission early in 1973, he was generally thought to be little more than an errand boy for H. R. Haldeman and John R. Ehrlichman.

title: Ford Suggests That Unbiased Party Clear Up Tape Discrepancies
description: MONTEREY, Calif., June 22 Vice President Ford suggested today that a third party listen to Presidential tape recordings to clear up discrepancies between versions prepared by the White House and the House Judiciary Committee.

title: Miss Brooks Has Nuptials
description: In St. Bede's Episcopal Chapel, Greenwich, Conn., yesterday afternoon Miss Victoria Lynne Brooks, a teacher at the Kinkaid School in Houston, was married to Mark Linn Ulrey, who is on the faculty of the Duchesne Academy in Houston. The Rev. Samuel Walker performed the ceremony.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Hale Irwin, winner of the United States Open, singles out as the turning point the 35foot birdie putt on the ninth hole of the final round that put him in the lead: I felt a lot better when I made that putt. I felt that being on top I was driving the car and they would have to find me.

title: Driver's Widow Wins Case
description: LEWISTOWN, Pa., June 22 (AP)  The family of a truck driver killed while the police were chasing another vehicle has won $200,000 damages in Mifflin County Court. Lewistown Borough was ordered Wednesday to pay the widow and four children of Amos Emery, Brookville. Mr. Emery was forced off the road during a chase on March 17, 1970.

title: Chess:
description: NICE, France, June 19 The United States team, recovering from its defeat by West Germany in the championship finals of the 21st International Team Tournament, won its matches with the Netherlands and Argentina by identical scores of 21.

description: AKRON, Ohio, June 22Forrest (Fuzzy) Fezler, tired of the runnerup role, says, I'm not gonna let it go this time.

title: The King of Porn, ah-Corn:The King of Porn, ah-Corn
description: THE sharp, cheerlessly reassuring smell of disinfectant seeped through the balcony of the World the other afternoon. A half-dozen men, smokers all, sat there singly, trying to ignore both the smell, as depressing to the erotic instinct as a stop watch, and the loud conversation from the theater lobby. Several employes were bent on discussing coffee breaks or some other subject of equal importance, which made the screen dialogue difficult to understand. I very much wanted to hear. Not only had I paid five dollars to pass through a turnstile to get in, but I was anxious to see "Memories Within Miss Aggie," a movie that one critic has described as being "rich with intimations of 'Psycho,' and 'Images' and Faulkner," and whose director, Gerard Damiano, a former hairdresser and X-ray, technician, has been called the Ingmar Bergman of porn.That last must have been a typo. Corn is more like it.On the screen a small, intensely yellow-haired young woman and a young man of no evident passions frolic through the snow in a wildly unconvincing mime of rural innocence. The woman's pencil-thin eyebrows suggest an easier access to tweezers and urban fashion than provided for in the screenplay, but that could be dramatic license. The couple giggle, roll about in the drifts and toss snowballs at each other, though neither is very good. Each throws in the cautious underhand manner of the rookie pitcher on a team of Brownies. Finally the young man and the young woman fall into each other's arms, exhausted, prompting the following bit of Ingmar Bergman dialogue, spoken in ersatz Ethan Frome accents:She: "I feel funny."He: "I do too."She: "I wonder why."He: "Being close, mebbee."She: "I feel funny."Which, perhaps because it's where they began, leads them to an empty house where they take off their clothes and, in the words of still another critic, perform sex "with feeling."As a matter of fact, feeling is one of the things that is conspicuously absent in the porn parts of "Memories Within Miss Aggie."The actors work earnestly enough, but they don't seem to be interested. Even Harry Reems, the supporting star of Damiano's "Deep Throat" and "The Devil in Miss Jones," seems to be tiring. This may be why he doubled as production manager on this new film and is listed as Herb Streicher in the credits, which may or may not be his real name. His fatigue may also have prompted him to wear the fake moustache he does in "Memories Within Miss Aggie," as if he didn't want to be recognized. However, pasting a moustache on Harry Reems is like trying to disguise a camel by making him wear galoshes."Memories," in one of its earlier weeks at the World Theater, was reported by Variety to be the second highest grossing picture in New York, topped only by "Mame" at Radio City Music Hall. This is depressing news for anyone seriously interested in the fate of movies, or even seriously interested in the liberation of pornography."Memories Within Miss Aggie" is an overcooked, guilt-stuffed cabbage of a movie, which, like "The Devil in Miss Jones," pretends to seriousness through its synthetically solemn framing device.Miss Aggie (Deborah Ashira), a tall gaunt woman whose makeup isn't quite good enough to convince me she's the old lady she's supposed to be, wanders around her farmhouse in what I take to be upstate New York. The snowy landscape outside is photographed adequately by Harry Flecks, and I suspect it's the existence of the snow, not any Nykvist-like talent on the part of the cameraman that makes people compare Damiano to Bergman.Aggie has lived alone too long, as she tells us several more times than is necessary if we're over the age of 21 or even 6. She moves about the house grumpily, talking to a portly New York actor (Patrick Farrelly), who's presented as being a handyman but who just sits by the stove all day.Aggie has troubled memories of having done something "bad" when she was younger. When she thinks about it hard enough we, the audience, are treated to her fantasies, three in all, each with a different New York porn queen masquerading as Aggie's vision of herself.In the first one, in which the very worldly, very yellow-haired Aggie is supposedly deflowered, Aggie is played by Kim Pope. In the second fantasy, Aggie is played by an actress who looks so butch that only wide-angle close-ups can testify to the fact that she's not really Holly Woodlawn. In the third fantasy, and the only one that has a suspicion of humor or erotic style, Aggie (Darby Lloyd Rains) sees herself in an old-fashioned, turn-of-the-century bordello.When Aggie has gotten through her three fantasies, which are probably all that the budget would allow, Damiano lets us in on a secret that we could have been let in on at any earlier point in the film. That isare you readythat none of these things really happened, and that Miss Aggie, as crazy as a bedbug, put a carving knife through the skull of the man whose body she still keeps by the kitchen stove.Damiano, I'm afraid, is no Hitchcock, no Polanski, no Faulkner. He's just your ordinary, run-of-the-mill moviegoer and sometime reader who doesn't hesitate to lift the cast-offs, the remnants, of other people's ideas, which are evidently all he is capable of lifting.It is significant that the only scene in the film that has any impact is the murder scene, not because it's well done but because the violence seems cruel to a much greater degree than any of the sex scenes have seemed erotic.Damiano's approach to sex is, if anything, anti-erotic, from Linda Lovelace's grotesque, nose-drooling accomplishments in "Deep Throat," to the emphasis on guilt and repression in both "Miss Jones" and "Aggie."Although I hope I've an open mind on the subject, I think it's quite likely that there is no such thing as good pornography. If it's good, then it's not pornographic, Which is not quite the same thing as saying there isn't high class pornography. Some of the films made by the Mitchell Brothers in San Francisco, including "Behind The Green Door," have a kind of slickness about themgood looking people and a lot of smooth, swoopy camera movements. However, these things are to serious movies what Andre Kostelanetz's arrangements are to serious music. In Damiano's case let's not get carried away and so confused by drabness that we start calling his ugly little movies art.If the man seems to have hit on a successful thing, it may well be because many people in his audience feel freer to enjoy the pure porn interludes if they're wrapped in a dreary moral fable with all of the psychological depth of a True Romance story.To a greater or lesser extent, most Americans are puritans, and from the evidence of his three most successful films, Damiano is one of the fiercest. Sex is bad. Sex is dirty. It is something to be disinfected, one way and another. If Damiano had written "The Scarlet Letter," you can bet that Hester Prynne would have gone just as looney as poor old Rev. Dimmesdaleand died an even worse death. I hesitate to imagine how.

title: Phone Rate Rise Rejected
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., June 22 (AP)The New England Telephone Company request for a 17 per cent temporary rate increase for Vermont customers was unanimously rejected yesterday by the State Public Service Board.

title: Serenity of '50's Housing Project In Queens Is Jarred by 2 Slayings
description: Fear of violent crime in their midst has never been a nagging preoccupation for most of the 2,000 families living in the serene, campusstyle Pomonok Houses near Queens College in Flushing.

title: People and Business
description: Suburban shopping centers in New Jersey continue to expand, and a $25million program to provide additional retailing and other facilities at the Monmouth Shopping Center in Eatontown is proceeding on schedule.

title: A.B.A. Will Retain Setup And Renew N.B.A. Suit
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 22  The American Basketball Association, angered on Thursday by a refusal from the National Basketball Association ownership to consider a merger agreement, announced late last night that it had dressed its wounds and was ready to resume war with the older league.

title: DR. JAMES MATHERS, CARDIOLOGIST, DEAD
description: Dr. James Alexander Lamond Mathers, a specialist in internal medicine and cardiology on the staff of Presbyterian Hospital, died Friday at his summer home in Virginia Beach. He was 61 years old and lived at 231 Davidson Place, Englewood, N.J.

title: Parkway Will Sell Unleaded Gasoline
description: WOODBRIDGE  Unleaded gasoline will be available at all service stations on the Garden State Parkway, starting July 1.

title: FUND CRISIS FACED BY PRESBYTERIANS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 21A financial crisis in, the United Presbyterian Church has emerged as the dominant concern of the governing assembly here with news that the denomination has exhausted its usable reserves.

title: Dance
description: HIS is a requiem for a lightheavyweight. The National Ballet of Washington, D.C., announced that it had officially suspended operations effective June 12. The company's Board of Trustees had met the day before and decided to suspend until further notice. The statement continued: The momentous decision of the Board was received with utmost regret and immeasurable sadness by the Ballet's founding president, Mrs. Richard J. Riddell. Necessary financial support has not been forthcoming. No hope has been offered to offset the approximately $300,000 needed to balance the budget, plus a like amount to start the company on an upward thrust.

title: Milk Industry Is in Financial Trouble
description: PERTH AMBOYDeclining profits and consumer resistance to increasing retail prices have created new problems for the state's milk industry, which is reported to be in financial trouble.

description: ACROSS

title: The case against the Vice President
description: The Investigation and Resignation of Vice President Spiro T. Agnew. By Richard M. Cohen and Jules Witcover. A Washington Post Book. Illustrated. 373 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $10.

title: Marketplace of Ideas
description: By signing the bill that has now passed both houses of Congress to stretch out through 1980 postalrate increases for mailed publications, President Nixon has an opportunity to save milk magazines and small newspapers from going under and to allow a diversity of voices to continue to compete in the marketplace of ideas.

title: Virginia Crow Becomes Bride
description: Miss Virginia Hanford Crow, daughter of Ralph Langstaff Crow Jr. of Rye, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Barbara Godwin Crow, was married yesterday afternoon to Edward Shorney Mills 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ensign Mills of Lakeville, Conn., and Schermerhorn's Landing, N. Y.

title: U.S. Says Noise Level in City Bars Federal Funds for Housing
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  Some New York City slums are so noisy and crowded that environmentalists in the Federal Department of Housing and Urpan Development have declared them unsuitable for new Goveriunentsubsidized housing.

title: Byrne Prods Port Unit on Mass Transit
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne has instructed the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to come up with a masstransit proposal showing exactly how it intends to use its planning expertise and borrowing capacity to develop major transit improvements for New Jersey.

title: Miss Aasen Plays Divertimento Role With Bright Charm
description: Divertimento No. 15 is one of those sublime ballets that offer the talented an opportunity to sparkle or to be as dull as dishwater. Muriel Aasen made a bubbly first appearance in the production with the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater Friday evening.

title: Fish Find a Place in a Walkup's Landscape
description: If, as real estate brokers are given to saying, elegance is expressed in exclusivity, the 20 or so tenants of fivestory Yorkville walkup may have a unique status symbol. They have as their front yard what may be the city's only fully stocked fishpond.

title: Second Farah Plant to Open
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 22 (UPI)The Farah Manufacturing Co., showing a rapid recovery from a long strike, will reopen a second San Antonio plant, next Month and increase employment beyond prestrike levels. William F. Farah, president of the nation's largest men's slacks concern, said Wednesday that his Highway 90 plant would open July. 8 to join the Frio City Road Plant that returned to production in May.

title: Campaign Tax Dollar Loses
description: BOSTON, June 22 (AP) The Massachusetts House has rejected legislation that would permit taxpayers to allocate $1 of their income tax to a political fund. An opponent of the measure said it would be incredible to start collecting money before a policy decision was made on the public financing concept.

title: Acrostic puzzle
description: Guess the words defined below and write them over their numbered dashes. Then transfer each letter to the correspondingly numbered square in the pattern. Black squares indicate word endings. The filled pattern will contain a quotation reading from left to right. The first letters of the guessed words will form an acrostic giving author's name and title of work.

title: New Skyline Emerging On East Side North of 86th
description: A spurt in residential construction north of 86th Street and east of Fifth Avenue is producing an extraordinary new area of contemporary urban housingthe Upper Upper East, Side.

title: World News Briefs
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 22 (AP)A 24  year  old American missionary nurse was freed by antiGovernment guerrillas of the Eritrean Liberation Front today and said she felt fine after her fourweek ordeal.

title: A Teacher Of Teachers Insists on a Real World
description: Lawrence A. Cremin, an education historian and philosopher, recently was named the seventh president of Columbia University's Teachers College. In a talk with Donald Johnston, a Week in Review editor, he discussed teacher training and the future of Teachers College.

title: A Mandatory Study Of Nazi Holocaust Is Urged in Schools
description: Three Brooklyn Assemblymen intend to introduce a bill at the next legislative session in January to make instruction about the Nazi holocaust a standard unit in all high school courses on modern history.

title: Epilogue
description: Dr. Howard B. Levy, a former Army doctor who opposed the war in Vietnam, has lost his appeal of a courtmartial conviction for refusing to conduct a training program for Special Forces medical aid men.

title: Theater In Brooklyn Focuses On Children
description: It's something they can almost reach out and touchit's like children's theater should be, completely magic, said Mrs. Jane Stanton, describing what she called theonly teenage summer stock troupe in the New York area, the Popcorn and Popsickle Theater.

title: Gritty places and strong women
description: Margaret Laurence's fifth novel is ambitious and compelling but not quite brought off. The life of Morag Gunn, a Canadian novelist in middle age, is written in two layers and three styles. The strength, and zest of the book are in the Memorybank Movies of Morag's orphaned childhood in Manawaka, a bleak town on the Southern Ontario plains. Her foster mother Prin, goodnatured and feebleminded, fattens grotesquely on the comfort of sweets. Her foster father Christie, the town garbage collector, suffers from shellshock and reverse pride at ostracism: glorying through his drunken rants in Highland ancestry that captures Morag's imagination. The two languages of the meat of the book are Christie's rhetoric: And it was old men and old women with thin shanks and men in in their prime and women with the child inside them and a great scattering of small children, like, and all of them was driven away from the lands of their fathers and onto the wild rocks of the shore, then, to fish if they could and pry the shellfish off on the rocks, there, for food, and Morag's earthyshrewd, bitter observations of the smalltown world: At four o'clock they can go home. She still does not know how to read. Some school this turned out to be. But has learned one thing for sure. Hang onto your  and never let them know you are ascared.

title: 8Oar Crew Title Won By Harvard
description: SEATTLE, June 22Harvard finished its rowing season triumphantly today, confirming what the experts have been saying all season, that this year's varsity is an exemplary one in along line of Harry Parkercoached Cantab crews.

title: Textbook on Creation Rejected as Inaccurate
description: ATLANTA, June 22 (UPI) A textbook that teaches the divine theory of creation has been turned down by the Atlanta School Board on the grounds that it is biased and inaccurate.

title: Bulletproof Vests for Police
description: LOS ANGELES, June 22 (UPI) The City Council has appropriated $350,000 to buy bulletproof vests for the city's 7,000 policemen after such a vest saved the life of Frank F. Goulard, an officer who bought it on his own.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThere was a disturbing flavor of businessasusual when W. Bonham Crawford, president of the Edison Electric Institute, discussed the electric utility industry's problems here the other day.

description: By Doris Buchanan Smith. 222 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $5.50. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: Mrs. Dryfoos Wed To Eldon Mayer Jr.
description: Mrs. Sally Allison Dryfoos of New York, widow of John M. Dryfoos, was married in Beach Haven, N. J., yesterday afternoon to Eldon C. Mayer Jr. of Princeton, N. J. The ceremony was performed in Holy Innocents Episcopal Church by the Rev. Gilbert D. Martin.

title: Robin needed time
description: Leg of lamb, for God's sake! You have an overdeveloped sense of wonder. Jeffrey Rabinowitz is chiding Robin Parks, whom he calls Robinowitz, because of the hard time she's having becoming a vegetarian. He is an architect from East 62d Street, she an English teacher from patrician Boston. They are building a house in rural New Hampshire. Thoreau is their hero, and they both prefer a Brandenburg Concerto to the Grateful Dead, but they still have their differences. Jeff, whom the Peace Corps sent to Africa, isn't as bothered by the black flies, and Robin, a closet carnivore, keeps imagining juicy roasts on silver platters.

title: Lucks, 13, Leaps 184 in Youth Meet
description: John Lucks, a 13yearold student at Birch Wathen School, set a meet record of 18 feet 4 inches in winning the long jump yesterday at the citywide track and field meet of the United States Youth Games at Downing Stadium.

title: Gardens
description: APARADE of young trees lines State Street in Westport, Conn. Where just a few years ago there were monotonous treeless stretches along this heavily traveled four miles, there now are maples, plane trees, honey locusts, red oaks, crabapples, hawthorns and ginkgos. The Greening of the Post Road is becoming a reality.

title: News of the Screen
description: Having run the artistic gamut from fiction to acting (Anna Lucasta) to prolific playwriting (Wedding Band, Trouble in Mind, etc.), Alice Childress is now beaded toward the movie scene. Robert B. Radnitz, producer of such films as Sounder and the recent Where the Lilies Bloom, has acquired rights to her 1973 novel, A Hero Ain't Nothin but a Sandwich, and has also signed the black author to adapt her wellreceived book to the screen.

title: Curtain Rises Wednesday at Garden State Center
description: HOLMDELThe Garden State Arts Center will open its 1974 season on Wednesday with a concert by the National Symphony. As usual, the 5,000seat amphitheater will be the scene again this summer of topflight classical and popular entertainment.

title: DR. ROBERT H. IVY
description: Dr. Robert H. Ivy, a retired plastic surgeon who had been a longtime faculty member at the University of Pennsylvania, died in his sleep yesterday at his summer home in Skytop, Pa. He was 93 years old and lived also in Lansdowne, Pa.

title: Red Smith
description: Mr. Foreman, said a man from somewhere else, the United Nations is an organization for peace. Do you think fighting contributes to peace?

title: Full Disability Pay Urged
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)  A United Mine Workers official has urged a Senate panel to pass legislation that would allow disabled workers to receive 100 per cent of their former pay. Dr. Lorin Kerr, the union's occupational health director, testified Thursday before a Senate Labor subcommittee.

title: Driver's Widow Wins Case
description: LEWISTOWN, Pa., June 22 (AP)  The family of a truck driver killed while the police were chasing another vehicle has won $200,000 damages in Mifflin County Court. Lewistown Borough was ordered Wednesday to pay the widow and four children of Amos Emery, Brookville. Mr. Emery was forced off the road during a chase on March 17, 1970.
