description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 1 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 1 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 1 P.M.)

title: Aspira Aids Passaic Students
description: PASSAIC  Sixty students of Hispanic origin have found a new lease on life through the efforts of the Passaic High School chapter of Aspira, a federally funded selfhelp program for Spanishspeaking teenagers.

title: Fashion
description: The best looking sunglasses around this summer have come a long way from the showoff bugeyed goggles worn as status symbols by the beautiful people of the nineteensixties. These are cleareyed shades, intended to keep eyes beautifully squintfree  and visible. Rims are narrow, if they exist at all. And the lenses often as not are dark at the top, light at the bottomjust like an automobile windshield.

title: Evelyn Cutler, F. A. Goodhue 3d. Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Cutler of Dresden Mills, Me., have announced the engagement. of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Treat Cutler, to Francis Abbot Goodhue 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Jr. of Mount Kisco, N. Y. Mrs. Goodhue was recently nominated the Republican party candidate for the State Assembly in the 93d Assembly District.

title: Carole Leavy Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Leavy of Paramus, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Jeanne Leavy, to Dennis E. Kuruc, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Kuruc of Garfield, N. J.

title: Tax Proposal At Crossroads
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne and top officials in his administration are repbrtedly at the crossroads involving the fate of his efforts to reform New Jersey's tax system.

title: Composing the Alliance
description: RICHMOND, Va.Henry Kissinger is an authority on Metternich, the Austrian diplomatic genius whom many consider a prototype of the brilliant Secretary of State. Asked once why he had failed to achieve his ultimate policy ambitions, Metternich replied: Because I sometimes governed Europe, never Austria. Some critics have speculated that Mr. Kissinger's weak point was that he sometimes governed the world, never Europe.

title: Elizabeth Robertson Engaged To L. R. Arnold, Law Student
description: Miss Elizabeth Averett Robertson, a greatgranddaughter of President Grover Cleveland, plans to be married in September to Laurence Ray Arnold, a law student at Emory University.

title: Grandmother's Bequest Helps Youth in Fencing
description: Mike Marx, a 15yearold high school sophomore, came all the way from Portland, Ore., to take part in the national fencing championships, which began an eightday stand at the Hotel Commodore yesterday morning. Hischief concern was getting past the opening preliminary round.

title: Whales Above Whalers
description: What meaning have the songs of the humpback whale? What does the blue whale's enormous and complex brain signify by way of intelligence? Is it true, as believed, that these magnificent creatures are immune to malignanciesand if so, why?

title: Our Plays Are Tamer Than Reality
description: ONCE upon a time in the theater there was a form called melodrama. We got rid of it. We got rid of it simply because it was not lifelike, not truthful. In melodrama, highly placed people tended to behave like thugs, or even to be thugs, darkly hatched conspiracies were spun to entrap the innocent, doors were bashed down if that was the only way of accomplishing villainous objectives, kidnappings were common (or at least that was often what the man with the moustache had in mind, and was foiled at), dastardly lies were told, guns went off.

title: Some Features of the Economy Are Very Dangerous
description: WASHINGTONFor the first time in a generation, some serious people are talking about the danger of a world slump or depression. The Economist of London, for example, describes the Labor Government of Harold Wilson as facing a deteriorating economic situation even grimmer than faced the last minority Labor Government in 1929.31as big slump, but with very serious inflation. Geoffrey Barraclough writes in The New York Review of Books of the coming depression, though he does not expect it this year or next. Concentrating on the extraordinary problems posed by the explosion world oil prices, Walter Levy tells in Foreign Affairs of a situation comparable in Its potential for economic and political disaster to the Great Depression of the 1930's,

title: Barbara Hatch Bride Of W. B. Spillman Jr.
description: Miss Barbara Sherman Hatch, who has made her home in London recently, was married there yesterday to William Bert Spillman Jr., a doctoral candidate in physics at Northeastern University.

title: Some Are Frightened By Casual Acceptance Of the Sledgehammer
description: The almost casual way in which so many business and investment people accept the soundness of the Federal. Reserve Board's high interest rate policy is frightening. It's as if there were no question concerning the efficacy, and/or equity of using monetary policy in its crudest, most sledgehammerlike form to stop inflation.

title: Music
description: IT is almost too pat, too predictable, too much like one of those pieties that musicappreciation books are foreve mumbling. In this year, the centennial Of their births, both Charles Ives and Ainold Schoenberg are being accorded the classic coldshoulder treatanent by the most prestigious music festivals in their respective homelands. Neither composer is, of course, without honor elsewhere: before the year is out commemorative concerts by the hundreds will have been given. But what could be more platitudinous than that the Vienna Festival, which ended yesterday, offered not a note of Schoenberg's music and that the Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood, which opens on July 5, has programed nothing by the most illustrious of New England  not to mention American  composers?

title: SHOP TALK
description: MADISONThe Far Corners has an interesting and varied assortment of folk art and utilitarian objects made by craftsmen all over the world.

title: Smith First In Sprints On Coast
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 23Willie Smith of Uniondale (L.I,) High School captured the 100meter and 200meter sprints as New York City area athletes won five events in the Golden West national scholastic track and field invitation meet at Hughes Stadium last night.

title: Animal Waste Emerging As a Valuable Resource
description: DENVER, June 23Animal manure is emerging as a valued member of the family of world resources. A proliferating band of Rumpelstiltskins are turning manure into feed, fuel and fertilizer.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Miss Babashoff Is Triple Winner

title: Red Sox Beat Indians, 80, Petrocelli Slams 2 Homers
description: Last season when the Boston Red Sox finished eight games behind the Baltimore Orioles in the American League's Eastern Division despite a team batting average of .267, they decided that the answer to better luck in 1974 was to acquire some improved pitching.

title: Whalers Pick Wesleyan
description: HARTFORD, June 23 (AP) The New England Whalers of the World Hockey League will train at Wesleyan University's hockey rink in Middletown, Conn., for the 197475 season, Jack Kelley, general manager said today. The team will be at Wesleyan from Sept. 20 to Oct. 3.

title: Operatic Airs Offset the Rain as 5,000 Salute Italians
description: HOLMDEL, June 23An allday rain curbed some of the activities but not the enthusiasm of performers and audience celebrating the fourth annual Italian festival at the Garden State Arts Center here today.

title: Producers Withhold No Offshore Gas, Industry Unit Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 23The Natural Gas Supply Committee, an industry group that represents producers, said today that no significant volume of offshore gas in the Gulf of Mexico was being withheld from the market.

title: Solitary Confinement Opposed in a Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 23A trial challenging the right of San Quentin Prison officials to keep six inmates in solitary confinement opened here last week before United States District Judge Alfonso J. Zirpoli.

title: Brooklyn Woman Stabbed And Raped in Prospect Park
description: A 34yearold Brooklyn wornman was found stabbed and raped yesterday morning near the boathouse, in Prospect Park, the police said. Her condition was listed as critical at Maimonides Hospital.

title: BANKRUPTCY HELD A CONSUMER LOSS
description: Consumers lose about $500million a year because bankruptcy laws and procedures are confusing and give large creditors such as banks and investors priority in recouping funds from insolvent businesses, according to legal specialists in the field.

title: Mrs. Amend Bride Of Richard Schalk
description: In the Holy Family Chapel at the College of New Rochelle yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Lois Scarpino Amend, widow of Myles B. Amend Jr., was married to Richard Riordan Schalk, publicrelations manager here for the Aluminum Company of America.

title: Lauda Wins Dutch Race In Ferrari
description: ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, June 23  In a race that made watching the seagulls seem exciting by comparison, Ferrari proved its reliability today with a convincing one, two finish in the Dutch Grand Prix.

title: U.S. Will Pay $530Million In Raises Delayed by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP1)Officials said today that the Federal Government would disburse $530million additional in pay over the next few months because of court rulings that President Nixon illegally delayed pay rises in 1972.

title: Father Celebrates Release Of Nurse by Ethiopia Rebels
description: FREEHOLD, June 23A minister whose 24yearold daughter was released unharmed yesterday after being held prisoner by Ethiopian rebels since May 27 gave prayerful thanks at a special service this morning and then celebrated with 100 friends at a hastily prepared buffet luncheon this afternoon.

title: Sandra Haynie Golf Victor on 73288
description: SUTTON, Mass., June 23 (AP)Sandra Haynie, shot a string of early birdies in the rain and held on over the ??ack nine to win the Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship tournament today for the second time. She carded a 72hole score of 288, four under par.

title: Tropical Depression, in Gulf
description: MIAMI, June 23 (UPI)  A tropical depression that could become the first tropical storm of the 1974 season moved out today over the southwest Gulf of Mexico. Small craft from the Yucatan Peninsula westward were advised to stay in port. The National Hurricane Center in Miami said the depression was nearing the strength of tropical storm.

title: Israel Bona Chief Appointed
description: Michael Arnon, onetime secretary of Israel's Cabinet, has been appointed president and hief executive officer of the Israel Bond Organization, with headquarters at 215 Park AveItte South. Mr. Arnon, a former Israeli Ambassador to Ghana and consul geenral in New York, will be responsible for the worldwide sales of Israel bonds.

title: Miss Cuningham Westchester Bride
description: Miss Elizabeth Bayard Cuningham and E. W. Richard Templeton were married yesterday afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church in New Rochelle, N.Y., by the Rev. Kenneth C. Morris.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: New Summary and index, Page 31

title: Bridge New Yorkers Capture Lead In Grand National Playoffs
description: New York's representatives dominated the Grand National zonal playoff matches in Boston during the weekend. Sam Stayman, Victor Mitchell, Jim Cayne, Matt Granovetter and Joel Stuart, all of New York, built up commanding leads against two other teams contending for the right to compete in the national quarterfinals next month.

title: Poland Ousts Italy From World Cup, 21
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, June 23Sit down, Italian fans, and take a deep breath. Italy, the choice of many to reach the World Cup soccer final, lost to Poland, 21, today and was eliminated.

title: Conference of Leftist Catholics May Lead to New Italian Party
description: ROME, June 23A conference of leftwing dissenters within the Roman Catholic Church that ended today may lead to the birth of a second Catholic political party in Italy.

title: Local Purges in Portugal Enable the Communists to Gain Ground
description: LISBON, June 23  A purge of municipal councils associated with the ousted dictatorship is giving the Portuguese Communist party one of its best opportunities yet to establish a. local power base.

title: Colbert Captures Four Man Golf Playoff
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 23Jim Colbert, who combines one of the sunniest dispositions on the pro tour with guts and a good putting stroke, won the American Golf Classic today on the second hole of a Suddendeath playoff involving four players.

title: Protecting Privacy
description: The American capacity to collect and to store information about individuals and the American tendency express ineffectual alarm at that development have grown enormously in the last decade and a half. Unfortunately, Congress's ability to develop legislation safeguarding the individual's right to privacy has lagged far behind computer technology. The nation is left with a vague sense that information monsters inevitably threaten to transform the society in which we live.

title: NIXON AIDE BALKS AT SPECULATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 23Leonard Garment, a counsel to President Nixon, declined today to say whether Mr. Nixon would abide by the decision the. Supreme Court ordered him to provide material to the Watergate special prosecutor.

title: 40 Reported Dead in Floods As Rains Engulf Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, June 23 (AP)Forty persons were reported dead and 50,000 homeless as heavy rains engulfed the hilly Chittagong district in southeastern Bangladesh, officials said today.

title: Major Bills in Congress
Miss Carillo Wins Eastern Net Title
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 23  Mary Carillo of Douglaston, Queens, the fourthseeded player, won the Eastern clay court women's singles championship today, defeating secondseeded Barbara Goldman of Fort Lee, N. J., 63, 76, at the Indoor Racquet Club of New Rochelle.

title: REPORT SAYS INDIA PLANS HBOMB TEST
description: NEW DELHI, June 23 (AP)An Indian news agency reported today that the Indian Atomic Energy Commission planned to detonate a hydrogen explosive device following up its underground atomic test last month.

title: Conservative La Jolla Finds Coexistence Difficult With Pioneer Nude Bathing Beach
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., June 23 First came the lowflying aircraft, and next there were hovering helicopters, and then United States Navy warships patrolling unusually close to shore.

title: SHIPMENTS CLIMB IN MACHINE TOOLS
description: New orders for machine tools slipped stightly in May, to $283.9million from the $285.5million total reported in April, but rose 25.7 per cent above the $225.8million of new orders placed in May, 1973, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported over the weekend.

title: Advertising: Consumer Safety
description: The National Advertising Review Board has released the report of its first consultative panelits first effort to go beyond matters of truth and accuracy and offer guidelines to prevent possible harmful effects from advering.

title: Colson's Religious Experience: Its Significance for Evangelicals
description: WASHINGTON, June 23When Charles W. Colson left the Federal Courthouse here Friday after being sentenced to prison for his part in the Watergate scandals, he looked, with his furrowed brow and slightly disheveled hair, like a little boy about to cry. He also looked, with his hornrimmed glasses and sober expression, a little like an owl.

title: NURSE'S RELEASE HAILED BY FATHER
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., June 23A minister whose 24  year  old daughter was released unharmed yesterday after being held prisoner by Ethiopian rebels since May 27 gave prayerful thanks at a special service this morning and then celebrated with 100 friends at a hastily prepared buffet luncheon this afternoon.

title: Center for Black Culture Thriving Now in Boston
description: BOSTON, June 23There is still a Star of David chiseled into the stone facade over the door at 122 Elm Hill Avenue in Boston's impoverished black district of RoXbury, but inside there's not much that is Jewish.

title: Posters in Peking Tell of Bloodshed In Rightist Uprising
description: PEKING, June 23 (Reuters)Violence has broken out in China's southeastern province of Kiangsi, according to wall posters appearing in Peking today.

title: Ford Flies to Minneapolis
description: MONTEREY, Calif., June 23 (AP)  Vice President Ford, refreshed by a weekend of golf, flew to Minneapolis today for another day on the links before going on to Chicago for a speech to the 123d annual convention of the American Medical Association.

title: Showdown Near Over Double Hulls for Tankers
description: WASHINGTON, June 23An interdepartmental showdown is fast approaching on the question of requiring new Americanbuilt oil tankers operating between United States ports to have double bottoms for increased protection against oil spills in event of grounding or collision.

title: Charles Lewis, Taught Golf To Woodrow Wilson, Dies
description: COLLINSVILLE, Okla., June 22 (AP)Charles Frank Lewis, golf instructor to President Woodrow Wilson and British Kings Edward VIII and George VI, died yesterday. He was 85 years old, and had retired in 1958.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE COMEDY OF SURVIVAL. By Joseph W. Meeker. Foreword by Konrad Lorenz. 217 pages. Scribner's. $8.95.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Shoemaker Again Takes Hollywood Gold Cup Race
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 23  Bill Shoemaker, who scered a great personal triumph here a year ago in riding Kennedy Road to an upset victory in the Hollywood Gold Cup, did it again today aboard Tree of Knowledge and almost doubled the total earnings of his mount by taking the $90,000 first prize.

title: Dutiful Beame Enters Limelight
description: SAN DIEGO, June 23Mayor Beame made a dutiful, but at times impatient, first appearance this weekend on the stage that his predecessor, John V. Lindsay, had used to advance a Presidential campaign.

title: Sandra Haynie Golf Victor on 73288
description: SUTTON, Mass., June 23 (AP)Sandra Haynie shot a string of early birdies in the rain and held on over the back nine to win the Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship tournament today for the second time. She carded a 72hole score of 288, four under par.

title: Armed Youths Free 5 at Bridgeport Jail
description: Four armed, masked youths invaded a Bridgeport, Conn., juvenile detention center early yesterday and fled with five teenaged inmatesthree boys and two girlsafter shooting matron in the hip and locking two men guards in the escapees' cells, the police said.

title: Events Today
description: LUCHOW'S OOMPAH BAND, Bryant Park, 12:15.

title: Black Groups Criticize H.E.W. On School Desegregation Plans
description: WASHINGTON, June 23A decision by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to accept plans for the desegregation of statecontrolled colleges and universities in eight states is receiving sharp criticism from black groups in two of the states.

title: Major Bills in Congress
Fire Destroys Rare Cars
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 23 (AP)Seven antique cars, including four rare models, were destroyed by fire yesterday on the estate of Robert C. Sprague, vice president of the Sprague Electric Company. Mr. Sprague estimated the damage at $500,000. The moll included two Model H 1906 Cadillacs, a 1902 Wheeler, a 1909 Stevens Duryea, a 1925 Silver Ghost Rolls Royce, a custom 1963 Ford station wagon and a 1909 Stanley Steamer E2.

title: Wimbledon: A Smashing Field Is Set
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 23That missing magic comes back to Wimbledon tomorrow when John Newcombe, who has not lost a match here since 1969, heads a field that at last includes the elite of tennis after a twoyeargap due to bans and boycotts.

title: Profiteers in Cambodia Find Food Is Now Gold
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia With her major cities besieged by Communistled insurgents, Cambodia has become a paradise for a new kind of profiteeringnot in gold or opium, but in food.

title: HOUSE CANDIDATE RUNS WITH NO FOE
description: DAYTON, Ohio, June 23 Representative Charles W. Whalen Jr. moved easily yesterday from house to house along Deeds Avenue in the lower middleclass section of north Dayton preceded by two youthful volunteers who rang doorbells and told the people that their Congressman was walking down the street and would like to stop by briefly at the door to say hello.

title: Dr. E. F. Jarvis Weds Mrs. Mary J. Zimmer
description: Mrs. Mary Jane Zimmer and Dr. Embree F. Jarvis were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Theodore Hoskins in the Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport, Conn.

title: Large Soviet Purchases Brighten Japan's Cultured Pearl Trade
description: TOKYO, June 23The Soviet Union's resumption of purchasing large quantities of cultured pearls from Japan is giving the sagging pearl industry here a ray of hope for the revival of an export boom.

title: OldTimers Look Back on DodgerGiant Rivalry
description: LOS ANGELES, June 23A continentwidth removed from its origins, which go back 85 years, the richest rivalry in American sportsbetween the baseball Dodgers and Giantswas celebrated again today in an oldtimers' day ceremony here.

title: MRS. JOHN DORRANCE JR.
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP)  Mrs. Angeline Carter Dorrance, wife of John T. Dorrance Jr., board chairman of the Campbell Soup Company, died today at Bryn Mawr Hospital. She was 59 years old.Surviving are two daughters and a brother.

title: Armed Youths Free 5 at Bridgeport Jail
description: Four armed, masked youths invaded a Bridgeport, Conn., juvenile detention center early yesterday and fled with five teenaged inmatesthree boys and two girlsafter shooting matron in the hip and locking two men guards in the escapees' cells, the police said.

title: TV Review
description: In Male Menopause: The Pause That Perplexes, the Special of the Week on Public Television tonight at 8 o'clock, Richard V. Brown, the producer, successfully realizes only about half the potential of his subject. That half is well done, pinpointing the mental and spiritual crises of the middleage male trapped betwen youth worship and obsolescence in the job marketplace.

title: Colbert Captures FourMan Golf Playoff
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 23Jim Colbert, who combines one of the sunniest dispositions on the pro tour with guts and a good putting stroke, won the American Golf Classic today on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff involving four players.

title: Kissinger Feted by Rockefellers
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 23Henry A. Kissinger played another starring role last night, this time cast as a new bridegroom, rather than as Secretary of State.

title: AUSTRIANS ELECT SOCJALIST AGAIN
description: VIENNA, June 23Rudolf Kirchschlger, a lawyer and diplomat who has been his country's Foreign Minister since 1970, was elected President of Austria today to succeed Franz Jonas, who died. April 24.

title: Georgia Sheriff Slain
description: CEDARTOWN, Ga., June 23 (AP)  The sheriff of Polk County in north Georgia was shot and killed early today as he and another man investigated a burglar alarm, the police said. Sheriff Frank Lott, 64 years old, was killed and his companion, 19yearold Benjamin S. Clark Jr., was wounded.

title: SeventhDay Adventists Open 71st Annual Camp
description: TRANQUILITY, June 23This pastoral location in the northwest part of the state took on the trappings of an oldfashioned revival meeting this weekend as hundreds of people pitched tents or set up campers and trailers for the 71st annual meeting of the state's Seventhday Adventists.

title: Nigerians in New York: A Big, Happy Family Though Loosely Related
description: There is a saying among Nigerians living here that if you go to the South Pole, you'll find a cousin. And he'll pass you on to cousins in Hawaii, or London, or New York. Actually, there is no word for cousin in the Nigerian languages; the stranger on your doorstep will announce that he is your brother, a word that wraps up all relationships, including that of a friend of a friend.

title: Young Democrats Elect
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 23 (AP)Robert Harding, 25 years old, a graduate student in urban and regional management and planning at the University of Massachusetts, was elected president of the Massachusetts Young Democrats here yesterday.

title: Broken Glasses at the Waldorf
description: From deep within him, deep below the smooth face and the clever jokes and the funny poems, the ugly core of cruelty in Muhammad All occasionally surfaces. It was there to be seen when he tortured Floyd Patterson nearly a decade ago for being a white American, when he later punished Ernie Terrell for not calling him by his Black Muslim name, when he recently insulted Joe Frazier's intelligence. It was there to be seen Saturday night when, in a hysterical frenzy at the boxing writers dinner, he was flinging water glasses from the dais at George Foreman after they had been pried apart in a serious scuffle. It also was there to be heard when he was snarling, I'll beat your Christian [anatomy deleted], you white flagwaving [expletive deleted] you, a reference to when the world heavyweight champion waved a small American flag in the ring following his 1968 Olympic goldmedal victory. On the other occasions when his cruelty surfaced, Ali always retained his cool. But this time he lost the poise he prides himself on. He may have also lost the psychological edge he always seeks over his opponents. When they meet, again in Zaire, Africa, on Sept. 24, that could be important.

title: Passaic Parishioners Protest Plan to Close Catholic School
description: PASSAIC, June 23  More than 500 persons protested at an outdoor rally at the Holy Rosary Church this afternoon against the decision of the Roman Catholic Diocese to consolidate the church school with three other parochial elementary schools in this city.

title: Lexa Logue Has Nuptials
description: Miss Alexandra Woods Logue, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Gibson Logue Jr. of Philadelphia, was married there yesterday afternoon to Ian Scott Shrank,, son of Mr and Mrs. Leon Shrank of CoIonia, N. J. Rabbi Steven Westman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Spoleto: Moliere Farce
description: SPOLETO, Italy, June 23  The special distinction of Gian Carlo Menotti's Spoleto. Festival is its originality. It never copies, it always invents. It displays new young musicians, new works in dance and drama, or even just new ways of looking at classics. Thus this festival in this oldest and loveliest of festival cities is perpetually young and perpetually renewed.

title: Mrs. Sue Wertheimer Kuskin Is Married to Peter F. Frank
description: Mrs, Sue Wertheimer Kuskin of Scarsdale, director of community services for the Preventive Medicine InstituteStrang Clinic, was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Feldman Frank of New York, executive vice president of Kahn & Feldman, a yarnprocessing company, of which his father is president. Justice Sidney A. Fine of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Lefkowitz Advises Renters On the Interest on Security
description: Apartment tenants who have not received interest on their rentsecurity deposits were advised yesterday that they could demand the interest money from their landlords.

title: Schuykill Crews Win Two Events
description: The Schuylkill Boat Club of Philadelphia won both the intermediate and senior eightoared events ofthe 74th annual Metropolitan rowing championship regatta yesterday on the Orchard Beach lagoon in the Bronx.

title: Lynn Wechsler Becomes Bride Of G. M. Kramer
description: At Temple Emanuel in Mount Lebanon, Pa., yesterday, Miss Lynn Barth Wechsler and Glenn Morton Kramer, 1974 graduates of Washington University in St. Louis, were married by Rabbi Leonard Winograd.

title: MAYORS HEAD OFF A DIVISIVE BATTLE OVER WATERGATE
description: SAN DIEGO, June 23The nation's Mayors have apparently headed off what they feared would be a bitter and divisive battle by rejecting three Watergaterelated resolutions.

title: Communists Again Quit Truce Teams in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 23The Vietcong and the North Vietnamese have announced that they are suspending participation in the two ceasefire commissions here in protest over purported acts of sabotage by Saigon and the United States.

title: New Swiss Canton Voted in Jura. Area By a Close Margin
description: GENEVA, June 23A new Swiss canton formed from half of the 565squaremile Jura region, a predominantly Frenchspeaking area of western Switzerland, became a certainty today when its residents voted to annual a decision of the 1815 Congress of Vienna.

title: A.M.A. FACES RIFT ON PEER REVIEW
description: CHICAGO, June 23  The American Medical Association formally opened its 123d annual convention here today with its leadership hoping to prevent an open split in the medical profession over the issue of peer review.

title: Major Copper Producers Meeting Today on Prices
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, June 23A fixed minimum price for copper seems the likely outcome of a meeting of ministers from the world's four major copperexporting countries that opens here in the Zambian capital tomorrow.

title: MEMORIAL HONORS KATHARINE CORNELL
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., June 23 (AP)Stage and film stars mingled with shellfisher men at the Town Hall here today to pay tribute to Katharine Cornell during a twohour memorial gathering. There were no religious services.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Little did Donia Dickerson, a Nashville art broker, dream when she commissioned twin bronze crosses for herself and her husband for their 18th wedding anniversary last July that she would be starting something.

title: ROCKETS TO TINT THE SKIES TONIGHT
description: A rocket barrage that promises to be more spectacular than any such space experiment to date is scheduled to paint the skies above the East Coast in rainbow colors tonight, weather permitting.

title: Terrier Best at Staten Island
description: With the rain beating down, a pert wirehaired fox terrier gave a smart performance and never gave up as he marched to the bestinshow trophy on the parade grounds at Fort Wadsworth yesterday in the Staten Island Kennel Club show.

title: ROCKETS TO TINT THE SKIES TONIGHT
description: A rocket barrage that promises to be inore spectacular than any such space ex periment to date is scheduled to paint the skies above the East Coast in rainbow colors tonight, weather permitting.

title: New Hope for SALT
description: It's not startling to find the Pentagon and the Kremlin in disagreement; but when they agree, that's news!

title: JOHN E. LONG
description: John E. Long, who retired as president of the NassauSuffolk Building Trades Council and as business agent of Bricklayers Union Local 30 in 1964, died yesterday in Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, L. I. lie was 71 years old and lived in Brightwaters, L. I.

title: Sindona Associate Leaving Franklin
description: A director closely associated with Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who is the biggest shareholder in the Franklin New York Corporationthe parent of the Franklin National Bankis resigning from the board of the holding company.

title: RISING PROFITS SEEN FOR OIL EXPORTERS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 23 (AP)Economists for the United Nations say that because of last year's quadrupling of oil prices, earnings of organized oilexporting countries may well reach $85billion in 1974, over five times the 1972 level.

title: Distinctive Fallout Patterns for Bullets Reported by Scientists
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 21A bullet whizzing through the air, it has been found here at Pennsylvania State University, leaves a distinctive fallout pattern of metallic residues on the surface below its flight path as it proceeds from gun to target.

title: Brown Boveri and Lehigh Awarded T.V.A. Contracts
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 23 (AP)The Tennessee Valley Authority announced over the weekend two contract awards for work in its system.

title: 59 Graduate From Lower East Side Prep School
description: Fiftynine youngsters were graduated yesterday from New York's only specialized school for dropouts and for students with language problems who have recently immigrated to this country, and 42 of them said they expected to enter college next fall.

title: Traps for Bubonic Plague
description: ESTES PARK, Colo., June 23 (AP)  The State Health Department has set up tiny insect traps in Rocky Mountain National Park in an effort to kill fleas on deer mice that may carry bubonic plague. A deer mouse was found Friday to be infested with a flea carrying the disease. About 700 persons were ordered out of a 30acre campground area and the tiny tube traps to kill fleas were set up.

title: Bert Frohman, 74, Dead; Director of the Eden Roc
description: Bert Frohman, a former vaudeville performer who had recently been executive director of the Eden Roc Hotel in Miami Beach, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 16625 Powells Cove Boulevard, Beechhurst, Queens.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Attempt to Oust Chief of Police Perils Atlanta's Racial Harmony
description: ATLANTA, June 23When MaYnard Jackson was inaugurated sic months ago as Atlanta's first black Mayor, many members of this city's legendary legion of civic boosters saw his installation as ultimate proof that Atlanta was, indeed, the Southern city that was too busy, to hate.

title: Mrs. Ellen Lew Bride of Dr. Harlan Spitz
description: Mrs. Ellen Handler Lew of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Dr. Harlan Spitz, a pediatrician, were married last evening at the St. Moritz. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Avraham Albrecht.

title: City U. Names Panel To Look Into Fees Charged Students
description: A wideranging study of mandated studentactivity fees at the 19 colleges of the City University is to be made this summer by a newly appointed ninemember commission.

title: Pairing Women With the Same Vacation Idea
description: He who travels alone sometimes gets soaked. This has been true ever since Noah's Ark where, one suspects, advertised rates were for double occupancy.

title: $10Million TV Drama Project Set Up to Spur Quality Writing
description: A $10million project, which its sponsors hope will create a new body of American literature through television, has been established for public TV through grants from the Ford Foundation, the National Endowment for the Arts and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: Model for the Catskills
description: The Adirondack Park Agency has again demonstrated the advantage of having a permanent and official planning body for a great natural resource area. By vote of six to four, the agency has denied a petition to expose seventeen lakes and ponds in designated wilderness areas to the noise and pollution of aircraft.

title: Profiteers in Cambodia Find Food Is Now Gold
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia With her major cities besieged by Communistled insurgents, Cambodia has become a paradise for a new kind of profiteeringnot in gold or opium, but in food.

title: Bresnahan Gets Post
description: RENTON, Wash., June 23 (AP)John J. Bresnahan of Rye, N.Y., was appointed administrative officer of the Thoroughbred Racing Association yesterday by Frank M. Basil, president of the T.R.A. Bresnahan, 38 years old, will take over duties previously handled by Spencer Drayton.

title: National Airlines in Profit
description: MIAMI, June 23 (UPI)  National Airlines announced Saturday its highest May profits on record and said in appreciation it had mailed out bonuses to its 8,000 employes of $100 each. The record earnings for May were $2.5million, or 30 cents per share, compared with $1million, or 12 cents a share, in May 1973. Net income for the first 11 months of fiscal 1974 was $28million, or $3.29 per share.

title: Meeting Reported Scheduled On Rhode Island Refinery
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 23 (UPI)A meeting to discuss the drawing up of a prelimininary oilrefinery proposal has been arranged between Rhode Island's Governor, Philip W. Noel and representatives of Aristotle Onassis.

title: Tennis Ban Spurs Suit By W.T.T.

title: JEROME L. BLACK
description: Jerome L. Black, a lawyer and executive director of Merlin Industries, Inc., a silver reclamation concern, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Bellevue Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 400 East 56th Street.

title: Rag Hijacking Thwarted After Show at Waldorf
description: Four men who had allegedly plotted to hijack truckload of valuable Persian rugs that had been exhibited yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel were arrested last night by a 12man squad of detectives and Federal customs agents, the police reported.

title: Russian Church, Short of Clergy, Trains Many Priests by Mail
description: ZAGORSK, U.S.S.R.  The Russian Orthodox Church has a shortage of clergy and is offering theological correspondence courses to hundreds of parish priests ordained without formal seminary training to try to fill the gap, according to a leading church prelate.

title: REBOZO DISPUTED ON A HUGHES DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 23The staff of the Senate Watergate committee has obtained evidence that contradicts Charles G. Rebozo's public assertions that no one from, the Howard R. Hughes organization ever mentioned to him the billionaire's pending takeover of Air West, a struggling Californiabased carrier.

title: Calley Appeal Due Today
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., June 23 (UPI)Former First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. of the Army plans a Federal court appeal tomorrow to try to overturn his murder conviction in the My Lai slayings on the ground that his constitutional rights were violated. Mr. Calley, who has spent only a week behind bars since his conviction in 1971, contends he was denied a fair trial because the courtmartial board was influenced by military superiors who were looking for a scapegoat for the atrocities at the Vietnamese hamlet.

title: FARMERS WIN PLEA ON USE OF CHILDREN
description: PORTLAND, Ore., June 23A panel of three Federal judges ruled yesterday that children under 12 years of age may haryest strawberies here while farmers seek to overturn a new law prohibiting child labor.

title: GROUP CLAIMS ROLE IN FLORIDA KILLINGS
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 23  Selfstyled black revolutionaries have claimed responsibility for the killing of two white youths here.

title: U.S. Aides Deny Kissinger Made Secret Arms Deals
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 Secretary of State Kissinger made no secret arrangements with Soviet leaders about the missilelimitation agreement of 1972, but he also did not inform Congress of several aspects of it that may have led to confusion over the agreements, according to high Administration officials.

description: CINCINNATI, June 23 (AP) Johnny Bench, the Cincinnati Reds' catcher who will mark his 1,000th game in the major leagues in Houston tomorrow, has been named American Legion baseball graduate of the year for 1973. Bench was a Legion baseball standout at Anadarko, Okla, The award is presented to a member of the national program who best exemplifies the principles and ideals of American Legion baseball.

Multer was reelected president yesterday of Bnai Zion, the national Zionist fraternal organization, at the close of the organization's 65th annual meeting in Monticello, N.Y. Rabbi William Berkowitz of New York was reelected as chairman of the organization's administrative committee and Herman Z. Quittman was reelected executive vice president.

title: Grim Expectations
description: LONDON, June 23The British mid dle class has been fair game for social critics through this century. Shaw mocked its morality; others have pronounced it smug, philistine, parochial.

title: $43,000 in Art Works Stolen From Home of Newhouse Here
description: A burglar who apparently knew more about how to get in than what to take out broke into Samuel I. Newhouse Jr.'s East Side townhouse over the weekend and took five of the magazine publisher's art works valued at $43,000, but passed up much more valuable art, the police reported yesterday.

title: Experts Reject Arguments For Nixon's Defying Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The constitutional defense being erected by President Nixon against demands that he produce additional evidence for the Watergate and impeachment proceedings are viewed by number of experts interviewed over the last week as a flimsy argument standing on shaky factual ground.

title: Red Friesell, Football Referee In Famous 5thDown Call, Dies
description: PITTSBURGH, June 23William H. Red) Friesell Jr., a veteran football referee who made a famous officiating error in the 1940 CornellDartmouth game, died today in Shadyside Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in suburban Fox Chapel.

title: Concert
description: KATONAH, N. Y., June 22 Most of what one loves about outdoor summer music festivals was present in abundance here tonight, as the 29th Caramoor Festival got under way with a Viennese orchestral program under the direction of Julius Rudel.

title: HitRun Driver Hurts 2 Boys In Times Sq.
description: Two boys from New Jersey visiting the city with their father were injured by a hitandrun driver in Times Square yesterday afternoon, and a woman motorist was stopped in Greenwich Village 10 minutes later and charged with hitting them, the police reported.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: OCEANPORT, June 23Major rules changes involving horse racing in the state are expected to be made by the end of the year or sooner.

title: Terrier Best at Staten Island
description: With the rain beating down, a pert wirehaired fox terrier gave a smart performance and never gave up as he marched to the bestinshow trophy on the parade grounds at Fort Wadsworth yesterday in the Staten Island Kennel Club show.

title: ARGENTINE PRESS IN A CRISIS PERIOD
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 21Faced with strikes and mounting political pressure from the Peronist Government, the mass media have entered a period of crisis that some commentators and political figures feel is threatening press freedom in Argentina.

title: Bresnahan Gets Post
description: RENTON, Wash., June 23 (AP)John J. Bresnahan of Rye, N.Y., was appointed administrative officer of the Thoroughbred Racing Association yesterday by Frank M. Basil, president of the T.R.A. Bresnahan, 38 years old, will take over duties previously handled by Spencer Drayton.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Striking clerical workers of the Maplewood Equipment Company agreed to return to work after accepting a management wage and benefit offer. A company spokesman said clerical workers received an increase in wages, improved health insurance and pension benefits, and increased vacation time.

title: Eberle Allays Fears on Tariff Switch
description: WASHINGTON, June 23William D. Eberle, the President's Special Representative for Trade Negotiations, assured traders today that any change of the United States import tariff schedules to what is called the Brussels Tariff Nomenclature would require an act of Congress and that no such legislation could be submitted to Congress before mid1975 at the earliest.

title: AUSTRIANS ELECT SOCIALIST AGAIN;Foreign Minister Gains the Presidency in a Close Race With Rightist;
description: VIENNA, June 23Rudolf Kirchschlger, a lawyer and diplomat who has been his country's Foreign Minister since 1970, was elected President of Austria today to succeed Franz Jonas, who died April 24.

title: The Screen
description: "The Groove Tube," a 75-minute, running satire of stultifyingly familiar television staples  from kiddie shows to newscasts to serials to commercialshas arrived here, on the heels of out-of-town acclaim and an ad hailing "1974's most hilarious, wildest movie." It is indeed wild, and often hilarious. But much of it is blandly dull.The movie that opened here yesterday at the East-side Cinema is an outgrowth of a local theater "happening" five years ago. Audiences and reviewers acclaimed a package of video-taped satirical skits devised by two bright young men, Ken Shapiro and Lane Sarasohn that was beamed by several monitors in a small showcase.But "The Groove Tube" must have been infinitely funnier and certainly fresher in its original proportion, beamed from a home-screen exactly the size of its target. Now, bowdlerized and stretched out on a large, movie-house screen, the joke wears thin.Some of it is funny indeed, such as a kiddie show with a host-clown reading from "Fanny Hill." A methodical warning against venereal disease is outrageously funny. And so is a punctiliously scathing wrap-up of a typical, network newscast.But the torrent of "commercials" gets tiresome, especially one product extolling  and showing  human excrement. A "hitchhiker" prologue is flat, so are a "sex olympics" bit and several others.Mr. Shapiro, most prominently, and Mr. Sarasohn are also in the cast that includes Richard Belzer, Chevy Chase, Mary Mendham, Bill Kemmill and others.It's too bad "The Groove Tube" had to go Hollywood, or at least Wagnerian. Besides, is TV really as awful as this, when you can get the Marx Brothers night after nightfree?

title: About New York Perils and Problems of City Life
description: Dr. Alex Rosen of the New York University Medical Center was on a crowded street in midtown not long ago, when, perhaps a block away, he saw an old man collapse and fall to the ground. No one, however, stopped to help him, and he lay on that crowded street, alone and unattended.

title: Heavy North Vietnam Fire Is Reported Close to Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 23 (UPI)North Vietnamese troops fired a barrage of more than 1,000 shells into Government positions 25 miles north of Saigon yesterday in the heaviest bombardment on record so close to the capital, the Saigon command said.

title: Change Creeps Into World of Bronx Albanians
description: They toast long life with a grape liquor they call raki, washing down chalky slabs of feta cheese. They strum a twostring lute, the qefteli, and welcome callers with a stiff handshake and an Old World bow.

title: Money Isn't Enough at City Culture Unit
description: Mayor Beame's recent guarantee that the city's partment of Cultural Affairs would receive about $250,000 in program money this year sent a sigh of relief rippling through the crowded offices occupied by the department in Central Park's Arsenal Buirding.

description: MONTGOMERY, Pa.I met Jeb the day he arrived at Allenwood Federal Prison Camp in Pennsylvania and we quickly became friends.

title: India's Nuclear Explosion
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia  Let us stand in New Delhi and view the world through Indian binoculars. Let us also make a close examination of conditions inside India and raise the question of why India set off her first nuclear explosion. Why at this time? There are two possible reasons.

title: Personal Finance: KeoghPlan Rules
description: A Keogh plan, which can be established by a selfemployed person to set up a retirement fund, provides certain tax advantages. These can be lost, however, If certain formalities are overlooked, according to the Internal Revenue Service and the United States Tax Court.

title: Rise in U.S. Investment Stirs Little Controversy
description: HONG KONG, June 23The surge of American investment in Asia has provoked remarkably little controversy in the region, mainly because it has coincided with an even more rapid and conspicuous expansion of Japanese economic interests. Asian demonstrators who protest against foreign businessmen usually have the Japanese in mind.

title: Islamic Parley Avoiding Conflict

title: PASSERBY IS SLAIN IN AIDING A WOMAN
description: A man who was trying to raise cash by pretending that he needed it to bury his wife stabbed his motherinlaw and three other persons, one fatally, late Saturday, the police reported.

title: Secret Study on Laos Aid Says Almost All Goes to One Faction
description: WASHINGTON, June 23Senator Edward M. Kennedy expressed concern today that the United States, through economic and military aid to on?? Laotian faction, might be per petnating political divisions i?? Lags despite the formation of ?? new coalition Government.

title: Black Educator Files Suit
description: SARASOTA, Fla., June 23 (AP)  A black school superintendent has sued his school board for $1million for not making him principal of a predominately white elementary school here. The suit by Ozell Von Stephens accuses the Sarasota School Board of racial prejudice in its decision last April to acquiesce to protests against his appointment by parents of white children at Tuttle Elementary School.

title: Parents Workto Unravel Deaths of Two Youths
description: Michael Bernd has been dead since last September, but his tombstone has not yet been placed. His parents want the tombstone to say murdered on it, but the cemetery would prefer that it say he died at the age of 21, and leave it at that.

title: Drowsy Watchmen
description: When it originally announced its firstquarter earnings figures two months ago, the Franklin National Bank made a mistake. It said its profits for that period were $582,000, but it now says it lost over $40 million in the first quarter, and $63 million in the first five months. As one bank stock analyst put it, the bank is now really trying to go naked.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ART OUT The artists are both young and old, experienced and not, they have not had oneman shows, are generally unknown in the broad artcollectors' world and their work is still relatively cheap. All the more reason to stop in at Associatcd American Artist's Gallery at 663 Park Fifth Avenue any day this week through Saturday to look at what is actually a collection of seven oneman shows. The artists  Bill Brauer, Mark Bulwinkle, Sandria Hu, Robert Marsh, Michael Miller, Kenjilo Nanao and Sidney Schatzky  are each given separate niches for their graphics. Each artist has 10 on display. And, although the show is uneven, there is variety sufficient to interest the casual galleryhopper as well as the adventurous collector. The Museum print department has already purchased several of the prints, according to the gallery's director, Sylvan Cole. AAA gallery is open Monday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. For information, call PI., 54211.

description: Agreement on a $2aweek rent rise yesterday ended a threeweek rent strike by nearly 300 residents of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association on Lexington Avenue at 92d Street, negotiators disclosed last night.

The purchase offer was accepted by C. J. Hytrone Jr., the trustee for WestgateCalifornia, which is in reorganization. The offer is, subject to approval by the Federal District Court in San Diego. Federal Judge L. C. Nielson has set July 1 as the date for a court hearing on the offer.

New York will receive $690million, an increase of $22million, and will remain the largest single recipient of Federal revenue sharing funds, according to a computer printout made by the Office of Revenue Sharing, Department of the Treasury.

title: The Baggy Vase
description: Have you ever looked at those brown bags of varying sizes that you lug home from the store and wondered whether it possibly could have any secondary use other than to pack a lunch or to line a garbage can? A design firm named Teleidescope, Inc., didand came up with an answer. It has developed a plastic coating that provides a glossy, reasonably rigid, waterproof finish. And there you have itHard Brown Bags, as the company calls them, good to use as a vase, a planter, a wastebasket, a pencil holder or just a general catchall. The bags are made in three sizes6 inches tall ($3); 11 inches ($5), and 16 inches ($8). They'll be available at the housewares department on Bloomingdale's sixth floor and on Bendel's main floor around July 8.

Planned for 30 clay courts and with room for a small stadium to hold tournaments, the Tennisport will be the biggest club here next to the. West Side, which has 56 courts and is host to the annual United States Open championships.

The plan became a legal mandate when it was accepted by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, which hailed it as a farsighted model for the nation.

title: Senate Approves Livestock Loan Bill

The bill, which was approved by a vote of 82 to 9, was sent to the House of Representatives where similar legislation is under consideration.

description: TRENTON, June 24State Treasurer Richard C. Leone charged today that a statewide tax increase on business and industrial property as an alternative to Governor Byrne's proposed state income tax would undermine New Jersey's economy and increase unemployment.

title: French Church Attacks Reports Cardinal Died in Woman's Room
description: PARIS, June 24  The Roman Catholic hierarchy of France has reacted irately to press reports of the circumstances of the death of Jean Cardinal Danielou, one of the country's most prominent church leaders and intellectuals.

title: Mrs. Edgar Kaiser, Wife Of Industrialist, Is Dead
description: MOSCOW, June 24 (UPI) Mrs. Sue Mead Kaiser, wife of the industrialist Edgar F. Kaiser, died in the Intourist Hotel today, apparently of a heart attack, United States diplomats said. She was 65 years old.

title: Portuguese Mingle With Guinean Rebels in an Informal Truce
description: BISSAU, Portuguese Guinea, June 24The ceasefire talks between the Portuguese Government and the liberation movement have been broken off, but an informal ceasefire has been in effect for about a month. The soldiers of both armies fraternize widely and a feeling of headlong decolonization is in the air.

title: BEAMS JOGS AIDE OF NIXON ON FUNDS
description: SAN DIEGO June 24  Federal revenuesharing rules discriminate against New York City, Mayor Beame complained to President Nixon's No. 1 domesticaffairs adviser over breakfast here today.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER DIP
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market dropped again yesterday after announcements of a flurry of increases in banks' prime interest rates.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Protests Against Wagner Force Cancellation of Tel Aviv Concert
description: TEL AVIV, June 24  The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra today surrendered to threats by World War II partisans and concentrationcamp survivors and canceled Wednesday night's concert, which was to have included works by Richard Wagner.

title: CAB HITS OFFICER, DRAGS HIM 20 FEET
description: A police officer suffered a fractured skull, two broken legs and serious internal injuries yesterday when he was hit end dragged by a cab he was about to inspect at the 114th precinct station house in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Farmer and State Fight For Custody of Fawns
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., June 24 (AP)  A Superior Court judge here is handling a custoday suit over two waifs with tawny fur and white spots.

title: CONVERSION ISSUE DISTURBS A RABBI
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 24The head of the nation's largest Orthodox Jewish body charged the Conservative and Reform movements of Judaism today with unwarranted interference in Israel's political and religious life.

title: Ondine and Tempest Reach Bermuda
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 24The Bermuda race, one of yachting's most prestigious races, streamed through the home stretch toward this island in the Atlantic today, and the first two boats across the finish line both cracked the 18yearold record for the 635mile course.

title: Milhaud's Major Works
description: Of Darius Milhaud's more than 400 works, the following is a selected list of particularly important works from throughout his career, with preferred recordings when currently available.

title: Fund Set for Fireman Killed Making Rescue
description: Firemen yesterday announced that they were setting up a fund in memory of Harold J. Hoey Jr., a 34yearold South Bronx fireman who plunged five stories to his death June 12 while trying to rescue two aged persons on a burning roof. Both were saved.

title: Sakharov Says Issue of Rights Should Be on Summit Agenda
description: MOSCOW, June 24Andrei D. Sakharov, the nuclear physicist, today urged President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev to take up issues of free emigration and free exchange of information in their forthcoming talks.

title: Two More Disaster Areas
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)  President Nixon declared Iowa and Alaska major disaster areas today and expanded a previous disaster declaration for Illinois. The action triggers Federal aid for relief from variety of weathercaused damage and destruction.

title: Engineers Complete Inspection of a Link Of West Side Road
description: Engineers have completed the first phase of inspecting the deteriorated West Side HighwayHenry Hudson Parkway elevated structure six weeks ahead of schedule, the city announced yesterday.

title: President Suffered Leg Inflammation; Condition Resolved
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The White House disclosed tonight that President Nixon recently suffered from phlebitis, an inflammation in a leg vein, but said that the condition had presumably abated.

title: New Powers Emerge in Cup Soccer
description: FRANCFURT, West Germany, June 24Despite the absence of the Soviet Union and Hungary from the World Cup tournament, several Eastern countries have emerged as strong contenders for that area's first world soccer title.

title: Oregon Five on Tour
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 24 (UPI)  The University of Oregon basketball team left today for Australia and a 20game schedule during a 30day tour sponsored by the State Department.

title: WATERGATE JUSTICE CRITICIZED BY SAXBE
description: COEUR D'ALENE, Idaho, June 24 (AP) Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today that it was unfair for Watergate convicts to receive shortprison sentences while thieves serve years behind bars.

title: Advertising: Great Wall Breach
description: Getting one's foot in the door is very important for salesmen and admen. David Blank, president of Crestwood Advertising, has his foot in a door in the Great Wall of China.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker has asked Community School District 9, in the Bronx, to look into allegations of corporal punishment at two more schools, making a total of four in the District where such charges have been made. The district superintendent, John Greene, said that he had already acted on a parents' complaint involving Public School 114 and that a substitute teacher, who allegedly struck and scratched a pupil, would not be employed there again. The other school involved is P.S. 64, where a staff member was accused of striking pupils and calling them crazy and animals. Junior High School 22 is in District 9. Last Friday there were charges involving P.S. 53.

title: BRITISH ATOM TEST IN U.S. DISCLOSED
description: LONDON, June 24  Prime Minister Wilson announced today that Britain's first nuclear bomb test in nine years was carried out a few weeks ago in Nevada.

title: RODINO UNIT ISSUES 4 NEW SUBPOENAS; 49 TAPES SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The House Judiciary Committee, trying to accelerate the impeachment inquiry, issued what were described as its final four subpoenas today for White House tape recordings and authorized President Nixon's defense counsel to begin presenting rebuttal evidence on Thursday.

title: Getty to Raise Fuel Prices
description: The Getty Oil Company announced yesterday that it would raise fuel prices, beginning today. The company said that No. 2 fuel oil and diesel fuel would go up 2 cents a gallon; kerosene and jet fuel JP 5 by 2.3 cents a gallon; propane by 1.32 cents a gallon, and aromatics by 5 cents a gallon.

title: 10YEAR BAN ASKED BY U.S. ON WHALING
description: LONDON, June 24 (UPI)The United States, against strong Japanese and Soviet opposition, today demanded a 10year moratorium on commercial killing of whales to save them from extinction.

title: Despite Questions, Meat's a Good Buy
description: WASHINGTON, June 24Meat Prices Reduced; See How Much You Save, the nation's largest supermarket chain proclaimed in bold type over a newspaper advertisement published here today. Among the prices listed, some of those for beef cuts reflected reductions as great as 60 cents a pound since early February. Those meat specials, offered by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, and other such promotions that have been announced by various chains across the country tended to support Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, who has been proclaiming for the last week that meat is now a whale of good buy.

title: Banking Found Strong
description: The condition of the nation's banks is in general very strong and the Government can prevent any real harm to the economy that might result from the troubles of the Franklin National Bank, Kenneth Rush, President Nixon's White House economic counselor, said. Details on Page 53.

title: Girl's Fear Alerts Officer; Youth Held in Sodomy
description: An expression of fear on the face of a 17yearold Brooklyn girl tipped off a patrolman yesterday morning that her male companion was less than friend and led to the man's arrest.

title: The Real Health Issue
description: The public debate which was supposedly to lead the enactment of an effective national health insurance program has turned into a sputtering contest of irrelevant and misleading information. After initial signs that an acceptable compromise might emerge from a variety of proposals, the chances of such a rational outcome have been greatly reduced by the tug o war between those who insist that nothing is needed versus those who demand all or nothing.

title: Milhaud Dies at 81
description: Darius. Milhaud, composer who helped overturn traditional French music in the nineteentwenties, died at his home in Geneva. He was 81 years old. Page 40.

title: Mariner Beaten as Cup Trials Open
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 24 There was good news and bad news today at the opening of the America's Cup trials. Of the four United States yachts competing for the right to defend the, trophy next September, the recipients of good news were Courageous and Intrepid, the receivers of bad tidings, Mariner and Valiant.

title: Byrne Says He Opposes Tocks Construction Now
description: TRENTON, June 24Governor Byrne announced tonight that he was opposed to the construction of the controversial Tocks Island dam at this time. The Governor also called for a complete reevaluation by the Federal Government of the proposed dam across the upper Delaware River. He urged Congress to approve funds for further environmental impact studies, but to withhold funds for the edam's actual construction.

title: G.M. Tells Analysts Here It Is Flexible on Car Sizes
description: We'd like to be like a Supermarket, Oscar Lundin, the executive vice president of finance of the General Motors Corporation said, relaxing after a meeting here yesterday with financial analysts. We don't know exactly what kind of peas the customer will want. But we're going to have all kinds of peas.

title: Trade Council Expanding in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, June 24A former sportinggoods store overlooking an embankment of the winding Moscow River is undergoing a crash renovation here as the future Soviet headquarters of a trade coalition involving American business and the Soviet Government.

title: Italians Rebuke American Press For Adverse Comment in Crisis
description: ROME, June 24  American press comments on the financial and political crisis through which Italy is going have caused irritation here, and one columnist charged that the United States must share the responsibility for this nation's plight.

title: Contract Awards
description: Global Marine, Inc., and Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, Ltd., announced yesterday that they had signed a letter of intent to enter into a joint venture with the first project to be a $40million, 450foot drilling ship using a Global Marine design.

title: WOMEN'SUNIT BILL PASSED IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, June 24The As sembly today gave final legislative approval to a bill that would set up a Division on Women within the Department of Community Affairs.

title: Priest Calls on Drinan To Speak Up on Beaks
description: PITTSBURGH, June 24 (UPI) The Rev. Dr. John McLaughlin, a Jesuit priest who is a special assistant to President Nixon, called on a House Judiciary Committee member today to deny under oath that he is leaking secret information on the impeachment inquiry to the news media.

title: Bank Robber Gets $461
description: A holdup man got away with $461 yesterday at the branch of the First National City Bank at 415 Broadway near Canal Street. The holdup occurred at 11:20 A.M.

title: RODINO UNIT ISSUES 4 NEW SUBPOENAS; 49 TAPES SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The House Judiciary Committee, trying to accelerate the impeachment inquiry, issued what were described as its final foursubpoenas today for White House tape recordings and authorized President Nixon's defense counsel to begin presenting rebuttal evidence on Thursday.

title: Indians, With Peterson, Rout Yanks, 103
description: After worrying through a sleepless night, Fritz Peterson pitched against the Yankees last night and put on a good show for all his old friends who were there, working seven strong innings as the Cleveland Indians won, 103.

title: Gulf Forms New Unit
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday it had formed new subsidiary that will sell retail auto parts and service. The new subsidiary, known as the Gulf Merchandising Company, will intially operate 10 stores in the Houston area under the name Turnkey Autd Parts and Services.

title: Largest City Total In Tax Notes Sold At Highest Interest
description: In the largest sale of taxanticipation notes in the city's history, $800million worth were sold yesterday at an average interest rate of 7.188 per cent.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: STANDARD BRED RACE HORSE

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: PATRICIA M'QUILLAN, '73 FEMINIST OF YEAR
description: Patricia Fogarty McQuillan, last year's New York Feminist of the Year, died of cancer yesterday in a clinic in Bonn, where she had gone recently for treatment. She was 50 years old and lived at 240 East 76th Street.

title: NEWS INDEX
KIDDER COMPLETES CLARK, DODGE DEAL
description: Kidder, Peabody & Co., Inc., reported yesterday consummation of its acquisition of Clark, Dodge & Co., Inc., a mediumsize retail brokerage house that has suffered continuing losses, like many others in recent months.

title: Court Defers Grand Jury Data Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Supreme Court postponed for two weeks today a ruling on whether the Justices should inspect the Watergate grand jury's records to help them decide if the jurors could name President Nixon as an unindicted coconspirator.

title: Dave Anderson
description: His name, Evel Knievel, would be enough to make him unique. But he embellishes it. He rides motorcycles, through the air as well as on the ground. He doesn't wear a black leather jacket; his leather jacket is white with red, white and blue stars and stripes. He is 35 years old, handsome, married, with three children and mischief in a smile as dazzling as the diamonds on the fingers. He walks with a slight limp, the price of his daredevil theatrics. Perhaps as a distraction for his limp, he carries a black walking stick with a diamondstudded, removable top. Inside the stick are vials of vodka, scotch, bourbon, gin and rye. Yesterday he was swinging the walking stick as he strode into the Belvedere suite of the Rainbow Room in a white suit, floppycollared red shirt and red shoes. He was there to receive a check for $6million, his guarantee for his Sept. 8 attempt to soar across the milewide Snake River Canyon near Twin Falls, Idaho, in his Sky Cycle X2, a steampowered vehicle that resembles a miniature jet fighter without wings.

title: Heroic Mt. Vernon Officer Slain by Robber in Bar
description: A Mount Vernon police de tective with a hero' recorc Was slain by a closerange shot gun blast early yesterday wher he drew his service revolver and exchanged fire with a rob ber in a bar there.

title: HAWAIIANS CALL FOR REPARATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 24A group of Hawaiian natives, seeking reparations for lands taken by the United States in the 19th century, is in Washington this week for the introduction of legislation that would pay Hawaiian natives $1billion and give them first rights to any Federal lands in the Hawaiian islands that are declared surplus.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TRENTON, June 24Overpowering high school baseball pitchers aren't unusual, so not many people got excited at St. Anthony's in the spring when 18yearold Al Paglione went undefeated in 11 games, pitched five shutouts, struck out an average of nine a game, allowed one earned run in his first 47 innings and finished the season with an earnedrun average of 0.24.

title: DR. SAMUEL B. MOORE
description: Dr. Samuel Barlow Moore, a psychiatrist in Glen Cove, L, I., died Sunday at his home in Locust Valley, L. I. He was 60 years old.

title: Revenue Share to 3 States. To Go Up by $32Million
description: WASHINGTON, June 24New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will receive a total of $32million more revenuesharing funds for the fiscal year beginning Monday. New York will receive $690million, an increase of $22million, and will remain the largest single recipient of Federal revenuesharing funds, according to a computer printout made by the Office of Revenue Sharing, Department of the Treasury.

title: Texas Court Says W.F.L. Can Recruit
description: DALLAS, June 24 (AP) A state appeals court judge cleared the way today for recruiting of Dallas Cowboy football players by the World Football League.

title: Fans and Friends Give Betty Hutton a Benefit Here
description: It took repeated assurance's that her fans and showbusiness friends really loved her and only wanted a chance to prove it to persuade Betty Hutton, the former Hollywood star who had fallen on hard times, to agree to last night's benefit in her honor at the Riverboat nightclubrestaurant here.

title: Petersen Says Silbert's Confirmation Could Be Used in President's Defense
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Senate approval of the promotion of a former Watergate prosecutor could aid the President's defense against impeachment, Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Petersen acknowledged today.

title: People in Sports
description: Julia Meade, who has sold coldwater detergent, among other products, to millions of American women, yesterday asked them to band together with heart and soul to raise money for the United States Olympic team.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL INCREASES PRICES
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had raised prices on a number of rolled steel products by 5 to 15 per cent. Affected by the increases are steel goods used by the construction, shipbuilding and automobile industries.

title: Estill Green, 78, Engineer, Dies; Executive of Bell Laboratories
description: Estill I. Green, who retired in 1960 as executive vice president of Bell Laboratories, died yesterday of a heart attack in St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Nixon Friends Concerned By Stonewalling on Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, June 23Some of President Nixon's dosest and most loyal Senate friends are showing concern oner his rejection of demands for more tapes in the impeachment inquiry.

title: Gibson Entering 2d Term Amid Calls for Innovation
description: NEWARKFour years ago a civil engineer working in the Health Department here won election as this city's first black Mayor.

title: Planned or Planless?
description: The Board of Standards and Appeals ideally represents a judicious balance in the city's building process. When a developer is faced with a genuine economic hardship on a particular construction site, such as an oddshaped lot or unusual foundation conditions, he can askand often getsan exception to the zoning requirements to make up his additional costs. Usually this means a larger structure or permission for nonconforming features.

title: KuwaitiBased Gulf Is Reported Buying Into Lonrho Stock
description: LONDON, June 24According to today's London Evening Standard, the Kuwaitibased Gulf International group, has been buying heavily into Lonrho, the Britishowned conglomerate with commercial and mining interests in Africa.

title: DEAL BY PEUGEOT AND CITROEN DUE
description: PARIS, June 24The troubled Citron automobile works announced tonight a move toward merger with the rival company of Peugeot.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (Reuters)The Federal Trade Commission was formally asked today to block the proposed acquisition by Mobil Oil Corporation of the Marcor Corporation in a petition filed by Representative LesAspin, Democrat of Wisconsin. Mr. Aspin asked the F.T.C. to bring restraint of trade proceedings against the proposed merger. He specifically asked the agency to investigate the planned purchase and seek a Federal court injunction to block it.

title: Plot's Body Found in Wreck
description: SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., June 24 (AP)The body of Louis Morgan, 45 years old, of Watertown was found today in the wreckage of his twin  engine plane, which crashed on an Adirondack mountaintop 20 miles south of here in the Clear Lake region. Authorities said the victim was en route from Watertown to Burlington, Vt., when the plane crashed.

title: Solzhenitsyn Gives Terms for His Return
description: In his first extended interview since his expulsion from the Soviet Union in February, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn said he would return to live in Russia if his work could be freely published there.

title: Goldwater Accepts Aid From Rotary for Indians
description: POINT PLEASANT, June 24 (AP)Senator Barry M. Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, spent about 20 minutes here. today to accept a check from a local Rotary district for an American Indian relief program.

title: Tito Follows Pact With His First Visit To West Germany
description: BONN, June 24President Tito of Yugoslavia arrived here today on his first official visit to West Germany.

title: Billboards a Canvas For Connecticut Art
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 24  A tentative first step toward a new, popular form of billboard art in Connecticut was taken today when reproductions of three paintings by Connecticut artists were pasted on billboards here and in Hartford

title: Arabs Kill 4 Israelis And Then Are Slain In Apartment Raid
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, June 25Three Arab guerrillas broke into a small apartment house in the northern resort town of Nahariya last night and killed three Israeli civilians before being slain themselves in a gunfight with Israeli soldiers.

title: Gloria Goldsmith Raiffa, Pratt ExCounseling Aide
description: Mrs. Gloria Goldsmith Raiffa, former assistant director of counseling and testing at the Pratt Institute and the wife of Elliot Raiffa, an executive of the IBM Corporation, died Sunday in Maimonides Hospital. She was 39 years old and lived at 469 Rugby Road in Brooklyn.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Nonagricultural jobs in New Jersey rose to about 2.5 million during May, Joseph A. Hoffman, State Commissioner of Labor and Industry said. He attributed the increase mainly to the addition of 25,000 jobs in nonmanufacturing industries to the work roles.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Bridal for Debora Read Graves
description: Miss Debora Read Graves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Graves of Rye, N.Y., was married in Mamaroneck, N. Y., yesterday afternoon to John Wesley Westcott 3d, son of Mr. Westcott Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Mrs. Mary Ingraham Westcott of Rye.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended June 18.

title: Doctors Are Turning to Films, Videotapes and Courses to Explore How to Deal With Death and the Dying
description: SEATTLE, June 24For centuries doctors have learned how to handle death and the dying patient not in medical school but through everyday experience. Some physicians have done it very well, others poorly.

title: Nixon Expected to Talk To Russian People on TV
description: WASHINGTON, June 24President Nixon is expected to address the Russian people on live television when he is in Moscow for his summit meeting.

title: Saigon Asserts Communists Destroyed Fuel and Shells
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 24 (AP)Communist units blew up fuel tanks and an ammunition dump outside Hue overnight, the Saigon command said.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: LONDON, June 24A Mei Ping jar from the collection of Frederick M. Mayer of New York was sold today for $554,000 at Christie's.

title: BRITISH ATOM TEST IN U.S. DISCLOSED
description: LONDON, June 24 Prime Minister Wilson announced today that Britain's first nuclear bomb test in nine years was carried out a few weeks ago in Nevada.

title: Myrdal and Clark Plan New Racial Study
description: Dr. Kenneth. B. Clark, the black psychologist whose studies of the harmful effects of segregation were noted in the 1954 Supreme Court decision ordering desegregation of public schools, and Dr. Gunnar Myrdal, Swedish author of An American Dilemma, the 1944 classic, are teaming up for a new study of racial problems in the United States.

title: PicturePostcard Show Opens at Hofstra
description: Working anonymously, for the glory of their God, some men build cathedrals. Others, equally, anonymous, serve their fellow and illustrate postcards.

title: CERTAINTEED BACKS AID TO VALLEY FORGE
description: The Certainteed Products Corporation anounced yesterday that it would assist the Valley Forge Corporation, a 71 per centowned subsidiary, by guaranteeing up to $6.2million in funds for the troubled company.

title: People in Sports
description: Julia Meade, who has sold coldwater detergent, among other products, to millions of American women, yesterday asked them to band together with heart and soul to raise money for the United States Olympic team.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, June 24 (AP)Steve Williams may get a chance to race Valeriy Borzov when a United States track and field team meets the Soviet Union on July 5 and 6. A 40man United States team was named today by the Amateur Athletic Union for the dual meet at Durham, N. C.

title: JEWEL THIEVES GET $450,000 IN LOOT
description: Gold and diamonds worth about $450,000 were stolen from a West New York jewelry store last weekend by burglars described by the police as a team of four or five experts. The burglary was discovered yesterday.
