title: STATUS OF BANKS TERMED STRONG
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 The condition of the nation's banks is in general very strong and the Government can prevent any real harm to the economy that might result from the troubles of the Franklin National Bank, President Nixon's economic counselor said today.

title: Periodic Relicensing Exams Urged for Doctors
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  A group of health care experts urged Congress today to enact Federal legislation that Would force doctors to demonstrate their medical proficiency throughout their professional lives.

title: Dealers Say Prime Rate Rise in U.S. Felt in Europe
description: LONDON, June 24The British pound fell sharply today against the United States dollar and most European currencies. Prices on the London Stock Exchange also decline?? amid continuing anxieties over the state of Britain's economy.

title: BAR ASKED TO STUDY SECRECY ON BODIES
description: The Onondaga County (N.Y.) Bar Association was asked yesterday to investigate whether it was proper for the lawyers for Robert F. Garrow, who is on trial for murder in Lake Pleasant, N.Y., to withhold knowledge of two killings.

title: No Loss
description: The bottom line management philosophy of Madison Square Garden's new president, Alan N. Cohen, which has brought howls of protest from the sporting world, may nevertheless prove an unexpected boon for our town. Mr. Cohen wants the Garden to be a profitable enterprise. Thus, he is thinking about ending the Garden's professional boxing program because New York's taxes make it extremely difficult to attract the highly touted fights that are essential to making the big buck from bloodletting.

title: The Costs of Grain and Labor Are Squeezing Cattle Feeders
description: MENLO, Kan., June 22Gary Baalman has no real quarrel with the American housewife. If she thinks beef prices are too high in the supermarket, he more or less agrees with her at least, in view of the price live cattle are bringing.

title: DROP IN SPENDING SOUGHT BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 President Nixon, turning his attention to the nation's economy on the eve of his departure for the Soviet Union, said today that the Federal Govern* ment would try to limit spending to $300billion in the fiscal year beginning next Monday.

title: Mini Still Reigns, but Are Its Days Numbered?
description: Contrary to what you read in the fashion bibles, hear from the people on Seventh Avenue, see on the skinny lunchers at La Grenouille and observe at the chic little fashion shows, the miniskirt, dahlings, is not dead.

title: RESERVE EASING. OTC LIST RULES
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Federal Reserve Board adopted today an amendment reducing the standards that an overthecounter stock must meet in order for brokers to be allowed to lend money on it, subject to the Reserve's margin requirements.

title: Pakistani Denies He Said Israel Aided Indian ATest
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 24 (UPI)Pakistan's Foreign Minister, Aziz Ahmed, today denied saying at the Islamic Conference of Foreign Ministers here that Israel had collaborated in India's recent nuclear explosion, although official records showed that he had.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Profits More Elusive on Broadway
description: The Broadway season has ended, but there is no surcease for producers from the economic facts of Broadway. Costs keep rising. More and more, profits are pipe dreams. And it is increasingly difficult to raise money for new shows.

title: Governor Considers a Bid To His Conservative Rival
description: Governor Wilson, reacting to pressure from T. David Bullard his Conservative party chal lenger, conferred with political aides yesterday in an effort to avoid a Conservative party primary contest.

title: Ah, the Other Paris Restaurants
description: PARISWhen we first explored the great restaurants of Paris and France we willingly played Pantagruel morning, noon and night, sampling any dish that issued forth from oven or saucepan, We seldom passed a pastry shop between meals without spending a few centimes for a barquette here, a sorbet there.

title: CONNALLY LINKED TO JACOBSEN CALL
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 John B. Connally telephoned President Nixon in 1972 to express concern about a Justice Department investigation of Jake Jacobsen's role in a Texas savingsandloan scandal, according to a wellplaced source.

title: Bridge: York Team Is Victor In Grand National Playoff
description: A powerful New York team will represent the Northeastern zone in the quarterfinal stage of the Grand National Team Championship.

title: F.B.I. TO CURB DATA ON ARREST RECORDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) The F.B.I. is taking steps to curtail the distribution of arrest records to banks and state and local governments, its director, Clarence M. Kelley, an nounced today.

title: Notes on People
description: Smith College will begin its second century next year with its first woman president.

title: Peron's Grim Milestone
description: It was not a very felicitous first anniversary of the return of Gen. Juan Pern from eighteen years of exile that Argentina celebrated, last week. President Peron himself was forced by an influenza attack, to cancel trip to Rosario to observe the anniversary. It was one of several illnesses that have incapacitated the 78yearold general since he reassumed the Presidency last October.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ONE UP In Central Park tonight, the Metropolitan Opera will begin its summer series of free operas in concert with Puccini's Turandot, in the Sheep Meadow. Singing Turandot will be Elinor Ross; Lucine Amara is Liu, and James McCracken is Calaf. And, for the trivia fanciers, Robert Goodloe is Ping, Andrea Veils is Pang, and Charles Anthony is Pong. Originally canceled by the Met for lack of funds, the operainthepark series was financially saved with funds from the New York State Council of the Arts, the city's Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration and the Miller Brewing Company.

title: A. E. GIEGENGACK, PUBLIC PRINTER
description: Augustus E. Giegengack, Public Printer of the United States from 1934 to 1948, died Friday in the Westwood Retirement Home, Bethesda, Md. He was 84 years old.

title: Silver Futures Drop by 20c Daily Limit
description: Traders rushed to sell silver futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, and the selling was so heavy that prices dropped the 20centanounce limit not long after the opening.

title: President Suffered Leg Inflammation; Condition Resolved
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The White House disclosed tonight that President Nixon recently suffered from phlebitis, an inflammation in a leg vein, but said that the condition had presumably abated.

title: Busby Loses Bid for 2d Straight NoHitter, Then Loses Game
description: Thirtysix years ago this month, Cincinnati's Johnny Vander Meer accomplished a pitching feat that made history. Vander Meer pitched two consecutive nohit games, beating the Boston Braves on June 11 and duplicating the feat against the Brooklyn Dodgers on June 15.

title: SENATE REJECTS MOVE TO CUT TAX
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI)The Senate, overwhelmingly defeated, today a tax package that would have cut income taxes and ended several business tax breaks, including the oil depletion allowance.

title: Wood Field and Stream: Plight of Bluefin Tuna Is Recognized
description: Frank Mather 3d, the Woods Hole (Mass.) Oceanographic Institution scientist who was a pioneer in population, growth and migration research on the Atlantic bluefin tuna, and who in recent years has been warning that the stocks of this magnificent game and food fish have been dangerously depleted, is now experiencing belated recognition of his efforts.

title: Darius Milhaud, Rebel Composer, Dies
description: Darius Milhaud, the composer who helped overturn traditional French music in the nineteentwenties, died at his home in Geneva Saturday. He was 81 years old and leaves his wife, Madeleine, and a son, Daniel.

title: A 17thCentury Tree in Newburgh May Be 20thCentury Traffic Victim
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y.Somebody, no one is sure quite who, planted a tree where some ancient Iroquois and Algonquin Indian trails crossed in 1699. It was only 41 years after, the death of Oliver Cromwell and 76 years before the Battle of Bunker Hill.

title: Patent Output Doubled
description: WASHINGTON June 24The Patent Office has announced that it is doubling its usual output of patents this week, to come as close as possible in the fiscal year ending June 30 to the 80,000 patents for which Congress appropriated funds. The week's output, issuing half on Tuesday and half on Friday, will be 3,310, bringing the total for the fiscal year to 79,300.

title: KissingerJackson Debate Grows Heated
description: WASHINGTON, June 24Secretary of State Kissinger and Senator Henry M. Jackson today continued their dispute over whether the Secretary had made secret arrangements with Moscow regarding the agreement of 1972 limiting some offensive nuclear missiles for five years.

title: Typical Disagreements
description: WASHINGTON, JUNE 24One reward of writing a regular newspaper column is the discovery of the rich variety of dissent that still thrives in the United States. Every week the mail brings refreshing evidence that Americans remain a wonderfully disputatious race eager to catch the arrogant columnist in his foolishness and torment him with demands for public confession of his poor judgment, muddied thought, careless cruelties, subversive opinion, bad grammar, weak history and general ignorance.

title: Books of The Times
description: AN AMERICAN LIFE: One Man's Road to Watergate. By Jeb Stuart Magruder. 338 pages. Illustrated. Atheneum. $10. One expects to disdain Jeb StuartMagruder's An American Life: One Man's Road to Watergate. (After all, what has someone so relatively low on the Watergate totem pole to offer, except excuses for himself?) And for a while at least, one's disdain holds sway. Indeed, how else is one to respond to the moral flabbiness Mr. Magruder evinces while recounting his youth and early career? flow is one to react to his admission that he discovered early in life how it was for him to wangle his way with his charm and good looks? Or to his statement, explaining why he felt a certain falling out between his college fraternity and its national office was ridic ulous, that I couldn't see now it was going to dishonor Phi Delta Theta to have one Jew in its Williams chapter? Or to the too feeble objections he raises to jobs he held as a young man that involved manufacturing faulty merchandise or selling goods by illegitimate means?

title: CHARLES E. REINHOLD
description: Charles E. Reinhold, treasurer, since 1955 of Periodical Publishers' Service Bureau, a subsidiary of the Hearst Corporation handling subscription sales, died Sunday at his home in Sandusky, Ohio. He was 56 years old.

title: High Court Upholds Carnal Knowledge but Rules Ad for U.S. Report Obscene
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Supreme Court ruled today that the motion picture Carnal Knowledge was not obscene but that an advertisement for an illustrated version of the report of the Presidential commission on obscenity was.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 25, 1974

title: Massachusetts Seeks Aid
description: BOSTON, June 24 (AP)The Massachusetts Education Commissioner, Gregory R. Anrig, said today that he had asked the Federal Government to release several million dollars in aid to the state to help Boston carry out school integration, ordered by a Federal court decision, this fall.

title: Study of Upper Atmosphere Put Off Because of Clouds
description: A volley of rockets that was to have been fired from Wallops Island, off the Virginia coast, beginning yesterday afternoon, was postponed because cloud cover threatened to obcure the chemical trails to be written in the sky for upper atmosphere studies.

title: SUDAN TO GIVE UP TERRORIST KILLERS OF 2 U. S. ENVOYS
description: CAIRO, June 24  President Gaafar alNimeiry of the Sudan today decided to hand over to the Palestine Liberation Organization the guerrillas who killed two American diplomats and a Belgian in a siege of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum 15 months ago, the Middle East News Agency reported.

title: The Stage: Fragments
description: In Fragments of a Trilogy, now running at La Mama (in the theater's annex on Great Jones Street), Andrei Serban, the innovative Rumanian director, offers Medea, Electra and The Trojan Womenall in one hour and all in Greek. This would seem to be an act of caprice, if not selfdefeat, until one experiences the work.

title: Grain Crop Estimates Lag
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) Poor weather has dimmed hopes for superlarge grain crops this year to help cool consumer food prices, but 1974 harvests of corn and wheat still are expected to be at record levels, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Bombs in Buenos Aires Shake Foreign Offices
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 24 (UPI)  An apparently coordinated campaign of bombings aimed at foreign business shook downtown Buenos Aires tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Elliot H. Sharp's tirade (letter June 19) against the class action lawyer combines curious logic with twisted arithmetic. He complains that it is not uncommon for the lawyers to gain $100,000 or more by settling [class action] cases out of court, with stockholders benefiting by as little as a cent a share.

title: F.B.I. Asks Court to Dismiss Suit Over Surveillance on Girl
description: NEWARK, June 24 (UPI) The F.B.T. asked a Federal judge today to dismiss a suit filed by a high school student charging that a Federal Bureau of Investigation check on a letter that the student had written to the Socialist Workers party was illegal and the hallmark of a police state.

title: Loans Totaling $92Million Approved by World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI)The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced today the approval of three loans totaling $92million for development projects in Morocco, Nigeria and Turkey.

title: Arabs Kill 4 Israelis And Then Are Slain In Apartment Raid
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, June 25Three Arab guerrillas broke into a small apartment house in the northern resort town of Nahariya last night and killed three Israeli civilians before being slain themselves in gunfight with Israeli soldiers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Byrne of New Jersey said that, pending complete reevaluation by the Federal Government, he was opposed to construction of the Tocks Island Dam project.Mr. Byrne made the statement In a letter to Senators John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi and Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, both chairmen of subcommittees of the Senate Appropriations Committee.The Congressmen are considering appropriations for the project, which would create a 37milelong lake behind a dam built on the Delaware River in northeastern Pennsylvania.

title: Corning Glass Works Earnings Decline Despite Record Sales
DRUG FLOW NOTED DESPITE NEW LAWS
description: The state's stringent new antidrug laws have not measurably slowed the overall flow of drugs or driven major narcotics dealers out of business, according to many lawenforcement authorities.

title: Accipiter Victor as Aqueduct Opens
ACCORD IN MOSCOW TO LIMIT ATESTS SEEN BY KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States and the Soviet Union were hoping to announce during President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Moscow that they had reached agreement in principle to limit underground nuclear tests.

title: Two Die in Ulster While Taking Bomb Into a Supermarket
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Julie 24Two men were killed by a premature exxplosion as they carried a bomb into a supermarket in Londonderry today.

title: A Case Study in Disillusion: U.S. Aid Effort in India
description: NEW DELHIIf there is such a thing as a historic anticlimax, then one occurred here early this year when Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan conferred his blessing and that of the United States on an Indian national piety and aspiration known as zero net aid.

title: Market Place: Amex Studing 2 Block Trades
description: The episode began with an apparently straightforward block transaction last Friday that ended a steady rise in Struthers Wells shares over the past several weeks. The rise had carried the stock to 8 on Tuesday of last week.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: EDWARD J. RIESBECK
description: Edward J. Riesbeck, president for four decades of the Astoria Federal Savings and Loan Association, died Friday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L. I. He was 70 years old and lived at 17001 32d Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

title: 1,500 Police Officers Attend Funeral Rites for Slain Lieutenant Here
description: The widow of Lieut. Henry O. Schmiemann and their five children sat side by side at a Mass of the Resurrection for the slain police officer yesterday, their faces and their bearing as much a triumph of disciplined composure as the formation of 1,500 policemen and policewomen who stood at attention later in a final salute.

title: Favorites Win at Wimbledon, But Gorman Is Almost Beaten
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 24It took Tom Gorman five sets and 3 match points to defeat Anand Amritraj today in the only match remotely close to an upset before the largest openingday crowd in Wimbledon tennis history.

title: Watergate Sentences
description: Charles Cason, who entered a guilty plea under terms of an arrangement with Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, appears to have received a slightly stiffer sentence than Dwight Chapin, who spurned a guilty plea and insisted on trial.

title: Indians' Suit Spurs New Vote in Part of an Iowa House District
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, June 24  Responding to the complaint by an Indian tribal council, a Federal judge here ordered today that four of the 472 precincts in Iowa's Third Congressional District conduct a new election on July 2.

title: PRINTERS GIVEN HELP TO LEARN NEW WAYS
description: A Federal grant of $301,480 to help train 100 commercialshop printers in photo composition and computerized typesetting was announced jointly yesterday by State Industrial Commissioner Louis L. Levine and Bertram A. Powers, president of Typographical Union No. 6.

title: U.S. Interest Rates Rise As British Pound Slides
description: The weakened economic situation was reflected in developments on both sides of the Atlantic yesterday. Interest rates continued their upward march in the United States, contributing to the weakening of both the pound and stock prices in London. There was also an official prediction that Italy's balanceofpayments deficit would reach $10billion for the year.

title: Father Slain Near Bank Here Resisting Theft of Son's Deposit
description: A 65yearold Queens man was shot fatally yesterday outside a Brooklyn bank when he apparently resisted a gunman attempting to steal a deposit he was carrying to the bank for his son.

title: Expensive European Cities
description: GENEVA, June 24 (Reuters) Seven European cities, headed by Stockholm, are more expensive to live in than New York, a private business research organization said today. The Geneva firm, Business International, said the six other expensive European cities were Oslo, Dusseldorf, Frankfurt, Zurich, Copenhagen and Geneva.

title: PADDLING INQUIRY MAY BE WIDENED
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker has asked officials of Community School District 9 in the Bronx to look into allegations of corporal punishment at two other district schools, Public Schools 64 and 114.

title: 6 Offices Now Handle Tax Program Inquiries
description: The Byrne administration has established six regional hot line telephone numbers to answer public inquiries about the Governor's proposed incometax program.

title: Iran Says She Has No Intention To Develop Nuclear Weapons
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 24The Iranian Government denied today that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi had said that his nation intended to have nuclear weapons soon. A Government minister quoted the Shah as saying that Iran had no such I intentions.

title: SUDAN TO GIVE UP TERRORIST KILLERS OF 2 U. S. ENVOYS
description: CAIRO, June 24  President Gaafar alNimeiry of the Sudan today decided to hand over to the Palestine Liberation Organization the guerrillas who killed two American diplomats and Belgian in a siege of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum 15 months ago, the Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Chicago Bank Lifts Loan Rate to 11.8%
description: The First National Bank of Chicago raised its corporate base lending rateits equivalent of the prime interest rate for business loansto a record 11.8 per cent yesterday, from 11.5 per cent. Five large California banks quickly raised their rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 11 per cent, but for the time being the predominant rate at most of the largest banks' in the country continues at 11 per cent.

title: Colombo Also Puts 1974 Oil Cost at $6Billion
description: MILAN, Italy, June 24 Treasury Minister Emilio Colombo said today that Italy's balanceofpayments deficit had run $1billion a month in the first five months of the year and would total $10billion for 1974.

title: DRUG FLOW NOTED DESPITE NEW LAWS
description: The state's stringent new antidrug laws have not measurably slowed the overall flow of drugs or driven major narcotics dealers out of business, according to many lawenforcement authorities.

title: COLSON SAYS C.I.A. CONCERNED NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, June 24Charles W. Colson said today that President Nixon expressed concern to him during a telephone conversation in January about the possibility that the Central Intelligence Agency had played a far greater role in the Watergate scandal than has been publicly revealed.

title: JAWORSKI ALTERS TACTICS ON TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Watergate prosecutor's office told a Federal judge today that it was changing its tactics in the upcoming plumbers trial and would no longer try to prove that John D. Ehrlichman attempted to conceal his alleged involvement in an unlawful burglary in 1971.

title: Gibson Entering 2d Term Amid Calls for Innovation
description: NEWARKFour years ago a civil engineer working in the Health Department here won election as this city's first black Mayor.

title: Excerpts From Secretary Kissinger's News Conference on Missile Agreements
description: Following are excerpts from an opening statement by Secretary of State Kissinger at his news conference in Washington yesterday and from a questionandanswer period, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: COMPUTER TO EASE WORK OF MUSEUMS
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., June 23 Nearly 100,000 works of art have been catalogued in a computerized system that promises to ease the work of museums organizing loan exhibitions and of scholars and policemen seeking specific information.

title: Benjamin Jon Winter Marries Susan Rosenfeld in Montreal
description: Miss Susan Jane Rosenfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Rosenfeld of Montreal and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Benjamin Jon Winter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Winter of Rye, N. Y.

title: T.W.A. Lease Financing On 4 L1011 Planes Set
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday it had completed 380million of lease financing of four Lockheed L1011 aircraft.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: 2 Gunmen Rob Pastor Of Sunday Collection
description: Two gunmen robbed the pastor of a Washington Heights church of $1,900 yesterday as he was about to take the Sunday collection to the bank.

title: DROP IN SPENDING SOUGHT BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 President Nixon; turning his attention to the nation's econonly on the eve of his departure for the Soviet Union, said today that the Federal Government would try to limit spending to $300billion in the fiscal year beginning next Monday.

title: ACCORD IN MOSCOW TO LIMIT ATESTS SEEN BY KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States and the Soviet Union were hoping to announce during President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Moscow that they had reached agreement in principle to limit underground nuclear tests.

title: Four Radiation Bursts Are Linked to Collapsing Star
description: Four rapidfire bursts of radiation, detected a mile underground in South Dakota, have tentatively been interpreted as deluges of antimatter thrown off by a star collapsing to a superdense state.

title: The Supreme Court Backs Government On Tax Deduction
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) The Supreme Court reversed today a decision that the Government said would have cost the Treasury about $400million a year in taxes paid by electric utilities.

title: Education Post Is Filled
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) Charles H. Buzzell of Beverly, Mass., has been appointed associate commissioner for occupational planning in the United States Office of Education, it was announced today.

title: Auschwitz's Message
description: ROXBURY, Conn.  Springtime at Auschwitz. The phrase itself has the echo of a bad and tasteless joke, but spring still arrives in the depths of southern Poland, even at Autchwitz. Just beyond the Onceelectrified fences, still standing, the forsythia puts forth its yellow buds in gently rolling pastures where sheep now graze; The early songbirds chatter even here, on the nearly unending grounds of this Godforsaken place in the remote hinterland of the country. At Birkenau, that sector of the Auschwitz complex that was the extermination camp for millions, one is staggered by the sheer vastness of the enterprise stretching out acre upon acre in all directions.

title: Lebanon Asks Arab Aid With Her Air Defenses
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24Lebanon has asked the Arab nations for assistance in strengthening her air defenses against Israel, Premier Takieddin Solh announced today.

title: Rodriguez Wins Bout
description: Fausto (Cejas) Rodriquez, 147 pounds, of the Dominican Republic, the world's fifthranked welterweight contender, made a successful United States debut last night when he earned a majority decision over Art Kettles, 145, of Asbury Park, N.J., in a 10round bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: Maiden Name Rejected
description: WORCESTER, Mass., June 24 (AP)The Board of Registrar of Voters removed a woman's name from the voter registration roles today because she refused to be listed by her married name. The registrars decided that the law required the woman, who uses her maiden name, Frances M. Anthes, to be registered under her legal name, Mrs. Charles J. Washburn.

title: Births
description: BLAKEWilliam & Carole, announce the ar rival of Lisa's brother Andrew George on June 22, 1974.

title: JAMES E. M'MULLEN
description: James E, McMullen, retired partner of the investing firm of Payson and Trask, 748 Madison Avenue, died in Colorado Springs Monday after a long illness. He was 67 years old and lived in Larchmont, N. Y.

title: RODIN UNIT VOTES EARLY DISCLOSURE OF MOST EVIDENCE
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The House Judiciary Committee decided today, despite bitter and bipartisan dissent, to make public as soon as possible virtually all the evidence assembled for its investigation of President Nixon's conduct in office.

title: Schools Plan Extra Help for City U.Bound Students
description: The city school system, in partnership with The City University, will start a major program next fall to overcome the basic educational deficiencies, of some of its high school graduates  a task that must know be done by the university after the graduates are enrolled under its open admissions policy.

title: Rebel Clashes in Philippines Force 19,000 From Homes
description: COTABATO CITY, Philippines, June 25 (AP)More than 19,000 people have fled their homes since renewed fighting broke out last week between the Philippine Government and Moslem rebels in central Mindanao, provincial officials said today.

title: People in Sports
description: Leroy Kelly, the Cleveland Browns allstar running back, has been placed on waivers and several National Football League clubs have expressed interest in acquiring the 34yearold star.

title: PRESIDENT RESIGNS FROM CERTAIMEED
description: The CertainTeed Products Corporation announced yesterday that Byron C. Radaker had resigned as president and a director to pursue other interests.

title: Ford Tells A.M.A. of Concern For Doctor and Patient Privacy
description: CHICAGO, June 25  Vice President Ford expressed grave concern today over what he termed the growing tendency to violate the privacy of doctors and patients.

title: Islands of Amenity
description: New York is not walltowall congestion everywhere. There are residential areas where planned community development has included open space and trees within the city's borders. To the people who live there, the advantages of their welldisposed housing and green and pleasant surroundings are obvious; to some investors, the open land earns nothing and creates the itch to build. With building sites increasingly scarce and costly, these areas are about as safe as the speculator's next dollar.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Brick Township man charged with wounding three policemen and a youth in a shootout last January in Toms River was convicted by an Ocean County jury. The panel deliberated four hours before returning the verdict against Richard Natale, 41 years old.

title: Planning Unit Introduces Neighborhood Miniplans
description: A new concept in neighborlhood planning, epitomized by series of miniplans tailored to the needs of individual communities, is being inaugurated by the City Planning CommisSion.

title: Vietnam Veterans Protest On Federal Aid in Newark
description: Chanting demonstrators pushed into the lobby of the Veterans Administration Building in downtown Newark yesterday to protest local procedures in aiding veterans and to call attention to a fourday national demonstration planned for Washington, beginning next Monday.

title: Colson Is Disbarred By Court in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)  Charles W. Colson, the former White House aide who pleaded guilty to obstructing justice in disseminating derogatory material about Daniel Ellsberg, was disbarred today by the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.

title: Russians' Curiosity About U.S.Is Rising
description: MOSCOW, June 25 The questions follow one upon another with sometimes relentless repitition. How much money does the Average American worker earn? How many hours does he labor to buy a pair of shoes? Can he own a car? How big an apartment does he have? How much rent must he pay?

title: DISTRICT 1 BOARD OFF TO SLOW START
description: The newly elected school hoard for District 1 in Manhattan held its first successful public meeting last night, although the session was marred by long delays by supporters of the Hispanic minority bloc and by the audience.

title: MILK COOPERATIVE NAMED IN LAWSUIT
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 25 (AP) The nation's largest milk cooperative faces up to $3.5million in penalties for alleged violation of Texas antitrust laws.

title: Mrs. King Advances Routinely
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 25The fivetime Wimbledon winner, Mrs. Billie Jean King, stepped onto center court today as defending champion against Kathy May of Beverly Hills, Calif., America's top junior and 18 years old last week.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Carbon Fuel Company said yesterday that it had signed a contract with a minimum duration of 15 years under which all coal produced at its West Virginia operations would be sold to the United States Steel Corporation, effective last April 1. The company's West Virginia operations produced about 1.8 million tons of metallurgical coal during 1973 and Carbon Fuel plans to increase production to 3 million tons annually by 1977. Value of the contract was not disclosed, but Carbon Fuel said it included a loan of $4.5million repayable in equal installments over the 15year length of the contract.

title: Samuels Picks Up Support of Bronx Chairman
description: Howard J. Samuels, the Democratic designee for Governor, yesterday picked up the endorsement of the last holdout among the Democratic chair men of the major downstate counties, Patrick J. Cunningham of the Bronx.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: About 575 hockey fans who bought season tickets for the New York Golden Blades last season but lost out on seeing most of the games when the World Hockey Association franchise was moved will get more than $250,000 in refunds, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday. Lefkowitz said the ticketholders missed threefourths of the Blades' home games after the club moved from the city to Cherry Hill, N. J., last year and became the Jersey Knights. The franchise has since been moved to San Diego for the 197475 season.

title: About New York
description: O.K., crime, here we are, the cop behind the wheel of the taxi said. He was driving up Broadway, two cops in the taxi with him, looking for crooks. There were none, or at least none they could be sure of, and while this was a good thing for honest citizens on Broadway, it was bad for the cops. It meant they had nothing to do.

title: U.S. Backs $300Million Israeli Notes
description: Over the last three weeks, Israel has been borrowing $300million in the United States through an unusual issue of securities guaranteed by the United States Government.

title: Launching Delayed Again In Atmospheric Testing
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., June 25 (AP)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration postponed today for a third time its scheduled launching of 54 rockets to test the atmosphere.

title: Iran and France Set A Technological Pact
description: PARIS, June 25 (Reuters) The Shah of Iran, in talks with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, today sealed the biggest agreement ever for technological cooperation between an oilproducing country and an industrial power.

title: City Will Open Pay Television to All Producers
description: The city's new regulations for pay television by cable provides open access to all entrepreneurs who might choose to offer programing for pay, Morris Tarshis, director of the Bureau of Franchises, said yesterday.

title: New Security Hardware Is Planned for City Jails
description: The title of the bluecovered book was Understanding, but the contents had more to do with force than with reason. The pages had been hollowed out, and in the recess was an imitation pistol, carved from soap but good enough to use in an attempted prison escape.

title: Bordoni Explains Stepdown From Franklin Directorship
description: Carlo Bordoni, who resigned recently as a director of the Franklin New York Corporation, said yesterday that he had left the board to devote full time to his recently assumed post as managing director of Societa Generale Immobilaire, a Romebased realestate and construction company. Mr. Bordoni is an associate of Michele Sindona, the largest sheholder in the bankholding company.

title: NIXON IN BRUSSELS FOR TALKS TODAY WITH NATO CHIEFS
description: BRUSSELS, June 25Only five days after completing a tour of the Middle East, President Nixon arrived here tonight to confer with Western European leaders before going on to Moscow. Thursday for his third summit meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Tigers' Lolich Top Tamer of Orioles
Phlebitis: In Some Cases It Is Serious
description: Phlebitis, the condition from which President Nixon has been suffering in recent weeks, is regarded in medical circles as common and not serious if treated properly. Nevertheless, phlebitis, or inflammation of a vein, can lead to sudden and even fatal complications in some people.

title: U.S. Denounces the Sudan For Yielding Murderers
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The United States, in a strongly worded statement, said today that it was dismayed over the Sudan's decision to turn over to the Palestine. Liberation Organization the eight confessed killers of two seniorAmerican diplomats and a Belgian.

title: SAWIIILL ASSAILED IN STRIP MINE RIFT
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Nixon Administration was accused today of using grossly distorted figures and scare tactics to defeat a pending Federal strip mine control bill in Congress.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Classified tdates distdibuted in metdotdolitan New York and adiacent territory.

title: Change Into Studio Building Planned For SingleRoom Hotel on West Side
description: The lessee of West Side Towers, a singleroomoccupancy hotel at 230 West 76th Street, says he plans to begin renovations next month to convert it into a studio building. The rents will be $250 or more a month, he said.

title: International Reserves Blamed As a Major Cause of Inflation
description: MILAN, Italy, June 25An explosion of international reserves, which countries use to settle debts with one another, was seen today as one of the principal causes of world inflation.

title: Arnholt Smith Case Dropped by I. R. S.
description: SAN DIEGO, June 25  The Internal Revenue Service has withdrawn from a Federal grand jury's criminal investigation of C. Arnholt Smith and has notified the longtime friend of President Nixon that it will not prosecute him on charges of income tax fraud.

title: ANTONIO MORELLI
description: Antonio Morelli, former cone ductor and musical director at the Sands Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., died June 17 in Las Vegas at the age of 69.

title: Fight for Fair Taxes
description: Governor Byrne of New Jersey normally can count on legislative margins of three to one in support of his major proposals, but the state's political history made it certain that he would face an uphill fight when he decided last month to press for a longneeded state income tax.

title: Reed's Knick Role Remains in Doubt
description: The status of Willis Reed's future with the Knicks remains unsettled.

title: RODINO UNIT VOTES EARLY DISCLOSURE OF MOST EVIDENCE
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The House Judiciary Committee decided today, despite bitter and bipartisan dissent, to make public as soon as possible virtually all the evidence assembled for its investigation of President Nixon's conduct in office.

title: Bankruptcy Action Filed By Commonwealth Corp.
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. June 25  Commonwealth Corporation, one of the largest mortgage banking companies in the Southeast and adviser to Commonwealth National Realty Trust, filed bankruptcy proceedings here today under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Body of Man Shot to Death Found in Oil Drum in River
description: After breaking through two padlocks on a 55gallon oil drum, the police yesterday found the body of a man with a bullet hole in his head and his hands tied behind his back, detectives said.

title: Atoms for Peace In the Middle East
description: WASHINGTON  When President Nixon promised to sell nuclear fuel and power plants to Egypt and Israel the outstanding commitment of his Middle Eastern triphe was in part carrying out a policy originally conceived by exPresident Eisenhower and his former atomic energy chief in 1967, during the Lyndon Johnson Administration.

title: 3 Die in I.B.M. Plane Crash
description: BARNWELL, S. C., June 25 (AP)A small jet plane owned by the International Business Machines Corporation crashed near here last night, killing all three persons aboard. The victims were identified as Paul Whitman, 40 years old, of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., James Murphy, 28, of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., both I.B.M. employes, and Thomas O'Brien of Savannah, Ga., the pilot, whose age was not determined.

title: CanAm Race Canceled
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, June 25 (AP)The CanAm road race scheduled for Sept. 15 here has been canceled because of a lack of sponsorship.

title: 4Ton CastIron Landmark Facade Panels Stolen Here
description: The theft of nearly all of a lourton city landmarka 126yearold castiron building facade that had been carefully disassembled for preservationwas discovered yesterday when three men were observed trying to make off with the last piece.

title: Oil Pipe Town Girds for Rush of Workers
description: VALDEZ, AlaskaThe quiet beauty still clings to this little place, hidden at the end of a fjord and sheltered by mountain peaks. But occasional sounds, as emphatic at the crack of ice off the front of a glacier, forecast the human flood that is only months away.

title: Malfunction Delays L.I.R.R.
description: A thirdrail malfunction briefly closed one of the Long Island Rail Road's four lines under the East River at the height of the evening rush hour yesterday, causing delays of up to 15 minutes for thousands of homewardbound riders, the railroad reported. A company spokesman said the partial shutdown occurred shortly before 5 P.M.

title: 42 Tons of Marijuana Seized Near Border
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPIAmerican and Mexican agents have made the largest seizure of marijuana in United StatesMexican border, the Drug Enforcement Administration announced today.

title: 2 Men Are Added To U.S. Track Team
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 25 (AP)Mike Shine, a hurdler, and Charlie Maguire, a distance runner, of Penn State were named today to the 40man United States track and field team that will compete against the Soviet Union in a dual meet July 5 and 6 at Durham, N.C.

title: U.S. Backs $300 Million Israeli Notes
description: Over the last three weeks, Israel has been borrowing $300million in the United States through an unusual issue of securities guaranteed by the United States Government.

title: ALLEGHANY INQUIRY POSTPONED TO JULY
description: The questioning of officials of the Alleghany Corporation by lawyers of the USM Corporation, which was scheduled to get under way here yesterday, has been postponed until July 15 to give the parties involved additional time to prepare for the inquiry.

title: Smaller Units for Notes Under Study by Goldin
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin, disclosed yesterday that, in keeping with a campaign promise, he was considering how to make New York City notes available to small investors.

title: People and Business
description: The W. T. Grant Company, which had a 78 per cent decline in earnings last year and a $6.9million loss in the first quarter of the current fiscal year, announced the resignation yesterday of Richard W. Mayer as chairman and chief executive officer. In addition, Edward Staley, the previous chief executive, resigned as a director.

title: MERGER DEAL SET FOR HUGHES TOOL
description: The Hughes Tool Company announced yesterday in Houston that it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire Byron Jackson, Inc., a subsidiary of the BorgWarner Corporation, under approxicately the same terms as first proposed last Dec. 20.

title: Brando Leaves Hospital
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25 (UPI)Marlon Brando was released today from the U.C.L.A. Medical Center, where he underwent treatment for a torn throat. The actor's secretary, Alice Marshak, said the 50yearold actor had damaged his throat vomiting after apparently having eaten spoiled fish in Tahiti two weeks ago.

title: Lawyer Barred for Year
description: TRENTON, June 25 (UPI)August J. Landi of Edgewater was prohibited from practicing law for one year by the State Supreme Court today. The court ordered the suspension after the Bergen County Ethics Committee accused Mr. Landi of unethical conduct for having filed false incometax returns.

title: FUTURES IN CORN PLUNGE IN PRICE
description: Despite the lowered Government estimate of corn production, traders reacted with disappointment and sold enough corn futures yesterday to lower prices sharply. The reason was that much of their recent buying of corn had been based on expectations of a much lower corn estimate.

title: But Only Gliding'
description: When George Weller wrote his novel about Harvard, Not to Eat, Not for Love, he took his title from an Emerson passage about a trip to Cambridge, Mass., where he saw snakes gliding up a tree, not to eat, not for love, but only gliding.

title: A LISTING OF SOME OF THE FESTIVAL'S HIGHLIGHTS
description: Following ore; some prospective high points of this year's Newport Jazz Festival:

title: Filly Makes Trovato a Most Happy Fella
Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Helen M. Thompson, 66, Dead; ExHead of Orchestra League
description: Helen M. Thompson, who served for 20 years as chief staff executive of the American Symphony Orchestra League and as manager of the New York Philharmonic from 1970 to 1973, died yesterday morning of a heart attack in Carmel, Calif. She was 66 years old.

title: AL FATAH ASSERTS ITPLANNEDATTACK ON TOWN IN ISRAEL
description: CAIRO, June 25Al Fatah, the largest and most moderate of the Palestinian resistance organizations, announced today that it was responsible for the guerrilla raid that resulted in seven deaths last night at the Israeli town of Nahariya.

title: Oklahoma Governor May Face Federal Suit for Fraud on Tax
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, June 21 Oklahoma's Governor, David Hall, was told unofficially this week that auditors in the Internal Revenue Service had recommended that he be prosecuted for income tax fraud. He said that this was good news and bad news.

title: Reds' Pilot Hospitalized
description: CINCINNATI, June 25 (AP) George (Sparky) Anderson, the Cincinnati Reds manager, was flown here from Houston tonight and hospitalized with neck and back pains, the National League club said. A spokesman said Anderson would remain under care until the situation improved.

title: Exploiting Children
description: Among the best of the strengthening amendments to the Fair Labor Standards Act approved by Congress this year was one aimed at ending the shameful exploitation of children on the nation's farms. It prohibited the hiring of boys and girls under 12 to work on large farms, a limitation so modest that its enactment should have come long before agribusiness had all but abolished the family farm.

title: Woman, 22, Falls to Death
description: A 22yearold women, fell of jumped to her death yesterday from the roof of the building she resided in at 234 West 13th Stret. The police reported that she had recently been under a physician's care.

title: World Whale Talks Set Up New Curbs; Impact Is in Doubt
description: LONDON, June 25The International Whaling Commission approved measures today designed to insure that no species of whales face extinction, but there was no indication that the two leading whaling nations would abide by them.

title: Allison to Change Cars
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., June 25 (AP)Bobby Allison said today he would change cars for the next week's Firecracker 400 at the Daytona International Speedway. Allison said he would switch from his Chevrolet to an American Motors Matador previously assigned to Gary Bettenhausen.

title: Marilyn Monroe Story Is Attributed to Hecht
description: The publisher of a forthcoming autobiography of Marilyn Monroe, titled My Story, said yesterday the book was written by the late Ben Hecht.

title: Scaramouche Takes OverAll Honors In NewportBermuda Yachting Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 25  Scaramouche, a 55foot white sloop from the Great Lakes, enhanced her record as the hottest yacht in racing today when she was declared the winner of the 635mile Bermuda classic with half the 167 boats still under sail in the Atlantic.

title: DOLLAR OFF ABROAD; GOLD PRICE RALLIES
description: BRUSSELS, June 25 (UPI)News of a United States trade deficit hit the advancing dollar on European markets today and sent it tumbling.

title: Red Sox Rained Out
description: BOSTON, June 25 (UPI)The scheduled American League game tonight between the Boston Red Sox and the Milwaukee Brewers was postponed because of rain. The game will be made up on Sept, 6.

title: A Soviet Aide Is Back in China For Talks on the Border Issue
description: MOSCOW, June 25The Soviet Union has sent its chief border, negotiator to Peking for talks on the longstanding border quarrel on the eve of President Nixon's visit.

title: WILLIAM E. LONG
description: William E. Long, a pianist who entertained transAtlantic passengers on vessels of United States Lines and American Export Lines, died Monday of cancer at Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 8801 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Real Estate Official On L.I. Is Accused Of Bribing Banker
description: Herbert Frutkin, a long Island realestate man, was arrested yesterday on charges of paying a bank officer approximately $20,000, so he could fraudulently borrow $355,000 from the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company in 1972 and 1973.

title: Paribas, Warburg Merging U.S. Units With A. G. Becker
description: Twoforeignbased investment companies have announced an agreement in principle with A. G. Becker & Co., Inc., a major regional investment broker, to consolidate their United States operations.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, June 25Judy Panissidi's biggest problem as an umpire so far has been getting pair of steeltipped baseball shoes that fit her small feet.

title: Newport Jazz Makes City Syncopation Capital for 10 Days
description: The Newport Jazz Festival will open a 10day stand here Friday with hundreds of performers and a new format that will end the urban sprawl of its first two years in New York and make midtown Manhattan the syncopation capital of the world.

title: MERGER SUPPORTED BY PRESBYTERIANS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 25 (UPI)Delegates to the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church approved without dissenttoday local study of a plan to reunite the 2.9millionmember denomination with its 900,000member Southern counterpart.

title: Cup Soccer Scores
description: World Cup soccer scores will be reported daily in the sports section. Please do not telephone The New York Times for results. Lufthansa Airlines will providt all scores at 2123578400 in New York, 5164893930 on Long Island, 8006453860 in New Jersey. In other areas, call the tollfree Lufthansa reservations number listed in the telephone directory.

title: New Golf Tourney Carries Exemption
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)The winner of the first Tournament Players championship, beginning Aug. 29 at Atlanta, will be exempt from qualifying for next year's United States Open, golf officials said today.

title: Pro Transactions
description: MONTREAL (NL)Recalled Dennis Blair, righthanded pitcher, from its International League affiliate.

title: Democratic Mayors Seek More Power in Party Policies and Choice of 1976 Candidates
description: SAN DIEGO, June 25Democratic Mayors announced here today a program to give them more power in national and party policies.

title: Portuguese in Mozambique Report Killing Black Miners
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, June 25 (Reuters)Seven blacks were killed today and at least six others were wounded when Portuguese troops at a border post opened fire on a disorderly crowd of mine workers returning from South Africa, a military spokesman said here.

title: NEOFASCIST CHIEF RESIGNS IN ITALY
description: ROME, June 25The Italian admiral who has been president of the NeoFascist party resigned today in a dispute over the involvement of rightists in the terrorist incidents that have angered the country in recent months.

title: Prof. Bernard Serin Dead; Taught Physics at Rutgers
description: Prof. Bernard Serin, a retired member of the physics department of Rutgers University and a specialist in lowtemperature physics and experimental conductivity, died June 18 in Manchester, England, He was 52 years old.

title: SOVIET LAUNCHES RESEARCH STATION
description: MOSCOW, June 25  The Soviet Union launched an orbital research station today, putting itself in a position for a space spectacular during President Nixon's visit here later this week.

title: Bridge:
description: Steering the contract into the right hand may need some very delicate bidding. This does not refer to those husbandandwife partners who contrive that the wifeor in some rare cases the husbandshall be a permanent dummy. The problem is purely technical one.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: U.S. Immunity Offer to L.I. Aide Alleged for Testimony on G.O.P.
description: The United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn offered John W. Burke, the Supervisor of Oyster Bay, immunity from prosecution in exchange for damaging testimony against high Republican officials in Nassau County, Mr. Burke's lawyer has said.

title: MSGR. T. J. FEENEY, 74, OF LADY OF VICTORY
description: Msgr. Thomas J. Feeney, pastor of the Lady of Victory Roman Catholic parish in Floral Park, L.I., died Monday at Nassau Hospital, Mineola after a stroke. He was 74.

title: Eisenhower a General
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) John S. D. Eisenhower, son of President Eisenhower, today was made a onestar general in the Army Reserve. He rose to colonel while on active duty, then quit the Army after serving 19 years, although that meant he forfeited all pensions.

title: House Study of Alleged Immigration Service Corruption Reopens
description: WASHINGTON, June 25A House subcommittee reopened today its inquiry into alleged Corruption in the Immigration and Naturalization Service as a result of charges two weeks ago that a Justice Department investigation had been a Coverup

title: News Summary and Index
description: News Summary and Index

title: $60 YOUTH REBATE CANCELED BY KLM
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, under strong pressure from the United States Government and competing airlines, said yesterday that it had dropped a controversial rebate scheme under white travelers to Amsterdam aged 16 through 23 have been paid $50 for answering an opinion questionnaire.

title: U.S. TRADE SHOWS DEFICIT FOR MAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 25A decline, possibly temporary, in agricultural exports, together with a continued growth in imports, swung the United States balance of trade into a nearrecord deficit in May, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SUSPECT DETAINED IN SLAYING OF BOY
description: A 33yearold accused child molester and former mental patient was being held last night in connection with the razor killing of a 7yearold boy on the lower East Side last August a crime that led to the angry siege of the local police station a few days later by residents mistakingly believing the police had caught the killer.

title: Limon Troupe Will Revive Dance at Y
description: The Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association at Lexington Avenue and 92d Street, considered a national dance center in the nineteenforties and fifties has announced its aim to revive that center and invited the Jose Limn Dance Company to become the institution's resident dance company.

title: DEBENTURES SELL AT A RECORD YIELD
description: Trapped in a crumbling credit market, the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company sold $250million of debentures yesterday at a record yield of 9.5 per cent. It was the highest yield ever paid on any Bell System issue and exceeded the previous record, 9.35 per cent, on $100million of debentures sold by the New Jersey Telephone Company on June 16, 1970.

title: Sabres Add Hershey Club
description: BUFFALO, N. Y., June 25 (UPI)The National Hockey League Buffalo Sabres suspended operations with their Cincinnati farm club today and signed a working agreement with the American Hockey League Hershey Bears.

title: U.S. Appealing Approval Of Georgia Bank Merger
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)The Justice Department naintained today that a Federal judge in Georgia erred in approving a proposed merger of he Citizens and Southern Naional Bank with six smaller Georgia banks.

title: $500 Foils Bout Thrusts Fencing Into Pro Picture
description: Fencing, always considered one of the most amateur of sports, is about to take on a professional tinge. A $500 foils bout will be held in the Hotel Commodore's Grand Ballroom Saturday night to give the closing session of the eightday national championships a booster shot.

title: SHOTS IN ARGENTINA STRIKE U.S EMBASSY
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 25 Reuters) The United States Embassy here was machinegunned from a moving car early, today, shortly after a series of bomb explosions had caused widespread damage.

title: Rules for the Candidate Under Attack Called Freedom Curb
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Supreme Court struck down today a Florida law requiring newspapers to print replies from political candidates attacked in their columns. The Justices held that the law was an unconstitutional restriction on freedom of the press.

title: Barker and Martinez Trial Starts in Capital Today
description: MIAMI, June 25Bernard L. Barker and Eugenio R. Martinez, who go on trial in Washington tomorrow, accused of breaking into the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist, left their hometown here this afternoon virtually penniless.

title: Even More Eclecticism Added To the Mahavishnu Orchestra
description: John McLaughlin's newly incarnated Mahavishnu Orchestra played for the first time in Manhattan on Monday evening at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park, and let neither the onslaught of rain nor the reservations of a few critics stop it.

title: 4 U. N. SOLDIERS KILLED IN GOLAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25Four Austrian soldiers serving with the United Nations peace force in the Golan Heights were killed today when their vehicle hit a land mine, Secretary General Waldheim announced.

title: 37 Senators Express Doubts on ATest Curb
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Thirtyseven Senators said today that they would have serious reservations about supporting a limit on underground nuclear testing unless it contained provisions for an eventual end to all such tests.

title: Trade Shows Deficit
description: The United States balance of trade was swung into nearrecord deficit in May by a decline, which may be temporary, in agricultural exports and a continued rise in imports. Details on Page 59.

title: Actress Left $400,000
description: ZANESVILLE, Ohio June 25 (UPI)  The will of Agnes Moorehead was filed in Muskingum County Probate Court here yesterday showing assets of nearly $400,000 in Ohio. The actress died May 30 at the age of 67.

title: Sikkim's Monarch Goes to New Delhi For Talks in Crisis
description: NEW DELHI, June 25The monarch of Sikkim arrived here tonight in an effort to persuade the Indian Government to allow his Himalayan kingdom to keep its separate entity.

title: Trade Shows Deficit
description: The United States balance of trade was swung into a nearrecord deficit in May by a decline, which may be temporary, in agricultural exports and a continued rise in imports. Details on Page 59.

title: Planning Unit Introduces Neighborhood Miniplans
description: A new concept in neighborhood planning, epitomized by a series of miniplans tailored to the needs of individual communities, is being inaugurated by the City Planning Commission.

title: CLEANAIR GOALS RELAXED CITY
description: The Federal Government sharply relaxed its pressure yesterday on New York City to achieve healthful air standards.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Today at the supermarket, two rib lamb chops are $1.54. At the same time, cattlemen complain that they don't get enough price to continue production. So they run to the Government to put on a promotion campaign to get rid of the excessive meat supplies backed up between production and sales.

title: Citizens Group Formed to Fight Byrne's IncomeTax Program
description: TRENTON, June 25 (AP)A citizens organization began a drive today to defeat the Byrne administration's incometax program.

title: Vinyl Chloride Exposure Limit Is Opposed by Plastics Industry
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Representatives of the plastics industry pressed today for a relaxation of proposed Federal rules governing worker exposure to vinyl chloride, a chemical that has been linked to 21 cases of a rare, fatal liver cancer.

title: Cold Days, Dark Nights
description: NEW MARKET, Tenn.  Mother Jones, that elderly rabblerouser who beat coal operators with brooms and became a coalfield legend in the bloody United Mine Workers organizing drives earlier in this century, promised when she got to heaven she would harass the Lord about the pitiful condition of West Virginia coal miners. Either Mother Jones did not make it up there or the Lord is a coal operator, a retired U.M.W. organizer said recently. The Mother Jones dilemma aside, it is still hell to be a coal miner.

title: TOP NIXON AIDES SPARED PAY CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The House of Representatives, apparently heading admonitions not to engage in political overkill, sidestepped today an opportunity to cut the number and salaries of some of President Nixon's top aides.

title: U.S. Court Rejects Railroad Revamping
description: The Regional Rail Reorganization Act of 1973, which President Nixon signed into law on Jan. 2 and which provides a means by which the Penn Central and other bankrupt railroads could become part of a new taxpayersupported railroad, was found unconstitutional in part yesterday by a special threejudge Federal court in Philadelphia.

title: Presidential Journey
description: President Nixon's eightday journey to Brussels and Moscow will focus on the future of dtente with the Soviet Union; but it begins fittingly with a summit meeting of the NATO allies, the first in seventeen years.

title: Big Board Seat Stile Off
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of a seat for $72,000, down $1,000 from the previous sale on Monday.. The current price of a seat is $66,000 bid and $77,000 asked the exchange said,

title: Acrylic 2Seater Sells for $6,500
description: Malcolm Bricklin is a native Philadelphian who favors Western clothes and now lives in Arizona. A man who made his first money in building supplies, he now is very excited about automobiles and car safety.

title: Orthodox Jews Pick New Yorker for Post
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 25The Rabbinical Council of America today elected Rabbi Fabian Schonfeld of New York as president of the 1,000member Orthodox body. The action was taken at the 38th annual convention of the council at the Caribbean Hotel.

title: Drugs for Hyperactive Child Scored
description: CHICAGO, June 25  A psychologist studying the effects of stimulant drugs on hyperactive children has found that while the controversial treatment calms the behavior and increases the attention span of the children for whom it is prescribed, it does not improve their school performance.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW INCREASE
description: Confounding many analysts prices rose yesterday on tin American Stock Exchange despite the spreading increase is the prime rate. The only explanation for the first rise in 10 straight sessions was that the gain was mostly a rebound from the recent sharp losses and perhaps the expectation of a decline in business bank loans for the week ending today.

title: Army Copier Is Forced Down on Jones Beach
description: JONES BEACH STATE PARK, L.I., June 25 (AP) An Army helicopter lost power and landed on Jones Beach today with what an Army spokesman described as classified cargo.

title: RALPH DEPAOLA, BROKER, 51, DIES
description: Ralph DePaola, a broker who was credited with a major role in developing the money market in this city, died on Monday at his home in Washington Township, N.J. He was 51 years old.

title: Thousands Mourn 4 Victims in Israel
description: NAHARIYA, Israel, June 25 Several thousand mourners poured out their grief at a beachfront cemetery this evening during the funeral for the four Israeli victims of the Arab guerrilla attack on this northern resort town.

title: Streisand's Pete's Sake Opens the Astor Plaza
description: Loews Astor Plaza, the movie theater whose completion has been delayed for more than three years, will open today with the premiere of the Barbra Streisand comedy For Pete's Sake.

title: The Uninvited Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, June 25One of the misfortunes of President Nixon's present mission to Moscow is that he did not take along some of the leaders of Congress, whose understanding of the complex issues of military arms control is vital to Congressional approval of whatever agreements are reached there.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: NIXON IN BRUSSELS FOR TALKS TODAY WITH NATO CHIEFS
description: BRUSSELS, June 25Only five days after completing a tour of the Middle East, President Nixon arrived here tonight to confer with Western European leaders before going on to Moscow Thursday for his third summit meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: TIMES IS CRITICIZED BY NEWS COUNCIL
description: The National News Council, a group that investigates public grievances about the national news media, said yesterday that The New York Times had been remiss in handling complaints earlier this year about an article it published regarding a report on the effects of chemical herbicides that the United States used in the war in Vietnam.

title: Congressional Panel Backs Control of U.S. Nuclear Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The SenateHouse Atomic Energy Committee approved a bill today to give Congress veto authority over transfers of United States nuclear technology to foreign countries.

title: Red Smith
description: If baseball's annual AllStar game has any excuse for existence, it is the opportunity it creates to present on one field the 18 players the fans most enjoy watching. When the late Arch Ward, sports editor of the Chicago Tribune, thought it up as a promotion stunt for his paper, he called it the Dream Game, on the theory that to see Babe Ruth, Jimmy Foxx, Charley Gehringer and Joe Cronin as teammates opposing Frank Frisch, Bill Terry, Gabby Hartnett and Paul Waner would he a dream come true for every Godfearing Tribune reader who had ever read his pants shiny on a bleacher bench. It was conceived as an exhibition, a showcase for the display of the sport's most illustrious figures, and not as a Valid test of strength between leagues. That is why it is a mistake to complain when players are elected on the basis of personal popularity or boxoffice appeal instead of their current batting averages. If the goal were to assemble the strongest team a league could muster in order to defeat the cream of the other league, the job ought to be left to professional baseball men. It is entrusted to the fans purposely in order that they may their preferences.

title: Marine Foils Team Captures U.S. Title
description: A United States Marine Corps team based at Quantico, Va., won the national team foils championship at the Commodore Hotel late Monday night.

title: Byrne Signs Tenant Bills, Including Eviction Curbs
description: TRENTON, June 25  Governor Byrne signed into law today a package of four tenants' rights bills that are believed here to make up the most consumeroriented legislation of its kind in the nation.

title: COMPLAINTS RISE ON AUTO REPAIRS
description: The automobile repair industry is sick, a conference of consumer affairs officials from around the country has been told.

title: $50 YOUTH REBATE CANCELED BY KLM
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, under strong pressure from the United States Government and competing airlines, said yesterday that it had dropped a controversial rebate scheme under white travelers to Amsterdam aged 16 through 23 have been paid $50 for answering an opinion questionnaire.

title: Kelly Retires Next Week As Head of State Police
description: TRENTON, June 25 (AP)Governor Byrne announced today that Col. David B. Kelly, Superintendent of the state police, would retire next week to accept a position in private industry. Colonel Kelly's retirement came earlier than had been expected. He has been strongly criticized by some state troopers recently for allegedly making arbitrary policy decisions and being too harsh a disciplinarian.

title: Nadjari Checks 150 Cases For Illegal Drug Sentences
description: The office of Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, is reviewing the court records of 150 narcotics cases in the five boroughs where defendants, convicted of felonies before the more stringent laws took effect last September, may have been sentenced illegally and, in effect, set free.

title: House Panel Bars Stiff Curbs On Tax Breaks on Real Estate
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The House Ways and Means Committee voted down today the major portion of a taxreform proposal that was aimed at reducing the tax advantages that wealthy persons can get frm investing in real estate.

title: Soviet Wheat Crop Pat Below Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reuters)  Soviet wheat production this year seems likely to fall short of earlier predictions, but total 1974 production of all grains is still expected to reach Moscow's officially stated goal of 205 million tons, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: DOW CLIMBS 1252 AS VOLUME RISES
description: The stock market turned bullish yesterday although analysts insisted its rally was just technical.

title: U.S. Denounces the Sudan. For Yielding Murderers
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The United States, in a strongly worded statement, said today that it was dismayed over the Sudan's decision to turn over to the Palestine Liberation  Organization the eight confessed killers of two senior American diplomats and a Belgian.

title: Daily Rate for New Car Sales Climbing
description: DETROIT, June 25Sales of new cars are showing signs of pulling out of the long 1974 model slump, although retail deliveries are still well below 1973 levels.

title: AL FATAH ASSERTS IT SET UP ATTACK ON TOWN IN ISRAEL
description: CAIRO, June 25Al Fatah, the largest and most moderate of the Palestinian resistance organizations, announced today that it was responsible for the guerrilla raid that resulted in seven deaths last night at the Israeli town of Nahariya.

title: Jersey's High Court Rules Catena Must Stay in Jail
description: TRENTON, June 25 The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered that Gerardo Catena, the reputed Mafia kingpin in the state, remain confined on civil contempt charges for refusing to tell the State Commission of Investigation what it wanted to know about organized crime in New Jersey.

title: Impeachment Homework: Panel Hits Books
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Bill Cohen practices the piano at 2 A.M. these days. Larry Hogan has been able to get to the movies only once in the last six months. Tom Railsback has trouble sleeping. Liz Holtzman has suspended ner Sunday afternoon office hours in her district.

title: I.B.M. Announces Rise Of 17% in Dividend
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday a 17 per cent increase in its quarterly cash dividend paid to holders of the company's 147 million common shares.

title: TV Writers to Get Awards From Lilly For Human Values
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25The Eli Lilly Endowment today established a series of prizes to reward television writers for programs that affirm human values in American television.

title: Ordinary Citizen Given Right to a Libel Suit Over False Report
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Supreme Court ruled today that an ordinary citizen elevated to sudden prominence by news events can sue any newspaper or radio or television station that circulates a false and defamatory account of his role in those events.

title: FRAUD IS CHARGED IN STOCK OFFERING
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Securities and Exchange Commission today brought charges of fraud and other violations of Federal Securities law against the defunct firm of Laidlaw & Co. and 20 other respondents in connection with an unsuccessful offering of 200,000 shares of Sa Corn stock in October, 1972.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: India Denies She Is Working On Hydrogen Bomb Project
description: NEW DELHI, India, June 25 (AP)The Indian Atomic Energy Commission today denied that it was developing a hydrogen explosive device as a followup to its underground atomic test last month.

title: CLEANAIR GOALS RELAXED FOR CITY
description: The Federal Government sharply relaxed its pressure yesterday on New York City to achieve healthful air standards.

title: Economic Theory Goes Awry
description: Among the casualties of the present inflation, economic stagnation, soaring interest rates and slumping stock and bond markets are major elements of modern economic theory. The economists, never the jolliest of men, are feeling even more dismal than usual and guiltridden to boot.

title: Interaction Students And Thelin Group Give Jazz Concert
description: Young musicians who have been attending Jazz Interaction weekly workshops since February were given a showcase Monday evening in a program at the Pub Theatrical, Broadway at 51st Street, that also included a visiting Swedish jazz quartet, the Eje Thelin Group.

title: Bank of Montreal Prime Up
description: MONTREAL, June 25 (AP)The Bank of Montreal announced today an increase of  per cent in its prime lending rate to 11 per cent.

title: 4 Called Part of $1Million Holdup Ring
description: Four men described as part of a loosely knit band of armed robbers who stole and squandered more than $1million over the last four years have been arrested by Nassau County detectives and charged with individual holdups that netted more than $250,000.

title: Foreman A Deux And Wetzig Works Contrast in Dance
description: Betsy Wetzig's choreography is as simplistic as Laura Foreman's is darkly complex, and they shared an unusually mixed program at the Cubiculo on Monday evening. Miss Wetzig takes a theme such as play, birth or loneliness and elaborates straightforwardly on it, while Miss Foreman places her dancers in an Eden and inserts the snake of discord into the scene.

title: Business Briefs
description: MEXICO CITY, June 26 (AP)The Mexican Government has ordered a price freeze on all basic consumer products until Jan. 1 in a bid to combat inflation that is running at 22 per cent. It also agreed to study a labor demand to link wage increases to the cost of living.

title: $15Million Moore Bonus for Toronto
description: TORONTO, June 25A municipal controversy over the purchase of a work by Henry Moore, the crowding of the Tate Gallery in London and an opportune visit here by the British sculptor have combined to bring Toronto a bonusthe largest collection of Mr. Moore's work in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Rodino Panel Embroiled In Debate Before Public
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Members of the House Judiciary Committee demonstrated today that, even in a process as lofty as impeachment, partisan pressures and human disorder can sometimes prevail.

title: 4 ARE CONVICTED IN F. H. A. SCANDAL
description: The president of one of the largest mortgagelending concerns in the East, his wife and two other persons were convicted by a Federal District Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday of conspiracy to misuse Federal funds designed to help the poor bur houses.

title: Model Says Man Took Ring From Shared Room
description: A Manhattan model complained in a lawsuit yesterday that a Maryland business executive had kept her diamond ring after she had shared a hotel room with him here last Aug. 21.

title: CALLEY'S BAIL PLEA DENIED BY JUSTICES
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The Supreme Court denied today an application for bail by former First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who is seeking review of his courtmartial conviction in the My Lai killings.

title: GasExporting Countries Told U.S. Insists on Realistic Price
description: ALGIERS, June 25  Two representatives of the United States Government have cautioned the world's naturalgas exporting countries to keep prices realistic and supplies secure if they expect to sell up to the United States.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: STATE BACKS PLAN TO SHIFT INMATES
description: WINSLOW TOWNSHIP, June 25The state's Department of Institutions and Agencies has begun a campaign to convince local residents that a plan to have 60 Leesburg state prison inmates live here at the Ancora Psychiatric Hospital, where they work in the laundry, will not pose a threat to the safety of Camden County residents.

title: Public Schools Close Today With Officials Saying It's Been a Very Good Year
description: Classes will end today for what many Board of Education officials feel has been the most successful year in the New York City public schools since before the 1968 Ocean HillBrownsville eruptions in Brooklyn.

title: SPANIARDS HONOR DON JUAN AS KING
description: LISBON, June 24  A few hundred Spanish monarchists stood on a raindrenched lawn in nearby Estoril yesterday and shouted Long live the King! at a tall man long frustrated in his ambition to be ruler of Spain.

title: 2 Surrender in Texas In Jersey Bride's Death
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. (UPI)  Two San Antonio men surrendered today and each was held in lieu of $250,000 bond on charges of murdering a heavily insured New Jersey bride on her honeymoon in New Orleans in January.

title: Yukio Abe, 73, Chairman Of Daiwa Securities, Dies
description: Yukio Abe, chairman of the Daiwa Securities Comany, Ltd., a leading Japanese securities firm, died Monday at Nakajima Hospital, Tokyo, after a stroke.

title: City Alimony Jail Is Sold At Auction for $107,000
description: An increasingly apprehensive bride and groom waited down the hall in a Roosevelt Hotel anteroom yesterday as the city's old alimony jail was auctioned off in the Grand Ballroom for $107,000.

title: 2 ExNazis Linked to Pogrom Are Sentenced in Hamburg
description: BONN, June 25A Hamburg court sentenced two former Nazi officials to prison today for participation in the murder of 15,000 Jews in 1941 and 1942 in the region of Slonim, a former Polish city now in West European Russia.

title: Accent Still On Defense In Soccer
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 25The second round of the World Cup soccer tournament, which gets under way with four matches tomorrow, is not expected to he much different from the first. This means more play that accentuates the negative.

title: GOING OUT /Guide
description: MUSIC, MUSIC, MUSIC The, choice is yours, baroque or string ensemble or jazz a la Newport, midday or evening, Manhattan or Brooklyn, as the number and variety of outdoor concerts swell with the onset of summer.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL MONTREAL (NL)Recalled Dennis Blair, righthanded pitcher; from its International League affiliate.

title: JAILING OF CATENA BACKED IN JERSEY
