description: TRENTON, June 25 The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered that Gerardo Catena, the reputed Mafia kingpin in the state, remain confined on civil contempt charges for refusing to tell the State Commission of Investigation what it wanted to know about organized crime in New Jersey.

title: Influx of Physicians From Abroad Held To Have Declined
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Nixon Administration officials told the Senate health subcommittee today that an influx of foreigntrained doctors, which is spurring intense controversy, in the medical profession, had crested and was apparently de clining.

title: District 2 Panel Confirms Ouster of Mrs. Lansky
description: The District 2 School Board, at an emotionaland at times tumultuous  public meeting, confirmed last night its decision to replace Superintendent Rhoda S. Lansky with the district's current deputy superintendent, Dr. Barbara Weldon.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: JOSEPH H. HEIL
description: Joseph H. Heil, an artist and collagist, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at Doctors hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 46 East 82d Street.

title: FRANK F. SHULOCK
description: Frank F. Shulock, a textile broker and specialist in the sale of surplus fabrics, died in his office Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 425 West 23d Street.

title: Mabel B. Turner, 87, Led National Cathedral School
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Miss Mabel B. Turner, educator and principal for nearly two decades, of the National Cathedral School for Girls here, died Satuiday of a heart attack at Montgomery General Hospital in suburban Maryland. She was 87 years old.

title: U.S. Aides Differ in Views On Aid for Ailing Airlines
description: The heads of two Federal agencies took opposing stands yesterday on House bills to provide subsidies to prop financially distressed United States airlines flying international routes.

title: Topless Dancing Ruled A Form of Expression
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled here yesterday that dancing is a form of expression protected by the First Amenrment and supported a lowercourt decision barring the town of North Hempstead, L.I., from prosecuting owners of topless bars.

title: Allegany D.A. Denies Charge
description: BELMONT, N.Y., June 25 (UPI)  Allegany County District Attorney John D'Arcy pleaded not guilty today to numerous charges of misconduct while in office. Mr. D'Arcy was named recently in a misdemeanor indictment containing 85 counts ranging from impairing the morals of a minor to thirddegree assault.

title: Beame Goes South of Border To Talk Shop With a Mayor
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, June 25While a sevenpiece mariachi band whooped and wailed in the background, Maypr Beame of New York City and his counterpart in this tawdry border town, Marco Antonio Bolanos Cacho, the presidente municipal, traded tales of politics and government today.

title: U.S. Military Presence Is in Asia as of Old, but Justification for It Is All New
description: SUBIC BAY, the Philippines  In foreign ministries and embassies around Southeast Asia, the prospect of a military disengagement by the United States is still discussed as a major imponderable. But here at the naval base that is generally held to be the single most valuable American installation in the region, they talk of doubling the size of a large floating drydock so it can accommodate aircraft carriers.

title: House Backs Extension Of U.S. Export Controls
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reuters)The House of Representatives approved today 30day extension of the Export Administration Act, which gives the Commerce Department authority to impose export controls. The act is due to expire on June 30.

title: Loews' Net Income Climbs in Quarter
description: The Loews Corporation reported yesterday increased net income for the third fiscal quarter ended May 31, but a decline for the nine months despite a $4.4million income from the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation. This was realized from equity earnings in its 25.3 per cent investment in the steel company, or about 20.4 per cent of the voting interest.

title: MRS. JOHN J. M'GLENN
description: Mrs. Mary O'Keefe McGlenn, wife of John J. McGlenn, an International Business Machines Corporation vice president, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center, Paterson, N. J. She was 52 years old.

title: CANNED HEAT OPENS RUN AT BOTTOM LINE
description: Canned Heat, which opened at the Bottom Line on Monday and plays through tonight, dates to 1965, when it was one of the first and best white blues bands. Aside from its blues and rhythmandblues recreations, Canned Heat was the archetypal party band, fun and full of good times.

title: British Millionaire's Daughter Sentenced to 9 Years in Art Thefts for I.R.A.
description: DUBLIN, June 25Bridget Rose Dugdale, 33yearold daughter of an English millionaire, was sentenced to nine years' imprisonment here today for receiving 19 paintings known to have been stolen. She pleaded proudly and incorruptibly guilty to the charge in Special Criminal Court.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Rules for the Candidate Under Attack Called Freedom Curb
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Supreme Court struck down today a Florida law requiring newspapers to print replies from political candidates attacked in their columns. The Justices held that the law was an unconstitutional restriction on freedom of the press.

title: City MinorityHiring Plan For Projects Takes Effect
description: The city's mandatory plan to increase jobs for minority workers on federally subsidized city projects went into effect yesterday.

title: Auto That Outsold Model T Fading
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, June 24The Beetle runs and runs, according to the Volkswagen slogan, but by early July, it won't be, at least not off the assembly lines here.

title: Missile Misunderstanding Clarifies a Power Struggle
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Senator Henry M. Jackson and Secretary of State Kissinger have spent the last few days trading charges and denials over what seemed to be misunderstandings and technicalities connected with the 1972 missilelimitation agreement. Above the public arguments, however, at least in the eyes of many of the participants, hover the kinds of deeper conflicts, confusion and just plain politics that move and shake Washington.

title: ERVIN REPORT AIDE DRAFTS PROPOSALS
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)Recommendations that Congress limit a President's use of executive privilege and define exactly what he can do in the name of national security have been proposed for the Senate Watergate committee's final report.

title: TV: The Joy of Hobbies
description: Now that it's summer, and the prospect of televised impeachment hearings stil seems dim, WNET/Channel 13 is once again entering a period that borders on improvisation. If the current hearings were televised, public TV would he rerunning them in evening prime time, and all scheduling problems would be eliminated.

title: Mocking the Dead
description: Last year, when the authorities in Khartoum captured eight Black September gunmen who had tortured and killed a Belgian and two American diplomats, the Sudanese Government condemned the outrage and promised to bring the criminals to justice. The Sudanese Foreign Minister called the brutal killings a criminal act to be prosecuted and punished. Sudan's President Nimeiry himself denounced the barbarous deed on television.

title: Greenburgh Official Asks State to Investigate Town
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 25The Supervisor of the Town of Greenburgh, Anthony F. Veteran, said today that he had written to Governor Wilson asking for an independent investigation of allegations of active organized crime within the town and within its Police Department.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: Conte Seeking Reelection
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) Representative Silvio O. Conte, Republican of Massachusetts, announced today, that he would seek reelection. Since 1959, Mr, Conte has represented Massachusetts's first Congressional District, comprising most of the state's four western counties, except Springfield. He is unopposed in the Republican primary.

title: Student Convicted as Yugoslavia Fights Dissent in Universities
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 25A 21yearold student was convicted here today on charges of disseminating hostile propaganda in what appeared to be an important step forward in the Government's efforts to eliminate dissent in the universities.

title: A RIGHTS ADVOCATE WINS IN MISSISSIPPI
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 25Rev. Kenneth L. Dean, a white who helped Mississippi blacks gain civil rights in the nineteensixties, won the Democratic nomination in the Fourth Congressional District in a runoff today.

title: FRANCIS E. HAYES
description: Francis E. Hayes, insurance executive, died Monday after a heart attack in the emergency room of Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 47 Tallman Avenue, Nyack, N. Y.

title: Arnholt Smith Case Dropped by I.R.S.
description: SAN DIEGO, June 25  The Internal Revenue Service has withdrawn from a Federal grand jury's criminal investigation of C. Arnholt Smith and has notified the longtime friend of President Nixon that it will not prosecute him on charges of income tax fraud.

title: CanAm Race Canceled
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, June 25 (AP)The CanAm road race scheduled for Sept. 15 here has been cancelled because of a lack of sponsorshi.

title: 4Ton CastIron Landmark Facade Panels Stolen Here
description: Working in daylight under the startled eyes of a construction contractor, three thieves made off yesterday with the last panels of a fourton city landmarka 126yearold castiron facade of a fourstory structure described as a rare architectural treasure.

title: Winds Keep Yacht Trials Landlocked
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 25 It was blowing too hard to continue the America's Cup trials today, so the New York Yacht Club called off the racing for the four 12Meter yachts involved. There were gusts from the Northeast up to 30 knots and waves six feet and over. These yachts are racers, but not ocean racers.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DESIGNATED HEIR. By Maxine Kumin. 174 pages. Viking. $6.95.

title: Scaasi Revives The HatOne More Time
description: The hat Remember? It's what a woman would buy to cheer herself up. A vestigial article of apparel, along with garter belts and bustles, that has periodic revivals, mostly to keep the head warm in winter, shaded in summer.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2 P.M. (RadioWMCA, 2 P.M.

title: AIDE SAYS ISRAEL HAS NO AARMS
description: WASHINGTON, June 25Shimon Peres, the new Israeli Defense Minister, said today that Israel did not have tactical nuclear weapons, but declined to say whether she had a plant to process plutonium for atomic weapons.

title: McDowell, Velez Lead Candidates For Stottlemyre's Spot, on Roster
description: The Yankees are in the midst of making their 13th roster move of the season and it could turn out to be the unluckiest one of all.

title: Market Places:

title: 18 Show Up For 3Day Knick Camp
description: Luther Rackley and Jim Ard went jobhunting yesterday. So did 16 other hopefuls as the Knicks opened a threeday camp at Pace College in search of talent. It was the first such camp the Knicks had run at this time of the year since 1966.

title: Dr. Edward Little, 76, Dies; Expert on Arctic Infields
description: SAN DIEGO, June 25 (UPI)Dr. Edward Little, a leading researcher on the Arctic ice fields and on polar survival, died Saturday. He was 76 years old.

title: Nixon Signs Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)  President Nixon has signed legislation giving the Government power to order electricity plants to start burning coal instead of relatively scarce oil and gas, White House sources said today. The bill is the Energy Supply and Environmental Coordiantion Act of 1974.

title: For the Veteran Partygoers Wizard of Oz Was Neato
description: Christopher and Gregory Brody threw a joint birthday bash the other day. Actually it was a bit prematureChristopher's birthday isn't until July 23 and Gregory's is July 27but by July all their friends would be scattered from Southampton to St. Tropez.

title: Nadjari Checks 150 Cases For Illegal Drug Sentences
description: The office of Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, is reviewing the court records of 150 narcotics cases in the five boroughs where defendants, convicted of felonies before the more stringent laws took effect last September, may have been sentenced illegally and, in effect, set free.

title: German Banks Told to Give Data on Foreign Exchange
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 30 (Reuters) West German banks must report details of their forward foreign exchange transactions starting next month, the Bundesbank said today. Banks will be required to report their forward currency transaction positions up to the last day of each month in three categoriesup to one month, one to three months and more than three months.

title: Four Convicted Here in F.H.A. Case
description: The president of one of the largest mortgagelending concerns in the East, his wife and two other persons were convicted by a Federal District Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday of conspiracy to misuse Federal funds designed to help the poor buy houses.

title: Maheu Damage Suit Is Sent to the Jury On Trial's 69th Day
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25United States District Judge Harry Pregerson submitted Robert A. Maheu's $17.3million defamation suit against Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation to a sixmember jury shortly before noon today on the 69th day of trial.

title: Spotlight Never Dims on Jazz Scene That Floats From Club to Club
description: When the Newport Jazz Festival, a triumph of logistics dealing with a breed always on the move, opens here Friday, it will find a city steeped in the art it loves.

title: Advertising: Buying Prime Time
description: They're not losing that much commercial time, but the effect is psychological. And that's what this business ispsychological.

title: SIGNS PROMISED AT L.I. CRASH SITE
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., June 25  The State Department of Transportation promised a group of housewives from Rocky Point today that it would put up big new warning signs near a school where a child was killed by a car last week.

title: Koosman and Kranepool Star As Mets Top Cubs Again, 51
description: CHICAGO, June 25Nobody on the New York Mets wants to admit that injuries have helped them, but for the second game in a row since John Milner tripped over a chair and hurt his wrist and Felix Milan came down with an infected nostril, their replacements have been winning games.

title: Popular History Museum Planned for Bicentennial
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) A $10million popular history museum housing a visual and electronic projection of the events of 200 years ago will be the centerpiece of the city's contribution to the bicentennial celebration.

title: May Sales Rose 14.2% at Chain Stores
description: In the best monthly advance so far this year, chainstore sales in May registered a gain of 14.2 per cent over the level of May, 1973. For the year to date, sales rose by 13.1 per cent over those of the JanuaryMay period of 1973.

title: Death Sentence Imposed
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., June 26 (UPI)  Ronald L. Sims, 23 years old, who shot a man in the back with a shotgun at point blank range in a $10 holdup, became today the second killer sentenced to be executed since California out the death penalty back on the law books.

title: Health Department Charges Violation At 23 Food Outlets
description: The Health Department has announced the names of 23 more restaurants and food stores charged with having ?? lated the Health Code.

title: Theater: Actor's Dozen
description: One way for a theaterlover to test his dedication is to perch from 6 P.M. to 1:45 A.M. watching 13 short new plays; with 10minute breathers. Was it worthwhile? Yes, decidedly. With its third, annual summer festival, rotating through tomorrow and wrapping up a repeat, final marathon on Saturday, the WPA Theater, at 333 Bowery (4739345), remains one of the brightest Off Off Broadweir beacons.

description: I like the city of New York and I'd like to keep playing there, but I'm going to sit down after the season and look over the whole situation. The speaker was Joe Namath, announcing he would not negotiate a new contract with the New York Jets this year.

description: A 25,000acre oceanfront tract in South Carolina, valued at $20million, has been donated as a preserve to The Nature Conservancy, a landconservation organization.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Detroit Diesel Allison division of the General Motors Corporation received a $30.2million Army contract for diesel engines for combat vehicles, it was announced yesterday.

title: Associated Milk Products Defends Market Practices
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., (UPI)Associated Milk Producers, Inc., said yesterday its marketing procedures were proper and fair, and denied charges filed by the Texas Attorney General of antitrust practices.

title: Books of The Times
description: Joseph Epstein's Divorced in America is depressing. It is depressing not so much because of the bleakly negative portrait of Marriage in an Age of Possibility it paints, but more because it does so with such intelligence and honesty. Take, for instance, the very circumstances that produced the book. For reasons that will soon

title: ExSenator Ernest Gruening, 87, Dies
description: Former Senator Ernest Gruening of Alaska, who was one of the first outspoken critics of United States involvement in Vietnam, died in a Washington hospital last night of cancer. He was 87 years old.

title: Galiber Is Cleared
description: A Bronx grand jury in effect cleared State Senator Joseph L. Galiber yesterday of corruption charges that had prevented his appointment as the city's first black Deputy Mayor last January. The panel had investigated corporate campaign contributions and alleged forged checks but refused to return a true bill. Details on Page 49.

title: Woman Legislator Robbed
description: BOSTON, June 26 (UPI)Representative Margaret M. Heckler, Republican of Massachusetts, was robbed last night of about $100 when three gunmen wearing ski masks held up the Warren Tavern, a reproduction of a Revolutionary period tavern, in Charlestown. The police said, one of the robbers had stood at the door while the two others went from table to table robbing customers. About $1,800 was taken from the patrons and another $1,800 from the tavern.

title: Indians Triumph as Torres Cuts Off a Big Inning

Now the Yankees are limping off on another journey after having lost four of five games in the place they call home.

title: Coty Awards Go to Halston and Beene
description: Geoffrey Beene and R. Halston Frowick (he's more widely known as Halston) were elected to the Hall of Fame by the Coty American Fashion Critics' Awards committee, it was announced yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The House voted 407 to 7 today to approve $20.8billion appropriations for the Department of Housing and Urban Development and 10 independent agencies.

title: HARPER STRIKERS FACE NEW THREAT
description: The executive vice president of Harper & Row said yesterday that if the 10day old strike at the bookpublishing house continued, it was inevitable sooner or later that we'll have to hire some permanent replacements.

title: ALLIED CHIEFS SIGN NATO DECLARATION

description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 26The fifth Islamic Conference of Foreign Ministers, as it concluded here last night, issued what amounted to a condemnation of the Philippine Government for its treatment of its Moslem minority.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, JUNE 27, 1974
description: International President Nixon and other leaders of the North Atlantic Alliance signed a new declaration intended to insure close consultation and end bickering among them. In private meetings as well, Mr: Nixon gave the allies assurances that he would protect their. interests in his Moscow talks with the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev. The ceremony marked the formal conclusion of some 14 months of bargaining. [1:3.]

title: Morrow to Replace the Wolfman At WNBC After Stint at ABC
description: Cousin Brucie Morrow, the rock disk jockey, who has dommated the nighttime radio ratings in the New York area over the last decade, is leaving WABC and taking over Wolfman Jack's competitive slot on WNBC.

title: Mrs. Margaret Barnes, 57, Of Life Insurance Institute
description: Mrs. Margaret Gallagher Barnes, a retired executive of the Institute of Life Insurance, died Tuesday at Mercy Hospital in Miami. She was 57 years old and, until a year ago, had lived at 25 Sutton Place South.

description: WASHINGTON, Rule 26 (AP) The Senate passed today legislation to keep benefits from expiring Sunday for four million veterans who served between 1955 and 1966, including 285,000 now enrolled in school.

title: Wilson Seeks to Placate Conservatives and Avoid a Primary
description: In an attempt to placate dissident Conservatives who have threatened a primary challenge, Governor Wilson issued a statement yesterday listing various dollarsaving programs instituted for taxpayers by his administration in the last legislative session.

title: RABBIS DEPLORE LOSS OF YOUTHS
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 26American Orthodox rabbis acknowledge that they have failed to capture what one of them described as the hearts and minds of many of our educated, intellectual Jewish youth.

title: Tests Blamed for Tremors
description: VENTURA, Calif., June 26 (AP)  A Navy spokesman said today that offshore aircraft sonic tests were probably the cause of tremors that shook buildings throughout a large area of Southern California last night and early this morning. The shakes were felt from Santa Barbara to Long Beach, 100 miles apart. No damage was reported, but the police said they had received hundreds of tlephone calls front worried residents.

title: Ballet: Hamburg's Popular Neumeier
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, June 24John Neumeier is today, one of the four or five bestknown choreographers in Western Europe. But the Wisconsinborn Mr. Neumeier is still a relatively unknown force in the United States, although his Don Juan, which he created for Rudolf Nureyev and the National Ballet of Canada, has done something to rectify that disparity. Also, next month his version of Stravinsky's Le Baiser de la Fee is to be staged by the American Ballet Theater.

title: Why City Is Switching From Master Plan to Miniglan
description: Make no little plans, wrote Daniel Burnham, the Chicago architect, in the introduction to his monumental Plan for Chicago of 1909, a work which played a crucial role in encouraging cities and towns throughout the United States to adopt sweeping, utopian master plans to guide their growth.

title: Benjamin Whitaker, Taught Economics at Union College
description: Dr. Benjamin P. Whitaker, a retired economics professor, died Tuesday of a heart attack at Coeur D'Alene, Idaho. He was 74 years old and lived in Schenectady, N.Y.

title: Girl, 6, Drowns in Harlem
description: The body of 6yearold Angeline Trainer of 181 West 151st Street, the Bronx, was pulled from the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, but &forts to revive her failed. According to the police, the child was playing with a friend at 151st Street and the river's edge when she fell into the river.

description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: PleaBargaining Study Is Ordered by Saxbe
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Attorney General William B. Saxbe has ordered a general study of the way pleabargaining is used in the criminal justice system, Justice Department officials said today.Mr. Saxbe decided on the study following the criticism and controversy over the pleabargaining carried out by Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, according to the officials. However, they said, the study will encompass the whole spectrum of the justice system, and it is not clear whether the special prosecution's plea bargains will even be examined.

title: 5 TeenAgers Hunted in Rape of Visiting Nurse
description: The police sought five teenagers on the Lower East Side yesterday for the rape and robbery of a nurse on a sick call in a rundown tenement in the East Village.

title: Nixon Brother Says Watergate Hurts His Health and Finances
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., June 26 (AP)F. Donald Nixon, brother of President Nixon, says that the Watergate affair and harassment by Senate investigators have damaged his health and have left him in financial difficulty.

title: Chess : After 10 Rounds, U.S. Holds A Shaky 4th Place at Nice
description: NICE, June 25  While the Soviet Union continued its powerful progress toward the international team championship, the United States erratically held fourth place.

title: A. M.A. Will Back Peer Review Plan But Seeks Changes
description: CHICAGO, June 26  The American Medical Association voted overwhelmingly today, 185 to 57, to cooperate with the Government in establishing a federally supported system of medical peer review.

description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: Personal Finance
description: When a sophisticated investor buys a bank certificate of deposit, few tears are shed for him if the hank goes under. He is supposed to know what he is doing.

title: Copter Landing on L.I. Becomes Atom Mystery
description: MINEOLA, L. L, June 26 The Army refused today to comment on reports that one of its helicopters that made an emergency landing here yesterday was carrying nuclear warheads.

title: DR. C. GEORGE TEDESCHI
description: Dr. C. George Tedeschi, clinical professor of pathology at the Boston University School of Medicine died yesterday of a heart attack at Framingham Union Hospital, Framingham, Mass. He was 69 years old.

title: Film: Streisand in 'For Pete's Sake':The Cast 'Truck Turner,' a Barrage of Shootouts The Cast
description: Some of the Brooklyn locations in "For Pete's Sake" are recognizably Borough Hall, Fourth Avenue, Grand Army Plaza and Prospect Park, while some are recognizably mock-ups built on a Hollywood backlot. It doesn't make any difference, however."For Pete's Sake," a movie put together to honor its star, Barbra Streisand, is an often boisterously funny old-time farce. Its interest is not the truth that is a reflection of reality but an arm-twisting, gag-stuffed exaggeration of it. Or sometimes the method is diminution. When a bomb explodes to demolish an entire building, it's the equivalent of a hot foot in our dreary world.The movie opened yesterday at the new Astor Plaza, Orpheum and Columbia 2 Theaters.The story is about a young Brooklyn taxi driver named Pete (Michael Sarrazin) and mostly about his wife, Henrietta (Miss Streisand), nick-named Henry, a smart-mouthed, brassy girl whose confidence in herself is always unwarranted. When Pete decides he wants to go back to college to get his degree, Henry borrows $3,000 from a Mafia loan shark to invest in pork-belly futures, thus to finance their future.From the Mafia, Henry's downward path leads her to a more or less enforced membership in a call-girl operation, which proves short-lived when she accidentally breaks the nose of her first client, and finally to fronting for a gang of contemporary cattle rustlers. The latter provides the opportunity for one of the picture's most spectacular gags, the sort that is funny because of its predictability, not in spite of it.Without apology, Stanley Shapiro and Maurice Richlin, who wrote the screenplay, and Peter Yates, who directed it, make use of the most ancient devices of farce: outlandish disguises, sudden reversals in fortune, pratfalls, wisecracks. Some of their material is fondly familiar; some is in raucously bad taste.How long has it been since you've seen a movie in which a man has to hide in a closet when a husband comes home early, or in which there's a lazy, ill-tempered maid? That is, one who is black? "For Pete's Sake" courts disaster, but most of the time manages to sidestep it.Mr. Shapiro and Mr. Richlin, who wrote some very successful nonsex comedies in the late nineteen-fifties and early sixties ("Pillow Talk," "Lover, Come Back"), have the good, glib form of the best of television's situation-comedy writers. The movie may not hold together as any kind of larger comic statement, but the laughs are self-sustaining throughout.The picture is also beautifully cast in its supporting roles, with Heywood Hale Broun as a libidinuos Brooklyn judge, with Estelle Parsons as Henry's hilariously greedy, self-satisfied sister-in-law and, particularly, with Molly Picon as a motherly Brooklyn madam named Mrs. Cherry, who congratulates Henry on coming to realize that sex is, after all, a business not a pleasure.Mr. Sarrazin, like most of Miss Streisand's leading men, isn't called upon to do much more than to be present, which he does well enough. The star herself barges through the movie with a self-assurance that is very funny, because it seems always on the edge of collapse, as when she finds herself pursued by a police dog that is able to read subway signs.Miss Streisand's comedy range is narrow, like a cartoon character's, but "For Pete's Sake" operates almost entirely within that range. She's at her best in this kind of farce. It manages to make her aggressiveness, undisguised in films such as "The Way We Were," seem more like pluck.

title: People in Sports
description: I like the city of New York and I'd like to keep playing there, but I'm going to sit down after the season and look over the whole situation. The speaker was Joe Namath, announcing he would not negotiate a new contract with the New York Jets this year.

title: State Bar to Weigh Lawyers' Silence On Two Murders
description: A committee of the New York State Bar Association will investigate whether two lawyers breached professional ethics when they failed to disclose for more than six months that they had seen the bodies of two women whom their client had admitted killing.

title: U. S. QUESTIONS CAIRO ON 8 KILLERS' HAVEN
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The State Department said today that the United States had questioned Egypt about Cairo's giving haven to eight Palestinian guerrillas who killed two senior American diplomats and a Belgian in the Sudan last year.

title: Under the Summit
description: MOSCOW, June 26The most delicate and profound negotiations over the past six years, passing another milestone here at the third U.S.Soviet summit, have not been the dealings between Mr. Nixon and Mr. Brezhnev. They have been the negotiations between Mr. Nixon and Mr. Kissinger, whose differences in approach have rarely surfaced but which may explain some of what has happened in the past month and much of what will happen next week.

title: WHEAT FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Enthusiastic buyers pushed wheat prices up yesterday early in the session on the Chicago Board of Trade following news that China had purchased an additional 1 million tons of wheat from Canada. This latest order added to a recent previous order brought the total this season to about 112 million bushels.

title: Insiders Stockholdings
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading shareholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: CHARGES DISMISSED ON N.S.M.C. CLAIMS
description: CHICAGO, June 26 (AP)A Federal judge in Washington, D.C., has approved a settlement of three classaction suits against the National Student Marketing Corporation, the company announced.

title: Free Press
description: In its unanimous decision striking down Florida's right to reply law, the Supreme Court gives reassurance that the Constitution means exactly what it says in prohibiting government abridgment of freedom of the press.

title: O'Dwyer Sees a Flaw in City's History
description: If City Council President Paul O'Dwyer has his way, the official founding of New York City will be backdated 39 yearsfrom 1664, when the English took over Nieuw Amsterdam, to 1625, when the early Dutch settlers were arriving in, full force.

title: Carnival Ride Closed
description: BOSTON, June 26 (AP)The Lawrence Carr Amusement Company of Wilmington has been enjoined from operating or admitting passengers to carnival ride that malfunc?? earlier this month, killing one woman and injuring 19 other persons.

title: 1,700 Meet at Parley for Elderly
description: ASBURY PARK, June 26The New Jersey Council on Senior Citizens held its 11th annual meeting in Convention Hall here today and in a crisp, businesslike threehour session demanded increased consideration for the older citizens trapped between rising costs amd fixed retirement incomes.

title: Tenured Teachers Win Reinstatement At a Jersey College
description: NEWARK, June 26A State Superior Court judge today ordered Bloomfield College, a private, coeducational institution in neighboring Bloomfield, to reinstate 13 tenured faculty members it dismissed last June and to disregard an order that had abolished tenure for all other members of the teaching staff.

title: Walter Lengsfelder Dies; Organic Chemist, Painter
description: Walter Lengsfelder, organic chemist and painter, died Tuesday at Palm Desert, Calif. at the age of 69. He lived at 12 Cove Lane in Great Neck, L.I.

title: COURT SETS BACK ANTITRUST THEORY
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 The Supreme Court cleared today the acquisition of the third largest bank in Spokane, Wash., by the second largest bank in the state of Washington, rejecting protests by Government antitrust lawyers that the move would reduce potential competition in the area.

title: What Witnesses May Tell House Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary committee, has said that 14 will set narrow bounds for the interrogation of the witnesses before the inquiry into possible impeachment of President Nixon.

title: City Ballet and Opera Get A $6.3Million Ford Grant
description: The New York City Ballet and the New York City Opera, beset by the high cost of performing and facing the prospect of reducing standards or raising ticket prices, will receive $6.3million in Ford Foundation money, with the proviso that much of it be matched on a $2to$1 basis.

title: MRS. J. T. HARRISON SR.
description: Mrs. Gertrude Leyerich Harrison, widow of John T. Harrison Sr., an insurance broker, died Tuesday in Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived in Greens Farms, Conn., and formerly had lived at 1 East End Avenue here.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The label lists so many chemicals you would think it's a new synthetic breakfast food: ceresin, carnauba, sesame oil, squalane, BHA, BHT, etc. But it's not food, it's just Max Factor. Whipped Creme Mascara ($2 for onequarter of a fluid ounce.)

title: India Cool to Sikkim King's Plea, Tells Him to Take a Lesser Role
description: NEW DELHI, June 26The monarch of the Indian protectorate of Sikkim received no sympathy from the Indian Government today when he presented his objections to a new Constitution reducing him to titular chief of state.

title: Court Rejects All Charges Against Pfizer and Others
description: Pfizer, Inc., said yesterday that a Federal judge in Raleigh, IN C., had thrown out all charges in an antibiotics antitrust, damage suit filed by North Carolina in January, 1969, against Pfizer, the American Cyanamid Company, the Bris ItolMyers Company, the Squibb Corporation and the Upjohn Company.

title: F.B.I. Denies Any Hazard In Potscard Sent to Justices
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI)Postcards with nerve gas allegedly concealed beneath stamps were mailed last week to the nine Supreme Court Justices. But the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today all the postcards had been intercepted and that initial tests had detected no nerve gas.

title: U.S. Team Captures Onion Patch Yachting Series
Cairo Formally Charges 92 As Conspirators in a Plot
description: CAIRO, June 26 (Reuters)Ninetytwo people were formally charged today with joining an armed clandestine organization that allegedly attempted to take over Cairo's technical military academy last April as part of a conspiracy to overthrow President Anwar elSadat.

title: New Archbishop Is Settling In at Newark
description: NEWARKThere is a new tenant at 89 Ridge Street in the North Ward. His possessions are few and his accommodations comfortable, but modest. He is the Most Rev. Peter L. Gerety, 61 years old, the newly designated Roman Catholic Archbishop of Newark and the first ever to live in city.

title: Trial Starts In the Death Of Boy, 1I/2
description: TOMS RIVER, June 26 (UPI) A Lavallette man's teenage wife testified today that her husband kicked and beat her 18monthold son to death because the child would not sleep in a cardboard box.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Mercantile Seat Sale Up
description: CHICAGO, June 26 (AP)A membership on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange changed, hands today for $107,500 up $2,500 from the previous sale on Tuesday. The record price, for a membership is $125,000 set in March, 1973.

title: RODINO'S INQUIRY VOTES TO SUMMON 5 KEY WITNESSES
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 The House Judiciary Committee voted tonight to call five key. figures as witnesses before its inquiry into the possible impeachment of President Nixon as Democratic members won a narrow, partisan victory.

title: Newark Police Unit Is Upheld In Ban on AfroStyle Haircuts.
description: TRENTON, June 26 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld the Newark Police Department in prohibiting Afrostyle haircuts.

title: In U.S., Kissinger Faces Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 President Nixon's trip to Moscow cones at a time when his policy of seeking reduced tensions with the Soviet Union has won wide support but the specific steps to accomplish that goal have run into strong opposition. This seeming paradox has become a source of frustration for Secretary of State Kissinger, who has found the Congress and influential sectors of public opinion pleased with the course of SovietAmerican relations, but reluctant to make the commitments that, in Mr. Kissinger's view, are needed to make such a course more durable.

title: Bridge: Bistate Championship Play Starts in the Catskills Today
description: New York players who hunt for regional titles, or more modestly search for the red points that are needed to achieve lifemaster rank, have a rare opportunity this weekend to visit the Catskills in midsummer.

title: Ziegler Says Nixon's Leg Is Swollen but Not Painful
description: BRUSSELS, June 26President Nixon's left leg continues to be swollen from phlebitis but is no longer painful, Ronaid L. Ziegler, his press secretary, said today as Mr. Nixon walked the streets of Brussels shaking hands and chatting with admirers.

title: REFORMERS LOSE SENATE TAX FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Tax reformers gave up their fight in the Senate today after failing to muster even a majority vote  let alone the necessary twothirds  to end a filibuster by their opponents.

title: U.S. STEEL RAISES ITS PRICES BY 5.5% ON MILL PRODUCTS
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest, steelmaker, announced yesterday that it was raising prices for about half of its total ship ments beginning July 1.

title: ITALIANS RELYING ON U.S. AID IN OIL
description: MILAN, June 26Italy is counting on the United States to help pay her bills to oilexporting nations, Guido Carli, governor of the Italian central bank, said today.

title: Parents and Anker Aides Clash as Files Are Signed
description: Representatives of School Chancellor Irving Anker, aided by the police, pushed their way through protesting parents and pupils yesterday afternoon to enter and take over temporatily a Washington Heights school that has figured in a bitter twoyear jurisdictional dispute between the central Board of Education and a local school board.

title: France Lowers Voting Age
description: PARIS, June 26 (UPI)The National Assembly lowered the voting age from 21 to 18 last night, giving the vote to 2.6 million French youths. The Assembly passed a bill that had already passed the Council of Ministers.

title: 37 Seized in Drug Raids
description: MOUNT HOLLY, June 26 (UPI)Law enforcement officers arrested 37 persons in drug raids in Bordentown, Medford Lakes, Mount Holly, Delran, and Riverside, all in Burlington County, and in Voorhees and Cherry Hill in Camden County.

title: H. J. Heinz Posts Records for Earnings
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Brooklyn Sailing Set
description: The Miramar Yacht Club of Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, will play host to the Laser Class Atlantic Coast sailing championships on Saturday and Sunday. The races will beheld off Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station. Registration is still open. Details may be obtained from Lee Morrison, race chairman, at (212) 3323870.

title: Disputed Wyeth Museum May Move
description: CUSHING, Maine, June 26 (AP)Andrew Wyeth may leave this coastal village, which has been made famous by his paintings and sketches, because of a dispute with townspeople.

title: Later Action Favored
description: Meshulam Riklis, chairman of both the RapidAmerican Corporation and the McCrory Corporation, said yesterday that he would recommend that negotiations for the merger of these companies be halted and reviewed again at the end of the fiscal year on Jan. 31, 1975.

title: BUDGET GOAL TIED TO NEW ESTIMATES
description: WASHINGTON, June 26President Nixon's budget chief disclosed today that more than half of the $5billion budget cutback announced Monday by President Nixon results from new estimates that some programs may not spend as much as had been thought, rather than from conscious Administration deeisions to reduce spending.

title: Retreat on Air Pollution
description: The apparent decision in Washington to ease pressure on New York City to meet Federal clean air standards marks an unwelcome retreat that could adversely affect the health of every New Yorker and the economic vitality of the city itself.

title: RODINO'S INQUIRY VOTES TO SUMMON 5 KEY WITNESSES
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 The House Judiciary Committee voted tonight to call five key figures as witnesses before its inquiry into the possible impeachment of President Nixon as Democratic members won a narrow, partisan victory.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Decoy Man
description: CLAYTON, N.Y.  This small riverfront town in the heart of the Thousand Islands region has many attractions, and among them is Donald R. Wolfe, a fiercely independent carver of splendid decorative and working waterfowl decoys.

title: WALDHEIM MEETING PROTESTED BY ISRAEL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 26  Yosef Tekoah, Is. rael's chief delegate, protested to Secretary General Waldheim today that the United Nations chief had found appropriate to meet with three Palestiniap terrorists during his recent trip to Africa and the Middle East.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PARIS, Ky., June 26 (UPI)Claiborne Farm's manager, William Taylor confirmed today that Secretariat and Riva Ridge had ensured that their $11.08million syndication would not collapse by getting 60 per cent of their mares in foal. We have several more mares to be heard from, but it looks like they will have a high percentage in foal, said Taylor.

title: ALLIED CHIEFS SIGN NATO DECLARATION
description: BRUSSELS, June 26  The leaders of the 15nation North Atlantic alliance today signed a new declaration intended to insure close consultations and end months of bickering among them.

title: Notes on People
description: William L. Calley Jr., the only soldier to be convicted for the My Lai massacre, entered a military prison yesterday for the first time. It did not appear that he would be there long.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Opposing Detente Views

title: Catholic Study Sees Influence on Church Of Secular Society
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI)Tolerance for such secular ideas as abortion and other methods of birth control that are disapproved of has taken the place of church teaching for a significantly large number of American Roman Catholics, according to a new study by the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.

title: In Iowa, Farm Costs Are Upbut So Are the Profits
description: JEFFERSON, IowaClarence Springer and his wife, Ruby, paid from 10 to 15 per cent more last week for everything they bought for themselves or for their seed and farm chemical business.

title: Man Slain in Harlem Club
description: A man identified only as Neno was fatally shot early yesterday in an East Harlem social club at 327 East 108th Street. The alleged assailant, Jose Roldan, who gave the club as his address, was charged with homicide.

title: Samaritan Wounded Thwarting Robbery Of a Bronx Man, 65
description: A bystander, undeterred by a robber's gun during a sidewalk daylight holdup in the Bronx, was credited yesterday by the police with helping to catch two suspects despite being, struck twice by bullets in his left leg.

title: Lob Cohen's Mexican Standoff
description: Phil Bieber, who occasionally favors this column with a letter, is a learned student of the running horse with a formidable memory and a minnesinger's gift for story telling. His tales about the race track have illumined this space several times in the past. Today he offers a touch of American history with a splash of local color, dips into etymology and throws light on the origin of an expression still commonly used in sports by persons who haven't the faintest notion of its source. Here Mr. Bieber takes over, with just a few interjections and amplifications.

title: COAST SCHOOL CASE ORDERED REOPENED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has ruled here that a Federal district judge used an erroneous legal standard when he ordered desegregation of San Francisco's elementary schools by citywide busing in 1971.

title: Byrne Designates Olaff As Chief of State Police
description: TRENTON, June 26 (AP) Maj. Eugene E. Olaff, deputy chief of the state police, will become Acting Superintendent, succeeding Col. David B. Kelly, who is retiring this week after nine years as the top state policeman.

title: Equality for St. John's: Women's Athletic Chief
description: Vicki Kresse has seen more school, college and pro basketball games in the last two years than ever before. That was part of her courtship with and marriage to John Kresse, the assistant basketball coach at St. John's and formerly with the Nets of the American Basketball Association.

title: ANGRY FARMERS a PARADE IN ROME
description: ROME, June 26Thousands of discontented peasants from all over the country held rally here today to protest Government plans for dealing with Italy's grave financial troubles.

title: Ear Invasion Spurs Gentle Folk To Riverside Drive Barricades
description: It has been a rather genteel but effective rumble up in the Riverside Park area where a tiny group of middleclass residents organized to take on a slothful city bureaucracy in defense of a solid, pleasant, oldfashioned community.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SUMMER BIDS FAIR Among the more overlooked and underrated summer tourist attractions available to both New Yorkers and outoftowners are the auctions that will be continuing through the season at Sotheby Parke Bernet and its offMadison Avenue summer quarters at PB 84, on 84th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues.

title: People and Business
description: Stephen S. Gardner, chairman of Philadelphia's Girard Bank and once called by a competitor Mr. AllAmerica Nice Guy, is slated to be nominated soon to the No. 2 post at the Treasury Department.

title: A Science Council Is Urged As Agency in White House
description: The National Academy of Sciences urged President Nixon and Congress yesterday to reestablish in the White House a panel to advise the President and such agencies as the National Security Council on matters involving science and technology.

title: British Airport Is Guarded Against Arab Terrorists After a Warning
description: LONDON, June 26British troops and policemen began a major security operation at Heathrow Airport today in response to a warning that Arab terrorists might attempt an attack there this weekend.

title: St. Regis Plans to Spend $85Million on Maine Mill
description: The St. Regis Paper Company announced yesterday that it planned an $85million expansion of a mill at Bucksport, Me., operated by its printing and packaging papers division.

title: Sugar Lifts Cola Prices
description: The soaring cost of sugar has been a major factor in recent large increases in the prices of cola drinks and other beverages but the prices of sugarless diet drinks made by the same companies have been increased exactly as much as the sugared drinks each time there has been a rise.

title: NEW COURSE DUE ON COPPER PRICES
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, June 26The world's four major capper exporting nations ended a conference in Lusaka today with a veiled threat that from now on they would take a major role in controlling copper prices on the world market. An announcement issued by the Intergovernmental Council of Copper Exporting Nations, after the end of the threeday meeting said that the member countries have decided to completely coordinate the policy to be followed in the world copper market

title: Football Stars in Streamlined Stage
description: OAKDALE, L. I., June 26Considering that only five months ago they had no players and were operating in a oneroom office with a single telephone, the New York Stars of the World Football League have come a long way.

title: Heavy Casualties Reported In New Philippine Fighting
description: ZAMBOANGA, The Philippines, June 26 (AP)  Fighting between Government troops and Moslem rebels erupted today in two coastal towns in the province of Zamboanga del Sur, and travelers reported scores killed on both sides.

title: Movement Gains in Portugal To Repeal Law Banning Divorce
description: LISBON, June 26A strong movement challenging the Roman Catholic Church's ban on divorce has emerged in Portugal as a result of the revolution in April.

title: Ronson Meeting Adjourned
description: The reconvened annual meeting of the Ronson Corporation will be adjourned from 2:30 P.M. today to 10:30 A.M. on July 10. The meeting, originally held June 13, was adjourned to permit a count of pro??ies in a bid by Liquifin, A.G, of Lichtenstein to take over Ronson.

title: Moscow Is Gratified by Gain in Trade
description: MOSCOW, June 26  When American astronauts arrived here last Sunday for joint training with Soviet astronauts, one of the Russians commented that the program for their joint space flight was going well technically but we are still ill at ease with each other. In a capsule, this remark summarizes the Soviet view of accommodation with Washington the day before President Nixon arrives here and two years after he came for his first summit visit in May, 1972.

title: Tests Set in Hearst Extortion
description: LOS ANGELES, June 26 (UPI) Ralph Lee Jones, a 42yearold Van Nuys trucker, was sent to Federal prison for a psychiatric study yesterday after pleading guilty to attempting to extort $100,000 from William Randolph Hearst by claiming to have information about Mr. Hearst's kidnapped daughter, Patricia. After the threemonth study, he will return to Federal District Court for final sentencing.

title: CHILEAN ASSUMES FULL LEADERSHIP
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 26The leader of the fourman junta that took power last September became chief of state of Chile today. The three other members were relegated to what was described as an advisory and legislative role.

title: SOVIET RELEASES LEADING DISSIDENT
description: MOSCOW, June 26Pyotr G. Grigorenko, the former army general who became one of the Soviet Union's outspoken campaigners for wider civil rights, was released today after five years of confinement in Soviet mental hospitals.

title: CHINA PURCHASES CANADIAN WHEAT
description: MONTREAL, June 26Canada announced today the sale of 74.6 million bushels of wheat to China, one of the largest single contracts she has ever made.

title: Bankrupoty Payment Plan By Ancorp National Is Set
description: Ancorp National Services, Inc., operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, announced yesterday that its board and a committee of creditors had agreed on a plan of repayment of about $40million of debt.

title: IMPEACHMENT CASE ON TV IS SUPPORTED
description: The latest nationwide Gallup Poll showed that 53 per cent of the public favored televising House impeachment proceedings if they are undertaken, while 40 per cent were opposed.

title: Israel to Sell City $30Million Notes
description: The city will invest $30million from its pension funds into an unusual $300million security offering by Israel that is guaranteed by the United States Government, Controller Harrison J. Goldin announced yesterday.

title: COURT'S RULING HELD NO BAR TO RAIL PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (Reuters)The United States Railway Association, the agency created to reorganize the bankrupt Eastern railroads, will continue its plans despite an adverse court ruling, the agency said today.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN NURSES' STRIKE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 A tentative settlement in the threeweek strike of 4,400 nurses at 43 northern California hospitals was announced today by W. J. Usery Jr., head of the Federal Mediation Service.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The chairman of the arbitration panel in the dispute between the 42 voluntary hospitals in the city and District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employes said yesterday that the panel would draft a settlement plan before the current contract expired at midnight Sunday even though it faced an apparently insoluble situation.

title: Cosmos 662 Lanuched
description: MOSCOW, June 26 (UPI)The Soviet Union launched a Cosmos satellite today, one day after launching an unmanned Salyut space laboratory, the Tass press agency said. It did, not indicate whether the two missions were connected. The Cosinos shot was the 662d in the unmanned series. Tass said the craft is orbiting the earth, every 95 minutes and that its instruments are operating without hitch.

title: Petersen Says Prosecutors Failed to Check Some Evidence in Plumbers Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Henry E. Petersen, who supervised the early days of the Watergate investigation, acknowledged today that the prosecutors had failed to check out a lead in the case provided by the Central Intelligence Agency that might have led the investigators to an early break in the plumbers case.

title: INTERIM BOARD ENDS A CITY SCHOOL ERA
description: After five tumultuous years that ushered in the decentralization of the public school system, the city's interim Board of Education held its final monthly public meeting last night in an atmosphere of rare tranquality.

title: 25 in Yonkers Accused Of Welfare Fraud Scheme.
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 26A Yonkers cab company and 25 employes have been indicted in an alleged scheme to defraud the county and state of $50,000 in welfare and unemploymnt insurance payments, the Westchester County District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, said today.

title: Soviet Looks to 10Year Trade Agreement With U.S.
description: MOSCOW, June 26The Soviet Union today stressed the need for broader longterm trade cooperation and connections with the United States.

title: European Leaders Turn NATO Talk Into Summit Meeting of Their Own
description: BRUSSELS, June 26Many of Europe's new leaders used the Atlantic alliance meeting here today as a makeshift summit of their own.

title: Success Has Apricot Hue For Couple
description: An apricot, according to Webster, is an orangecolored fruit. But to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Felden it's a miniature poodle. To fanciers, the apricot is the most difficult color to attain in a breeding program. The Feldens, dens, from Barrington, Ill., have been among the most successful of the apricot miniature poodle set.

title: U.S., Unions and Industry Fault City's Plan on Hiring Minorities
description: Representatives of the building trades unions and employers as well as the Department of Labor said yesterday that the city had put into effect an unsatisfactory plan for hiring minority workers in the construction industry despite what the representatives said was a pledge by city officials to give them more time to develop a more comprehensive program.

title: SCHLESINGER SAYS SYRIANS HAVE MIG23
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UN) Secretary of Defense James R, Schlesinger said today that the Soviet Union had supplied Syria with advanced MIG23 fighter planes, which the Russians had not even given to their European allies.

title: DEMOCRATS SET ANNUAL TELETHON
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Putting the finishing touches on their third annual fundraising telethon, prominent national Democrats are convinced that they have built themselves a modest but dependable money tree.

title: Riverside Bridge Stripped of Bronze, Part of a Wave of Thefts
description: Seven sections of ornamental bronze railing have been ripped from the Riverside Drive bridge at 96th Street.

title: Error in 12th Sets Up Series Sweep for Berra, 54
description: CHICAGO, June 26Manager Yogi Berra turned his walking wounded into runners today, and they turned out to be the tying and winning runs as the New York Mets defeated the Chicago Cubs, 54, in 12 innings.

title: 7 Close to Nixon Listed To Testily on Plumbers
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Henry A. Kissinger, Gen. Alex ander M. Haig Jr. and five other present and former high ranking Nixon Administration officials were listed as tentative witnesses today as the White House plumbers trial opened here in Federal Court.

title: HENRY DATER, 65, NAVAL HISTORIAN
description: Dr. Henry M. Dater, historian land principal chronicler of United States Antarctic operations since their beginning in 1947, died yesterday of cancer in Washington. He was 65 years old.

title: City Ballet and Opera Get A $6.3Million Ford Grant
description: The New York City Ballet and the New York City Opera, beset by the high cost of performing and facing the prospect of reducing standards or raising ticket prices, will receive $6.3million in Ford Foundation money, with the proviso that much of it he matched on a $2to$1 basis.

title: In U.S., Kissinger Faces Challenge.
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 President Nixon's trip to Moscow comes at a time when his policy of seeking reduced tensions with the Soviet Union has won wide support but the specific steps to accomas plish that goal have lsis run into strong opposition. This seeming paradox has become a source of frustration for Secretary of State Kissinger, who has found the Congress and influential sectors of public opinion pleased with the course of SovietAmerican relations, but reluctant to make the commitments that, in Mr. Kissinger's view, are needed to make such a durable.

title: Nixon Will Name Eight To U.S. Science Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)  President Nixon will nominate six new members to the National Science Board of the National Science Foundation and will reappoint two others, a White House announcement said today.

title: The British Miracle
description: LONDON, June 26Over the postwar years we have had the German Miracle, the Italian, the Japanesethe spurts of economic growth that made those countries newly rich. The British read about all that and longed for an economic miracle of their own, something to end the long slow slide down the international prosperity tables.

title: Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The Supreme Court took the following actions today: ANTITRUST Affirmed a decision permitting the second largest bank in the State of Washington to acquire the third largest bank in Spokane, over objections by the Department of Justice that the move would lessen competition. (No. 7338, United States v. Marine Bancorporation.) Dissenting: White, Brennan, and Marshall.

title: Aides to Humphrey, Mills Said to Balk at Testifying
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The campaign managers for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Representative Wilbur S. Mills have invoked the Fifth Amendment and todeclined testify about the receipt of thousands of dollars in corporate contributions in the 1972 primary campaign, according to the staff of the Senate Watergate committee.

title: NORTON TO ISSUE HISTORY OF STATES
description: WASHINGTON, June 26W. W. Norton & Co., Inc., has been chosen by the American Association for State and Local History to publish its 51volume bicentennial history series entitled The States and the Nation.

title: 7 Top State U. Aides Pass 5Year Reviews
description: As a result of a recently adopted process of assessing the performances of top administrators of the State University of New York with a view to increasing their accountability, the trustees of the university yesterday reappointed Chancellor Ernest L. Boyer and six university presidents to new fiveyear terms.

title: Disaster Relief Approved
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) A bill authorizing $150million in disaster relief for subSaharan Africa, Pakistan and Nicaragua was approved by the House of Representatives today and sent to the Senate.

title: City to Purchase $30Million in U.S.Backed Israeli Notes
description: The city will invest $30million from its pension funds into an unusual $300million security offering by Israel that is guaranteed by the United States Government, Controller Harrison J. Goldin announced yesterday.

title: A.E.C. PACT SIGNED BY ISRAEL AND EGYPT
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) Provisional contracts with Egypt and Israeli to enrich uranium for use as fuel in nuclear power plants were signed today by the Atomic Energy Commission.

title: Torpor in Surrealist Colonial Setting: Portuguese Guinea's Former Capital
description: BOLAMA, Guinea, June 24 A statue of President Ulysses S. Grant looks over the large, treestudded central square of Bolama and over the goat and the smiling boy who are the only living creatures in sight.

title: Supreme Court Delays Ruling on Critical Detroit School Integration Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 26School officials, civil rights advocates and several million Michigan residents were left uninformed on a critical national issue today when the Supreme Court failed to hand down a decision in the Detroit school integration case.

title: Spy's Skeleton Found in British Home
description: LONDON, June 26, (Reuters)The British police today were confronted with a crime detection classicthe mystery of a locked room Containing the body of an intelligence chief who disappeared almost three years ago.

title: Mayors From the 3State Metropolitan Area Find San Diego Conference Is a 3Ply Event
description: SAN DIEGO, June 26Kenneth A. Gibson had a lateafternoon lunch of three tiny packs of raisins and the opportunity to, be the first black president of the National Mayors Organization.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne signed into law a bill requiring that all public schools provide lunches for students. The bill, which goes into effect in a year, was sponsored by Assemblyman James W. Bornheimer, Democrat of Middlesex, who said the measure was paramount because children can study better if they have full stomachs.

title: Luxurious Dining on ParistoLyons Express
description: PARISUntil we took the train from Paris to Lyons a few months ago, we had forgotten that dining on a train can be pleasure enough to be an end in itself. Our greatest frames of reference had previously been a cafeteriatype disaster on an Amtrak train between Boston and New York; a ham and cheese special between New York and Philadelphia, and a bag of peanuts en route from Jamaica to East Hampton.

title: Market Place: Realty Trusts More Squeezed
description: There was further evidence yesterday that the real estate investment trust industry is being squeezed by the current recordhigh interest rates that have taken major bank prime lending rates to 11 per cent.

title: ROBERT I. LUDGATE
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 26Robert I. Ludgate, a partner in the stock brokerage firm of Maples & Goldschmidt, an associate on the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at Brushy Hill Road, Darien.

title: A Book You Can Put Down
description: THE NOTHING BOOK. 192 pages. Harmony Books. $3.

title: U.S. AID AGAIN ASKED BY T.W.A. AND PAN AM
description: The nation's two leading international airlines renewed yesterday their appeals for Government funds to offset huge increases in fuel prices, warning that alternative measures under study by the Administration would not go far enough or come soon enough.

title: Expos Win as Hunt's Bat Is Hit by Pitch
A British Airline Alleges U.S. Balks Shuttle Plan
description: LONDON, June 26  Laker Airways, a small privately owned British airline, charged today that the United States Government was illegally blocking its plan to provide lowcost transAtlantic jet service in an effort to protect American carriers from competition

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: Ouster Upset for 13 Tenured in Jersey
description: NEWARK, June 26A State Superior Court Judge today ordered Bloomfield College, a private, coeducational institution in neighboring Bloomfield, to reinstate 13 tenured faculty members it dismissed last June and to disregard an order that had abolished tenure for all other members of the teaching staff.

title: COURT DISCIPLINES EXETHICS COUNSEL
description: The former counsel of a committee that investigated unethical conduct among lawyers has been suspended from practicing law for three years because he engaged in professional misconduct.

title: Reserve Mining Granted Delay in Filing of Proposal
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 26 (AP) United States District Judge Miles Lord ordered a threeday extension yesterday of a filing deadline for the Reserve Mining Company to submit a plan for onland disposal of taconite tailings. The deadline was extended from Saturday until next Tuesday.

title: Texas Acquisition Set
description: The Norwegian Oil Corpora tion, Ltd., a Norwegian owned and manned exploration concern, acquired Oil and Gas Futures, Inc., of Texas yesterday for $16million in cash. Oil and Gas Futures is an exploration company with concessions in Louisiana, Texas and Oklahoma and oil production of about 7,000 barreis a day.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PARAMUS, June 26John Minda explained the maneuver to the women on the ice. When he had finished, Sue McNamee skated, got the puck on her stick, went down the ice and put her shot into the net. Her husband, Mike, cheered in the stands as she raised her arms.

title: Head of Matteawan Quits; Faced Charges on Death
description: The superintendent of Matteawan State Hospital in Beacon, N. Y., has resigned after being threatened with charges by the State Correctional Services Department in connection with the death of a woman patient, a spokesman for the department said last night.

title: Envoys Accused on Parking
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26 (AP)  The United States representative to the United Nations, John A. Scali, says there is continuing widespread violation of parking and traffic regulations by diplomats in New York. He made the comment in a letter to. Secretary General Waldheim, who had transmitted to him a protest from the Moroccan representative against the police for towing away his official car.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Ballet: Feld's Reopening
description: The Eliot Feld Ballet reopened at the Newman Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater on Tuesday night for an extra twoweek season. Only a month after its debut, the young company shows signs of settling down.

title: Screen: A Fatal Flavor
description: "Three the Hard Way," which opened yesterday at the DeMille and Loews Cine Theaters, is a hideously inane black exploitation movie that glories in reverse racism. It's about a plan to kill off all of America's blacks by tainting the water supply with a liquid that looks very much like strawberry syrup."It works like sickle-cell anemia," says the mad doctor, "only quicker." "Good," says his rich white employer. "It took God seven days to create the world. We'll cleanse it in three."Jim Brown, Fred Williamson and Fred Kelly, three of the more popular black actors of the day, play the amateur agents who thwart the plans. They all swagger too much and don't know what to do with their hands when they aren't massacring the enemy. Sometimes they play chess.The most startling thing about the film is that it was directed by Gordon Parks Jr., who seemed to know what he was doing when he made "Super Fly" and "Thomasine and Bushrod." "Three the Hard Way" is badly written, staged and edited. It is also terribly acted by the stars as well as by Jay Robinson, who plays the rich white fanatic with all the force of a man who should wear paperweights in his shoes.

title: LIVESTOCK AID BILL MODIFIED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) A House Agriculture subcommittee scaled down today a proposed emergency creditguarantee bill for distressed livestock producers and voted to open the program to nonfarmers.

title: Rise in Prime Weakens Market
description: The stock market was flit by prime rate increases by at least a dozen banks yesterday and the gains of Tuesday's technical rally were just about erased.

title: End to U.S. Role Is Voted In Closing Home Sale Costs
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The House Banking Committee has voted to repeal the Federal Government's authority to regulate closing and settlement costs in home sales.

title: Evert Bid Halted by Tie, Dusk
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 26  John Newcombe, Ilie Nastase and Stan Smith, the three men most people think can win the Wimbledon tennis title, advanced in straight sets almost unnoticed in a raindelayed program today.

title: Charles Micaud of U. of Denver, Writer on French Politics, Dies
description: Prof. Charles A. Micaud of the University of Denver, Graduate School of International Studies died Sunday of cancer in Denver. He was 64 years old.

title: Maheu Trial Judge Rejects Def erase Bid On Jury Instruction
description: LOS ANGELES, June 26A Federal judge rejected today a demand by lawyers for Howard R. Hughes that he amend his instructions to a jury that is deliberating Robert A. Maheu's $17.3million defamation claim against the Summa Corporation, the holding company that controls the Hughes financial interests.

title: ROWLES PLAYS JAZZ WITH GENTLE TOUCH
description: Jimmy Rowles plays the piano with such a light, gentle totich that it is always surprising to find how lean and resilient his jazz performances really are. At Bradley's, on University Place near 11th Street, where he started a threeweek run on Monday, Mr. Rowles, backed by Bill Takas on bass, is mixing his bag of esoteric tunes  such as Restless, which was last heard of when Hal Kemp was playing it in the thirties  and standards as varied as Liza, Limehouse Blues and It Might as Well Be Spring with a sense of constant exploration.

title: South Africa Denies Trip To Nonwhite Cricket Aide
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 26 (Reuters)The South African Government announced today that it had turned down a request from Hassan Howa, chairman of the Black Cricket Board of Control, for a passport to attend a meeting of the International Cricket Association in London.

title: BYRNE REITERATES VIEW ON TURNPIKE
description: TRENTON, June 26Governor Byrne reiterated his opposi, tion to the construction of a 38mile spur of the New Jersey Turnpike today, saying he would block any further efforts by the Turnpike Authority to acquire land for the project:

title: Gypsy Cab Driver Shot
description: Lloyd Saunders, 67 years old, the driver of a gypsy cab, of 324 Powers. Avenue in the South Bronx, was shot in the head and right shoulder by five males who robbed him early yesterday at 127th Street and Third Avenue, the police of the East 118th Street station reported. The wounded driver, taken to the Hospital for Joint Diseases, was reported in serious condition.

title: Tax Shelter That Attracted Notables Studied by S.E.C.
description: An oildrilling tax shelter that attracted a glittering array of movie and television stars, bigbusiness men and other wellknown personalities is under criminal investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, S.E.C. sources disclosed yesterday.

title: The Evolution of a Liberated Lilly
description: An 18yearold girl from Queens who works in a supermarket chain was molested one recent Monday in Madison Square Park at lunchtime and everyone just stood around and laughed.

title: West Germany Beats Yugoslavia, 20; Brazil, Poland, Netherlands Also Win
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, June 26All is well again today in West Germany. After losing to East Germany in Hamburg last Saturday, the West. German soccer team convinced its, countrymen this afternoon that it has the potential to take the World Cup, turning back Yugoslavia, 20.

title: E.P.A. ENDS DRIVE TO BAN DEFOLIANT
description: After more than three years of research to determine the hazard to Americans of domestic use of a highly toxic defoliant used in the Vietnam war, the Environmental Protection Agency has withdrawn its legal motions seeking a ban on the substance, known as 2, 4, 5T.

title: GIBSON CHAIRMAN OF MAYORS' BOARD
description: SAN DIEGO, June 26Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark was elected chairman today of the advisory board of the United States Conference Mayors.

title: Regents Appear Ready to Ease Stand on Busing
description: ALBANY, June 26  The State Board of Regents devoted a full day of its monthly meeting here today to a review of its position on school integration, amid signs that a growing number of the governing panel would favor softening the board's longstanding commitment to integration.

title: LEBANON WEIGHS ARAB MILITARY AID
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 26In an atmosphere of public tension, the Cabinet met today to consider what help it might ask from other Arab nations to defend Lebanon against possible new Israeli attacks on Palestinian centers within her borders.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Aides to Humphrey, Mills Said to Balk at Testifying
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The campaign managers for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Representative Wilbur D. Mills have invoked the Fifth Amendment and declined to testify about the receipt of thousands of dollars in corporate contributions in the 1972 primary campaign, according to the staff of the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Atmosphere Test Series May Be Postponed Again
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va. June 26 (AP)  Partly clearing weather turned into a heavy overcast here today, and the space agency's plans for a launching tomorrow of 54 test rockets to study the upper atmosphere again became a touchandgo affair.

title: Abrams Says His Religion Cost Him Party's Backing
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx charged yesterday that the Democratic State Committee had denied him its designation for Attorney General primarily because he is Jewish.

title: Hearing Ordered on Kramer Campaign
description: TRENTON, June 26The New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission today ordered a public hearing on charges that the campaign of Mayorelect Lawrence F. Kramer of Paterson had illegally diverted about $9,000 in contributions to two City Council candidates, in an effort to avoid exceeding the state ceiling on campaign expenses.

title: Timeless Moment $16 Victor in Sprint
Shah Suggests to French Iran  to  Europe Gas Line
description: PARIS, June 26 (Reuters)The Shah of Iran suggested today that a gas pipeline be built from Iran to Europe.

title: Citicorp Plan Faulted
description: Savings banks, which have been hit by deposit outflows moving toward higher interest rates than they are permitted to pay, are seeking to block Citicorp from selling $250million or more of floatingrate notes. Details on Page 71.

title: Inequity in Youth Sentences Upset by U.S. Judges Here
description: Defendants under the age of 21 cannot be given longer prison terms than adults convicted of the same offenses, and youths serving such sentences must be released, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Sohio Pipe Obtains Credit
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said yesterday that the Sohio Pipe Line Company, a wholly owned subsidiary, had obtained a $600million revolving credit from a group of 18 banks led by the Chase Manhattan Bank. The funds will bel used to finance part of Sohio's share of construction costs of the Trans Alaska Pipeline sys tom. Sohio Pipe also has a $300million standby credit with a group of banks also led by Chase.

title: U.S. STEEL RAISES ITS PRICES BY 5.5% ON MILL PRODUCTS
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, announced yesterday that it was raising prices for about a half of its total shipments beginning July 1.

title: Music: Jazz and Baroque
description: Lincoln Center inaugurated a series of five free lunchhour outdoor concerts yesterday with a casually delightful combination of baroque and jazz.

title: Congress Urged to Amend Laws to Spur Use of Coal
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The White House issued statement today urging Congress to adopt amendments to the Clean Air Act that have been proposed by the Administration.

title: COURT SETS BACK ANTITRUST THEORY
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The Supreme Court cleared today the acquisition of the third largest bank in Spokane, Wash., by the second largeft bank in the state of Washington, rejecting protests by Government antitrust lawyers that the move would reduce potential competition in the area.

title: Hopes for Pinochet
description: The emergence of Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte Chief of State could mean a gradual easing of the repression in which Chile has been held since the overthrow of President Salvador Allende's Marxist Government last September. This is the hope of many Chileans who have been trying to persuade the governing junta to end the terror and launch the task of national reconciliation.

title: A.M.A. Will Back Peer Review Plan, But Seeks Changes
description: CHICAGO, June 26  The American Medical Association voted overwhelmingly today, 185 to 57, to cooperate with the Government in establishing a federally supported system of medical peer review.

title: St. Clair Sees a Rebuttal By Dean on Hush Money
description: WASHINGTON, June 26John W.
