description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 28 Not since 1968, when Billy Ha jghton drove Carlisle, the 7to5 choice, to a 1length triiimph; has there been so wideopen an American Trotting Championship as the 29th annual fixture at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP IN DULL TRADING
description: The downward slide of prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market continued yesterday, for the third day in slightly stepped up but dull trading.

title: Few Oil Woes at Northern States
description: MINNEAPOLISAlthough the Northern States Power Company, the big electric power producer in the Upper Midwest, has not been wholly spared the problems buffeting the rest of the utility industry, its senior executives concede that it is decidedly better off than the ildependent coastal, utilities.

title: Loans Written Off U.S. Issues Sold
description: The new chairman of the Franklin National Bank said yesterday that the financially troubled bank was writing off an additional $11.8million in loans as losses, and had sold large volume of Government securities at an additional loss of $2.2million.

title: Asarco to Open Silver Mine
description: WALLACE, Idaho, June 28 (AP)The American Smelting and Refining Company has announced it would spend $10million to open the first major new silver mine in north Idaho in 10 years. Fred Owsley of Wallace, manager for Marco's Northwest mining department, said yesterday that, estimated annual production from the mine near here would be 2.2 million ounces of silver.

title: Lassa Victim Recovers
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, June 28 (Agence FrancePresse)  A West German doctor who was sent home to Hamburg in March with a littleknown and often fatal African disease has recovered and returned to work in Nigeria, it was announced today. Dr. Bernhard Mandrella, who works at a hospital in Onitsha Province has contracted Lassa fever.

title: Inquiry Finds Test Scores Were Withheld at P.S. 81
description: Investigators from Chancellor Irving Anker's office have confirmed that an assistant principal at a Brooklyn elementary school told teachers not to turn in the reading test scores ofsome lowscoring pupils in a possible effort to make the school's test results look better.

title: Policy At Home And Abroad
description: WASHINGTON  Although Leonid Brezhney has made it amply clear he is not concerned with American politics, the dismal Watergate scandal, or current attempts to cut down Henry Kissinger, there is little doubt that the impact of these affairs is bound to diminish results of the present Moscow summit talks.

title: Lansky's Conviction On Contempt Upset By Appellate Court
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 28 (AP)  The contempt conviction of Meyer Lansky, alleged financial wizard of organized crime, was reversed by a Federal appeals court today.

title: The Stage
description: Dame Agatha Christie's Murder at the Vicarage makes entertainingly tidy, tense watching these Thursdays through Saturdays at Lolly's Theater Club, 808 Lexington Avenue at 62d Street. (8327407.

title: Blue Cross Pact Extended
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (AP)A 30day extension of the contract between Blue Cross and 53 nonprofit hospitals in the Philadelphia area has been announced by Blue Cross and the Delaware Valley Hospital Council.

title: Highlights of the Accords On Housing, Fuel, Health
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Following are highlights the three agreements signed in Moscow today.

title: Palestinian Slain As Factions Clash In Lebanon Camp
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 28Rival Palestinian groups clashed at two refugee camps here and one guerrilla was killed.

title: Dtente Marches On
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Following is the leaked record of the first conversation between President Nixon and Leonid Brezhnev in Moscow yesterday.

title: Gruening Service Monday
description: WASHINGTON, June 28A memorial service will be held here for former Senator Ernest Gruening of Alaska on Monday at 11 A.M. in the nave of the National Cathedral. Senator Gruening, one of the earliest and most outspoken critics of the Vietnam war and Governor of Alaska from 1939 to 1953, died here two days ago of cancer. He was 87 years old.

title: Kalmbach to Begin Term
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) A convicted Watergate defendant, Herbert W. Kalmbach, will surrender to the Federal authorities in Baltimore by noon Monday to begin serving a sixto18month sentence for campaign finance violations, the Justice Department said today. The department said the arrangement for the President's former lawyer to surrender was made at the request of the House Judiciary Committee, which expects to summon him to testify in impeachment proceedings.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Bus Talks to Continue in Face of Strike

title: Whitney Museum Taking Stock
description: There is something awesome about the fundamental duty of the Whitney Museum of American Art. Its mandate is, after all, to explain America to the Americans. American art has always done this, but exactly how it was done, and who did it best and how well the explanations are standing up to the test of timeall these are difficult questions. I do not envy the institution that has to tackle them and will be judged by the success or failure of its endeavors.

title: Telethon Ban at 2 Stations Is Upheld
description: The decision of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company not to carry the Democratic National Telethon this weekend was defended yesterday by Donald H. McGannon, president of the broadcasting company.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
SUSAN B. WHITNEY
description: Susan Brewster Whitney, an artist and a great  granddaughter of Eli Whitney, inventor of the cotton gin, died Wednesday at her home, 560 Park Avenue. She was 89 years fold.

title: International Commission Decides to Limit Whaling
description: LONDON, June 28 (Reuters) The International Whaling Commission concluded its 26th annual convention today, having taken at least one small step toward saving the world's largest creature from extinction.

title: House Rejects Plan to Prohibit Federal Funds in Abortion Work
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The House has turned back an attempt to prohibit use of any Federal funds directly or indirectly for abortions or abortion research.

title: Amtrak Extension Backed
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The Department of Transportation has extended Amtrak's rail passenger route system by authorizing the corporation to operate between Boston and Chicago and between Cincinnati and Norfolk, Va.

title: Housewife Wins at Net
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., June 28 (AP)Mrs. Ginny Mahoney, a 29yearold housewife from Barrington, R.I., won the New England women's tennis championship today by defeating topseeded Ann Murphy of East Hartford, Conn., 61, 76, at Longwood.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Friends and Relatives Gather To Spruce Up Old Fire Engines
description: VALHALLA, N. Y.Everyune knows why firemen wear red suspenders, but why in blazes are they covering their fire engines with Saran Wrap?

title: 42 Tenants Rehabilitating A Hotel in Times Square
description: The tenants of a Times Square hotel that was scheduled to be shut down last March have begun to transform it into a decent place to live, three city officials said yesterday.

title: Blue Cross Pact Extended
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (AP)A 30day extension of the contract between Blue Cross and 53 nonprofit hospitals in the Philadelphia area has been announced by Blue Cross and the Delaware Valley Hospital Council.

title: Failure of Herstatt Disturbs Banking
description: MILAN, Italy, June 28The failure of West Germany's biggest private bank, Bankhaus I. D. Herstatt of Cologne, has dealt another blow at confidence in the monetary world and has caused a general retrenchment in the foreignexchange dealings of international banks.

title: Guerrillas Freed by Sudan Reported Jailed in Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The State Department said today that it had been informed that the eight Palestinian guerrillas who were convicted of killing two senior American diplomats and a Belgian in Khartoum last year were now in prison in Egypt.

title: 4 Indicted in MailOrder Fraud Involving a Total of $1.6Million
description: NEWARK, June 28  Sep mate indictments against two fatherandson teams accused. of mailorder fraud totaling nearly $1.6million were returned by a Federal grand jury today.

title: GRANT HYDE CODE, 78, ACTOR AND TEACHER
description: Grant Hyde Code, actor, teacher, dancer and publicrelations man, died yesterday in his apartment at the St. Frandis Hotel. He was 78 years old.

title: Kremlin Briefly Holds A White House Aide
description: MOSCOW, June 28 (AP)Soviet security men hustled a White House press aide out of a room in the Kremlin where Mrs. Richard M. Nixon was having tea today with the wives of high Soviet officials.

title: Chase Manhattan To Bay an Interest In London Concern
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that would acquire a 50 per cent interest in a new company to take over the consumer finance activities of the First National Finance Corporation of London. The company, which will be owned jointly by Chase and First National Finance, will have a net worth of $48million, of which $20.4million will be contributed by First National and $27.6million by Chase. Both companies will be equally represented on the board and its chairman will be Pat Matthews, deputy chairman Finance.

title: Wages Spurt, Strikes Rise; Major Settlements Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 With labor demanding big wage increases to catch up to the cost of living, the two months since Federal wageprice controls expired have brought a round of collectivebargaining settlements of 8 to 10 per cent a yearand moreand a big increase in strikes.

title: Rabin Drops Out of Appeals Court Race
description: Samuel Rabin, an associate judge of the State Court of Appeals and the Republican designee for election to that post in November, withdrew from the race yesterday.

title: 2 Democrats See Gains Obscured by Scandal
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP)Two prominent Congressional Democrats said today that public and press preoccupation with Watergate was obscuring significant achievements by Congress.

title: More Paper, Less Work?
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) The Justice Department has sent a memo to all its divisions seeking nominations for awards given each year by the Government to employes, who contribute the most to reducing paper work. Six (6) copies of any nomination, rather than four (4) should be submitted, the memo said.

title: Swim Mark Broken by Coast Girl
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., June 28 (AP)Sixteenyearold Heather Greenwood of the Fresno Swim Club set a world record today in the women's 400 meter freestyle, the first event of the eighth annual Santa Clara international invitation swimming and diving meet. Her time was 4 minutes 17.33 seconds.

title: Toronto Festival a Showcase for City's Ethnic Diversity
description: TORONTO, June 26In an Assyrian Orthodox Church basement temporarily converted to resemble a Middle Eastern souk, or market, a man wearing Arab robes was amiably attempting to explain a Palestinian point of view to a visitor with a Serbian name.

title: Expo 74 and Its Theme
description: SPOKANE, Wash.There is an unwritten law that all world's fairs must have a theme. But the themes typically are so lofty and amorphous  like A Century of Progress  that nobody remembers them. Expo 74, covering a compact 100acre expanse of land and water athwart the Spokane River on the edge of this city's downtown area, promises to be a noteworthy exception to this rule.

title: Italy Over One Hurdle
description: Premier Rumor's reconstituted centerleft Government has decisively won its first vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies for a stabilization proram designed to cope with Italy's worst economic crisis since World War II. A comparable endorsement is expected from the Senate, probably next week; but the real test will then begin for Mr. Rumor's coalition and for the antiinflation measures expected to soak up nearly $5 billion of purchasing power this year.

title: Agency Will Listen to Proposals For Less Costly West Side Road
description: The citystate agency whose proposals for a future West Side Highway include a controvenial sixlane Interstate System route said yesterday that it was willing to listen to solid suggestions for a less costly and more modest express. way.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: ACTION ON BULLET IS WEIGHED BY D.A.
description: Nicholas Ferraro, the Queens District Attorney said yesterday that his office was aleanimg strongly toward going to court to force the removal of ti bullet from a suspect In the murder of a police lieutenant two weeks ago.

title: Power in the World Economic Arena
description: PALENVILLE, N. Y.The world is experlericing ti massive power shift. There is talk of military budgets, multiplewarhead missiles, strategicarms talks and counterforce strategy But the real issues lie in the international economic arena. There, the United States and its allies battle among themselves, while the Soviet Union, a sometime enemy, is rapidly gaining ground.

title: Newport's Wein Is Undaunted by Rain
description: The weather was rotten, as it often has been for the opening of the Newport Jazz Festival, but the perisitent showers brought sunshine to the soul of George Wein.

title: Westchester Prosecutor Plans Own Greenburgh Crime Inquiry
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 28The Westchester County District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, said today that he would conduct an investigation into allegations concerning organized crime in the Town of Greenburgh, where a state inquiry has been requested.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Jersey City man arrested in Newark was charged yesterday with the slaying of a woman found stabbed death in her Greenville apartment. The suspect, William Frank Marshall, 30 years old, was accused of killing Henriette Gray, 24, early yesterday morning in her bedroom. The police said Mr. Marshall was Miss Gray's boyfriend.

title: U.S. Track Juniors Set 4 Marks Against U.S.S.R.
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 28 (AP) American teenagers, showing surprising strength in the distance races, broke four meet records tonight in their headtohead junior track and field meet with the Soviet Union. But they also committed a blunder in the 440yard relay that cost them a victory in the event.

title: Anne Faulconer Wed in London
description: Miss Anne Mannington Faulconer and Mark Nathaniel Collins were married yesterday evening in St. Paul's Cathedral in London. The bride, who lives in London, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Jamieson Faulconer of Norfolk, Va. Mr. Collins is the son of Canon L. John Collins of St. Paul's and Mrs. Collins of London and Mount Bures, Suffolk, England.

title: Army Suspends Dog Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)The Army has suspended its plans to buy beagle pups for use in tests of nerve gas and poisons and has started a search for a substitute animal, Pentagon sources said today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DUBLIN, June 28 (AP)  A fortune in horseflesh was assembled at the Curragh race course for tomorrow's Irish Derby, the country's greatest and most colorful sporting event and one of the world's famous races.

title: As Steel Goes...
description: When the ending of economic controls after World War II brought an explosion of increases in prices and wages, steel became the yardstick for measuring how much trouble this country was in. As steel goes, so goes inflation, was the watchword in the Truman years. It was still the watchword when President Kennedy cracked down on Big Steel for price gouging in 1962.

title: Cliff Friend Dead at 80; Composer and Song Writer
description: Cliff Friend, song composer, writer and pianist, died Thursday in Las Vegas, Nev. He was SO years old.

title: NORTH KOREA SINKS SEOUL PATROL SHIP
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 28 (Reuters)  North Korean gunboats sank a South Korean patrol vessel today in a high seas clash in which fighter planes from both nations scrambled for action.

title: Stocks Near 800 on Dow Jones
description: The stock market managedbut just barelyto keep above the 800 level on the DowJones industrial average in yesterday's trading.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Scrap City
description: New York either has some very odd art lovers or some very astute thieves. It takes a fair amount of determination to steal a fourton castiron landmark building by James Bogardus, lamp posts from the Firemen's Memorial on Riverside Drive, or seven sections of bronze bridge railings by Carrere and Hastings.

title: People and Business
description: Six nominees, including William W. Scranton, former Governor of Pennsylvania, have been confirmed by the Senate to terms on the United States Railway Association. However, the nomination of Arthur D. Lewis is chairman was held up by Senator Lowell Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, who was reported to have said that Mr. Lewis was not dynamic enough far she job.

title: FOUR ARE CHARGED WiTH MAIL FRAUD
description: NEWARK, June 28  Separate indictments against two fatherandson teams accused of mailorder frauds totaling nearly $1.6million were returned by a Federal grand jury today.

title: Bridge: Catskills Tournament Offers A WarmUp for the Nationals
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 28The opportunity to get some serious practice for the Summer Nationals, due to begin in New York in two weeks, brought players flocking in droves to the New YorkNew Jersey Regional Championships here this weekend.

title: The C.I.A. and the Public
description: The following article is adapted from a speech that William E. Colby, Director of Central Intelligence, gave before the Los, Angeles World Affairs Coma ht it, he alludes to the boob The CIA and the Cult of Intelligence, by Victor Marcliettl, who worked for the C.I.A. for fourteen years as a SovietMilitary, specialist and executive assistant to the deputy director, and John D. Marks; an analyst and staff assistant to the intelligence director of the State Department.

title: WOMEN SEE DELAY ON EQUAL RIGHTS
description: WICHITA, Kan., Julie 28Leaders of the fight for ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution agreed today that they would probably fail to achieve their target by the end of next year.

title: Diners' Club Faces Coast Antitrust Suit By Merchant Outlet
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 28A local restaurant owner filed a classaction suit today in United States District Court here alleging that the Diners' Club was violating Federal antitrust laws by preventing merchants that utilize its services from offering discounts to cash customers.

title: RYE ANNOUNCES OFFICE CLOSURES
description: Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co., Inc., struggling to contain unspecified losses, told employes yesterday that it was closing 10 of its 55 branch offices. Six of the big brokerage firm's research staff of 20 have also departed and early this week the firm discontinued a sales training program.

title: Stage: London Pleasures
description: LONDON, June 28Does establishment drama have to be stuffy drama? I think not, and my view is upheld by Britain's two major establishment theaters, the National Theater and the Royal Shakespeare Company. In the last day or two, I have seen Peter Mall's staging of Shakespeare's The Tempest, which In its way was establishment theater in excelsis, but also two modern plays, one for each company, by John Hopkins and Peter Barnes.

title: Statements by Rodino and Clawson
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Following is a transcript of remarks on the House floor today by Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee and a statement issued by Ken W. Clawson, White House director of communications, regarding a published report that Mr. Rodino had said that all 21 Democrats on the committee were prepared to vote to recommend impeachment of President Nixon:

title: It's the Present, Not Future, That's Worrying Virdon
description: BALTIMORE, June 28The news out of Anaheim that Dick Williams had signed a 3year contract as manager of the California Angels hasn't changed the outlook of Bill Virdon, the New York Yankees' manager.

title: THEATER LEAGUE, EQUITY IN ACCORD
description: An agreement on a new threeyear contract for actors and stage managers in Broadway and touring shows was reached yesterday between the Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Theaters.

title: NEW DEFENSE SET IN PLUMBERS CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Attorneys for John D. Ehrlichman offered today a new defense in the White House plumbers case, accusing David R. Young Jr., who is expected to be a key prosecution witness, of falsifying statements and documents against Mr. Ehrlichman in order to save his own neck.

title: Bells Toll as Sarajevo Remembers a Bloody Morning in 1914
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, June 28Bells in the main Serbian Orthodox church here tolled this morning at 10:15 to commemorate the event in Sarajevo 60 years ago that led to World War I.

title: American Party Petitions
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 28 (UPI) American party ieaders, vowing to offer Texas voters an alternative in the November elections, turned in today petitions signed by more than 40,000 people to get their nominees listed on the ballot in the state.

title: Gerety ls Installed as Archbishop
description: NEWARK, June 28  The Most Rev. Peter L. Gerety was installed today as Archbishop of Newark in a solemn yet joyful ceremony at the elegant Sacred Heart Cathedral here.

title: Grand Union Net Off
Court Backs Horsemen in '69 Boycott
description: The Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association won a legal battle with the State of New York yesterday when Justice Martin B. Stecher dismissed a suit in Manhattan Supreme Court brought five years ago by Attorney General Louis., J. Lefkowitz against the horsemens' group.

title: Smaller Transactions Formally Completed
description: Prior to yesterday's signing of contracts for the $20billion chemical barter deal in Moscow, two other comparatively smaller deals had been formally completed by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and Soviet authorities.

title: NIXON AIDES SPLIT OVER MISSILE PACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 President Nixon flew to Moscow with his two principal advisers on national security still in disagreement over what would constitute an acceptable accord now to limit strategic nuclear weapons, high Administration officials have disclosed.

title: Realty Trust Data Delays Cause Concern at S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is getting an increasing number of requests from real estate investment trusts for extensions of time for filing financial status reportsa development causing concern within the S.E.C.

title: Kahane Sentenced in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, June 28 (Reuters)  Rabbi Meir Kahane, founder of the Jewish Defense League, was given a twoyear suspended prison sentence today on a charge of having conspired to damage the foreign relations of Israel with another friendly countrythe United States.

title: WINE TALK
description: Think of waltzes, think of Wine, Women and Song, and you almost inevitably think of Austria, particularly Vienna. But who really knows anything about Austrian wine?

title: Jazz Events
description: Today's events in the Newport Jazz Festival: 1 P.M., Carnegie Hall. Music of the New Breed: Norman Connors's Dance of Magic, Roland Hanna's New York Jazz 4, with Ron Carter, Ben Riley and Frank Wess; Dewey Redman 5, Michel Urbaniak.

title: NEW DEFENSE SET IN PLUMBERS' CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Attorneys for John D. Ehrlichman offered today a new defense in the White House plumbers case, accusing David R. Young Jr., who is expected to be key prosecution witness, of falsifying statements and documents against Mr. Ehrlichman in order to save his own neck.

title: Connors Beats Dent and Ashe Wins As Rain Still Slows Wimbledon Tennis
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 28It took a long time doing but Jimmy Connors is shakily in the third round at Wimbledon, which is in a shambles after three days of rain.

title: Marcos Decrees Broad Amnesty For Rebels Who Stop Fighting
description: MANILA, June 28 (UPI)President Ferdinand E. Marcos signed a sweeping amnesty decree today, offering a pardon to Moslem rebels who lay down their arms and cease fighting their independence in the southern Philippines.

title: ... So Goes Inflation'
description: In the last year or two the steel companies and the United Steelworkers of America have been making a zealous joint effort to persuade the country of their social responsibility in avoiding strikes and heightening productivity. The specter of competition from foreign steel made costconsciousness a mutual concern, with clear benefits for the economy.

title: Racing Association Opens a Fair at Saratoga in First Bid for OffSeason Action
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 28The New York Racing Association and the Harry M. Stevens Company jointly bet $1million at the Saratoga Race Track today, but it wasn't on a horse or a rice.

title: OCCIDENTAL SIGNS DEAL WITH SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, June 28  The Occidental Petroleum Corporation today signed four contracts with the Soviet Union activating a mammoth, 20year $20billion chemical barter, the largest commercial transaction ever made between the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: Emhart Is Bidding for USM Shares
description: The Emhart Corporation, a leading manufacturer of builders' hardware, disclosed yesterday that it had been holding discussions with the Allegheny Corporation on the proposed purchase of all the USM Corporation common stock held by Allegheny.

title: SYDNEY H. LANE
description: Sydney H. Lane, who had his own insurance brokerage concern here until his retirement a few years ago, died yesterday of complications following surgery. He was 76 years old and lived at 25 Hutchinson Avenue, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: A Happier Smith Makes Cards' Fans Happy, Too
description: Yogi Berra's ailing troops received a welcome respite last night when the second game in the Mets' fourgame set with the rampaging St. Louis Cardinals at Shea Stadium was postponed because of rain. The contest will be made up as part of a doubleheader tomorrow afternoon starting at 1:15.

title: Fischer Renounces His Chess Title in Rules Dispute
description: PARIS, June 28Bobby Fischer, the brooding and contentious genius of chess notified the International Chess Federation today that he was renouncing his title of world champion.

title: FORUM PLANNED BY BLACK WOMEN
description: NEWARK, June 28The Congress of African People announced today the convening next weekend of an African Women's Conference to create a national black women's organization, and to present a forum for principled dialogue around the issues of nationalism, panAfricanism and socialism.

title: Panel Bars Public CampaignFunding
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The House Administration Committee, nearing the end of three months of work on a major campaign spending bill, rejected today a proposal for the use of taxpayers' money to help finance Presidential primary election campaigns.

title: Guerrillas Freed by Sudan Reported Jailed in Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The State Department said today that it had been informed that the eight Palestinian guerrillas who were convicted of killing two senior American diplomats and a Belgian in Khartoum last year were now in prison in Egypt.

title: Construction Plans For Nuclear Plants Canceled by Utility
description: Construction plans for two major nuclear generating units valued at $1.4billion were canceled yesterday by the Consumers Power Company of Michigan. At the same time, the Boston Edison Company announced that it was deferring the planned construction of nuclear generating unit.

title: New York City's Housing Crisis
description: The bitter discussion over rent decontrol in the recent state legislative session obscured events that have led to a housing crisis in New York City. Operating costs of housing are under. going largescale inflation yet inflation's effects are only dimly perceived by the city's renters. All owners, whether of singlefamily homes or large apartment complexes, have become aware of these costs.

title: Quick Way Found to Identify Pollutant Gases in Air
description: WASHINGTON, June 28A quick method of identifying pollutant gases in the air, patented this week for Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N. J., may be useful in industrial plants. Lloyd B. Kreuzer, while serving as a scientist at the laboratories, combined a laser and an electronic computer for the purpose. The invention covered by Patent 3,820,901 is capable of identifying concentrations of gases as low as one part in 10 billion.

title: GERRY SEVERN
description: Gerry Severn, who served as managing director of Ballet Theater and other ballet companies under his former name of German Sevastianov, died in Switzerland Wednesday.

title: BULLARD LEAVES GOVERNOR RACE
description: ALBANY, June 28T. David Bullard, who was eligible to run as a Conservative party candidate for Governor in the Sept. 10 primary election, withdrew today, assuring Governor Wilson of both the Republican and the Conservative nominations for Governor in the Nov. 5 general election.

title: Dalmatian Gains First Top Award
description: GREENE, N. Y., June 28A Dalmatian who answers to the name of Blizzard proved an allweather dog today at the SusqueNango Kennel Club's Show on Rogers Memorial Field. First he took the breed in the sunlight, then the group under an overcast sky and finally the top honors in a pelting rainstorm.

title: HEALTHFUND CURB IS CALLED ILLEGAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Senator Warren G. Magnuson accused the Administration today of illegally withholding appropriated funds that should have been spent for health research programs during the ifscal year that ends Sunday.

title: RAYMOND LEE
description: LOS ANGELES, June 28 Raymond Lee, an actor in silent movies who later wrote about the film industry, died Wednesday at a suburban hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Fiat Motor Sales Off 20%
description: TURIN, Italy, June 28 (Reuters)The Fiat Motor Company said today its sales dropped by about 20 per cent in the first six months of this year. The situation was more grave in Italy than the rest of Europe, Umberto Agnelli, the managing director, told a company board meeting.

title: Tass Deletion of a Word In Nixon Speech Disputed
description: MOSCOW, June 28A controversy was stirred here today when the word personal was dropped from the official Russian translation of a speech by President Nixon last night in which he said that the personal relationship between him and the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, would be he basis for continued SovietAmerican accommodation.

title: Nationalist Put Off Board of Education By Mayor Gibson
description: NEWARK, June 28Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson announced today that he was removing Adhimu Chunga, the controversial 21yearold black nationalist, from the city's Board of Education and replacing him with George Branch, a moderate, 46yearold black staff member of the Newark Housing Authority.

title: Firing of Rockets Off Again; Shots Are Vowed by Monday
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., June 28 (AP)Poor weather postponed for the fifth day today the firing of 54 research rockets from this space agency base. But scientists intent on making the first comprehensive probe of the earth's upper atmosphere indicated they would get the mission under way before their Monday deadline.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Except for Casey Stengel, they are names that live mostly in oblivion. They are the oldtimers of the New York Mets, to be honored at Shea Stadium today in connection with the team's 10th anniversary season there. But the true oldtimer of the Mets remains with them. And he's only 29 years old. Ed Kranepool is the only player in captivity to have been with the Mets in each of their 13 seasons. As such, he is the only one to have performed with or for the 17 men who will be anointed today with applause. For some, an introduction will generate more applause at Shea than any of their accomplishments ever did. For others, particularly Stengel, it will be a return to the glory that once was, even in the national comedy of last place. Ed Kranepool remembers them all, some more than others.

title: Weiskopf, With 141, Is Shot Ahead
description: OAK BROOK, Ill, June 28  Tom Weiskopf patiently put together a oneunderpar 70 today and took a onestroke lead after the second round of the $200,000 Western open golf tournament. His 141 total is the only score below par.

title: Business Briefs
description: U.S. Sues Two Companies on Lithium

title: Voluntary Regents
description: The wholesale theft and sale of State Regents' examination papers and answer sheets by a group of highschool students cannot be dismissed as a juvenile prank. Those who stole the tests committed a criminal act; those who bought the stolen goods are tainted with dishonor. Candidates for higher education are old enough to be held to a standard of integrity that recognizes these actions for what they are.

title: F.B.I. Enters the Search For Burlington Baby Sitter
description: BURLINGTON, June 28The Federal Bureau of Investigation las begun an intensive search into the unexplained disappearance of Margaret Fox, a 14yearold girl, who left her home here last Monday to take a bus to her first babysitting job.

title: With 11% Pay Rises Nurses in California End a 3Week Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 28Some 4,400 nurses who had struck 43 northern California hospitals for three weeks returned to work this morning after ratifying a twoyear agreement here last night.

title: MORE PRODUCERS RAISE STEEL PRICES
description: The steel industry, following price increases by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation on Monday and the United States Steel Corporation on Wdnesday, yesterday joined the move to higher prices for a broad range of steel products. Steel price rises were announced by both the Republic Steel Corporation and the Armco Steel Corporation. Trade sources said that the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation and the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation had also joined in the rise.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: SUMMIT MEETING SEEKS TO CURTAIL MISSILE DEFENSE
description: MOSCOW, June 28  President Nixon and the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, moved today toward an agreement to reduce the ceiling on antimissile defense systems permitted under the treaty they signed here two years ago.

title: Italy's Premier Wins Vote of Confidence
description: ROME, June 28  The Chamber of Deputies, by a vote of 326 to 225, voiced its confidence in Premier Mariano Rumor and his Cabinet today, implicitly authorizing the patched  up Government to raise $5billion in new taxes in the next 12 months.

title: Record Soviet Deal
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation formally concluded four contracts with the Soviet Union for a $20billion chemical barter over 20 years in the largest commercial deal ever made between the Soviet Union and the United States. Page 35.

title: Record Soviet Deal
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation formally concluded four contracts with the Soviet Union for a $20billion chemical barter over 20 years in the largest commercial deal ever triade between the Soviet Union and the United States. Page 35.

title: EDWARD HEGI, 88, EXTIMES CASHIER
description: Edward A. Hegi, who retired as cashier of The New York Times in 1957 after 53 years of service with the newspaper, died Thursday in the Englewood Hospital. He will 88 years, old and lived at 157 Holland Avenue, New Milford, N.J.

title: Mets, Yankees Rained Out
description: Rain forced the postponement last night of games involving both the Mets and Yankees. The Mets will make up their game against the St. Louis Cardinals as part of a doubleheader tomorrow at Shea Stadium. On their next trip to Baltimore, the Yankees will play a twilightnight doubleheader against the Orioles on Sept. 11.

title: Canada Gives Taiwan Writer Resident Status
description: OTTAWA, June 28Canada has granted a new immigration status, permitting permanent residence here, to a Taiwan newsman whose presence in this country has long irked Peking's diplomatic and press representatives.

title: Toyota Car Exports to Rise
description: TOKYO, June 28 (Reuters)Toyota Motor Company, Ltd., said today it planned to increase its exports by 50,000 vehicles this year because of poor sales at home. The company said it now planned to export 850,000 vehicles, rather than the 800,000 it had originally projected.

title: Housewife Wins at Net
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., June 28 (AP)Mrs. Ginny Mahoney, a 29yearold housewife from Barrington, R.I., won the New England women's tennis championship today by defeating topseeded Ann Murphy of East Hartford; Conn., 61, 76, at Longwood.

title: ExForeign Minister Assassinated in Yemen
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, June 29 (AP)Mohammed Ahmed Noman, former Foreign Minister of Yemen, was shot to death last night in Beirut, the police here reported.

title: Behind Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 We finally quit, not because we hit on a rational formula, but because we were exhausted and finally we got one that almost none of us could understand at the moment, said Representative James C. Gorman, California Democrat and member of the Ways and Means Committee, explaining how the formula for general revenue sharing came about. We were told that statistics were not available to run the [computer] print on it, so we adopted it, and it is here for you today.

title: Hackensack Marks First Gay Pride Day
description: HACKENSACK, June 28This city, the seat of Bergen County, today became the first in the state to observe officially Gay Pride Day. But with the exception of some 50 members of the Gay Activists Alliance of New Jersey, which sponsored the event, few residents seemed to know or care about the occasion.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: 15.3 HAND Beautiful 10 Yr Old Chestnut Gelding. Half thoroughbred, half quarter horse. Sound. Grt dispostn. $1,000 5166929672

title: Shah of Iran Reported to Shift To Firm Orders for Concordes
description: PARIS, June 28Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi has decided to change Iran's longstanding option on the Concorde supersonic airliner into a firm order for three, according to a report circulated here tonight. But confirmation was not immediately available.

title: VICTORY BY BYRNE SEEN IN TAX FIGHT
description: TRENTON, June 28The chairman of the Assembly's Taxation Committee predicted today that the $940million incometax program proposed by Governor Byrne for upgrading New Jersey's public school system and easing the local property tax would pass the Assembly when it conies up for a vote sometime next month.

title: Sakharov Is Planning To Begin Hunger Strike
description: MOSCOW, June 28Andrei D. Sakharov, the nuclear physicist, announced today that he would start a hunger strike to protest against the illegal and brutal repression of political prisoners.

title: M'CRORY OPTIONS ON STORES SLATED
description: Meshulim Riklas, chairman of the McCrory Corporation, confirmed yesterday earlier reports that McCrory had granted options on the leases of six stores in its S. Klein Department Stores division to the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation's Korvette division.

title: CHARLES B. LEVINE
description: Charles B. Levine, founder of Kings Displays, which makes display signs for Broadway shows, died Thursday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 75 years old and lived at 515 East 53d Street in Brooklyn.

title: Hungary Moves Cautiously in Making Western Friends
description: BUDAPESTAs the formal retraints of cold war days dissolve in the face of European dtente, Communist leaders in Hungary, as elsewhere in Eastern Europe, are expecting their people to exhibit an ideological immunity to the anticipated flood, of heretical bourgeois ideas from the West.

title: A SOVIET SCIENTIST TOLD HE MAY LEAVE
description: MOSCOW, June 28 (UPI)An electrochemist, the highestranking Soviet scientist to apply to emigrate to Israel, has been told he can leave by the end of 1975, his oldest son said today.

title: Article 1  No Title
Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Daylight Savings Time

title: 8 Apparent Motorcyclists Held In Queens and Nassau Incidents
description: Eight persons, all apparently members of the Pagans motorcycle club, were arrested by the police in Nassau County and in Queens in two separate incidents yesterday and last night.

title: Prosecutor and Manson Lawyer Indicted for Perjury Over Leak
description: LOS ANGELES, June 28 The chief prosecutor and a defense lawyer in the 1970 murder trial of Charles Manson were indicted today on three counts each of perjury as the threeyearold William Farr case took another turn.

title: ROBERT L. LEWIS
description: Robert L. Lewis, president of the Robert Lewis Travel Service here, died Thurday in Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 53 years old and had lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: Maheu Jury Weighs New Data on Complex Hughes Business Deals
description: LOS ANGELES, June 28A sixmember Federal court jury here seems to be methodically reassessing all the evidence presented in the four months of the trial of Robert A. Maheu's defamation suit against the Howard R. Hughes holding company, Summa Corporation.

title: Notes on People
description: The Vatican announced that Secretary of State Kissinger would call on Pope Paul VI late next week. They are expected to discuss the future of Jerusalem and proposals for creating a state for Palestinians. Then the Secretary, who played soccer as a boy in Germany, plans to attend the World Cup finals in Munich next weekend. He will also meet there with Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher.

title: Duane Stranahan Jr. Weds Mrs. McKelvy
description: Mrs. Cecily Stoddard McKelvy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson Stoddard of Southport, Conn., was married yesterday evening to Duane Stranahan Jr., son of Mr. Stranahan and Mrs. Virginia Secor Stranahan, both of Perrysburg, Ohio.

title: Canada Warns Argentina To Use Reactor for Peace
description: OTTAWA, June 28The Canadian Government has asked Argentina for assurances that the nuclear reactor she is due to get from Canada for a power plant will not be used to produce an explosive device. If the assurances are not given, a spokesman for the External Affairs Department said today, Canada will consider canceling the deal, which is worth $140million.

title: People in Sports
description: Brian Dowling, the former star quarterback at Yale who has been a seldomused reserve behind Jim Plunkett with the New England Patriots the last two seasons, signed a multiyear contract yesterday with the New York Stars of the World Football League. The contract will take effect in 1976, when the 6foot2inch passer will have fulfilled his contractual obligations to the Patriots of the National Football League.

title: Ervin Staff Finds Nixon FundRaisers Did Not Act to Screen Illegal '72 Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Fundraisers for President Nixon's 1972 reelection campaign made no effort whatsoever to insure that contributions they solicited from businessmen were not illegally drawn from corporate funds, the staff of the Senate Watergate committee has charged.

title: Reds Repel Braves and Frisbees to Win, Then Lose
description: It rained in New York, Baltimore and Pittsburgh last night, washing out the baseball games scheduled in those cities.

title: Court Backs Horsemen in '69 Boycott
description: The Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association won a legal battle with the State of New York yesterday when Justice Martin B. Stecher dismissed a suit in Manhattan Supreme Court brought five years ago by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz against the horsemens' group.

title: Midseason Change Follows Loss of Games, Fans
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 Wes Westrum replaced Charlie Fox as manager of the San Francisco Giants today, as the two men switched assignments. Fox, resigning for the good of the club, will take over the major league scouting duties Westrum was performing until Horace Stoneham, the owner, called him in this morning and made him manager.

title: Concorde Orders Seen
description: The Shah of Iran has decided to change his country's longstanding option on the Concorde supersonic airliner into a firm order for three, according to a report circulating in Paris. Confirmation was not immediately available. Details on Page 34.

title: F.B.I. Enters Search For a Jersey Girl, 14
description: BURLINGTON, N.J., June 28The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun an intensive inquiry into the unexplained disappearance of 14yearold Margaret Fox, who left her home here last Monday to take a bus to her first babysitting job.

title: Ethiopian Troops Reported Holding Parts of the Capital
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Saturday, June 29 (AP)Heavily armed troops impatient with the pace of reform in Ethiopia were occupying parts of the capital today in a new threat to the civilian Government.

title: Leaks: A Fact of Life
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Two of the biggest leaks in Washington are about to dry up.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STATEN ISLE TOO Everybody, really everybody, has at one time or another critised the Staten Island Ferrylstill the best transportation buy in New York at 10 cents the round tripMit beginning this week you'll be able to combine the 20minute sail with either of two extensive tours of historic Stater, Island, the newest and certainly among the more interesting tours in this tourridden town.

title: Body Is Found in East River
description: A Brooklyn longshoreman yesterday found the body of man, bound and gagged, floating in the East River off the old Brooklyn Navy yard, the police reported. The victim was tentatively identified as Jose Colon, 27 years old, of 152 Norman Ave., Brooklyn.

title: SOME IN G.O.P. SAY RODINO IS BIASED ON IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee was accused of bias today by some Republicans, and a White House spokesman called for him to be discharged from running the inquiry into the possible impeachment of President Nixon.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: SUMMIT MEETING SEEKS TO CURTAIL MISSILE DEFENSE
description: MOSCOW, June 28  President Nixon and the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, moved today toward an agreement to reduce the ceiling on antimissile defense systems permitted under the treaty they signed here two years ago.

title: PRICES TO FARMS OFF 6% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) Prices for raw farm products, slumping for the fourth consecutive month, declined another 6 per cent in the month ended June 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a June 19 editorial you relate my decision not to run for Congress to the new district lines and to my decision to challenge those lines. These decisions were independently arrived at, for entirely different reasons.

title: The City's Hustle and Bustle As a Quilting Group Sees It
description: As far as maps of New York City go, it's a cartographer's nightmare  a hodgepodge of misshapen boroughs, misplaced streets and missing landmarks.

title: DALKON SHIELD SALE HALTED BY COMPANY
description: RICHMOND, June 28 (UPI)The A. H. Robins Company announced today it was suspending distribution and sale of its Dalkon Shield intrauterine contraceptive device pending a safety study by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: SOME IN G.O.P. SAY RODINO IS BIASED ON IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee was accused of bias today by some Republicans, and a White House spokesman called for him to be discharged from running the inquiry into the possible impeachment of President Nixon.

title: SETTLEMENT IS SET BY ELECTRONIC DATA
description: DALLAS, June 28 (UPI)The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said today it had reached a final settlement in the termination of its computer service contract with duPont Glore Forgan.

title: GloomandDoom Author Brings Message of Hope
description: Harry Browne, author of bestselling gloomanddoom books on dollar devaluation and runaway inflation, took his show to Carnegie Hall this week to tell a twothirds full house of devotees, some Wall Street skeptics and true believers that depression is just around the corner.

title: Hospital Union Awarded $30 Raise in 2Year Pact
description: A stateappointed arbitration ipanel last night awarded 35,000 employes at voluntary hospitals and nursing homes a twoyear contract providing pay increases of at least $30 a week through July 1, 1976.

title: Bhutto Regrets Crimes in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, June 2E Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan publicly apologized, today for what he called the shameful repression and unspeakable crimes committed in Bangladesh by the Pakistani Army before the eastern part of Pakistan gained indeperdence in December, 1971.

title: Winkles Cites Rift With Robinson as Downfall
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 28 (AP)Bobby Winkles said today that while Frqnk Robinson should be a major league baseball manager right now, he would never again manage a team that included Frank Robinson as a player.

title: Major League Baseball and Standings
Buckley Finds No Soviet Boats Off L.I.
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., June 28 Senator James L. Buckley went looking for a Russian fishing fleet off Long Island today but failed to find any trawlers.

title: Japanese Communist Shows the Party's New Face
description: SHIROISHI, Japan Katsu toshi Honda stood in the misty rain, an umbrella shielding the careful grooming that makes him look like a rising young business executive, and went crisply through his basic campaign speech, which was broadcast over a piercing loudspeaker.

title: Mariner to Be Rebuilt After Third Loss
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 28Mariner, the million dollar mistake of the America's Cup, trials, will undergo major surgery to her hull starting on Monday hack where she was built, Derecktor's Shipyard in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: LOUIS ISAACSON
description: Louis Isaacson, president of the 40,000member International Union of Dolls, Toys, Novelties, Playthings and Allied Products of the United States and Canada, an A.F.L.C.I.O. union, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Long Island Jewish Hospital yesterday. He was 73 years old and lived at 817 Glenridge Avenue, North Woodmere, L. I.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: $2.7Billion Budget Is Signed by Byrne; $1.1 Million Cut Out
description: TRENTON, June 28 (UPI)Governor Byrne today signed an appropriations budget of $2.756billion for the 1975 fiscal year, cutting out $1.1million in extra spending sought by the Legislature.

title: Show Title is Taken By Nissen
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 29 Nissen, owned and ridden by Valerie Monnett of Honolulu, made his first start on the summer circuit a successful one, by winning the small junior working hunter championship today at the Middlesex County Horse Show.

title: No Standout Apparent in Rich Trot
description: WESTBURY L. I., June 28 Not since 1968, when Billy 7to5 choice, to 1length triumph; has there been so wideopen in American Trotting Championship as the 29th annual fixture at Roose welt Raceway tomorrow night.

title: Asia Development Fund Set
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (Reuters)The Asian Development Bank announced today the establishment of the Asian Development Fund following the pledge of $236.92million to the A.D.F. by 10 developed member countries of the bank.

title: SUIT ON SUBWAY DIN DISMISSED BY JUDGE
description: A State Supreme Court justice dismissed a lawsuit yesterday that had sought to compel the Transit Authority to reduce the noise level in the city's subways, and the chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority took the opportunity to announce a renewed effort to solve the noise problem.

title: Police Here Weigh Proposal to Give Force Wide Psychological Services
description: A detailed plan that woulc enable the Police Department here to provide its members with the mostextensive psy, chological services of any police department in the corm. try is now under consideration by Commissioner Michae J. Codd.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL ON HEALTH ETHICS
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The House passed by 311 to 10 today a health research training bill that would also create a national commission on medical ethics and put temporary ban on research involving the human fetus.

title: French Assembly Allows Wide Contraceptive Sales
description: PARIS, June 28The French Assembly gave overwhelming endorsement today to a law not only authorizing general distribution of contraceptives but also providing that the cost be borne by the social security system.

title: Construction Plans For Nuclear Plants Canceled by Utility
description: Construction plans for two major nuclear generating units valued at $1.4 billion were canceled yesterday by the Consumers Power. Company of Michigan. At the same time, the Boston Edison Company announced that it was deferring the planned construction of a nuclear generating unit.

title: Maheu Jury Weighs New Data on Complex Hughes Business Deals
description: LOS ANGELES, June 28?? sixmember Federal court jur?? here seems to be methodicall reassessing all the evidenc?? presented in the four months o?? the trial of Robert A. Maheu' defamation suit against th?? Howard R. Hughes holding company, Summa Corporation??

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: Miss McMullen Leads Golf on 67
description: MONTREAL, June 28 (UPI) Kathy McMullen shot one of the finest rounds of her fouryear career, a sixunderpar 67; for a stroke lead after the first round of the $60,000 Peter Jackson, golf tournament today.

title: Party Runs Clinics for All
description: SHIOGAMA, Japan  The Japan Communist party may be the only political party in the world to run a string of hospitals and medical clinics.

title: Regents Against Busing Obtain Review of Policy
description: The State Board of Regents, acting under growing pressure from board members who oppose busing, will review its 14yearold policy of firm support for busing as a tool for integration in the public schools.

title: The Screen: S*P*Y*S
description: From time to time, it's necessary to tug a forelock over the question of good actors in terrible movies. Did a project that sounded promising in advance degenerate during the actual filming? Or were the actors and their agents temporarily blinded to the idiocies of the script? Or (forlorn thought) did the stars contribute some of the bilge that floods the narrative? The only mystery contained in S*P*Y*Sa feeble attempt to spoof the Central Intelligence Agency is why Donald Sutherland and Elliott Gould ever chose to be in it. The movie opened yesterday at the UA Columbia 1 and Guild theaters.

title: RABIN AND WILSON IN LONDON TALKS
description: LONDON, June 28 (Reuters) Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and Prime Minister Wilson had a 90minute discussion here today on the situation in the Middle East, informed British sources said.

title: DDT Is Used in Battle Against Timber Moth
description: GRAND COULEE, Wash.,  The attack was set for dawn. So the pilot's briefing started the night before.

title: Antiques: Folk Art Show
description: SANDWICH, Mass.  Appropriately, in this, the first public showing of the folk art collection of Herbert Waide Hemphill Jr., a stonyfaced squaw and brave flank the entrance to the exhibition in the Heritage Plantation's museum here.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: JAMES J. CAULFIELD
description: James J. Caulfield, who retired in 1970 after 41 years as a pressman for The New York Times, died of cancer yesterday at his home, 163 Rorbell Street in Brooklyn. He was 65 years old.

title: Regents Against Busing Obtain Review of Policy
description: The State Board of Regents, acting under growing pressure from board members who oppose busing, will review its 14yearold policy of firm support for busing as a tool for integration in the public schools.

title: Portuguese Guinea Front: Recent Foes Clasp Hands
description: TEIXEIRA PINTO, Portuguese Guinea, June 27Gingerly, the heavily armed soldiers of the liberation movement stepped out of the forest into the cleared strip along the road leading north from this district town.

title: It's Tea and a Circus For Two First Ladies
description: MOSCOW, June 28 (AP)While their husbands discussed affairs of state, Patricia R. Nixon and Viktoria Petrovna Brezhnev renewed acquaintances today, attended a junior circus and had tea at the opulent Grand Kremlin Palace.

title: Industrial Sugar Price Is Trimmed by Sacred
description: The Sucrest Corporation, a major sugar refiner and marketer, announced yesterday that it was reducing the price of industrial sugar by 55 cents on a 100pound bag, effective July 3.

title: Sic Transit...
description: New York's battered hopes for Federal transit operating assistance to help save the 35cent fare received another setback this week when the House Public Works Committee failed once more to produce a final draft of longawaited masstransit legislation.

title: HomeStake Chairman Asserts His Good Faith
description: TULSA, Okla., June 28 (UPI)The former chairman of a bankrupt oil drilling company allegedly involved in a $100million swindle said today he acted in good faith with the company's investors.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Court Dismisses SubwayNoise Suit

title: Gerety Is Installed as Archbishop
description: NEWARK, June 28  The Most Rev,. Geter L. Gerety was installed today as Archibishop of Newark in a solemn yet joyful ceremony at the elegant Sacred Hearth Cathedral here.

title: Vonkers Implements The New State Law To Stabilize Rents
description: The Yonkers City Council voted last night to make the state's new apartmentrentstabilization law effective there.

title: Gillespie Rules the Day As jazz Festival Opens
description: Although the first major event of the 1974 Newport Jazz Festival, The Musical Life of Charlie Parker, did not take place until last night, the festival actually got under way in the morning and by midafternoon was swinging to the music of a big band that set a challenging standard for the bands that will follow it during the next 10 days.

title: Mrs. Kirouc Golf Victor
description: CRANSTON, R.I., June 28 (AP)Mrs. Martha Wilkinson Kirouac, of Barrington, the 1970 United States amateur champion, defeated Judy Whalon of East, Providence on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff today and won the Rhode Island women's amateur golf tournament.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE GREAT AMERICAN POPULAR SINGERS. By Henry Pleasants. 384 pages. Simon & Schuster. $9.95

title: American League In Business Here
description: The American League officially opened its headquarters here yesterday with what the league president, Lee MacPhail, called an office warming. The new office is situated at Park Avenue near Grand Central Station.

title: Coach of Yugoslav Team Apologizes for Its Loss
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 28While some heads of state use prime television time to find excuses for their actions, Milian Miljanic, the Yugoslav coach, today took time off to appear on television and publicly apologize to his fellow countrymen for his actions against West Germany on Wednesday night.

title: 3 MORE SENTENCED IN GRUMMAN CASE
description: Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein yesterday sentenced three additional defendants who had pleaded guilty to rigging bids to obtain subcontracts for the production of technical manuals for the Grumman Aerospace Corporation of Bethpage, L.I.

title: Japan Reports $1Pillion Payments Gap
description: TOKYO, June 24  Discouraging economic news here today seemed likely to deepen the underlying Japanese anxiety over the immediate future of the economy.

title: NIXON AIDES SPLIT OVER MISSILE PACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 President Nixon flew to Moscow with his two principal advisers on national security still in disagreement over what would constitute an acceptable accord now to limit strategic nuclear weapons, high Administration officials have disclosed.

title: Wages Spurt, Strikes Rise; Major Settlements Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 With labor demanding big wage increases to catch up to the cost of living, the two months since Federal wageprice controls expired have brought round of collectivebargaining settlements of 8 to 10 per cent a yearand moreand a big increase in strikes.

title: Miss Mahony Wed in Suburb
description: Miss Barbara Lee Mahony, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Mahony Jr. of Bedford, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Fred I. Kent 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kent 2d of Salisbury, Conn. The Rev. Kenneth E. Nye, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Sakharov Begins Fast
description: MOSCOW, June 29 (UPI)Andrei D, Sakharov, the physicist, began a hunger strike today to protest political detention in the Soviet Union. His stepdaughter, Mrs. Tatyana Yankelevich, said he had received telephone calls from Britain and the United States, expressing support. She said he was taking only mineral water during his fast.

title: News of the Camera World
description: THE Photography Institute of the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, is offering an eightweek course in beginning photography starting tomorrow evening at 7:30. Registration will be going on during the day, from 9 to 5. The fee for the course will he $??. and the phore number to call for more information is (212) 4756200.

title: Photography
description: ONE of many ideas which underwent modification to the point of metamorphosis during Susan Sontag's recent tripartite skirmish with photography in the New York Review of Books was her startling announcement that, Strictly speaking, it is doubtful that a photograph can help us to understand anything. Sontag's reconsideration of this stance was implicit in her subsequent evaluations of the politics and ethics of various modes of photographic imagemaking. All possibility of understanding, as she pointed out, is rooted in the ability to say no, and once she began saying no to numerous bodies of photographic work some stringent revision became necessary.

title: WIFE WILL GOVERN WHILE PERON IS ILL
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 29Vice President Maria Estela Martinez de Perlin became Acting President of Argentina today while her husband, Juan Domingo Perlin, lay seriously ill with what his personal physicians described as infectious bronchitis with heart complications.

title: Rediscovering Recipe for Profits
description: The new chairman of the General Foods Corporation received a visitor the other day in his shirtsleeves. The shirt screamed yellow and blue stripes behind the somber maroon of James L. Ferguson's necktie.

title: Alice M. Dana, Lee Spencer Jr. Are Wed Here
description: Miss Alice Marie Dana, an assistant producer for news at WNET/Channel 13, was married here yesterday afternoon to Lee Bowen Spencer Jr., who is with the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Planned Hempstead Firehouse Opposed
description: HEMPSTEAD  Protesting the planned construction of a new volunteer firehouse, a group of residents of the Village of Hempstead picketed the proposed site for two days last week.

title: Jazz Events
description: Today's events in the Newport Jazz Festival:

title: Jane Hodge Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs, John Murray Hodge of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Hodge, to Kenneth R. Goldstein, who is with Brout & Co., certified public accountants here. He is the son, of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Goldstein of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Brooklyn dab Driver Honored
description: A Brooklyn taxicab driver, one of 1.800 drivers recently trained by the Police Department to report street crimes and distress calls on twoway cab radios, was honored last week for his alert that summoned the police quickly to a Queens shooting.

title: Miss Alexis Belinda Tollefson Bride of Peter Jay Schieffelin
description: Miss Alexis Belinda Toiletson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Warren Tollefson of Northridge, Calif., was married yesterday morning to Peter Jay Schieffelin, a descendant of John Jay, first Chief Justice of the United States, and of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt.

title: City Plan for Minority Construction Workers Leaves Issue Unsettled
description: After months of fruitless negotiations over conflicting approaches to assure more constructionindustry jobs for minority workers, the city's plan for mandatory action went into effect last week.

title: The Partisans
description: Impeachment: Emerging Party Rancor

title: Varied Summer Classes Start in City Tomorrow
description: School will begin all over for thousands of city students tomorrow as the Board of Education's summer programs start classes.

title: Gardens
description: SPITTLEBUG: A mass of frothy bubbles in the axils of softtextured plants hides the nymph of the spittlebug The protective covering is formed by the young insect and pulled over its head so. can suck the plant juices undetected. The insect is related to leafhoppers and is sometimes called a froghopper. A serious pest of alfalfa, it is a backyard curiosity. There is one brood a year.

title: Cobble Hill: From Stable To a House In 145 Years
description: After 10 years of crosscountry touring with a children's theater, Dorothy and Richard Turmail returned to New York as apartment tenants. They gravitated to brownstone garden apartments and repeatedly found themselves renovation refugees, moving on just ahead of some new owner's restoration plans.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: A $777 MILLION DEFICIT in the nation's balance of trade for May, against a $93million surplus in April, was reported by the Commerce Department.. The May deficit was the largest since October, 1971. ... A threejudge panel in the Federal Court in Philadelphia found the Regional Rail Reorganization Act of 1973 unconstitutional. ... The F.T.C. plans to issue complaints against major oil companies and others in a move to break up interlocking directorates.

title: Eleanor S. Dick, Finch Graduate, Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Mathews Dick Jr. of Washington and Newport, R.I., have announced the engagement of Mr. Dick's daughter, Miss Eleanor Swan Dick, to Barclay Douglas Jr., son of Mr. Douglas of Newport and New York and the late Mrs. Douglas.

title: Air Unit Changing Role
description: WESTHAMPTONThe Air National Guard unit at Suffolk County airport here, at present part of the Air Defense System, will become an air rescue group next year.

title: Tribute to an American LonerA New Mark Tobey Exhibition
description: THIS summer's major exhibition at the National Collection of Fine Arts in Washington is called Tribute to Mark Tobey, who, at the age of 84, living in Basel, is dean in absentia of American abstract painting. By inference, the exhibition is subtitled Not a retrospective. A bare half dozen of the seventy works in the show are early figurative or semifigurative paintings, and these are selected not as a thumbnail roundup, but as the most immediate antecedents to Tobey's fully developed art.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN outdoor carpeting was first introduced a little over 10 years ago it came in only one style or patterna feltlike thin material that closely resembled the padding frequently used under regular carpeting. Although this is still one of the most widely sold (and least expensive) types, there are now numerous other styles and patterns from which the shopper can choose, including artificial turf materials that look almost like real grass and others that come in tufted or loop pile yarns. Many of these are sold for indoor use in rooms that get hard wear, as well as for outdoor useso most dealers now refer to them as indooroutdoor carpets.

title: Candidate In Queens Seeks Help From Nixon
description: If James E. Eagan has his way, President Nixon will walk the streets of Queens with him this summer as he attempts the uphill challenge of unseating Representative James J. Delaney.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Hailed on His First Year
description: LOS ANGELES, June 29 Tom Mix once rode the cinematic range on the 180 acres where the gleaming officeshopping complex called Century City now stands.

title: Justice Department Reform
description: The recent interrogation of Henry E. Petersen by Sam J. Ervin Jr. in Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on the nomination of Earl J. Silbert as United States Attorney for the District of Columbia raises a question that is far more important than whether an Attorney General controls his wife or tonguenamely, whether his legal conscience is wholly controlled by the President.

title: News of the Stage
description: Kay Ballard, who last appeared on Broadway in the title role of Molly, the musical based on The Goldbergs, Gertrude Berg's radio and television series, has signed to star in a musical version of William Inge's Come Back, Little Sheba, scheduled to open here in January.

title: Summertime, When Cooking Should Be Easy
description: How does one reconcile the joy of sharing one's weekend nestor fulltime homewith good friends and the effort of feeding them?

title: Miss Wilsey Wed To Paul Marshall
description: Miss Suzanne DeForest Wilsey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Colver Wilsey of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Paul Scott Marshall, son of Paul Wesley Marshall of Pittsburgh and the late Rachel Jones Marshall. The Rev. John Wadsworth Howe Jr. performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Church in Farmington, Conn.

title: What Makes Jim Dale Run And Jump and Skid and Dance?
description: JIM DALE smashed his fist into the palm of his hand, hard. You have to hit it! he exclaimed. Hit it! You have to hit that certain level. The level I want to reach keeps getting higher, though, and that's what makes me sweat.

title: Divided Cyprus Shuns National Spirit
description: NICOSIA, CyprusA joke making the rounds of foreign embassies here says that the Greek Cypriotes should return to Greece, the Turkish Cypriotes to Turkey, and the island should be given to the Palestinians.

title: Impeachment Panel Rift May Spread in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Partisan conflicts that split the House Judiciary Committee this week and brought White House call for the committee chairman's ouster were described today as the advance warning signs of a coming political eruption in Congress over impeachment.

title: AROUND THE
description: SUMMER READING

title: Scarlett Leas Is Bride Of William Robertson
description: St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton. L. I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Scarlet Leas, a greatgreatgranddaughter of John Wanamaker, the Philadelphia merchant, to William Douglas Robertson, son of Mrs. Donald L. Carter of South Dartmouth, Mass., and the late Dr. Gordon Farquhar Robertson of Greenwich, Conn.

title: For Good Listening Why Not Try the Philharmonic's Floor?
description: LIFE is an unstable compound of a few certainties (i.e., the entire West Side eventually will be paved over to accommodate a 48lane truck speedway) and a crushing number of mysteries (i.e., why does a sevenfoot basketball player who earns a quarter of a million a year feel it necessary to wear shoes with fiveinch heels?). Among the lesser mysteries pressing on our attention recently was the case of the New York Philharmonic's enorimously successful Rug Concert series. For the second year it was demonstrated conclusively that some people do not need to sit upright, as in church, to enjoy symphony concerts. That, however, is not the puzzle, We'll come to it.

title: Senate Committee Aide Is On a Mission to Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (Reuters)The staff director of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is on a 10day visit to Cuba for talks with senior officials there.

title: Here Come the Sons and Daughters Of The Godfather and Funny Girl
description: DID you ever wonder what became of the Corleone clan after they made New York a safe place in which to bring up the Mafia? Well, you can stop wondering and gird yourself for The Godfather, Part IIone of a multitude of spinoffs headed your way in what may well go down in the books as the Year of the Sequel.

title: Theater: This Is No Time for Aristophanes
description: THERE are those who would hold our comic theater remiss in failing to make much of Watergate. Where, it may be asked, is our Aristophanes, ready to march into the amphitheater and risk his popularity and perhaps his neck by hurling anathemas, naming names? Totting up the political dirty tricks that pockmarked 5thcentury Athens (B.C.), Aristophanes was willing, in his muchadmired plays, to be highly, even libelously, specific. A certain demagogue was an unbearable ape, the greatest rogue of all. When the demagogue threatened reprisals, as demagogues so often do, the playwright simply scoffed: He fears, if he ventures forth without his bludgeon, he will be stripped of his clothes. A bold a big hit.

title: Baron David de Rothschild Marries
description: PARIS, June 29Baron David de Rothschild of the Paris banking family and Miss Olimpia Aldobrandini of Venice were married today in a civil ceremony presided over by the bridegroom's mother, acting in her capacity as Mayor.

title: School Bell Is Ringing Abroad
description: PRINCETON  A program aimed at exposing American high school students to foreign cultures is gaining prominence.

title: Male Chauvinist Rabbits
description: What with Watership Down firmly entrenched on the bestseller list, the time has come to put in a good word for lady rabbits.

title: Bursteins Have Child
description: A daughter was born June 4 to Dr. and Mrs. Stephen D. Burstein of Freeport, L. I. at the South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, L. J. Mrs. Burstein, whose husband is a neurosurgeon, is the former Miss Ronnie Sue Deutsch. The child has been named Alissa Aimee.

title: Palestinians Are a Problem For the U.S., As Well
description: WASHINGTONA newsman asked a State Department official the other day what the United States policy was toward the Palestinians.

title: Stewardesses Protest Suggestive Airline Ads
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The sexually suggestive advertising campaigns of two major airlines have sparked a new furor over whether such selling techniques represent a sellout of women employes.

title: One Cuban Province Holds Vote Today; First in 15 Years
description: HAVANA, June 29 (Reuters) An election, the first in Cuba in more than 15 years, is being held tomorrow in Matanzas, the smallest of the country's six provinces.

title: Jana Rooted in 40's By Babs Gonsalves And Groovy Quintet
description: Expubidence, which was what Babs Gonsalves called his music and his quintet at Fordham University on Saturday afternoon  part of the free jazz series held in conjunction with the Newport Jazz Festival was never really defined by the singer. But essentially this madeup word seemed to stand for some freewheeling, on structured music, with Mr. Gonsalves serving as host in a manner that, a couple of decades ago, belonged to the hipsters.

title: The Fiery Trial
description: A Life of Lincoln. By Herbert Mitgang. Illustrated. 207 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $7.95.

title: Methadol Testing In Need Of Recruits
description: Tests in Brooklyn and Suffolk County of a methadonetype drug, which its backers contend is longerlasting than methadone and has fewer side effects, have been slowed by the reluctance of addicts to participate in them.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 30, 1974

title: 6 Japanese Die in Training
description: TOKYO, June 29 (UPI)  Six Japanese soldiers were killed and six others wounded when a mortar shell exploded today during a firing drill in Hokkalir do, the northern army headquarters said.

title: Notes: The Computer Goes ACamping
description: NOT long ago people planning to camp out in any state or national park had to get an early start to beat the crowd; otherwise all the sites would be taken. In fact, many a latestarter and his suffering family spent the night in their car at a park entrance, hoping to get a site when someone checked out in the morning. An improvement in this system came when a few of the more popular camping areas decided to accept reservations by mail. But notification as to whether a reservation had been accepted or not was slow.

title: Grand Prix Unit Remains a Closed Club by Barring Outsiders
description: PARIS, JUNE 29  It was reaching the point where winning grand prix races was not as difficult as starting them. Chris Amon, the talented driver from New Zealand, was having entry applications returned so quickly he must have thought he had a communicable disease.

title: Jocelyn Hevener Kress Bride of Webb Turner
description: Miss Jocelyn Hevener Kress, daughter of Mrs. Rush Harrison Kress and the late Mr. Kress, who was chairman of the board of S. H. Kress & Co., was married yesterday afternoon to Webb William Turner of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Turner of Petersburg, Va.

title: Ethiopian Troops Seize Key Centers in the Capital
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 29 (AP)Ethiopian troops imposed a curfew on the capital of Addis Ababa tonight and in effect declared themselves in control of the country.

title: Miss Hackett Has Nuptials
