title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Victoria Nicolson Wed in England
description: Miss Victoria Anne Nicolson, daughter of David Lancaster Nicolson, chairman of British Airways, and Mrs. Nicolson of London and Dunsfold, England, was married yesterday in Dunsfold to Godfrey Lowell Cabot Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Welles Henderson of Gladwyne, Pa., and Manchester, Mass.

title: NIXON, BREZHNEV IN TRADE ACCORD; THEY FLY TO YALTA
description: YALTA, U.S.S.R., June 29President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, today signed a 10year economic agreement designed to promote SovietAmerican trade and then flew to the Crimea, historic meeting place of the Big Three in World War II, to carry on their talks on arms control.

title: No objective correlative needed
description: When in 1949 Ernest Hemingway wrote a laudatory introduction to the original New Directions edition of Vittorini's 1937 novel In Sicily (reprinted in the present omnibus), he was returning a compliment. For Vittorini, along with Cesare Pavese, another important admirer of Hemingway, was an Americanista. His critical promotion of American writers during the thirties had been more than an objective appreciation; it was also a form of revolt in an Italy which officially rated Italianita the paramount literary quality.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the moments when Dick Williams resigned as manager of the Oakland A's after two consecutive World Series triumphs, he mentioned how he yearned to return to the East Coast, particularly to Riviera Beach, Fla., where he lives. He also was thinking of New York, until the Yankees were prevented from hiring him. Now that he has signed to manage the, California Angels, his sense of geography is suspect. Anaheim is only on the east coast of an Orange County spillway. He is quick to explain that his decision involved the return of the native. He grew up in the Los Angeles area, his mother and stepfather live there, his wife's parents live there, his daughter attends a nearby college. But no apology is necessary. Dick Williams is a major league manager. He had an opportunity to manage a major league team that not only offered him an extravagant annual salary of perhaps $100,000 through 1977, but also could persuade Charles 0. Finley to sanction his employment. Rand McNally's approval was neither needed nor sought.

title: Saigon's Plastic Surgery Clinic Is a Busy Haven for the Injured Vietnamese
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 29  The 10yearold boy with the melancholy eyes is Phan Thanh Anh. He was swinging a knife through long green elephant grass, clearing some new land for farming, when something exploded and blew all the fingers off his left hand.

title: WEICKER CHARGES 370 LAW ABUSES BY NIXON FORCES
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican member of the Senate Watergate committee, charged today that members of President Nixon's Administration and campaign organization had been responsible for some 370 abuses of law or of the Constitution in the course of the Watergate scandals.

title: Aviator Weds Miss McShane
description: The Butler Memorial Chapel at Marymount Secondary School in Tarrytown, N.Y., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Miss Maureen Eloise McShane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence E. McShane of Chappaqua, N.Y., to Ens. Erwin Benham Elliott 3d, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Jr. of Miami.

title: Television
description: IF all goes according to the plan of the National Association of Broadcasters, chief lobbying arm for the broadcast industry, the script might make an interesting TV series called the Great American Ripoff Machine. It could be the program that asks the question: How do you make a powerful industry almighty?

title: Spinney Hill Plan Backed by Court
description: A Federal court judge removed last week the final obstacle to the start of construction of the Spinney Hill urban renewal housing project, which was first proposed a decade ago.

title: Cattlemen's Beef
description: Through all the months of skyrocketing beef prices, the free market had no stancher defenders than the nation's cattlemen. The law of supply and demand took on the status of Holy Writ in their argument against any Governmental interference with the right of the cow to jump over the moon when it came to prices.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Daylight Savings Time

title: Stamps
description: WHAT Virgil wrote as he began the AeneidI sing of arms and the man seems a fitting epic note to strike for new stamps dealing with arms and men at arms over the centuries, issues that are a constant in philately.

title: MARGARINE NEARS PRICE OF BUTTER
description: NEW BERLIN, Wis., June 27 The price of margarine, which initially gained favor in the United States primarily because it cost much less than butter, is now almost as expensive as the highpriced spread.

title: Rita O'Shaughnessy Wed
description: Miss Rita O'Shaughnessy, fashion editor at The Daily News Record, a men'swear publication, was married here yesterday morning to Thomas M. Hamilton, an account executive at the William Esty Advertising Agency. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Theodore P. O'Shaughnessy of New York and the late Mr. O'Shaughnessy. Harold Hamilton of Eastchester and the late Mrs. Hamilton are the bridegroom's parents. The Rev. Michael F. Gallagher performed the ceremony in the Our Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Proper Bostonian First
description: SALEM, N. H., June 29 (AP)Proper Bostonian put. on a burst of speed at the top of the stretch to win the $10,000 Welcome Rack Handicap at Rockingham Park today. John Giovanni rode the winner over the six furlongs in 1:09 45 to a return of $7.80, $3.80 and $3.

title: A. Misplaced Anger
description: A study such as that just published by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education appears to support the anger of many Americans at what the Government calls affirmative action and they denounce as reverse discrimination. That anger is still misplaced, if understandable; it is like being angry at a painful treatment rather than at the wound or illness that made it necessary.

title: Chess: Americans Press the Battle For the No. 3 Spot in Nice
description: NICE, June 27The United States squad pressed its battle for third place with Bulgaria, behind the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia, by defeating Spain 31 in round 11 and taking a 21 lead over the Philippines in round 12 of the International Team Tournament.

title: Sidney Schantz Fiance Of Miss Joyce Chatlin
description: The engagement of Miss Joyce Marilyn Chatlin, who received a degree from the Pennsylvania College of Optometry, and Sidney Schantz, a labor economist in Washington, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Nathan Steinway of Washington.

title: The Visiting Homemaker: Aid for the Sick and the Disabled
Diagramless, 22 by 17
description: ACROSS

title: Belgian Judge Praises Japanese Dog Fanciers
description: Japanese fanciers were praised for their good sportsmanship by Mrs. Denise Nizet de Leemans, who judged at a dog show in Tokyo.

title: Mrs. Van Steeden Wed to F. T. Keegan
description: Mrs. Nancy Major Van Steeden of Darien, Conn., widow of Peter Van Steeden 3d, was married yesterday afternoon to F. Thomas Keegan of Ballston Spa, N. Y. The Rev. Samuel W. Fogal performed the ceremony In the First Congregational Church in Darien.

title: Equality for Women Will Raise a Host of Problems for Colleges
description: Remember the campus unrest of the late nineteensixties, when college and high school athletes began to question why they should run through brick walls? When the crewcut coach wondered whether to communicate with his longhaired competitor or kick him off the team?

title: Son to Mrs. M. M. Russo
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Matthew M. Russo of Jericho, L. I., on June 12 in the Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N. Y. The child has been named Michael Benjamin.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Friday was the third anniversary of the shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the Mafia chieftain gravely wounded at an ItalianAmerican Day rally in Columbus Circle. His alleged assailant, Jerome Johnson, was slain on the spot.

title: Rebels Assure Portugal's Black Troops
description: CACINE, Portuguese Guinea, June 26When Portugal and the nationalist movement were at war, nowhere was the fighting heavier than on this southernmost peninsula where Portuguese Guinea, the Republic of Guinea and the Atlantic meet.

title: North of 86th, The Pipeline For Housing Is Extensive
description: An article last week detailed the residential construction that is creating a new Upper Upper East Side north of 86th Street. A total of 7,000 housing units for a wide range of income levels are under construction or just completed at a cost of more than $250million. The following article tells about the pipeline that may add to that total, and the community efforts to influence its course.

title: The spy who spied on spies
description: John Le Carrel's new bookhis seventh in thirteen yearsis a thoroughly enjoyable English spy novel about the discovery of a double agent at the highest level of the British Intelligence bureaucracy. It reconfirms the impression that Le Carr belongs to the select company of such spy and detective story writers as Arthur Conan Doyle and Graham Greene in England and Dashiell Hammett, James M. Cain, Raymond Chandler and Ross Macdonald in America. There are those who read crime and espionage books for the plot and those who read them for the atmosphere; the former talk of ingenious puzzles and take pride in pure ratiocination; the latter think themselves more literary, worry about style and characterization, and tend to praise their favorite writers as real novelists. Le Carrel's books like those of the six authors just mentionedoffer plenty for both kinds of readers.

title: INFLATION IS ISSUE IN CANADIAN VOTE
description: MONTREAL, June 29Mrs. Lise Labelle wheeled her basket slowly down a supermarket aisle here the other day, methodically comparing prices.

title: Church Council Drops Five Top Jobs
description: Five top officials of the National Council of Churches have been told that their jobs. will be abolished by next January as part of a new structure and style of management approved by the General Assembly of the ecumenical organization in 1972.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The nauseating Watergate scandal continues to drag along interminably without any light at the end of the tunnel. The American people are bored to death with the incessant stream of leaks, innuendos and accusations, proved and unproved. As a result the reputation of the Congress and the media has fallen to new lows in the eyes of the public.

title: Brooklyn Hospital Expanding
description: Ground was broken last week for a 20story, $8.6million staff apartment building that is part of the first phase of an expansion program by Brooklyn Hospital, the oldest voluntary hospital in the borough.

title: Epilogue
description: Day of the Beetle

title: A Retreat for Firemen of Old
description: BOONTONAlthough many retired people throughout the country encounter difficulty in being accepted by homes for the elderly, principally because they are overcrowded, New Jersey's professional and volunteer retired firemen have no such problem. The New Jersey Firemen's Home, on an 81acre estate on Lathrop Avenue, is said to be the only one of its kind in the country.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Basketball

title: The World
description: All factions of the Palestinian guerrilla movement appear to have embarked on a program of expanded violence. The aim seems obvious to gain them the representation they seek at the forthcoming peace talks in Geneva, or to force postponement of the talks.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Four leases for more than 56,000 square feet of space have been signed at One Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, the 50story office building on the west side of Second Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets.

title: McNally 2Hitter Foils Yanks' Swing to Right, 20
description: BALTIMORE, June 29The Yankees newlook righthanded lineup performed much like their oldlook lineup tonight as Dave McNally of the Orioles continued lefthanded pitchers' dominance of the New Yorkers with a twohit, 20 victory.

title: GUERRILLAS ATTACK MEKONG SUPPLY SHIP
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 29 (AP)  Guerrillas attacked a Government supply convoy in the Mekong River 40 miles Southeast of Phnom Penh today and set a Panamanian freighter ablaze, forcing its crew to abandon ship, port sources reported.

title: That Firm Fall Program Schedule Has Fallen Apart, and Here's Why
description: THIS will he a column about the Federal Communications Commission and the primetime access rule. Already you are stoppering your yawn with the first available elbow 1 agree. Reading about the primetime access rule is almost as boring as writing about it. Still, it's a squalid story worth pondering in a squalid time.

title: Woman Sailor One of Guys Aboard Racing Yacht
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 29Ondine's the name, the only yacht in the world this week with a record in the great Bermuda race, books by Darwin and Camus below deck and a crew of 20 men and one 23yearold woman.

title: Quiet, restful, joyfuland beautiful
description: There is an alternative to the sharpangled aggressive houses that are ruining the natural beauty of so many beach communities. It is the organic architecture that Frank Lloyd Wright advocated more than 70 years ago. The Fire Island house on these pages, designed by Thomas L. Moore for the Kevin Corrigans, is an object lesson in this organic, environmental style. The house is nestled almost imperceptibly into its surroundings, despite the fact that the site is only 85 by 180 feet. From the Saltaire boardwalk, it is almost invisible. The Corrigans had wanted a simple house in this beach community where Mrs. Corrigan had spent summers as a child. Since they were thinking simple, they had not thought architect until they had looked through the prefabricated house catalogues and even gone so far as to ask a local builder to draw up a plan. We were skeptical of architects, Mr. Corrigan said, because the builder had told us they doubled the cost of a house. But just down the boardwalk lived Tom houses in Saltaire (one of them for his own family) that the Corrigans admired. They were impressed by the sensitive siting of the three houses and the way Mr. Moore preserved the trees and island vegetation. The Corrigans started thinking designer and Mr. Moore worked out the plan for this onestory, wideeaved pavilion with two wingsone for the Corrigans' tour teenage children and one for the parentsand lots of deck space. After the house was built, it struck me that our land had not been all that interesting. The house actually enhanced the beauty of the site, Mr. Corrigan said. Windows frame woodland views as artful as Japanese scroll paintings. Decks wind around old trees. And two neighboring houses, both in the blatant lookatme style that has become so grating, have been subdued to abstract design backdrops to the Corrigans' unobtrusive house. Mr. Moore's design, which called for stock building materials and mostly builtin furniture, enabled the 1,650squarefoot house to be brought in for less than $40,000 two years agofurnished.

title: North Broadway Takes Handicap at Aqueduct
Carol Kestnbaum Bride
description: The marriage of Miss Carol Ruth Kestnbaum to Peter K. Scott, both of Arlington, Va., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride. Magistrate Willard Pierce of Arlington County performed the ceremony. The couple are lawyers in the office of the chief counsel of the Internal Revenue Service in Washington. Mrs. Scott is a daughter of Mrs. Edward Kestnbaum of New York and the late Mr. Kestnbaum. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Scott of Tulsa, Okla.

title: Calendar of Horse Shows
description: Today Middlesex County, Johnson Park, New Brunswick, N.J., Regular, green and amateurowner hunters; preliminary and junior jumpers, Johnson Park Jumper Special, fine harness, parade, Arabians, Morgans, threegaited, fivegaited, equitation in hunter and saddle seat. 9 A.M.

title: Preview Scheduled For Operation Sail
description: SANDY HOOKA preview of Operation Sail, which is expected to be one of the most picturesque events of the 1976 bicentennial celebration, will take place this week.

title: The Nation
description: The Supreme Court, in effect, has conceded the failure of its repeated attempts to write a definition of obscenity precise enough to be applied by lawenforcement officials and lower courts with a minimum of appeals.

title: Animals in Art Are Being Displayed in Queens
description: A dragon may be benign or malevolent, depending on whether his heritage is Eastern or Western. To a European a frog was once a magical, medicinal creature; to an ancient Egyptian, it was the goddess of water. To a person in medieval Europe a pair of stags might have represented some of the world's gentlest,, wisest animals, while to a person in the Southwestern Caspian region in the 12th or 11th century B.C., they might have been religious objects.

title: Savoir Wins $50,000 Trot At Roosevelt
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 29 Savoir, the world's most affluent active trotter kept prominently placed throughout by his driver, Jimmy Arthur, was the comfortable winner of the $50,000 American Trotting Championship at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: World News Briefs
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 29 (AP)The Soviet Union has given its support to a proposed 200mile offshore economic limit so long as navigation through international straits is not restricted.

title: A Complex Love Story Reduced to a Flirtatious Sexual Battle
description: YOU can almost judge a film director by the magazine that puts him on its cover. The track record is too good for mere coincidence: Frank Capra, Hollywood's favorite Depression Pollyanna populist, earned a Time portrait in the 1930's (Orson Welles and John Huston couldn't cut Mr. Luce's mustard later on.) Stanley Kubrick made the cover of Saturday Review just at the time his work turned from supple satire to sour pseudophilosophies.

title: A Sailor in Bermuda Race Logs His Labor of Love
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 29The restaurants, bars and yacht clubs of this beautiful island are still filled with yachting chatter following the 635mile race from Newport to Bermuda. The tales range from fighting heavy seas and bucking the powerful Gulf Stream to drifting in a becalming lull and searching in the darkness for wind.

title: Miss Zinn Is Bride Of John R. Prouty
description: The marriage of Miss Deborah Ann Zinn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Harrison Zinn Jr., of Old Greenwich, Conn., to John Ryan Prouty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Reginald Prouty of Katonah, N. Y., took place yesterday afternon.

title: State U. Aids School Science
description: HAUPPAUGE  Thousands of junior high school science students on Long Island have been receiving stimulation from intellectual sparks generated by the department of physics of the State University at Stony Brook.

title: 10Cent Subway Fare In Newark to Continue
description: NEWARK, June 29 (AP)The successful reducedfare experiment on the Newark subway system, scheduled to end yesterday, has been extended through Aug. 30, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today.

title: Dissenters in Latin Nations Swept Aside as Intolerance and Repression Grow
description: BUENOS AIRESPolitical intolerance and the repression of political dissent have grown in the last few years in several LatinAmerican nations.

title: News Summary and Index
Through Katmandu With a 13YearOld Hustler Named Harry
description: TRAVELERS learn to spot the junior con men who lurk outside tourist hotels. So when the boy fell into step beside me in Katmandu, the ancient templestudded capital of Nepal, I automatically increased my pace. A slight 13yearold in Tshirt and jeans, with a shock of black hair and a tentative smile, he trotted to keep up with me. Hello, how you?

title: The Mood in the Capital
description: WASHINGTONThe capital is loitering along these days in an almosphere of fatigue, restlessness, frustratan and recrimination. It is not composing its differences but polarizing its politics and skirmishing ineffeetively on a dozen fronts at the same time.

title: PALESTINIAN TOLL IN CLASH PUT AT 20
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29As many as 20 people are reported to have been killed and 17 wounded in yesterday's clashes between rival Palestinian guerrilla factions in refugee camps in Lebanon.

title: World Cup Play to Resume at 4 Sites
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 29The second round of soccer's World Cup will continue with four matches in four cities tomorrow, and the winners of the first matches in the round, Poland, West Germany, Brazil and the Netherlands, are expected to triumph again.

title: ...And Watching Them Spread
description: LONDONFrance will sell five nuclear reactors to Iran and the United States may supply another. Hardly alarming news by itself: the list of countries with power reactors is long already. But it follows both India's first nuclear explosion and a remark attributedrightly or wronglyto the Shah about nuclear weapons for Iran.

title: A G.I.'s Vietnam Diary
description: Mortar rounds explode outside. His shoulder is sore and scarred from shrapnel, he is crazed with fear and confused about his feelings for the girl back home. When 21yearold Dominick Yezzo naively records in his Vietnam Diary that he can't grasp everything in Hemingway's, The Sun Also Rises, the irony is unintended, but effective.

title: In Queens, a Graffiti GoodBy Party
description: They're taking it off, a lanky, jeanclad youth said yesterday in Public School 147, where 200 Cambria Heights, Queens, residents had assembled to scrub off graffiti. But I'm going to put it right back up again.

title: There Are New Laws, and the Idea of Medicine Is Changing
description: The classic picture of the American doctor might have been by Norman Rockwella kindly man sitting through the country night by the bedside of a sick child. Today, such a picture is all but an anachronism. Surveys have shown that most physicians have fled the countryside for the affluent suburbs, that they drive Cadillacs instead of buggies and that sick children are more likely to be treated ever the phone or tended to in hospitals by foreign house staff.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: My Summer Vacation: The Boy Speaks to the Man Over a 40Year Gulf
description: THE chattering of the birds wakens me, as it usually does when I sleep late. It's a lovely, warm morning. I take my time about getting up.

title: Bombing Forced on Youth
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 29 (UPI)Gunmen kidnapped a teenage girl early today and forced her boyfriend to plant a 200pound car bomb in exchange for her life. The bomb caused extensive damage in the town of Kilrea, 60 miles west of here, but no casualties.

title: Preparing for a literary life
description: The town of Malgudi, which does not appear anywhere in the authoritative volume, Murray's Handbook to India, is the creation of India's bestknown Englishlanguage novelist, R. K. Narayan. In 10 novels Mr. Narayan has described in detail the complexity of the place, from the features of landscape and the weather, to the various buildings  the school, the station  and all the classes and castes, the plotters and pundits, right down to the municipal sweepers. The foundations of Malgudi were laid in pure idleness, in that mood of apprehension every writer knows as the beginning of a kind of uneasy apprenticeship to an unformed idea.

title: Music
description: IT is 7:50 P.M. at the Metropolitan Opera House, and the handsome soldier (a dragoon) is buttoning himself up. There are about 10 buttons around the trapdoor in his breeches and 21 knobby metal buttons down the front of his jacket. The dragoon works steadily, onehanding button after button into their little elastic loops. He must hurry. Over the public address system a voice is telling everybody backstage that this evening's Carmen, part of the Met's June Festival, will begin in 10 minutes. En garde, soldiers, he announces. Several dragoons plod across the dressing room. Once again, it's time to go out there on stage and date the cigarette girls.

title: Dacca Is Disappointed in Pakistani's Visit
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, June 29 Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan returned home today, ending a threeday mission of reconciliation to Bangladesh. But Bengali officials expressed disappointment with the results of the visit.

title: Susan Cochrane Wed
description: Miss Susan Blackburne Cochrane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Campbell Cochrane of Brightwaters, L. T., and Edwin Frederick Heinen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Heinen, also of Brightwaters, were married at noon yesterday in St. Peter's bytheSea Episcopal Church in Bay Shore, L.I. The rector, the Rev. Donald S. McPhail, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Revs. Edmund. Bosch and Alan Edministon.

title: Geriatric Center Offers New Plan
description: A geriatric center in Brooklyn, which will stress a rehabilitation plan in which the elderly will be returned to their homes in the community, will be dedicated today.

title: HENRY M. LESTER, PHOTO EXPERT, 75
description: Henry M. Lester, a scientific and industrial photographer and a photographic publisher and inventor, died yesterday in University Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 270 West End Avenue.

title: Museum Evokes History of Old Morris Canal
description: LAKE HOPATCONG  A fisherman's brainstorm here 150 years ago led to the Legislature's chartering New Jersey's oldest and longest canal, the creation of the slate's largest single lake and, eventually, a museum that reflects the history of the waterway.

title: New Novel
description: By Gwen Davis. 540 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $8.95.

title: SAWHILL DECLARES BIG CONCERNS BALK OILSHARING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 29In his first general criticism of the oil industry, the Federal Energy Administrator, John C. Sawhill, accused 15 major companies today of footdragging and calculated resistance to the Government's plan for the major companies to share their relatively cheap crude oil supplies with independent refiners.

title: New Jersey
description: THEATER

title: Drew Scholar, 86, Is Retiring Again
description: MADISON  America's dean of Renaissance scholars, Allan H. Gilbert, an athletic, 86yearold author of 15 books, retired last month from the Drew University faculty, his second retirement in 17 years.

title: The Track Loses, Too, When Trotting Returns To Its Home in Goshen
description: Tomorrow, Historic Track in Goshen, N. Y., will begin its annual week of Grand Circuit harness racing. The track traces its history back to 1838, when trotters were still raced to saddle. In this article, E. Roland Harriman of Arden, N. Y., near Goshen, reflects on his long association with the sport as an owner, driver and administrator. Harriman owns the track and is the president of the Hall of Fame of the Trotter.

title: Expansion of Adult Education Predicted by State U. Officials
description: The presidents of two mayor state educational institutions on Long Island, after being reappointed last week to new fiveyear terms, asserted that the trend in university education would be increasingly in the direction of adult education and that, predictions to the contrary, enrollment in Long Island schools would soar to a new high within the next ??.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: News of the Screen
description: The grim, complex and bloody history of the rivalries in the United Mine Workers union exposed by the murders of the reformist mine leader Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter, will be dramatized in a feature to be produced independently by Harrison Starr, Jules V. Schwerin and Iris Sawyer. The film will be adapted from two books acquired by the threeDeath and the Mines: Rebellion and Murder in the U.M.W. by A. Britten Hume, published in 1971 by Grossman, and Act of Vengeance, which Trevor Armbrister is currently completing for publication by the Saturday Review Press.

title: Foyt, Rutherford and Bobby Unser Head Auto Racing Field Today
description: LONG POND, Pa., June 29 The eyes not only of Texas but of the whole autoracing community are on A. J. (Super Tex) Foyt, who will be muscling his way tomorrow ??rough what he calls a bunch of idiots in the United States Auto Club's third and last 500mile race of the season.

title: Ideas & Trends Education, Astrophysics, Religion
description: The fifth Islamic Conference of Foreign Ministers that concluded in Kuala Lumpur last week was more than just a demonstration that over 500 million people in North Africa, the Middle East and South Asia are bound by sentiments loyalty to a shared faith. The fact that its declarations were predominantly political indicates the degree to which religion and politics are integrated in the Moslem world.

title: Khrushchev Remembers
description: This is the second volume of the Khrushchev memoirs. The first volume raised the question of the authenticity of the burbling torrent of often inaccurate, often distorted, often bombastic but almost always revealing reminiscences purportedly by the onetime Soviet leader. It also countered that question of authenticitypositively. As I said then in the Book Review: First things first. This is Nikita S. Khrushchev speaking.

title: Slippage
description: The White House strategy of obstruction and delay has successfully blurred the national focus on impeachment. Hard issues are slipping away, not because the facts have changed nor have the charges been refuted, but because doubts have been sown about the fairness of the process. An equally subtle campaign has been mounted to persuade the American public that to pursue the case of Richard M. Nixon is to weaken the Presidency and the nation.

title: Decisions, decisions, decisions
description: A longing to be able to predict and, best of all, select the sex of offspring has given rise since ancient times to a rich variety of folklore prescriptions. They range from the Hebrew Talmud suggestion that placing the marriage bed in a northsouth direction favors the conception of boys and the advice of the Greek philosopher Parmenides in the fifth century B.C. that wives wishing boys should lie on their right side after intercourse to tae practice, still current among husbands in Germany's Spessart mountains, of taking an ax along to bed to produce male progeny and leaving it in the woodshed when they wish girls.

title: Rocket Tests Begin On Virginia Coast After Many Delays
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., June 29 (AP)One rocket launched tonight by the nation's space agency spread clouds of colorful chemicalsc n the skies over some of the East Coast, but second shot failed when the missile malfunctioned and tumbled in flames into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Headliners
description: In the name of the last prophet, I say toba (sorry) to you. With these words, Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto of Pakistan last week asked forgiveness from the Bengali people for atrocities committed by the Pakistani Army during the Bangladesh struggle for independence. Mr. Bhutto arrived in Bangladesh to seek reconciliation between his country and its severed province.

title: What the Rodino Committee Has Been Seeking
description: WASHINGTONThe House Judiciary Committee has subpoenaed President Nixon eight times now, seven times asking for White House tapes and once for diaries. The committee has received nothing from Mr. Nixon that it has demanded.

title: A Whitney Who Shuns Glamour for a Life of Quiet Satisfaction
description: The building has never made any of the most prestigious lists, and the apartment is a model for nothing but living comfortably. The paintings on the wall are the only signs of distinction and they are personal, creative expressions.

title: Aid for Minorities Backed in Report To Jewish Groups
description: Jewish community relations agencies have indicated they will join in a cooperative effort with black and Chicano groups in supporting affirmative action policies that advance educational and employment opportunities among minorities.

title: Anderson Quits Hospital
description: CINCINNATI (UPI)  The Cincinnati Reds' manager, Sparky Anderson, was released from Christ Hospital today after undergoing treatment for a stiff neck and hack pain. Anderson left the team during a series in Houston on Tuesday to return here for treatment.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Luring Bass
description: JEFFERSON, Me.  He came up out of the dark water at the edge of the rocky shallows and engulfed my yellow flyrod popping bug.

title: Met Junior Mile, 3Mile To McCarey
description: Kevin McCarey, a Villanova sophomore who missed the crosscountry and indoor seasons because of mononucleosis, came to Downing Stadium yesterday for the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior track and field championships intending to get a good workout.

title: Bettors Up in Arms Over New OTB Tax
description: In the crowded offtrack betting parlor at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, an elderly, toothless man, warned, This place will be like a morgue Monday with the new surcharge. He had just placed a $2 bet on the fifth race at Aqueduct.

title: Extra Land Pleases, Scares Wyckoff
description: WYCKOFF  Most residents of this Bergen County township would seriously oppose anyone who attempted to change the quiet pace of their community. Wyckoff is a closely knit, affluent and very suburban town, one that many of its inhabitants. contend has grown too much already. We're growing too fast, said Mrs. Richard Turner. I think the town has tripled in size since I moved here 27 years ago. We used to be small and cooperative, and little by little we seem Co be outgrowing that. If we even slightly lose our sense of community, it's time to stop growing.

title: A Character Named Berra
description: In the summer of 1947 a visitor in Yankee Stadium sat in the home dugout between Bucky Harris, the manager, and Al Schacht, the pitcherturnedclown. A thickset player clumped past them to the water cooler and Schacht's elbow nudged the visitor's right ribs. A character, Al said. The player clumped past on the way back to his seat and Harris nudged the visitor's left side. A character, the manager said. The player was a rookie right fielder named Larry Berra. As far as the visitor could see, he had done nothing more eccentric than take a drink of water, but Harris and Schacht were authorities whose verdict had to he respected. Lawrence Peter Berra was a character.

title: The Crimson Tide Captures Jump
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 29  The Crimson Tide, a 5yearold chestnut gelding with a minimum of experience, won the preliminary jumper class today at the Middlesex County horse show and raised questions about his name.

title: Jacqueline Kibbee Bride of Neil Crouse
description: Miss Jacqueline Ann Kibbee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Kibbee, was married yesterday afternoon to Neil I. Crouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clebron Crouse of Three Mile Bay, N. Y. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Chapel of SS. Faith, Hope and Charity by the Rev. Simeon Gardner.

title: Inside the Wedding Palaces
description: For the large catering houses that specialize in weddings, the last day of June is a welcome finale to the most hectic time of their year.

title: Intrepid Gives Courageous First Losses
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 29Intrepid, the 7yearold wood hulled yacht that has defended the America's Cup twice, snapped Courageous's undefeated record by beating the new aluminum yacht twice today as the preliminary selection trials ended.

title: Contract Offer to Be Discussed By Hospital Workers' Assembly
description: The 1,000member delegate assembly of District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employes will meet tonight at the Commodore Hotel to take action on a new contract awarded by arbitrators Friday night to 35,000 workers in 52 voluntary hospitals and nursing homes in the city.

title: Zumwalt, Retiring, Says Navy Supremacy Is Lost
description: ANNOPOLIS, Md., June 29 (AP)Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., winding up a frequently controversial stint as Chief of Naval Operations, said today that the United States had lost its supremacy at sea.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONOver the last few weeks, Governor Byrne has been stumping the state almost daily in behalf of his taxreform program. At the same time, his opponents have been equally busy, including sending one organization after another to lobby against the Governor's program before a Legislature that seems eager to listen to their arguments.

title: Speculator Plies His Trade and Cashes In
description: A garden apartment development on Staten Island that had been for sale for a year has found a new owner after passing through the hands of two potential purchasers within two months.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Are there some political motives mixed in with the economic ones in President Nixon's decision to crack down hard on Federal spending, in the new fiscal year beginning tomorrow?

title: The Mask Of State
description: During a recent visit to Washington, I found that a reference to Charles Colson's religious conversion guaranteed a laugh from the grimmest gathering of political sophisticates. It was sure to touch off an instant competition of Buchwaldstyle oneliners, tinged, nevertheless, by a slight underglow of professional appreciation for what appears to me a supreme con. I was not surprised, even though my daily journey through three newspapersan addict's cursehad revealed in elaborate detail the precise manner and timing of this onset of gracethe slow agony of preparation, tears shed and mingled, the joy of resolution that bestows inner tranquility before the remorseless strokes of judgment. My President, this is why I must desert thee.

title: Fashion
description: 1. Classic Spanish espadrille is twotoned brown and orange canvas. $5. Casa Moneo, 210 West 14th St.

title: Seton Hall to Open Art Gallery in Fall
description: SOUTH ORANGE  Seton Hall University will open a new art gallery in the fall. Converted from an 1887 carriage house near the northern end of the campus, the gallery will be named the Father Monella Art Center, in honor of the late Rev. Vincent Monella. He was founder of the Center for Italian Culture of South Orange.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayUSAC Schaefer 500 at Pocono International Raceway, Long Popd, Pa., 1 P.M.

title: Shakespeare Fete Aids Apprentices
description: MADISONThe New Jersey Shakespeare Festival at Drew University is well known as the state's only professional repertory company. Less well known is the fact that it operates one of the country's outstanding apprenticeship programs for aspiring actors and actresses.

title: What They Are Saying
description: John Holt, the vice chairman of the AllEngland Club, which runs the Wimbledon Tennis tournament, defends the policy of permitting the players to wear allwhite clothing only: It's a matter the players' sweat, you see. It looks rather ghastly on television  a player's colored shirt wrung through with sweat. The public has indicated they don't like it.

title: Detente, With Caution
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nixon is in the Soviet Unionto furtherthe cause of dtente. There should be no one in Washington who does not wish him success. But at the same time that we work for the lessening of tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union, we must continue to watch not just the rhetoric but also the realities of United StatesSoviet relations.

title: Jean Buist Is Bride of Jeffrey R. Algatt
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Newton, N. J., yesterday afternoon, Miss Jean Morford Buist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richardson Buist of Sparta and Vernon, N. J., became the bride of Jeffrey Raymond Algatt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond A. Algatt of Bloomsburg, Pa.

title: Technicality Stalls Landmark Plan
description: A group of residents of the Newtown section of Queens is trying to have a preRevolutionary cemetery declared a city landmark, but no one knows who owns the property.

title: Stars Lose Scrimmage
description: GLASSBORO, N.J., June 29 (UPI)The Philadelphia Bell of the World Football League held off a fourthperiod rally by the New York Stars tonight to take scrimmaze 2422.

title: 1:58 Mile at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRING, N. Y., June 29The fastest 3yearold pace of the year in North America occurred at Saratoga tonight when Mirror Image posted a time of 1:58 in the $2,5,000 Harold Haswell Memorial.

title: Wooing the Pension Funds
description: Pension fund managers, sitting on top of the fastestrising mountain of investment capital in the country, are being wooed from all sides, now that they have soured on the stock market.

title: Kelley Is Promoted
description: HARTFORD, June 29 (AP) Jack Kelley, the New England Whaler general manager, was named the World Hockey League's club's executive vice president today.

title: Summit Vignettes: A Hush Descends On Littered Moscow Press Center
description: MOSCOW, June 29  A hush has descended on the third floor of the Intourist Hotel on Gorky Street, where the Moscow press center for President Nixon's summit visit has been set up.

title: Carina, Doberman, Gains 16th Best at Upstate Show
description: GREENE, N. Y., June 29In a sylvan setting in this village named for a Revolutionary War hero, Gen. Nathaniel Greene, a Doberman pinscher, Oh. Galaxy's Corry Carina, was named best in show at the Chenango Valley Kennel Club fixture. The elegant blackandtan trotted across the rainsoaked turf of Buck Jones Memorial Field along the banks of the Chenango River to catch the eye of William Kendrick.

title: The Ballet
description: An unusual number of debuts in major roles provided a special interest in the New York City Ballet's performance Friday night of George Balanchine's A Midsummer Night's Dream at the State Theater.

title: English Prince Captures $250,000 Irish Derby
description: DUBLIN, June 29 (AP)English Prince and Imperial Prince made today a grand day for the Williams family at Ireland's Curragh racecourse by running one, two in the $250,000 Irish Sweeps Derby.

title: Stengel Hogs Stage At OldTimers Day
description: He rode in from center field in a green and yellow stagecoach, then spent the entire OldTimers' Game doing what he does best talking.

title: City Seeks 52 Acres of Creedmoor Land
description: Under a proposal being advanced by the City Planning Commission and the Parks Department, 52 acres of land adjacent to Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens would be converted into a horticultural center and a neighborhood recreational facility.

title: Track Stars in Meet
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 29The feature of the Rochester Institute of Technology invitation track meet tomorrow will be appearances by Ivory Crockett, the world recordholder, in the 100yard dash and Marty Liguori and Dick Buerkle in the mile. Events begin at 1 P.M.

title: Subway Venders Going
description: Vending machines will begin disappearing tomorrow from the city's subway platforms, and it is uncertain whether they will ever be replaced. Page 19.

title: V.F.W. Denies Auxiliary Presidency To a Woman Sympathetic to Amnesty
description: An elementary school teacher from Johnstown, N. Y., who expressed sympathy for granting amnesty to Vietnam draft resisters was barred yesterday from taking office as president of the state Veterans of Foreign War Ladies Auxiliary.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: Daily Border Crossings by West Germans Decline
description: ROTTENBACH, West GermanyWest Germans living along the border with East Germany are showing dwindling interest in taking advantage of the bordercrossing privileges negotiated last July.

title: Fieldsboro Hopeful on Sewers
description: FIELDSBOROFour weeks ago, Mayor Leonard Lehman and four of the six Councilmen in this Burlington County borough of 680 residents quit their posts because they could not get aid to build a sewer system.

title: Bradley's First Year
description: Tom Bradley, the first black Mayor of Los Angeles, marks his first anniversary in office tomorrow with wide, although not universal, acclaim for what is looked upon in the nation's thirdlargest city as a bravura performance. Page 26.

title: Loosening Restraints on Capital Markets
description: The Securities and Ex, change Commission must play a more constructive role in the solutions of the major problems of Wall Street the poor financial condition of the industry and its diminishing ability to raise the capital needed for economic expansion.

title: BLACK TERRORISM SEEN IN 2 DEATHS
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 29The murder of two white teenagers by a group calling itself the Black Liberation Army, and the reported abduction of three other young white men, appear to be part of an organizational and terrorist campaign being conducted by black fanatics in this city, according to the police and other sources.

title: Hovey Freeman Jr. Weds Miss Graham
description: Miss Evelyn Byrd Graham and Hovey Thomas Freeman Jr., were married yesterday afternoon in Christ. Episcopal Church in Sackets Harbor, N.Y., by the Rev. Elliott F. Metcalf.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THEY called him a crackpot and a prophet of doom. Now they just call him a prophet of doom, the young man said happily as he slipped into his seat in Carnegie Hall Thursday night to hear a lecture by Harry, Browne on the investment, implications of the end of the world. Mr. Browne's advice is to buy gold for safety, silver for profits, Swiss francs or maybe Dutch guilders for liquidity and a gun for protection.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: A Kicky Caress From Blossom
description: In contemporary popular music, whether rock, soul, or middle of the road, you sing the hell out of a song or you don't get any attention. If you want your record on the charts baby, it's best to be a leatherlunged, stridentvoiced salesman.

title: On the 7:21, The Stakes Are High For Poker
description: Even the conductor had to pause the other morning on the 7:21 from Port Jefferson when the pot was well over $100 and one of the pokerplaying commuters broke a $50 bill to keep his hand alive.

title: Kathleen Cross Married
description: Miss Kathleen Anne Cross and John Nicholas Blackman Jr., graduates of Westminster College of Pennsylvania, were married last evening in the chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence MacColl Horton performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. William Leslie Cross Jr. of Butler, Pa. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Blackman of Darien.

title: Sunday Observer
description: We are going to celebrate revolution again this week. It has become a curious rite, this annual 4th of July bow to bloody upheaval, for most of us are ill at ease with Washington, Adams and Jefferson, are only slightly less Tory than Lord North and pay huge tax bills each year to suppress revolutionary movements around the earth.

title: World at Midyear: Inflation Epidemic
description: MILAN, Italy Midway through this troubled year, which has already witnessed the worst worldwide inflation in history, a foreboding atmosphere has built up in the international business community.

title: Debating The Big Weapons...
description: Although the meeting between President Nixon and Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev is not expected to lead to a dramatic second agreement on nuclear arms limitationsthe Soviet and American positions are so far apart that they provide no area for brokerage on SALT IIit will still be possible to define an area in which negotiations can continue however difficult.

title: WATERGATE PANE TO EXPIRE TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 After a hectic lifetime of 20 months, during which it moved from the Washington wings to center stage and back to the wings again, the Senate Watergate committee will officially pass out of existence tomorrow.

title: Mrs. Jurmain Has Son
description: A son was born June 11 to Dr. and Mrs. Richard Bruce Jurmain at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital in Los Angeles. The child has been named David Arthur. Mrs. Jurmain is the former Miss Suzanne Enders Tripp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Tripp of New York.

title: CITY REVISES RULE ON FOSTER SHIFTS
description: For four years, Madeline Smith, a widow, has been caring for two foster children, now 8 and 6 years old. They call her Mommy and she has wanted to adopt them.

title: Strike at Midnight Confronts N.F.L.
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI)The National Football League, already challenged by a rival new league, is confronted with a players' strike of major dimensions Monday that could wreck the preseason schedule.

title: U.S. Defeats Russians In Junior Track Meet
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 29. (AP)The United States team, showing surprising strength in the field events and the distance runs, scored climactic milerelay victories over the Soviet Union team tonight to win the junior track and field meet between the two countries.

title: Letters
description: Gremlins in the chowder

title: Dance: Two Pigeons
description: LONDON, June 29  It is often maintained that Britain's Royal Ballet dances better at New York's Metropolitan Opera House than at its own London home at Covent Garden. Such a theory was given some substance by a performance this week of Sir Frederick Ashton's The Two Pigeons, which was one of suprising mediocrity. One would scarcely have guessed that this was the same company New York had cheered only last month.

title: Edith McKee Rockefeller Is Married
description: Miss Edith McKee Rockefeller and Edwin C. Laird 3d were married yesterday afternoon in Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y.

title: Strategic Arms Limitation Talks find the superpowers still yearning for unthinkable weapons to preserve Mutual Assured Destruction
description: Further progress in strategic arms limitation is perhaps the most important issue on the agenda for the current NixonBrezhnev summit meeting. In fact, the Moscow talks could be the culmination of the second round of arms negotiations referred to as SALT H. Yet Secretary of State Henry Kissinger has cautioned that the summit would not result in any comprehensive strategic arms limitation agreements, and that only agreements in a more limited sphere are possible.

title: Paula Kalayski Married to Skater
description: St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge, Mass., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Miss Paula Jean Kalayski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul. Zachary Kalayski of Bel Air, Md., to John Misha Petkevich, 1971 United States men's figureskating champion.

title: Yank Games This Week
description: TodayAt Baltimore. TomorrowAt Detroit, night. TuesdayAt Detroit, night. WednesdayAt Detroit, night. ThursdayAt Detroit, twilight. FridayAt Texas, night. SaturdayAt Texas, night.

title: Music for Playing as Well as for Pondering
description: THERE has for years been a saying that musicologists don't know enough about performance and performers don't know enough about musicology. It is, like such generalizations, a halt truth. A great many people in either area know what their counterparts are doing. But it does point to the fact that many universities, particularly those in the Ivy League, have music departments that frown on involvement in the teaching of performance. (Yale has a school of music, in addition to its department, which teaches performance.) They are concerned with thinking about music and not in bringing music to life. Performance, in an extreme analogy, becomes a question of dirtying one's hands, like a theoretical scientist working in a laboratory.

title: History of Queens Village
description: Vincent F. Seyfried is a high school English teacher with a love of history, a flair for writing, and the patience to put the two together. The result: A new book entitled The Story of Queens Village.

title: Linda Solari, Neill D. Reilly Marry on L.I.
description: Miss Linda Marie Solari, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Solari of Manhasset, L. I., and Neill Daniel Reilly, son of Mr: and Mrs. Thomas Reilly, also of Manhasset, were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Joseph Sweeney in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: Tenants Resisting Coop Conversion
description: FORT LEERentleveling ordinances in many New Jersey communities are forcing apartmenthouse owners to attempt to convert their buildings into cooperatives. In the absence of protective legislation, these attempts have led not only to eviction actions against those tenants who decline to buy apartments but also a move in the State Legislature to adopt regulations already in effect in New York.

title: F.H.A. Loan Case Nears Completion
description: Last week's convictions in Vie Federal Housing AdminisRation insurance scandal wore welcomed by Housing And Urban Development Administration spokesmen as a deterrent to realestate Swindlers who might attempt to take advantage of the poor.

title: Littleton Mayo Brodie Marries Anne Willis
description: Miss Anne Elizabeth Willis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Melville Willis of Richmond, was married here yesterday afternoon to Littleton Mayo Brodie, an investor of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The 55member police force of Garden City, L.I., which has been working without a contract for more than a year, reached a settlement Friday night with the village administration.

title: 3 Offshore Sites Rate High as Oil Source
description: TRENTONWhile oil interests await a decision from Washington concerning leases for offshore drilling, there are increasing signs that three possible sites off New Jersey may be among the first to be considered.

title: Janice Vernier Becomes Bride
description: Miss Janice Claire Vernier, daughter of Carlton Pietre Vernier of Auburn, N. Y., and Quonchontaug, R. L, and the late Mrs. Lucy Messner Vernier, was married yesterday afternoon to Halsted Sartorious Vander Poel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Vander Poel of Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: A Cultural Assist in Freeport
description: FREEPORT  The Freeport Village Board of Trustees and the Board of Education have jointly formed a Freeport Arts Council, which will spend $50,000 in 197475 to bring a threepart cultural program to both school children and the community atlarge.

title: The Marais: Art, Elegance, Pickles, Poverty  and a Festival
description: FIVE elderly women huddled under tattered black umbrellas on the steps of St. Paul in Paris. They were waiting for a tour guide named Max. Even before he rounded the corner, they heard his cane tapping along the sidewalk and began to twitter in anticipation. After a de rigueur Comment allezvous? he led them down the treacherously narrow Rue du Prevt, past the FrancoYugoslav cafe and the kosher butcher shop, into a building on Rue Ave Maria. Next to the sootcovered garbage cans in the entry a bum tipped his beret with derisive grin. The women stiffened, and a longsuffering look of Anything for Art sprinted across their faces.

title: Matlack's OneHitter Stops Cards, 4 to 0
description: If Jon Matlack had a vote, he might approve of the introduction of the designated hitter into the National League.

title: Mailbag
description: (Stanley Milgram, a professor of psychology at City University of New York, Etas conducted experiments which conclude that the most heinous acts would he committed by the average person in situations of normal obedience to authority. Milgram's experiments were recently described on the CBSTV show Sixty Minutes and then commented on in these pages by Daniel Bell, the Harvard sociologist. Dr. Bell questioned whether the subjects of the Milgram experiments were morally responsible: for their acts since they lacked any recourse to independent inquiry and had no alternative but to accept the word of more technically knowledgeable supervisors. The following letters from readers were prompted by Dr. Bell's article.)

title: Peter Allen Weds Deborah B. Winsor
description: Miss Deborah Baker Winsor, daughter of Mrs. Julian H. Richardson of Beverly Farms, Mass., and Woodstock, Vt., and the late Robert Winsor, was married yesterday afternoon, to Peter Flanders Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Allen of Dover, Mass. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms, Mass., by the Rev. Russell Dewart.

title: AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Mary S. Fearey And S. H. Hollis Have Nuptials
description: Miss Mary Senior Fearey 2d, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Fearey of New York and Edgartown, Mass., was married at noon yesterday to Stuart Holman Lollis, son of Maj. Gen. Shelton E. Lollis, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Lollis of Orchard Lake, Mich.

title: Letters: The Classic Roller Coaster Rides
description: To the Editor: Robert Cartmell's piece The Quest for the Ultimate Roller Coaster (Travel Section, June 9), was a delight and made me pine for the dear dead days at Chicago's Riverview Park. The Bobs was truly a classic machine and just one of the many roller coasters at Riverview calculated to appeal to varying degrees of foolhardiness. I remember a pleasant if subdued ride called the Greyhound and another whose name escapes me that was equipped with flat cars in which one reclined while being whisked in comparative silence (it had rubber wheels) through an almostenclosed tubelike run. But the real favorite was the Fireball, a monstrous device that plunged down the first hill at speeds purporting to top. 100 miles per hour and then went into a vicious bank through a tunnel that made one feel sure decapitation was just ahead. The line between excitement and terror was deliciously, exquisitely ephemeral; we loved nothing better.

title: Shop That Caters To the Gourmets
description: PARAMUS  It takes only 80 minutes or less, not 80 days, for the food fancier to go around the world in the gourmet section at Stern's Department Store.

title: U.S. Assures the Israelis Of New Weapons If Needed
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The United States has assured Israel that it will provide her with a new generation of fighterbombers if necessary to help modernize the Israeli Air Force Administration officials sali yesterday.

title: Trade, Dtente . . .
description: The evolving accommodation between the United States and the Soviet Union reflected in the NixonBrezhnev summit meeting in Moscow has taken both countries a goodly distance from their starting point in January 1971, when Mr. Nixon wrote his first personal letter as President to the Soviet leader. But it would be an error to forget the fundamental transaction that initiated this era of negotiation between the two superpowers and helped shape the Kremlin foreign policy that was announced, along with a new FiveYear Plan for the economy, at the Soviet Communist party Congress in March of that year.

title: Leslie Perry Bride Of Robert P. Blank
description: Miss Leslie Christina Perry, daughter of Mrs. John R. Perry of Weymouth, Mass., and the late Mr. Perry, was married there yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception to Robert Philip Blank of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Blank of New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: Dov Cohen Fiance Of Susan Newman
description: Miss Susan Newman and Dov Cohen plan to be married this autumn. Their engagement has been announced by Alfred Newman, a retired cantor, and Mrs. Newman, parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Shragai Cohen, associate director of the Greater New York Committee of State of Israel Bonds, and Mrs. Cohen. Both families live in Brooklyn.

title: Stiff AntiObscenity Bill Is Signed in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, June 29 (UPI)Gov. Francis W. Sargent signed yesterday a controversial obscenity statute that imposes stiff fines and prison sentences for producing and distributing pornography.

title: S.E.C. at 40 Pushes Reform
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will be 40 years old tomorrow, and for some months now the staff of the commission have been acting as though they really believed the old bromidelife begins at 40.

title: Topless Ruling Upsets L.I. Town
description: Topless dancing is constitutional, according to a Federal appellate court decision handed down last week. But that does not make it acceptable to some North Hempstead Town officials and residents.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Finding a summer job is again proving difficult this year for some 2.3 million students and other young people who are seeking temporary employment.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Court Decides A Question Of Tenure

title: CITY SAID TO OWE STATE 50MILLION
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that because of the lack of a contract the city had failed to pay more than $50million to the state for physicians; services performed at the Kings County Medical Center for a fiveyear period that ended June 30, 1973.

title: The Region
description: New York State's strict new drug law, which has been in effect for 10 months, seems to have been tough on a few smalltime operators, but there is evidence that it has done little to impede narcotics traffic or to diminish the availability of hard drugs in the metropolitan area.

title: Weiskopf 5 Shots Up Witha 212
description: OAK BROOK, Ill., June 29 Tom Weiskopf had to birdie the last two holes to match par 71 today as he increased his lead to five shots after the third round of the $200,000 Western open.

title: Byrne Is Seen Firm on Tocks
description: TRENTONAlthough Governor Byrne's opposition to construction of the Tocks Island Dam is said to be temporary and conditional, highranking officials in his administration believe it is unlikely that the controversial project will be built during his term in office.

title: Dr. I. Edwin Goldwasser Dies; City Schools Official Was 95
description: I. Edwin Goldwasser, who had three major careers in this cityas an educator, an executive in philanthropy and as a business mandied yesterday at the Jewish Home and Hospital, 120 West 106th Street. He was 95 years old.

title: Lynches Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Lynch of New York on June 3 in the Lenox Hill Hospital. The child has been named John Curtis.

title: Marie House Kohler Is Bride Of Francis Cabot in Wisconsin
description: Miss Marie House Kohler, a greatgranddaughter of John M. Kohler, who founded the Kohler Company, manufacturers of plumbing supplies, was married Yesterday afternoon to Francis Colin Cabot, a grandson of the late George W. Perkins, who served as Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs under President Harry S. Truman.

title: A World War II Plane to Be Returned
description: A World War II Navy fighter plane that was born on Long Island and died some 32 years ago in the steamy jungles of Guadalcanal in the Solomon Islands is expected to return home soon.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: (STEPHEN) BARLAY: THE SECRETS BUSINESS  Bug peddlers ... a strange breed ... show symptoms of a desperate craving for respectability ... They like to talk about the simple pleasures of listening, and to brand even their most blatantly aggressive wares as weapons of selfdefense.

title: Jersey City Getting SixStory Hospital
description: JERSEY CITY  The St. Francis community Health Center will dedicate a new sixstory hospital here today.

title: Numismatics
description: RELATIVELY few in numbers but tireless in their activities, the fastbuck coin dealers have found, a new object for their attentions. Aided by all the current excitement about cent shortages, they have discovered a hitherto unknown rarity and are enthusiastically promoting it with all the old familiar comeons: Extremely limited supplies; By a fortunate purchase we have acquired just a few rolls (or bags) of these increasingly hardtoget coins; Of necessity our prices are subject to daytoday changes; We urgently advise you to order now while our supply lastswe don't know when if ever we will be able to replenish our stock; and so on and on the rare coins they are so generously offering to sellat a mere 12 to 15 times face value(i.e., $600 to $750 for a bag containing $50 worth of coins)is the 1974S penny. By unofficial estimate, several million of these coins have already been struck at the San Francisco branch mint. Such an estimate has to be unofficial, for the Bureau of the Mint's monthly production reports normally reveal only the total output of each coin from all minting facilities combined.

title: Cartoons: The World Seems Ready for Madness
description: CARTOONISTS defy mortality and the rule of reason. Lighting up the darkness of each day, some of the best cartoonists appear to have been around forever, and oneGeorge W. Boothseems finally to have arrived.

title: How to Play a Taller Rival
description: On a tennis court, just as on a basketball court, height counts. Big tennis players, without question, have a lot more going for them than small players. They have a longer reach in all directions and, since each player has the same amount of court to cover, that's a plus for them. They can stretch out farther to volley an attempted passing shot and leap higher to smash back a lob. They usually have an advantage in power, too, simply because they're bigger. And their height gives them more court to aim at on overheads and serves.

title: What the Thunder Said
description: WASHINGTONMuch illinformed and alarmist speculation has been touched off by the United States decision to sell nuclear power reactors to Egypt and Israel. This prompted talk of spreading the risk of atomic war in a notoriously dangerous area.

title: Ed who?
description: BAYTOWN, Tex. John Glenn is to Ed Gibson as Charles Lindbergh is to Joe Nobody, the zillionth guy to fly in a 707. Ed Gibson is one of three men who have done something no other human being in the history of the world has done his achievement is stupendous. He will go around for the rest of his life being, Ed Who?

title: 200 Are Reported Killed In Landslide in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 29 Officials estimated that at least 200 persons had been killed in a landslide that covered a section of highway about 95 miles east of Bogot on the road to Villavicencio.

title: Districts Fighting Busing Laud Regents' Plan to Review Policy
description: The four school districts presently under state integration orders yesterday applauded the State Board of Regents' decision to reevaluate New York's 14yearold policy favoring busing as a tool for integration.

title: Food
description: The most sophisticated meringues are those that are spread thin and baked in a slow oven until fragile and crisp, easily shattered with a fork. We have recently fallen heir to two marvelous recipesa Torta Cavour and a spirited pie in a meringue shell. The first is from an Italian pastry chef and the other from a firstrate cook and friend, Joe Famularo.

title: Dance
description: HAPPY is the land that doesn't have a history and, perhaps by the same token, happy is the land that doesn't have any folk dances. I don't mean the harmless little mummeries of sleepy English villages, or even the bottomslapping gusto and yodeling of Switzerland's pleasant peasants. I mean all those rough and tough Slavic folk dances, since so many of them seem to have arisen through days of war and years of occupation.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Public Sculpture in New York City: Lesser Art and Lost Ideals
description: THE conditions of modern city life are not conducive to a high appreciation of public sculpture. Public ceremonials are now occasions for irony rather than enthusiasm. The iconography of heroism, especially in its historical and military forms, no longer commands universal assent. Few pieties about our common life inspire any unanimity of feeling, and we lack, in any case, a common style for their expression. City lifethe entire life of our civilizationis now factional and fragmented, conducted for the most part in social or cultural enclaves upon which the outsider hesitates to trespass. A sculptor may now and then be invited to embellish a public space with a harmonious design, but we would never dream of requiring him to represent in recognizable detail an event of national importance. To the extent that the making of public sculpture continues among usand it does, of courseit does so as a purely esthetic activity. Its obligation to evoke something other than itseft is quite dead.

title: INDIA BIDS SIKKIM ADOPT NEW LAWS
description: NEW DELHI, June 29 (AP)Prime Minister Indira Gandhi pressed the ruler of Sikkim today to agree to an Indianwritten Constitution for his Himalayan kingdom and to seek reconciliation with his political opponents.

title: TEACHERS' GROUP TURNING MILITANT
description: CHICAGO, June 29  The increasingly activist complexion of the National Education Association is in evidence here as the oncestaid, 1.4millionmember teachers' organization prepares to begin its 112th annual convention.

title: Lieut. Paul Johnson Weds Amy E. Ryan
description: Miss Amy Elizabeth Ryan and Lieut. Paul J. Johnson, U.S.A., were married yesterday in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L.I. by the Rev Louis Aufiero.

title: Claire Swain Huntington Is Bride
description: Miss Claire Swain Huntington and Kimball Patrick McCloud, graduates of Stanford University were married at noon yesterday in Clenbrook, Nev. The Rev. C. Harold Van Zee performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Lake Tahoe summer home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Huntington of Los Angeles. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. McCloud of Piedmont, Calif., and Barilocat, Argentina.

title: Misses Greenwood, Cook Set Swim Meet Records
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., June 29 (AP)Two worldrecord holders, Heather Greenwood of Fresno, Calif., and Wendy Cook of Vancouver, British Columbia, broke meet records today in the second day of the eighth annual Santa Clara international invitation swimming and diving meet.

title: Safe Swimming Pool Slides
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission has announced that it will soon begin development of mandatory safety standards for swimming pool slides.

title: Vatican Has a Boom In Postal Business As Italy's Mail Lags
description: ROME, June 29 Vatican City, the center of the Roman Catholic Church, has been ministering to an increasing number of people in an unlikely capacitythrough its mail system, which seems to function more efficiently than Italy's.

title: Alison Webber Wed to George Muhlfeld
description: Miss Alison Jane Webber, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard John Webber of Minnetonka, Minn., was married yesterday afternoon to George Blakeslee Muhlfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bearss Muhlfeld of Englewood, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Henry Powers of the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly at the Muhlfeld home.
