description: General

title: SYDNEY B. CARPENDER
description: Sydney B. Carpender, vice president of the Carrier Corporation and president of its marine and international division from 1930 to 1934, died Friday at his home in Crystal Lake, Carbondale, Pa. He was 89 years old.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1LOU MYERS

title: Bonnie Schnapp Bride
description: Miss Bonnie Eileen Schnapp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Schnapp of New Rochelle, N. Y., and Alex Jay Keller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald H. Keller of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., were married yesterday evening in the Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle by Rabbi Samuel Schafler, a cousin of the bride. Mrs. Keller will become a faculty member at Grace Church School in September. Her husband is a student at the New York University Medical School.

title: Elaine Hall Fiancee Of Stephen Pearson
description: Miss Elaine Frances Hall, a senior at Wellesley College, and Stephen Dade Pearson, a senior at Harvard University, plan to be married July 20. Mr. and Mrs. Willard Bagnell Hall have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Pearson. Both families are of Miami.

title: 55Mile Limit Cuts Highway Fatalities, And Drivers Like It
description: The controversial 55mileanhour speed limit is making dramatic inroads in the nation's traffic toll, as well as winning public approval.

title: We should be celebrating the bicentennial now
description: Two hundred years ago, the 4th of July was a date which had no meaning whatsoever for Americans. The big celebration days were June 4, the birthday of the Father of the country, King George III, and Jan. 18, the birthday of his consort, homely, prolific Queen Charlotte. But Americans of 1774 did share one thing with Americans of 1974a state of profound political uneasiness. The turbulence began in the last month of 1773, when a group of Bostonians disguised as Mohawk Indians threw 342 chests of British East India Company tea worth 9,659 6s 4d into their harbor.

title: Miss Zunino Wed to P. P. Puschel
description: In the Carlyle yesterday evening, Miss Natalia Louise Zunino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Zunino Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., became the bride of Philip P. Puschel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Puschel of Riverside, Conn., and Vergennes, Vt.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To The Editor: It was thoughtful of you to label Carlos Fuentes for us (May 5). He does such a clever job of disguising his scholarship in the, review of Juan Goytisolo's Count Julian that I read the piece twice and then came upon your footnote setting forth his credentials: Fellow at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in Washington, D.C. Mirabile dictu!

title: After Chou Enlai, WhoAnd What?
description: Obviously ailing for the first time in recent years, Mr. Chou continues to insist, through his aides, that the main reason is his age. He thereby does what he can to repudiate speculation that he is suffering either from an unforeseen disease or from a political sickness, as so many China watchers in the outside world have assumed.

title: New Breed Newport Concert Suffers From Overamplification
description: Musicians whom the Newport Jazz Festival has elected to identify as the new breed are, with some exceptions, drowning in their own overamplification, if one is to judge by a concert yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall called The Music of the New Breed.

title: Queens Policeman Dies Trying to Still a Dispute
description: A 54yearold policeman celebrating his 24th anniversary on the force collapsed and died of a heart attack in Flushing, Queens, yesterday while trying to settle a dispute between a mother and her 19yearold daughter.

title: George Whelan, 59, Dies; Jersey City Police Deputy
description: JERSEY CITY, June 29 (UPI)  Deputy Police Chief George Whelan, died early today apparently of a heart attack suffered while on duty. He was 59 years old.

title: Chautauqua Lives!
description: YOU'VE heard of Chautauqua, of coursethat traveling tent show of lecturers who brought a touch of culture to smalltown America back in the days of the nickelodeon. You might even, given enough encouragement, recall that the tent show got its name from a kind of summer colony, up in southwestern New York, where old Aunt Mary spent her vacations. The associations are all pasttense.

title: Henley's Swans Make Way for Oars
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, June 29For 50 weeks of the year the River Thames, which flows through this tiny English town, is ruled by the swans. The swans in Henley belong to the Queen, giving them preogatives few humans enjoy. But for two weeks at regatta time, the Queen's swankeeper ceremoniously removes the birds from their realm to make way for oarsmen whose presence lifts this town from its idyllic isolation into the rowing capital of the world.

title: The Bow and the Lyre
description: Though this is not a new book (the first edition, in Spanish, appeared in Mexico in 1955), it is a book so timeless and so profound that it will always be new. The subtitles read: The Poem. The Poetic Revelation. Poetry and History, topics inexhaustible to thought, modified by the appearance of each new poet, forever provisional, and forever readdressed. These are solitary thinkings, such as dodge/Conception to the very bourne of heaven, appearing as aphorism, epigram and prophecy as well as exposition and argument. The torrent of Paz's writing claims assent by passion; the book has the indisputable truth of testimony, and whatever its serviceability as a generalized poetic, it is unquestionably one of the strongest and most eloquent diaries of the poetic process in our century. This book represents only a part, and that not the most recent part, of Paz's many writings on past and contemporary culture and literature, from The Labyrinth of Solitude to his recent Charles Eliot Norton lectures; taken together, however, the central essays translated in this volume take a formidable place beside Paz's volumes of poetry.

title: NIXON ON BOMBING RECORDED IN TAPE
description: LOS ANGELES, June 29 (UPI) The House Judiciary Committee has been given another tape transcript in which President Nixon refers caustically to the bombing in Vietnam and the reason for moving the 1972 Republican National Convention to Miami from San Diego, The Los Angeles Times said today.

title: Dr. Chrzanowski And Dr. Hawkins Have Nuptials
description: Dr. Katherine Ann Hawkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Hawkins of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Dr. Paul Jonathan Chrzanowski, son of Dr. Gerard Chrzanowski and Mrs. Jane Cullen, both of New York.

title: STRIKE IS EXPECTED IN COPPER INDUSTRY
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., June 29 (AP)Most of the nation's 35,000 copper workers are ready to strike for higher wages at midnight tomorrow.

title: Chapot to Join U.S. Team For Rest of Europe Tour
description: Frank Chapot, the 40yearold captain of the United States Equestrian Team, leaves tonight to join the squad for the remainder of its European tour. The press of business prevented Chapot from competing in the first two shows of the tour  Wiesbaden, West Germany, and Lucerne, Switzerland.

title: Food Proves a Lure For BigBand Fans
description: NUTLEY  Within seven months recently, the Colony III nightclub here sponsored six bigband performances, bringing in Maynard Ferguson and Buddy Rich twice each and Woody Herman and Stan Kenton once.

title: Film: Shock Treatment for Laughs
description: ONE way and another, popular film comedy seems to be going to pieces. Sometimes literally. In Andy Warhol's Frankenstein, directed by Paul Morrissey, the mad doctor and his faithful assistant Otto seek a head to attach to the otherwisefinished, perfect specimen of Serbian youth they are stitching together in the lab. When they find the right man, they decapitate him onscreen with a pair of shears that look like King Kong's toenail scissors.

title: What's Doing in BUENOS AIRES
description: TWO WORLDSThe most striking aspect of Buenos Aires is the lingering aristocratic flavor of the wellkept parks, broad avenues, modern highrise apartment buildings and older Frenchstyle mansions in the Barrio Norte; literally the Northern Neighborhood. In contrast, south of the city center there is La Boca, the Little Italy section pressing against the harbor on the River Plate. Here the working class lives and works along cobblestoned streets, mingling after hours in cafes, cozy Italian restaurants and raunchy bars. The inhabitants' colloquial Spanish heavily laced with lunfardo, a dialect that can be traced back to the 19thcentury underworldis often difficult for other Argentines to understand. But wherever visitors wander, be it Norte, La Boca or any other section of this huge city of almost three million people, they'll find that the streets are safe at all hours. The climate is mild and the seasons are reversed; winter begins in June and summer in December. But it seldom freezes and never snows. The high temperatures in July and August areRESTAURANTS  As part of its policy to promote meat exports, the Argentine Government does not permit the sale of beef in Buenos Aires restaurants during the first two weeks of everytmonth. But when beef is available. La Cabana at Entre Rios 454 is still the best. For $10 a couple can enjoy charcoalbroiled steak or mixed grill, a side dish and a good red wine. Possibly the finest Continental food in town is served at the Claridge Hotel's restaurant at Tucuman 535, where the bill for two will come close to $20.. Excellent Argentine provincial dishes and good folk music (not tango) are available at El Chaleco Colorado at Cochabamba 240 in the San Telmo district. The price there, including wine, is about $8 a head. For a tasty lunch try any of the small restaurants on the Costanera, the parklined avenue along the River Plate. These are simple places, with picture windows facing the river. Cost, with wine:

title: Book Ends
description: Rule Book. Howto books being popular these days what about a compendium of how to play over 400 sports? Consider it done sports fans. It's called Rules of the Game and will be published in October as the joint venture of a New Yorkbased publishing service called Two Continents, a London publisher of books for the American market called Paddington Press and another London editorialdesign firm called The Diagram Group. Rules of the Game was conceived by The Diagram Group, which had heretofore specialized in book graphics but hankered after doing complete books. A book on how to play all the world's major competitive games was one project they had simmering on the back burner. The hitch was, as it usually is, money, so now enter Paddington Press. This was founded about two years ago by John and Janet Marqusee, two Americans who fled the United States with their seven children for the supposed ampler amenities of London. The Marqusees and The Diagram Group got together and the Rules of the Game project came alive. A team of editorial people was formed under Ruth Midgley, the 28yearold managing editor, and they began collating the material collected by correspondence with sports committees the world over, representing over 2,000 replies from 21 countries. The task was to compress and simplify (and sometimes translate) pages and pages of tediously detailed rule books. The result will be several pages of simplified explanation of each sport (some sports require one page, some as many as six), accompanied by illustrations of players in action. Asked what was the most complicated sport, Miss Midgley readily replied, Ice hockey. The only sport that did not have any written rules turned out to be that old pub standby, darts; Miss Midgley's team codified the rules gleaned from oral tradition and received the Imprimatur of the sport's adepts in England. The book includes all those exotic Olympic sports such as whitewater canoeing, as well as dorfball (a Dutch basketballtype game which requires teams made up of six men awl six women), canoe polo, kendo and sleddog, pigeon and kayak racing. The next link in the publishing chain was Two Continents, a publishing service rather than a publisher, which takes a book in any stage from MS. to final book and produces, distributes, publicizes, handles accounts, etc.in short what a publisher does, except that the author pays the costs, plus an administrative fee, and receives something like 70 per cent of the monetary returns, plus all subsidiaryrights money. Two Continents, founded by Leonard Shatzkin, a veteran sales and production man, performs the bulk of its work for foreign publishers who want to publish in the United States or paperback publishers wishing to bring out a hardcover edition of an original title. Rules of the Game has a 100,000copy first printing, 30,000 of which has already been ordered for Australia.

title: Bridge
description: If the history of contract bridge could be personalizedand viewed in terms of one living player, that player would surely be Waldemar Von Zedtwitz of New York. As a young man he won auction bridge tournaments. He was on hand when the late Harold Vanderbilt introduced contract bridge, and became the favorite partner of the railroad tycoon.

title: CITY REVISES RUE ON FOSTER SHIFTS
description: For four years, Madeline Smith, a widow, has been caring for two foster children, now 8 and 6 years old. They call her Mommy and she has wanted to adopt them.

title: Patriots Path Opens Thursday
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIPRibboncutting ceremonies on Thursday will mark the official opening of the first section of the longawaited Patriots Path. The event represents the culmination of years of planning and hard work by conservationists and historyconscious local residents.

title: Iceland Votes Today On New Government As Issues Intensify
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 29 (Reuters)Icelanders are voting tomorrow in a genera?? election called after the leftist coalition Cabinet split last month over proposals for a rollback of wages.

title: State Agencies Held Inept on U.S. Aid
description: MORRISTOWNA Federal official has urged that responsibility for administering United States aid in New Jersey be shifted from state agencies to the Governor's office. The agencies, he asserted, are doing an ineffective job.

title: Important people
description: ACROSS

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read with amazement Joel Blau's letter [June 2]describing the new luxury building planned for 96th Street and Broadway as an assault on the West Side community. Has Mr. Blau taken a good look at 96th Street and Broadway recently? You practically have to trip over the drunks and derelicts congregated there. Along with them, of course, is the accumulation of bottles and garbage littering the street. There are also two old movie houses whose torn and broken seats and faulty, airconditioning make them less than desirable. These are more of an assault to the community than the proposed building.

title: Judith Van Ingen, Teacher, Is Bride
description: Miss Judith Van Ingen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler Van Ingen of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Alan Miness, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Miness of New York.

title: And Now a Word From Somebody Real
description: THE next time you see someone on a television commercial who looks just like the guy next door, take a closer look. The way things are going in the TV ad game these days, he may very well be the guy next door and he may be selling anything from soup to soap and stocks and bonds.

title: West Point Sports Clinic Helps Train Boys and Gives Academy a Lift
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., June 27 Last year, LeRoy Alitz, wrestling coach at the United States Military Academy, suggested that the institution offer its facilities for a twoweek wrestling clinic open to high school boys.

title: Shea Case Stirs Memories of Earlier Police Slaying
description: Thomas J. Shea, It turns out, was not the first New York City police officer indicted for a murder in the line of duty, but the second, and the one before him was also acquitted after testifying that he had thought the suspect he shot lead a gun.

title: FAKE WINE STIRS ITALIAN SCANDAL
description: Rome, June 29  Romans thought what they were drinking was Frascati wine from the nearby hills, but it was actually a vile concoction of water, dregs from pressed grapes, molasses meant to be cattle feed and coloring.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: FOURTH OF JULY

title: Hot N'Nasty Takes Dash by 12 Lengths
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (AP)  Dan Lasater's Not N'Nasty led all the way in winning the $29,675 Schuylkill Stakes for 2yearold fillies today at Liberty Bell Race Track. Her margin was 12 lengths over Myrtlewood Beauty.

title: Mary C. Woodville, a Chemist, Wed to Dr. Howard Snyder 3d
description: Miss Mary C. Woodville, daughter of Mrs. Curtis Woodville of Washington and Capt. J. L. Warren Woodville, U.S.N., retired, of McLean, Va., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Howard McCruni Snyder 3d, son of Maj. Gen. Howard Snyder Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Snyder of Columbus, Ga.

title: Retired Performers Go On With Show
description: FLORENCE TOWNSHIPOf all the socalled retirement communities in New Jersey, perhaps the most unusual one can be found on a 22acre site 12 miles south of Trenton.

title: Acrobatic Penguin Joins Aquarium
description: The Coney Island Aquarium has opened several new exhibits for summer visitors and the facility's outdoor show is getting a new star, Pete the Penguin.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information Om today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Duffers Are Video Stars Of DelaneyShea Show
description: NARRISON, N.Y., June 29 The men at the New York Association of Hosiery Salesmen's annual outing were slapping their knees in laughter during their cocktail party at the Westchester Country Club last Tuesday night. They were watching a new television sports show that starred themselves swinging golf clubsa videotape replay of the morning golf tournament, with commentary by members of the foursomes.

title: The Case of the President Before the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTONThe historic confrontation that is to take place in the Supreme Court in a week is most simply summed up in the titles of the two cases: United States America v. Richard M. Nixon and Richard M. Nixon United States of America.

title: Son to Mrs. Williams
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. David H. Williams of Chevy Chase, Md., on June 19 in the Sibley Hospital in Washington. Mrs. Williams is the former Miss Diana Amanda Gillian Pritchard, daughter of Col. Sir Derek Pritchard British Army, retired, and Lady Pritchard of London. The child is named David Derek. His father is a lawyer with the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Horse Show Results AT OAKLAND, N.J.
description: LILY POND SHOW

title: An American Life
description: This confession of a key Watergate conspirator is a tasty dish for those now feasting on Presidential carrion. The real nourishment in An American Life, however, is in the story of Jeb Magruder's journey before the gates of power swung open to him. Unsparing in its account of the Nixon White House, An American Life is also unsparing in its account of an amiably vapid young man who stumbled up and tumbled down the ladder of success without ever knowing where he was going, or why.

title: Stand up Comedy: Roles Replacing Oneliners
description: ONCE saw a guy fishing in the Hudson River at 125th Streetthat is patience! Supposing he did catch something? Do you have any idea what kind of monster fish that's gpt to be? What a tough New York fish! Robert Klein, an agile young comedian is addressing a spellbound audience. He leaps in the air, arms outstretched menacingly, and then, in a thundering, angry voice, as though he had become the monster he was describing, shouts at the hapless angler: BOOM! Get that goddamned hook outta my mouth, you idiot! What, you think that tickles, you moron? He swipes with his hand. Gimme that bait! Twenty years of dodging tugboatsyou think I'm going to fall for that hook, you rube? What are you, from out of town?

title: Mariner's Designer Aims to Add Speed
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 29 Within and without yacht racing, there are a number of people who taunt technology and curse the computer. Those kinds of people will find comfort in the saga of Mariner, the new 12Meter yacht which had the benefit of years of tank testing and heretofore unavailable computer conformations only to turn out to be a dud.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Savings Time

title: Mrs. Egbert Wed to W. S. Kilborne
description: Mrs. Virginia Wylie Egbert, widow of Donald D. Egbert, art historian of Princeton University, was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to William S. Kilborne, chairman of the Harkil Corporation, business consultants here.

title: Mrs. Stamm Is Rewed
description: Mrs. Edith McCormick Stamm of Westport, Conn., widow of Dr. Richard A. Stamm, was married yesterday morning to Bruce T. Russell of Brooklyn, news editor of The New York Post. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Sandy McPherson at his home in Westport. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Dr. Vannevar Bush Is Dead at 84
description: BELMONT, Mass., June 29Vannevar Bush, the engineer who marshaled American technology for World War II and ushered in the atomic age, died latelast night at his home here. He was 84 years old.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: On the Unfit Americans And Pecking Between Platform and Paddle Tennis
description: To The Editor: The New York Times recently reported results of a sports participation survey conducted by the A. C. Nielsen Company. The results were most interesting, especially in view of the discrepancy in findings of the Nielsen survey with a similar survey conducted late in 1972 for the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports by Opinion Research Corporation.

title: Safe Swimming Pool Slides
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission has announced that it will soon begin development of mandatory safety standards for swimming pool slides.

title: Violence and Bruising Labor Plague Cutters of Pulpwood
description: WAYNESBORO, Miss., June 22The little episode disturbed only a few, and the officers of the corporation in New York might or might not think of it as a part of the cost of paper.

title: Security Deposit Law Is Pressed
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has begun to process a number of tenant complaints against landlords who have failed to place security deposits in interestbearing accounts.

title: Max Hirshfeld Fiance Of Nina Felice Mason
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eli Mason of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nine Felice Mason, to Max Hirshfeld, son of Dr. and Mrs. Julian Hirshfeld of Gastonia, N. C.

title: Fresno State Gains Coach
description: FULLERTON, Calif., June 29 (UPI)John Godden, defensive coach for California State  Fullerton's football team for the past two seasons, has accepted a similar position at Fresno State, it was announced today.

title: Chess Unit Asks Fischer To Reconsider on Title
description: NICE, France, June 29 (AP) The International Chess Federation today gave Bobby Fischer, the world chess champion, three months to change his mind and accept its rules for the 1975 world championship. Earlier, the federation's general assembly overwhelmingly rejected demands that the rules be changed to suit Fischer.

title: Tracy Chester Bride of Louis Hipp 3d
description: Miss Tracy Chester, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hawley Thomas Chester Jr. of Greenwick, Conn., and Louis Maynard Hipp 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hipp Jr., of Greenwich, formerly of Greensboro, N.C., were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. George A. Pera at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich.

title: INVESTING
description: When Samuel R. Callaway of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company signed a lease at 9 West 57th Street a while back, he eyed the 20foot ceiling on the second floor and tucked in a clause allowing unlimited alterations.

title: Manhattan Is Growing, As Always, Horizontally
description: Manhattan is growing in the dimension for which it is not famoushorizontally, into the surrounding waters, and it has done so for years. This lateral expansion has been achieved historically by creating new land out of landfill and, more recently, also by building concrete decks on top of piling.

title: Diagramless, 20 by 20
description: ACROSS

title: Marilyn Rankin Plans Nuptials
description: Bruce Rankin, Canadian consul general in New York, and Mrs. Rankin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Louise Rankin, to Ronald Frederick Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Harris of Toronto.

title: Not Long Ago, Such General Mistrust Was Unthinkable
description: From Alexander Hamilton to William Simon, business has been our reigning private institution. The robber barons and the Depression pushed the theory and practice of capitalist enterprise to its breaking point, but most Americans still retained a faith in the large corporation as our provider, a faith not without some foundation: in the last forty years, the real percapita income of American citizens has tripled; in the past 30 years, technological breakthroughs from computerization to penicillin have enriched our lives. This corporate cornucopia seemed so beneficial that authoreconomist Robert Heilbroner said in 1966 that he believed major corporations had attained such legitimacy as to be immune from successful attack.

title: New Park for Morris County
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP  With the opening this summer of 308acre Schooleys Mountain Park, the Morris County Park Commission not only is adding a 13th facility to an already parkrich county but also is preserving open space that otherwise would have been acquired for subdivision and housing.

title: DECLINE IN MOVING TO ISRAEL DECRIED
description: American Zionist leaders yesterday deplored the decline of aliya (imigration to Israel) and appealed to the Israeli Government to provide improved housing and social inducements to overcome the problem.

title: Beame's 3x5 Cards Tally His Six Months' Progress
description: The checklists of things done and things to do that Abraham D. Beame keeps in his own bookkeeper's handwriting on 3by5 cards tell, in his opinion, how his administration has successfully imposed its style on City Hall.

title: China Cannot Forget the Soviet Divisions on the Border
description: PEKINGChinese foreign policy experts see no harm in President Nixon's trip to Moscow. They expect the American President is merely seeking diplomatic achievements but will not sacrifice the interests of the United States or Europe. Agreements reached in Moscow, the Chinese think, may sound important, but will have as little effect on the world situation as the signing of a dozen agreements during Mr. Nixon's last visit. They view the Soviet Union, on the other hand, as the more dangerous of the two superpowers, the only real and present threat.

title: Criminals At Large
description: John Crowe keeps up the good work in BLOODWATER (Dodd, Mead, $4.95). This is the third of his mysteries set in the mythical Buena Costa County of California, and it maintains, the high standard of its predecessors. A businessman, who used to be a cop, is murdered, and a police sergeant is put on the case. He finds himself dealing with the powerful and amoral rulers of the town, with complicated relationships, with a mystery that goes back many years and with an attractive young woman.

title: Karpman Team Wins
description: Michael Karpman of Lehman College and Vivian Brody defeated Craig Kroll and Mrs, Eileen Krieger, 67, 75, 64, yesterday in the final of the Riverdale Mental Health Clinic's mixeddoubles handicap tennis tournament at the Riverdale Country School.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
Roche Bows To Orantes In Five Sets
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29  Manuel Orantes, the Spaniard with the Halloween grin, and Tom Okker, the flying Dutchman, reached the fourth round today as the sun shone, a holiday crowd of 26,000 streamed through the gates and the Wimbledon tennis tournament was back in business after days of rain.

title: SUBWAY TO LOSE VENDING DEVICES
description: Starting tomorrow, the 6,000 vending machines that have erratically dispensed candy, ice cream, peanuts and the like will begin disappearing from subway platforms throughout the city.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I believe that your investment specialists take too many risks in the three hypothetical instances you cite (Inflation: Enemy of Investors, Too, June 9).

title: A Sumptuous Show of Drawings at the Modern
description: THERE is no disputing taste, as an old saying has it, and taste predominatesand, in a sense, prevails over any critical demurrersin the large and stunning summer exhibition, Seurat to Matisse: Drawing in France, now on view at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street It is not solely the taste of William S. Lieberman, the museum's Director of the Department of Drawings, who selected the 184 drawings, collages and mixedmedia works, but the sheer visual taste, as well, of the artists includedvirtually a historic roster of the modern movement from the PostImpressionists Seurat, Signac and Van Gogh to such latterday figures Giacometti.

title: Jazz: BeBop Pioneers Mark Charlie Parker Era as Festival Hears Five Groups
description: Charlie Parker, the alto saxophonist who died 19 years ago, provided the 1974 Newport Jazz Festival with the basis for an opening program on Friday evening that was both historic in its overview and contemporary in its performance.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The article by Jeffrey Madrick makes the untenable assertion that the individual investor is no longer necessary because only a relatively small portion of the nation's capital requirements are Met through the sale of new issues of stock (Are Things Really That Bad?, May 26).

title: Journey to the end of the world
description: Nobody knows quite what to do with LouisFerdinand Cline, Le Docteur Destouches, 18941961, as it says on his gravestone: this multipersonality, split Gemini driven by the passions of Scorpio (with the scorpion's desire to sting himself to death), healer and reveler in destruction, history's clairvoyant and mudspattered participant, verbalvisionary genius and hack pamphleteer. It is difficult for most of us, living in the eitheror world of morality, engaged in the endless, futile struggle to separate good from evil, to cope with the lightninglike ambivalence of genius. We want our heroes to be good. (And yet, Blake: Energy is eternal delight.)

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: Many people complain that Xrated pornographic movies are the only films being shown at their neighborhood theaters these days. They say they would like to see musicals and dramas that are intended for the enjoyment of all members of the family, rather than for audiences composed of sex maniacs and degenerates.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The New York Sets of World Team Tennis named Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia yesterday as head coach for the rest of the season. He replaces Manuel Santana, who has returned to. Spain.

title: Reflections on Moving Out... and In
description: ROSLYN, L. T.Barbara Gadarian slapped her hands onto her hips, tossed her head Just enough to flip her blonde hair off her eyes and surrendered a bittersweet smile as she watched the moving men pack her world into large cardboard boxes. Soon the wearying process would be over and her family would be settled.

title: TORONTO DIVIDED ON DEVELOPMENT
description: TORONTOHow to keep on building for more and more people without destroying the gracious environment created in a more leisurely era is the classic urban dilemma facing Toronto, Canada's secondlargest city.

title: Sally Ann Bear Is Bride
description: Miss Sally Ann Bear, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Henry Bear of Buffalo, was married yesterday afternoon to David Ames Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ames of North Easton, Mass., and Boston. The Rev. Alastair Sellers performed the ceremony in the Newtown (Conn.) Congregational Church.

title: Leading Performers Will Star in Nassau
description: EAST MEADOWA per formance by the Benny Goodman Sextette at the Eisenhower Park Lakeside Theater here Friday evening will herald a series of 23 free outdoor concerts for Nassau County residents. Jose Feliciano will appear on Saturday and the Maynard Ferguson Band on Sunday.

title: Some Results Are Promising
description: Five years have passed since the State Legislature decentralized the New York City schools and four years since elected community school boards took office. What has happened in the interim is that, after a shaky start, the decentralized system on the whole is functioningalbeit better in some districts than others.

title: The Horns Of the Moon
description: Of these three books the first two are short, simple chronicles, as unpretentious as they are unambitious. Mr. Smith is a competent American journalist, Mr. Procktor, a doubtless equally competent English schoolteacher, both too young to have known Nazism at first hand, both curious to find out what happened and to pass on their knowlege to those who may well be both younger and more mystified by the horrible weirdness of it all. Neither book produces any startling new theory or explanation either of Hitler's motives or of the insanity and wickedness he was able to impose upon a nation noted for its sanity and seldom more wicked than its neighbors.

title: Park Guard Victor In Delaware Upset
description: DELAWARE PARK, June 29 (AP)Park Guard won the Viking Spirit Purse at Delaware Park today, coming on through the stretch to upset five other 3yearolds in the $12,000 feature, a prep for next Sunday's Rosemont Stakes. The winner's time for the mile and 70 yards was 1:42 1/5.

title: Economics Force Erie To Shift Freight Run
description: HOBOKENThe ErieLackawanna Railway is completing the process of making its Greenwood LakeBoonton line the main route for long through freights between the Midwest and the carrier's vast Croxton Yards complex in Jersey City.

title: Frank Sutton, Actor, Dies at 51; Was Sgt. Carter of Gomer Pyle
description: SHREVEPORT, La., June 29 (AP)  Frank Sutton, who played the tough Marine Corps Sergeant Carter in the Gomer Pyle television series, died last night at the age of 51.

title: Why a Met Pitcher Finds Himself at 36 In Medical School
description: On Thursday, Oct. 16, 1969, the New York Mets became world champions of baseball. As a player on that team and a contributor to the team's success, I was ecstatic. Today, almost five years later, the tremendous satisfaction of pitching well in the National League playoffs and World Series and the overwhelming intoxication of a New York tickertape parade is still fresh in my mind. I am out of baseball now. I am back in college as a 36yearold medical student. Let me tell you why.

title: TRUCKERS UPSET BY PARKING RULES
description: A refrigeration serviceman pays another man up to $20 a day just to sit in his van when he has to work in midtown Manhattan.

title: A tale of one city American Odyssey
description: The author of Rivers of Blood, Years of Darkness, a study of the Watts riot, now has written American Odyssey, a history of Detroit and, by implication, all of urban America. This new book is an ambitious and, in some ways, an ingenious work. Most urban history is written in period pieces, but Cpnot starts with Detroit's founding in 1701. As this tale of a city unfolds, the author carefully relates it to national and regional trends, especially economic ones and, for good measure, includes much European history relevant to American industrialization, immigration and urbanization. But, lest the reader be overwhelmed by these larger themes, Conot deftly reduces them to a human scale by studding his account with biographies of many ordinary people. It is straight narrative historydeeply researched, well written, dramatic, and needless to say, it is long

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Retailers and manufacturers are living in troublesome times these days.

title: Grain Prices' Outlook Is Up
description: Although many analysts maintain that the surge in food prices may be oversome basic foodstuffs, In fact, have declined substantially from their peaks  others hold out dim prospects for extended relief for inflationweary consumers.

title: The suffering of the passengers did not end on board ship
description: A black limousine, flying the Nazi swastika, with a young SS man at the wheel, turned a corner and ran Into a crowd of demonstrators running towards the railway station in Hamburg, Germany. Storm troopers, armed with clubs, made way for the car when they saw the flag and armband of the SS driver. Inside the car, huddled together in terror, was a family of Jews, Fritz Spanier, his wife, Babette and their 7yearold twins, Renee and Ines.

title: Dirk Roberts Weds Miss Susan Haine
description: Miss Susan Jean Haine, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Wesley Haine of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday morning at St. John's Episcopal Church to Dirk Stanley Roberts, son of Dr. and, Mrs. Thomas N. Roberts of New York and East Hampton, L. I. Canon Stanley F. Hemsley performed the ceremony.

title: Provisions of Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Following are highlights from the SovietAmerican economic agreement signed in Moscow today:

title: The Moths and the Birds
description: Now comes the time of the big, spectacular moths, the time when the Polyphemus and the Sphinx haunt the flower garden at dusk and the Luna beats its frail wings at the window screen, trying to reach the light inside. Luna, the light green moth, often four inches in wingspan, sometimes is called the most beautiful insect America.
